title: CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER AT XYLAN RESIGNS
description: The Xylan Corporation's chief financial officer, C. Stephen Cordial, resigned yesterday after 10 months on the job amid reports of conflicts with the chairman, Steve Y. Kim. The resignation capped a day of rampant speculation about Mr. Cordial's future. Xylan shares fell $5, to $37.50 in trading of 1.3 million shares, more than double its three-month daily average. The company, which makes switching systems for computer networks, said only that Mr. Cordial was leaving to ''pursue other interests'' and emphasized there was no problem with its finances. Xylan shares have fallen by almost half since setting a 52-week high of $74.3125 on May 20. The decline accelerated in the last week, after the company, which is based in Calabasas, Calif., and makes switching systems for computer networks, failed to exceed analyst estimates in its second-quarter earnings.

title: Sheffer to Play in Israel
description: The University of Connecticut standout DORON SHEFFER, believed to be Israel's best hope to crack the National Basketball Association barrier for the first time, has given up that dream for now and signed with a top team in his homeland. Sheffer, drafted in June by the Los Angeles Clippers after starring for three years at UConn, said yesterday he had decided to return home after realizing his chances of making the Clippers were ''close to zero.'' Sheffer said his three-year contract with the perennial Israeli champion Maccabi Tel Aviv contains an escape clause in case he is offered another chance with an N.B.A. team. (AP)

title: MGM Grand to Develop Casinos in South Africa
description: MGM Grand Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to develop and manage South African casinos planned by Tsogo Sun Gaming and Entertainment. MGM Grand said that Tsogo Sun, a venture of South African Breweries Ltd. and Tsogo Investment Holdings, plans to apply for at least 15 casino licenses.

title: QUINTILES TRANSNATIONAL PLANS TO BUY BRI INTERNATIONAL
description: The Quintiles Transnational Corporation said yesterday that it planned to buy BRI International Inc., a provider of research services to pharmaceutical, biotechnology and medical-device industries, for $133.5 million in stock. Quintiles, of Research Park Triangle, N.C., said it would exchange 1.9 million shares for all of BRI's stock. BRI International, based in Arlington, Va., had revenues of $42.6 million for the year ended Nov. 30, 1995. Quintiles, also a provider of contract research services, had revenues of $156 million in 1995. Shares of Quintiles rose $2.75, to $69.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Padres Thirst for Power and Get Vaughn From Brewers
description: Cecil Fielder, the Yankees' newest high-priced star, was not the most prolific run producer traded last night before the major league trading deadline. The San Diego Padres, seeking a power boost for their pennant run, grabbed Greg Vaughn, one of the American League's primary power hitters this season, from the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: From a Tiny Industry Niche, Help in the T.W.A. Crash
description: The fiery ending of T.W.A. Flight 800 cast a harsh light into various corners of the aviation business. But some key data for investigating the disaster came from a tiny industry niche here that the National Transportation Safety Board never knew existed.

title: How Strange Is Small and Vice Versa
description: WHERE DOES THE WEIRDNESS GO?

title: From Workhouse to Workfare
description: If Bill Clinton, as an Oxford student, had studied the history of the poor in early 19th-century England, he might not have decided to sign the welfare reform bill.

title: A Sad Day for Poor Children
description: President Clinton's defense at yesterday's press conference of his decision to sign an atrocious welfare bill exaggerated its tiny virtues and ignored some large faults. His disappointing excuse was that the flawed bill was the last realistic chance to fulfill his campaign promise to ''end welfare as we know it.'' Last chance? This conservative Congress longs to send him as many bills as it takes to cut welfare.

title: Beefeater Account Goes to Mezzina
description: Domecq Importers in Old Greenwich, Conn., a unit of Allied Domecq P.L.C., said yesterday that it had selected Mezzina/Brown in New York to handle advertising for Beefeater gin in the United States. Billings on the account, which has been inactive, have not been determined.

title: A Blooming Letdown at Kew: Nothing to Sniff At
description: Admittedly, this is a country that is crazy about plants.

title: Proof: If Godot Exists, He's Likely to Be Irish
description: There is a chill beauty about the landscape. It's as flat and arid as Death Valley, the horizontal lines broken only by the stalk of a leafless tree, which looks like an abandoned coat rack, and a small boulder that can be used as a settee. The vast gray-blue sky suggests no particular time of day. We are in the universe of Samuel Beckett, in that Krazy Kat corner of it where Vladimir, called Didi, and Estragon, called Gogo, modern literature's two most valiant vagrants, have come to attend the elusive Godot.

title: Points of Agreement, and Disagreement, on the Wefare Bill
description: After vetoing two Republic versions of welfare overhaul legislation, President Clinton said yesterday that he would sign a compromise bill that would end the Federal guarantee of cash assistance for the poor. The bill was completed this week by House and Senate conference committees; here are provisions on which legislators did not try to accommodate the Clinton Administration, and those on which they did.

title: U.S. Tops Japan to Earn Date With Surprising Australia
description: The day after the Australian men proclaimed the greatest basketball victory in their nation's history in reaching the Olympic semifinals, the women completed a joyful matching set. They earned a rematch with the United States and a chance for a first basketball medal by eliminating Russia from medal contention with a 74-70 overtime quarterfinal victory this afternoon.

title: Trying to Cope With Success
description: This week, the British duo Everything but the Girl's single ''Missing'' became the first song to spend an entire year on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart. The group, which has been together for 12 years and never before had a hit single in the United States, is understandably amazed and baffled by the success.

title: A Twist: Labor Day Parade's Not on Labor Day
description: After being lambasted for years for resisting change, New York City's labor leaders made an announcement yesterday showing that they were, after all, intent on shaking things up: they said that New York's annual Labor Day parade would no longer be on Labor Day.

title: Unemployment Climbs in France
description: French unemployment returned to a postwar high in June. The number of job seekers rose for the second consecutive month, by 22,800, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 3.066 million, the Government said yesterday. That pushed the unemployment rate to 12.5 percent, from 12.4 percent in May. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Buchanan Agrees Not to Speak at the Convention
description: Patrick J. Buchanan said today that he accepted the Republican Party's decision to deny him a speech before its convention, adding that he still planned to attend it -- and hoped to leave it -- as a Republican.

title: Private Buses Are Scrutinized
description: When the State Department of Transportation made a surprise inspection in May of eight buses of a Tennessee company hired to provide service in Bergen County, every bus flunked. They were ordered off the road immediately for problems ranging from leaky fuel tanks to worn tires. All passed a second inspection a day or two later, said Gary Mariano, director of private carrier affairs for New Jersey Transit. But the incident, first reported in The Record of Hackensack, has prompted changes in the maintenance procedures of the company, TCT Transit Services of Knoxville, Tenn., and two New Jersey Transit employees have been assigned full time to monitor private carriers hired by the agency, Mr. Mariano said.

title: People
description: * Roger Bentley was named senior vice president and executive creative director at Hill, Holliday/Altschiller, New York, a unit of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos. He had been a senior art director at Wieden & Kennedy, Portland, Ore.

title: Anti-Terrorist Laws Near
description: The White House and Congressional negotiators announced this evening that they were near agreement on a new package of laws to combat terrorism.

title: Banks' Access To Wall Street May Widen
description: The Federal Reserve took a step today to loosen the Depression-era law that limits banks from competing in the securities business, proposing new regulations that would allow some of the largest banking companies to expand greatly the business they conduct on Wall Street.

title: A Parody Of Shows Covering Pop News
description: Television doesn't need another clone of ''Entertainment Tonight,'' but there has been a void where the ''E.T.'' parodies ought to be. ''The Daily Show,'' a comedy-news show that began last week on Comedy Central (11:30 P.M., Monday through Thursday) is racing to fill that vacuum. Like ''E.T.'', ''The Daily Show'' reported last weekend's movie grosses; unlike ''E.T.,'' the new show understood that the information would make just as much sense if the American receipts were converted to lire. ''Big weekend for the latest John Grisham thriller,'' a voice said in Italian. '' 'A Time to Kill' brought in 22 billion 98 million lire!'' That puts pop-culture trivia into the absurd perspective it deserves.

title: In Selecting Federal Judges, Clinton Has Not Tried to Reverse Republicans
description: When Bill Clinton took office, many supporters were hoping he would quickly begin undoing a major legacy from 12 years of Republican control of the White House: the remarkably successful effort of Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush to remake the nation's Federal courts by selecting judges known for their conservative views.

title: Giants Abandon Shotgun Offense
description: Coach Dan Reeves said the Giants will not be using the shotgun formation at all this season. The coach's philosophy is that since many of the Super Bowl-winning teams like the Dallas Cowboys and the San Francisco 49ers do not use it, then the Giants will not use it either.

title: Iraqi Weight Lifter Leaves Games to Seek Asylum in U.S.
description: Twelve days ago, Raed Ahmed carried the Iraqi flag into the opening ceremonies of the Summer Games. Today, the burly weight lifter walked out of the Olympic Village and said he would ask for political asylum in the United States

title: Executive Changes
description: MEDQUIST INC., Marlton, N.J., named David Cohen, its president and chief executive, to the additional position of chairman, succeeding James R. Emshoff, who will continue as a director.

title: Pack Signs Five-Year Deal And Defends Nets' Decision
description: The nerve of Robert Pack. That could mean his fearlessness on the court or an injury that scared teams away.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-11

title: U.S. Approves Safer Vaccine For Blocking Fatal Cough
description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved a vaccine to prevent whooping cough in infants that is less likely than the current vaccine to cause fever, irritability and other side effects.

title: Bond Prices Have a Rally For a 2d Day
description: Treasury prices rose sharply yesterday for the second consecutive session, bolstered by a report that pointed to unexpected weakness in manufacturing.

title: Nusrat Khan Postponed
description: The Pakistani singer Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan, originally scheduled to appear tonight at Radio City Music Hall, has postponed his concert until Aug. 21. Mr. Khan is recovering from hand surgery. Tickets for tonight's concert will be honored on Aug. 21; refunds are available at the point of purchase. Information: (212) 632-4000.

title: Warriors' Smith Arraigned
description: JOE SMITH, the Golden State Warriors' top draft pick last season, was arraigned yesterday in Chesapeake, Va., on a charge of malicious wounding after he was accused of hitting and cutting a male dancer with a bottle.

title: Clinton Recalls His Promise, Weighs History, and Decides
description: When President Clinton and a dozen of his top advisers sat down in the Cabinet Room to discuss the welfare bill this morning, everyone knew he faced the biggest domestic decision of his Presidency. Though they were prepared to close ranks behind him, the President's advisers knew this was their last chance to be heard on an issue on which there was no middle ground left.

title: Ohio Upholds Public Funding of Private and Religious Schools
description: An Ohio state court yesterday upheld the constitutionality of a program based in Cleveland that allows students to use public money to pay for private and religious schooling, handing a major victory to school choice supporters.

title: GATX AND PARTNERS ORDER 11 BOEING JETLINERS
description: The GATX Capital Corporation said yesterday that two partnerships affiliated with the company had ordered 11 Boeing jetliners for a total of as much as $1.2 billion. GATX Capital, a financing business owned by the GATX Corporation, a railroad and freight shipping company, said it had formed GATX 737-800 Partners with Heller Financial Inc., which is a subsidiary of Fuji Bank Ltd., and the Kanematsu Corporation, both of Japan. Ten 737-800 jetliners were ordered from the Boeing Company of Seattle, with options for another 10. GATX 757 Partners also ordered a new Boeing 757-200.

title: 15 Are Killed As Commuters Stampede In South Africa
description: An effort to crack down on rush-hour fare dodgers set off a stampede today at a railway station in the black township of Tembisa, killing at least 15 people and injuring more than 50, officials said.

title: Devers Misses 2d Medal
description: Gail Devers, the 100-meter dash winner, finished fourth in the 100-meter hurdles. Sergri Bubka had to pull out of the pole vault with an inflamed Achilles' tendon.

title: Abortion-Drug Users
description: To the Editor:

title: No Medals for Drug Tests
description: Only a few contenders at this year's Olympics have been found to be using performance-enhancing drugs. But because the testing methods are so flawed, we don't really have any idea how many athletes at the Games use these substances.

title: Korey Kay Gets Affinity Work
description: The Affinity Technology Group said yesterday that it had named Korey Kay & Partners in New York to its consumer advertising account, which had been handled by various agencies on a project basis. Affinity makes electronic funds transfer processors that are marketed as Affinity Automated Loan Machines. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Dance Notes
description: Doing Something About AIDS

title: Travel Update: Major Highway North of Paris to Be Closed
description: PARIS  A busy stretch of the A1 highway from Paris to the north of France will be closed Monday until Aug. 18, entailing lengthy detours around the northern suburbs of the French capital.

title: First Yachting Medal for U.S.
description: An American finally won a medal in the Olympic yachting competition today when Courtenay Becker-Dey held off a last-minute charge by Shirley Robertson of Britain and finished third in the Europe class.

title: Adelphi Head Describes Buying Art in Europe
description: The president of Adelphi University told a state panel yesterday that he made repeated trips to Europe at the university's expense to promote Adelphi and seek donations of art for a campus art collection.

title: Michelin Sales Advance by 5.4%
description: Michelin, the world's largest tire maker, said that its first-half sales rose 5.4 percent on a combination of higher prices and a focus on products with high profit margins.

title: In Philadelphia, Tea and Empathy
description: WHAT is more ephemeral than a show house? Like playhouses, they present enticing possibilities to the curious who drift through them, offering the promise of a painless fresh start. After a few months, having inspired some and titillated many, they disappear forever.

title: Refunds for Electric Users?
description: Hearings are planned on whether customers of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company and the Atlantic Electric Company are entitled to refunds because the Salem I and Salem II nuclear power plants have been out of commission for more than a year, the State Board of Public Utilities announced yesterday. Because of mechanical problems, the two companies shut Salem I down in May 1995 and Salem II a month later, said Jennifer Salvato, a board spokeswoman. Customers' bills reflect the costs of building the two reactors, but not the costs of maintaining the inoperative plants, said Neil Brown, a P.S.E.& G. spokesman. The hearings are expected this fall, Ms. Salvato said.

title: Bill to Increase Minimum Pay Clears Hurdle In a New Deal
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed tonight to raise the Federal minimum wage to $5.15 an hour, virtually assuring a 90-cent increase for more than 10 million Americans on Sept. 1, 1997. The minimum wage would rise by 50 cents on Oct. 1 of this year and by 40 cents 11 months later.

title: CHIRON CORP. (CHIR,NNM)
description: The Chiron Corporation reported a surge in second-quarter earnings yesterday, citing increased sales of Aredia, a cancer treatment it markets for Ciba-Geigy A.G., and the sale of its share of a generic drug venture.

title: When Nine Is Enough: 'Sorry, Carl'
description: JON DRUMMOND was 15 years old and a sophomore at Overbrook High School in Philadelphia in 1984, when Carl Lewis turned the Los Angeles Coliseum into his personal playground and lighted an Olympic fire that burned for 12 medal-filled years, all the way to Monday night. Lewis has been the biggest name in track for as long as Drummond can remember, his Michael Jordan, and now he was in a position, put there by Lewis, of having to say that Lewis should take his long jump gold medal and just go home.

title: Giants' Changes Cross Up the Defense
description: In the great scheme of things, Michael Strahan's moving from the right side of the defensive line to the left will not rank up there with Babe Ruth moving from pitcher to outfielder. To the Giants, though, it is all relative. And what may seem to many to be such a small issue today produced one of the more bizarre chapters in the Dan Reeves regime.

title: Chrysler wants Jeep owners to take to the hills so badly, the company is setting up a camp for them.
description: FOR those of you not spending enough time driving during your summer vacation, the Chrysler Corporation has the perfect solution: take your car to camp.

title: Make That a 'Good-English-or-Else' Law
description: To the Editor:

title: William Zaro, 81, Bakery Chain Founder
description: William Zaro, a founder and former co-president of the Zaro's Bread Basket shops dotting New York City and its environs, died on Monday at New York University Hospital. A former resident of Bergenfield, N.J., he was 81 and lived in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Fulfilling '92's Promise, Capturing a '96 Issue
description: For months, Bob Dole's advisers have had a potent television commercial in their heads: ''President Clinton vetoed welfare reform not once, not twice, but three times. Action speaks louder than words.''

title: Governors Endorse the Shift in Control Over Welfare Money
description: Promising that they would further winnow aid rolls, the nation's governors yesterday generally welcomed President Clinton's decision to sign a welfare bill that makes assistance for the poor strictly a state concern.

title: U.S. and Japan Inch Toward Semiconductor Trade Accord
description: As a decade-old landmark agreement on semiconductor trade expired tonight, Japanese and American industry executives and their government counterparts kept negotiating and said that it appeared an extension of the accord was near.

title: Last Chance for United States
description: The losing streak is still going and the mood is getting ugly on the United States men's team. The Americans, 0-6 in Atlanta and 0-25-4 in Olympic history, face Malaysia (0-3-3) today in their last chance for another four years to finally get a victory. The United States lost to South Africa, 3-0, yesterday and Coach Jonathan Clark was asked about his frustration level.

title: Salvesen Rejects Takeover Offer
description: Christian Salvesen P.L.C., a British food distribution company, said it had rejected a takeover offer yesterday from Hays P.L.C., but would consider a higher bid. Terms were not disclosed, but news reports put the offer at $1.67 billion. Chris Masters, Salvesen's chief executive, said on Monday that it was ''difficult to see any industrial logic'' in the deal. Hays , which distributes items ranging from chemicals to frozen bread, had said its offer was negotiable. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Designed to View Subs, Scanner Details Sea-Floor Debris
description: The crisp black-and-white photograph could have been snapped on a spotlighted stage. Etched in rivet-by-rivet detail is a large flat piece of metal, more than 20 feet across, covered by two letters -- T R -- the first letters in Trans World Airlines.

title: People on Welfare, Too, Find a Lot to Criticize
description: The part about having to work after two years on the Federal welfare rolls does not faze Kristin Nichols.

title: Letting Social Security dabble in the stock market.
description: LOOKING for a painless way to cut the gap between what the baby boomers have been promised from Social Security and current revenue projections? Shift a big chunk of the system's trust fund to common stocks, which have enjoyed four times the return of Treasury bonds since the 1920's.

title: Thinking About October? Texas No Place for Yanks
description: By bolting to a comfortable lead atop the American League East with two months left in the regular season, the Yankees have had time to begin pondering what their possible path through the post-season will look like. Which teams will they play? Where will they play?

title: Rating of Sex Offenders' Risk Is Upheld
description: In a decision that refines the rules governing community notification under ''Megan's Law,'' New Jersey's Supreme Court today upheld the state's method of judging the danger posed by paroled sex offenders.

title: Fiedler Signs With Bengals
description: Quarterback JAY FIEDLER signed with the Cincinnati Bengals yesterday, one day after he asked for his release from the Philadelphia Eagles. Fiedler, who signed with the Eagles as a free agent from Dartmouth in 1994, was their third-string quarterback in each of the past two seasons. He was inactive for all 32 games. (AP)

title: Flight Attendant Sues Boggs
description: Leaning against a wall just outside the Yankee clubhouse today, Wade Boggs sounded contrite and said he regretted the actions that have caused a flight attendant to file a lawsuit against him alleging verbal harassment on a team flight from Newark to Milwaukee earlier this season.

title: When Theory Fails
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Agents in Atlanta Comb Guard's Apartment
description: As he sat impassively outside for more than 10 hours, Federal investigators today conducted a meticulous search of the apartment of Richard A. Jewell, the security guard who has gone from hero to suspect in the Centennial Olympic Park bombing.

title: Right-Handed Pop in Pinstripes: Fielder Is a Yankee
description: Keenly aware that they were susceptible to left-handed pitchers, the Yankees made a bold move just hours before the trading deadline tonight when they acquired the slugger Cecil Fielder from the Detroit Tigers for the disgruntled Ruben Sierra, the elite pitching prospect Matt Drews and cash considerations of between $500,000 and $1 million.

title: Favored Armstrong Gambles And Loses
description: Three of the world's elite professional cyclists Pascal Richard of Switzerland (gold), Rolf Sorensen of Denmark (silver) and Max Sciandri of Britain (bronze) -- won the medals today in the first Olympic road race open to pros.

title: Ethical Furor Erupts in Britain: Should Embryos Be Destroyed?
description: Britain plans to destroy more than 3,000 unclaimed human embryos from fertility clinics today, in keeping with a law that has stirred horror and religious outrage among some segments of society and ethical and practical questions as well.

title: Teachings From Corner Have U.S. Team on Roll
description: When David Reid first walked into a North Philadelphia recreation center where Al Mitchell, the United States boxing coach worked, he did not exactly have the skills to secure an Olympic medal. After all, he was 10 years old. But like many of the kids in the neighborhood, putting on the gloves enraptured him.

title: Massachusetts Radio Sales
description: The American Radio Systems Corporation said today that it had signed an agreement to buy two radio stations in Massachusetts, WAAF-FM in Boston and WWTM-AM in Worcester, for $24.8 million. The radio stations are owned by Zapis Communications. American Radio Systems owns four other radio stations in Boston.

title: Filipinos Illegally Jailed a Terror Suspect
description: Under sharp cross-examination by the defense in the trial of three men accused of plotting to blow up American jetliners in Asia, a Philippine police official conceded yesterday that one of the defendants had been jailed in Manila without having been arrested, advised of his rights or arraigned before a judge, as Philippine law requires.

title: Young Drinkers Pursued
description: Last winter, the state started placing local police and Alcoholic Beverage Control Division officers in liquor stores in college towns to catch minors buying liquor. The ''cops in shops'' program resulted in 363 arrests, including 58 of people trying to buy alcohol for drinkers under 21, officials said yesterday. Now, the program has been expanded to 18 beach towns, including Atlantic City, Avalon and Wildwood, said the State Attorney General, Peter Verniero. He made his announcement at a liquor store in Seaside Heights, which has been trying to shake off its image as a rowdy hangout for teen-agers.

title: Design Breakup, Design Breakout
description: WHEN William Sofield and Thomas O'Brien, the team behind Aero Studios in SoHo, broke up their partnership this spring, everyone in the design industry wondered what would happen to downtown's hottest young firm. The answer is beginning to emerge. From SoHo to 57th Street, the former partners are giving new meaning to the dictum ''Divide and conquer.''

title: Remains of 13 Victims Are Recovered
description: Divers working in rough seas off Long Island recovered the remains of 13 victims from the wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 yesterday, while at a Queens hotel, Federal officials told relatives who are beginning their third week of a bitter vigil that it was unlikely that the remains of all 230 victims would be found.

title: In Galbreath, Jets Might Have Another Bargain
description: Of course, Matt Brock said today, he knows the newest Jet, guard Harry Galbreath.

title: Iran Wrestler Protests U.S. Opponent's Gold
description: Abbas Jadidi was tired. Abbas Jadidi was angry. Abbas Jadidi was mortified. The Iranian freestyle wrestler was locked in an overtime struggle against Kurt Angle of the United States today in the final of the 220-pound class. Jadidi thought he had won, but he had not.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The director Sir PETER HALL, who is also the founder of the Royal Shakespeare Company, has been named artistic director of the Old Vic Theater in London. He will establish a repertory company there in an effort to restore the Old Vic to its glory days of the 1940's and 50's.

title: G.O.P. Moderates to Push Delegates for Abortion-Rights Plank
description: Raising the specter of a sharply divided Republican National Convention next month, two of the party's leading moderates, Gov. Pete Wilson of California and Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts, said today that they would press delegates to substitute an abortion rights plank for the party's anti-abortion one.

title: Pact Would Allow Workers To Retain Health Benefits
description: Two years after comprehensive national health insurance died in Congress, House and Senate leaders tonight announced agreement on legislation that would allow workers to take their health insurance coverage from job to job.

title: THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: Kansas

title: Senate Approves Temporary Nuclear Waste Site
description: The Senate approved a measure today to establish an interim nuclear-waste storage site in Nevada, but opponents of the bill pointed out that President Clinton had said he would veto the legislation if it reached the White House.

title: WORLD AIRWAYS TO DISCONTINUE MONEY-LOSING FLIGHTS
description: World Airways Inc. said yesterday that it would discontinue its money-losing commercial flights and focus on its military and international charter flights. The company also said its second-quarter profit rose 22 percent, to $14.5 million, or $1.20 a share, from $11.9 million, or $1.18. Revenue rose 14 percent, to $86.6 million from $75.8 million. World Airways, based in Herndon, Va., said it would discontinue flights from New York to Tel Aviv on Sept. 3 and from New York to Johannesburg on Aug. 23. Holders of tickets for later dates will be booked on flights of Trans World Airlines Inc. or Tower Air Inc.

title: Japan Is to Use an Old Law To Combat Food Poisoning
description: Stepping up its fight against serious outbreaks of food poisoning, Japan's Health and Welfare Ministry decided today to invoke a century-old law that gives the Government emergency powers to set up quarantines and take other stringent steps to fight epidemics.

title: Cigar Draws a Crowd At Any Time of Day
description: Even for a workout in the rain before 7 o'clock in the morning, Cigar drew a crowd as he trained for his next performance: trying to win his 17th race in a row and break the modern record set half a century ago by Calumet Farm's Citation.

title: Allan (Scotty) Connal, 68, TV Producer
description: Allan B. (Scotty) Connal, a leading figure in the growth of cable televised sports and winner of an Emmy award as an executive producer at NBC for coverage of the 1975 World Series, died on Tuesday in Atlanta. He was 68.

title: Metro Digest
description: THE CRASH

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: President of Silicon Graphics Decides to Resign
description: Silicon Graphics Inc. said today that Thomas A. Jermoluk had resigned as president and chief operating officer, effective immediately.

title: In District of Columbia, Life Isn't All Despair
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Olympic Letdown For World's Best Vaulter
description: Sergei Bubka of Ukraine has broken the world record in the pole vault 35 times, but he could not break his streak of futility at the Olympics today, leaving the competition because of an inflamed Achilles' tendon without a single attempt. Four years ago, he failed to clear a height at the Summer Games in Barcelona, Spain. Instead of leaving the centennial Games with an expected gold medal around his neck, he departed with a bag of ice around his foot.

title: U.S. to Provide More Meat Price Data
description: Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman ordered more frequent market reports today on livestock and beef prices in an effort to insure fair price competition in the meatpacking industry.

title: U.S. Missed Its Chance on Castro's Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: Judaism and the West
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Throw Crackpottery at Haunted Houses
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. and Saudis Agree to Split Cost of Safeguarding G.I.'s
description: The United States and Saudi Arabia agreed today to split the estimated $200 million cost of moving nearly 4,000 American soldiers stationed in Saudi Arabia to other bases to protect them from terrorist attacks.

title: L.I. Couple Are Laid to Rest Two Weeks After Fatal Flight
description: Six years ago, Eric and Virginia Holst exchanged their wedding vows standing side by side at the altar of St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church here on Main Street and Ocean Avenue. Today, their coffins rested side by side before the same altar.

title: Capricious Storm Rewrites Subway and Commuter Service Timetables
description: A fierce thunderstorm that lashed the metropolitan area yesterday spawned floods that immobilized hundreds of thousands of subway and commuter rail travelers and caused inconvenience from the suburbs of New Jersey to the far reaches of Brooklyn and Long Island.

title: Points of Agreement, and Disagreement, on the Wefare Bill
description: After vetoing two Republic versions of welfare overhaul legislation, President Clinton said yesterday that he would sign a compromise bill that would end the Federal guarantee of cash assistance for the poor. The bill was completed this week by House and Senate conference committees; here are provisions on which legislators did not try to accommodate the Clinton Administration, and those on which they did.

title: Bavaria Tightens Abortion Curbs, Clashing With Bonn Law
description: Regional legislators in Bavaria, Germany's most Catholic state, approved maverick laws today that tighten restrictions on abortion, reviving debate on an issue that, unlike the situation in the United States, had been widely viewed as settled.

title: African Leader Offers The West a New Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Many Hurdles For Devers
description: AFTER winning her first heat of the women's 100-meter hurdles on Monday morning, Gail Devers was listening to her coach, Bobby Kersee, as they hurried out of the Olympic Stadium. Quickly, she lifted her right leg several times, then stood still while Kersee swung her right arm back and forth.

title: CLINTON TO SIGN WELFARE BILL THAT ENDS U.S. AID GUARANTEE AND GIVES STATES BROAD POWER
description: After hours of suspense and soul-searching, President Clinton said today that he would sign a bill that reverses six decades of social welfare policy and touches the lives of tens of millions of people.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Woman Sentenced in Daughter's Death
description: As a judge sentenced her to 15 years to life in prison for killing her daughter, Awilda Lopez slumped over the defense table yesterday, wailing over her punishment for a slaying that exposed the failings of New York City's child welfare system.

title: Bitter Burden on Sarajevo: Invalids of War
description: Through four years of war, the people of Sarajevo prided themselves on their solidarity. They picked up their dead from the streets, they embraced the wounded, they grieved in cathedrals, churches and mosques.

title: Infusion for Europe Online
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G. is in talks to invest in Europe Online S.A., the troubled on-line information service, both companies said today. Compuserve and the ITT Corporation have already been identified in press reports as potential investors in Europe Online. ''These are negotiations about concrete offers -- from among others Deutsche Telekom -- and a final decision is expected this week,'' said Alexander Fink, a spokesman for Europe Online. Earlier this month, the Luxembourg-based company won court protection from its creditors.

title: Chris Jones Gives Mets 5th Victory In a Row
description: There may be no more popular player on the Mets than Chris Jones, whose work ethic and determination, despite his status as a reserve player, are admired throughout the team.

title: INSIDE
description: A Fading Vigil

title: Company Briefs
description: ANIXTER INC., Skokie, Ill., a unit of Anixter International Inc., said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell as much as $200 million of debt securities.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Lawmakers Advance On Health Insurance

title: Glaxo Registers Surge in Earnings
description: Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C., the world's largest pharmaceutical company, said yesterday that growth in sales of new drugs led to a strong jump in earnings for the first six months of the year. The profit figure topped analyst forecasts, which peaked at $:1.50 billion, or $2.33 billion. Glaxo said pretax profit rose to $:1.55 billion from $:1.16 billion, despite a 16 percent drop in sales of its anti-ulcer drug, Zantac.

title: AMERICAN RE RISES ON NEWS THAT STAKE MAY BE SOLD
description: Shares of the American Re Corporation rose 10 percent following a report that Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, owner of 64 percent of the reinsurance company, is in talks to sell its stake. Shares of American Re rose $5.125, to $56, on the New York Stock Exchange after The Wall Street Journal, citing people familiar with the situation, reported that units of the General Electric Company and the Munich Reinsurance Company had approached Kohlberg Kravis about selling its stake. Kohlberg Kravis, the biggest buyout firm in the United States, and American Re declined to comment. Munich Reinsurance, the world's largest reinsurer, denied the report.

title: Lawmakers Advance On Health Insurance
description: Two years after comprehensive national health insurance died in Congress, House and Senate leaders announced agreement on legislation that would allow workers to take health insurance from job to job.

title: No Headline
description: ''Where is the heart of this Congress? This bill is mean. It is base. It is downright lowdown. What does it profit a great nation to conquer the world, only to lose its soul?''

title: Hollywood Babble On
description: That's entertainment.

title: Jamaican Hurdler Makes Mark
description: When experts talk about Jamaica's outstanding female runners, the list usually begins with Merlene Ottey. After tonight, the list will begin with Deon Hemmings.

title: CHRONICLE
description: If the political conventions are approaching, can cookie baking be far behind?

title: New York Costs For Its Program Seen as Surging
description: President Clinton's decision yesterday to transform the nation's welfare system left both local officials and welfare advocates gasping at the enormous new costs of public assistance they say will have to be borne by city and state taxpayers.

title: In District of Columbia, Life Isn't All Despair
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Take note, those who read nuances into the chairmanships of society's major parties: Once again the torch has been passed for the Costume Institute benefit of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Guilty Plea in Chicken Case
description: A 46-year-old man who had been a fugitive for 23 years pleaded guilty yesterday to wire fraud charges arising from a broken promise to ship 55 tons of frozen chicken to Romania, prosecutors said. In 1993, a Maryland businessman paid Dominic A.B. Bangura $54,146 for the chicken, but the shipment never arrived, said John Carney, the assistant United States attorney who prosecuted the case. Mr. Bangura, who had escaped prosecution on an earlier wire fraud case, was caught last year in connection with an unrelated computer theft case, Mr. Carney said.

title: Suit Challenges Accord That Bars Legal Services Class-Action Cases for Poor
description: As a Congressionally imposed deadline takes effect today for legal services lawyers to withdraw from class-action lawsuits, a prominent civil liberties lawyer is challenging the constitutionality of the measure.

title: Text of President Clinton's Announcement on Welfare Legislation
description: Following are President Clinton's remarks today at a news conference on welfare legislation, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:

title: Rap Star Faces Charges
description: The rap star known variously as Notorious B.I.G. and Biggie Smalls was arrested at his home last week on weapons and drug charges after a police officer inquiring about an illegally parked car smelled marijuana smoke, the authorities said. The police found an assault weapon with a defaced serial number and a small amount of marijuana and charged the singer, whose real name is Christopher G. Wallace, and James Lloyd, a rap performer with the stage name Li'l Caesar, according to Fred L. Schwanwede, an assistant prosecutor for Bergen County. Six other people at Mr. Wallace's home were charged as disorderly persons, Mr. Schwanwede said.

title: News Reports' Naming of Bomb Suspect Raises Ethics Issue
description: Television stations and newspapers do not usually identify someone connected with a crime until the authorities have spoken on the record about their suspicions, or until the person has been arraigned, arrested or taken into custody.

title: In High Season, Publishers Are Awash in Unsold Books
description: It's the time of the year to nestle in a beach chair with the sun, a tan and the great American novel of the nanosecond. But the problem with that old-fashioned rite of summer is that books by the thousands are instead washing back to publishers in a mighty tide of rejected literature known wearily in the trade as returns.

title: Under Old Paint, Steel's Satiny Gleam
description: SOME of the freshest-looking furniture today is actually old: early 20th-century steel pieces that have been stripped of their paint to show a sculptural simplicity and warm, gray patina. The surface is evocative and natural, and gives a provocative fillip to silhouettes that are often very classical. Stripped to their bare bones, these pieces are honest, clean and sensuous.

title: Remarks by Gingrich and Other G.O.P. Supporters
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by Speaker Newt Gingrich and other Republicans, Representatives John R. Kasich, E. Clay Shaw Jr. and Jennifer Dunn, on welfare legislation, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription service:

title: After 3 Years, New Delays For School In the Bronx
description: When the steel and concrete outlines of a new four-story school began rising from the east side of Webster Avenue in August of 1991, residents of the Bedford Park section of the Bronx were hopeful that relief would soon come for their overcrowded schools.

title: Billboard of Names Proposed
description: Train passengers and drivers on the New Jersey Turnpike would have something new to look at if city officials get their way. The Police Department wants to use billboards to display the names of men convicted of soliciting prostitutes, Police Director Patrick Maloney said yesterday. Billboards would be more effective than publishing the names in local newspapers, as is done elsewhere, because nearly all of the offenders come from out of town, Mr. Maloney said. The proposal has the support of Mayor J. Christian Bollwage and the city's lawyers, but billboard companies say they fear lawsuits from the men involved. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Mayweather Ends Cuban Domination
description: Lorenzo Aragon shadow-boxed in the training room next to his opponent, pounding the mitts tremendously hard. The noise was so loud, it echoed underneath the stands of the Alexander Memorial Coliseum.

title: Surviving AIDS: Now What?
description: THEY are being given time they never imagined they would have for the journey. Now all they have to figure out is where they are going.

title: Microsoft Voices Confidence It Can Grow in Face of Changes
description: Executives of the Microsoft Corporation met today with Wall Street analysts, seeking to convince them that the company would not only be able to grapple with the changes brought on by the Internet but also stay on the remarkable growth path that led to a 46 percent increase in revenue and a 48 percent increase in earnings in its 1996 fiscal year ended in June.

title: Let's Have a Plank, Not a Club
description: Like millions of Americans, I am pro-Dole and pro-choice. I am pro-Dole, because of a conviction that America needs Bob Dole's strong character, personal courage and moral leadership. I am pro-choice because of a fundamental belief that no government should have the power to coerce a woman to make so personal a decision against her will or beliefs. Keeping government out of a decision that should be made instead by a woman with her family, doctor and pastor, priest or rabbi is consistent with the heritage of a nation founded by people fleeing intrusive governments and with the conservative traditions of a political party committed to limiting the scope of government.

title: Bomb-Detection Stocks Ride Wave of Fear
description: Companies that make bomb-detection devices or sell security services have seen their stocks rise since the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800. Share prices for companies like Invision Technologies, Barringer Technologies and Magal Security Systems have doubled, and in some cases tripled, in the last two weeks.

title: In District of Columbia, Life Isn't All Despair
description: To the Editor:

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Pruning Fruit Trees

title: The CD-ROM Way to Go: Planning Trips on Screen
description: ANYONE who has ever tried to refold a map can see the attraction of planning a trip with a computer.

title: H. A. Cook, 81; Headed Center For Students
description: Howard A. Cook, who worked to improve understanding among nations, first as a diplomat and then as president of International House in New York City for 25 years, died on Monday at his home in Chatham in Columbia County, N.Y. He was 81.

title: Darwin in the Mirror
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Readers of this column may gain the impression that almost all players are tournament tigers out for blood, but in many places the game is social and played for fun. An example is the Civic Club of Williamstown, Mass., founded in 1920. It consists of eight players who meet in each other's homes for an evening of dining, conversation and bridge.

title: Sterling Forest, Almost Out of the Woods
description: Sterling Forest, a vital watershed straddling the New York-New Jersey border, may soon be liberated from Congressional bondage. On Tuesday the House of Representatives authorized $17.5 million to help acquire the forest from developers, a down payment on a deal that will ultimately require $55 million in Federal, state and private money to complete. The struggle to save the forest now shifts to the Senate, where Alfonse D'Amato's support will be crucial.

title: Pitcher Draws Criticism For Actions at AIDS Event
description: MARK DEWEY, a San Francisco Giants pitcher who refused to join in a pre-game show of solidarity with AIDS volunteers, is being criticized by some gay leaders. Dewey, a fundamentalist Christian, also wore his red AIDS ribbon sideways during ''Until There's a Cure Day'' on Sunday, making the looped ribbon resemble the Christian fish symbol.

title: Harold Fox, Who Took Credit For the Zoot Suit, Dies at 86
description: Harold C. Fox, the Chicago clothier and sometime big-band trumpeter who claimed credit for creating and naming the zoot suit with the reet pleat, the reave sleeve, the ripe stripe, the stuff cuff and the drape shape that was the stage rage during the boogie-woogie rhyme time of the early 1940's, died on Sunday at his home in Siesta Key, Fla. He was 86.

title: Album Sales Are Sagging? Turn Up the Lights and Jump
description: Hootie and the Blowfish made sure no one left Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night without knowing the name of its latest record, ''Fairweather Johnson.'' On four different occasions, the band's guitarist, Mark Bryan, reminded the audience to buy the album.

title: TELE-COMMUNICATIONS ACQUIRES VIACOM'S TV HOLDINGS
description: Tele-Communications Inc. said yesterday that its TCI Communications Inc. unit had completed the acquisition of Viacom Inc.'s cable television holdings for $2.3 billion. As a result of the purchase, TCI Communications now serves more than 1.1 million customers in the San Francisco area and about 930,000 in the Seattle area, in addition to expanding its presence in Oregon and Ohio. Tele-Communications, based in Englewood, Colo., is the nation's largest cable company.

title: Prices for Heating Oil Rise; Corn Slips and Coffee Gains
description: Heating oil prices jumped on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday after refinery inventories declined again, surprising traders who expected a rise in preparation for winter heating demand.

title: Amid Praise, a Peppering Of Criticism and Dismay
description: President Clinton's decision to sign a Republican welfare bill brought qualified praise from political opponents, muted criticism from some close political allies and expressions of deep dismay from an array of social welfare organizations, religious groups and advocates for the poor.

title: Bubka Grounded Again
description: HARVEY ARATON

title: Immigration Official Falsified Documents for Illegal Aliens
description: A senior immigration official in New Jersey accepted gifts ranging from Oriental rugs to roofing materials for falsifying documents that enabled aliens to enter the United States illegally, Federal authorities said yesterday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE HOCKEY

title: Dole's Statement on Measure
description: Following is Bob Dole's statement yesterday on President Clinton's endorsement of Republican-sponsored legislation to overhaul the welfare system:

title: Seizing the Crime Issue, Clinton Blurs Party Lines
description: After nearly three decades of Republican dominance of the issue, President Clinton has scrapped his party's traditional approach to crime and criminal justice, embracing a series of punitive measures that have given him conservative credentials and threatened the Republicans' lock on law and order.

title: Turmoil in Indonesia
description: Indonesia's long-suppressed political life erupted into violence in Jakarta last weekend. After Indonesian police forcibly evicted supporters of an embattled but peaceable opposition leader from her party's headquarters, anti-government rioters surged through downtown streets, clashing with police and soldiers and burning government offices and banks.

title: Official's Wife Charged With Battery on Officer
description: The wife of a top International Olympic Committee official was arrested early this morning and charged with kneeing a female police officer in the groin as she was trying to cite her for jaywalking.

title: U.S. Blocks a Plan to Allow Iraq to Sell $2 Billion in Oil
description: The United States blocked agreement today on procedures that would open the way for emergency sales of oil by Iraq, the chairman of the Security Council's sanctions committee said.

title: Landlord Sentenced For Evading Taxes
description: A man long considered one of Manhattan's worst slumlords pleaded guilty to tax evasion charges in Manhattan Supreme Court this week and told the judge that he was no longer in the real estate business.

title: Swede Follows Road of Intrigue to Gold in the Hurdles
description: Lyudmila Engquist of Sweden won the Olympic 100-meter hurdles tonight by an eyelash, four years after she competed in the Summer Games with a different name, a different nationality and considerably different luck.

title: 'No Parking'? No Problem, For the Clergy
description: For years, many doctors, teachers, politicians and reporters have been able to do something that most New Yorkers could only dream about: park legally in an illegal space. Yesterday, the City Council voted to create a new category of privileged parkers: the clergy.

title: Perec Takes On Double Mission
description: She is a native of Guadeloupe, lives in Hollywood and runs for the French Olympic team. Now Marie-Jose Perec is making huge splash in Atlanta.

title: Awash in Chic, Embattled Hotel Hopes to Fit In
description: EMANUEL STERN understands perfectly the sociological process that has made possible his dream of building the first hotel in SoHo in a century.

title: Friends and Colleagues Extol Life and Career of Lee Lescaze
description: The personal qualities and journalistic strengths of Lee Adrien Lescaze, a former foreign editor of The Washington Post and later of The Wall Street Journal, were recalled yesterday at a memorial gathering at the Harvard Club in Manhattan.

title: Stagecoach Holdings To Buy Porterbrook
description: Stagecoach Holdings P.L.C., a British Transportation group, said yesterday it planned to buy the country's biggest rail car leasing company, Porterbrook Leasing Ltd., for $:475.5 million, or $732 million.

title: 'Ocean,' Pounding in an Urban Forest
description: Beauty is definitely not in the eye of the beholder, and Merce Cunningham's ''Ocean,'' a 90-minute dance work bathed in a theatrical blend of light and sound, is beautiful by any definition.

title: GRAND UNION AGREES TO SELL SHARES TO INVESTOR GROUP
description: The Grand Union Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell $100 million of preferred stock to an investor group including the family of Roy Disney, vice chairman of the Walt Disney Company, which could give the investor group a controlling stake. Grand Union, based in Wayne, N.J., said the preferred stock was convertible to between 58 percent and 61 percent of its common shares. The maximum conversion price would be $7.25 and the minimum would be $6.50. The Shamrock Group would have the right to name a majority of Grand Union's directors, and Roger Stangeland would remain chairman. Grand Union, which operates 229 stores in the Northeast, emerged from bankruptcy court protection in June.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Louisiana Company to Run 2 New York Nuclear Plants
description: The New York State Power Authority, seeking major improvements at the nuclear plants it operates in Westchester County and on the shore of Lake Ontario, said yesterday that it planned to hire a New Orleans company to manage the plants.

title: Defeating a Good Friend Has a Golden Lining
description: When Lindsay Davenport was 8 years old and already busy pounding the California hard courts, the Olympics came to town in 1984 and her father, Wink, revealed himself to be an authentic Olympian, a veteran of the 1968 volleyball squad.

title: Fu Wins Gold on Springboard to Complete Sweep
description: China's Fu Mingxia completed the first women's Olympic double in diving since 1960 with a convincing victory tonight in the three-meter springboard.

title: Forget the Trial: It's the Royal Gossip that Has Spain's Tabloids Salivating
description: The Crown Prince of Spain was not in the drab Manhattan courtroom yesterday. Nor was the 24-year-old American woman the Spanish tabloids say is ''sexy,'' ''leggy'' and the Prince's latest sweetheart.

title: Defying Evil, and Mortality
description: ''I SMOKE in my dreams,'' she says in that jazzy voice that hints of adventure and defiance. ''I wake myself up some nights, just laughing about something, and I'll have a cigarette in my hand.''

title: Kasich Tells Governors to Stop 'Bellyaching' About Measure
description: Representative John R. Kasich, chairman of the House Budget Committee, today admonished governors who have complained about parts of the Republican-sponsored welfare plan ''to stop bellyaching.''

title: Serena's Song in the Whitney
description: Serena's Song, the filly who started racing colts in last year's Kentucky Derby, and outran them in last year's Haskell, is back at Saratoga and up to her old tricks, challenging colts again in the Whitney Handicap on Saturday.

title: Grupo Sidek of Mexico Replaces Half of Board
description: Grupo Sidek replaced more than half its board members yesterday and also removed the brothers who founded the Mexican real estate and steel group from day-to-day involvement in operations. Sidek is in the throes of a debt reorganization to stave off bankruptcy.

title: Moynihan's Dark Days
description: With the passage of the Republican plan to overhaul welfare, these have become grim times for Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, who has spent more than three decades in scholarly examination of American poverty and dependency.

title: Throw Them Out
description: They should have included, in this charade called welfare reform, instructions on how you actually get these useless elderly people out of their dwellings -- these blind people, and the men and women addled by Alzheimer's, and the ones disabled by strokes or cancer or heart disease. I'm talking about the elderly disabled immigrants who, by the grace of our President and a rabid Congress, are soon to be suddenly destitute. Paying rent will be out of the question, so they will have to be evicted. Do you get stretchers and carry them out of their homes and leave them at the curb, or do you wheel them out, or do you just drag them out?

title: For Enjoying Nature and Answering Its Calls
description: It was one of those only-in-New York events. Instead of a ribbon-cutting, they snipped toilet paper (with golden scissors), and the most salient sound bite to come out of the news conference was probably that of a toilet flush.

title: Sam Aaron, 84, the Dean of Wine Merchants, Is Dead
description: Sam Aaron, the dean of New York wine merchants and a seminal figure in developing America's taste for wine, died on Wednesday at New York University Medical Center. He was 84 and lived in Manhattan and East Hampton, L.I.

title: Firm Suspends Analyst in Leak
description: Robertson, Stephens & Company, the San Francisco brokerage firm involved in a dispute with a client, the Xylan Corporation, suspended the analyst at the center of the controversy yesterday.

title: F.B.I. Chief Pleads for Anti-Terror Firepower
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation warned today that the United States had become a prime target for terrorists, and appealed to Congress to approve expanded wiretapping authority and other counterterrorism measures.

title: Another Consolidation Of Manhattan Brokers
description: Catching much of New York City's real estate brokerage industry by surprise, Douglas Elliman, the large Manhattan-based brokerage firm, with more than 300 agents, announced this week that it had acquired Ambrose MarElia, a medium-sized firm with 83 full- and part-time agents.

title: Secret With a Saxophone
description: Lou Donaldson, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 255-4037. Taking Lou Donaldson, an alto saxophonist, for granted is a risk: he's liable to play some extraordinary be-bop at any time, and harmonically advanced be-bop at that. He's also a direct link to vaudeville, singing funny songs and telling jokes. He's scathing at mostly the right times. He rarely puts what he knows on records, so his blues surety is often shocking; he's one of jazz's best-kept secrets. Sets tonight through Sunday are at 9:30, 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M., with no third set on Sunday night. There is a $15 cover and $10 minimum.

title: Victory By Adkins Fine, if Not Johnsonian
description: It was Derrick Adkins's crowning moment. He had handled the pressure, handled his long-time rival Samuel Matete and won the gold medal in the men's 400-meter hurdles in his adopted hometown.

title: Company Briefs
description: BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORP., New York, completed its acquisition of Wolfensohn & Co., New York, for $210 million in cash and stock.

title: Atlanta Sees Games As a Great Sales Tool
description: In Montreal, they're still paying off Olympic i.o.u.'s that shot past $1 billion. While Barcelona pulled off one of Europe's grandest waterfront restorations and made a small operating profit, it also wound up with debts of $1.4 billion. Los Angeles made a profit, too, but gained little in jobs or other economic benefits.

title: House Approves Measure On Official U.S. Language
description: After nearly six hours of emotional debate, the House today approved a bill that would make English the official language of the United States.

title: A Scientist, a Discovery, a Plot: Let the Special Effects Begin!
description: ''Chain Reaction'' could be the name of any action film directed by Andrew Davis, whose crisp, efficient style worked almost as well for Steven Seagal (''Above the Law,'' ''Under Siege'') as it did for Harrison Ford (''The Fugitive,'' Mr. Davis's well-deserved smash). This director's no-nonsense approach to making thrillers means simply putting a hero in jeopardy and then sending him on the run.

title: Inside Art
description: The Federal Give-and-Take. And Give.

title: Investors Say Prudential Unit Cheated Them on Restitution
description: Almost three years after Prudential Securities agreed to repay every client it defrauded in the largest investment scandal in history, some of those customers are accusing the firm of cheating them all over again.

title: State Commission Seeks Stiff Penalty for Duva
description: The New York State Athletic Commission filed charges yesterday seeking the revocation of the fight manager LOU DUVA's license and forfeiture of all or part of the $1 million RIDDICK BOWE was to be paid for his heavyweight fight against ANDREW GOLOTA.

title: 7 Met Errors Revive Past: Can Anyone Play This Game?
description: The Mets made the kind of history yesterday at Shea Stadium that their grandchildren will never hear about. There will be no boasting or reminiscing. No one will insist that he played a part in the record-breaking performance. Some things are best forgotten.

title: 'American' Arrowhead Found in Siberia
description: Early Americans known as the Clovis people left a trail of elegant, fluted arrowheads at campsites far and wide, beginning about 11,200 years ago. These distinctive artifacts have appeared to archeologists to be a thoroughly North American invention, a technology Stone Age hunters developed after they migrated across the Bering land bridge from Asia to the New World.

title: Quarterback Hoping to Connect With Jets
description: John Paci, the fourth-string quarterback for the Jets, has grown accustomed to expecting the unexpected. Less than six months ago, the 6-foot-3-inch, 222-pounder from Huntington, L.I., was prepared at the ripe old age of 23 to call it a career after being cut by the Frankfurt Galaxy of the World League of American Football.

title: Across the Generations, Side by Side
description: ''Affinities: Contemporary and Historic Art'' at Snyder Fine Art trolls the margins of the art world to touching and instructive effect: it links the work of nine contemporary artists who are not very well known with that of artists from earlier generations whom they admire. The show has been organized by Gary Snyder, the gallery's owner, in collaboration with the younger generation of artists, most of whom he met through their repeated visits to his gallery, which specializes in under-known artists from the 1920's through the 50's.

title: Italian Court Throws Out Case in 1944 Rome Massacre
description: In a verdict that was bitterly condemned across the Italian political spectrum, a military tribunal in Rome yesterday threw out a case against a former SS captain charged in the 1944 massacre of more than 300 civilians outside Rome, after concluding that the statute of limitations had run out.

title: Telling Tales With a Piano
description: The pianist David Hazeltine opened the standard ''Every Time We Say Goodbye'' with an unaccompanied rewriting of the tune. Usually, harmonically advanced musicians toss the melody out, but Mr. Hazeltine made the words ''Every time we say goodbye I die a little'' whisper from his version, all the while cloaking them with rich chords that for a minute even suggested John Coltrane's ''Giant Steps.''

title: Clinton Loses Composure on Travel Office
description: His eyes narrowed in anger, President Clinton today punctured what was supposed to be a Rose Garden ceremony celebrating good economic news by heatedly renouncing a White House promise to pay the legal bills of travel office employees who had been dismissed.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review yesterday about a production of ''Waiting for Godot'' by the Gate Theater of Dublin at the John Jay Theater in Manhattan confused the names of the characters who in one scene contemplate suicide by hanging themselves from a tree branch. In the scene, Gogo worries that if he goes first, the branch will then be too frail to support the added weight of Didi, leaving Didi alive and alone.

title: Fittipaldi May Retire
description: The Brazilian-born racing star EMERSON FITTIPALDI, who is recovering from a serious neck injury suffered in a spectacular crash last weekend, said yesterday that he might never race again.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Almost everybody who left Savann East the other night stopped by the open kitchen to smile appreciatively and wish the owners good luck.

title: So Genteel, So Scheming, So Austen
description: THE posthumous queen of genteel cinema is still on a roll. Jane Austen remains a hot ticket with the arrival of ''Emma,'' another decorative comedy of 19th-century manners honed to a sharply 20th-century edge. With anachronistic snap bordering on irreverence, Douglas McGrath's agile first feature manages to be nearly as savvy as ''Clueless,'' the deliriously pop version of this story. Just as that film did, ''Emma'' turns the role of Austen's best-loved busybody into a showcase for a show-stopping young star.

title: CHIRON STOCK DIVES AFTER POOR EARNINGS REPORT
description: Shares of the Chiron Corporation fell 12 percent yesterday, one day after the company reported disappointing second-quarter earnings. Investors were also concerned about delays in drug approvals and uncertainty over the future of the drug, Aredia, a bone-cancer treatment that Chiron sells for Ciba-Geigy. Ciba-Geigy plans to take back Aredia after it merges with Sandoz this year. Chiron shares fell $10.75 to $77.25, in trading of 3.4 million shares. Analysts at the Genesis Merchant Group, CS First Boston and Cowen & Company cut their ratings for Chiron, based in Emeryville, Calif.

title: Art in Review
description: Gustav Klutsis

title: Ospreys Return Inland, Too
description: After an absence of about a quarter-century, the osprey seems to be making a comeback in inland areas, state biologists said yesterday. Two female osprey chicks from a nest near the Delaware River in Hunterdon County were observed earlier this week making their first flight, said Jim Sciascia, a state biologist with the Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife. The osprey became scarce when DDT, which weakens eggshells, came into wide use, reducing the birth rate. Eventually, the birds returned to the coast but were spotted inland only rarely until recently.

title: The Spoken Word
description: GALLERY TALK AND TOUR, Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street. Three artists -- Chakaia Booker, a sculptor; Richard Lewis, a painter, and Michael Richards, a sculptural installation artist -- will speak about their work and lead a tour through the museum's second-floor galleries. Sunday at 3 P.M. Admission, $5; $3 for students and the elderly; $1 for children under 12. Information: (212) 864-4500.

title: Sweet Girl vs. Awful Adults. Guess Who Prevails.
description: Danny DeVito can certainly be forgiven for stealing his own movie, since he does it in such jaunty high style. United in wretched fashion excess and happy connubial malice, Mr. DeVito and his wife, Rhea Perlman, play Harry and Zinnia Wormwood, the rotten parents of Roald Dahl's smart and solitary little heroine. Like any young Dahl protagonist, she must defend herself from the evils of a cruel, patently ridiculous adult world. In the manner of his earlier ''Throw Momma From the Train'' and ''The War of the Roses,'' Mr. DeVito brings out the merrily black comedy in such a battle.

title: Bankrupt, Goetz Still Owes Victim
description: Even though he filed for bankruptcy protection, Bernhard H. Goetz is still liable for a $43 million jury award against him for paralyzing a young man 12 years ago, a Federal judge ruled yesterday.

title: Sir Arthur McDonald, 93; Set Up Radar to Thwart Blitz
description: Air Marshal Sir Arthur McDonald, a career Royal Air Force officer who conducted a secret rehearsal of the Battle of Britain three years before the Luftwaffe flew into a well-prepared hornet's nest that handed Hitler his first defeat and changed the course of World War II, died on July 26. He was 93.

title: Agassi Is Now Just a Match Away From Coveted Gold
description: The ultimate tennis tug of war, the one that not only rewards its winner with an Olympic gold medal but also anoints him a national hero, has boiled down to two guys on the rebound.

title: His Battle Now Lost, Moynihan Still Cries Out
description: After more than three decades of scholarly examination of American poverty and dependency, at a moment when the United States is fundamentally altering the approach to those problems that it has followed since the heady New Deal days of 1935, the gloriously garrulous Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan managed just two sentences on Wednesday.

title: In Special Education, Early Intervention Works
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Two Bits

title: An Ex-Radical Puts Chicago 8 In Distant Past
description: FOR those of you who have not played Trivial Pursuit in a while, here's a blast from the past that could win the game. What 1960's group was Lee Weiner part of?

title: MARINER HEALTH PLANS TO ACQUIRE ALLIED HEALTH
description: Mariner Health Group Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Allegis Health Services Inc., an operator of stand-alone and hospital nursing facilities, for about $110 million. Mariner Health, which operates medical clinics and provides rehabilitation services, said it would pay $95 million in cash and assume $15 million in debt. Allegis owns five nursing facilities and leases three, and manages three hospital-based skilled nursing units in the Baltimore-Washington area. The company, which also provides pharmacy and rehabilitation services, had revenue of $68.7 million for the year ended May 31. After the deal, Mariner Health will operate 78 inpatient centers and 57 outpatient clinics. The company will also operate eight pharmacies and manage rehabilitation programs in 429 skilled nursing facilities and 138 other sites.

title: Woman Dies. Complications Ensue.
description: THE TRIGGERMAN'S DANCE

title: Israel Must Sharpen Its High-Tech Edge
description: To the Editor:

title: Philip B. Yampolsky, Buddhism Expert, 75
description: Philip B. Yampolsky, a scholar of Zen Buddhism, died on Sunday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 75 and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Shakers, a Modernist and a Lasting Utopian Spirit
description: ''Hands to work, hearts to God.'' That was the motto of the religious group known as the United Society of Believers, or Shakers. And work they did, establishing self-sustaining communities across the United States in the 19th century and creating their own distinctive styles in art, craft and architecture.

title: Protecting Americans in Saudi Arabia
description: Americans can take some reassurance from the agreement to relocate some 4,000 of the 5,000 United States troops in Saudi Arabia from vulnerable urban locations to a remote desert air base. Yet intelligence officials warn that the danger of another terrorist attack on American installations in the kingdom remains high. Providing better security requires not just relocation, but improved coordination between American and Saudi officials involved in tracking potential terrorists.

title: Ethical Issues Pose Test To a Detroit Lawmaker
description: For the last six years, Representative Barbara-Rose Collins has represented one of the nation's poorest Congressional districts, which stretches across the southern half of the Motor City. Houses can cost less than used cars in downtrodden neighborhoods here in the 15th Congressional District.

title: Playing With Game Theory
description: John Zorn, Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. John Zorn will be performing ''Cobra,'' one of his best works; he's acting as prompter, a sort of conductor. ''Cobra'' is a game piece, constructed around game theory, and the musicians all get a chance, through a complicated cueing system, to control the direction of the music. These shows are dependent on the quality of the musicians, and this grouping is full of downtown all-stars, including Zeena Parkins, Ikue Mori, Cyro Baptista, Susie Ibarra, William Parker and D. J. Spooky. Sets tonight are at 9 and 11; there is a $10 cover. PETER WATROUS

title: Pilot Bilked Helmsley, Officials Say
description: Leona Helmsley, the hotelier who was one of the most notorious tax cheats of the 1980's, has herself been defrauded, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: American Defeats Swede for Gold Medal
description: Shooting with poise and accuracy beyond his years, Justin Huish, 21, won a gold medal yesterday by defeating four opponents from four nations at Stone Mountain, Ga.

title: 3 Major Steel Companies Raising Prices by 3% to 5%
description: Trying to move up toward the price levels that prevailed in 1994, three major steel companies announced yesterday that they would raise prices by 3 to 5 percent for steel used for such things as cars, trucks, appliances and home construction. But steel is now so small a part of the economy that the price increases, if they stick, are not expected to be inflationary.

title: All Is Not Bleak in Treatment of Alzheimer's
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-8

title: Lincoln Center Festival '96
description: Lincoln Center Festival '96, featuring indoor and outdoor performances, runs through Aug. 11, mainly at locations in and around Lincoln Center. Some performances are free; otherwise, tickets range from $10 to $100. Tickets for the Beckett festival at the John Jay Theater, 899 10th Avenue, between 58th and 59th Streets, are $45 for each performance. Lincoln Center Festival tickets can be purchased at the festival box office at Avery Fisher Hall or at box offices at the New York State Theater and the Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, and through Center Charge, (212) 721-6500. Festival hot line: (212) 875-5132. Through Sunday, the New York Video Festival will offer screenings and discussions at the Walter Reade Theater. Admission is $8 ($5 for members of the Film Society of Lincoln Center). Schedule and other information: (212) 875-5600. Here is the schedule of Lincoln Center Festival events this weekend:

title: A Bassist Who Jostles Traditional Structures
description: The bassist Reggie Workman turns what swing band leaders used to call ''vamping till ready'' into a process of intimate communion. His deep, resounding ostinatos energize his musicians at the beginning of a piece; when the band hits solo territory, he's well inside the music, staying tight within the pitch areas of the soloists, intoning notes with a purposeful calm as if rubbing oil into wood.

title: Gay Zimbabweans Win Fight for Book-Fair Booth
description: Despite threats of violence and intense Government opposition, a Zimbabwean gay organization opened a stand today at an international book fair being held here after winning a court ruling granting it the right to take part in the exhibition.

title: Royal Bank of Scotland To Buy Warburg Unit
description: The Royal Bank of Scotland announced yesterday that it would buy the custody and bank services business of S. G. Warburg & Company. The bank said the purchase price would depend on a valuation of the Warburg assets and estimated it to be $:5 million to $:20 million ($7.69 million to $30.76 million).

title: Olympic Diary
description: The Olympic city's streets are alive and on fire -- with evangelism. Wherever there is a crowd, the word ''Jesus'' lilts from the throats of 13-year-old Korean missionaries and throbs from the battery-powered loudspeakers of street preachers from northern Georgia. There is a puppet show designed to turn the very young to Christ, and a man with a big sign that says hell is just a heartbeat away.

title: Asian Group Buys Four Seasons Hotel
description: The Four Seasons Hotel on 57th Street in Manhattan, one of the most expensive hotels ever built in New York City, was sold yesterday by a Japanese bank to a group of investors based in Hong Kong and Shanghai.

title: A Papal Portrait to Stir the Soul (or Fry It)
description: The greatest painting in any exhibition in America is here in a show that is the summer's sleeper. The show is ''Masterpieces From the Palazzo Doria Pamphili, Rome,'' at the National Gallery of Art, and the painting is Velazquez's portrait of Pope Innocent X. In terms of fame, this is not quite like saying the ''Mona Lisa'' has come from Paris, but it is close, and why the event has not caused more of a stir is a little baffling.

title: Fear of Fare Cards
description: The blue and yellow plastic Metrocard that will eventually replace bus and subway tokens in New York City made its debut two and a half years ago, but only 8 percent of transit riders use it. The millions who cling to tokens are not stupid or hostile to technology. They have simply concluded that the benefits conferred by the card do not yet justify switching. Erratic system design and poor marketing have combined to delay the moment when the card will begin to inspire confidence in users and make economic sense for the city.

title: Door Opens for Lewis's 10th
description: Carl Lewis's chances of winning a 10th Olympic gold medal were greatly enhanced today when one of his teammates, Leroy Burrell, withdrew from the United States 4x100-meter relay team, saying that he had severe pain in his Achilles' tendon. Coach Erv Hunt has not yet named Lewis to replace Burrell for Saturday's race, but he said on Tuesday that Lewis would get ''strong consideration'' if any sprinters withdrew because of injury.

title: ATLANTA: Day 14 -- Highlights
description: DECATHLON REDEMPTION -- For four years Dan O'Brien worked toward the decathlon title that eluded him in 1992 when he failed to even qualify for the Olympics. Last night he achieved that goal, becoming the first American to win the event since 1976. Page B9.

title: Russian Ends Baumgartner's Bid for 3d Olympic Title
description: The dream came tumbling down today for Bruce Baumgartner.

title: HEALTH CARE BILL SHIELDING WORKERS CLEARED BY HOUSE
description: After bitter argument about who was to blame for past failures, the House of Representatives tonight passed the first major health insurance legislation in a decade.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Some people have a knack for giving just the right gift. DAVID CAREY, the publisher of the newly revived House & Garden, seems to have it. Certainly, he could not have picked a better present to give DOMINIQUE BROWNING, the editor of the magazine, at a party Wednesday at the Lenox Room restaurant.

title: U.S. Envoy in Bosnian City To Discuss Election Impasse
description: Because separatist Croats still refuse to honor the results of recent municipal elections here -- a vote seen as a test case for national elections -- a senior Washington official arrived today to meet the local equivalent of old-style Chicago party bosses.
