title: F.B.I. Takes Republican Fire For Handling of Personnel Files
description: In a rare attack on the Federal Bureau of Investigation, House Republicans investigating the White House's handling of background files strongly criticized the agency today for a series of actions they said served the political interests of the Clinton Administration and undermined the bureau's independence.

title: Art in Review
description: 'The Cool and the Crazy'

title: China Completes Sweep In Match It Had to Win
description: One of the last remaining Communist national sports powers stood tall today when China's Liu Guoliang defeated a countryman, Wang Tao, in a five-game match to win the men's Olympic table tennis gold medal at the Georgia World Congress Center.

title: Immigration Overhaul Moves Toward Vote
description: House and Senate Republicans cleared the way today for a vote on overhauling immigration law, resolving a sharpdispute over how to educate children who are illegal immigrants.

title: Time Settles Libel Case Brought by a Reporter
description: Three and a half years after reporting that a former Moscow bureau chief for The Washington Post might have accepted money from the K.G.B., Time magazine apologized to the reporter in High Court here today and agreed to pay him $262,000 in damages.

title: No Arrests Imminent in Atlanta Bombing, F.B.I. Chief Says
description: As evidence experts began to analyze truckloads of belongings seized from an Atlanta security guard, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that no arrests were imminent in the bombing at Centennial Olympic Park here.

title: Robert Vesco, the Fugitive Financier, Goes on Trial in Cuba on Fraud Charges
description: More than 25 years after he fled the United States to avoid Federal charges of fraud and began enjoying the life of a well-heeled and well-connected fugitive, the financier Robert L. Vesco went on trial in a Havana courtroom today, charged with similar offenses against the Cuban Government.

title: Alcatel Alsthom Says First-Half Sales Fell
description: Alcatel Alsthom S.A., Europe's biggest telecommunications-equipment company, said yesterday that first-half sales fell 5.1 percent, hurt by a slowdown in submarine cable activities. The Paris-based company posted sales of 74.3 billion French francs ($14.9 billion), down from 78.3 billion francs last year.

title: Sigh of Relief Greets New Telephone Rules
description: The Federal Communications Commission issued its long-awaited rules on local telephone competition yesterday, and nobody was more relieved than the chiefs of the local phone companies.

title: Yanks Finally Solve Texas
description: Kenny Rogers wanted to show his former Texas teammates that he is still a proficient starter. Cecil Fielder wanted to show his new Yankee teammates that he will be an outstanding addition. The Yankees wanted to show themselves that they could actually top the Rangers at the Ballpark in Arlington.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: An Electronic Reunion
description: Cluster, the Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. What can make reunions by obscure European groups like Cluster more exciting than classic-rock reunions is that the former often haven't performed in the United States before. This was true of the influential German progressive-rock group Faust when it reunited two years ago and toured the United States for the first time, though its performance-art-oriented shows were disappointing. One hopes Sunday's show by Cluster, a more academic German progressive rock group from the 1970's, will be as good as its albums. Consisting of the composers Hans-Joachim Roedilius and Dieter Moebius, Cluster may be best known for its instrumental collaborations with Brian Eno, but its own late-70's music offers just as strong a mix of atmospheric electronics, classical inspiration and forward propulsion. The performance is on Sunday night at 9:30; admission is $10 in advance, $12 on the day of the show.

title: Where Is Our Political Courage on Health Care?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fielder Offers Big Hug And Is Set to 'Go for It'
description: Cecil Fielder reached into his locker to retrieve his new uniform tonight and suddenly the euphoria of being traded to the Yankees overwhelmed him. Fielder pulled on the pants, slipped his arms through the jersey and wondered why he felt so nervous.

title: Cast Buddha's Eyes On Untrampled Nature
description: To the Editor:

title: Antitrust Chief to Resign From Justice Department
description: Anne K. Bingaman said today that she would resign as the Justice Department's antitrust chief, leaving behind a record of aggressive enforcement efforts and mixed results.

title: $25 and Under
description: Spruced-Up Vietnamese

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about an increase in the number of books being returned to publishers misstated the title of a publishing executive, Irwyn Applebaum. He is president of Bantam Books, not of Bantam Doubleday Dell, the parent of the Bantam Books division.

title: Rough Seas Hinder Divers, Bringing 'Least Productive Day'
description: For the first time in more than a week, divers investigating the explosion of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 off the coast of Long Island failed today to recover any bodies. And for the second consecutive day, bad weather roiled the crash site, severely hampering efforts to pull up wreckage.

title: Women's Soccer: 76,481 Fans, 1 U.S. Gold
description: They have been together a long time close to a decade for some of them -- and tonight the American women won a prize they could not have imagined when they began assembling. By beating a spirited and talented China, 2-1, they won a gold medal in the first women's soccer tournament in Summer Games history.

title: NBC's Time Warp
description: NBC has always made it clear that ratings are the yardstick by which it will judge the success of its Olympic Games coverage. Since the ratings have been high, the network is happy, and future broadcasts are likely to follow this year's pattern. That would be a shame. While some of NBC's reports have been riveting, the camerawork astonishing and the focus on long-neglected women's sports more than welcome, the network has made some dangerous decisions about the way it blurs reality in the name of a good story.

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption in some editions yesterday about the Olympic freestyle wrestling competition misidentified the wrestler standing in front of the American flag and smiling broadly. He was Kendall Cross, who won the 125.5-pound class, not Kurt Angle, the 220-pound gold medalist.

title: Japan Rips 5 Homers And Tags U.S. Out
description: With bats falling suddenly silent, the United States' chances for a gold medal and a showdown with Cuba ended tonight in an 11-2 rout by Japan in the Olympic baseball semifinals.

title: Johnson Sets World Mark For 2d Gold
description: He crossed the finish line, saw the stunning world record at 200 meters and let out a scream. Later, Michael Johnson slumped to the track on all fours. He had the same reaction to his time of 19.32 seconds as did the other 82,884 spectators at Olympic Stadium. Disbelief. The bronze medalist in the race was so startled that he thought it insufficient to shake Johnson's hand. So he bowed.

title: Toward Safer Food
description: Congress has agreed to provide the money to underwrite major changes in the nation's meat and poultry inspection system. By a substantial margin yesterday, the House approved $574 million for the Agriculture Department's food safety and inspection service, and the Senate concurred. The end result should be a system that will give consumers greater confidence that what they are buying is safe.

title: Growth Rose In the Spring; Easing Is Seen
description: The economy boomed in the spring but it may now be easing to a more sustainable pace, according to new figures issued today. They gave a sharp lift to financial markets and touched off a daylong spate of campaign-related argument in Washington.

title: Home Video
description: Pencil in Nov. 12 for ''Mission: Impossible,'' the first of several hits in theaters this summer to be assigned a video release date this fall. Paramount will price the tape low to encourage people to buy the movie. Analysts say Warner and Fox are likely to follow the same strategy when they release, respectively, ''Twister'' and ''Independence Day,'' probably this fall or winter.

title: Welfare Card Plan to Grow
description: New Jersey will become the sixth state in the country to give welfare recipients an electronic debit card for buying groceries and obtaining welfare benefits, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The card has been already been used in Camden, Hudson and Essex counties under a pilot program that will be expanded statewide by the end of next year, said Jacqueline Tencza, a spokeswoman for the Department of Human Services. She said the card would put an end to the black market in food stamps.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Down Periscope

title: 19.32 -- Johnson's Olympic Aim Was to Carve Himself A Niche in History
description: WHEN Michael Johnson won the Olympic 400 meters on Monday night, he did it with smarts as well as speed.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Double the Glory
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: U.S. Considers Larger Role In Airport Security System
description: Transportation Secretary Federico Pena said today that protecting airlines from terrorism had become a national security issue and that the Clinton Administration was considering giving the Federal Government a greater role in a security system now controlled by airlines and airports.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Surge Broadly, With Dow Up 65.84 Points

title: Listening In On Terrorism
description: President Clinton's major proposals for new powers to fight terrorism are useful and pose no threat to Americans' civil liberties.

title: WARNACO TO SELL HATHAWAY UNIT TO CFH ACQUISITION
description: Warnaco Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Hathaway men's shirt business to an investor group organized by former Maine Gov. John McKernan Jr., saving 675 jobs at Hathaway factories in Waterville, Me., and Prescott, Ontario. Warnaco had intended to close them as part of leaving the Hathaway business. Terms of the cash deal were not disclosed. Warnaco, of New York, said on May 23 that Mr. McKernan had assembled the investor group. Warnaco said it had secured a commitment from CFH Acquisition L.L.C. to preserve most of the jobs at the two plants.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Juror

title: Field Cannot Get Close to Ukrainians
description: With an insurmountable lead in the men's 470 event off Savannah, Ga., Yevhen Braslavets and Ihor Matviyenko of Ukraine sat out the final race and still won the gold medal by 19 points. Britain's 1995 world champions, John Merricks and Ian Walker, eked out a 12th-place finish to nab the silver by 1 point over Portugal's Vitor Rocha and Nuno Barreto.

title: Where Is Our Political Courage on Health Care?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bonds for Stadium Advance
description: Plans to build a $22 million baseball and soccer stadium complex in a park in Newark's Ironbound section moved forward yesterday when the City Council gave preliminary approval to a $5 million bond ordinance to cover its share of the project. The stadium is being developed jointly with Essex County and the state Casino Reinvestment and Development Authority in Atlantic City. The Council shrugged off complaints from a neighborhood group that wants to preserve the park for community recreation. The group believes that city money would be better spent cleaning up the park and building a long-promised playground, said Nancy Zak, a member of the Save River Bank Park Coalition.

title: AT&T and Jones Reach a Deal
description: The Dallas Cowboys' owner, Jerry Jones, said yesterday that he has made another deal with a corporate sponsor. But this one, he says, won't bring him into another conflict with the National Football League and its official sponsors.

title: For Children
description: Henna Painting

title: At Last, O'Brien Has His Moment
description: Dan O'Brien's quest is finally over.

title: Bond Prices Soar on Signs Of Slowdown
description: Amid fresh signs of an economic slowdown, bond prices surged yesterday. Investors hope to see confirmation of a slowdown in the July jobs report due today.

title: Howard R. Gill, 73, Golf Digest Founder
description: Howard Reed Gill Jr., a founder of Golf Digest magazine who helped build it from a schoolmates' enterprise into an international monthly selling more than a million copies, died on Tuesday at his home in Fairfield, Conn. He was 73 and also had a residence on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Exuberant Rural Rhythms Of Black Brazilian Culture
description: The rhythms of northeastern Brazil, soaked in black Atlantic culture, aren't like samba and bossa nova: they're exuberant rather than introspective, and the dust of the country dance is always in the air. Tico da Costa, a composer and singer from the region, came to the Knitting Factory on Tuesday night in a benefit concert for El Taller Latinoamericano, a nonprofit arts and education center on the Upper West Side.

title: Missing Student's Parents Accuse School of Neglect
description: April Gregory had worked at the McDonald's restaurant near the Syracuse University campus for three years, sometimes walking to work when her father's car did not run but almost always, her co-workers said, arriving on time.

title: All Is Not Bleak in Treatment of Alzheimer's
description: To the Editor

title: Rutgers Coach States Goal
description: Terry Shea, the new football coach at Rutgers, mentioned the key word -- bowl -- enough times to make his job description clear.

title: Excerpts From Debate in the Senate on the Welfare Measure
description: Following are excerpts from remarks on the Senate floor yesterday by Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York; Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas; Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, and Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota, on welfare legislation, as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: Bank of France Cuts An Interest Rate
description: The Bank of France reduced its ceiling interest rate yesterday for the first time since April 25, a move that economists said signaled the bank's willingness to cut the more important intervention rate in the weeks ahead. The bank's monetary policy council, at its last meeting before a three-week break, cut the little-used 5-to-10-day securities repurchase rate to 4.75 percent from 4.90 percent.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Home Is Where the Art Is'

title: Miss Piggy Stars In Baked Lay's Ad
description: Miss Piggy is playing supermodel in a television commercial for Baked Lay's potato crisps that was created by the BBDO New York unit of the Omnicom Group.

title: Quaker State Moves To Foote, Cone
description: The Quaker State Corporation and Temerlin McClain in Irving, Tex., unexpectedly said yesterday that they had mutually parted ways on their accounts because of ''disagreements over future advertising strategies.''

title: Margaret Cousins, Fiction Writer, 91
description: Margaret Cousins, a writer and editor of books and magazines, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in San Antonio, Tex. She was 91.

title: Where Teen-Agers Learn About Art And Teach About Living in Peace
description: Every Friday at 1 P.M. for six months beginning in January of last year, 15 Palestinian and 15 Israeli teen-agers -- from Gaza, Jaffa, Jericho, Jerusalem, Ramallah and Tel Aviv -- gathered together to learn the art of photography and, as political events unhappily unfolded, to argue about bombings, border closings and the fate of Jerusalem. A year and a half later, on a sweltering evening in New York, Americans, Israelis and Palestinians crammed into the Puffin Room in SoHo to view ''Documenting Life Styles,'' a selection of the students' photos.

title: South Korean and Dane Hit the Ground Smiling
description: Neither lost a game in this tournament. But when they won their gold medals today, both lost their balance. Bang Soo Hyun, the daughter of a popular South Korean comedian, dropped to one knee and mumbled a serious prayer. Poul-Erik Hoyer-Larsen, the Danish family man, covered his eyes, collapsed to the ground and assumed something resembling the fetal position.

title: GTE ANNOUNCES A SECOND BUYBACK OF ITS SHARES
description: The GTE Corporation said yesterday that it would buy back as many as 25 million shares of its stock. The telecommunications company said it would use the shares it buys back during the next year for employee benefit and investment programs. The company has 970 million shares outstanding. GTE shares rose 87.5 cents to $42. Last August, GTE, which is based in Stamford, Conn., said it would buy back as many as 20 million shares to offset the number of shares issued through employee stock plans. The company has completed about 80 percent of that buyback.

title: Accounts
description: * Bayer Corp., West Haven, Conn., a unit of Bayer A.G., to Carrafiello Diehl & Associates, Irvington, N.Y., to introduce Baycol, a drug aimed at lowering cholesterol that is expected to be on the market next year. Carrafiello Diehl already handles advertising for another Bayer product, Adalat CC, a calcium channel blocker. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Netanyahu Takes Secret Trip To Explore Lebanon Pullout
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu made a furtive trip last week that apparently took him to Europe in search of an agreement that would include Israel's withdrawal from southern Lebanon, Israeli officials said today.

title: Three Americans Fall In the Semifinal Round
description: Ariel Hernandez floated across the ring effortlessly, tattooing his gloves off the headgear of Roshii Wells. A right jab here, a straight left there. Bip, bip, bip. He went through his opponent's gloves like everyone went through the United States boxing team tonight.

title: Britain Says Scientists Find Disease Can Pass From Cow to Calf
description: The Government said today that scientific experimentation had shown that so-called mad cow disease, which had been thought to be transmitted through contaminated feed, could also be passed directly from a cow to her calf.

title: Ives Upon A Breeze, Unplugged
description: During a free concert by the Naumburg Wind Symphony in Central Park on Tuesday night, the conductor Randall Brion tried an experiment. For one piece, ''The Circus Band,'' by Charles Ives, he asked his sound engineer to flick off the amplification. And suddenly the audience was treated to the pleasures of concert band music as it was during its glory days, when ensembles led by the marchmeister John Philip Sousa, Arthur Pryor (billed the ''Paganini of the Trombone'') and others toured America's parks and town squares.

title: Art in Review
description: Ik-Joong Kang

title: 2 Acquitted by Whitewater Jury; Mistrial Declared on Other Counts
description: A Federal jury today handed a major setback to the Whitewater independent counsel's office when it acquitted two Arkansas bankers of four felony counts, including charges that they conspired to conceal large cash withdrawals by Bill Clinton's 1990 campaign for Governor of Arkansas.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Executive Decision

title: Leonard Mulls Return
description: SUGAR RAY LEONARD, 40 years old and five years removed from his last fight, said yesterday that he might come out of retirement to fight HECTOR (MACHO) CAMACHO.

title: Clinton Selects F.C.C. Nominee
description: President Clinton announced yesterday that he had nominated Regina Keeney as a commissioner of the Federal Communications Commission. Ms. Keeney, who is currently the chief of the commission's common carrier bureau, would fill a seat vacated by Andrew C. Barrett, who resigned in April.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Australia Shows Heart, But U.S. Exhibits Skill
description: One moment, one bold if misguided act, can now represent the world's effort to compete with National Basketball Association stars for an Olympic gold medal. The sight of Shane Heal, a 6-foot, 194-pound guard, successfully planting his feet and drawing a charging foul against the 6-foot-9-inch, 255-pound Karl Malone, is all you need to know about the attitude that Australia brought to the semifinals of the Olympic men's basketball tournament tonight.

title: Oil Soars as Report Says Group In Iran May Have Crash Role
description: Crude oil prices jumped on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday after a report by a Congressional group suggested that terrorists in Iran might have been behind the bombing of Trans World Airlines Flight 800. This raised speculation among oil traders that sanctions could be broadened against one of the world's largest producers.

title: G.M. Sales Decline, but Chrysler's Surge
description: The General Motors Corporation's sales fell by 2.3 percent in July from a year earlier while the Chrysler Corporation's sales surged 18.8 percent, as overall demand for vehicles appeared to cool and shift toward mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks instead of cars.

title: Blast Mars Pemex's 22% Earnings Gain
description: A disastrous explosion that flattened much of a major natural-gas refining complex last week ruined what had been shaping up as a triumphal announcement today of a 22 percent gain in pretax earnings for Petroleos Mexicanos, Mexico's petroleum monopoly.

title: Fence Sought at Youth Prison
description: Earlier this month, two teen-agers walked away from the New Jersey Training School for Boys and held two people hostage at knifepoint before they were caught. Responding to the escape, a couple living near the institution gathered more than 3,000 signatures asking that a security fence be placed around the detention center, Robert Glessman, an organizer of the petition drive, said yesterday.

title: ANTITRUST LAWSUIT FILED AGAINST GENERAL ELECTRIC
description: The Justice Department's antitrust division sued the General Electric Company in a Federal court in Montana yesterday, charging that the company's licensing agreements thwart competition in the market for servicing medical equipment. At issue is whether hospitals and clinics that have licensed G.E.'s proprietary diagnostic software to service their own G.E.-made CAT scanners and medical devices should be allowed to offer similar diagnostic services to other hospitals. The company said its agreements prohibit customers from using its own software to compete with G.E. The Justice Department seeks a ruling banning any limits. Analysts estimated that domestic service contracts, the only segment affected by the suit, account for a few million dollars of the estimated $3.8 billion in sales of G.E.'s medical equipment in 1996.

title: Thruway Chief Says Toll Rise May Be Needed
description: The chairman of the New York State Thruway Authority raised the possibility yesterday that a toll increase could be imposed on the 240 million vehicles a year that travel its roads. The chairman, Howard E. Steinberg, issued a statement saying the authority needs a new capital program to maintain its aging roads and bridges.

title: Allied Irish Banks Posts 14% Profit Gain
description: Allied Irish Banks reported yesterday a 14 percent jump in half-year profits to a record $:201.1 million (Irish), or $326 million, and said it was optimistic that second-half figures would also outstrip last year's.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Deluged Areas Of Subway To Be Fitted With Pumps
description: A day after subway service was disrupted by a torrential thunderstorm, the Transit Authority said yesterday that it was adding water pumps at the hardest-hit spots.

title: Senate Stalls Forest Bill
description: A measure to preserve Sterling Forest from development appears to be stalled in the United States Senate, leading some supporters to worry that the legislation -- greeted with euphoria when it passed the House of Representatives on Tuesday -- might lose momentum. Action on the bill is unlikely before the weekend, when Congress begins a month-long recess, said Bill Wise, a spokesman for Senator Frank Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey. A hold has been placed on the measure, indicating that at least one senator objected to bringing it up for a vote.

title: Effort to Save Strip of Beach May Be Impractical, Army Corps Says
description: Twice in the last two years, the Army Corps of Engineers has worked for days and spent hundreds of thousands of dollars to restore sand to a 500-foot strip of oceanfront in front of three high-rise condominiums in Monmouth Beach. Both times, a few months later, storms washed the beach back into the Atlantic in a matter of hours.

title: 2 Money Agencies Accused of Moving Narcotics Profits
description: Ten current and former employees of two businesses that transfer money have been charged with laundering up to $1.3 million identified as illegal drug profits, Federal authorities said yesterday.

title: Beethoven, The Before And After
description: COMPARISON turns so easily to competition that one was hard pressed to listen to Beethoven's so-called ''Leonore'' on Tuesday night and his ''Fidelio'' on Wednesday and not notice some struggle for the hearts and minds of listeners going on. ''Leonore'' is the convenient title we choose for the original version of Beethoven's only opera. It appeared (disastrously) in 1805 and was revised a year later.

title: Zambian Women, Doomed to Life on a Rock Pile
description: They spend their days, their careers, breaking big rocks into little ones.

title: French Insurer Plans Sale of Bank Subsidiary
description: In a move that will raise almost $1 billion, the state-controlled insurer Groupe des Assurances Nationales of France will sell a majority of its stake in CIC, a network of banks, in a private placement, the French Government said yesterday. The sale of 67 percent of the 93 percent stake in CIC -- known formally as Compagnie Financiere de CIC et de l'Union Europeenne -- is part of the preparation for the parent company's sale to private investors.

title: 7 Die in Jail, Setting Arab Against Arab
description: A prisoner who showed signs of torture by the Palestinian police died late Wednesday, setting off angry protests today in Nablus, on the West Bank, and a stormy debate among Palestinian legislators that echoed mounting public resentment over abuses by Yasir Arafat's security forces.

title: Pataki Signs Bill for Environmental Bond Act Referendum
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today signed a bill scheduling a November referendum on a $1.75 billion bond act intended to preserve open spaces, clean up waterways, close landfills and pay for other environmental projects.

title: INSIDE
description: Warning on Terrorism

title: Art in Review
description: James Lee Byars

title: Brooklyn Man Convicted in Scheme to Defraud the Elderly
description: A Brooklyn man was convicted yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn of defrauding more than 400 elderly people of more than $500,000 in a series of fraudulent telemarketing schemes.

title: Many Ballots Weren't Sent, Perot Rival Says
description: Voicing growing doubts over the ability of the Reform Party to choose its Presidential nominee fairly through a nationwide ballot, one candidate, Richard D. Lamm, the self-described underdog in the contest, said today that barely half of the party's supporters had received ballots in a national survey conducted last month.

title: Several Companies in Bidding To Own Petersen Publishing
description: Several prominent magazine companies are bidding to buy the Petersen Publishing Company, which publishes such established titles as Hot Rod, Motor Trend, Guns & Ammo and Sassy, according to people close to the negotiations.

title: Political Novice Has Glitzy Backing in House Race Against Nadler
description: It was a glitzy fund-raiser in an art gallery in Manhattan's trendy SoHo section that generated a large crowd. CNN was there, and ''Entertainment Tonight.'' All for a political neophyte seeking to unseat a well-known, well-financed incumbent Congressman.

title: 7-Eleven convenience stores gain instant status by teaming up with Fox Sports.
description: SIX years ago, the Southland Corporation and its chain of 7-Eleven convenience stores filed for bankruptcy protection. The home of ''Slurpee'' and the ''Big Gulp'' was bloated and inefficient, and its image among consumers was largely that of a corner mart frequented by working-class men loading up on cigarettes and beer.

title: Secure, and Dangerous
description: After the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 and the bombing in Olympic Centennial Park in Atlanta, the air waves were full of politicians and experts grimly warning of a heightened terrorist threat. Our solons, in broad bipartisan coalition, are rushing to enact new antiterrorism laws before Congress recesses, spurred on by an impatient President, who only last week cautioned against jumping to conclusions about the cause of the T.W.A. disaster.

title: Senate Passes Welfare Measure, Sending It for Clinton's Signature
description: The Senate completed Congressional action tonight on a comprehensive welfare bill that would reverse six decades of social policy, eliminating the Federal guarantee of cash assistance for the nation's poorest children. The measure goes next to President Clinton, who has said he will sign it.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about President Clinton's decision to sign the welfare bill omitted the reason for the absence of Maggie Williams, chief of staff to Hillary Rodham Clinton, from the final White House meeting to review the decision. Ms. Williams was in Chicago helping prepare for the Democratic National Convention and unaware of the meeting in Washington, which was arranged at the last minute on Wednesday morning.

title: Romancing the Bottle on the Big Screen
description: To the Editor:

title: Keep in Mind
description: ''VIETNAM MEMORIES, STORIES LEFT AT THE WALL,'' a new exhibition aimed at older children in which mementos from the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington are on display through the fall. These include model planes, toy cars, dolls and military memorabilia like hats and medals. There is also an interactive section using a CD-ROM in which information about the wall and the names on it can be obtained. At the Jersey Explorer Children's Museum, 192 Dodd Street, East Orange, N.J. Museum admission, $3 a person; children 2 and under, free; admission is also free to just the Vietnam exhibition. Hours: Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. (during the week, open to school groups only). Information: (201) 673-6900.

title: Yale International Rejects Acquisition Bid
description: Yale International Inc., formerly known as Spreckels Industries, said today that its board had rejected American Enterprises L.L.C.'s unsolicited acquisition offer of $16.50 a share.

title: U.S. CAN TO ACQUIRE CROWN CORK BUSINESSES
description: The United States Can Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy certain aerosol-can businesses from the Crown Cork and Seal Company for $58.6 million, including the assumption of $5.8 million of debt. United States Can, of Oak Brook, Ill., said the assets are part of Crown Cork's operations in Britain and Italy, as well as the aerosol-can businesses of its Carnaud Metalbox S.A. subsidiary in France, Spain and Germany. Crown Cork, of Philadelphia, agreed to divest the businesses to reduce its share of the European market for aerosol cans following its $3.9 billion acquisition of Carnaud Metalbox in February. The deal is expected to close in the third quarter.

title: Special Session Is Weighed By Pataki on Welfare Bill
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he might call a special session of the State Legislature to wrestle with the impact of the far-reaching Federal welfare bill on New York State's poverty programs, long the most generous and expansive in the nation.

title: To Hide Pay, Adelphi Head Refused to File I.R.S. Report
description: The president of Adelphi University told a state panel yesterday that he had concealed his rapidly rising pay and benefits from public view for five years by ordering his staff not to file a Federal disclosure form that is required from nonprofit institutions. The Internal Revenue Service fined the university $11,500 for not filing the forms.

title: Two Officers Who Retired Are Accused Of Extortion
description: Two retired New York City police officers have been charged with extortion and loan-sharking, and one has also been accused of threatening to kill a Port Chester businessman to get him to accept a settlement in a lawsuit.

title: Ideas on the Piano
description: George Colligan, Bradley's, 70 University Place, Greenwich Village, (212) 228-6440. George Colligan is a young, good pianist with a percussive touch and a sure sense for swing. His rhythmic abilities let him try figures and ideas that most musicians his age might stumble over. He's convened a group that includes Mark Turner, a tenor saxophonist who has his own following among younger musicians; he's the quiet thinker of the tenor. They'll be joined by the veteran bassist Buster Williams. Shows tonight and tomorrow are at 10, midnight and 2 A.M. There is a $15 cover and an $8 minimum.

title: Pan Am and Carnival Air Call Off Merger Plan
description: Carnival Air Lines and Pan American World Airways have called off their short-lived plans to merge. Reuven Wertheim, the chairman of Carnival Air Lines, said in a statement yesterday that the two parties could not come to terms.

title: TRAVEL UPDATE : New Bridge in Paris Is Set to Open
description: PARIS  The 37th bridge across the Seine in Paris, the Pont Charles-de-Gaulle, will open for traffic at 5 A.M. next Thursday, the city hall has announced.

title: Krajina's Serbs
description: To the Editor:

title: Boeing Buying Rockwell Units In Stock Deal That's Tax Free
description: After months of pursuing possible buyers, the Rockwell International Corporation announced today that it had sold its aerospace and weapons businesses to the Boeing Company for $860 million in stock tax free.

title: Jewish Studies, Part III
description: To the Editor:

title: Hip-Hop Classicists
description: The Roots, Central Park Summerstage, mid-park at 72d Street, (212) 360-2777. The second album by the Roots, ''Illadelph Halflife,'' is one of the year's best rap offerings, with the Philadelphia hip-hop classicists backed by a traditional drum set played as it were a drum machine, a street poet named Ursula Rucker, popular musicians like Q-Tip of A Tribe Called Quest and D'Angelo and jazz musicians like Steve Coleman and Cassandra Wilson. Throughout the album, the Roots move indiscriminately from politically conscious lyrics (not just about black America but also about Bosnia, the Olympics and terrorism) to silly rhymes (''roam like a cellular phone/far from home''). Unfortunately, the album won't be out for another six weeks. Though it may be a handicap not knowing all the new songs when the Roots perform with Bass Is Base at Central Park Summerstage tomorrow (followed on Monday by a three-night stand at the Knitting Factory, with different guest jazz musicians and rappers each night), the show should be a revelation. The Roots are among the few hip-hop acts that thrive on stage. The Summerstage concert is at 3 P.M., and admission is free. NEIL STRAUSS

title: CHRONICLE
description: ''Malaguena'' may seem so familiar, but quick . . . who wrote it?

title: No Headline
description: ''You cannot believe the savagery with which people attack toilets. They break the plumbing, they smash them. They go wild. I can see how people might injure schools or places where they've had difficulties, but I do not see how anyone can bear a grudge against a toilet.''

title: Wallace Is Too Noisy
description: JOHN WALLACE, a first-round draft choice of the Knicks, was told by a judge yesterday in Rochester that a charge issued against him on Wednesday night would be dropped if Wallace stayed out of trouble for the next six months.

title: Coughlin Gives Giants Food for Thought Over His Success With Expansion Team
description: When the Giants play the Jacksonville Jaguars tonight in their first exhibition game, will both teams wonder what could have been?

title: Mariners' Maneuver: Stock Up on Left-Handers
description: If this is the way the Seattle Mariners want to play, they just better look at what happened to the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Restaurants
description: In 1851, a bandit surrounded the theater in the small Italian town of Forlimpopoli in Emilia. He took the audience hostage, demanded a huge ransom and changed Italian food history: the shock of the event made the Artusi family move to Tuscany.

title: RETIREMENT CARE ASSOCIATES PLANS A SPINOFF
description: Retirement Care Associates Inc. said it would spin off its retirement and assisted-living business and hired Natwest Markets as its financial adviser. ''The spinoff would increase shareholder value by better realizing the market value of our retirement and assisted-living business,'' Chris Brogdon, the company's president, said. Retirement Care, which is based in Atlanta, owns or operates 95 nursing homes, retirement and assisted-living centers.

title: British Telecom Says AT&T Claims Are False
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said yesterday that it had served a writ on the AT&T Corporation charging that AT&T had made ''maliciously'' false statements that its service was cheaper. British Telecommunications said it would make a full statement of claim to the High Court in London by Aug. 9. AT&T called the charge unfounded.

title: Clinton's Welfare Shift Ends Tortuous Journey
description: Four years ago, candidate Bill Clinton issued a ringing promise to ''end welfare as we know it,'' to ''empower people with the education, training and child care they need'' to escape the trap of dependency. As President, he proposed to increase welfare spending by $10 billion to accomplish those goals.

title: Escapades on Fire Island
description: IT'S a barefoot society, car-free and carefree, but as long as anyone can remember, Fire Island, the skinny sandspit stretched along the underside of Long Island, has had its distinctive hierarchy. At the top are the natives, flinty souls who live year round on the 32-mile-long barrier island between the end of Robert Moses State Park and Moriches Inlet, where the Hamptons begin. The natives, it is said, look down on the homeowners and other summer folk who seasonally throng the roughly two dozen communities. The homeowners turn up their noses at the renters. The renters disdain the groupers who chip in for housing shares. And all feel superior to the day-trippers who sail in on the morning ferries and sail out again in the evening.

title: And Now What?
description: No question about it, the factory wasn't working right anymore -- outdated and inefficient. The medical product it made was getting more expensive to turn out and, even though it had for more than six decades sustained millions of American lives, it was very often ineffective, sometimes addictive. The stockholders wanted something better for their investment and were muttering about downsizing, beginning at the top.

title: Fights Erupt at Prison
description: A lockdown was imposed at the state's maximum security prison yesterday after fights broke out among hundreds of inmates, The Associated Press reported. The fights involved 200 to 250 inmates, some of whom used handmade weapons, during the inmates' regular recreation period in the prison yard at about 6 P.M., said a department spokesman, Bob McHugh. Most of the approximately 1,900 inmates at the New Jersey State Prison in Trenton were confined to their cells, he said. Several inmates were injured, but none of the injuries appeared to be serious, Mr. McHugh said. He said corrections officials did not know what caused the fights.

title: Hip Antics Of Folks In the Age Of Safe Sex
description: In one of the more successful sketches in ''I Love You, You're Perfect, Now Change,'' the musical revue that opened last night at the Westside Theater/Upstairs, two busy Manhattan types, on a first date, agree that there isn't time for preliminaries.

title: Royal Dutch/Shell Posts A Drop in Earnings
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group posted lower second-quarter profits yesterday, citing weakness in its chemicals business and the effect of foreign currency movements. Royal Dutch/Shell reported a profit of $:1.187 billion ($1.85 billion), down from $:1.227 billion ($1.91 billion) a year ago.

title: Little League Passion Comes to New York
description: It was, as they used to say around Shea Stadium, Baseball Like It Oughta Be -- competitive, passion-inspiring and nerve-rackingly suspenseful. As one fan exclaimed in mid-game: ''Baseball'll kill you, I swear to God.''

title: Prison Search After Brawl Uncovers Weapons
description: Hours after an inmate brawl during an outdoor basketball game, a cell-by-cell search of the New Jersey State Prison in Trenton found a substantial number of makeshift weapons yesterday.

title: Return to Symmetry
description: To the Editor:

title: No Free Transfers
description: To the Editor:

title: Michael M. Rea, 69, A Collector of Art And First Editions
description: Michael M. Rea, an art collector and publisher who established the Rea Award for the Short Story, died on Wednesday at his home in Washington, Conn. Mr. Rea, who also had a home in Palm Beach, Fla., was 69.

title: After Cutbacks, School Budget Includes Extra For 18 Districts
description: After three years of steady budget cuts, more than half of the city's 32 community school districts will have slightly more money to spend this year than they did last year, according to preliminary budget figures issued yesterday by the Board of Education.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Toronto Sun Managers Plan to Buy Company
description: The Toronto Sun Publishing Corporation and Rogers Communications Inc. said yesterday that they had reached an agreement under which a Toronto Sun management group would offer $16 a share (Canadian), or $11.64 (United States), for all of the company's stock. A total value for the bid was not disclosed. Rogers Communications, a Canadian broadcasting and publishing concern, agreed to support the offer. It will tender its 60.2 percent stake in the publishing concern at least until Nov. 8, or unless another bidder emerges with an offer of not less than $16.50 (Canadian) a share, it said.

title: In the Attic? Hillary?
description: The dazzling footwork with which President Clinton abandoned Franklin Roosevelt and joined the Gingrich Republicans' anti-children crusade has blinded all humanity so completely that no one has thought to ask, ''But what has he done with Hillary?''

title: Edmund Fogarty, 76, Priest Who Headed Child Care Services
description: Msgr. Edmund F. Fogarty, a child care specialist who spent two decades with the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, died yesterday in the rectory of the St. Elizabeth Ann Seton parish in Shrub Oak, N.Y., where he had been pastor for 14 years. He was 76.

title: Growth in Jobs Slowed in July, Breaking Trend
description: After several months in overdrive, the economy is showing signs of slowing to a more moderate but still healthy pace that is generating no increases in inflation, Government figures indicated today.

title: Bonn Seeks Extradition Of SS Officer Freed by Italy
description: Less than a day after an Italian military court freed a former Nazi SS captain in the 1944 massacre of more than 335 civilians outside Rome, Germany pressed today for his extradition to face murder charges in the same case.

title: Philip Jerry, 41, Choreographer And Dancer With the Joffrey
description: Philip C. R. Jerry, a choreographer and a leading dancer with the Joffrey Ballet, died on Friday at Albany Medical Center. He was 41 and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Republican Congressman Discloses He Is a Homosexual
description: Three weeks ago, Representative Jim Kolbe, a Republican from Arizona, voted with the majority to deny Federal recognition to same-sex marriages and absolve states of the obligation to honor such marriages performed in other states.

title: With a Stable Economy, Clinton Hopes for Credit
description: More than any other issue, the economy was Bill Clinton's ticket to the Presidency four years ago.

title: Fare-Increase Ploy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Intolerance in Turkey
description: Turkey's war against its Kurdish guerrillas has taken 20,000 lives since 1984, mainly in the Kurdish southeast. Now the unwarranted arrest of nonviolent Kurdish political leaders threatens to put a political solution even further out of reach.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: In Shift, Islam Is Unaffected by 2 Deadly Incidents
description: The emotions many Americans have experienced over the last two weeks, in the wake of the destruction of T.W.A. Flight 800 and the lethal bomb blast at the Olympics, have had a familiar quality. As after the Oklahoma City bombing a year ago, these incidents have left many people shocked, grieving, and with a heightened sense of vulnerability to violence in the most unexpected circumstances.

title: Impatient Customer
description: To the Editor:

title: Taylor to Give Drug Talks
description: The former Giants linebacker LAWRENCE TAYLOR will warn high school football players about the dangers of drugs as part of an out-of-court settlement of a charge of trying to buy crack cocaine.

title: Dwindling Down to a Precious Few
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: Token Convenience
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the investigation of the bombing at Centennial Olympic Park in Atlanta misstated the reason that AT&T dismissed the Borg-Warner Corporation as the provider of private security for its pavilion at the park. The company was dismissed after AT&T received reports about the theft of a sign and about security guards who left their posts, not after a series of thefts of telecommunications equipment.

title: For First Time in 84 Years, Americans Miss Out on Gold
description: Greg Louganis stopped by the Georgia Tech Aquatic Center earlier this week. He was working as a television reporter, and his presence was a nagging reminder of how much American divers have slipped since he wrung out his chamois for the last time after winning two more gold medals at the 1988 Summer Olympics.

title: 2 Performers Show Why They Split
description: The Replacements entered the 1980's ripping and roaring, becoming the smartest, brashest, loudest pop-punk band ever to perform songs by Kiss, Cher and Black Sabbath. They left the decade with thinking caps on, recording contemplative, more classic-sounding rock, pop and roots music before breaking up in 1990, too soon to cash in on the alternative-rock explosion they helped create. When two former members of the Minneapolis band played separate concerts in Manhattan this week, each held onto a different phase of the Replacements' career.

title: An Exuberant Portrayer Of Beckettian Distress
description: Rosaleen Linehan, Ireland's favorite actress, sat in her garden in the Dublin suburb of Blackrock recently, fingering a heavily annotated text of Samuel Beckett's ''Happy Days.'' She confided with a smile that the official description of her on her visa to enter the United States read ''alien of extraordinary ability.''

title: Harbaugh Takes 4-Year Deal
description: A year ago, JIM HARBAUGH was a reluctant backup quarterback for the Indianapolis Colts. Today, he's a millionaire with a four-year contract. Harbaugh had signed a one-year contract for $4.08 million early last month after the Colts designated him as their franchise player. Harbaugh's agent, LEIGH STEINBERG, said the new deal is worth $13 million over four years, including a $4 million signing bonus.

title: Tantalizing Piece of 747's Cockpit Is Found
description: The seas calmed today, the fog lifted, and investigators searching the watery crash site of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 discovered a tantalizing piece of wreckage -- a section of the cockpit that they hope will lead them to other significant debris, as well as to an explanation for why the jumbo jet exploded in mid-air last month.

title: Carjackings Up; Gangs Cited
description: Reports of carjacking and domestic violence increased dramatically in New Jersey during 1995, the state police said yesterday. There were 781 carjackings reported last year, compared with 574 the year before, perhaps because the crime has become an initiation rite for would-be gang members, said John Hagerty, a spokesman for the state police.

title: Rivera's Struggles and Botched Play Lead to Yanks' Wild Defeat
description: Bright zeros filled the scoreboard tonight, inning after swift inning, while two of the premier pitchers in the American League dazzled and dominated. Whatever Kevin Appier did against the Yankees, Dwight Gooden tried to do it even better against the Royals. Both seemingly did whatever they wanted for nine scoreless innings. Things were tidy.

title: Russia Improvises an Inauguration
description: In Soviet times, the closest thing to a festive inauguration ceremony for a new leader was the funeral of his predecessor.

title: Medicare Ad Angers Zimmer
description: United States Representative Richard A. Zimmer has threatened to sue 10 radio stations for libel if they continue broadcasting an advertisement that accuses him of having voted to ''cut Medicare spending.'' Mr. Zimmer, Republican of Delaware Township, maintains that he voted to limit growth in Medicare spending, not to cut existing benefits, said Geoffrey S. Berman, a lawyer who drafted a July 30 letter to the stations protesting the ad. Some of the stations have agreed to stop broadcasting the ad, sponsored by an advocacy group called New Jersey Citizen Action, Mr. Berman said yesterday. But several have said they will continue running it.

title: Serb Fighter Now Fights Ruling Party In Bosnia
description: He was an officer in the Yugoslav Army, he organized the Serbian military units that held this town against Muslim and Croatian forces in the Bosnian war, and he became a senior intelligence officer in the Bosnian Serb army. So at first it would seem that Milovan Stankovic, 47, is exactly the wrong kind of person to have started an important opposition newspaper in Serb-controlled Bosnia.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5

title: Americans' Final Hurdle Is Brazil
description: One victory away from a once-distant goal, Katrina McClain stood outside a dressing room in the Georgia Dome this afternoon, a thick bag of ice fastened to her left knee. Her strength and effort had once again become the central part of a decisive advantage inside, the factor that the undefeated United States women's basketball team used to reach the gold medal game in the Olympic tournament.

title: Visitors to Check for Fraud
description: Hoping to cut down on an estimated $3.2 million in welfare fraud, state officials said they would hire a private firm to help municipalities expose recipients who use a false address to collect benefits from more than one source. Under a pilot program involving the state's 11 busiest local welfare offices, investigators from the firm will visit the addresses provided by applicants for general assistance, said John McKeegan, a spokesman for the Department of Human Services. Some local officials have bristled at the state's plan to use outsiders to check up on them.

title: Evidence Was Just Enough
description: The prosecution offered no motive for the double killing, nor was there any physical evidence linking the defendants, Sean Washington and Kevin Baker, to the crime. All John Wynne, an assistant Camden County prosecutor, could offer the jury was eyewitness testimony from a woman who had known both the defendants and the victims, Margaret Wilson and Rodney Turner. But the witness, Denise Rand, admitted she had used cocaine just two hours before the January 1995 killings. Yet in a verdict Thursday that stunned onlookers, the jury took less than three hours to convict both defendants in the murders. Mr. Wynne said yesterday he was surprised, but believed the verdict was just because no one had shown any reason for Ms. Rand to lie. TERRY PRISTIN

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Healthy Economic Growth Is Shown With More Jobs

title: Newman Seems to Be the Target
description: Lou Duva was upset. Rock Newman was unavailable. And the New York State Athletic Commission was standing firm, one day after it announced that it was temporarily suspending the licenses of Duva and Newman's Spencer Promotions and withholding $1 million of Riddick Bowe's $5 million purse in the aftermath of the July 11 brawl at Madison Square Garden after Bowe's heavyweight bout with Andrew Golota.

title: Returnees Ante Up Venture Capital: Their Ideas
description: When several dozen Vietnamese-American residents gathered at a restaurant for a party here recently, four mysterious people took a table nearby and watched.

title: Nigerian Leaps From Obscurity To Gold Medal
description: When Chioma Ajunwa of Nigeria stepped onto the runway tonight for her first long jump, she had come out of nowhere in every sense of the word. She had spent the last four years forced away from track and field because of a drug suspension. Until Thursday's qualifying round, she had never even met Jackie Joyner-Kersee.

title: Dole Asserts Clinton Violated Election Law
description: The Dole campaign said today that the Clinton White House had illegally used taxpayer money for partisan political purposes.

title: Around Town, Too Many Signs, Few Respites
description: To the Editor:

title: Drama at Track, and Upset on Tennis Court
description: Jackie Joyner-Kersee ended her storied Olympic career tonight with a bronze medal behind a Nigerian woman in the long jump, Lindsay Davenport of the United States won an unexpected gold medal in tennis in the afternoon and Carl Lewis's future continued to raise the same question Ross Perot's campaign once did: Will he run or won't he?

title: In Atlanta, the Arts, Heart and Soul
description: There were days during the first week of the 1996 Olympic Games in Atlanta when the sun beat down as relentlessly as predicted, but the streets of this miragelike corporate city were dotted with tables staffed by friendly volunteers offering free water and even cookies. It was true that Atlanta was crowded to the point of claustrophobia, with waves of visitors jamming the streets and the city's valiant two-line Marta subway system. And yes, by the end of the week there was something very like the much-feared terrorist attack, when a bomb went off in the Centennial Olympic Park early on Saturday morning, bringing the bomb threats that seemed to empty midtown office buildings and trains regularly for a few days after and filled the city with knapsack-searching police, security guards and military personnel.

title: Excerpts From an Interview With Clinton on the Economy
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Clinton conducted July 8 with reporters and editors of The New York Times:

title: Lukas Plots the Course for His Stars
description: D. Wayne Lukas was back in town today, the impresario at work on a busy weekend, casting his filly star against males at Saratoga and entering four other horses in two other races that revived the wars of the Triple Crown.

title: Casinos Rake In Less
description: The gambling industry's winning streak abated somewhat last month, with casino revenues in Atlantic City showing a 1.4 percent decrease -- to $363.1 million, from $368.4 million -- compared with July 1995, according to figures released yesterday by the Casino Association of New Jersey. Income from table games increased by 2 percent, but revenue from slot machines declined by 1.2 percent even though 3,087 new machines were added, the association said. The casino industry blamed bad weather, competition from the Olympics, traffic problems and the decline in the stock market.

title: Myanmar Sanctions
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: As 4,000 players prepared for 10 days of play in the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, a New York squad came within a hairbreadth of achieving a major upset.

title: Brands's Intensity Salvages Day for U.S.
description: To call Tom Brands more intense than most other wrestlers would be as simplistic as calling Michael Johnson faster than most other sprinters. Brands, a 28-year-old fireball from Iowa City, used that intense aggressiveness today to win the 136.5-pound gold medal in Olympic freestyle wrestling.

title: Giants Overcome Mistakes
description: When Dave Brown was crunched by two Jacksonville Jaguars and bent in half like a tin can, it took him several seconds to get up. He eventually pulled himself together, and in a game that was at times quite ugly, Brown looked pretty good.

title: Somali Clan Leader Who Opposed U.S. Is Dead
description: Mohammed Farah Aidid, the Somali clan leader whose fighters humiliated United States forces trying to arrest him in 1993, has died, his colleagues reported yesterday, apparently from wounds suffered a week ago in a street battle in Mogadishu, the capital.

title: No Headline
description: ''We already tried that when the Queen of England visited, and it was a big problem. Russia is not yet ready for tuxedos.''

title: Clinton Campaign Joins Effort For Free Time on Television
description: The Clinton campaign announced today that it would help create a system of free, uniform blocks of television time for Presidential candidates this fall, adding its weight to the Dole campaign's and increasing the pressure on the networks to provide the time.

title: One U.S. Boxer Left Standing For the Finals
description: David Reid stood in front of the television in the press tent. ''C'mon T, c'mon T,'' he repeated over and over. But it was no use. He would have to go at it alone.

title: 34 Months and Still No Divorce
description: In January, the divorce lawyer Raoul Lionel Felder predicted cruel and inhuman treatment from an unlikely source, the New York State judicial system.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 15
description: Home Run Derby

title: IVAX SAYS EARNINGS RESULTS ARE BELOW PROJECTIONS
description: The Ivax Corporation said yesterday that second-quarter results fell below its own projections because lower sales of its generic drugs resulted in high customer inventory, forcing it to give more credits than expected. Ivax reported a loss from operations of $13.9 million, compared with net income of $28.1 million, or 24 cents, a year earlier. A charge of $2.07 million, or 2 cents, for debt reduction in the most recent quarter resulted in a loss of $16 million.

title: Jets Take Revamped Show on the Road
description: Once again, the New York Jets' travels will take them to this Southern city that favors catfish over lox.

title: Republicans Weaken House Bill on Combating Terrorism
description: Pressured into swift action by the suspicious crash of a T.W.A. jumbo jet, a bombing in Atlanta, and a plea from President Clinton, the House of Representatives approved a bill today to improve airport security across the nation and increase efforts against terrorism. But the legislation fell far short of the Administration's goals.

title: Cubans Slug Their Way Past Japan to Gold Medal
description: Olympic baseball's aluminum bat home run derby ended as expected today with the defending champion, Cuba, out-slugging Japan by 13-9 for the gold medal.

title: Milken-Ellison Group Buying British Stake
description: A partnership formed by Michael R. Milken and Lawrence J. Ellison agreed yesterday to pay $:109 million ($169 million) for a 50.1 percent stake in the CRT Group, a provider of computer training near Liverpool, England. The Los Angeles-based partnership, Education Technology, was formed in January with an investment of $300 million from Mr. Milken, the former junk bond trader, and Mr. Ellison, president and chief executive of the Oracle Corporation, a major technology company based in Redwood City, Calif.

title: For U.S. Fliers in France, Only Hang-Up Is the Menu
description: The arrival of three United States Air Force high-altitude U-2 spy planes early this year at the air base just outside this Provencal city of 40,000 raised a few chauvinistic French eyebrows, it is true.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S.-Japan Accord on Chips

title: Not If, But When
description: When I last saw David Brudnoy 16 months ago, his heart and lungs were heavy with disease and his spindly legs needed the support of a cane. Mr. Brudnoy, the star conservative host of Boston talk radio, had recently stunned his WBZ audience by announcing he had AIDS. He told me without much conviction that he hoped to live ''three or four more years.''

title: Islamic Bomb Is Jolt for Church and French : Bishop Is Slain in Algeria After Seeing Paris Official
description: PARIS  Terrorists have murdered the Roman Catholic bishop of Oran, in eastern Algeria, in another shock for the French government as well as for the Algerian church, beset by tragedy.

title: Kiptanui's Long Wait Becomes 4 Years Longer
description: For four years, Moses Kiptanui watched and waited.

title: U.S. Women's Team Feels Slighted by TV
description: The United States women's soccer team defeated China, 2-1, to win the gold medal on Thursday night in front of 76,481 fans in Athens, Ga. But it was nearly shut out of prime-time television attention by NBC.

title: Of Limited Use
description: To the Editor:

title: HUNTSMAN CHEMICAL SWEETENS ITS OFFER FOR REXENE
description: The Huntsman Chemical Corporation increased to $15 a share its offer to buy a rival petrochemical manufacturer, the Rexene Corporation. The latest offer increases to $281.6 million the cash portion of the offer. Including the assumption of $175 million in Rexene debt, the total offer is worth $456.6 million. Huntsman's earlier offer totaled $442 million. Rexene, based in Dallas, last month rejected a $14-a-share offer from Huntsman, which is based in Salt Lake City and is the largest privately held chemical company in the United States.

title: 10 Events, 6 Golds and a Lot of Tales
description: Flanked by America's five other living gold-medal winning decathletes, Dan O'Brien explained what his thoughts were on Thursday night as he prepared to undertake the last of 10 events, the 1,500 meter race, the one he dreads most.

title: Police Beating Is Protested
description: About 40 supporters of a man who claims the Irvington police beat him severely held an all-day protest in front of City Hall yesterday to demand that the officers be brought to justice. The man, Max Antoine, 28, of East Orange, was charged with assaulting a police officer in the June 2 fracas that occurred when officers tried to shut down a party. But Mr. Antoine says three Irvington officers attacked him when he tried to get their badge numbers and beat him with their hands, feet and nightsticks. His lawyer, Michael Kazer, said the beating left Mr. Antoine blind in one eye, deaf in one ear, and with knee and ankle injuries that require surgery.

title: Track Queen Can Accept Bronze Age
description: SHE looked down the runway at the rest of her life. She would never again wear a competitor's number and propel herself down the runway. Her right thigh was wrapped tightly, but not enough to hide the twanging of her hamstring. She was in sixth place, not where Jackie Joyner-Kersee usually resides.

title: Gant Slam Ruins Night For Jones And Mets
description: Bobby Jones cannot fight the gravity of his season, a force that seems to tug every high of his back to earth, that insists upon grounding any game he wins by a defeat the next time out.

title: World Bank Fund to Help Poor Countries
description: Taking the first step toward a new strategy to stimulate the flow of billions of dollars in private capital to the developing world, the World Bank has effectively set aside $250 million that could be used to guarantee new investment in poor countries against expropriation and other political risks.

title: U.S. Mining Is Making A Comeback, of Sorts
description: Diamond mining, an enterprise whose risk and effort have long stymied all but the most faithful prospectors, is making a comeback in the United States after a dry spell of more than 75 years.

title: All in the Wrist?
description: To the Editor:

title: Discounts in Chicago
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Stop Recycling
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil's Female Stars Finally Have a Medal
description: THE mission, should anyone from NBC choose to accept it, is to announce the Olympic women's basketball gold medal game tomorrow night without using one-name shortcuts for those eccentric and tantalizing souls from Brazil when they dare to challenge the corporate-sponsored powerhouse from the United States.

title: Power Through Cyberspace
description: The posters, a blend of cyberlingo and hip-hop-speak, beckon from phone booths in the heart of Bedford-Stuyvesant. They are often ripped down by day's end. But sometimes they last long enough to lure a would-be cybernaut to a new frontier.

title: The Good, the Bad, the Ridiculous
description: The Republic has been treated to the spectacle of grown men and women in Congress behaving like college students pulling a last-ditch all-nighter. Their aim was to pile up a record with which to impress the voters or to club their opponents this fall. The entire show was alarming because when Congress gets in a hurry it can do even more damage than when it has plenty of time.

title: New York Summer Games
description: While I applaud Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's efforts to promote our great city as the site of the 2008 Summer Olympics, I can only wonder if the events might not be enlivened by the inclusion of our favorite native ''quality-of-life'' sports -- the many competitions for which all New Yorkers train every day.

title: Reveling in the Nonsense Of Punctured Pomposity
description: One of the more fascinating byways in operatic history leads from Bayreuth, Germany, in 1882, by way of Paris to Hartford in 1934; from Wagner's ''Parsifal'' to its near-inversion, the Virgil Thomson-Gertrude Stein confection ''Four Saints in Three Acts.'' Robert Wilson has just traveled that path, having directed ''Parsifal'' in 1992 at the Houston Grand Opera and ''Four Saints'' last January in Houston and now at the Lincoln Center Festival.

title: Rodman Will Return to Bulls
description: DENNIS RODMAN, the National Basketball Association rebounding leader, who had threatened to leave the game, has decided to return to the Chicago Bulls next season.

title: U.S. SURGICAL BEGINS A TAKEOVER BID FOR CIRCON
description: The U.S. Surgical Corporation said yesterday that it had begun an unsolicited takeover bid for a smaller rival, the Circon Corporation, valued at $18 a share, or about $230 million. After news of the bid, Circon shares soared nearly 56 percent, or $6.75, to $18.875 in morning trading on the Nasdaq stock market. Circon, based in Santa Barbara, Calif., is the largest producer of advanced endoscopes and miniature color-video systems for medical applications, with annual sales of about $160 million. U.S. Surgical is based in Norwalk, Conn. The takeover bid was first reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column Thursday about Gail Devers and the women's 100-meter hurdles race at the Olympics misstated the nationality of the silver medal winner, Brigita Bukovec in some editions. She is from Slovenia, not Slovakia.

title: France Gives Details Of Thomson Sale
description: The French Government said yesterday that the privatization of Thomson S.A., a military contractor, would be through a direct sale to investors and reaffirmed that the sale would be before the end of 1996. France will retain a share, the Government said.

title: Brutal Case Illustrates Trend Of Guns' Replacing Toys
description: No one noticed at first when the mother and her skinny 12-year-old son walked quietly into the South-Central police station here on Thursday evening.

title: Michel Debre, 84, Dies; de Gaulle Protege and Ex-Premier
description: Michel Debre, who played a central role in drafting France's 1958 Constitution and went on to serve as the Fifth Republic's first Prime Minister under President Charles de Gaulle, died today at his home in Montlouis-sur-Loire, 150 miles south of Paris. He was 84.

title: Official Asks If President Of Adelphi Should Stay
description: With Adelphi University's enrollment dropping sharply, its money limited and its campus in turmoil, the head of a state review panel asked Adelphi's president yesterday whether he can effectively continue in office.

title: Subway Grate Falls on Track, Causing Fire And Shutdown
description: A rusted Depression-era underground grate suspended high above an East Side subway tunnel tumbled to the tracks early yesterday, leading to electrical explosions and a fire that hampered service to much of Queens and Manhattan for nine hours and trapped dozens of riders in blinding smoke.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a November referendum in New York on a $1.75 billion environmental bond act inaccurately described an $800 million bond act that was defeated by voters in 1992. That bond act was aimed at financing job creation in the state, not environmental projects.

title: Putting a Number to the Monthly Gyration in Bonds
description: No single piece of economic data seems to affect the stock and bond markets these days as much as the monthly employment report. The anticipation in the marketplace -- the speculation about what the numbers will be -- is enormous. So it is not surprising that a formula has appeared for predicting how much interest rates will move in response to the job numbers.

title: U.S. and Japan Renew a Chip Accord, but With Changes
description: After marathon negotiating sessions that were laden with election politics on both sides of the Pacific, the United States and Japan agreed today to a new and unusual trade accord governing the computer chip industry, one that reflects the revival of the American electronics industry since the first accord was signed a decade ago.

title: Eurocopter Sells Saudis 12 Helicopters
description: Saudi Arabia agreed to buy 12 search-and-rescue helicopters made by the French-German venture Eurocopter, the French Defense Ministry said yesterday. The contract's value was not given, but estimates range from 850 million francs ($170 million) to 1.2 billion francs ($240 million), depending on the configuration of the helicopter, the Cougar Mark II.

title: A Different Verdict in Little Rock
description: The White House is entitled to take comfort from the failure of the Whitewater prosecutor to convict two of President Clinton's political backers of financial misdealings during the 1990 campaign for Governor of Arkansas. On Thursday, a Federal jury in Little Rock acquitted Herby Branscum Jr. and Robert Hill of four felony counts, including a conspiracy charge in which the prosecution had sought to implicate Bruce Lindsey, then and now a close Clinton friend and trusted aide.

title: Celtics Sign Walker
description: The Boston Celtics signed their top draft pick, ANTOINE WALKER, yesterday and also worked out a deal to keep the free agent GREG MINOR with the team.

title: Bankers' Jurors Disbelieved Chief Prosecution Witness
description: In the end, say the jurors in the latest case brought by the Whitewater independent counsel's office, they voted to acquit two Arkansas bankers of four felony counts because Neal T. Ainley, the Government's main witness, had appeared evasive during his testimony.

title: Challenge for Lindy Lane
description: A battle of the sexes will be staged today at the Meadowlands, where a pair of 3-year-old fillies, Act of Grace and Continental Victory, will attempt to turn the tables on the favored colt, Lindy Lane, in the $1.2 million Cadillac Hambletonian.

title: Company Briefs
description: CHARTER POWER SYSTEMS INC., Plymouth Meeting, Pa., which produces and markets integrated reserve power systems, said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 500,000 shares, or 7.7 percent of the company's common stock outstanding.

title: Bonds Continue Strong Rally On a Modest Growth in Jobs
description: Prices of Treasury securities surged yesterday after employment data for July showed economic growth slowing with little inflation. The rally pushed the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a benchmark for corporate and consumer interest rates -- to a four-month low.

title: WAGES AND HEALTH LEAD THE AGENDA AS CONGRESS ACTS
description: Rushing toward a monthlong recess, Congress today gave final legislative approval to a variety of bills that would raise the Federal minimum wage, make drinking water safer and guarantee workers' ability to carry health insurance from job to job.

title: Johnson Smashes World Record and Completes Double
description: ATLANTA  His head and his legs were curved back as if his belt buckle had been tied to a speedboat yanking him along. Except for this: Michael Johnson wasn't wearing a belt.

title: At F.B.I. Lab, a Scientific Mission and a Challenge of Its Methods
description: In clean, brightly lighted laboratories at the J. Edgar Hoover Building, the scientific examination of mangled pieces of wreckage from T.W.A. Flight 800 inches forward. Far from the grim recovery effort, away from the victims' grieving families, teams of white-coated chemists, metallurgists and explosives experts quietly scrape, swab and pick through the shattered debris flown from Long Island.

title: Prayer and Politics Mingle In Dole's Visit to Olympics
description: Bob Dole knelt in silence today at a hillside at the foot of last week's fatal pipe-bomb explosion at Centennial Olympic Park, before heading to the Olympic stadium for what has become the latest stop on the Presidential campaign trail.

title: Officer Admits Paying to Try to Have Dallas Football Star Killed
description: A former Dallas police officer today admitted in court that he had paid an undercover narcotics agent $2,960 to have the Dallas Cowboy football star Michael Irvin killed and that he had sold police records to someone he believed to be a drug dealer.

title: Judicial Activism Of a Different Flavor
description: To the Editor:

title: Republicans Dilute Terrorism Measure
description: The House passed a bill to improve airport security across the nation and bolster efforts against terrorism. But under pressure from the National Rifle Association, Republican leaders rejected two crucial White House proposals. One would require manufacturers to mark bomb ingredients so they could be traced in detonated explosives. The other would assist the authorities in obtaining broader wiretaps.

title: Raise Your Hand if You Love Metrocard
description: To the Editor:

title: Anabolic Steroid Use Grows, Legal or Not
description: Whenever the Olympic Games take the world stage, accusations about the use of performance-enhancing drugs are sure to follow. This time, pointed fingers and knowing nudges have been directed at various athletes, including Eastern European athletes, five of whom tested positive for a stimulant and were disqualified from competing in the Games.

title: NEW POWER MACINTOSH LINE OF COMPUTERS IS DISPLAYED
description: Apple Computer Inc. yesterday displayed a Power Macintosh line of computers based on the Power PC 604e chip. The line offers speeds of as much as 200 megahertz and all models now include 8X-speed CD-ROM drives. The line includes Apple's first multiprocessing desktop model, which features dual Power PC 604e processors running at 180 MHz to improve performance on compute-intensive tasks. The Power Macintosh 9500/200 includes a 200 MHz chip and will be fully available in September for an estimated price of $4,899. The multiprocessing model, the 9500/180MP will ship in September and will retail for $5,699. The Power Macintosh 8500/180 includes a 180 MHz chip and will be fully available in September for $4,499.

title: Chicago Protesters Get Time Slots
description: Any group that wants to stage a protest or a prayer anywhere near the 1996 Democratic National Convention will first have to take its chances in the city's newest lottery.

title: A Cram Course in Priorities: Food and Sex
description: ''Phat Beach'' offers slim pickings.

title: Americans in Perfect Sync
description: The United States synchronized swim team knew what it would take to win the gold medal: a near-perfect score.

title: Deal Is Reached in Inquiry Of Ex-Navy Yard Chief
description: To escape prosecution on a possible perjury charge, the former president of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation has admitted to lying about the improper purchase of office furniture, according to sources close to the investigation.

title: No Pause to Refresh
description: To the Editor:

title: Against Odds, Davenport Takes Title
description: There were Olympic-sized odds on her opponent's side of the net in every department except one. As a 6-foot-2-inch tower of power, Lindsay Davenport was used to dwarfing the competition.

title: ISRAEL WILL ALLOW SETTLERS TO BUILD
description: The Likud Government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu took one of its first specific steps today toward reversing the dovish policies of its predecessors, lifting a four-year-old freeze on the expansion of settlements in the West Bank and Gaza.

title: New Jobs Data Brighten Mood On Wall Street
description: The negative mood of the nation's financial markets evaporated yesterday after the July employment report signaled that the economy -- which grew briskly during this year's second quarter -- might be slowing down a little.

title: Democrats Say Dole's Economic Forecasts Are Far Too Rosy
description: During last year's budget battle, Bob Dole and his fellow Republicans accused the Clinton Administration of using unrealistically rosy assumptions of economic growth to make its deficit-cutting plan add up, and insisted that the White House use more conservative numbers.

title: Agency Proposes Cut in Lilco Rates
description: Citing ''poor economic conditions on Long Island'' linked to high electric costs, the staff of the State Public Service Commission proposed a 5.2 percent reduction today in rates of the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Mexican Whistle-Blower Held on Drug Charge
description: A former official of a Mexican anti-drug unit has been arrested on charges of narcotics trafficking and bribery just days after he made headlines with similar accusations against his former colleagues.

title: Export Growth Slows for Asia's Tiger Economies
description: Are East Asia's fiercely competitive tiger economies starting to lose their fangs?
