title: New Nassau County Legislature Draws Crowds and Critics
description: Measured by public attendance, the fledgling band of lawmakers that took office here Jan. 1 as the newly created Nassau County Legislature is a hit.

title: Report Blames Poor Farmers For Depleting World Forests
description: An international agricultural research organization, reopening an impassioned debate over who is responsible for the decline of the world's tropical forests, says in a report to be published on Sunday that poor farmers in the developing world could destroy half the remaining forest cover, with logging threatening the rest.

title: Handling the Uninvited -- Termites
description: EVERY homeowner should be concerned about termites. It is estimated that these voracious insects damage 1.8 million to 2 million homes each year. Often the homeowner is unaware that there is any termite activity until serious structural damage occurs. It's difficult to spot termite infestation because the insects do not actually inhabit the structures of a house -- they only forage there. They live in nests that are widely spread beneath the soil.

title: A Henna Party (Don't Rinse)
description: There was a party at an art gallery in the East Village on Thursday, but no one was looking at art. Well, not on the walls, anyway.

title: A Jazz-Age Survivor
description: UNTIL he was partly paralyzed by a stroke in 1993, Joseph Chris Columbo Morris was the oldest working musician in Atlantic City. Mr. Morris, a drummer better known as Crazy Chris Columbo, liked to call himself ''the luckiest man alive.''

title: A Well-Known Name Overcomes a Label
description: Much of Russell Cosby's life has been defined by how others perceived him. Was he a real, flesh and blood human being, or merely a cartoon character created by his older brother, Bill Cosby, for a popular 1970's cartoon series, ''Fat Albert and the Cosby Kids,'' who also often turned up in his brother's comedy routines about childhood? Was he a wise, common-sense man who put three children through college or ''the slow learner'' who educators once said would never be able to carry out basic math and reading tasks?

title: QUESTIONS FOR: Maria Ewing
description: An American operatic soprano, Ewing will sing in concert this week with the New York Philharmonic.

title: Sprinters' Best Starts Are Stopped
description: As the Olympics conclude, athletic feats have been highlighted by the improbable, the unbelievable, the incredulous as well as such twisting, tumbling, looping through the air, straining, sweating, gasping and yowling that is rarely witnessed or heard, unless, of course, you are trying to cross Broadway at 42d Street.

title: Portraits of the Artists, on the Big Screen
description: THE ART WORLD SPENT THE 80's getting used to reading about itself in glossy magazines. In the 90's it may grow accustomed to seeing itself ascend to the big screen.

title: Lift the Ceiling
description: To the Editor:

title: A Family of Struggling Orphans
description: CHRISTOPHER Keyser, a creator of the Fox Network's ''Party of Five,'' is finally able to chuckle over the dark season that followed the fall 1994 debut of the unusual family drama. Now that the critically lauded, ever more popular ''Party of Five'' begins its third season on Wednesday, Aug. 21, Mr. Keyser says he can at last stop crossing his fingers overthe fate of his once left-for-dead series.

title: Alice R. Davis, David Tornquist
description: Alice Ruth Davis, a daughter of Mary Ann and Charles Winslow Davis of Aurora, Ohio, was married yesterday to David Emmons Tornquist, a son of Gisela Brand Tornquist and Thomas Emmons Tornquist of East Setauket, L.I. The Rev. Sally Wile performed the United Church of Christ ceremony at the Plymouth Church of Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: Condos for Sale On E. 62d St.
description: In an unusual financial arrangement, the striking 1910 neo-Medieval terra cotta and brick building at 40 East 62d Street currently owned and partially used by the adjacent Browning School is to become a condominium, with the school owning the second, third and half of the fourth floors, plus part of the first floor.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3

title: Eat, Drink, Play (Yes, Play): 8 Places to Find Your Chi
description: The New Jersey section asked Dr. Noel Nowicki, the Kessler Institute's resident acupuncturist, what he tells patients who want to improve their overall health.

title: Ms. Murphy, Mr. Buhler
description: Katherine Theresa Murphy, a daughter of Robert and Phyllis Murphy of Wethersfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Philipp Michael Buhler, the son of Fritz and Gisela Buhler of Basel, Switzerland. The Rev. John E. Halbourg, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: Grants That Aim to Use the Past to Help the Present
description: THE sprawling convention hall and Paramount Theater complex has anchored the boardwalk in Asbury Park since the 20's. But over time its fortunes along with those of the old resort city have changed, pushing it into disuse and disrepair.

title: 'Street Furniture' Irks Some Tastes
description: ''Street furniture'' may sound like an abandoned sofa on a sidewalk, but in City Hall parlance, it means things like newsstands, bus shelters, lampposts, kiosks and trash baskets.

title: Auditors: Experts Or Just Robots?
description: Are accountants professionals who exercise independent judgment, or do they just follow rules and checklists?

title: Little Girls in a Staged Spectacle for Big Bucks? That's Sportainment!
description: The time has come to call it by its rightful name: The Olympicapades. The Games are a five-ring circus, somewhere between the World Cup and the Ice Follies.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-13

title: Free Trade? Don't Sell Us That.
description: NOT so long ago, Rosa Molina felt she was doing pretty well in life. But now, like many Mexicans, she feels as if she's been mugged by a 19-month economic crisis. Her once-sunny outlook has withered to a brooding cynicism.

title: $500 Fekkai Haircut Gives Edge Needed to Succeed
description: To the Editor:

title: Water Work
description: THE EMERGING HUDSON RIVER PARK, with its open spaces, tree-lined biking and walking paths and grand views of the Statue of Liberty and the George Washington Bridge, will mark a new phase in New York's relationship with its waterfront. Or rather, it will restore a relationship that has been long lost.

title: Rank: 18 of 25. Not Funds, Olympic Sailing.
description: PERFORMANCE being so important to attracting cash, most mutual fund managers would be disheartened to end up ranking 18th out of 25, even if it was a tie. But Mark G. Holowesko, who manages billions of dollars in Templeton mutual funds, says he is happy with that outcome.

title: Westchester Guide
description: ART OFFERINGS

title: Trolling Through the Delights of Greece
description: MENTION Greek food to a Long Islander and he will think of souvlaki, Greek salad and storefronts. More adventuresome fare means a trip to Astoria's ethnic spots or, for really exciting Greek dishes, to Periyali in Manhattan. This charming, three-star restaurant, with its cutting-edge, haute Hellenic cuisine, has redefined Greek food for New Yorkers.

title: A GOOD NEWS/BAD NEWS AIDS JOKE
description: In ''A Good News/Bad News AIDS Joke'' (July 14), Larry Kramer seems to be making a point that the greed of drug companies is killing the victims of AIDS. In fact, quite the opposite is happening. The greed of drug companies is the only hope for the victims of AIDS.

title: America Sits and Watches
description: ONE of the many diplomats now struggling to end the chaos in Burundi says that a former Burundian minister sincerely believes that an American aircraft carrier is cruising Lake Tanganyika, ready to invade. When he's told that there's no way to sail a carrier into a lake in the central African highlands, he answers: ''They brought it in by helicopter.''

title: Shortsighted Boycotts
description: To the Editor:

title: Brett W. Scoll, Jonathan R. Perryman
description: Brett Whitney Scoll, the daughter of Geraldine and David Scoll of Weston, Mass., was married there yesterday to Dr. Jonathan Richard Perryman, a son of Nancy Roberts of Rumson, N.J., and Dr. Richard A. Perryman of Miami. The Rev. Robert Tyrrell performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Julia Church.

title: But This Mall Will Fly You There
description: As downtown shopping districts try to lure more New Jersey customers, at least one mall has set its sights on other clientele: Manhattanites.

title: Unease Over Dole Leads to Separate Campaigns
description: Increasingly uneasy that Bob Dole could bring them down in November, many Republican Congressional candidates say they are beginning to run campaigns independent of the presumed Presidential nominee.

title: The Christian Right Confesses Sins of Racism
description: WHEN Ralph Reed, the head of the Christian Coalition, called a meeting several weeks ago to protest the burnings of Southern black churches, an understandable skepticism hung in the air. Much of his support comes from conservative white evangelicals, a group that a few short decades ago was claiming a Biblical basis for segregation. And Mr. Reed himself is notably hostile to an array of Government safety-net programs prized by many black Americans. Some of his critics dismissed his showy meeting in Atlanta -- and his pledge to seek $1 million for church construction -- as a publicity stunt and a ruse.

title: 'Threepenny' Gala, One-Woman Shows
description: SUMMER after summer, Lucille Lortel, the mistress of the White Barn and the queen of Off Broadway, insists: ''I can't do it anymore.'' And then she does it one more time.

title: Republicans On New Tack
description: All of a sudden, the Republican 104th Congress seems to prefer the label of ''lawmaker'' to the old favorite, ''revolutionary.''

title: Dr. John Holt, 81, Radiology Authority
description: Dr. John Floyd Holt, a groundbreaking pediatric radiologist, died on July 22 at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich., where he was professor emeritus of radiology at the University of Michigan Medical Center. He was 81.

title: QUIZ
description: Here's a summertime quiz that combines two favorite hot-weather pastimes, going to movies and traveling to some of the nation's most popular vacation spots. Test your knowledge of films and the tourist attractions that were featured in them.

title: Talking Peace, Hardening the Line
description: Amid a flurry of news leaks about secret diplomatic initiatives by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, his Government moved to tighten Israel's hold on the West Bank and Golan Heights. It canceled the previous Labor Government's curbs on building in Jewish settlements and and ordered construction of two highways in the West Bank and two new bridges to the Golan Heights.

title: Mount Desert Island
description: When a guest ordered a strawberry daiquiri at the century-old Claremont Hotel recently, the bartender did something so simple it was downright startling: he retrieved fresh strawberries from the refrigerator, then gently washed and stemmed them by hand before dropping them into the blender.

title: INSIDE
description: Defiance Grows in Indonesia

title: Fat Chance
description: Those glorious bodies on display in Atlanta hardly need remind us that even out of competition, exercycles, ab crunchers, and personal-trainers-as-therapists are the apparati of life in the 90's. Still, given our love-hate relationship with fitness (and the fact that if we could, most of us would do it by proxy), how lovely that the hottest body of the summer is not Carl Lewis's, or even Demi Moore's, but rather Eddie Murphy's Nutty Professor.

title: Shh! Let's Keep It Down, Please
description: LONG ISLAND seems like a quiet place, until you go to Iowa. I was there in July for a writers' conference in Iowa City. The place was full of serious literary persons flown in from New York, distinguished authors of dire Prozac-inspired novels about the meaning of life or excruciating modern poetry with no rhyme or meter. Why they invited me to this gathering is a mystery: presumably for light relief.

title: Nomads
description: Bret Lott's new collection of short fiction evokes the yearning to find home -- in the broadest sense of the word -- that is felt by the nomadic citizens of late-20th-century America. The 16 sketches included in HOW TO GET HOME (John F. Blair, $18.95) are brief portraits of hapless individuals caught in the simple crisis of being alive, trying and usually failing to connect with the people around them. ''After Leston,'' the novella that opens the collection, is a model of compression, spare writing and poignancy, narrated by the title character from Mr. Lott's earlier novel, ''Jewel.'' Set in a working-class suburb of Los Angeles in the mid-1960's, just before the Watts riots, it tells the story of a white family that's uprooted itself from rural Mississippi in pursuit of an education for Brenda Kay, Jewel's retarded daughter. It's a simple story, told by a plain-spoken woman, yet it speaks volumes about love and loss, about the competition between our own ideas about the world and those of the people nearest to us -- about where a family ends and an individual begins. Barbara Quick

title: Beyond Graffiti: Artist Wants to Make His Mark in Business
description: This is the story of Cheese, graffiti artist turned well, turned graffiti artist.

title: The Art of Fishing, Next Generation
description: ''OH dude, that's BIG!'' said one fisherman as he eyed the shimmering foot-long rainbow trout another had just landed.

title: Landlord vs. Tenant: City Eviction Wars
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Jolted
description: WHAT WOMEN WANT

title: Policing of Pregnancies Won't Protect Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Tweedy, Browne Avoids the Hot Spots and Hunts for Value
description: AS the stock market stumbled through July and into an August rally, the talk among bulls was that the setback had created some real values.

title: Geppetto's Child, Despite the High-Tech Hardware
description: THE BRITISH DESIGNER Jamie Courtier was frantic by the time the sixth of the puppet heads he had created for the new movie ''The Adventures of Pinocchio'' had been rejected by the film makers. ''I was desperate when I began sculpting the seventh version.'' he said. ''So I did exactly what I thought was right. A puppet can't be designed by committee. It has to come from one person.''

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the International Datebook listing on page 21 of the Travel section today, for the World Mountain Bike Championships in Cairns, Australia, misstates the opening date. It is Sept. 12, not Sept. 16.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: ANNIVERSARY SAVINGS Loews Hotels is offering a 50 percent discount to Dec. 31 for guests turning 50 or marking a 50th wedding anniversary this year. The discount applies to the regular (rack) rate and not to any other programs, promotions or discounts. Guests need to notify the reservations agent that they wish to take advantage of the offer, and present proof of age or a marriage certificate at the front desk.

title: The Measure of Lewis
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Risky Plays and Lots of Penguins
description: LOOK at the flowers,'' says Joe Brancato, pointing to the petunias and the impatiens in bloom -- and to a surrounding garden, adorned with penguin figurines. ''We did all the landscaping.''

title: U.S. vs. the World
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Reflections of an On-Line Graduate
description: I saw my college for the first time on June 12, 1995, five hours before I graduated. My campus until that day had been my computer. I live in Bellingham, Wash., and for a year and a half I had been hooking up by modem to the State University of New York's Empire State College.

title: Limestone Shell Evokes Far Rockaway's Gatsby Era
description: TAKE a trip to the dreamy new Bayswater Point Park, a cool, leafy peninsula at the foot of Mott Avenue in Far Rockaway, Queens. The sun shimmers over the irregular prongs of Jamaica Bay, and distant jumbo jets taxi at Kennedy Airport far across the water, like elephants on the veldt, a mesmerizing sight.

title: Brickyard Struggle Caps Sweep For Jarrett
description: By now, it doesn't matter whether one of Robert Yates's Winston Cup teams is No. 1 in his heart and the other No. 2, or even whether one is Team A or Team B. Both are awesome, and the one with Dale Jarrett driving has shark-like instincts when big money floats by.

title: Charles Ives in Bard Spotlight
description: AUGUST is the time for band concerts in the park and cool jazz in the garden, and there are events in both categories this week. In addition, for the seventh summer in a row, August also brings a series of programs to Annandale-on-Hudson that are notable both for their unity and daring.

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today:

title: DOLE SEEKS A LIFT AS CAMPAIGN TILTS TO THE CONVENTION
description: In what his advisers say amounts to a third start-up of his Presidential campaign, Bob Dole is heading into an event-packed 11 days in which he plans to unveil a centerpiece economic proposal, select a running mate and deliver his acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention in San Diego.

title: Rebecca Kobrin, Kevin Feinblum
description: Rebecca Amy Kobrin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Kobrin of New York, is to be married today to Kevin Earle Feinblum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Feinblum of Johannesburg. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is to perform the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Reprieve for Army Museum
description: Plans to close the Harbor Defense Museum, the only Army museum in the city, have been temporarily scrapped after military officials persuaded the commanding officer at Fort Hamilton to keep it going with reduced hours.

title: From Atlanta To Munich Via 'Egmont'
description: IT WAS THE EERIEST OF COINCIDENCES. THE fatal bomb blast in Centennial Olympic Park in Atlanta last weekend inevitably carried longtime followers of the Olympic Games back to Munich in 1972, when 11 Israeli athletes were slain by Arab terrorists. At least one listener was carried back musically as well, and set to pondering the nature of musical homage and musical meaning.

title: Dina M. Britvan, Richard C. Beck
description: Dina Michele Britvan, a daughter of Elaine and Aaron Britvan of Plainview, L.I., was married last evening to Dr. Richard Craig Beck, the son of Phyllis Beck and Dr. Lester Beck of Dix Hills, L.I. Rabbi Arthur Rulnick performed the ceremony at the Woodbury (L.I.) Jewish Center.

title: Follow the Arrows
description: Not so long ago, scholars seemed close to agreement on when and how ancient people first colonized America. About 12,000 years ago, hunters followed their mammoth and mastodon prey across the Bering land bridge from Siberia into Alaska, then southward throughout the Americas. The clearest pieces of evidence were their gracefully fluted stone spear points, thought to be a distinctly American invention.

title: HOW TO MAKE A CORPSE TALK
description: From Mary Cantwell's article ''How to Make a Corpse Talk'' (July 14), it's evident that Patricia Cornwell likes all that money can buy, and I fear she has become more interested in selling books than writing them -- one of those mystery writers whose money lust propels them to crank out a book a year, culminating in the laughably unbelievable ''Cause of Death'' (Scarpetta saving Virginia from nuclear meltdown?). Sad, this, for Cornwell's first four ''crime novels'' rank as some of the finest of the genre.

title: Roof Section of Jetliner's First-Class Cabin Is Recovered
description: Salvage teams and divers accelerated their efforts to retrieve wreckage and victims from the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 today, recovering seven more bodies and a roughly 40- by 60-foot arc of the bulging roof of the first-class section of the jumbo jet.

title: Lots of Pizzas, in a Sometimes Odd Setting
description: INHERITING space formerly occupied by a Mexican restaurant, Vicolo Pizza and Trattoria in New Canaan has converted it into a cheerful evocation of Italy, complete with rough-textured pastel walls, one with an Italian scene; terra cotta tiled floor, framed posters, faux windows lighted from behind and a blue ceiling flecked with clouds.

title: Classical Briefs
description: STRAVINSKY: 'THE RITE OF SPRING,' 'FIREBIRD' SUITE, 'SONG OF THE NIGHTINGALE'

title: Measuring Riches In Ideas, Not Gold
description: WHEN it comes to money, Rebecca Goldstein is smack in the philosophical tradition.

title: Debra Ketchum, B. Q. Underhill
description: Debra Ann Ketchum, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Ketchum of Dummerston Center, Vt., was married yesterday to Benedict Quinn Underhill, a son of Jacob B. Underhill 3d of New York and the late Cynthia Lovejoy Robinson. The Rev. Robert E. Neale, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Berkeley Campus Boils Over New Issue: Profits
description: The University of California is famous for its loud protests and raucous rallies, but the most recent dispute here is more like something out of a business school case study: a raging debate over outsourcing, equity interests and guaranteed profit streams.

title: Three Flights Up, the Top of the World
description: JAY BERGEN possesses something that most mortals never will: an oval foyer with an antique-tile checkerboard floor.

title: Techno-Dwellings for the Cyber-Egos of the Mega-Rich
description: Some chilly nights, after his computer turns off every light bulb, the fireplace and the infrared heat over the patio, and before it adjusts the blinds, Charles Simonyi, Microsoft's chief programming wizard, stands on a cantilevered terrace of his 20,500-square-foot lake-side home here, marveling at what he calls ''the absolute magic,'' the quiet perfection of it all.

title: City Girls Return to Their Rosy Retreat
description: Sitting close together on the floor with other children waiting for the afternoon bus, Frances and Saquanna Minter showed little more than passing interest in the scene around them. While other youngsters chatted or clasped their mothers' hands in the face of their imminent departure, the two sisters -- Frances's head propped on Saquanna's folded leg -- looked tired. They looked as if they could use a vacation.

title: 'Independence Day' Is Not for the Young
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: PHOTO RAFFLE

title: Suddenly, Main Street Gives Malls a Run for Their Money
description: Even before the Gap moved into a pristine brick building here, the shopping district had potential. It was compact, with quaint architecture and a mix of restaurants and stores. The rents were reasonable, especially compared with those in fancy shopping malls. Above all, the residents were affluent and eager to spend.

title: The Unkindest Cut
description: IS there any coach in history with more egg on his face than Michael Jordan's high school basketball coach? Jordan, who was cut in his sophomore year, got over it and then some. But millions of other children -- many of them much younger than he was -- receive an athletic pink slip each year and never return to organized sports.

title: Office Builders Are Going Residential in Melville
description: MOST of the development on the truck and sod farms that once lined Route 110 in Melville has come in the shape of gleaming office buildings.

title: At Boardwalk, Battle Stations Over Decibels
description: IT'S a sunny Sunday afternoon, so Jack Toback is exercising his First Amendment rights on the boardwalk. At 1:30, he parks himself at National Boulevard, near the concession stands. The police arrive a little later.

title: In Bethel, Carhops and a Tradition of Fresh Ground Beef
description: IT'S a throwback to an era when cars had fins, a dollar would buy much more than a cup of coffee, and golden arches were a symbol of heaven instead of a place to get a fast burger.

title: Beat the Clock
description: How do you work and still have a life in the stressful 90's? Maybe you bang out business memos on your laptop during Olympics breaks. Dictate letters to a tape recorder as you shower. Perhaps you sub-contract some number-crunching to your whiz kid teen-ager, or maybe you have secret skills for avoiding that biggest of business time-wasters: the meeting. Send your story of clever time-management to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All sub missions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: After Bomb in Airport, Spain Tightens Security
description: A terrorist bomb that wounded 35 people, mostly British tourists, at the Reus airport in eastern Spain July 20 has prompted increased security measures in the region. Among them are the removal of airport trash cans, like the one where the bomb was hidden, and the hiring of additional airport security personnel. Extra police patrols have been added on Spain's popular Mediterranean beaches near the airport, 50 miles south of Barcelona, as Spanish authorities reacted swiftly to protect the nation's lucrative tourist industry.

title: Summers Without Vacations
description: Summer jobs? They're usually at the bottom, looking up -- difficult, frustrating, low-paying. But the rewards aren't to be measured in money. Who can put a value on grit and self-knowledge, hard-earned but good for a lifetime?

title: The New Jersey Name Game
description: What's in a name? Brendan Byrne Arena is now Continental Airlines Arena. Trenton State College will be the College of New Jersey. If you could rename something in New Jersey, what would it be, and why?

title: Databook
description: In the world of the campus lectures, names count for a lot. Where the college circuit was once a cocoon of scholars and lecturers often obscure outside the college universe, now the billing reflects the interests of the culture as a whole -- filmmakers, poets, playwrights, politicians and polemicists. The talks are usually open to the public, and there is usually charge an admission fee, often reduced for students. Here is a sampling from around the country of campus speakers scheduled for this fall.

title: Next Target: Nicotine
description: THE MEDICAL REPORTS LYING ON A TABLE IN DAVID KESSLER'S office include only the thinnest detail about the death of George Korizis, a 24-yera-old Tufts University graduate and Greek citizen who died alone in his Boston apartment on April 18. But there is a curious aspect to Korizis's case that has interested Kessler, who sit he Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration and who does not ordinarily pay attention to obscure deaths.

title: Hear that 'Weesee' or 'Tweet' or 'Tizip'? Well, Which Warbler Was It?
description: A WEEK ago, the ornithologist Roger Tory Peterson died at age 87 in Connecticut, leaving behind an impressively blunt style of bird identification. He once called the male goldfinch, for instance, ''the only small yellow bird with black wings'' and the purple finch ''a sparrow dipped in raspberry juice.''

title: Bring In da Noise
description: CHARLES IVES

title: On-Line Doctor Helps Mothers
description: WHEN Dr. Lori Semel practices pediatrics, she doesn't always wear a stethoscope or consult in her D*O*C*S for Kids White Plains office. By night, Dr. Semel takes off for space. Cyberspace, that is.

title: The Last Drop: Goodbye, Joe
description: On Nov. 20, 1993, Joe Bar, a coffee bar, opened for business at the corner of 91st Street and Broadway.

title: Why Piecework Isn't an Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Squander Their Lead. Franco Manages to Save It.
description: There are times when it is difficult to figure out if John Franco is the Mets closer by occupation or merely title. He was unused in three tight games in Colorado, only to be used in a mop-up role two nights later in Cincinnati. Mets Manager Dallas Green says he stands by his man. But sometimes action can speak louder than words.

title: Fun and the Environment, Down by the Riverside
description: THE ENVIRONMENT -- the trees-and-grass kind as well as the artificial surroundings of urban life -- will be the focus at the Bronxfest on the Harlem River on Saturday.

title: Ms. Shapiro And Mr. Bach
description: Alexandra Anastasia Ekaterina Shapiro and Jonathan Paul Bach, lawyers in New York, were married last evening at Wave Hill in Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony, assisted by Associate Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the United States Supreme Court.

title: When Parents Need Their Adult Children
description: WILLIAM CRAYNAK, a resident of Rocky Hill, cared for his elderly mother and handled her finances for seven years after a stroke left her unable to move or speak. She died four years ago. ''I didn't realize the physical and mental toll it took on me until after she died,'' said Mr. Craynak, who is married and has two children. ''But I still would have done it.''

title: Anderson Agrees to Terms With Bengals
description: The Cincinnati Bengals have reached an agreement in principle with their top draft pick, WILLIE ANDERSON, according to several reports. Terms of the multiyear deal with Anderson, an offensive tackle out of Auburn, were not released. (AP)

title: From the Salvage Heap to the Ivied Walls
description: Alvin Paige, artist in residence at American International College in Springfield, Mass., is always on the prowl for architectural elements. He then brings them to campus and incorporates them into new or refurbished buildings.

title: A Bawdy Company Strong on Body English
description: AN ENGLISH THEATER TROUPE with a French name, Theatre de Complicite resists easy categorization. Its performers, drawn from across Europe, are fiercely physical beings whose commitment to the body runs counter to prevailing notions of British talent as so many elegantly talking heads. But the actors are no less at home with text, whether devising their own or working within the classics. Earthy, bawdy, sometimes just rude, their theater can be delicate and moving. They celebrate the body one moment and lift, or even address, spirits the next.

title: The Jean-Luc Godard of Long Island
description: ELBOWS AT HIS SIDES AND PALE FINGERS CLASPED IN FRONT OF HIS chin, Hal Hartley slumps in a chair and stares miserably out his 33d-floor hotel window at a mute Tokyo sprawl, which seems like nothing if not the grim future. The son and brother of ironworkers, and himself a former punk apprentice on his father's seven-man skyscraper-raising crew, Hartley wears big, tawny work boots, blue janitorial pants and a faded work shirt, but the 6-foot-3 director has none of the physical self-possession of a hard hat. Hartley has lank, light brown hair and an upper lip permanently pursed by an attack by a Doberman a decade ago -- ''One of those screwed-up dogs that people tell you are harmless,'' he says.

title: Diane M. Reis, Joseph McCartin
description: Diane M. Reis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Reis Jr. of New York, was married last evening to Dr. Joseph A. McCartin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph V. McCartin of Troy, N.Y. The Rev. Gary Gallun, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Barns of Wolf Trap Farm in Vienna, Va.

title: 'Truth,' Meet Consequences
description: In the Soviet Union, those lucky few who could read both the official press and Western newspapers might have felt they were reading about two parallel universes -- in Pravda's case, a universe remarkably predictable, since everything fit the lessons the Communist rulers wanted readers to learn.

title: The Shad Run Through It: Lives and Harvests of a Delaware River Family
description: Fred Lewis, 81, has seen the shad-fishing industry die and return to life. During the Depression, he could make enough money hauling shad during their eight-week spawning run in the Delaware River to quit his job at a paper mill. Then pollution from mills like that one almost put an end to the shad migration. But then, he remembered recently, ''sometime around 1963 we started to take out the nets again, because they were coming back.''

title: A Grilled Meal That Can Be Put on Hold
description: DINNER on the grill has unmistakable allure. That is, until the host or hostess faces the prospect of standing and tending the cooking while guests chat and nibble hors d'oeuvres. A menu of items that can be grilled, then placed on hold in a warm oven, avoids all that.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: WHITE FLAMEBy James Grady.Dove, $22.95.

title: If It Happened in Cleveland, It's Here
description: Cleveland is the place where the river caught fire, right? Yes, in 1969, to be exact. But it is also the birthplace of the first traffic light and the Salisbury steak. Among its civic heroes is Eliot Ness, who came to Cleveland after his work with the Untouchables in Chicago and cleaned up crime but lost in a run to become mayor.

title: The Need to Plan for Care After Turning 65
description: FOR more than 20 years Linda Costanza, a social worker, has worked in programs on aging, mental health and employee assistance.

title: Let the Credit Cards Compete
description: TODAY, if you call your bank and ask for an American Express or Discover credit card, you'll be told to go elsewhere -- but don't bother trying another bank. Virtually all the 6,500 banks nationwide that issue credit cards belong to the Visa or Mastercard associations, and the handful of big banks that control these groups have collaborated successfully to eliminate unwanted competition.

title: Detecting Breast Cancer More Accurately
description: ABOUT one in every nine women will develop breast cancer, said Dr. Arthur G. Lerner, chief of surgery and medical director of the Cancer Program at White Plains Hospital Center.

title: Columbus Circle Folly
description: To the Editor:

title: Greyhound Connecting Miami Airport and Keys
description: Visitors to the Florida Keys can now make the journey from Miami International Airport using Greyhound's new bus service. The Florida Keys Shuttle operates between Miami and Key West three times a day, picking up passengers at three stops in Miami, including the airport. The bus makes 15 additional stops on the way to its final destination in Key West.

title: A War Criminal Goes Free
description: Shock and outrage erupted across Italy when a military tribunal found a former SS captain, who had admitted to his role in the Nazi massacre of 335 Italian civilians outside Rome in March 1944, guilty of multiple murder but set him free nonetheless. The bizarre verdict -- based on a tangled argument that was dubbed ''miserable and grotesque'' in one typical newspaper comment -- has brought about fresh indictment of Italy's justice system, and particularly its military courts, which critics say were the wrong place to try a former Nazi who claimed he was just obeying orders.

title: Rachel Fenderson, W. R. Spencer Jr.
description: Rachel Alice Fenderson, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph Fenderson of Centerport, L.I., was married last evening to Dr. William Robert Spencer Jr., a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Spencer of Welch, W.Va. Rabbi Arthur Schwartz performed the cermony at the Indian Hills Country Club in Northport, L.I.

title: Globally, Majority Rules
description: ALEKSANDR LEBED, who once belittled democracy and its followers, was asked at a news conference in Moscow not long ago how he would describe himself now. ''A semi-democrat,'' said President Boris N. Yeltsin's security chief. He is not alone. Last week, the Clinton Administration fessed up to having provided a democracy foundation in Burundi run by Pierre Buyoya with $145,500 in grants over the last two years. Ten days ago, Major Buyoya overthrew Burundi's elected government.

title: Difficult Lesson: Learning English
description: The day when Sawako Mitsui, 20, and Midori Usuta, 21, score above 500 on the Test of English as a Foreign Language is the day they will celebrate.

title: Colleagues, Heed This Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: Enjoying a Hefty Portuguese Barbecue Repast
description: THE two smiling women left the restaurant saying they needed to run around the block a few times. They had just split a whole barbecue chicken, family-style servings of mixed salad, french fries, rice, broccoli, carrots and a few baskets of chewy Portuguese cornbread. The cost of this feast was $13.95. A few soft drinks brought it to $16.99. But even with a tip their tab was still under $20 at the four-month-old Rodizio Bairrada in Smithtown.

title: Elana B. Elster, Jordan Horvath
description: Dr. Elana Beth Elster, the daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Sheldon E. Elster of Rockville, Md., is to be married today to Jordan Adam Horvath, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley S. Horvath of Oceanside, L.I. The bride's father, the rabbi of Congregation Kol Ami in Annapolis, Md., is to perform the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

title: Helicopter Teams Lift Trauma Victims Out of Adversity
description: JUST one and a half weeks after suddenly suffering cardiac arrest, 7-year-old Gregory Totero of New City was playing with his little brother in the helicopter that had taken him to the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla. On this happier day, Gregory was pushing buttons, turning wheels and having a grand time.

title: Susan D. Evans, John C. Bohan
description: Susan Durkee Evans, a daughter of Mrs. Dwight Durkee Evans of Milton, Mass., and the late Mr. Evans, was married yesterday to John Charles Bohan, a son of Linda A. Bohan of Brunswick, Me., and Thomas Lynch Bohan of Portland, Me. The Rev. Samuel S. Rodman 3d performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Milton.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: UPPER WEST SIDE

title: Heartening Signs for Specialty M.D.'s
description: THE message for young doctors seeking jobs in highly paid specialties has been clear for some time: don't bother.

title: Commentators and Competitors Sap the Spirit of the Games
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Susan Shapiro and Charlie Rubin
description: NO one was surprised that Susan Shapiro, a freelance writer, walked down the aisle in black. She always wears black. She would wear black on a tennis court except that she is not athletic. In fact, when she met Charlie Rubin, she liked him right away, in part because it was clear that he would never ask her to go camping.

title: Once Again, Legislature Meddles With Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Those Zany Russians and Their Talking Dogs
description: AFTER a year filled with war and the tensest election this country has ever endured, life in Russia is finally becoming normal again: plagues, bizarre acts of human savagery and magnificent visions of glowing creatures from other planets have edged back into the headlines.

title: For Cuban Veteran, Just Thought of Pro Career Brings Tears
description: The stress and sacrifice of long-term devotion to the Cuban sports machine caught up with one of its star female athletes this afternoon, moments after she won a gold medal, the highest achievement available to an athlete of that Communist country.

title: Rebecca Stetson, Jonathan Werner
description: Rebecca Anne Stetson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Stetson of Hooksett, N.H., was married yesterday to Jonathan Richard Werner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Werner of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Christopher J. Emerson performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Manchester, N.H.

title: At a Glance, A Computer Comes Alive
description: Boston College researchers have found a way to unleash the expressive powers of people who cannot speak or use their lumbs. Their system allows individuals -- for example, children with cerebral palsy -- to move a cursor on a computer screen by moving their eyes.

title: Prince Edward Island Idyll
description: IN early June, I sat in a field of daisies on the north side of Prince Edward Island, looking way below to the village of French River, cupped in rounded hills and almost perfectly reflected in a glistening finger of New London Bay. Nothing moved or marred the lovely picture, which deserved the legend ''All's right with the world.''

title: Boxing's Big Need: Spray or Roll-On
description: EVEN in the Olympics, if not especially in the Olympics, boxing always seems to need a deodorant.

title: Maria T. Heidcamp, Steven R. Kopits
description: Maria Teresa Heidcamp, an adviser to the Hungarian Ministry of Labor, was married yesterday to Steven Richard Kopits, a management consultant in Hungary. The Very Rev. Joseph P. O'Brien performed the ceremony at St. Cecilia's Church in Englewood, N.J.

title: A GOOD NEWS/BAD NEWS AIDS JOKE
description: Whom does Larry Kramer think he's fooling when he writes that he finds the fact that Burroughs Wellcome manufactures both amyl nitrate and AZT ''a bitter paradox,'' saying, ''the company that made money by 'enabling' promiscuity, as it were, is now making a fortune by trying to stem its aftermath''?

title: Flat Against the Rules
description: MANET'S MODERNISM Or, The Face of Painting in the 1860s.By Michael Fried.Illustrated. 647 pp. Chicago:The University of Chicago Press. $50.

title: A Tale of Federal Dollars at Work
description: TWO and a half years ago, when the Federal Government announced that 100 cities would receive $3 million Enterprise Community grants with which to create jobs in poor neighborhoods, Bridgeport and New Haven were among the recipients.

title: Finding a Niche on Broadway -- on the Sidewalk
description: ''Squatters'' are laying claim to the first two rows of the hit Broadway musical ''Rent.''

title: Jonathan Fried, Sharon Greenberger
description: Sharon Lee Greenberger, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norton Greenberger of Mission Hills, Kan., is to be married today to Jonathan Louis Fried, a son of Janice C. Fried of Brooklyn and Justice Bernard J. Fried of Manhattan. Rabbi Morris Margolies is to perform the ceremony at the Ritz-Carlton in Kansas City, Mo.

title: Farmers Sue, Saying Weevil Spray Killed Profits, Too
description: It is an average cotton crop, not a great one, but Clifford Smith will take it. Last year, Mr. Smith, the owner of the Los Coyotes Gin, ginned just 354 bales, or about 177,000 pounds, of cotton. This year, he expects to process 6,000 bales, or about 3 million pounds, and he plans to keep his gin running day and night for another three weeks.

title: Britain Carries Out A Destruction of Embryos
description: Anti-abortion groups expressed outrage and the Vatican called it a ''pre-natal massacre'' when Britain scheduled the destruction of more than 3,000 frozen human embryos -- four-cell organisms fertilized in vitro that had waited in vain for five years for implantation in a human womb. But British clinics went ahead as scheduled last week in compliance with a law stipulating that unclaimed human embryos cannot be stored for more than five years.

title: Olympic Final Count: 1 Gold, 2 Bronzes
description: IT was quite an Olympics for 18-year-old Cristina Teuscher of New Rochelle.

title: Sparta Without the Spartans
description: FOR many Englishmen of my background, Sparta isn't merely the city that defeated Athens in the Peloponnesian War 2,400 years ago. It is a living memory. We, too, were separated from our mothers at age 7 and dispatched to austere academies to be trained to be men or, rather, Men. We too were placed in the charge of bullying prefects, made to play ferocious games and fed the counterpart of the food that provoked an ancient Athenian wit to remark that he knew why Spartans were eager to die in battle. That way, they could escape the black soup their cooks made from pigs' blood.

title: Suburban Odyssey
description: MEADOWLANDSBy Louise Gluck.61 pp. Hopewell, N.J.:The Ecco Press. $22.

title: Amy Freedman, Evan Lieberman
description: Amy Margaret Freedman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Freedman of Larchmont, N.Y., was married last evening to Evan Scott Lieberman, a son of Alvin Lieberman and Dr. Janice Lieberman, both of New York. Rabbi Noah Kitty performed the ceremony at the bride's family's farm in Saxtons River, Vt.

title: In Georgia, Candidates Are Second
description: Russell K. Paul, the chairman of the Georgia Republican Party, has a recommendation for the candidates competing in runoff elections here on Tuesday.

description: The interview with Dr. Harold S. Koplewicz on the subject of prescribing Ritalin and Prozac to children did not include the following issues.

description: The pitch is simple: Want a bank in the neighborhood? Sign below.

description: To the Editor:

title: On Each Palette, a Choice of Political Colors
description: IN 1985, THERE WERE 15 galleries in Taipei; now there are more than 200. Most sell decorative oil paintings in a kitschy Impressionist style for bourgeois decorating, but a good number of more serious places sell engaged contemporary work in various so-called Western and Chinese and nativist Taiwanese styles.

title: To Punish Colombia, U.S. May Revoke Air Route
description: Avianca, the Colombian airline whose owner is among a handful of major business figures who have supported President Ernesto Samper as the United States exerts pressure for his ouster, is facing the possible cancellation of its lucrative service to New York or Miami.

title: Amy E. Blatz, John G. Parsons
description: Amy Elizabeth Blatz, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Nils Blatz of Brooklyn Heights, was married on Friday evening to John Gavin Parsons, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Parsons of Sea Cliff, L.I. Bishop Herbert G. Thompson Jr. of Southern Ohio performed the Episcopal ceremony at Grace Church Brooklyn Heights.

title: 2 Golds In Javelin. Now Comes Baseball.
description: Jan Zelezny showed tonight that his arm is unique, becoming the first man in 72 years to win consecutive Olympic gold medals in the javelin. Now he's going to show the Atlanta Braves how hard he can throw.

title: A Popular Ticket: Playing for Charity
description: AFTER a daylong rain drenched the golf course at the Woodway Country Club in Darien on June 3, more than a few people called Sister Carol Ann, a Benedictine nun, the following day to express their regrets. Sister Carol Ann is the principal of the Villa Maria Education Center in Stamford, and her annual fund-raising golf and tennis tournament was scheduled for that rainy day. Surely, the callers thought, the fourth annual Villa Maria Golf and Tennis Classic had been washed out.

title: B&B's in France
description: To the Editor: I, too, have fond memories of places in France and Italy similar to those written about by Ms. Chatfield-Taylor. What propels us to travel is the quest to capture the breadth and soul of a village, town, city or country.

title: Careful: Ugly Bugs Can Grow Up to Save a Garden
description: The epiphany on insects came during a bud-pinching session in the chrysanthemum bed one afternoon in early summer. The mums were doing reasonably well, though plagued by aphids and some sort of unknown ugly insect that was slow-moving and easy to squish.

title: Crime
description: If the opening scenes of Patricia Cornwell's CAUSE OF DEATH (Putnam, $25.95) don't grab you, then you're a bigger stiff than the corpse on Dr. Kay Scarpetta's morgue slab. Scarpetta, the Chief Medical Examiner for the state of Virginia, suits up and dives into frigid waters to bring up the dead man, a reporter for The Associated Press who was snooping around a decommissioned ship in the Norfolk Navy Yard. After conducting a lovingly detailed autopsy that reveals a peculiar nature of death, Scarpetta is targeted by a neo-fascist cult on an unholy mission to take over the world and ''to kill and maim, frighten, brainwash and torture'' all nonbelievers.

title: Suffolk Coroner Is Thrust Into Spotlight
description: IN his 18 months as Suffolk County Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Charles V. Wetli had attracted scant attention as his office went about its grim business of performing routine autopsies and assisting the police in criminal investigations.

title: About That Uniform
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Diving Shop Moves Closer to the Market

title: Scalping: Gritty Hand Of a Not-So-Free Market
description: WHEN Hootie and the Blowfish step onto the stage tonight at the Jones Beach amphitheater on Long Island, those in the first 10 rows may be tempted to give a standing ovation before the music starts.

title: Elena Sheppa, Parker McComas
description: Elena Sheppa and Parker McComas were married yesterday on Fire Island in the Church at Point O'Woods, L.I. The Rev. Martin Copenhaver, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: When Drugs Were Dealt, Neighborhood Did React
description: To the Editor:

title: Letting Words Stir Oceans of Thoughts
description: SCHOOL was out, the sun shone hot and swimming pools beckoned, but 30 children chose instead to spend their summer mornings reading here at the Learning Institute, a book-centered day camp for youngsters in kindergarten through second grade. The three-week, nonprofit program took place in two colorful classrooms in the Asbury Church, which rented out the space.

title: Design for Living
description: DARWIN'S BLACK BOXThe Biochemical Challenge to Evolution.By Michael J. Behe.Illustrated. 307 pp. New York:The Free Press. $25.

title: Trouble Aside, Arts Council Hands Out $17 Million
description: The New Jersey Council on the Arts, which has been forced to reduce its staff and budget in recent years and has temporarily curtailed some grant programs for a variety of reasons, awarded more than $17 million in grants to arts organizations throughout the state last week, including distribution of the final $8 million from a 1987 bond act.

title: An Author, a Book And Life in Darien
description: ORDINARILY, a novel about the goings on in a mental institution is not what one would snap up for a good read at the beach. But ''Life in the Rainbow,'' Richard Horan's first published novel, elicited such howls of laughter from the prospective publisher that it has not only made it into print, but also received glowing reviews.

title: Sticky, Gritty And Savvy
description: I'VE never met a child who didn't love a movie at a premiere,'' Peggy Siegal said on Tuesday at the ''Matilda'' party, at Circo on West 55th Street. ''It's a party, and children get it.''

title: Ilyssa S. Cohen, Steven E. Fox
description: Ilyssa Sue Cohen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack P. Cohen of Freehold, N.J., is to be married today to Steven E. Fox, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Fox of Saddle Brook, N.J. Cantor Wayne Siet is to officiate at the Marlboro (N.J.) Jewish Center.

title: Heather Collins, James Raymond
description: Heather Rutledge Collins, a daughter of Cecily Megrue of New Cannan, Conn., and Kenneth B. Collins of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday to James William Raymond, a son of Sheila and George Raymond of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Harold E. Masback 3d, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony with the Rev. Dariusz J. Zielonka, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. Michael's Lutheran Church in New Cannan.

title: Johnson's Plans: Endorse, Run Even Faster
description: His competition is finished, the Wheaties deal is done and Michael Johnson is free to put his feet up and reflect on his stunning performance here.

title: Much Ado About Budgeting
description: REMEMBER the scene in ''Hamlet'' in which Polonius, the old-fogey adviser, gives a windy lecture to his departing son, Laertes? ''Neither a borrower nor a lender be,'' he counsels at one point; it's the sole financial tip in the speech, and it's probably sufficient, given the more pressing problems of the young adults at Elsinore.

title: Opponents of Kmart Want Balanced Growth
description: To the Editor:

title: In Harrison It Is, Yes, a Grill and Bar
description: TRINITY'S deliberate inversion of the expected ''bar and grill'' points to a fresh take on this old neighborhood watering hole. Laura Ashley meets English tavern here, and the resulting decor of this union is both striking and new. Sunny island colors -- lime, yellow tempered by brushes of ochre -- distressed oak flooring, touches of blue glass and airy double-story ceilings have no trouble holding their own against the dark woods of beams, occasional cabinetry, tall wainscoting and a beauty of a long, carved bar. In the windows, greenery and rolled quilts held by ribbons tied with studied carelessness block the sun.

title: Send In The Script Doctors
description: Bob Dole, take heart. It may not be too late.

title: Dr. Richard Ebert, 83, Medical Educator
description: Dr. Richard Vincent Ebert, a specialist in heart and lung disease who led the medical faculties at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences and at the University of Minnesota, died on July 22 at his lake-side cabin in Cornucopia, Wis. He was 83 and lived in Little Rock.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: CHARLOTTE BRONTe: A Passionate Life

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 3/ A $285,000 award has forced Rebecca Goldstein, a novelist, to take a closer look at her family's finances and its debts. By Sana Siwolop.

title: Honoring the Craft Tradition In Litchfield County
description: LITCHFIELD COUNTY'S character, molded by artists and craftsmen since its settlement in the early 18th century, is reflected in the collections of the Litchfield Historical Society. Now a new generation of craftsmanship is addressed in an exhibition on display through Nov. 3.

title: Ann O. Portell, M. S. McGeehan
description: Ann Olivier Portell, the daughter of Jean and Dr. Josep Portell of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Michael Scott McGeehan, a son of Marianne and Jerry McGeehan of Lehighton, Pa. The Rev. Edmund M. O'Brien performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Lakeville, Conn.

title: A Season for Toadstools, by Whatever Name
description: A LOT of rain has fallen so far this year, meaning plant growth in many places has been rather astounding. Impatiens are gigantic. Lawns are lush and velvety green. Beans and onions are bulging.

title: In Hawaii, Flora Fights For Its Turf
description: Something is wrong with this picture of emerald lawns so green that they glow, of shrubs with leaves big as cafeteria trays, of blossoms that wink everywhere in candy-corn colors and waterfalls that spout from great nests of hibiscus.

title: Area Seeks a New Partner
description: If the residents of Prospect Heights had their way, the nearest station house would send officers to answer their calls for help, and their concerns would be heard by the community board that covers Park Slope, their trendier neighbor across Flatbush Avenue.

title: Two Venerable Cubans Provide Day's Only Punch
description: Ariel Hernandez, who has the rhythm of a salsa dancer, can still move. Felix Savon, more accurate than Nostradamus, can still stick.

title: Baltimore Embraces the N.F.L.'s Return, and Ravens Win
description: Paul Weisengoff drove nearly three hours with family and friends from Ocean City, Md., and sat under a tree near Memorial Stadium sipping a cold drink and surveying the sights. Never mind that kickoff, the first for the Baltimore Ravens, was more than six hours away.

title: Ms. Brotspies, Mr. Gersh
description: Michelle Lauren Brotspies, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert V. Brotspies of Edison, N.J., is to be married today to Kenneth Steven Gersh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Barry Gersh of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Henry M. Weiner is to perform the ceremony at the Grand Marquis, a reception hall in Old Bridge, N.J.

description: Community Board 9 won a turf battle of sorts last week at Riverbank State Park after a major concessionaire lost four of its six licenses.

description: ''The Art of Illustration''

title: Is That Really Tracy Chapman Smiling?
description: FROM TINA TURNER TO KISS, pop music loves a second coming. And none has been more sudden or surprising than the re-emergence of the once dour Tracy Chapman, whose aptly titled fourth album, ''New Beginning,'' has become a platinum-plus top 10 hit. It's success is driven by a song called ''Give Me One Reason,'' a sultry blues shuffle that she wrote 10 years ago but that sounds nothing like the protest folk that made her famous in the late 80's.

title: Rebecca C. Stiritz, John M. Daly
description: Rebecca Claire Stiritz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Stiritz of St. Louis, was married there yesterday to John Michael Daly, a son of Mrs. William J. Daly of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Daly. The Rev. William North, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Michael and St. George. Msgr. Jerome Wilkerson took part in the ceremony.

title: B&B's in France
description: To the Editor: French bed-and-breakfasts are indeed wonderful. They are usually called gites, and there is a vast network of these accommodations, most considerably less expensive than those in the article.

title: Not All Irish Eyes Are Smiling
description: The ancient Celts, a brave and fierce tribe, had only one fear: that the sky would fall on their heads. Today, Irish men and women watching the Atlanta Olympics know the feeling.

title: THE CYBER-MAXIMS OF ESTHER DYSON
description: If Esther Dyson's dictum ''the good writers will get sponsored'' is to be taken seriously, then who defines ''good'' (''The Cyber-Maxims of Esther Dyson,'' by Claudia Dreifus, July 7)? Or does she mean that only commercially successful authors, artists, composers need apply? One can imagine James Joyce approaching a Fortune 500 company:

title: Gardens Succeed In Very Sandy Soil
description: NOBODY can count the grains of sand on Fire Island, and that is good, because most people think that not much can grow beyond weeds and eelgrass.

title: Following the Flow of America's Narrative
description: MOST AMERICANS KNOW THE STIRRING tale of Teddy Roosevelt's ride up San Juan Hill during the Spanish-American War. If ever an event deserved the phrase ''defining moment,'' this was it: the wild charge that propelled Roosevelt into the headlines and made him Presidential material.

description: To the Sports Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Religion in Politics Hits a Speed Bump
description: The Christian Coalition still plans to pass out an estimated 45 million voter guides around the country this year to remind religious conservatives which candidates are on the right side of the issues. But the coalition may find some churches reluctant to help. The bipartisan Federal Election Commission last week sued the coalition, arguing that through the guides and other activities, it had illegally shed its nonpartisan posture to help Republicans campaign -- including former President George Bush, Speaker Newt Gingrich, Senator Jesse Helms and Oliver L. North.

title: Ms. Reinhardt And Mr. Noe
description: Elizabeth Hope Reinhardt, a daughter of Ralph and Gloria Reinhardt of Paramus, N.J., is to be married today to Christopher Alphonse Noe, the son of Alphonse and Judith Noe of Boston. The Rev. Gerard Graziano, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi H. Philip Berkowitz is to participate in the service.

description: JULIAN SCHNABEL was the director. But PEGGY SIEGAL, the publicist, seemed to be in charge.

description: To the Editor:

title: 33 Renoirs Go on View In Williamstown, Mass.
description: America's enthusiasm for the paintings of the French Impressionist Pierre-Auguste Renoir -- and, in particular, the unquenchable desire of two collectors to own his works -- is the subject of ''A Passion for Renoir: Sterling and Francine Clark Collect, 1916-51,'' at the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass. Running to Jan. 5, the exhibition also marks the opening of the museum's new galleries for temporary exhibitions, part of a 12,000-square-foot addition designed by Ann Beha Associates, Architects, of Boston.

title: Policing of Pregnancies Won't Protect Children
description: To the Editor:

title: After the Metrocard: A Bit of Plastic For Parking Meters
description: It's a typical scene: New Yorkers rummaging through pockets looking for change to feed a parking meter.

title: Blond, Bouncy and Feeling the Burn
description: SO you want to get in shape. You'd like to look a little better than hilarious in that bathing suit. You want to stop hating that fat person (whoever that is) in the mirror staring back at you. And sneering.

title: Hope for Clearing a Blight
description: To local business leaders, the vacant Sahara Hotel on Third Avenue and 14th Street has long been a blight, keeping the bloom of Union Square's economic revival from reaching this down-and-out strip two blocks to the east.

title: Prospect of Incinerators' Return Has Neighborhood Uneasy
description: Two years ago, a coalition of Mott Haven residents appeared to be gaining some success in their drive to shut down two three-story medical waste incinerators at 138th Street and Locust Avenue. The incinerators' 80-foot smokestacks, the coalition said, spewed high levels of carbon monoxide and were worsening health problems in the area. State inspectors agreed and the incinerators were temporarily shut down.

title: That Willinger Woman
description: THE SLOW, SENSUAL PACE OF LIFE IN THE Italian countryside has kept Faith Willinger there, eating the pasta and tasting the olive oil, for nearly 25 years. But somehow, the Italian temperament has eluded her. Willinger, large and irrepressible, does not amble through life; she charges -- arms open, nostrils quivering, tongue itching to taste.

title: The Limits of Authority
description: SCIENCE AND DISSENT IN POST-MAO CHINA

title: He Feels Your Pain
description: TO look at Dr. Noel Nowicki, or sit in his office at the Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation here, you wouldn't think he was anything other than an average, ordinary M.D. The standard-issue stethoscope is draped casually around his neck, his white jacket has his name embroidered over the left pocket, and old issues of The New England Journal of Medicine stand spine to spine on a plain bookshelf.

title: Greek Lawyer Pleased To Defend Serb Leader
description: When criminal lawyers are asked how they can represent unsavory clients, they often say that everyone has the right to counsel.

title: 'Summer in America' Gathers 21 Photographic Exhibitors
description: IT is a year and a half since Candace Perich established her photography gallery on Catoonah Street, in Ridgefield, and about two months since she moved it across the border, to Katonah Avenue, here.

title: How to Get the Better of a Wicked Headmistress
description: Matilda

title: Four Guidebooks and a Question
description: ONCE it was Baedeker or nothing. Now a slew of guidebooks compete for the privilege of answering the traveler's every question. Usually I take along only one book, but for a recent family trip to northern Italy I packed four: Fodor's for the basics, Michelin for authoritative facts and maps, and, just in case my teen-age children should awaken from their adolescent coma, the more thorough Cadogan's ''Tuscany and Umbria'' and ''Cento Citta'' by Paul Hofmann. It was an illuminating experience -- but less for what we learned about Italy than for what was revealed about the books. With guidebooks as with cooks, it seems, it's possible to have too many.

title: Facing Up To the Worst At T.W.A.
description: IT was the most horrible telephone call I've ever received. It woke me from a deep sleep just before 2:30 A.M. in London, where I was on a business trip.

title: Salvadoran War Zone to Get New Life as Park
description: Some of the heaviest fighting in this country's 12-year civil war took place on the slopes of the volcano that gives this area its name. Even today, more than four years after the war ended, bomb craters, deforested patches, man-made caves and ruins scar its flanks.

title: Joint 3-Town Panel on Trump's Project Protested
description: WHEN Donald J. Trump purchased Seven Springs last year for $7.5 million, he announced his intention to transform the 200-acre estate into a ''world-class'' country club and 15 mansions.

title: Tara L. Cohen, David Friedman
description: Tara Leigh Cohen, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Michael H. Cohen of Tarrytown, N.Y., was married last evening to David Marc Friedman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Friedman of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi David Holtz performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest country club in Alpine, N.J.

title: THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: Minnesota

title: Looking for Hudsontown? Take a Trip Down Memory Lane
description: Bob Leach of Jersey City is a writer of folk stories. His tales, rooted in the neighborhood culture of his childhood in the 1930's and 40's, revolve around the rough lives of saloonkeepers, hobos and workingmen. Like the old-time barroom poets in many of his stories, he reads his works aloud in local saloons.

title: Bombed Church Is Resurrected in Rome as Testament to Faith
description: The church of San Giorgio in Velabro is a Roman testament to faith. It started with the walls of an ancient Roman dwelling, columns and an apse were added in late antiquity, and in the 13th century a wealthy deacon added a glorious columned porch.

title: Democrats Are Fat, Happy and Adrift . . .
description: NOT since, well, the election of Bill Clinton in 1992 have Democrats sounded so triumphant. If Mr. Clinton maintains his lead in the polls, they note with a touch of braggadocio, he will be the first Democrat since Franklin D. Roosevelt to be elected to a second full term. Party leaders no longer dismiss out of hand talk that maybe, just maybe, Democrats will retake Congress in November.

title: Canada Shocks U.S. (Minus Lewis) in Relay
description: The United States left Carl Lewis off the Olympic 4x100-meter relay tonight and missed his vast international experience, losing the race for the first time except by disqualification.

title: Two Malaria Cases Leave Florida Health Officials With a Puzzle
description: Before July, Florida officials knew of only one person in the last 50 years who had contracted malaria while in the state. But last month, two men were treated for the disease in Palm Beach County, leading to an effort to identify the source of the infection and to extinguish it.

title: At the Casinos

title: Even Swimming Pig Can't Save Theme Park

In the interests of ecology and to staunch a hemorrhage of red ink, Southwest Texas State University in San Marcos has closed Aquarena Springs, a theme park it bought in 1994 for $7 million. The star attraction at the park was Ralph, who became a Texas icon by oinking exuberantly as he flung himself into a pond.

title: Interest on A Security Deposit
description: Q I live in a rent-stabilized building. As required by law, the landlord gets 1 percentage point of the security deposit interest as an administration fee. The bank represents it as an ''early withdrawal penalty'' on the IRS Form 1099 sent to me annually. Is the bank correct? Shouldn't the landlord be responsible for the income tax on the 1 percent interest he gets, while I pay the tax on the remainder of the interest? . . . Irving Slayton, Brooklyn.

title: New Home, Old Story
description: For 25 years, everywhere Robert L. Vesco has gone, accusations of fraud and chicanery have followed. After having fled the United States to avoid arrest for the looting of $224 million from a mutual fund, and after having then worn out his welcome in Costa Rica and the Bahamas, the fugitive financier last week found himself in a Havana courtroom, facing charges that he tried to hoodwink investors in an unproven miracle drug called TX. Mr. Vesco has lived since the early 1980's in Cuba, where, American officials say, he has helped Fidel Castro's Government circumvent the American economic embargo and has aided the Medellin drug cartel in obtaining an air route over the island.

description: MISSING LINKS

title: 'The Mechanic From Hell'
description: CAROL SCHNABEL'S grandmother had just died, and Ms. Schnabel, a handweaver from Vermont, was near the end of the long drive down to New York City for the funeral when she heard BeDUMM, BeDUMM, the unsettling sound of the wheels of her Saab 9000 CS hitting a pothole on the Cross Bronx Expressway. The entrails of her car clattered faintly and the steering went awry. It was a Saturday in March 1994 and Ms. Schnabel could not scare up an authorized Saab dealer, so she thumbed through the Yellow Pages in search of a mechanic and settled on a company listed as ''AAA Midtown,'' on West 50th Street. They sent a tow truck right away.

title: Just Kidding

title: The Segregated Reunions Of an Integrated School
description: When the Petersburg High School Class of 1971 holds its 25th reunion later this month, each reveler will get a T-shirt that reads, ''Back Together Again.'' The shirt is only half true.

title: A Good Outcome From a Bad Law
description: Federal District Judge Harold Baer Jr. recently lifted the detailed court-ordered decrees that long governed living conditions in New York City's jails. That is essentially the right outcome. Though judicial intervention was wholly appropriate in the 1970's, jail conditions have improved to the point where it no longer makes sense to administer the system under the terms of 20-year-old consent decrees.

title: Sending a Child Alone on Flights
description: IT'S the season of the child traveling alone: to go to camp or to visit grandparents, a divorced parent, or friends. The Air Transport Association estimates that 20,000 unaccompanied minors, that is, children 11 or under, take airplane trips daily, an average of one per flight. Over holidays and in the summer, you can often see more than one solo child on a flight; the airlines frequently seat them together for convenience and, presumably, companionship.

description: Earlier in the day, Continentalvictory set the stage. Later in the day, she stole the show.

description: It may not be high art, but the Jets were unwilling to display a work in progress without a proper frame tonight.

title: Hoopla With Dark Undertones
description: Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, the famed German soprano, was always good at planning. Her celebrated lieder recitals were models of preparation and balance, her forays onto the opera stage perfectly suited to her temperament and geared never to strain her voice. Even after her retirement, in 1979, capping an international career that lasted more than 30 years, Ms. Schwarzkopf kept control not only over her life but over her legacy as well.

title: Forget Keith Richards. Meet Daphne Hellman.
description: DAPHNE HELLMAN wants a gig. Not that she lacks opportunities to play her eclectic mix of baroque, country-western and pop ballads in public. On any given day, Ms. Hellman, who is 80, can be found plucking one of her seven gilded harps at the Mansfield Hotel, at a local hospital or, if a friend is around to carry her 85-pound instrument, on a subway platform under Bloomingdale's.

title: Revamping Welfare, Rebuilding Lives
description: Last week's historic action to dismantle the Federal welfare system could not have come too soon. A program that began with the best of intentions -- providing help for families who lost their primary source of income through no fault of their own -- has contributed to the breakdown of the family and stymied efforts at urban revitalization. The new law provides the best chance in decades to improve the lot of cities and the people who live in them.

title: Backward and Forward On Nuclear Tests
description: The Clinton Administration, with an eye on November, wanted a glittering signing ceremony in September for a treaty to end nuclear weapons testing worldwide. But Washington had not reckoned on the tenacity of India. India is unwilling to accept a treaty that does not set a timetable for the destruction of existing weapons; as now written the pact requires the ratification of all eight nations capable of making weapons before it can go into force, and India is vowing to block consensus and prevent the accord from going to the General Assembly for signing. Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States are the five acknowledged nuclear weapons powers; India, Israel and Pakistan are assumed to have clandestine programs.

title: Baaad Canadians
description: ''They know what they're doing,'' says Anne McCall-Simms, manager of the Skydome Hotel, the $350 accommodations built inside the Toronto Blue Jays' stadium. They are couples who happily fornicate during games with the curtains open. Though such incidents are rare -- three since the hotel opened in 1990 -- the latest occurred on Mother's Day, and Howard Starkman, a Jays spokesman, says, ''It was quite prolonged.'' Fan reaction? ''A roar. Nobody asked for a refund.'' By now the problem is a treasured local oddity, but hotel officials, fed up, are drafting a new check-in warning that promises speedy ejection of play pals. ''We're a family hotel,'' says McCall-Simms.

Not only was the body language amusing, but I recalled Bay Buchanan's brother, Pat, making fun of the ''tassel-loafered'' folks in Government. Lo and behold, what was the dapper Ralph Reed wearing if not tasseled loafers.

description: Kristin Birch Holzer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Holzer of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Matthew Augustus Fischer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William Fischer of Amherst, N.Y. The Rev. Sue Anne Morrow, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony in the Princeton University Chapel.

title: For Love of the Waterside Landscape
description: TODAY, high-speed arteries like the Turnpike and the Garden State Parkway dominate transporation in New Jersey, but in times past, people and goods moved through the state on the quieter, gentler capillaries of its rivers and canals. Although waterways lost their economic importance as barges gave way to tractor-trailers, they are reviving and thriving as backdrops for recreation, thanks to projects like the Delaware and Raritan Greenway.

title: Mahogany Hall Makes His Mark in Whitney
description: The filly star Serena's Song ran another memorable race against colts today and outran seven of them in the Whitney Handicap at Saratoga. But she could not outrun the eighth, a 5-year-old horse named Mahogany Hall, who charged from deep in the pack to snatch the race in the final 50 yards.

title: So, You Want to Hold an Olympics
description: SOMEWHERE between the constant carping of 30,000 journalists from around the world, bus drivers afraid to drive their buses on the freeway and the pipe bomb at Centennial Park, the same thought occurred to a lot of Atlantans early last week -- what have we got ourselves into?

title: All of a Sudden, Eugene O'Neill Is Everywhere
description: ON THE SMALL AUDITORIUM stage of Provincetown High School, the director Jose Quintero was holding a table of actors rapt. Mr. Quintero is 71 and, after a bout with throat cancer, speaks with a vibration-amplifying device that resembles a microphone pressed to his larynx.

description: Last month, the Virginia Military Institute -- the final holdout in the war over admitting women to military colleges -- caved and decided to admit women starting next year. Of course, this also means ''equal access'' to hazing rituals that have customarily been a pox on men. Is it worth it? Below, some torture highlights:

title: Europeans Leave the World in Their Wake
description: European boats took 17 of 18 medals in Olympic canoe and kayak sprints today, but there was little time for the victors to celebrate: Most will be back in action Sunday in other finals.

title: In Sea Bright, Free Sand and a Free Spirit
description: LOCKS of white hair tousled by wind, Charles Rooney clambers up a ladder to the top of the 15-foot wall of boulders that borders the beach in Sea Bright. Then he bellows: ''Look at that! There's enough beach for everybody! You can't expect to get all this free sand and then keep outsiders away. They're paying for it!''

title: The Giants Line Up Vulnerable To the Blitz
description: The first quarter against Jacksonville came and went, and some of the Giants' offensive linemen looked like they had just been through a small war. The talented but young starters on the line were not quite prepared for what was hitting them, literally and figuratively. Blitz after blitz after blitz came from the Jaguars. There was hardly time for the Giants to catch their breath.

title: Tony and Maria Sing, but the Star Is in the Pit

In Theaterfest's soul-satisfying production, it is the musical message of ''West Side Story'' that transmits the essential remembered sensations of the Broadway musical at its musical best.

But there are many coastal states that do not regularly monitor surf pollution, and millions of tourists may be unaware of whether it is safe to swim at any given time or place.

title: Arafat's Heirs
description: LIKE MANY OF HIS COLLEAGUES IN THE NEW PALESTINIAN LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL, AHMAD el-Diek came into politics the hard way. The elegant, soft-spoken son of a teacher, Diek preferred philosophy in school and never read a newspaper before he was arrested and thrown into an Israeli jail. Now, back in his home village of Salfit in the West Bank, Diek, 36, has plunged wholeheartedly into his new role as a member of the first elected legislature in Palestinian history. He speaks without bravado or bitterness of his years of ''active struggle.'' Prisons and exile were all just part of growing up under Israeli occupation. The reason he and others of his generation speak of the struggle now is that they are convinced that it prepared them to succeed Yasir Arafat, 67, and the other expatriate nationalists of the old Palestine Liberation Organization as leaders of the new Palestine.

title: These Master Gardeners Have Solutions (and Sympathy) for All Seasons
description: Some questions could come straight from the mailboxes of advice columnists. There was the woman who inadvertently wove a wreath with poison ivy, the one who brought a live black widow spider in for identification, and the man who wanted to find out how to kill his neighbor's tree.

description: TSHIMANGA BIAKABUTUKA, the first-round draft choice of the Carolina Panthers, says he wants to meet with the team's general manager to discuss ending his two-week holdout. Biakabutuka has written to BILL POLIAN, inviting him to call and discuss the negotiations. ''I do want to speak to him because I am the person involved,'' Biakabutuka told The Charlotte Observer. (AP)

description: In the wilds of the Yukon and northern British Columbia, the dominant mammals have long been bears and humans -- now roaming the bush in about equal numbers.
