Commercial Intertech, a maker of hydraulic components that is based in Youngstown, Ohio, has resisted repeated overtures from United Dominion, a maker of boilers, pumps and other equipment that is based in Charlotte, N.C.

title: Financial Arm Of G.E. to Buy Life Insurer for $1.8 Billion
description: The GE Capital Corporation announced an agreement yesterday to buy the First Colony Corporation for $1.8 billion in one of the largest deals ever in the life insurance industry.

title: AN ACQUISITION OF TRELLIS SOFTWARE IS PLANNED
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, the computer maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Trellis Software and Controls Inc., a closely held software company, for undisclosed terms. Trellis, based in Rochester Hills, Mich., develops motion-control software for the automotive, electronics and aerospace industries. As part of Hewlett-Packard, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., Trellis is to keep its name and stay in its current location.

title: Many Hits, Some Misses: The Post-Crash Web Rush
description: In the quest for information about the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, computer users have turned in record numbers to the global computer network, in particular, the World Wide Web.

title: Houses of Cyber-Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: Relatives of Victims Become Force for Change in Methods
description: They came from all over the United States and Europe. Some spoke English only haltingly. They were industry executives, lawyers and musicians. Hardly any had ever met a reporter.

title: It's Not a Pretty Movie (It Wasn't a Pretty War)
description: Images of drunken Bosnian Serb militiamen burning Muslim villages, killing elderly civilians and carting away truckloads of loot is not a version of the Bosnian war that has been acknowledged by many Serbs.

title: A U.S.-Japan Chip Industry Council (Or, Is It a Cartel?)
description: The new semiconductor agreement reached by the United States and Japan on Friday is supposed to end managed trade by governments. But will it give rise to a private cartel instead?

title: British Airways Net Is 11% Higher
description: British Airways said yesterday that strong demand and less discounting helped to increase profits in the first quarter 11 percent. The airline, which is planning an alliance with American Airlines, earned $:150 million, or $231 million, in its first quarter, compared with $:135 million a year earlier on sales of $:2.1 billion, up from $:1.9 billion.

title: Welfare Changes, While Big, Will Be Taking Shape Slowly
description: The welfare bill passed by Congress last week will eventually bring sweeping change to the nation's poor, but, in most states, it will probably not cause any sudden disruption. A little-noticed provision allows these states to continue operating the welfare programs they now have in place.

title: A Duo for the First Time, and Apparently Hitting It Off
description: Alvin Batiste, an underrecorded clarinet master, and Mark Whitfield, a precocious young guitarist, both live in Baton Rouge, La., and the elder musician has appeared on one of Mr. Whitfield's albums. But before Sunday, when they opened the Brooklyn Museum's ''Double Exposure'' series of four Sunday afternoon jazz-duet concerts, they had never played in duo before.

title: Visiting the Bronx When Hanging Out Meant Marbles
description: ''New York the Way It Was'' goes up to the Bronx tonight for an hour of affectionate reminiscing over living in proximity to the Bronx Zoo, Orchard Beach, the Loews Paradise and Yankee Stadium. But I can attest that most of the young Bronxite's long hours were spent hanging around the block or playing stickball or box ball or stoopball (Geraldine Ferraro says tonight it was remarkable what you could do with a Spalding, pronounced spal-DEEN) or potsy (hopscotch to the rest of the world) or contests involving immies (known as marbles in better neighborhoods) or cheese boxes or bottle caps, whose names, if they ever had any, I can't remember.

title: Eastern Europe's Ailing Press
description: When Russian television and newspapers hid Boris Yeltsin's health problems in the recent elections, it highlighted health problems of their own. Aware that a return to Communism might threaten their freedoms, journalists shamelessly plugged Mr. Yeltsin and ignored his Communist opponent. Unhappily, the deformed election coverage was not an exceptional case of bad journalism in the countries of the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. In many places the press is as distorted and shackled as it was under Communism.

title: At Hot Center of Debate On Global Warming
description: DR. BENJAMIN D. SANTER a shy, even-spoken, 41-year-old American climatologist who climbs mountains, runs marathons and enjoys a reputation for careful and scrupulous work -- is the chief author of what may be the most important finding of the decade in atmospheric science: that human activity is probably causing some measure of global climate change, as environmentalists have long assumed and skeptics have long denied.

title: British Drug Maker Expects Strong Half
description: Zeneca Group P.L.C., Britain's third-largest drug maker, is expected to post a 19 percent gain in first-half pretax profit on strong growth in new and existing products.

title: First Question for Steelers: Who Will Pass the Ball?
description: With under five minutes to play in last season's Super Bowl, the Pittsburgh Steelers were in the driver's seat, marching down the field for the go-ahead touchdown. The quarterback in that game, Neil O'Donnell, threw an interception that snuffed the drive and the Dallas Cowboys won, 27-17.

title: Hoover's Heirs
description: In a recent interview, President Clinton shared with us his dismay that nobody really knows how fast the economy can grow without inflation.

title: Jury Recommends Death For Killer of Polly Klaas
description: A jury today recommended the death penalty for the man who kidnapped 12-year-old Polly Klaas from a slumber party at her Northern California home in 1993 and murdered her near an abandoned lumber mill.

title: Silver Seeks Limit on Gifts To Committees In Transitions
description: Spurred by the secrecy surrounding Gov. George E. Pataki's inauguration and transition committees, the Speaker of the State Assembly today proposed a plan that would for the first time limit the size of donations made to such committees and require detailed public disclosure about their contributions and expenses.

title: New Mental Health Standard
description: The State Supreme Court made it tougher yesterday for courts to commit juveniles to mental hospitals against their will. While an adult cannot be involuntarily committed unless he is considered a danger to himself or others, previous rules allowed lower courts to commit children simply because they needed ''intensive psychiatric therapy.'' Yesterday's ruling, in a case involving a 15-year-old girl who attacked another youth with a box-cutter, raises the standard for committing children to the same ''dangerousness'' level as the standard for adults. ''Psychiatric commitment is an extreme and extraordinary measure,'' said Lily DeYoung of the State Public Defender's office. ''We need to make sure that it is used only as a last resort, and this ruling helps insure that.''

title: Howard: 2 Deals, 2 Teams, $200 Million
description: The battle for Juwan Howard's services took another turn yesterday, when the Washington Bullets signed Howard to a seven-year contract believed to be worth around $100 million.

title: A True Reform Party?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bilingual Americans Serve Global Markets
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Squeeze Some Joy Out of Trip
description: When you are constantly treading water, as the Yankees have been for most of the second half of the season, little things matter. The difference between the Yankees' reclining on their flight home tonight with a smile instead of a scowl was a ball that traveled 50 feet. Little things matter.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: 2 Killed and 2 Wounded in Mall Robbery
description: Two people were killed and two others were critically wounded yesterday as gunfire from a botched robbery rang through a shopping mall in southern New Jersey, sending shoppers and their children scurrying for cover.

title: American Radio To Acquire EZ
description: The American Radio Systems Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy EZ Communications Inc. for about $655 million in cash, stock and debt, which would make it the nation's largest radio broadcaster.

title: Strong Krona Hurts Profits at Electrolux
description: Electrolux A.B. of Sweden, Europe's largest appliance maker, said second-quarter pretax profits fell 14 percent. The company said that a stronger krona reduced the value of overseas sales in other currencies.

title: Citadel Suspends Coach
description: CHARLIE TAAFFE, the football coach at The Citadel, in Charleston, S.C., was suspended for the season yesterday after his second drunken-driving arrest in three years.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ford Reports Flat Sales, As Industry Hits Doldrums

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Connecticut Weekly's This Week column on Sunday about a concert by the Salt and Pepper Gospel Singers in New Haven at 6:30 P.M. Friday misstated the location. It will be at Amhryn Field, at the base of West Rock, not at Wooster Square Park.

title: Sweaters for a New Generation
description: The simple outfit of a sweater and pants is high fashion, thanks to the imprimaturs of designers like Calvin Klein and Jil Sander. And the latest news for sweaters is the V-neck, an alternative to the turtleneck, which has become a high-fashion staple in recent seasons.

title: OLYMPICS
description: In Atlanta, Some Whimsy for the Weary

title: The Measure of the Olympics
description: The Atlanta Olympics were shaken by terrorism, bedeviled by hucksterism and muddled by time-warp broadcasting, but they still provided triumphant displays of athletic achievement, some of it from unexpected performers.

title: 2 Reports Show More Strength in the Economy
description: The index of leading indicators, which is intended to predict business activity over the next half-year, advanced to the highest level on record in June, a sign the economy could be regaining momentum.

title: Smart Phone Partners Merge To Combat Cellular Giants
description: U.S. Order Inc., an electronic commerce company and maker of of so-called smart phones, said yesterday that it had agreed to merge with the Colonial Data Technologies Corporation to create a new company called the Tritech Corporation.

title: Death Penalty Asked for Korean Ex-Leader
description: South Korean prosecutors demanded today that former President Chun Doo Hwan be sentenced to death for his role in a military coup in 1979 and the massacre of pro-democracy protesters in the city of Kwangju in 1980.

title: Magic of Games Lifts And Reality Settles In
description: Dave White looked out at the midmorning desolation of Centennial Olympic Park with the not-quite-comprehending look of someone emerging from a storm cellar after a tornado.

title: REXENE REJECTS SWEETENED OFFER FROM HUNTSMAN
description: The Rexene Corporation said late yesterday that it had rejected a sweetened offer of $15 a share from the Huntsman Corporation because its board had decided the offer was not in the best interest of shareholders. The $281.6 million offer was the second Rexene has rejected from Huntsman. Jon Huntsman, the chairman and chief executive of his family owned Huntsman Corporation, said in a statement, ''The decision to reject the offer is clearly harmful to the best interests of Rexene shareholders.'' . But an analyst, Hal Granger of KDP Investment Advisors, said Huntsman was not likely to let Rexene, also a chemical and plastics company, go without a fight. Shares of Rexene have risen more than 50 percent since Huntsman first made its offer on July 19. The shares closed at $13.875 yesterday, up 12.5 cents, before the rejection was announced.

title: Maneuvering For Precision In New Census
description: THIS may strike some as premature, and it is one of those dry-as-toast topics that can send people searching for the sports section. But the time is at hand to decide exactly how the Census Bureau will calculate the United States population in 2000, under the Constitutional imperative of a national head count every 10 years. (Was that the riffling of newspaper pages we just heard?)

title: Executive Changes
description: BLOCKBUSTER ENTERTAINMENT, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a unit of Viacom Inc., promoted Thomas Byrne, its executive vice president for corporate development, to vice chairman. The company also promoted Adam Phillips, its senior vice president and general counsel, to executive vice president and Brian Woods, its senior vice president for marketing, to executive vice president and chief marketing officer.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the front page of Business Day yesterday, with an article about delays at Tele-TV, a television joint venture owned by Bell Atlantic, Nynex and Pacific Telesis, reversed the identities of two Tele-TV executives shown. David Grant was standing in the background, and Sandy Grushow was seated.

title: African Athletes Took Home More Than Olympic Medals
description: In recent years, the soccer world has watched with fascination as fleet-footed African stars have filled the ranks of many of Europe's top professional teams, leaving a question hanging in the air: how long will it take before African teams can compete consistently with the world's best?

title: Tadeus Reichstein, 99, Dies; Won Nobel for Cortisone Work
description: Dr. Tadeus Reichstein, a Swiss chemist who shared the Nobel Prize in medicine with two Americans for their work with cortisone, died Thursday at his home in Basel, Switzerland. He was 99.

title: Cleaning a Toxic Orchard
description: The scene was familiar: trucks hauling away tons of contaminated soil from the site of a new development. But the source of the pollution was not a defunct factory or an underground oil tank. It was an old apple orchard in Burlington Township. For the first time, the Department of Environmental Protection began yesterday supervising the cleanup of an agricultural toxic waste site. More than 28,000 cubic yards of dirt laced with arsenic and DDT used in pesticides are being removed from a lot next to the Sunset Ridge development and taken to the Burlington County landfill. Robert Van Fossen, assistant director of D.E.P.'s site remediation program, predicted that more farm-related contamination cleanups will follow.

title: Excerpts From Speech Outlining Dole's Economic and Tax Plans
description: Following are excerpts from remarks yesterday by Bob Dole in Chicago, as provided by the Federal Document Clearing House, a transcription service.

title: Jean Gerard, 58, Reagan Envoy Who Led U.S. to Leave Unesco
description: Jean Broward Shevlin Gerard, who as America's permanent representative at Unesco played a key role in President Reagan's decision to pull out of the agency in 1984, died of cancer at her home in Paris yesterday. She was 58.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Anheuser-Busch Companies, St. Louis, is selling $200 million of notes due in 2003 through Dillon, Read & Co. The noncallable notes carry an interest rate of 6.75 percent and are priced at par. The issue is rated A1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by Standard & Poor's.

title: In Honor of Hall of Famers, Sir Cat Triumphs
description: The Racing Hall of Fame opened its doors today to two premier jockeys of the past, Don Brumfield and George Barbee; a trainer who handled five champions, James Conway, and three renowned horses, Sunday Silence, Go for Wand and Sun Beau.

title: Earnings Up 30% At Rothschild Bank
description: N. M. Rothschild & Sons Ltd., the 186-year-old merchant bank, said pretax profit rose 30 percent in its latest fiscal year and reiterated that it would remain independent.

title: Texaco Places Account in Review
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it had placed in review its corporate advertising account, which has been handled by Bates USA in New York since late 1994. Billings were not disclosed.

title: A Suite With a View of the Web
description: THE popularity of plug-in modules for Web browsers like Netscape Navigator has led some pundits to conclude that we are finally well along the road to modular ''object-oriented'' software. Supposedly the Internet will soon be awash in single-purpose components that we will buy, rent or be permitted to use free of charge, though not necessarily free of advertising.

title: Dole Camp Accepts Uncompromising Abortion Plank
description: In the face of pressure from anti-abortion forces within the Republican Party, Bob Dole's strategists relented today and embraced a platform plank that not only continues to call for a constitutional amendment to outlaw all abortion but also makes no specific concession to party members on the opposing side of the issue.

title: Fashion Relearns Its Darwin: Be Adaptable or Be Extinct
description: Perhaps only a woman like Ivana Trump -- then wife of the Donald -- would have applauded when the Italian fashion house Gruppo GFT rolled out its first Emanuel collection five years ago. There were jackets and dresses in flamboyant French color mixes worthy of a Plaza Hotel couch, combinations of printed fabrics, brilliant gold buttons, and bodaciously feminine side-draped skirts.

title: The Democratic Tent
description: To the Editor:

title: Olympic Snapshots That Will Never Fade
description: I AM told that the next time I walk through the park, the acres of concrete will be replaced by grass and trees. There will be room to walk, time to reflect. The brand names of the corporate sponsors will blur, much like the world records set in swimming and track. The brilliant faces of children splashing in the fountains on sweltering afternoons during my walks from the main press center across the park to the World Congress Center or the Georgia Dome will remain.

title: Chess
description: The breeding grounds for future world title challengers are the prestigious tournaments on the circuit. And that makes the one in Dos Hermanas, Spain, in early June, special: the only one of the 10 top players in the world not participating was Anatoly Karpov, who was busy preparing for his championship match with Gata Kamsky. So far, Dos Hermanas is the strongest tourney of the year.

title: Huskey Hurts His Knee, Compounding Mets' Woes
description: It had already been a miserable night for the visiting Mets. Paul Wilson labored through another poor outing and the Mets' offense fizzled on a muggy night at Wrigley Field where ''A Celebration of the 1970's'' was the featured promotion.

title: The Los Angeles Times tries to attract readers and advertisers by leaving them hanging.
description: NEWSPAPERS sell advertising every day, but they advertise to promote themselves usually at specific strategic moments. To keep copies of Timeses and Newses, Posts, Heralds or Inquirers landing on front porches each morning or pulled from news vendors' stacks each day, newspapers rely most of the time on the quality in their pages and the habits of their readers.

title: DOLE OFFERS ECONOMIC PLAN CALLING FOR BROAD TAX CUT AIMED AT SPURRING GROWTH
description: Promising to ''finish the job Ronald Reagan started so brilliantly,'' Bob Dole today proposed a wide-ranging plan to spur the economy with $548 billion in tax cuts and a $500-per-child tax credit, all the while balancing the budget within five years.

title: Irsay Hospitalized
description: ROBERT IRSAY, owner of the Indianapolis Colts, has been hospitalized again, this time for pneumonia.

title: What A Dunce
description: It takes great self-confidence to write a newspaper column. Some might say it takes arrogance. Be that as it may, my willingness to pronounce on a great many matters of which I have little or no knowledge is one of my prime qualifications for this trade.

title: Now, Intense Scrutiny: Can This Plan Work?
description: Over the last few years political leaders of all stripes, Bob Dole foremost among them, have conditioned voters to see reducing the Federal budget deficit as Job 1 and to view with skepticism any promise of a free lunch.

title: Chief's Strategy for an Ailing Cruse Line
description: As the Queen Elizabeth 2 limped across the Atlantic in December 1994, plagued by exploding pipes and erupting toilets from an unfinished renovation, Peter Ward remembers feeling sorry for the world's most famous cruise liner -- but even sorrier that Cunard management allowed such an embarrassment to befall the crown jewel in its fleet.

title: A Second Team Raises Learning Curve
description: When Robert Yates says that his No. 28 Winston Cup team, with Ernie Irvan driving, is closer to his heart than his No. 88 team, with Dale Jarrett driving, it is not only candid, it is also literally true. On race day, Yates wears the uniform of Irvan's team, with his sponsor's name spread across his chest.

title: Pacificare Will Buy FHP, Its Health Care Rival
description: Hoping to cash in on the increasing number of Medicare recipients who are joining managed-care plans, Pacificare Health Systems Inc. announced yesterday that it would buy the FHP International Corporation for $35 a share -- $2.1 billion in cash and stock.

title: A Designer Mouse Joins the Quest To Combat a Rare Genetic Disease
description: A TEAM of scientists at the National Center for Human Genome Research and other institutions has used genetic engineering to create a new breed of mice remarkable not for their color or size, but for a peculiar defect. They have been bred to suffer one of the most unusual genetic diseases.

title: The Fastball Has Deserted Abbott, but Dignity Has Not
description: The baseball is helium in Jim Abbott's left hand it usually ends up in orbit. The former Yankee has his Olympic gold medal and his no-hitter, but his newest distinction is a dubious one: losing est pitcher in the major leagues.

title: Sandra I. Vreeland, Poetry Director, 38
description: Sandra Isham Vreeland, a poet who was the director of an AIDS poetry project for young people, died yesterday at her home in Bridgehampton, L.I. She was 38 and also had a residence in Manhattan.

title: People
description: Laura Levitan was named to the new post of senior vice president and client services director at Gaskell Associates, Westport, Conn. She had held a similar post at Clarion Marketing and Communications, Greenwich, Conn., a unit of the McManus Group.

title: Rising Health Costs Threaten Generous Benefits in Europe
description: Dr. Philippe Perez, a general practitioner in the Paris suburb of Thiais, used to think nothing of prescribing $500 worth of medicated salve a month for patients with painful herpes infection, because they would be almost completely reimbursed by the French national health insurance system.

title: Divorce Court System Encourages Delays
description: To the Editor:

title: Miami Cuts Del Rio
description: Calling it the most difficult roster decision of his career, Miami Dolphins Coach JIMMY JOHNSON released linebacker JACK DEL RIO yesterday.

title: Promising Less to the I.R.S.
description: Bob Dole's tax-cut plan, as analyzed through examples provided by Coopers & Lybrand, a major accounting firm, generally lightens the tax burden most significantly for moderate-income households with children. The $500-per-child tax credit accounts for much of the benefit for this group; it phases out at relatively high incomes.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about endangered plants in Hawaii described castor beans erroneously. While castor beans are used to produce an oil that functions as a laxative, the beans themselves contain a protein, ricin, that is highly poisonous. They are not ''edible.''

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with an article on Friday about welfare legislation misidentified two leading Republicans in some editions, and referred incorrectly to the focus of the gathering. In the photograph, Representative John Kasich of Ohio, not Representative William M. Thomas of California, was at far left. (Mr. Thomas was not in the picture.) Former Representative man Bob Michel of Illinois was misidentified as Mr. Kasich. The Republicans were applauding the health insurance legislation, not the welfare bill.

title: Giants' Maddox Gets a Start
description: It is one of those moves that on the surface makes sense but underneath is strange and even dangerous. The backup quarterback Tommy Maddox will start this week in the Giants' second exhibition game against Baltimore and the regular starter, Dave Brown, will watch from the sideline.

title: With Rise of H.M.O.'s, Medical Research Needs Federal Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Pensive Music Yearning To Be Alone
description: The music of Morton Feldman works best in isolation. It follows parameters so peculiar to itself that it often sounds uncomfortable when heard alongside the music of others. This past weekend, the Lincoln Center Festival '96 delivered a magnificent tribute to this lonely giant of American music; for a weekend, the resonant but intimate hall of the Ethical Culture Society on West 64th Street became an almost perfect Feldman world. Even those already convinced of Feldman's stature may have come away staggered by the intensity of vision communicated in this three-concert retrospective.

title: Smaller Raises for Teachers
description: Salary increases for public school teachers are falling, the New Jersey School Boards Association said yesterday. The average raise included in teacher contracts signed this spring was 3.9 percent, said Frank Belluscio, a spokesman for the association. In contrast, the average raise for the 1996-97 school year -- negotiated in 1994 -- was 5.3 percent.

title: PLASTIC-MAKING PROJECT LINKS B.P. AND DOW CHEMICAL
description: The Dow Chemical Company and the chemicals division of British Petroleum P.L.C. said yesterday that they were developing a plastic-making process together that they planned to license. The method would combine a Dow technology called Insite with a B.P. process called Innovene to make polyethylene, a plastic used in trash bags and packaging film. Insite is used to make plastics with higher strength, increased clarity and more uniform melting properties, the companies said. Innovene reduces manufacturing costs, they said. Dow is based in Midland, Mich., and B.P. is based in London.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LUKAS FOSS was a 15-year-old musician and AARON COPLAND a renowned composer, when they met about six decades ago. They remained friends until Mr. Copland died in 1990.

title: For Just One Screenful at a Time
description: Here is a program that does one little thing well. With Print Screen 2.0 running, you press the largely useless ''print screen'' button on the keyboard of a P.C. running any variety of Microsoft Windows, and the program does what its name says it does: an image of whatever was on the screen pops out of the printer.

title: Bucks Sign Gilliam
description: The Milwaukee Bucks signed the free-agent forward ARMON GILLIAM to a four-year contract, the team announced yesterday.

title: Help for the Flood-Plagued
description: Relief is on the way for residents of 200 flood-plagued houses near the Pascack Brook, which overflowed its banks five times last fall and winter. A plan to clear the brook of the silt and debris that block its flow is to be announced today by Bergen County officials and the Concerned Citizens of Hillsdale and Westwood. The cleanup will be done by the Bergen County Mosquito Control Commission.

title: Life With Grains, And Without
description: TALK about equal time. ''With the Grain'' by Raymond Sokolov (Alfred A. Knopf, $25) celebrates grains. ''Against the Grain'' by Jax Peters Lowell (Henry Holt, $14.95, paper) is a guide for people allergic to gluten and wheat.

title: Seabourn Cruise Line's revived campaign appears to be producing results.
description: WHEN Larry Pimental became president of the Seabourn Cruise Line in April 1992, he suspended the four-year-old luxury line's advertising. He believed that the money would be better spent training travel agents, who sell at least 95 percent of all cruises.

title: Bee Experts Rewrite the Advice On How to React After the Ouch
description: THE time-honored advice for taking care of bee stings, quoted faithfully in medical texts and first-aid manuals everywhere, is wrong, according to a study published in the current issue of The Lancet, a British medical journal.

title: G.M.'S SATURN DIVISION TO BUILD A LARGER CAR
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it would build a midsize Saturn car at its assembly plant in Wilmington, Del., in an effort to broaden the market for the popular brand, which until now has been offered only as a small car. The midsize car will be based on an Opel Vectra model sold in Europe. Production is expected to begin in 1999. The plan to build the new car was approved at a G.M. board meeting on Monday, and it spares the Wilmington plant from what had appeared to be a likely closing.

title: For Crash Victims' Families, A Painful Return to Routine
description: The bridal party burst into the Ramada Plaza Hotel near Kennedy Airport in a blur of white chiffon and dainty lace, the bridesmaids fluttering like pink hummingbirds and the lovers locked arm in arm. Immersed in the celebration of the life they were beginning, the couple may not have noticed the tired man with red-rimmed eyes who was mourning the life he had lost.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a visit by the Israeli Prime Minister to Jordan misstated the timing of Israel's capture of the Golan Heights. The area was taken from Syria in the 1967 Middle East war, not the 1973 war.

title: Sony Pictures Rumored to Plan Big Shake-Up
description: Michael J. Fuchs, the former chairman of Home Box Office, has emerged as one of several candidates to run Sony Pictures Entertainment, people close to the talks said today.

title: New Yorkers Face 2 Weeks of Storing Trash for Recycling
description: New York City will make its first major service cut in recycling next month when it scales back collections for half the city's households.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-6

title: Executive Changes
description: AMERICAN MOBILE SATELLITE CORP., Reston, Va., named Gary Parsons president and chief executive.

title: Goodyear to Close Centers
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced today that it was closing 9 of 20 distribution centers in an effort, it said, to reduce costs and improve customer service. The action could result in the loss of 240 jobs. Goodyear said outside companies would operate some distribution centers.

title: Ross Roy to Work Only for Chrysler
description: Ross Roy Communications, a unit of the Omnicom Group that specializes in services like direct marketing and retail advertising, said yesterday that it would resign all of its non-Chrysler Corporation business by the end of the year to become an exclusive agency for Chrysler.

title: Backlist: Advice From the Tried and True
description: BECAUSE of continual demand, the following books, even if published several years ago, are carried by most large chain bookstores. Some are kitchen primers that are useful for the novice as well as the experienced cook; others are specifically directed to the kitchen illiterate and might be too simplistic for people with some cooking experience. They are listed in order of publication.

title: Clinton's '93 Budget Drove Current Boom
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: Beth Sullivan was named to the new position of senior vice president and marketing research director at Arnold Communications, Boston. She previously held similar posts at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston.

title: Food Notes
description: Rising Dairy Costs

title: An Apotheosis for a Pot
description: THE quest for a perfect pot may be over. The Lincoln Centurion line of professional pots and pans is just about as good as cookware gets.

title: Roenick Set to Leave
description: JEREMY ROENICK has sold his house, moved to Massachusetts and pushed the Chicago Blackhawks out of his consciousness. Until recently, Roenick's stock answer to all questions about his free-agent status was that he hoped to stay in Chicago, his National Hockey League home since 1990.

title: Netscape Notifies Justice Dept. of Its Microsoft Complaint
description: Netscape Communications' bitter software marketing war with Microsoft escalated into a threat of legal action today, as Netscape brought the dispute to the attention of the Justice Department's antitrust division.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day yesterday showing large for-profit health plan operators carried an incomplete label. The list included only those publicly traded companies that derive the majority of their revenue from health plans; other large health plan operators were omitted.

title: Accounts
description: The Society of American Florists, Alexandria, Va., renamed Earle Palmer Brown, Bethesda, Md., to handle advertising for the association. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: Lynda Gudde, Dancer and Painter, 54
description: Lynda Gudde, a modern dancer and choreographer, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 54.

title: Relaxation Method May Aid Health
description: ''RELAX!'' is an admonition commonly heard by people with hypertension, or high blood pressure, a major risk factor for heart attacks, strokes and kidney disease. And indeed, a new study has shown that although hypertension may not always be caused by stress, practicing a form of meditation often used as a relaxation technique can be remarkably effective in controlling it.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: J. C. PENNEY TO BUY FAY'S DRUGSTORE CHAIN
description: The J. C. Penney Company said yesterday that it had reached a definitive agreement to buy the 272-store Fay's Inc. drugstore chain for $285 million in stock, making Penney's Thrift Drug chain the eighth largest in the nation. Under the agreement, Fay's shareholders will receive $12.75 in J. C. Penney stock tax free for each share of Fay's they hold, the companies said. On June 9, the day before Fay's announced it was in talks to sell the chain to Penney, its stock closed at $8.625. Yesterday, the shares of Fay's rose 37.5 cents, to $12.25. Shares of Penney fell $1.375, to $51.625. After the purchase is completed, the 654-store Thrift Drug chain will grow to 926 stores. J. C. Penney will keep the Fay's name on the company's stores in New York State, where most of the 272 Fay's stores are. Stores in Pennsylvania, Vermont and New Hampshire will become Thrift Drug stores.

title: Maiden Voyage of the Yankee Clipper
description: Greg Plate and his cousin, Danny Noonan, boarded the ferry looking for their hero Joe DiMaggio and hoping he would sign three baseballs. Kathleen McCarthy was looking only for a cold beer.

title: Cure for SoHo Is Simplicity Of Rural Japan
description: IT takes a hardy pioneer to carve out a community from a jumble of buildings bounded by concrete and asphalt. Marion Pinto was just that type of adventurer when she banded together with some of her artist friends in 1970 and converted the silent spaces of empty factories into the lofts of SoHo.

title: In New York Race, a New Breed of Republicans
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Doings For Yankees' Big Daddy
description: THE first thing the new home-run hitter for the Yankees did not want to be, he said, was ''over-geeked.'' ''I'm so excited to be here,'' Cecil Fielder said, ''that I don't wanna be too juiced about the whole thing.''

title: On Fielder's Night, Strawberry Makes It His Game
description: Darryl Strawberry had been looking for something like a lost set of car keys, searching all over when it was right in his pocket all along.

title: Total Affirms Commitment To Deals in Libya and Iran : Europeans Pump Up Defiance to New U.S. Sanctions
description: PARIS  Total SA plans to defend its investments in Libya and Iran, despite the threat of sanctions from the United States, and the French oil company is also looking for opportunities in countries that might be subject to similar American measures, its chairman said.

title: Car-rental companies in Europe are beginning to offer satellite-guided navigation systems.
description: NOW car-rental companies in Europe are picking up on the American penchant for satellite-guided navigation to help get drivers to their destinations. In Paris, the Kemwell Group is offering 20 luxury Citroen sedans equipped with real-time video mapping displays for an additional $20 a day, on top of the $79.80 daily rate. Voice prompts give drivers turn-by-turn directions -- in French, English and other European languages -- to addresses in Paris, Bordeaux, Lille, Lyons and Marseilles. Kemwell's toll-free number is (800) 678-0678.

title: A Soap Opera Ends: Let the Comedies Begin
description: THE most scrutinized executive in the television industry is sitting on a bar stool at Il Fornaio, a restaurant in the old town section here, waiting for her lunch appointment without a trace of impatience or tension.

title: Dole Airwaves Plan Adds Up, But Is Unlikely to Win Support
description: On the face of it, Bob Dole's proposal to raise $34 billion by selling broadcast licenses would seem plausible. The Federal Communications Commission has already raised $20 billion by auctioning off other, far less precious, slivers of the nation's airwaves.

title: Aiming for the I.R.S.
description: When Bob Dole said on Monday in introducing his economic program, ''I will eliminate the I.R.S. as we know it,'' he was invoking the same oratorical flourish Bill Clinton used for welfare four years before, and he aimed at another institution that many people love to hate.

title: Oxford Health Says It Nearly Doubled Profit
description: Oxford Health Plans Inc. said yesterday that second-quarter profits nearly doubled on an enrollment jump in managed health-care plans.

title: Political Savvy Tempers European Furor Over U.S. Bill Aimed at Libya and Iran
description: Beyond loud protests and warnings of reprisals, European officials today depicted President Clinton's threat of sanctions against foreign companies that invest heavily in Iran or Libya as an election-year ploy that would have little real effect on either trade or terrorism.

title: Hip-Hop and Reggae With a Punjabi Twist
description: Pop musicians are born to borrow, no matter where they come from. On Sunday and Monday, New Yorkers had a chance to hear English performers with Indian roots playing international hybrids that gleefully scrambled their sources. On Sunday Central Park Summerstage presented two Punjabi rock bands from Birmingham, England, the Safri Boys and D.C.S. And on Monday night at Wetlands, Najma sang blithely eclectic songs by the Indian film composer S. D. Burman.

title: The Mets' Offense Is Missing In Action
description: When Carlos Baerga and Alvaro Espinoza were acquired from Cleveland for Jeff Kent and Jose Vizcaino on July 29, Mets Manager Dallas Green had hoped it would be the start of a strong run to get back to .500 and stay in the wild-card chase.

title: Bus Crossing Control Arms
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a law yesterday requiring every school bus to be equipped with a crossing control arm, a device that keeps children at a distance from the bus so that the driver can see them when they cross in front of it. The law, spurred by the death this spring of a 7-year-old Trenton girl who was run over by a bus she had just left, also provides $2 million to school districts and bus owners to pay for the devices. ''This measure will save families the heartache of losing a child,'' the Governor said.

title: Corrections
description: A chronology with an article on July 20 about Food and Drug Administration advisers' recommending agency approval of the abortion drug RU-486 misidentified the original synthesizer of the drug. It was first made by Dr. Alain Belanger, then a post-doctoral fellow at Roussel Uclaff, under the direction of Dr. George Teutsch, the company's director of endocrine research, and not by Dr. Emile Baulieu, who was involved in later testing and development.

title: Oil Prices Fall as Iraqi Sales Seem Close to Being Cleared
description: Futures prices for crude oil fell yesterday after the United States said it would approve United Nations procedures governing Iraq's return to the world oil market.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday about houses being built by computer industry moguls misstated the location of Lawrence J. Ellison's 23-acre home. As the article stated correctly, Mr. Ellison lives in Woodside, Calif.

title: Suddenly, A Success In Poetry, And Not Everyone Applauds
description: There are some who insist that Virginia Hamilton Adair arrived like a comet, a spirited California poet of 83 blinded by glaucoma but with a lyric vision so clear that her first book inspired the sales executives to write verse in her honor.

title: Safety to Be Guide On Plant Start-Ups
description: Demand for electricity has been high in Connecticut after two hot days, and the state risks blackouts because safety concerns have shut down its four nuclear power plants. But the head of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said that safety, and not a need for power, would be the agency's primary concern. Page B4.

title: Where Will Howard Play Next Season?
description: JUWAN HOWARD's saga continued yesterday, with conflicting reports about his status. A National Basketball Association spokesman said an arbitration hearing was still scheduled to decide which team Howard would play for next season -- the Miami Heat, or the Washington Bullets. But ESPN reported yesterday that the Heat had dropped its efforts to sign the 6-foot-9-inch Howard, and that the forward would play for the Bullets next season.

title: Abraham Nash, Labor Leader, Writer and Cornell Professor, 80
description: Abraham Nash, a former labor leader who was a writer on social issues and a retired professor of sociology at Cornell University, died on Saturday at Presbyterian Hospital. He was 80 and lived in Washington Heights in Manhattan.

title: What May Signal a Slip in New Offerings? Guess
description: It seems as if only months ago, Zsa Zsa Gabor could have gone public, simply because her name is known around the world.

title: Antique Cookbooks Return as Time Machines
description: MOST people who cook have favorite culinary guides, one or two old reliables whose pages are smudged by fingerprints and spotted with sauce. Rick Ellis, whose business is preparing food to be photographed, keeps inspirational cookbooks on hand, too: 4,500 of them. ''At least, that was the number the last time I took inventory,'' he said.

title: Can't Cook? I Mean, Really Can't Cook?
description: NEVIS WEXLER, a book editor in her 30's who lives in Manhattan, says she can remember the very moment, about six years ago, when she realized she needed serious culinary coaching. ''One of my first company dinners was a veal stew calling for four cloves of garlic,'' she said. ''I assumed -- who knew? -- that one clove was one head of garlic.''

title: At Midnight, Striped Bass Come to Play
description: After our first evening of fly fishing for striped bass, I was concerned that the two days my visiting friends -- Vic Pomiecko and John Houlihan of Claremont, N.H. -- had set aside for angling on Martha's Vineyard with my youngest son, Jeff, and me, were not going to be enough.

title: Test Dummy's Report
description: FIRST, in the interest of disclosure: I am not a complete dummy when it comes to the kitchen.

title: Clinton Signs a Bill on Water Contaminants
description: Calling the measure a ''cornerstone in the foundation of security for American families,'' President Clinton today signed into law a far-reaching bill that would help states upgrade municipal water systems and require local water agencies to inform the public what contaminants have been found in the drinking water.

title: No Headline
description: ''A chap on an elephant sees a lot further in the bush than when he's just on the ground. And it makes quite an impression on the poachers.''

title: G.O.P. Moderates Vow to Revive Provision on Abortion Tolerance
description: Set back by conservatives who removed the compromise ''tolerance'' language on abortion from the Republican Party platform, moderates vowed today to wage a fight at the convention next week to reinstate at least an acknowledgment that some Republicans favor abortion rights.

title: Health-Care Bill Sacrifices Our Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Brute Strength! Africans Harness the Elephant
description: In Asia, the elephant is used for all manner of labor, perhaps most notably for hauling logs in areas where tractors cannot go. But Africans have traditionally steered clear of their elephants, a bigger, more skittish breed that kills people every year and is widely believed to be untamable.

title: An Ex-King's Private Life As Described by a Prince
description: If Prince Edward is looking for a career to go along with the family castles and whatnot,'' the youngest son of Queen Elizabeth II proves a diligent researcher, an amiable interviewer and a serviceable writer as he explores the oft-told tale of Edward VIII.

title: Overhauling Welfare: A Look at the Year Ahead
description: Once signed by President Clinton, the welfare bill will end the 61-year Federal guarantee of cash assistance for poor children and give states vast new authority to run their own welfare programs with lump sums of Federal money known as block grants. The measure will also require adult recipients to find work within two years, establish a five-year lifetime limit on benefits and curtail aid for noncitizens. ROBERT PEAR

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SIMON PROPERTY GROUP INC., Indianapolis, said shareholders of it and DeBartolo Realty, Youngstown, Ohio, had approved Simon's $3 billion purchase of DeBartolo.

title: Lewis Denies Angling for Relay Run
description: Trying to soften the harsh portrayal of him as an athlete seeking something he didn't deserve, Carl Lewis said yesterday that he never lobbied to run the 4x100-meter relay at the Atlanta Olympics, because he knew he would not be selected.

title: Trading Little Loopholes for a Giant One
description: Bob Dole's plan endorsing a big tax cut was as notable for what it left out as for what it left in. He did not come out in favor of a flat tax of the type recommended by his election rival, Steve Forbes. While the supply-siders did not get everything they wanted, however, Mr. Dole stated that his ultimate goal is a ''fairer, flatter system that will allow Americans to file their tax returns without the help of a lawyer or an accountant.'' He also said he would ''eliminate the I.R.S. as we know it,'' and declared his proposed cut ''the opening salvo in a battle to repeal the current tax code.''

title: For 10 Minutes, Cone Is Himself Once Again
description: It was a remarkable climb of a simple incline. It was such a little thing, pitching off a bullpen mound, but it had never meant so much to David Cone.

title: For Zapatistas, Talk Turns to Unarmed Struggle
description: About 2,000 sympathizers of the Zapatista rebels came from around the world to meet for three days on a plain of oozing mud in an Indian hamlet in southern Mexico to ruminate about the shortcomings of capitalism.

title: For Giants Receiver, Focus Is on Focusing
description: His heart is in the right place, but his head might need to be in the playbook more. Wide receiver Thomas Lewis has the speed that would make Michael Johnson take a second look, and the raw talent that would make Andre Rison wish he were 19 again. Lewis has the chance to be that good.

title: Divided Bosnia City's Croats Agree to Honor Vote Results
description: After weeks of intense haggling, the European Union extracted an agreement today from defiant Bosnian Croat politicians to honor local election results, thus allowing European reconstruction efforts to continue in this battered and partitioned city.

title: Van Kills Man on Bench
description: A van crashed onto a crowded stretch of Atlantic City's Boardwalk yesterday afternoon, killing a man who was sitting on a bench and plowing into a public bathroom. Police do not know why the driver, Irwin Cowan of Fresh Meadows, L.I., lost control of his van, which jumped the Boardwalk between the Tropicana and Bally's Grand casinos. But Officer John Dollard said that Mr. Cowan, 76, did not have the use of his legs and that a device allowing the brake and accelerator to be operated by hand might have malfunctioned. The man on the bench, Anthony Rando, 52, of Northfield, was killed instantly. No charges have been filed against Mr. Cowan.

title: Benoit Expected To Start for Nets
description: The Nets have scheduled a news conference for today at Continental Arena to announce the signing of David Benoit, a free-agent forward who spent the last five seasons with the Utah Jazz.

title: Corrections
description: The On Baseball column yesterday, about negotiations between the owners and players, inaccurately rendered the explanation that Donald Fehr, head of the Major League Baseball Players Association, gave for his appearance on an American Bar Association panel. He said he did it at the request of Mike Kelly, a partner of Rob Manfred, a lawyer for the owners, not at Mr. Manfred's request. The quotation should have read: ''I'm being criticized for doing Rob Manfred's partner a favor.''

title: British Food Distributor Rejects Takeover Offer
description: Christian Salvesen P.L.C., a British food distributor, rejected an increased takeover offer yesterday from Hays P.L.C. Hays then withdrew the bid, which was valued at $:1.1 billion ($1.7 billion).

title: Westinghouse Posted Deficit In 2d Quarter
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported a loss for the second quarter today, largely as a result of a $116 million charge for environmental cleanup costs.

title: N.R.C. Chief Says Safety Will Rule Plant Start-Ups
description: On a steamy day when Connecticut faced a risk of blackouts because safety concerns had shut down its four nuclear power plants, the head of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said that safety, rather than the state's need for power, would remain the agency's primary concern.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Vice President AL GORE and his family are taking a vacation in what they probably assumed would be politically friendly territory.

title: Detective Shot 3 Times by Sniper Is Saved by Bulletproof Vest
description: A police detective deployed as part of a crackdown on drug trafficking in high-crime precincts was shot by a sniper as he stood on a Brooklyn street corner yesterday afternoon. The detective's bulletproof vest deflected the bullets, saving the officer's life, officials said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Netscape Escalates Battle With Microsoft

title: The Russians' Secret? Shh, It's W-o-r-k
description: Anyone who worked as hard as he did, Bach is supposed to have said, would have accomplished as much. That monumental bit of inanity came to mind during the recent four-concert stand by the Kirov Orchestra and Chorus of St. Petersburg, Russia, at the Lincoln Center Festival '96, part of an American tour that ended yesterday in Los Angeles.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Stewardship Of Adelphi U. Is Questioned
description: Questioning whether Adelphi University can survive further declines in enrollment, a state panel yesterday challenged the chairwoman of the university's board over its management of the school.

title: Despite Violations, Rape Suspect Left Prison
description: The man arrested and charged with a rape in Central Park over the weekend won early release from a prison sentence for his fourth rape and robbery conviction under a law that requires the state to free well-behaved convicts once they have served two-thirds of their maximum sentence. The release came even after he set a cell fire at one prison and assaulted a female correction officer at another, state correction and parole officials said yesterday.

title: The ABC's of E.I.T.'s
description: A student of mine needed help with her language skills. She received a holistic score below the goal of 8 on the C.M.T. prompt. She also did poorly on the D.R.P.

title: KANSAS CITY POWER RESCHEDULES VOTE ON MERGER
description: The Kansas City Power and Light Company said yesterday that it had rescheduled a special shareholders meeting for Aug. 16 to vote on the company's proposed $1.7 billion merger with Utilicorp United Inc. Kansas City Power had postponed the meeting, originally scheduled for today, after a Federal court ruling that two-thirds of all Kansas City Power shareholders would have to vote in favor of the deal for it to go through. The company said the merger should require only a majority vote. It also said yesterday that its board had increased its quarterly cash dividend by 3.8 percent, to 40.5 cents a share from 39 cents. Kansas City Power said the increased dividend would be payable on Sept. 20 to shareholders of record on Aug. 29.

title: Town Sired By Malls Creates Downtown
description: With their golden retriever, Jake, leading the way, Craig and Nancy Knudsen set out on a stroll in this Chicago suburb on a pleasant evening, looking fit and cheerful and not lacking for much of anything -- except maybe a destination.

title: Wheatley Wants to Play Despite Pain in His Feet
description: Giants running back Tyrone Wheatley says that if the team's medical staff approves, he will try to play and practice -- even though he would be playing in a lot of pain -- no matter what the injury is to his leg.

title: Restaurateurs Rise From Supporting Roles
description: JEAN-CLAUDE IACOVELLI is scouting locations in SoHo for a pasta restaurant. He already owns Jean Claude and SoHo Steak in that downtown neighborhood and Caffe Lure nearby.

title: Group Files to Oppose Mayor
description: The Mayor of Atlantic City, James Whelan, says his political enemies threaten to try to force him from office every year. This year, however, they appear to be serious. A group called the Committee to Recall James Whelan from the Office of Mayor filed papers with the city clerk yesterday to begin the recall process.

title: Wine Talk
description: WITH the death last week of Sam Aaron, a founder 62 years ago of Sherry-Lehmann Wine and Spirits in New York, the American wine industry lost one of the few survivors of its romantic period, the years before and just after World War II.

title: The Shrinking Tent
description: Only a few years ago, people with a taste for pre-convention juggling acts had to watch the Democrats. But these days Bob Dole is in the center ring, flinging first one abortion position and then another into the air. Mr. Dole's factional problem is vexing. A tolerant stance would appeal to the suburban moderates without whom he cannot win. But if he moves in that direction, he knows the pro-life activists will torment him for the next three months.

title: CISCO TO BUY COMPUTER NETWORKING EQUIPMENT MAKER
description: Cisco Systems Inc., the world's largest maker of computer networking equipment, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Nashoba Networks Inc. for about $100 million in stock. Nashoba makes so-called token ring switches, which are computer networking products that help move data between computer systems in a local area network. Under the agreement, the number of Cisco shares to be exchanged will be calculated based on an average price for its shares during a specified period. The number of shares will be between 1.55 million and 2.32 million. Shares of Cisco rose $1.688 yesterday to close at $57.25. Nashoba is privately held.

title: Jail Time for Desecration
description: Two teen-agers who spray-painted Nazi swastikas on grave markers in a Jewish cemetery in Saddle Brook last October were sentenced in Federal court yesterday. Kevin Coombs, 19, of Garfield, was sentenced to 15 months and Christopher Talbot, 19, of Lodi, was sentenced to 12 months for the desecration. Prosecutors had said the men wanted to start a racist skinhead group in northern New Jersey.

title: Two Officers Convicted in 30th Precinct
description: In the final trial of police officers from the scandal-ridden 30th Precinct, a Manhattan Supreme Court jury yesterday found two officers guilty of stealing money from a drug dealer in northwest Harlem.

title: With G.O.P. Convention, Ad Campaigns Gear Up
description: When Bob Dole comes to collect the Republican Presidential nomination here next week, he will be greeted by a television advertisement pointing out that he was divorced before marrying Elizabeth Hanford.

title: Union Pension Funds Give Land a Try
description: Construction that began in July on an office and warehouse complex here is the latest step in the effort of two labor union pension funds to complete development of an office park they own in this town 15 miles north of Boston.

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC SELLING 2 GYPSUM WALLBOARD PLANTS
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell two gypsum wallboard plants to the Lafarge Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. The two plants, in Buchanan, N.Y., and Wilmington, Del., had combined sales of $75 million in 1995. Georgia-Pacific, the paper and building products maker based in Atlanta, was ordered to sell the plants by the Department of Justice, which cited antitrust concerns in the company's acquisition of Domtar Inc.'s North American wallboard business in April. Lafarge, based in Reston, Va., is a subsidiary of the French-owned LaFarge Group.

title: Bomb Inquiry Again Focuses On Apartment
description: For the third time in a week, Federal investigators today searched the apartment of Richard A. Jewell, the Atlanta security guard who remains a suspect in the July 27 bombing at Centennial Olympic Park.

title: ARAFAT SAYS PLAN FOR SETTLEMENTS VIOLATES ACCORDS
description: In a bitter speech that showed growing disillusionment with the policies of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, Yasir Arafat today called the Israeli Government's decision to permit the expansion of Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza a ''flagrant violation'' of the Palestinian-Israeli accords that should be resisted ''on the ground.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about two sisters who went to Connecticut under the auspices of the Fresh Air Fund carried a misspelled byline. The writer's name is Mira Schwirtz, not Schwartz.

title: MOORE DROPS ATTEMPT TO ACQUIRE WALLACE COMPUTER
description: The Moore Corporation said yesterday that it had dropped its yearlong hostile bid to acquire Wallace Computer Services Inc. Moore's board said it had determined that the best interests of Moore shareholders could be served without Wallace, which Moore had been trying to buy for $1.4 billion. Moore, based in Toronto, is a provider of business forms. Wallace, based in Hillside, Ill., does commercial printing including business forms and sells computers and office supplies.

title: Ross Perot Will Not Like This Book
description: CITIZEN PEROT

title: Yes, Invest Social Security in Stock Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Committing of Rapist Upheld
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the state did not overstep its authority when it committed a rapist to a psychiatric hospital months after he finished his prison term. The court overturned a lower court's ruling that Donald Chapman of Wyckoff, who told his therapist he still harbored violent fantasies upon his release from the Avenel Diagnostic and Treatment Center in 1992, could not be held against his will.

title: Investigators Doubt Explosion Occurred in Cockpit
description: After picking apart some of the wadded remains of the cockpit of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, investigators concluded yesterday that the catastrophic explosion that destroyed the Boeing 747 most likely did not originate inside the cockpit or in the electronics bay beneath it.

title: Citizenship Proposal Faces Obstacle in the Constitution
description: In proposing to deny United States citizenship to children born in this country to illegal immigrants, members of the Republican Platform Committee are challenging a pillar of constitutional law erected nearly 130 years ago.

title: Personal Health
description: IN days gone by, children were often warned that reading in poor light or in awkward positions would ''ruin'' their eyes. Fortunately, problems rarely ensued. Not so among today's computer users; many experience preventable eye or vision problems.

title: Clues in Meteorite Seem to Show Signs of Life on Mars Long Ago
description: Scientists studying a meteorite that fell to Earth from Mars have identified organic compounds and certain minerals that they conclude ''are evidence for primitive life on early Mars.''

title: Takeover of Snapple Is the Prime Suspect in the Food Giant's Weak Showing
description: ''I clearly understand my role as C.E.O.,'' William D. Smithburg, chairman and chief executive of the Quaker Oats Company, recently told Wall Street analysts. It boils down to ''value builder for shareholders,'' he said.

title: Just Follow These Steps
description: MOST recipes in the basic cookbooks are written in a very simple way, with every step detailed. They tend to be presented as narratives and to be given without nutritional information. Here are two that are typical, presented as they appear in the books. The first is from ''The Kitchen Survival Guide'' by Lora Brody; the second, from ''The Complete Idiot's Guide to Cooking Basics'' by Ronnie Fein.

title: It Isn't Farmers Who Kill Rain Forests
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigration Fable
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICA ONLINE BUYS AT&T COMPUTER GAME UNIT
description: America Online Inc., the computer on-line service, said yesterday that it had bought Imagination Network Inc., a money-losing computer game unit of the AT&T Corporation. The purchase price was not disclosed. AT&T had paid more than $40 million in November 1994 to acquire the 80 percent of the company that it did not already own. AT&T officials declined to estimate the size of the losses the company incurred during its sole ownership of Imagination. Imagination said it would operate as a wholly owned subsidiary of America Online.

title: Air Force Punishes 16 Officers With Link to Ron Brown Crash
description: Sixteen Air Force officers, including two generals, were reprimanded in connection with the April 3 plane crash in Croatia that killed Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and 34 other people, the Air Force announced today.

title: High-Fives and Higher Numbers as Johnson Becomes a Jet at Last
description: It took a surprise visit to New York, and incentives based on playing like an All-Pro, but wide receiver Keyshawn Johnson and the Jets finally agreed to terms today.

title: Mall Gunman Is Identified
description: The authorities yesterday identified the gunman who was shot and killed during a robbery in the Deptford Mall on Monday and said he had a record of minor arrests in three states.

title: Bowing to Party Pressure, A Republican Drops Out
description: Representative Wes Cooley of Oregon abruptly dropped his bid for re-election today, bowing to weeks of pressure from Republican leaders in the House who feared that questions about his war record and his wife's pension had rendered him unelectable.

title: Chastened yet Cocky, Operative Returns
description: Edward J. Rollins Jr., the cocky Republican consultant who admitted to fabrication after bragging that church ministers were paid to suppress the black vote in the 1993 New Jersey elections, returned to the scene of the lie today.

title: In This Corner, the Latest Unknown
description: Crawford Grimsley radiates a toothy smile as he imagines fighting for a $10 million payday. That is, once he bursts from boxing's shadows in a fight planned for Sept. 15 against the age-defying George Foreman.

title: Loret Miller Ruppe, 60, Dies; Reinvigorated the Peace Corps
description: Loret Miller Ruppe, who was head of the Peace Corps longer than anyone else in the organization's 35-year history and was credited by many with restoring much of its Kennedy-era vitality, died yesterday at her home in Bethesda, Md. She was 60.

title: Jack and Bob, Going to the Chapel
description: When I was a boy, the men in my neighborhood had names like Charlie, Wilbur, Jimmy, Homer, T. Paine, Frank, Marvin, Gus and Sam. They had served in World War II and come back to Tampa, Fla., to settle down. In the morning, they went off to jobs in sales, journalism, banking, law, accounting, dentistry and politics. At night, they came home to women named Mildred, Mary, Bobbie, Nell, Jean, Patti, Cile, Georgie and Martha. They were married to them. They had to be. It was the South.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: MCDERMOTT INTERNATIONAL SHARES RISE ON REVIEW PLAN
description: The shares of McDermott International Inc. rose nearly 11 percent yesterday after the company said it had hired Merrill Lynch & Company to evaluate its business lines. The company, which is based in New Orleans, also said its chief executive, Robert E. Howson, was retiring, but it did not name a replacement. The hiring of Merrill Lynch is aimed at turning around the company's businesses, which include electric power generating, engineering and construction, and providing fuel and parts to governments. The company has had disappointing earnings for the last few years. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of McDermott rose $1.75 to $20.125.

title: Water's Effect on Debris Weighing on Recovery
description: Three weeks after the Atlantic Ocean swallowed a flaming Boeing 747, investigators continue to explore a prevailing theory that the downfall of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 was caused by a bomb. But their complicated mission is made all the more complex by the very water in which much of the plane rests.

title: Nursing Homes Draw Attention As Worker-Safety Focus Shifts
description: When people consider the most dangerous places to work in America, nursing homes probably do not place high on the list. But they should. Only truck drivers and common laborers suffer more on-the-job injuries than nursing home workers do.

title: Italy's Plan to Sell Communications Giant
description: The Italian Government said yesterday that it would sell its remaining stake in Stet S.p.A., the telecommunications company, next February or March, after selling or spinning off its telephone equipment and publishing units. At current market prices, the Government's stake is worth 16 trillion lire, or $10.5 billion.

title: INSIDE
description: Inching Ahead in Bosnia

title: Flights of Imagination: How Birds Transfigure The Arts and Vice Versa
description: Art exhibitions built around themes rather than individual artists often seem to work when they focus on art movements, geographic regions or ancient civilizations. Shows examining how artists through the ages have tackled a specific subject generally fare less well, no doubt because works inspired by, say, religion or nature or the female nude are too varied or too numerous to make much sense.

title: Improving Preschool Special Education
description: New York's Governor and State Legislature, though often incapable of working together on the most innocuous of issues, have quietly agreed to make dramatic changes in the sensitive matter of preschool education for handicapped children. The news has alarmed parents who fear loss of services and some of the private schools that serve disabled children. But the state's leaders are taking responsible and necessary steps to restructure a program that has been in danger of running out of control.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The current issue of Newsweek has a ''To Our Readers'' note saying that the columnist JOE KLEIN has returned to the magazine as a contributing editor.

title: Dole Taking Clear Aim At Nation's Tax Collector
description: Just as Bill Clinton found an easy target four years ago in attacking the welfare system, Bob Dole has now taken aim at another institution that many people love to hate.

title: Hord W. Hardin, 84, an Official Who Led the Masters Golf Event
description: Hord W. Hardin, whose autocratic rule over golf's Masters tournament was legendary, died on Monday in Harbor Springs, Mich., after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: In New York Race, a New Breed of Republicans
description: To the Editor:

title: Wregget Is Re-signed
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins signed the veteran goaltender KEN WREGGET to a new contract yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: SARAH WALL is heading from Zabar's up Broadway to the apartment she and her husband have sublet for the summer. A dapper-looking man carrying a suitcase approaches from the opposite direction and stops her.

title: Comprehensive Study Finds Parents and Peers Are Most Crucial Influences on Students
description: Educators have squared off for 30 years over whether the home or school environment has a greater influence on student academic performance. In recent years, school-oriented reformers have dominated the debate, and billions of dollars have been poured into reconfiguring schools, reworking curriculums and retraining teachers.

title: Finally, It's Beginning to Feel a Lot Like Summer
description: So maybe this will be remembered as the brief, hot summer.

title: Olympic TV Coverage Won Viewer Approval
description: To the Editor:

title: In P.G.A., Faldo to Aim For Aura of Big Winner
description: Not even he, the most precise of precisionists, could pinpoint the moment. But something happened three weeks ago in England that unsettled him. Nick Faldo became fallible again.

title: Fooling All the People
description: Arianna Huffington, writes Ed Rollins, ''was the most ruthless, unscrupulous, and ambitious person I'd met in 30 years in national politics -- not to mention that she sometimes seemed truly pathological.'' And that's the nice part! Mrs. Huffington -- wife of the defeated California senatorial candidate Michael -- is already issuing denials and threatening a lawsuit against Mr. Rollins, the former G.O.P. political consultant, whose burn-every-bridge memoir, ''Bare Knuckles and Back Rooms,'' is published today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DONNA HANOVER GIULIANI is continuing to spread her wings beyond Gracie Mansion.

title: African Nations Opposed to Burundi Coup Begin a Blockade
description: Without waiting for formal international sanctions to be imposed on Burundi, several African nations have closed their borders or severed air links with the landlocked nation in recent days to put pressure on military leaders who took over in a coup nearly two weeks ago, United Nations officials said today.

title: Columbus Circle Dream
description: To the Editor:

title: Urine Test For H.I.V. Is Approved
description: Federal health officials yesterday approved the first urine test to detect H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, but said it was not as accurate as the standard blood test.

title: A New Israeli Settlement Policy
description: The new Israeli Government has devised a policy for Jewish settlements in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip that could put additional land in these disputed areas under Jewish control. The displacement of Arabs who now live or farm there would create geographic and political obstacles to a durable peace with the Palestinians.

title: G.O.P.'S FRESHMEN OUT ON THE STUMP
description: Seventy Republican freshmen, the self-styled revolutionaries whose election fate is the key to control of the House of Representatives, are out campaigning this week, some comfortable -- even safe -- and others battling to keep their careers alive.

title: Earnings Rise For Stockbrokers
description: Stockbrokers are earning more, according to statistics released yesterday by the Securities Industry Association.

title: Indonesia Moves Quickly to Suppress a Budding Opposition
description: In the aftermath of the worst rioting here in decades, the Government has taken the upper hand, moving aggressively to suppress a variety of opposition groups that had begun groping toward a common cause.

title: When Permanent House Guest Is Frank Lloyd Wright
description: One night in 1957, William Cass was watching what came to be a famous Mike Wallace television interview with Frank Lloyd Wright in the living room of his row house in Corona, Queens.

title: Always the Same but Always New
description: ''Flirt'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 6. The film opens today at the Film Forum, 209 Houston Street, South Village.

title: Sears Expands Role With Young & Rubicam
description: The Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that it had further expanded its relationship with the Chicago and New York offices of Young & Rubicam Inc., by naming them the first to handle responsibilities for its Home Services group which provides appliance repair, installations and home improvements. Though billings were not disclosed, trade publications estimated them at $30 million.

title: Florida Is Cutting-Edge Lab For Big Generational Shifts
description: Early most mornings, the Port Charlotte Town Center mall fills with brisk gray-haired walkers ready for their air-conditioned laps. The exercise can end with coffee at the food courtyard or a blood pressure check at the Bon Secours-St. Joseph Healthcare Group storefront, next to the video store.

title: Knicks Sign Their Three First-Rounders
description: They are rookies, they are joining a talented team and playing time will be difficult to come by. Yet the Knick careers of John Wallace, Walter McCarty and Dontae' Jones officially began yesterday when the team announced that it had signed its three first-round picks.

title: GOLF REPORT
description: Northville L. I. Classic

title: In Moscow, Scapegoating at a Congress of Poor Losers
description: Wasn't it supposed to be capitalism that died of internal contradictions?

title: Flank Steak With a Vegetable Medley
description: This dinner of flank steak and orecchiette with summer vegetables calls for fresh corn.

title: Stern Picks Ackerman to Shape W.N.B.A.
description: The hours will be long, the details could become tedious and the year ahead should be chaotic, but VAL ACKERMAN realizes she is making history and she wants to make sure she gets it right.

title: Dole 'Very Near' Decision On Choosing Running Mate
description: Bob Dole told his senior staff today that he was ''very near a final decision'' on a Vice President, but campaign aides said the timing of the announcement was up in the air.

title: On the Trail of Peru's Maoist Rebels
description: Gen. Manuel Varela Gamarra, Peru's chief military officer for this vast jungle region dominated by Shining Path guerrillas, seemed awfully relaxed for someone who was nearly killed last week when the rebels bombed his home in Lima.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When Dreamworks SKG opens its animation campus in Glendale, Calif., at the end of next year, there will be a village with five buildings two to three stories high, piazzas, an orchard of olive and pear trees and an artificial stream that will meander under buildings and widen into a small lake.

title: High Design, Lower Prices
description: MXYPLYZYK has expanded its ''mx.'' The store New Yorkers love to mispronounce -- it's mix-EE-plizz-ick, after a character in the Superman comics -- has opened a second location on Greenwich Avenue and is expanding, from furnishings in earth tones and natural materials to housewares with an industrial look.

title: Life on Mars?
description: There is a temptation to make light of the claim that evidence of primitive microscopic life has been detected in a rock that fell from Mars. After so many decades of wondering whether intelligent beings had built canals on the planet's surface, it seems an awful letdown to be arguing now over whether a tiny single-celled organism might have existed billions of years ago on the red planet.

title: For the Boss, A Change For the Better
description: IF there is one overriding theme of the Yankees' magical march toward the post-season, it is one of second chances and new beginnings.

title: Assad Doesn't See 'the Slightest Hope' of Peace in Israeli Offer
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria said today that an Israeli proposal to resume talks between the two countries had not offered ''the slightest hope of the possibility of a forthcoming peace.''

title: First-Half Profit Up 32% at Schering
description: Schering Pharmaceuticals A.G., the German pharmaceutical and chemical company, said yesterday that its profit jumped 32 percent in the first half of this year, mostly because of favorable exchange rates. First-half profit rose to 244 million marks, or $164.4 million, from 185 million marks.

title: The Two Bob Doles
description: To the Editor;

title: CHRONICLE
description: TOM CRUISE is now an off-screen hero. On Tuesday night, the star of ''Mission Impossible'' helped rescue five people whose yacht had caught fire off the coast of Capri, according to a Reuters report.

title: Astros Seek Permission to Sell Team
description: The Houston Astros owner, DRAYTON McLANE, asked baseball's executive council yesterday for permission to negotiate a possible sale of the team to a Virginia businessman, BILL COLLINS.

title: Gallic Flair Sans Attitude
description: FRENCH antiques stores can be intimidating to the uninitiated, but not Gueridon. The store -- its name translates as ''round side table'' -- offers a very broad shopper-friendly selection by Alfonso Munoz and Jean-Philippe Mathieu, who started scouring flea markets when they lived in Paris. The inventory is both antique and contemporary, predominantly French of any age, but it also boasts some Spanish and American designs. Prices range from $250 to $7,000. Items shown at right include a French Art Deco buffet ($3,200) beneath a stainless-steel 60's mirror ($1,500), a glass Thonet table ($1,500), French 50's lamp ($450) and stone side tables ($395) by Antonio Da Motta, a very 90's New York designer. Gueridon is at 359 Lafayette Street (Bond Street); (212) 677-7740.

title: INSIDE
description: Reviewing Enterprise Zones

title: A Milk for the Cholesterol-Conscious
description: It seems like a publicist's dream: skim milk that looks like whole milk, tastes like 2 percent milk and may lower cholesterol levels in many people.

title: Dole's Tax-Cut Proposal Frightens Liberals
description: To the Editor:

title: Calendar: Design Show, Tours and Craft Courses
description: Design Winners
