title: Rose Hamburger, Racing Fan And Oldest Handicapper, 105
description: Rose Hamburger, who spent half a century as a real estate agent before eagerly coming out of a reluctant five-year retirement last December to start a new career -- as a racing handicapper for The New York Post -- died on Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 105.

title: CHRYSLER PRESIDENT SAYS HE HAS NO PLANS TO RETIRE SOON
description: Robert Lutz, the president of the Chrysler Corporation, said yesterday that he had ''absolutely no plans to leave'' the auto maker when he turns 65 in March. Mr. Lutz said he probably would stay at Chrysler for two years after his next birthday, though perhaps with a different title. His comments contradicted recent speculation that he would retire early next year. Mr. Lutz said he wanted to be more involved next year in creating new products for Chrysler.

title: Prosecutors Block a Deal to Divert Indicted Trash Hauler's Wealth
description: When New York City's largest trash-hauler was indicted last year on charges that it had Mafia ties, an independent monitor was appointed to make sure the owners did not divert the company's enormous wealth before the case went to trial.

title: Case Accusing 3 of Plotting To Bomb Jets Shows a Flaw
description: The Government's case against three men accused of plotting to bomb American jetliners experienced a potential setback yesterday when an agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation conceded that his notes failed to show that he had asked one of the defendants, Wali Khan Amin Shah, if he had participated in the bombing conspiracy.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: VALUJET INC. (VJET, NNM)
description: Valujet Inc. yesterday reported a loss of $9.6 million in the second quarter, which included the crash on May 11 in the Florida Everglades and the grounding of Valujet Airlines.

title: Replying to Skeptics, NASA Defends Claims About Mars
description: Scientists and space agency officials today reaffirmed their claim of finding strong evidence for past life on Mars and asked skeptics among the world's scientists to join them in conducting even more rigorous tests needed to confirm or disprove it.

title: Breathing Spain, With Less Clatter
description: Pilar Rioja has grown as an artist in public over 24 seasons in New York City. A program presented by Ms. Rioja on Tuesday night at the Repertorio Espanol Gramercy Arts Theater suggests that she is entering one of the most compelling phases of that growth.

title: Invincible Rabbit Army Besieges a Paris Airport
description: Charles de Gaulle Airport in this township just northeast of Paris handles 30 million passengers a year. About 45,000 people work here, servicing and refueling planes, processing passengers on 1,000 flights a day, and loading cargo and baggage.

title: On Day 1, Johnson Audits N.F.L. 101
description: His new teammates joked and asked him for a loan today as Keyshawn Johnson, the top pick in last spring's draft, put on a Jets uniform for the first time as an official member of the team.

title: N.A.S.D. and Government Seen in Pact to Curb Abuses
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the National Association of Securities Dealers are expected to announce a $100 million agreement today to end abuses on the Nasdaq stock market, people with knowledge of the deal said yesterday.

title: L'Oreal Sales Rose 11.8% in First Half
description: L'Oreal S.A., the French hair care and beauty products group, said yesterday that its sales in the first half of the year rose 11.8 percent, to 30.12 billion francs, or $5.96 billion, from 26.95 billion francs in the comparable period of 1995.

title: Jackson Holbrook Bailey, 70, an Authority on Asian Civilizations
description: Jackson Holbrook Bailey, a leading American educator in Asian studies, died on Aug. 2 at his home in Brattleboro, Vt. He was 70.

title: Just More Voodoo
description: To the Editor:

title: Pay Cut and Probation Ordered for Coach
description: Two years' probation and a 25 percent pay cut have been ordered for the Weber State basketball coach, RON ABEGGLEN, under self-imposed sanctions proposed by the school for National Collegiate Athletic Association rules violations.

title: Advanced Voice, AT&T in Accord
description: Advanced Voice Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had reached a three-year agreement with the the AT&T Corporation to co-market an AT&T program that offers voice-messaging to schools.

title: G.O.P. Readies a Made-for-TV Convention
description: Planning even for the networks' commercial breaks, Republicans here have scripted a four-day political television program, which they are calling a convention. Now the question is whether the networks will broadcast it for them.

title: G.O.P.'S MODERATES ACCEPT AN ACCORD ON ABORTION ISSUE
description: Bob Dole and other Republican leaders found a way today to avoid a divisive floor fight over abortion at the Republican National Convention next week.

title: Big On-Line Crash Frustrates Businesses
description: A network blackout at America Online left many small businesses and home-office workers without electronic mail and other network services yesterday, illustrating the growing importance of on-line communications to modern commerce.

title: Drummer Gives His Sidemen Lots of Room for Solo Flight
description: Louis Hayes, a hard-bop drummer who formed his style in the 1960's playing behind such heroes of the form as Cannonball Adderley and Horace Silver, is loud in an evolved, perfected way. He doesn't break through with single, assaultive hits, which is the tiresome way to drum loudly in jazz; instead, he builds up a dense hill of sound as a bottom layer, so that the propulsive accents don't come as a shock.

title: Schroeder? Yes, Schroeder
description: SCHROEDER may be a shy cartoon character, but Marcello Ziliani has given him reason to shine. Mr. Ziliani has created a line of four sconces, each named for a member of the ''Peanuts'' gang. The classiest guy in the group, Schroeder is elegant and understated, nine inches tall with an acid-etched blown-glass shade in white, blue or yellow that looks striated ($200). At Lightforms, 168 Eighth Avenue (19th Street) and at 509 Amsterdam Avenue (85th Street). The importer is Flos USA: (516) 549-2745.

title: Sowing the Classics, Reaping New Listeners
description: O.K., so maybe it doesn't have the ring of Academy of St. Martin in the Fields or Orchestre de la Suisse Romande. But when it comes to putting live classical music where the people are, the New York City Housing Authority Symphony plays second fiddle to none.

title: N.F.L. TRAINING CAMP REPORT
description: Dallas Cowboys

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a breakfast meeting in Washington with the political consultant Edward J. Rollins Jr. misattributed a comment made at the meeting. It was Mr. Rollins, and not the breakfast host, Godfrey Sperling Jr. of the Christian Science Monitor, who said, ''There's always some misleading that goes on in the course of this town and its business.''

title: Public Favors The Democrats, New Poll Finds
description: For the first time in four years, the Democratic Party is viewed more favorably by voters than the Republican Party, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: MARRIOTT INTERNATIONAL SELLS COMMUNITIES FOR ELDERLY
description: Marriott International Inc. said yesterday that it had sold four assisted-living communities for the elderly to National Health Investors Inc. for $54 million. Marriott International, a hotel-management company based in Bethesda, Md., said it would continue to operate the centers under a long-term lease. The centers, called Brighton Gardens, are in Dallas; Edison, N.J.; and Maitland and West Palm Beach, Fla. Marriott International said the sale was part of its plan to concentrate on developing and managing operations rather than owning real estate. The Host Marriott Corporation, from which Marriott International was split three years ago, owns many of the hotels that Marriott International manages. National Health Investors is a real estate investment trust based in Murfreesboro, Tenn.

title: Intel Is Delaying Introduction of a New Chip
description: The Intel Corporation said yesterday that it was delaying introduction of a Pentium chip with enhanced multimedia capabilities because it could not produce enough high-speed versions of the processor.

title: Queens Man Arrested in Killings Of Family Members 7 Years Ago
description: A 31-year-old Queens man long suspected of killing his cousin and her two sons seven years ago was charged with their murders today based on evidence from DNA testing, Suffolk County authorities said.

title: No Headline
description: ''It brings you back to the days when there was no Internet. We can fax and retype documents, but it certainly isn't as efficient.''

title: In Republican State, Dole Finds Himself Lagging Behind
description: In the 1964 campaign, old-timers in Pennsylvania politics say, Senator Hugh Scott, a moderate Republican, fled to the western end of the state every time the party's conservative Presidential nominee, Barry Goldwater, visited the eastern end and vice versa.

title: Appeal by Minister Won't Be Blocked
description: The Bronx District Attorney said yesterday that he would not try to block an appeal in the state courts for a Methodist minister who was imprisoned for a decade on a conviction of sexually abusing children.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It is not safe to be in the restaurant business.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: N.A.S.D. and Government

title: Drug Merger Displaces 1,800
description: The Ciba-Geigy Corporation, a pharmaceutical giant, said yesterday that it did not know yet how many people would lose their jobs out of the 1,800 who will be displaced from the company's Summit plant to prepare for a $27 billion merger with Sandoz. Gloria Martini, a spokeswoman for Ciba-Geigy, said 400 of the company's 2,200 workers in Summit would stay there, while the rest would be dismissed or moved to an East Hanover plant where Sandoz now employs 2,100 workers. The merger, pending before the Federal Trade Commission, would create the world's second-largest pharmaceutical company.

title: Chicken A la East Hampton
description: WHAT did the analyst say to the chicken farmer?

title: Thorpe Agrees to 3-Year Piston Pact
description: OTIS THORPE knew it was strictly business that the Detroit Pistons made him wait. It turned out, however, to be very good business for the 12-year veteran. Thorpe agreed yesterday to a three-year contract believed to be worth between $15 million and $20 million. The Pistons had to make Thorpe wait because of N.B.A. salary cap considerations.

title: Fed Finds Growth Is in Check as Labor Supply Tightens
description: Economic growth slackened a bit in early summer as consumers spent cautiously for most big-ticket items, a survey by the Federal Reserve of business people around the country found today.

title: Team Owners May Take Labor Dispute Back to Court
description: Baseball's owners took the first official step yesterday toward taking their labor dispute with the players back to court and back into the antagonistic public arena. Randy Levine, the owners' chief labor executive, said the owners' labor policy committee, meeting in Milwaukee, authorized him to make a ''last and final'' offer to the union and proceed to court ''at my discretion.''

title: Experts Say Mars Life Is Still Only Speculative
description: Experts in planetary science and the chemistry of life said yesterday that although NASA's evidence of past life on Mars is suggestive and exciting, it will remain speculative until samples collected directly from Martian rock can be examined and analyzed.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Dividing Bearded Irises

title: Boise State Coach Says Cancer Recurs
description: Six months after reporting that his rare form of cancer was in remission, the Boise State University head football coach, POKEY ALLEN, announced that it has recurred.

title: For Elderly Riders, A Metrocard Hurdle
description: Older riders were supposed to be one group of bus and subway riders that would naturally gravitate to the Transit Authority's Metrocard in place of cash or tokens. But many elderly riders say there are too many barriers to obtaining the card. They argue that acquiring the Metrocards requires too many steps and too long a wait, and forces them to go into the subways, even if they only ride buses.

title: Lai Venuti Lai Gets A Parent Company
description: The LVL Communications Corporation has been formed in Santa Clara, Calif., as the parent company for Lai Venuti Lai Advertising, which specializes in technology accounts; LVL Interactive, and the i-Storm Studios production company. Cal Lai, 40, chairman and chief executive at Lai Venuti Lai Advertising, was named to handle those additional duties at LVL Communications.

title: Annapolis Seeks Ouster Of 15 Cadets For Drug Case
description: The United States Naval Academy has recommended to the Secretary of the Navy that 15 students be expelled from the academy for possessing and using illegal drugs.

title: New York's Jails Require Careful Oversight
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Javelin Thrower Shows Braves His Stuff
description: Jan Zelezny gave a mighty heave and threw the baseball, the first he had ever gripped, over the backstop and into the tarpaulin rolled up beside the infield at Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Akzo Nobel Reports Only Small Profit Drop
description: Akzo Nobel N.V. said yesterday that its earnings fell 4 percent in the second quarter, less than expected, as surprising earnings growth at its coating division offset a deterioration at the fibers business. The company, the largest chemical and drug maker in the Netherlands, earned a net profit of 367 million guilders, or $220 million, against 384 million guilders a year earlier.

title: Will Dole Fight?
description: Before Bob Dole could take on Bill Clinton, he first had to take control of the Republican Party in convention assembled.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in some editions yesterday about the Internal Revenue Service misstated the amount of taxes collected from individuals in the 1995 fiscal year. It was $590.5 billion, not $59.5 billion.

title: PLUM CREEK TO BUY ASSETS FROM RIVERWOOD
description: The Plum Creek Timber Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 538,000 acres of Southern timberland, two sawmills, a plywood factory and a tree nursery from the Riverwood International Corporation for $540 million. The purchase will add to Plum Creek's 2 million acres of timberland and diversify its holdings. The assets being acquired operate under the U.S. Timberlands/Wood Products unit of Riverwood, which is based in Atlanta, and employ 700 people, all of which are expected to be hired by Plum Creek, which is based in Seattle. In March, the New York investment firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice Inc. bought Riverwood from the Manville Corporation and Riverwood shareholders.

title: Jeter Continues Stellar Play, Until the 10th
description: He has been one of the Yankees' hottest hitters lately. Last night, he drove in the tying run with a seventh-inning sacrifice fly. Then, Derek Jeter made two exceptional plays at shortstop in the top of the eighth.

title: A New Day In the Sun For Brahms
description: Batten down the hatches for another Brahms year, this one centering on the 100th anniversary of the composer's death, next April.

title: Suspect in Central Park Attack Is Arraigned in Yonkers Case
description: John J. Royster, the Bronx drifter charged with nearly beating to death a 32-year-old Manhattan piano teacher in Central Park, was arraigned today in Westchester County Court in the rape and assault of a 26-year-old Yonkers woman nearly forgotten in the publicity and public outrage surrounding the Central Park case.

title: Clinton Touts Technology on California Visit
description: President Clinton swept into California today, touting the benefits of technology and holding out an olive branch to Silicon Valley executives whose enthusiasm for him cooled after he vetoed securities legislation last year even though it was passionately sought by the high-tech companies to cut down on lawsuits by shareholders.

title: Can It Be? Germany's Railroads Are Not Running on Time
description: The Government is talking austerity, the labor unions are talking strikes, unification has cost a fortune, jobs are scarce as hens' teeth. And now the trains don't run on time anymore.

title: Yale Denies Reports That Cozza Is Retiring
description: Yale officials yesterday denied recent reports that the longtime football coach CARM COZZA has decided he will retire at the end of this season, but acknowledged he is considering the possibility. STEVE CONN, Yale's sports information director, said Cozza wants to talk with his team during training camp before determining how he feels about the situation.

title: Up a Pond Without a Paddle
description: I'M always complaining about my ponds,'' said Carolyne Roehm, the former fashion designer, glancing toward the extravagant series of interconnecting ponds and waterfalls on what was once a dry meadow at Weatherstone Farm, her sprawling estate in Sharon, Conn.

title: Turner Broadcasting Earnings Down 47.9% in 2d Quarter
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. said today that its second-quarter earnings fell 47.9 percent because of weak results at its Castle Rock Entertainment film unit.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SANYO ELECTRIC CO., Osaka, Japan, said a subsidiary, Three Oceans Inc., would invest $5 million in St. Andrews Golf Corp. of Las Vegas, Nev., a subsidiary of Las Vegas Discount Golf and Tennis Inc., to help finance the construction of an entertainment park.

title: Investment Banks Plan to Merge
description: The Southcoast Capital Corporation and the Brenner Securities Corporation, two closely held investment banks, said this week that they intended to merge.

title: Independent Counsel Law Is Working Just Fine
description: To the Editor:

title: No Traces of a Bomb As Doctors Work On
description: Since Trans World Airlines Flight 800 exploded on July 17, a team of leading medical examiners has worked long hours not only to identify the bodies of victims pulled from the ocean but also to help determine the cause of the crash.

title: Jersey City Schools Improve
description: Seven years into a state takeover of the Jersey City school system, students' scores on standardized tests are showing marked improvement, the State Education Department said yesterday. This past school year, 73 percent of the city's eleventh graders passed tests required for graduation, up from 66 percent in 1994-95. Eighth graders showed similar gains. Peter Peretzman, a spokesman for the department, said that once 85 percent of the city's students have passed standardized tests, the state would consider relinquishing control of the district.

title: Revived Watson Has Just One Hole Left
description: There is a look on Tom Watson's face these days, a sort of serene smile, a confident expression that says more about his state of mind coming into this week's P.G.A. Championship than words ever could.

title: 5 Counties on Migration List
description: Five New Jersey counties are among the 50 in the nation most affected by immigration, the Washington-based Center for Immigration Studies reported yesterday. The center, which supports cuts in legal immigration, used census and immigration statistics to compile an ''immigration index'' based on the percentage of residents who are foreign-born, speak English poorly or speak a language other than English at home. Hudson County, which has many immigrants from Latin America and the Indian subcontinent, was ranked ninth in the nation. Passaic, Union, Bergen and Essex were also in the top 50.

title: While the Queen's Away . . .
description: Cleaners on scaffolding dragged six-foot-long feather dusters across plaster cornices, painters retouched a gilded staircase, antique sofas were carried out for reupholstering. Minions with portable vacuums strapped to their waists gently cleaned dust from the green silk curtains patterned after the originals ordered by William IV's wife, Adelaide, in order to give employment to Irish weavers.

title: GOLDMAN SACHS TRUST BUYS BOSTON GLOBAL ADVISORS
description: The Goldman Sachs Trust Company said yesterday that it had acquired Boston Global Advisors Inc., a provider of securities lending services to institutional investors, from Paloma Partners L.L.C. of Greenwich, Conn., for more than $10 million. Securities lending occurs when firms lend their own or their clients' portfolios of securities to brokerage firms which use them to complete transactions. The Goldman Sachs Trust Company, a New York trust bank, is a subsidiary of Goldman Sachs Group L.P., the Wall Street investment bank.

title: Along a Road of Battles, 'No Trespassing' Signs
description: WHAT WOMEN WANT

title: Agents Search Office of Valujet's Ex-Contractor
description: F.B.I. agents today shut down and searched the Miami office of an airline maintenance company, looking for information related to the crash of Valujet Flight 592, which plunged into the Everglades on May 11, killing all 110 people aboard.

title: Questions Raised on Development Zones
description: Nearly a decade ago, New York began an ambitious program to spur economic growth in distressed communities across the state by offering businesses tax breaks and other handsome incentives to move into those communities.

title: Financial Publisher Faces Fraud Charges
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has filed fraud charges against Yale Hirsch, a publisher of investment newsletters, contending that he accepted payments to tout a stock.

title: Dresdner Bank Posts Earnings Rise
description: Dresdner Bank A.G., the second- largest bank in Germany, said yesterday that its operating earnings rose 44 percent in the first half of 1996. The bank cited favorable conditions in the securities markets as the primary reason for growth.

title: Malaysian Company To Buy Brierley Stake
description: Malex Industries, a maker of fiber cement products that is based in Malaysia, said yesterday that it would buy a 20 percent stake in Brierley Investments Ltd. of New Zealand in a transaction valued at 1.42 billion Malaysian ringgit, or $570 million. Brierley, the fourth-largest publicly traded company in New Zealand, has interests in aviation, hotels, retailing and construction materials, in Australia, New Zealand and Britain.

title: Boosey & Hawkes Deal
description: Boosey & Hawkes P.L.C., a British music company, said this week that it would pay up to $27.5 million to acquire Rico International, a manufacturer of reeds used in musical instruments. Boosey & Hawkes makes brass, woodwind and string instruments, publishes sheet music and provides music for radio and television programs and advertising. Rico International makes its reeds for the mouthpieces of clarinets and saxophones at a manufacturing operation in Sun Valley, Calif.

title: The Nation's new welfare law is really reform on a shoestring
description: To Congressional Republicans, the new welfare law is a once-in-a-generation opportunity to replace a 60-year-old system that does not work. To Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the new approach is ''a social risk no sane person would take.'' So which is it? To many welfare experts outside the political rough and tumble, it appears to be both.

title: Those Movie Previews May Signal Flops
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Companies Ask Children How to Sell to Children
description: Meet Leah Mosner, a consultant for the Microsoft Corporation.

title: Police Press Intense Hunt for Sniper in Shooting of Detective Saved by Vest in Brooklyn
description: Scores of detectives and police officers went door to door through housing projects in Brooklyn yesterday in an intense manhunt for the sniper who shot a detective assigned to an anti-drug crackdown in Brownsville. The detective, who was saved by his bulletproof vest, left the hospital and immediately returned to the scene of the shooting to aid in the investigation.

title: An American Crusader Bent on Healing a European Scar
description: Jet lag does not seem to exist for Dr. Mira P. Brichto. At home in Cincinnati one recent morning, even before preparing treats for her five grandchildren, Dr. Brichto was making phone calls about two shipments of donated medical supplies destined for Eastern Europe.

title: How to Get Rich Exporting Jobs
description: ''CBS Reports'' draws blood tonight from such coldblooded neologisms as ''downsizing'' and ''outsourcing,'' bringing before the camera the downsized, outsourced people whose onetime employers are now doing their producing in other countries.

title: NEWS SERVICE CHIEF RESIGNS, THEN VOWS TO RETURN
description: The founder of Individual Inc., a provider of customized electronic news services, said yesterday he would resign as chief executive, two weeks after he took a leave from the company in a dispute with its board about the pace of acquisitions and investments. But later yesterday, the founder, Yosi Amram, called a special shareholder meeting and said he would fight to regain his position at the company, which is based in Burlington, Mass., if no agreement was reached with the board. Mr. Amram, who owns a 13.2 percent equity stake in the company, said he would request that ''an independent committee be created to evaluate the performance of the board members.''

title: Pfizer Is Told to End Claims About Antidepressant's Uses
description: In a stern warning letter, the Food and Drug Administration has ordered Pfizer Inc. to stop making unauthorized and misleading medical claims for Zoloft, its widely used treatment for episodes of severe depression.

title: Strawberry Provides Blast to the Past
description: For a ballplayer who has 303 career home runs, Darryl Strawberry was quick to insist that he does not seek them out.

title: Reid Basks in Golden Glow
description: The last time Oscar De La Hoya spoke to David Reid, he was offering Reid advice before the Olympic Games in Atlanta. De La Hoya had won a gold medal for the United States in Barcelona, Spain, four years earlier.

title: For Bicyclists Who Welcome A Little Help (Mostly Uphill)
description: ON steamy summer days in the nation's capital, commuters on their bicycles toil up the long hill from Embassy Row, past the Vice President's mansion and to the heights where the National Cathedral towers over the city and its nearby suburbs.

title: MetroStars Set to Name Player to Be Named
description: The MetroStars are finally close to getting the fifth allocated player they are entitled to as a replacement for Ruben Dario Hernandez, who returned to his native Colombia almost two months ago. Charlie Stillitano, the vice president and general manager of the Major League Soccer team, said yesterday that the MetroStars would have their last player before Monday.

title: Once More, Mets Stage Rallies to Save Everybody's Face
description: If there's one positive trait the Mets have displayed this season of highs and lows, it is their never-give-up attitude -- even when a situation seems hopeless.

title: A Nazi's Flawed Trial
description: On March 24, 1944, SS Capt. Erich Priebke and several colleagues rounded up 335 Italian men and boys, took them to the Ardeatine Caves south of Rome and shot them in the backs of their heads. Mr. Priebke allegedly checked off the victims' names before the massacre, which was a reprisal for the killing of 33 Nazi soldiers by Italian partisans the day before. Fifty years later he was caught. But last week a botched trial in an Italian court set Mr. Priebke free. Italy quickly rearrested him, and must now move to fix this miscarriage of justice or pass him to a nation that will.

title: Hostility to Whistle-Blowers Is Cited in A-Plant Problems
description: Northeast Utilities's hostility toward employees who raised safety concerns at its Millstone Point nuclear plants contributed to the breakdown in standards that eventually led to their shutdown by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, a commission panel reported today.

title: New Delhi Sets Dates for State Elections in Battle-Torn Kashmir
description: With an announcement of dates for an election next month in the part of Kashmir under its control, the Indian Government took a decisive step today toward carrying out its formula for peace in a territory -- India's only state with a Muslim majority -- that has been the scene of a convulsive war between Indian forces and separatist Muslim guerrillas.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17

title: Apple Computer Shifts Course on Its New Operating System
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it had scrapped plans for a major upgrade of its flagship Macintosh operating system software next year, and would instead roll out key features of the new code on a regular but piecemeal basis from now on.

title: Ex-Official Accused of Theft
description: A former aide to the Mayor of Wildwood has been indicted on charges that he embezzled more than $14,000 from the city and county. John Wallace was charged Tuesday with forging signatures of members of the city's tourism commission on $6,350 in checks, Stephen D. Moore, the Cape May County Prosecutor, said yesterday. Mr. Wallace and his wife are also accused of fraudulently obtaining about $8,000 in county welfare benefits between 1993 and 1995, when Mr. Wallace was an aide to Mayor Fred Wager.

title: Jackboots in Sandals
description: ''Sooner or later, it seems, everyone moves to Seattle . . . a place whose population . . . is essentially stable. . . .'' -- Newsweek

title: Bridge
description: One of North America's greatest veteran players competed today at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer National Championships.

title: Ad Council Work Focuses on Children
description: Two pro bono campaigns centering on children are being introduced by the Advertising Council, the advertising industry's public service organization in New York.

title: Throwing Out The Disabled, Or the Fraud?
description: SECTION 212 can be found about a quarter of the way into Washington's omnibus new welfare bill, under the numbing title ''Eligibility Redeterminations and Continuing Disability Reviews.'' It is, literally speaking, about assistance to disabled children.

title: Korean Car Maker Plans to Enter U.S. With Its Own Outlets
description: A South Korean manufacturer, with ambitious plans to sell cars around the world, said today that it intended to enter the United States market by opening 200 to 500 company-owned sales outlets in the next several years near college campuses.

title: Zulu Crash Course Doesn't Fit the Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: GUESS OFFERS STOCK AT LOW END OF EXPECTED RANGE
description: Guess Inc., the maker of jeans and other apparel, priced its initial public offering of stock yesterday at $18 a share, at the low end of the expected range. The share price and the number of shares to be sold have both been cut from the original plan, as the market for initial offerings has weakened over all. Guess initially intended to sell 9.2 million shares, or a 22 percent stake in the company, at $21 to $23 a share. This week, the price range was cut to $18 to $20 before being set yesterday at $18, for 7 million shares, or a 17 percent stake. The lead underwriter for the offering, which values the company at $754 million, is Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Prosecutor of Kevorkian Loses Re-election Bid
description: Richard Thompson, the county prosecutor who unsuccessfully fought for years to stop Dr. Jack Kevorkian, was easily defeated on Tuesday in a Republican primary election that was widely seen as a referendum on his handling of the issue of assisted suicide.

title: IRISH GROUP BUYS SALOMON'S BRITISH MORTGAGE UNIT
description: Salomon Inc. said yesterday that it had sold its British mortgage lending unit to the First National Building Society of Ireland for $:53 million, or $81.6 million. Salomon Inc., the parent company of Salomon Brothers, put the unit, the Mortgage Corporation, up for sale in February as part of a strategy to shed businesses not connected to its main securities activities. Salomon said the price for TMC Group represented a premium of $:33 million to its book value.

title: Tandem Chooses Anderson & Lembke
description: Tandem Computers in Cupertino, Calif., has named the San Francisco office of Anderson & Lembke to handle its account, which had been previously handled by the FCB Technology unit of True North Communications in San Francisco. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Dollar Gains as Fears Fade About Japanese Rate Increase
description: The dollar surged against the yen yesterday after the head of the Bank of Japan eased concern that Japan would soon raise interest rates.

title: Big News for Earthlings
description: There are defining moments in every epoch that capture the period's unique characteristics and change the course of history. The defining moment of the space age could well be the discovery that we are not alone in the universe.

title: The 10 major advertising makeovers done for 'Grease,' however painful, have paid off.
description: THERE is a moment of considerable anxiety for the creative teams at the advertising agencies hired by Fran and Barry Weissler, the Broadway producers of ''Grease.''

title: William Schoenfeld, Behaviorist And Psychology Professor, 80
description: William N. Schoenfeld, a behaviorist who helped establish psychology as a solid scientific discipline at American universities, died on Saturday at his home in Sun City West, Ariz. He was 80.

title: Public Scrutiny for Lawyers
description: New York State's Chief Judge, Judith Kaye, has announced a useful and overdue series of steps to lift standards in the legal profession and open the system for disciplining unscrupulous lawyers to greater public scrutiny.

title: A Rousing Send-Off for a Fit Cigar
description: They flocked to the race track at 6:45 today on a hot summer morning to watch him in his final dress rehearsal. And they saw the great Cigar make a regal farewell appearance before flying 3,000 miles on another journey into history.

title: Rodman to Treat Olympian and Parents
description: AMANDA BEARD, the 14-year-old Olympic swimming gold medalist, has an important event coming up today. She's going to a California Angels game with the flamboyant Chicago Bulls star DENNIS RODMAN and her parents.

title: In Blow to Mexican Government, Suspect in Slaying Is Cleared
description: The Government's efforts to clarify the 1994 assassination of Mexico's leading presidential candidate all but collapsed today with the acquittal of the governing-party worker charged last year as the second triggerman in the shooting.

title: Governing Costs Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Vetoes a Bill to Make City Contractors Raise Wages
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday vetoed a bill that would have required some city contractors to pay higher minimum wages to their employees, calling the measure irresponsible because it would add to the city's costs while also hurting minimum-wage workers.

title: Some Cured of Sickle Cell Disease By Transplants of Bone Marrow
description: A major international study has shown that bone marrow transplants can cure sickle cell disease in some children, a finding that experts say could herald a new era in treating the inherited blood disease.

title: Ex-Driver Claims AIDS Bias
description: A bus driver who says he was dismissed after telling his supervisors that he had the virus that causes AIDS filed a discrimination suit yesterday against his employer, Academy Bus Tours. The 42-year-old driver, identified in court papers only as John Doe, wants his job back along with money he would have earned since his dismissal last October, plus damages. The driver's lawyer, Richard M. Schall, said that his client had no AIDS symptoms and was able to do his job. James Tooman, human resources director for the Hoboken-based bus company, said he had not seen the lawsuit and could not comment.

title: Data Network Fails, Vexing Small Business
description: In the most extensive network blackout yet in cyberspace, America Online, the nation's largest operator of an on-line computer network, was out of action yesterday, leaving its six million subscribers, including many small businesses and home-office workers, without electronic mail and other key communications services.

title: EUROPE APPROVES OIL COMPANIES' JOINT OPERATIONS
description: British Petroleum P.L.C. and the Mobil Corporation said yesterday that they had received approval from the European Commission for a plan to combine their oil refining and marketing operations in Europe. The companies plan to combine $3.4 billion in B.P. assets and $1.6 billion in Mobil assets to create partnerships across Europe with annual sales of more than $20 billion. Several partnerships are expected to be operational by year's end, with all to be completed by the end of 1997, they said. B.P., based in London, and Mobil, based in Fairfax, Va., said they planned to set up a headquarters in Brussels for the venture.

title: Hope Is Slim For Recovery Of Last Bodies
description: Divers have not recovered any bodies from the wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 in the last 48 hours, and investigators said today they would not be surprised if no more remains were discovered.

title: Rebels Overrun Russian Troops In Chechen City
description: Chechen rebels dedicated to humiliating President Boris N. Yeltsin on the eve of his inaugural took virtual control of their republic's ruined capital today, killing scores of Russian soldiers, wounding hundreds more and sending rings of fire spreading across the city.

title: A Philharmonic Program As Varied as a Chinese Menu
description: In keeping with the grab-bag approach of the Lincoln Center Festival '96, absolutely no thematic thread connected the works that Kurt Masur performed with the New York Philharmonic on Tuesday night.

title: It's Not Greed
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Up on Hope That Demand Will Absorb Flow From Iraq
description: Crude oil prices rebounded yesterday from an initial drop on the New York Mercantile Exchange, amid optimism that world markets were strong enough to absorb a sale of Iraqi oil.

title: Hernan Siles Zuazo, Ex-President of Bolivia, Is Dead at 83
description: Hernan Siles Zuazo, the former President of Bolivia who was one of the chief engineers in moving the country toward political freedom, died on Tuesday night at a hospital in Montevideo, Uruguay, where he lived in retirement. He was 83.

title: New Indy Event in Colorado
description: The Indy Racing League, the Indy-car series started by the Indianapolis Motor Speedway this year, announced a new event yesterday for June 29, 1997, at the currently uncompleted Pikes Peak International Raceway in Fountain, Colo.

title: Forging a Cool Trail in Midtown, One Block at a Time
description: I TRIUMPHED over nature. I walked from East 57th Street and Madison Avenue to 42d and Fifth on a sultry summer afternoon and stayed cool -- by almost never going outside.

title: Just Hold the Speeches, At Least Until Later
description: Like almost everything else in the House, its quaint tradition of one-minute speeches at the beginning of each day has fallen into the hands of political aides who guide its acrimonious sessions.

title: Maddox Move Has Giants Looking Up Reeves's Sleeve
description: So who is Tommy Maddox and why all the fuss about him? Maddox is someone who seems to be different things to different people. To some, he is a tool being used by Giants Coach Dan Reeves to strike at the front office -- with which he feuds -- and to put the No. 1 quarterback Dave Brown in his place. To Reeves, Maddox is simply a talented quarterback, maybe the best on his team.

title: Dole Backs New Options For Auto Insurance
description: While Bob Dole's proposal of an across-the-board 15 percent tax cut has gotten all the attention, buried within his economic plan is a virtually unnoticed initiative to remake the nation's auto insurance system that could be worth billions of dollars to American drivers -- without requiring painful spending cuts or threatening to increase the budget deficit.

title: Stock-Fund Flows Off Sharply: A Warning Flare?
description: The amount of money flowing into stock mutual funds fell sharply in July to its lowest level in almost two years, an industry group reported yesterday, an ominous sign for the stock market that perhaps signals the end to a period of record growth in the fund industry.

title: Green on the Hot Seat During the August Heat
description: General Manager Joe McIlvaine insists he remains ''open-minded'' on whether to retain Dallas Green as the Mets' manager for next season and said today that a final decision would not be made for a few weeks. But with the Mets' faint wild-card hopes being deteriorated by injuries and lackluster performances, it seems only a drastic turn of events can keep Green from being the scapegoat for the team's disappointing season.

title: NBC's Olympic Canard
description: To the Editor:

title: Divide and Conquer
description: SOFA nightmare stories are nothing new. Picking out a sofa provides enough drama, but the plot thickens upon delivery: how many sofas have been abandoned near the service entrance because they couldn't fit into an elevator or up too-narrow stairs?

title: Poles No Place for Posters
description: With election season around the corner, Mayor Bret Schundler of Jersey City is warning campaign workers not to go to the poles -- utility poles, that is. In a city where campaign posters stapled over fliers for garage sales and lost pets have long littered the political landscape, Mr. Schundler has ordered city workers to begin enforcing an anti-littering ordinance that makes it illegal to attach posters to utility poles or other public property.

title: Abortion Opponents Prevail In 3 Republican Primaries
description: After campaigns that reinforced the Republican divide over abortion, voters in Georgia, Michigan and Kansas on Tuesday chose opponents of abortion rights over supporters of abortion rights in Republican primaries for the United States Senate.

title: New-Media Industry Lures Creative Energy
description: The other day, Derek A. Baker, an unassuming, churchgoing former Oklahoman, sat in his office piled with computer books and software and remarked on the eternally repeating cycles of New York City: people like him -- writers, artists, hungry capitalists -- have always come here seeking success. And from his seat as an old-timer in the new-media industry of New York, he said he felt he was watching that unfold once again.

title: 3d Victim of Shootout Dies
description: A third victim of Monday's shootout at the Deptford Mall died last night. Maureen Lavin, 15, of Swedesboro died of a gunshot wound to the head. Ms. Lavin had been hit by a stray bullet when a would-be robber exchanged gunfire with an armored-car guard. The guard, Rudolph Matlack, was listed in stable condition yesterday at Cooper Hospital-University Medical Center. The gunman, Vincent Reid, and another bystander died at the scene. Investigators who have been studying a bank surveillance videotape said yesterday that they had identified two men who may have also taken part in the robbery attempt.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: Tennessee

title: For Elderly, Getting Half-Fare Metrocards Is No Easy Ride
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority says it would love it if people would adopt the Metrocard, forsaking cash and the token. Try telling that to 71-year-old Gemma Fastiggi.

title: Moscow's Rich Flaunt Rottweilers
description: CLIFF is tethered at three angles, a King Kong among Rottweilers. As prospective buyers inspect the dozing puppies in the baby pen just beyond Cliff's reach, his mild-mannered owner yanks his chain. Cliff erupts in a slobbering frenzy of rage. The onlookers nod reverently before moving on; a square-head Staffordshire terrier is putting on the same show a few feet away.

title: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp.
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, the largest hospital chain in the United States, reported a $364 million second-quarter profit yesterday, in contrast to an $18 million loss in the period last year, which it attributed to its merger with the Healthtrust hospital chain.

title: Detective Tied To a Beating Outside Club Quits Force
description: A detective who is accused in a racial beating of a young black man outside a Long Island discotheque resigned yesterday from the New York City Police Department.

title: Mutilation of Egyptian Girls: Despite Ban, It Goes On
description: In the weeks since the Egyptian Health Minister banned the ritual genital mutilation of girls, no one in this Nile Delta farming town has consulted the senior local cleric on whether to proceed with the custom. People plan to do it anyway.

title: Move by Toyota Reported Into Japanese Chip Market
description: An affiliate of the Toyota Motor Corporation is planning a major expansion into the Japanese semiconductor business through a joint venture with Texas Instruments, Japan's leading business newspaper reported today.

title: U.S. Removes Bar on Sale Of Oil to Aid Iraqi Civilians
description: The United States today removed the last major roadblock to the sale of Iraqi oil to pay for emergency civilian needs, and United Nations officials said they hoped to put the plan into effect within a few weeks.

title: Nets Pick Up a Bargain as Benoit Signs Up
description: It seems as twisted as a spin move, but David Benoit held out for less during free agency. And he got what he wanted, a small salary and the New Jersey Nets.

title: Give Ukraine a Break
description: Two years ago, Ukraine seemed like a lost cause. A separatist had been elected president of the Crimean region, and the C.I.A. predicted Ukraine would break up. Hyperinflation of more than 10,000 percent raged, and the average monthly wage had slumped to $11.

title: The Ice Cream Caper: Hot Truck, Cold Cargo
description: Perhaps it was the return of warmer weather. Or maybe it was just a sudden craving.

title: Clinton Says Dole's Plan Would Bust The Budget
description: Savoring a last moment in the California spotlight before the Republican National Convention takes center stage, President Clinton today ridiculed Bob Dole's sweeping plan for $548 billion in tax cuts over the next six years and promised that he himself would not offer any tax cuts that jeopardized a balancing of the Federal budget.

title: SUNBEAM DISMISSES THREE TOP EXECUTIVES
description: The Sunbeam Corporation dismissed three top executives yesterday as it continues to make rapid changes to its management under its new chairman and chief executive, Albert Dunlap. Gone from the consumer-products concern, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., are the chief financial officer, Paul M. O'Hara; the president of the household products group, Richard L. Boynton, and the vice president of strategic planning for North America, Michael R. Beauregard. Mr. O'Hara was succeeded by Russell A. Kersh, executive vice president for finance and administration, who will retain his current titles. Spencer Volk, head of international operations, will temporarily head the household products group. The company has not determined whether it will fill Mr. Beauregard's position.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the Government's approval of the first urine test to detect H.I.V., the AIDS virus, misspelled the name of the company that will market the test. It is Seradyn (not Seradun) Inc.

title: OSHKOSH TRUCK TO BUY PIERCE MANUFACTURING
description: The Oshkosh Truck Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Pierce Manufacturing Inc., a privately owned maker of fire trucks, for $158 million. Pierce Manufacturing, which is based in Appleton, Wis., had sales of $180 million for the fiscal year that ended on Oct. 31. Oshkosh Truck, which has annual sales of $400 million, makes airport firefighting vehicles and snow emergency vehicles. The company, which is based in Oshkosh, Wis., also supplies heavy-duty trucks to the Defense Department.

title: Myanmar Sanctions Are Wrong Approach
description: To the Editor:

title: At Office Of Campaign, A Protest On Welfare
description: It was intended as a celebration of Bill Clinton's strong support among New York Democrats. The opening of the Clinton-Gore campaign's New York headquarters at 300 Park Avenue yesterday was a made-for-television event that brought out the firmament of the state's best-known Democrats: former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, former Mayor David N. Dinkins, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and a throng of congressmen, City Council members and state legislators.

title: Diner's Journal
description: I've been dreaming about the watermelon parfait.

title: Bettis Eager for a New Start With Steelers
description: Jerome Bettis got an introduction to the Steelers' offense well before he was traded from St. Louis to Pittsburgh last April. Steelers Coach Bill Cowher had it on display at the 1994 Pro Bowl in Honolulu. Cowher was coaching the American Football Conference squad and Bettis was one of the running backs for the National Football Conference.

title: Frozen Embryos Weren't 'Destroyed'
description: To the Editor:

title: Hicks, Muse and Travelers in Mexico Deal
description: A group led by Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. and Travelers Group Inc. agreed yesterday to buy $153 million of the stock of the Mexican insurer Seguros Comercial America.

title: Islanders Pursuing Roenick
description: It appears that Jeremy Roenick, the Chicago Blackhawks' gifted 26-year-old center and a restricted free agent, will be traded -- perhaps as soon as this weekend. And, if Islanders General Manager Mike Milbury has any say in the matter, it may be to his team.

title: Genetic Mutation Linked To Some AIDS Protection
description: A genetic mutation protects some people from infection with the AIDS virus even when they are repeatedly exposed to it through sex, two groups of scientists reported yesterday.

title: Honors
description: * The Advertising Club of New York Foundation has awarded more than $100,000 in academic grants to New York City high schools and to undergraduate and graduate college students.

title: A Muted Kremlin Inauguration
description: With his health in doubt, the war in Chechnya flaring and the Russian economy at a critical juncture, Boris Yeltsin begins his second term as President today with diminished expectations. Even the opulent inaugural ceremony once planned for the Kremlin's Cathedral Square has been scaled back and moved inside to reduce the strain on the ailing Mr. Yeltsin, who will apparently begin his new term by taking a long rest.

title: Kariya to Miss World Cup
description: First it was MARIO LEMIEUX. Now PAUL KARIYA of the Anaheim Mighty Ducks has withdrawn from Canada's entry in the coming World Cup of Hockey.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Wednesday comparing Quaker Oats' shares of seven food and beverage market categories with those of competitors carried an incorrect label on a bar breaking down the market in rice cakes. Quaker does have 77.6 percent of the market, but the second leading company, with 8.9 percent of the market, is the Hain Food Group Inc., not Pillsbury, which does not make rice cakes. The rest of the market is scattered in smaller shares.

title: Life at Stake. Must Act Fast. How to Decide?
description: Focusing on three life-or-death cases at the University of Chicago Medical Center, ''Dateline NBC'' brings home the excruciating decisions that are covered today by the bland phrase medical ethics. The current perplexities are side effects of the medical wonders of recent years, in particular an ability, at high cost, to sustain life that does not resemble living. Tonight's report pays particular attention to the doctors on the line.

title: Parables That Blend Love and Philosophy
description: Eric Rohmer's ''Rendezvous in Paris'' is an oasis of contemplative intelligence in the summer movie season, presenting three graceful and elegant parables with the moral agility that distinguishes Mr. Rohmer as the Aesop of amour. Precise, simple and deeply serious beneath their breezy and seductive surface, these stories enchantingly explore love's little treacheries and the stubborn immutability of human nature.

title: Like It or Not, Teams Brace for World Cup
description: Ask Neil Smith, National Hockey League executive, what he thinks about this month's inaugural World Cup in his sport and he will tell you, ''It's a positive thing for hockey.''

title: News Summary
description: International A2-12

title: A New Fashion Attitude by Women? Maybe
description: To the Editor:

title: Investigators Know More, but Not What Caused Crash
description: Since Trans World Airlines Flight 800 went down three weeks ago, virtually every one of the daily briefings on the Federal investigation has included the same discouraging moment. That is when James K. Kallstrom, the F.B.I. supervisor, recites a toll-free number and an E-mail address, then appeals for the public's help. He did it again yesterday.

description: Myron Lechay

title: Mugged In the Hospital
description: What is a woman supposed to do when, two days after major surgery, her health maintenance organization tells her she must leave the hospital and her physician insists that she stay put?
