description: From Dusk Till Dawn

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Restoration

title: Stanley B. Sussman; Conductor Was 58
description: Stanley B. Sussman, principal conductor for the Martha Graham Dance Company and the Cleveland-San Jose Ballet, was found dead on July 29 in his apartment in the Ansonia Hotel on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 58.

title: Washington's Democratic Mayor Is Wooing the G.O.P.
description: Some delegates to the Republican National Convention here face a social dilemma on Sunday night: Whether to attend the Salute to Newt Gingrich at Sea World -- or the reception being held by Marion S. Barry Jr., the Democratic Mayor of Washington.

title: Birthplace of Solidarity Is in Bankruptcy
description: A court declared the Gdansk shipyard bankrupt yesterday, months after the birthplace of the Solidarity movement in Poland disclosed it could no longer stay afloat in a free-market economy. Strikes at the shipyard in 1980 led to the creation of the trade union.

title: A Franchiser Is Selling Homes and All the Trimmings
description: The Time: Soon

title: Art in Review
description: Myung Ock Lim

title: Jefferson's Nightmare
description: The days leading up to the Republican Convention in San Diego have made plain a fact of exceptional significance. For the first time in United States history, a major political party is driven by religion.

title: 'Mad Cow' Shock Waves Unsettle the Synagogues of Paris
description: Panic about the possibility of catching the brain-destroying mad cow disease from eating meat has plunged the Jewish religious establishment in Paris into financial crisis and labor strife.

title: PATAKI SIGNS BILL SEEKING TO COMBAT DOMESTIC VIOLENCE
description: Giving more protection to victims of domestic violence, Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation yesterday that stiffens penalties for defying restraining orders and creates a wider range of violations.

title: A Body That Grows Up Before Its Owner Does
description: Francis Ford Coppola's ''Jack'' is about a boy whose body ages at four times the normal rate. His condition is peculiar and the film is, too, despite Mr. Coppola's best (and sometimes successful) efforts to keep it enjoyably light. While ''Jack'' has the egregious earmarks of a tritely inspirational story, it also has some unexpected flashes of real emotion. Within the limits and cliches of utterly predictable material, Mr. Coppola is still finally able to make this one from the heart.

title: As Sugar Fades, Hawaii Seeks a New Cash Crop
description: Herbert Cambra's grandfather hacked the wrist-thick tentacles of cane with a machete for 50 cents a day. Mr. Cambra's father handled the machines that crushed the giant grass and boiled its juice. Mr. Cambra himself drives the monstrous trucks that move the tangled stalks to the mill.

title: Lasorda Cannot Stay Away
description: TOMMY LASORDA, who retired as manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers last week, is spending three days in Albuquerque, N.M., with the Dukes, the Dodgers' Class AAA farm team, to evaluate prospects. In 1972, he managed the Dukes to a Pacific Coast League championship.

title: Stocks Retreat As Rates Rise; Dow Off 5.18
description: Stocks retreated for the second time this week as rising Treasury bond yields threatened to make financial and telephone shares less attractive, and the Procter & Gamble Company slumped.

title: Union Carbide and Exxon Unit in Venture
description: The Union Carbide Corporation and a unit of the Exxon Corporation said yesterday that they had agreed to form a joint venture to improve production processes for polyethylene, the most widely used plastic.

title: As Candidate, Dole Casts Off His Feats as a Skilled Senator
description: A few days into the first campaign swing by Bob Dole as a private citizen, he was asked to list some of the accomplishments that, looking back over his long tenure in the Senate, he was most proud of.

title: Sinking in Polls, French Conservatives Stand Firm on Spending
description: President Jacques Chirac and his conservative Government did little to make themselves more popular before joining the rest of the country on vacation this week, holding Government spending this year and next to $300 billion so that France can join the European common currency planned for the end of the decade.

title: Report on Earnings Lifts Shares of Nokia
description: The shares of Nokia Oy, the Finnish maker of mobile telephones, rose 10 percent yesterday after the company said its earnings in the second quarter fell less than expected and that profits would rise in the future.

title: Strawberry Knocks Sox Off With Two More Homers
description: The 35,898 fans would not let Darryl Strawberry sit down in the dugout. Not until they spied his bald head or one of his beefy hands or something to prove that he knew that they knew his second homer was indeed special. Finally, after 30 long, loud seconds, Strawberry and his shiny head peered out of the dugout and he waved. Then he sat down.

title: Masterworks on Vacation at the Met
description: Some people send their little Matthew or Jeremy to camp for the summer. Then there are those who send their little Giambattista or Louis-Leopold to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: New Life for a New Jersey Development
description: A housing development that was begun on the site of a former quarry in West Orange, N.J., in the 1980's and later abandoned is being revived by new owners, but at a much smaller scale.

title: Democrats To Pursue Pataki Case
description: The Democratic leaders of the State Assembly said today that they would appeal a court ruling restricting their authority to investigate the corporations that raised $2.6 million for Gov. George E. Pataki's inauguration and transition.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Everything Is Real'

title: 2 Caddies Protest No Shorts
description: The stifling combination of heat and humidity that has gripped Valhalla Golf Club all week sparked the first controversy of this year's P.G.A. Championship.

title: EQUITABLE COS. (EQ,N)
description: The Equitable Companies said yesterday that second-quarter earnings rose 9.7 percent as profit doubled at its Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. brokerage unit.

title: Art in Review
description: Larry Poons

title: P. & G.'s Net Rose 17.4% In 4th Quarter
description: Procter & Gamble reported a 17.4 percent gain in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, with higher profit margins, despite heightened competition in the diaper business and an increased tax rate.

title: No Place Like Home In the P.G.A.
description: Perhaps the mythological Norse gods decided to toss a little cold water on the hot party the guys were cooking up down here at Valhalla, the golf club named after their banquet hall. Maybe Thor, god of war, thunder and strength, decided to shake up the proceedings a little bit in the P.G.A. Championship today.

title: Students Plunge Into Union Activities
description: Daniel Lang, a straggly haired Yale sophomore, was getting a crash course in hardball union tactics as he and 11 other students picketed a tidy brick house on a tree-lined street in Queens.

title: In Abortion War, High-Tech Arms
description: They have a ''war room.'' They have ''rapid response capability.'' They have 102 crack infantry whips. And best of all, leaders of the Christian Coalition say, they have the technological weapons -- a hot new wireless, digital paging system -- to give them tactical superiority at the Republican National Convention here.

title: Dred Scott in San Diego
description: The Republican Convention has not started yet but already the delegates writing its platform have violated the meaning of being an American, the nature of America, the spirit of the American Constitution and a specific American ideal that has given it strength at home and glory abroad. Violated? They spat in its face.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Discovery for Giants: Seventh-Round Wonder
description: Every training camp there is a player who comes out of nowhere, from a school few have ever heard of, who was not drafted, or drafted so low he was given little chance to make the team. Then something happens.

title: Atlantans Made An Olympic Effort
description: To the Editor:

title: Human Error And Software Created Data Network Glitch
description: Software bugs and human error combined to create the huge system failure that blacked out America Online for nearly 19 hours on Wednesday, the company said yesterday. It called the failure a ''a coincidental series of sequential events that will most likely never occur again.''

title: Chief of Apple Computer Soothes the Jittery Faithful
description: If there is to be a comeback by Apple Computer, it may be led by true believers like William C. Wantz, a lawyer from Hagerstown, Md., and his 12-year-old son Toby.

title: After a Decade, Juvenile Crime Begins to Drop
description: The nationwide rate of juvenile violent crime fell slightly last year for the first time in almost a decade, and the rate of homicide by juveniles decreased for the second year in a row, down by 15.2 percent, Attorney General Janet Reno said yesterday.

title: 2 British Insurers Forming New Company
description: United Friendly Group P.L.C., a British life insurer, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the life insurer, Refuge Group P.L.C., to form a company valued at about $:1.5 billion, or $2.3 billion. The new company, United Assurance Group P.L.C., will focus on door-to-door sales of life and pensions policies.

title: Cone Is Free and Easy In Torre's Evaluation
description: Joe Torre hustled out of his office like a manager who had just been told George Steinbrenner was holding an emergency meeting in the bullpen. He looked determined and walked in a determined fashion, but Steinbrenner was not even at Yankee Stadium yesterday. Torre was going to see David Cone pitch.

title: Two Women's Bridge Teams Are Upset
description: Almost all the top-ranked teams continued on track here Wednesday in the Spingold Knockout Team Championships at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, but there were two major upsets in the Women's Knockout Teams.

title: U.S. Payment To a Church For Nursing Is Held Illegal
description: In a ruling that could cost Christian Science health care providers millions of dollars, a Federal judge has declared that Medicare and Medicaid reimbursements to the faith's nursing centers violate the constitutional separation of church and state.

title: Chechen Rebel Says Forces Will Pull Out of Capital
description: As Russian troops continued a bitter three-day battle to regain control of Grozny today, a rebel leader in Chechnya stated in an article to be published in Izvestia on Friday that the rebel forces had accomplished their mission and would soon withdraw.

title: PHARMACIA & UPJOHN IN MARKETING PACT WITH GILEAD
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. said yesterday that it would pay Gilead Sciences Inc. $60 million for overseas rights to a drug that helps AIDS patients fight blindness. Pharmacia plans to pay Gilead an initial fee of $10 million for the drug, to be sold under the name Vistide. After receiving European marketing clearance, Pharmacia plans to pay an additional $10 million, and to acquire $40 million of newly issued Gilead preferred shares. Additional financial terms, including royalty payments, were not disclosed. Gilead shares closed at $19.125, up $1.50 in Nasdaq trading. Gilead, based in Foster City, Calif., received Food and Drug Administration approval in June to sell Vistide.

title: TOUGH CRACKDOWN ON NASDAQ MARKET ANNOUNCED BY U.S.
description: The world's second-largest stock market, Nasdaq, has been dominated by a small group of brokers who fixed prices with impunity while those who were charged with regulating the market ignored the illegal behavior, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged today as it announced tough measures to change the way that market is administered.

title: O'Donnell Comes Out Throwing in Losing Effort
description: Whatever the Jets' offense will be this season, it had better bear little resemblance to the attack of the first two exhibition games. Or else.

title: The Rest of the Festival: The Last 3 Days at Lincoln Center
description: Lincoln Center Festival '96, featuring indoor and outdoor performances, runs through Sunday, mainly at locations in and around Lincoln Center. Some performances are free; otherwise, tickets range from $10 to $100. Tickets for the Beckett festival at the John Jay Theater, 899 10th Avenue, between 58th and 59th Streets, are $45 for each performance. Lincoln Center Festival tickets can be purchased at Avery Fisher Hall, the New York State Theater and the Walter Reade Theater, and through Center Charge, (212) 721-6500. Festival hot line: (212) 875-5132. Here is the schedule of festival events:

title: Meatless Fridays Urged as an Abortion Protest
description: John Cardinal O'Connor is urging Roman Catholics to return to the traditional practice of not eating meat on Fridays as a protest if Congress fails to override President Clinton's veto of a bill that would have outlawed certain late-term abortions.

title: Bungee Jumps: Adults Only
description: Bungee jumping in New Jersey will continue to be for adults only, state labor officials have decided. Action Park, an amusement park in Vernon, had asked the state to scrap a rule that requires bungee jumpers to be at least 18 years old and instead to impose a minimum weight limit of 80 pounds, The A.P. reported. But medical experts advised against the change, and Labor Commissioner Peter J. Calderone said yesterday that the age limit would stay.

title: Officials Suspect UN's Chief Sent Aide for African Support
description: GENEVA  Did Boutros Boutros Ghali send a human rights official on a two-week African tour to shore up support for his re-election as United Nations secretary-general in December? Some high-ranking U.S. and European officials here say they suspect that was the case.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: S.E.C. Censures Nasdaq, Citing Price-Fixing

title: Reed Elsevier Profit Rose in First Half
description: The publisher Reed Elsevier P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax earnings rose 12 percent in the first half of 1996, driven by growth in existing businesses and continuing strong sales at its Lexis-Nexis electronic data base unit. Reed also said that it had agreed to pay $:100.5 million, or $155 million, in cash for Tolley Publishing of Britain.

title: Rangers Acquire Burkett
description: The Texas Rangers acquired the right-hander JOHN BURKETT from the Florida Marlins yesterday for RYAN DEMPSTER, 19, a minor league right-hander, and a player to be determined later.

title: An Actor's Portrait, in Noir and White
description: A composite movie image of John Garfield, the most modern of 1940's Hollywood actors, finds him hurrying furtively through a shabby Manhattan neighborhood late at night to keep an assignation with some shady characters in a desolate Edward Hopper cafe. Stopping for a moment, he bends under a street lamp, cupping his hands to light a cigarette, his hat tilted down over one eyebrow, the collar of his overcoat turned up against the late-November chill.

title: A 'Mellow' Scientist David Stewart McKay
description: For a scientist like Dr. David S. McKay, it is hard to achieve a higher career peak than the one he reached in the 1960's, in the glory days of space exploration, when he instructed the Apollo astronauts in geology and analyzed the soil samples they brought back from the moon. It was ''extremely thrilling,'' Dr. McKay said, especially for a junior scientist.

title: Micron Cash-Out Leaves the I.R.S. Waiting
description: What do you do when the value of one of your greatest investments ever is waning but the profit is still huge? You do what a family corporation that is the largest shareholder in Micron Technologies has done: sell $150 million in stock in a way that will defer paying any capital gains taxes for six years.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: It's My Party

title: U.S. Mandates Educational TV for Children
description: After two years of arguing and a summer of on-again, off-again compromises, the Federal Communications Commission unanimously passed a regulation yesterday that requires television stations to show three hours of children's educational programming each week.

title: AMR TO SELL 20% OF SABRE IN A PUBLIC OFFERING
description: The AMR Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell about 20 percent of its Sabre travel reservation system to the public this year, ending months of speculation about the future of Sabre. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, AMR, which is based in Dallas, said that it expected to raise about $550 million from the offering before expenses. It plans to use the proceeds to repay part of the $850 million debt of Sabre. The Sabre network is used by 30,000 travel agencies in 74 countries to book airline tickets, hotel stays and other travel accommodations. Sabre's $1.7 billion in sales accounted for about 10 percent of AMR's $16.91 billion in revenue last year. In April, AMR reorganized Sabre, which had been part of its American Airlines unit, as a separate division, indicating that a sale or spinoff might follow. Yesterday, the company said the partial spinoff would occur in the fourth quarter. The announcement lifted AMR's shares on the New York Stock Exchange; they closed at $86.25, up $4.50.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CHEVRON CORP., San Francisco, the oil company, said that it planned to lay off 250 workers in the East San Francisco Bay area.

title: Indonesia's Provocative Label for Opposition: Communist
description: The Government is focusing its public response to a riot last month on a small leftist group, accusing it of treason and Communism, an accusation that harks back to the kind of violent uprising that brought President Suharto to power 30 years ago.

title: Home Video
description: Fighting Video Piracy

title: Exuberant Motion And Rollicking Jazz
description: ONE of the most brilliant conceits of Lincoln Center Festival '96 was the pairing of Judith Jamison, the artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, and Wynton Marsalis, the artistic director of Jazz at Lincoln Center. Larger than life and immensely popular, Ms. Jamison and Mr. Marsalis perfectly capture the heart and grit of New York City. And their collaboration, a world premiere called ''Sweet Release'' that was performed by the Ailey company and the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater, is the perfect exuberant, gaudy festival package.

title: People
description: * Peter J. Rawlins was named managing director for Europe, Middle East and Africa at Siegel & Gale, London, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., succeeding Malcolm Parkinson, who left. Mr. Rawlins was previously a consultant in London.

title: Diplomacy, Netanyahu Style: Too Important for Diplomats
description: Sweeping through the grounds of King Hussein's palace in Amman, Jordan, this week, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was accompanied by a retinue of about 25 senior aides and Israeli businessmen that was remarkable for one glaring omission: Not a single representative of the Israeli Foreign Ministry was present, aside from the departing ambassador.

title: A Postcard Picture of a Graffiti Artist
description: In his biographical film about his late friend and fellow artist Jean-Michel Basquiat, the painter Julian Schnabel creates a remembrance in kind. His ''Basquiat'' is bold, attention-getting and more than a little facile, a stylish-looking film without the connective tissue to give it real depth. Not surprisingly, Mr. Schnabel creates sharp, vivid images redolent of downtown New York in the 1980's and proves himself caustically familiar with this terrain. But the film's central figure remains a cipher, the subject of a colorful scrapbook rather than a revealing portrait.

title: Art in Review
description: Ana Busto

title: 10 Held as Unlicensed Medical Practitioners
description: Ten people who investigators said acted as doctors although they did not have licenses were arrested in Chinatown yesterday in a case that officials say highlights the way immigrant groups are taken advantage of when seeking medical care.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Metropolitan Opera has named a new talent scout, EVA WAGNER-PASQUIER, to look for emerging or undiscovered singers in Europe, and she is not exactly a newcomer to music. She is a great-great-granddaughter of Franz Liszt and a great-granddaughter of Richard Wagner.

title: Delta Air Lines Introduces New Budget Carrier
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. yesterday introduced a budget carrier aimed at taking back businesss from discount rivals like the Southwest Airlines Company.

title: 'Daughter' Called a Scam
description: David Brookman, prosecutors say, had problems. He explained in letters to several people in Mississippi that he had lost his job and health insurance and needed to raise $200,000 for a liver transplant for his daughter. But prosecutors said yesterday that Mr. Brookman did not have a daughter. On Wednesday, after raising about $1,000, Mr. Brookman, 26, of Fairview, was charged with attempted theft by fraud, said Charles Buckley, the Acting Bergen County Prosecutor.

title: A Final Round In Dole's Dance To Pick a No. 2
description: Just two days before he plans to announce his choice of a running mate, Bob Dole let it be known today that he had added a late entrant to the Vice-Presidential list, Jack F. Kemp, with whom Mr. Dole has often feuded in the past.

title: Touring and Tasting At L.I. Wineries
description: WHEN glaciers laid the groundwork for Long Island wine country, they artfully fashioned a maritime logo. Together, the North and South Forks form a stylized lobster claw. The image whets a visitor's appetite for a signature East End treat: seafood with chilled white wine.

title: Discount retailers woo customers with circulars that feature down-to-earth people and low prices.
description: RETAIL advertising dabbles almost exclusively in fantasy, creating worlds that most shoppers only wish they inhabited. In these ads, models mow the lawn in evening wear, couples with immaculately clean houses sip espresso and well-dressed husbands take over the child care with aplomb.

title: Vmark Places Account in Review
description: VMARK Software Inc., a software provider in Westboro, Mass., said yesterday that it had placed its account, which has been handled by Spiessl Kitchen Vosik Advertising in Boston for 12 years, in review. Billings were not disclosed. Paula Levis Suita, a spokeswoman for VMARK, said that Pile & Company in Boston, a consulting company, had been hired to help manage the review, in which six agencies have been invited to compete. She identified them as: Direct Advertising in Holliston, Mass.; Greenberg Seronick & Partners in Boston; Latus, Szostakowski & Sanders in Boston; Matzell, Richard & Watts in Boston; Stringer Furtado & Shaw in Lynnfield, Mass., and Wallwork Curry in Boston. A decision is expected next month.

title: Store Manager Is Indicted
description: When Newark's largest community development group opened a Dunkin' Donuts franchise in a struggling neighborhood in 1990, it sought to create opportunities for local residents. Allan Murray, who started at the store the day it opened and worked his way up to manager, seemed to be a classic success story for the group, the New Community Corporation. But Mr. Murray was indicted yesterday on charges that he pocketed $138,000 of the store's receipts during 1994 and 1995. Mr. Murray, 27, of Irvington, faces up to 20 years in prison if he is convicted.

title: Handicapped Take the Reins
description: Seven-year-old Stephen Gruzlovic of Trenton has been riding horses for three years, no mean feat in itself. But Stephen has cerebral palsy. Last night, he and fellow members of Horseback Riding for the Handicapped of New Jersey demonstrated their skills at the Horse Park in Imlaystown to publicize the group's efforts. Claire Schoenenberger, president of the organization, said riding provides physical therapy unmatched by any machine. ANDY NEWMAN

title: Kodak to Buy Into Fox Chain Of 550 Photo-Finishing Stores
description: The Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday that it would pay $56.1 million for 51 percent of the CPI Corporation's Fox Photo Film unit, a chain of 550 photo-finishing stores. ''This gives us a core of stores that we can use to launch a retail identity program throughout the country,'' Jerome W. Johnson, general manager of Kodak's domestic Consumer Imaging business, said.

title: Acapulco's Smut Ring: The Children Remember
description: On any sultry Acapulco night, Mexican boys move among the partying crowds on the oceanside boulevard, doing whatever they can to make a small living.

title: $147 Million Is Pledged To Renovate Apartments
description: In a major infusion of corporate cash that housing experts say has come at a crucial time, executives of 19 large New York City companies said yesterday that they had invested $147 million in a program to rehabilitate rundown city-owned apartment buildings.

title: Restaurants
description: ''Male or female?'' asks the waiter.

title: Slaves to Paris
description: To the Editor:

title: $101,600 Fine in Plant Blast
description: Sixteen months after an explosion at the Napp Technologies plant in Lodi killed five workers, the company has agreed to pay the Government $101,600 for safety violations at the plant, Federal officials said yesterday. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration had initially fined Napp $127,000 but agreed to downgrade a violation from ''willful'' to ''unclassified,'' an O.S.H.A. spokeswoman, Susan Hall Fleming, said.

title: Lower Copper Prices Hurt Chilean Concern
description: Codelco, Chile's state-owned copper company, said its profits declined 17 percent in the first half of 1996 because of a decline in copper prices. Profits totaled $684.7 million, compared with $826.6 million a year earlier, a company executive said.

title: Phillies Fire Hobson Amid Cocaine Charges
description: Days after a newspaper published court documents showing that Scranton Wilkes-Barre Red Barons Manager BUTCH HOBSON admitted using cocaine, the Philadelphia Phillies fired him yesterday.

title: Bosnian Serbs' New Public Face Is a Hard-Liner
description: Since Radovan Karadzic was indicted on war crimes charges and was forced by the West to relinquish his position as Bosnian Serb leader, a philosophical soul mate and a close colleague has increasingly become the public face of the Bosnian Serbs.

title: For Motorola, Computer Lead
description: Motorola Inc. said today that it expected to ship computers based on the Power PC platform in the first quarter of 1997, beating Apple Computer Inc. in offering machines that run Macintosh software as well as Microsoft's Windows NT.

title: An Epic That Celebrates Life, Even Beyond Death
description: It's about time: the Theatre de Complicite, the highly regarded touring company based in London, is making its debut in New York City, where, on Wednesday night, it opened at Alice Tully Hall with ''The Three Lives of Lucie Cabrol.'' This big, panoramic stage piece, about the life, death and afterlife of a French peasant woman, is epic theater of the sort rarely seen in America today. It's a seamlessly performed amalgam of conventional theater, narration, music, movement (what amounts to choreography) and mime. When was the last time you saw actors playing blueberry bushes?

title: Japan Trade Surplus Down 26% in June
description: The surplus in Japan's broadest measure of trade shrank 26 percent in June compared with a year earlier, helping the figure fall 35 percent for the first half of this year, the Finance Ministry said yesterday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: U.S. Documents Frustrate Guatemalans
description: After a hunger strike was held in front of the White House this spring, the Clinton Administration agreed to declassify thousands of United States Government documents concerning human rights abuses here. But Guatemalan prosecutors scrutinizing the papers are now wondering whether all the prodding and the protest was worth the effort.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Like many students about to embark on their last year of high school, CHELSEA CLINTON, 16, who will be a senior at the private Sidwell Friends School in Washington, spent part of this week touring college campuses with her mother, HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows in New York City that are to close soon:

title: The Revival of Liberalism
description: Three themes dominate the news coverage of the welfare reform bill President Clinton says he will sign. First, there is the Dick Morris Triumph, in which Mr. Clinton sells out his principles, and the poor, for a mess of votes on the advice of his cynical strategist. There is the Gingrich Resurgence, in which Congressional Republicans recapture their glory by fulfilling the biggest promise in their Contract With America. Finally, there is the Death of Liberalism: If a Democratic President can end the ''guarantee'' of cash aid to the poor begun in the New Deal, what does the party stand for?

title: Robert H. Clampitt, 69, Founder Of a Children's News Service
description: Robert H. Clampitt, the founder and president of Children's Express, a nationwide children's news service, died yesterday in Washington. He was 69.

title: The Game Of Second Chances
description: DEREK JETER didn't spell out exactly what he meant, but his comment aptly summed up one of the beauties of the game of baseball, the opportunity for rapid redemption.

title: For Children
description: Bookbinding

title: Trenton Man Faces Charges in the Slayings of 4 Women
description: At least four women who roamed the streets of a shabby part of Trenton looking for crack cocaine in the middle of the night met a slight soft-spoken young man.

title: Unearthing Answers About Scenes of New York
description: Was the charming ''Winter Scene in Brooklyn'' of 1853 painted by the artist Francis Guy or an unknown copyist? Could those be Orthodox Jews standing on a bridge in a tiny 1895 painting of Central Park by one John M. Slaney? And just who was the elegant human subject of ''Frank Work Driving a Fast Team of Trotters,'' circa 1892, a painting thought to be by John McAuliffe?

title: 60's Children's Zoo Is Saying Goodbye
description: Tomorrow, New Yorkers wistful over the fate of the Central Park Children's Zoo will be invited to say a final goodbye to Jonah, the spouting cement whale, and his fairy-tale neighbors. Then, the Children's Zoo, long derided as a prime example of 1960's kitsch, will be demolished.

title: Sales Sputter And Retailers Cite Weather
description: Sales fell sharply for many major retailers last month, a consequence at least in part of cooler temperatures cutting into sales of seasonal goods like summer clothing and air-conditioners.

title: $25 and Under
description: I love the smell of the dining room at Trattoria i Pagliacci, a small Italian restaurant that opened on Park Avenue South about a year ago. The yeasty aroma of fresh focaccia mingles with the scents of rosemary and garlic, of olive oil and sausage and Parmesan cheese. It's like an olfactory still life of an Italian grocery.

title: Corn and Soybeans Advance As Rain Misses Growing Area
description: Corn and soybean prices jumped on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday after scattered showers missed many dry fields in the eastern Corn Belt.

title: Miscellany
description: * The Publishers Information Bureau, New York, reported that magazine advertising pages in July rose 2.2 percent from July 1995, to 13,769. For the first seven months of 1996, total ad pages fell 1.4 percent, to 115,567, from the corresponding period last year.

title: Small Pieces of T.W.A. Jet's Wreckage Intrigue Investigators
description: Scuba divers collected hundreds of small pieces of wreckage yesterday from T.W.A. Flight 800 that investigators suspect came from the fuselage beneath the front baggage compartment. If their suspicion is confirmed, investigators will have another indication that the explosion that doomed the plane originated in that cargo hold.

title: High Fashion Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: The President's Strategist Puts His Faith in Timing and Telephone Calls
description: Dick Morris is so maniacal about not wasting time that on Monday mornings, when he makes his Washington shuttle flight for another week's work at strategizing over President Clinton's re-election effort, he takes his shoes off at the terminal shoeshine stand and pads off to the phone bank in his socks to make rapid-fire phone calls.

title: Cyberspace Blackout
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Officer Is Charged In Rape of Bronx Girl, 17
description: A Bronx police officer has been charged with raping a 17-year-old girl whom he arrested in a domestic dispute on Tuesday and whose release from jail he arranged the next day with no charges being filed, police and prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Frank Marcus, 68, Who Wrote 'The Killing of Sister George'
description: Frank Marcus, a playwright best known as the author of ''The Killing of Sister George,'' which was a success both in London and on Broadway, died on Monday in London. He was 68.

title: For Indonesian Workers at Nike Plant: Just Do It
description: For the last seven hours, Suryami and Mimin, 21-year-old factory workers, had been sitting at their sewing machines, stitching Nike sneakers for export, and they were bored.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Never mind that they have been divorced since May, following a four-year separation, but yesterday, PRINCE ANDREW and his former wife, the DUCHESS OF YORK, celebrated their 10th wedding anniversary at a party at the home they once shared, Sunninghill Park, near Windsor, the Press Association reported.

title: Herbert Huncke, the Hipster Who Defined 'Beat,' Dies at 81
description: Herbert Huncke, the charismatic street hustler, petty thief and perennial drug addict who enthralled and inspired a galaxy of acclaimed writers and gave the Beat Generation its name, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 81.

title: Software Error Returns Patent Office Mail
description: A ''software hiccup'' at the United States Postal Service caused nearly two weeks worth of mail to the Patent and Trademark Office's Washington branch -- an estimated 50,000 pieces -- to be returned to senders.

title: A Marsalis Sampler, Both Brief and Complex
description: Connected to Judith Jamison's fast-moving choreography, Wynton Marsalis's 30-minute score for the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's ''Sweet Release,'' performed Wednesday night at the New York State Theater, had little room for the kind of ecstasy implied in its title. In its favor, the piece felt more like a symphony fiendishly edited to fit on one side of an LP.

title: Harnisch's Form Returns As Mets Shut Out Marlins
description: There was a time when Pete Harnisch wasn't sure whether the speed of his fastball and the crispness of his slider would return. Sure, the doctors had told him it would take a year following shoulder surgery last August before he would be himself again. Harnisch figured he would be different. He would defy medical odds and baffle major league hitters, just as he had done in the past.

title: Simpson to Assist Maple Leafs
description: TERRY SIMPSON, a former head coach of the Winnipeg Jets, Philadelphia Flyers and Islanders, agreed Wednesday to become an assistant coach with the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: West Orange Chief Convicted Of Warning Suspect in a Raid
description: An Essex County jury convicted the suspended West Orange police chief today on charges that he warned the target of a drug investigation about an impending raid on her home.

title: Appeals Court Gives City Clearance to Evict Squatters in East Village
description: A state appeals court gave New York City the right yesterday to evict defiant squatters from four city-owned buildings on East 13th Street in Manhattan, setting the stage for a resolution of a long-simmering housing battle in the East Village.

title: Correction
description: An article on Wednesday about gay marriage misidentified a street in Baltimore where Gertrude Stein once lived. It is Biddle Street.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: White Squall

title: When to Tackle Welfare
description: The Federal Government will start taking down its safety net for the poor this month. If President Clinton signs the welfare bill passed by Congress, as he has promised, Washington will turn responsibility for taking care of the needy over to the states. Then governors and mayors will be in the unenviable position of figuring out what to do next.

title: Sculpture That Basks in Summer
description: SUMMER is the season for outdoor sculpture to make its annual appearance in New York, when the sun is out and the time is right for walking the streets and parks.

title: Favorite's Tactical Shift Brings Victory in Sprint
description: In the fast and furious world of world-class sprinters, a little change can sometimes make a big difference. That's what trainer John Kimmel was hoping for and that's what he got today when Prospect Bay came from just off the pace to beat Honour and Glory in the $100,000 A Phenomenon Stakes at Saratoga Race Course.

title: Liberal Arts, by Definition, Teach Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Gramercy Direct, New York, a unit of the Gramercy Group, was named as the first agency to handle direct marketing for two accounts, with combined billings estimated at $10 million: Eli Lilly & Co., Indianapolis, to introduce prescription insulin, which is expected to be introduced later this year, and Nomura Capital Asset Corp., New York, a unit of Nomura Investment Management Co., to handle a campaign aimed at commercial mortgage brokers.

title: AT&T Stays in School
description: To the Editor:

title: Atlantans Made An Olympic Effort
description: To the Editor:

title: Infusion of Cash To Renovate Housing
description: Executives of 19 large New York City companies said yesterday that they had invested $147 million in a program to rehabilitate rundown city-owned apartment buildings. Housing experts say the infusion of cash comes at a crucial time as government-backed housing programs for the poor are being cut. The investment, which is to be matched by $147 million in city money, represents the largest commitment so far by the New York Equity Fund, an eight-year-old program in which companies pay for housing rehabilitation in exchange for Federal tax breaks.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Tuesday about a performance of Morton Feldman's ''Why Patterns?'' at the Society for Ethical Culture on Friday misidentified the flutist, because of an incorrect listing in the program. He was Ransom Wilson, not John Palumbo.

title: Dispute Over 4th Area Code
description: As fax machines and computer lines use up telephone numbers in New Jersey's three area codes, plans to create new codes are stalled because of disagreements between long-distance and cellular phone companies. Officials from 10 companies who met Wednesday to discuss the future of the 609 area code failed to reach a consensus, Tim Ireland, spokesman for Bell Atlantic-New Jersey, told The Associated Press yesterday. The long-distance carriers want to split 609, which is projected to run out of numbers by 1998, into two geographical areas. Local and cellular phone companies prefer using the new prefix for newly installed phones throughout the old 609 area. The phone companies have asked the state Board of Public Utilities to referee the dispute.

title: The Wind Out There
description: It is just 116 miles from Salt Lake City, Utah, to Wendover, Nev., on Interstate 80. Perhaps half the distance lies across the Great Salt Lake Desert -- the salt flats. North of the salt flats, on clear days, the Newfoundland Mountains seem to float on a translucent band of air radiating upward from an arid ocean of bedded salt, which reaches right to the roadway. This is a place of desolate, eerie beauty. It is also, for people driving cars of a certain vintage, a place to begin distrusting the fan belt and listening for noises in the engine that were not there before.

title: Rwanda Joins Effort To Isolate Burundi
description: Rwanda's most powerful political figure, Vice President Paul Kagame, said in New York today that his country would join other African nations in putting pressure on the new military Government in Burundi by closing the border between the two countries, effectively completing a circle of sanctions around landlocked Burundi.

title: An Acquisition in Apparel
description: The VF Corporation said this week that it had bought Bulwark Protective Apparel, a maker of flame-retardant clothing, for $20 million in cash and notes. Bulwark, of Edmonton, Alberta, makes industrial apparel. VF, based here, is a big American producer of denim jeans.

title: Arab Note Ends Office Dispute
description: A confrontation between the Israeli Government and a Palestinian legislator who opened an office in East Jerusalem was resolved today when he submitted a written declaration that the office did not belong to the Palestinian Authority.

title: No Headline
description: ''The land ownership continues even though the sugar declines. So instead of growing sugar, now they grow hotels.''

title: Armageddon, With Plastic Surgery
description: If the Government deported all its ''immoral'' citizens to Los Angeles Island after a millennial earthquake severed the city from the mainland, who would be the person you might be most likely to meet there, wearing a wet suit, clutching a surfboard and waiting to ride the next tsunami? Why, Peter Fonda of course! And what would the star of psychedelic adventure movies like ''The Trip'' and ''Easy Rider'' exclaim if there were a sudden downpour? ''Acid rain!''

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Disagreement Over Safety Disrupts U.S.-Venezuela Flights
description: After a one-day disruption in air service between the United States and Venezuela, United Airlines restored service late yesterday, but American Airlines decided not to begin flying until this morning.

title: In Tomblike Vaults, the Future Flickers and Hums
description: This year's ''Art in the Anchorage,'' staged in the base of the Brooklyn Bridge, is more Anchorage than anything else. The exhibition is devoted to various forms of electronic, video and digital art: some for viewing, some for listening and some for both. Its contents tend to be so stripped down and minimal that the space seems nearly empty. Things could be worse: such attenuation lets the Anchorage's extraordinary interior take over almost completely, and in these days of virtual this and interactive that, it's refreshing to see new technology broached by art that errs on the side of understatement.

title: G.E. AND SHAMROCK IN LATIN MEDIA DEAL
description: The pension fund of the General Electric Company and the Shamrock Group, an investment firm, said that they had invested $30 million in the Latin Communications Group, owner of the Spanish-language El Diario-La Prensa newspaper in New York. G.E. and Shamrock, which is owned by the Roy E. Disney family, bought the majority of a $50 million equity offering by Latin Communications. The closely held media company said it would use the money to acquire Spanish-language media properties in prime United States markets.

title: INSIDE
description: Rule on Children's TV

title: Casino Lays Off 150 People
description: The Claridge Casino Hotel, Atlantic City's smallest gambling house, is laying off 150 workers, including two vice presidents. Glenn Lillie, Claridge's vice president for marketing and communications (who is not being laid off) said yesterday that increased competition, cool summer weather and a fatal car plunge from the fourth floor of the casino's new garage last month all hurt business. Mr. Lillie said the Claridge lost $6.3 million through the first half of 1996, compared with $1.8 million for the same period last year.

title: Reputed Mob Figure's Plea
description: Two weeks after admitting that he ran a $5 million-a-year gambling operation, a reputed mobster who authorities say is northern New Jersey's ranking member of the Gambino crime family, pleaded guilty yesterday in United States District Court in Newark to running a loan-sharking ring. Nicholas Mitarotonda, 58, of Montville, had already served three and a half years in prison for running gambling operations in New Jersey for John Gotti, the boss of the Gambino crime family, and was on parole. He admitted that his associates sometimes used violence to make customers, most of them gamblers, pay their debts. In exchange for his guilty pleas, Mr. Mitarotonda is expected to be sentenced to between 5 and 7 years in prison; he could have faced up to 20 years, the authorities said.

title: Challenge For Jets: To Become A Team
description: Now comes the hard part for the Jets: learning to play together.

title: Price Report Shows No Sign Of Inflation
description: Inflation is nowhere to be found these days.

title: A Known Quantity
description: In choosing Jack F. Kemp as his running mate, Bob Dole emulated the two most successful Republican politicians since World War II, Dwight D. Eisenhower and Ronald Reagan. Like them, he reached out to an element of the party with which he has often been at odds, the low-tax, pro-growth conservatives.

title: Count Dracula Never Had His Own Cable TV Show
description: The interview with the vampire takes place in a sixth-floor walk-up in the East Village, among the dark shadows cast by blood-red drapes of satin brocade.

title: Company Is Charged In a Crash
description: A propane gas company whose driver was killed in a fiery explosion here two years ago after his truck plowed into a guard rail on Interstate 287 was charged today with violating Federal safety regulations that limit the number of hours drivers can work without time off.

title: Toward Speedy Relief
description: To the Editor:

title: DeMatha Coach Out of Hospital
description: MORGAN WOOTTEN, the high school basketball coach who ranks among the career leaders in victories, returned home yesterday from the Baltimore hospital where he underwent a liver transplant, vowing to lead his team again. The 65-year-old DeMatha High School coach has compiled 1,094 victories in his four decades at the school. (AP)

title: THE QUARTERBACK AT THE GAME'S END
description: When Bob Dole would meet with his advisers to mull over prospects for his running mate, every once in a while he would blurt out, ''What about The Quarterback?''

title: DOLE IS SAID TO SETTLE ON KEMP, A SOMETIME FOE, TO FILL TICKET
description: Bob Dole settled tonight on Jack Kemp, the 61-year-old former Congressman from Buffalo and periodic political nemesis to Mr. Dole, to be his Vice Presidential running mate, aides to the former Kansas Senator said.

title: Cuban Composer's Work Isn't Banned in Havana
description: To the Editor:

title: Mugger's Plea: Let's Forget It
description: Hoping to let bygones be bygones, Willie King, the Harlem man charged with mugging the mother of Vincent Gigante, accused boss of the Genovese organized crime family, pleaded guilty to grand larceny in Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday.

title: Beliefs
description: Dear Beliefs:

title: Marathon Labor Talks Seen as a Positive Sign
description: In what could turn out to be the most pivotal development in baseball's long-running labor dispute, negotiators for the owners and the players held a series of bargaining sessions that began yesterday morning and extended into the early hours of this morning.

title: On Waves of Fresh Ideas
description: In most straight-ahead jazz piano playing, the idioms are fixed; if not one per set, then certainly one per piece. Geri Allen, in this regard, is exceptional. With considerable experience in several different schools of jazz playing, she thinks in differentiated waves, and both her compositions and her improvised solos fall neatly into disparate sections. Her changes of mood aren't gradual; they're total and abrupt. Her early set at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night was at times like a film of spliced cuts: a completely fresh idea would come along several times within the course of a solo, while the rhythm section plugged away continuously behind her.

title: And Women Are Paying Insurance Rates to Prove It
description: Once the butt of sexist jokes, women drivers now pose a genuine hazard: they are acting too much as men do behind the wheel. Having already drawn about equal in their numbers on the road, women are making gains in categories in which they have always lagged far behind: accidents and deaths.

title: A Tree Once Grew in Midtown Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: Sierra Hammers Home a Point by Driving in 5 Runs
description: Ruben Sierra is being paid $6 million this season to hit home runs and drive in runs. Because Sierra did not do enough of that for the Yankees, the brooding slugger was traded to the Detroit Tigers for Cecil Fielder a little over a week ago.

title: Rig Count Up by 8, to 809
description: Baker Hughes Inc. said today that the rig count, a measure of drilling activity, rose by 8 this week, to 809. Rigs drilling for oil rose by 8, to 305; those seeking natural gas were unchanged at 483 and those seeking either oil or gas were unchanged at 21.

title: Dance Club Sale Ordered
description: The company that owned a dance club where four young people were crushed to death during a stampede in 1994 was ordered yesterday to sell its assets and give the money to the victims' families. Judge Edward Beglin Jr. of Union County Superior Court ordered Edifa Inc., which owned El Balcon nightclub in Elizabeth, to pay a $5,000 fine, forfeit its liquor license and sell the club. The teen-agers were trampled after a party at the club on Dec. 3, 1994, when a fight erupted and hundreds of patrons, running down a narrow stairway, were blocked by a locked door. SARAH KERSHAW

title: Car Dealer Gets 5 Years for Bilking G.M. of More Than $400 Million
description: A former Long Island car dealer who admitted bilking the General Motors Corporation out of $422 million in one of the largest frauds in American corporate history was sentenced yesterday to five years in prison.

title: QUARTERDECK SHARES RISE ON TAKEOVER SPECULATION
description: The shares of the Quarterdeck Corporation rose yesterday for a second day on speculation that McAfee Associates Inc. might make an offer to buy Quarterdeck, a maker of software utilities. The speculation took hold in the market on Thursday, pushing Quarterdeck stock up about 15 percent; the stock continued to climb yesterday, after Business Week published a column that repeated the speculation. The stock rose 25 percent yesterday before the company said there had not been any talks. Still, the stock held to a gain of $1, or 11 percent, to $8.75 a share on the Nasdaq. Quarterdeck is not talking with McAfee and has not been in talks with McAfee, a spokeswoman said yesterday.

title: Executive Changes
description: ATLAS WORLD GROUP INC., Evansville, Ind., said its chairman and chief executive, Norman Gee, would retire at the end of the year and would be replaced by Walter Saubert.

title: Saatchi & Saatchi President Is Leaving After 8 Months
description: Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide said yesterday that its No. 2 executive, John Fitzgerald, would leave the agency after only eight months, effective immediately.

title: INSIDE
description: Giuliani Defends His Budget

title: Tension on East 13th Street As Squatters Await Eviction
description: A court ruling on Thursday that gave New York City the go-ahead to evict squatters from city-owned buildings in the East Village led to an uneasy standoff yesterday, with some squatters fearing a violent confrontation but with City Hall saying it was in no hurry to move against them.

title: Cigar Is Ready to Race for the Record
description: It was 7 o'clock this morning on an overcast day in southern California when Cigar was led out of Bill Shoemaker's barn at Del Mar race track and became the star of the show in the West, a horse with a 16-race winning streak who crossed the country for his date with history.

title: Politics Keeps Togo Swimmer High and Dry
description: JOHN DAGBOVI SENAKWAMI, the would-be Olympic swimmer from Togo by way of the Bronx, thought he knew something about endurance. He swam thousands of laps in the last two years in the hope of being the first of his compatriots to compete in the Summer Games.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Mickelson Leads the Young Guns Into the Third Round
description: A freshening wind blew across Valhalla Golf Club today, brightening the P.G.A. Championship considerably, sweeping a couple of golf's shining new faces to the top of the leader board and setting up a wild weekend in the season's final major.

title: 80-Year-Old Sent to Prison In Fraud Case
description: An 80-year-old man convicted of running a multimillion-dollar Ponzi scheme was sentenced today to 18 months in prison, making him one of the oldest people ever sent to a Federal penitentiary.

title: Water Hyacinth Isn't Lake's Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ''The fact is that winning political marriages are usually marriages of convenience, not marriages of love.''

title: After T.W.A. Crash, A 'Charity' Springs Up
description: Two weeks after a Boeing 747 exploded over the Atlantic, thousands of fax machines across the country started to churn out a financial plea that began, ''Assistance Fund Established to Benefit the Families of T.W.A. Flight 800.''

title: U.S.-Venezuela Flights Resumed
description: Flights between Venezuela and the United States resumed yesterday after a dispute between the two countries over air safety that had left hundreds of travelers stranded. Domingo Uzcategui, director of Simon Bolivar international airport in Caracas, said American and Venezuelan flights were turning around without problems.

title: Warrant for Shootout Suspect
description: Federal authorities issued an arrest warrant yesterday for a suspect sought in the robbery and shootout on Monday at the Deptford Mall. The suspect was identified as Moses Clary, 22, of Camden, whom the police said was one of at least three people involved in the botched robbery that left a bandit and a teen-age boy dead. A teen-age girl, hit by a stray bullet during a shootout between a gunman and an armored-car guard, died Wednesday night. Authorities were searching yesterday for Mr. Clary, who was charged with murder while committing a bank robbery and could face the death penalty, and for other associates of the dead suspect, Vincent Reid, 28, of Camden.

title: The Trials of Getting a New York Divorce
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Miracle Child' and Answered Prayers
description: When Daniel Saavedra fell ill with a rare pancreas disease three years ago, he went to see Miguel Angel Gaitan, and within weeks, he says, he made a full recovery.

title: Boeing Lands a $540 Million Contract
description: The Boeing Company said today that it had won an Air Force contract valued at $540 million for the sale and maintenance of four C-32A planes, used mostly to transport Government executives, including the Vice President.

title: Ex-Perot Volunteers Say Reform Party Is Using Old Tactics to Change the System
description: For several years, John Forrest has pitched in at the volunteers' telephone bank of United We Stand America, the nonprofit group that Ross Perot founded here three years ago. But Mr. Forrest quit late last year after discovering, he said, that the supposedly independent group was tapping its membership lists to drum up support for Mr. Perot's partisan political enterprise -- getting the Reform Party on the 1996 Presidential ballot nationally.

title: Company Briefs
description: BAY APARTMENT COMMUNITIES INC., San Jose, Calif., a real estate investment trust, said it had bought two apartment communities: Martinique Gardens in Costa Mesa, Calif, for which it paid $7.5 million, and Channing Heights Apartments in San Rafael, which cost $24.8 million.

title: Nordstrom Stock Falls 8% on Profit Drop
description: Nordstrom Inc., the department store chain, has surprised and angered Wall Street with its announcement that earnings fell 17 percent in the second quarter.

title: New Group in Mexico Affirms Rebel Status
description: An armed group claiming to be a new leftist guerrilla army sought to dispel doubts about its authenticity and goals by meeting with journalists this week in remote mountains along the coast of the Gulf of Mexico, across the country from where the group first appeared.

title: Robinson Signs With Lakers
description: Guard RUMEAL ROBINSON, a free agent, signed a contract yesterday with the Los Angeles Lakers. Terms were not released. Robinson, 29, averaged 5.7 points and 3.3 assists in 43 games for the Portland Trail Blazers last season. Robinson was chosen 10th over all by Atlanta in the 1990 draft after playing on a National Collegiate Athletic Association championship team at Michigan. He also played for the Nets. (AP)

title: William J. Green, 90, Builder Who Beat the Odds in Burma
description: William J. Green, who blocked for Red Grange at the University of Illinois, helped cut a 400-mile road through the jungles of Burma during World War II and then helped clear the way for the full integration of black troops into the United States Army in 1947, died on July 17 in a hospital in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 90.

title: Peace Eases Out Sex and Violence
description: Peace, tolerance, self-esteem, fondness for marijuana and giant thudding bass lines were the agenda of the Smokin' Grooves tour, which came to the Garden State Arts Center here on Wednesday night. The five-hour concert included hip-hop groups -- the Fugees, Cypress Hill, A Tribe Called Quest, Spearhead, Busta Rhymes and, for a few minutes, Call o' Da Wild -- and a reggae band, Ziggy Marley and the Melody Makers. With rock-ribbed reggae grooves and straightforward messages, Ziggy Marley topped a dance marathon that wasn't afraid to add preaching between the beats. The show balanced good intentions and good times.

title: Makeup of Hartford Schools Panel Challenged
description: A state panel charged with finding ways to integrate Hartford's schools with those of its suburban neighbors does not have enough minority members or Hartford residents, the plaintiffs in a landmark desegregation suit said today.

title: Fitch Undergoes Triple Bypass
description: Los Angeles Clippers Coach BILL FITCH, who has coached more games than anyone else in National Basketball Association history, was in stable condition yesterday after undergoing triple bypass surgery. Fitch, 62, underwent the operation late Thursday night at Columbia Conroe Regional Medical Center after experiencing chest pains earlier at his home in Conroe, Tex., just outside Houston, the Clippers said.

title: Duva's Suspension Rescinded
description: The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday rescinded the suspension it imposed last week on the fight promoter LOU DUVA. The commission suspended Duva because it thought he had pushed the referee during a fracas at the end of the RIDDICK BOWE-ANDREW GOLOTA bout at Madison Square Garden on July 11. After reviewing the tapes, it changed its ruling. Duva handles Golota, who was disqualified in the seventh round for the latest in a succession of low blows. Bowe's manager, ROCK NEWMAN, remains under suspension.

title: The Pistols, Courting and Challenging Legend
description: Maybe the Sex Pistols should never have reunited. They could have left their legacy intact, passing through rock history just once, like a comet. But if the Sex Pistols had to regroup and cash in on punk's late-breaking commercial triumph, they did things right at Roseland on Thursday night, where an audience that spanned 20 years of punk-rock thrilled to the Pistols' New York debut.

title: Judicial Activist
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I. Brokerage Firm Said to Be Under Investigation
description: Landmark International Equities, a Westbury, L.I., brokerage firm best known for taking public a company run by Oliver L. North, is being investigated by the National Association of Securities Dealers in the wake of running afoul of net capital requirements and quitting as a Nasdaq market-maker on Wednesday, according to a person familiar with the inquiry.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about changes in New York's domestic violence laws misstated the court history of a Brooklyn woman, Galina Komar, who was killed last February by a former boyfriend. Prosecutors had repeatedly appeared in court on Ms. Komar's behalf to complain about the boyfriend's threats, but Ms. Komar did not appear herself.

title: Officemax Sues Over 'Max' Use
description: Officemax Inc. is suing Circuit City Stores Inc. for using the name Carmax for its new chain of used-car stores.

title: Investor Gets Stake In Coca-Cola Amatil
description: A Malaysian investor, Robert Kuok Hock Nien, has acquired a 9.3 percent stake in Coca-Cola Amatil Ltd. of Australia for $667 million (Australian), or $520 million (United States), The Asian Wall Street Journal reported yesterday.

title: Welfare Law Is Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court said yesterday that New Jersey has the right to withhold increased payments from mothers who have more children while on welfare. The ruling, by the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, upholds a 1993 law that ended the practice of increasing welfare cash benefits by $64 a month for every child born. The ruling marks the second defeat for opponents, who contend that the law unfairly punishes children for the behavior of their mothers. Jacqueline Tencza, a spokeswoman for the Department of Human Services, said the intent of the ''family cap'' law was to ''send a message about personal responsibility -- if you have a child while on welfare, be sure you can care for that child both emotionally and financially.''

title: Twist of Fate for George's Mother
description: The Oilers' signing of EDDIE GEORGE, the Heisman Trophy winner, may have saved the life of his mother, DONNA, a Trans World Airlines flight attendant. She was scheduled to work Flight 800 from New York to Paris on July 17 and return two days later. But her son's agent, LAMONT SMITH, asked her to change her schedule so she could go to San Antonio on July 19 for her son's signing. Flight 800 crashed into the Atlantic Ocean south of Long Island, killing all on board. (AP)

title: Maddox Is Starting, Brown Is Sitting and Everyone Is Wondering
description: They are National Football League quarterbacks, so Dave Brown and Tommy Maddox should be used to news media overreaction and nonsense. Still, even they were probably not prepared for the rabid reaction when Giants Coach Dan Reeves announced that Maddox would be starting this week's exhibition game and that Brown was benched.

title: 2 Arrested in Burning Of Homeless Woman
description: A group of men who set fire to a homeless woman asleep in a Brooklyn subway station were caught early yesterday because they bragged about the attack, the police said.

title: Gay Reporter Wants to Be Activist
description: To labor leaders in this old blue-collar port, a shot-and-beer stronghold, Sandy Nelson is an unlikely hero -- a lesbian, Socialist journalist. But to the top editors at The News Tribune, where Ms. Nelson works, she is a walking conflict of interest whose off-duty activities threaten the credibility of journalism.

title: City's New Waste Agency Flexes Regulatory Muscles
description: For decades, most businesses in New York City had little say in determining who picked up their garbage, the prices charged or the length of the contracts with the garbage carters.

title: 2 Are Raped at Gunpoint at Harlem Pool After Closing
description: A young woman and a teen-age girl who sneaked into a public swimming pool in Harlem after hours with two male companions were raped at gunpoint early yesterday by two robbers, the police said.

title: CR Kay Suzie Breezes To the Breeders Crown
description: A 4-year-old filly with foot problems, which limited her to just one race all year, captured tonight's $500,000 Cadillac Breeders Crown at the Meadowlands Racetrack. CR Kay Suzie took over at the midway point and was never threatened the rest of the way by the 10 other trotters, including the heralded Coktail Jet of France.

title: Does Church's Focus on Abortion Sacrifice Social Agenda?
description: To the Editor:

title: KASH N' KARRY IN TAKEOVER TALKS WITH FOOD LION
description: Kash n' Karry Food Stores Inc. said yesterday that it had had discussions in the last several weeks with Food Lion Inc. about an acquisition of Kash n' Karry by Food Lion, but that the talks had been broken off. The shares of Kash n' Karry plunged after the announcement, closing at $20, down $9. Kash n' Karry emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection as a public company last year. The company has long been seen as a takeover candidate. The chain has 100 stores and annual sales of more than $1 billion.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-7

title: Thyssen's Chief Detained and Questioned
description: Thyssen A.G.'s chief executive and several other current or former managers were detained and questioned in connection with a possible fraud relating to the company's involvement in liquidating an East German metals trading company, Thyssen said yesterday. The chief executive, Dieter Vogel, and several other managers were held for questioning yesterday about accusations that they had misdirected 73 million marks ($49 million) in wrapping up the affairs of the East German company, Metallurgiehandel G.m.b.H.

title: The Suburb on the Hill
description: California (Southern C. at least which, however, the real C. I believe much repudiates) has completely bowled me over -- such a delicious difference from the rest of the U.S. do I find in it,'' Henry James wrote to his sister-in-law from San Diego in 1905. ''I speak of course all of nature and climate, fruits and flowers; for there is absolutely nothing else, and the sense of the shining social and human inane is utter.''

title: Reform Party's Split Widens With Its Convention at Hand
description: For a party that promises politics not as usual, Ross Perot's Reform Party -- on the eve of its first national Presidential nominating convention -- seems to be deeply mired in, well, politics as usual.

title: Transported By the Heart Unrestrained
description: After an opening fanfare by his band, Elder Edward Babb, director of the 19-piece McCullough Sons of Thunder, started comforting the Lincoln Center audience. ''If you're clapping your hands, it's all right. If you're stomping your feet, it's all right. Let's take time out to make a connection.'' The band -- a phalanx of 11 trombones, two trumpets, two tubas and a few drummers and cymbal players -- whispered, insofar as 11 trombones can whisper, a soft elegy beneath Mr. Babb's delivery.

title: Growth Area Seen for Religious Right
description: The religious right political movement has considerable opportunity for future growth because many of its prime potential constituents, politically conservative evangelicals, are unfamiliar with the movement and unaware of some of its leaders, according to a poll commissioned by the American Jewish Committee.

title: Of Athletes and Agents (Oh, and Money, Too)
description: It can be hard to get all those treacly Olympics human-interest stories out of your system. ''Arliss,'' a funny and caustic new series about a sports agent, is the perfect antidote. This is a show in which the hero rejects what he considers a low-ball salary for one of his players with the indignant remark: ''$750,000? Oh, come on, the guy's gotta eat!''

title: Unilever's Profit Declines by 12%
description: Unilever N.V., the British-Dutch maker of consumer products, said yesterday that its net earnings fell 12 percent in the second quarter because of unusual charges and that operating earnings would have risen 10 percent without them. The company said European sales were steady despite weaker demand in key markets, but conditions were better in North America and emerging markets.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Giuliani Spars With Monitors on the Budget
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday lashed out at recent reports from fiscal monitors on the city's $33 billion budget, which warn that a series of what the monitors call shortsighted measures might push New York into its worst financial trouble since it almost went bankrupt in the 1970's.

title: GULFSTREAM AEROSPACE FILES FOR PUBLIC OFFERING
description: The Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation, which was acquired in a leveraged buyout about six years ago, filed for an initial public offering yesterday that could raise as much as $700 million. Most of the money will go to Gulfstream's existing shareholders, including Forstmann Little & Company, which led the purchase of Gulfstream from the Chrysler Corporation in 1990 for more than $800 million. The filing yesterday values Gulfstream over all at about $1.8 billion, based on an initial stock price of $25 a share. The public would be buying 38.8 percent of the company's 72.2 million shares outstanding. Gulfstream, which is based in Savannah, Ga., makes business jets.

title: Currency Trader Sues Daiwa America
description: William S. Lipschutz, a well-known currency trader, sued the Daiwa America Corporation yesterday, contending that the securities firm defamed him in public statements after seizing a $33 million fund he managed.

title: Stock Funds Are Again Popular, Taking In $5 Billion for Week
description: Stock mutual funds took in more than $5 billion in the week ending Wednesday, the biggest weekly flow in two months, according to AMG Data Services, a tracker of mutual fund cash flows.

title: HAMBRECHT & QUIST REPORTS SALE OF 3.5 MILLION SHARES
description: Hambrecht & Quist Inc., the brokerage house based in San Francisco, said yesterday that it had sold 3.5 million shares for $56 million, or $16 a share, in an initial public offering. Despite tumult in its trademark business, managing the stock offerings of high-technology companies, and warnings that its financial results have softened recently, the shares opened at $18 each on the New York Stock Exchange, a 12.5 percent premium. They closed at $18.25. In its initial filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company had said it would raise as much as $80 million in the offering. The company later amended the estimate to $68.4 million.

title: U.S. Steps Up Effort to Get India to Join A-Test Ban
description: With less than a week to go before the world will know whether it has an agreement to ban all nuclear weapons tests for the first time in history, American and other negotiators at a disarmament conference in Geneva are waging a last-minute campaign to persuade India not to veto the treaty.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Cigarette Maker Ordered To Pay Damages for Cancer

title: Marlins Manage A Squeaker Over Mets
description: A leadoff walk in the 10th inning led to another dreadful night that Mets reliever Doug Henry would rather forget and one that a young Marlins infielder will always remember.

title: Smoker's Suit Brings Award Of $750,000 In Florida
description: In only the second time the tobacco industry has been ordered to pay damages in a liability case, a Florida jury yesterday awarded $750,000 to a Jacksonville man who smoked for 44 years before he was stricken with lung cancer five years ago.

title: Arkansas Governor Blocks Medicare Payment for an Abortion in Incest Case
description: Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas today refused to authorize a Medicaid payment for an abortion for a 15-year-old girl whose stepfather has been charged with incest, despite a Federal judge's order that such payments were required by Federal law.

title: Canada Reduces Interest Rates
description: Canada's central bank cut interest rates yesterday after the Government reported that the unemployment rate fell last month. Other major banks followed suit. Unemployment slipped to 9.8 percent, from 10 percent in June, as 19,000 jobs were added. In June, unemployment had jumped from 9.4 percent on a decline of 56,000 jobs.

title: Ex-Parks Manager Sentenced
description: The former manager of the Newark parks division was sentenced yesterday to 250 days of community service and 5 years of probation for accepting a $2,000 bribe to falsify city records. The manager, Bakbakkar Yehudah, 55, of Roselle, approved payments of $30,000 to two vendors who never delivered the goods: trees, shrubs and flowers in one case and tools in another, the authorities said. Mr. Yehudah is the sixth city official to plead guilty in the State Attorney General's investigation into corruption in Newark. A parallel Federal investigation has led to more than a dozen convictions, including a guilty plea last month by William R. Celester, the former police director.

title: A Crackdown on Nasdaq
description: For the first time in its history, the Securities and Exchange Commission has formally censured a major stock market. The target of Thursday's ruling was Nasdaq, the world's second-largest stock market, where millions of shares are traded daily in thousands of stocks, including many of America's most prominent high-technology issues like Microsoft and Intel.

title: A Discovery Energizes AIDS Researchers
description: A number of AIDS researchers have taken initial steps to try to develop drugs, or even a vaccine, based on the discovery that a mutant gene can protect some people from infection with the AIDS virus.

title: COLUMBIA MANAGEMENT SAID TO BE IN TALKS ON ITS SALE
description: Officials of Columbia Management, a mutual fund company based in Portland, Ore., said yesterday that they were in talks on selling the company. They would not say with whom they were talking, but people familiar with the negotiations said that the Royal Bank of Canada was the leading contender to buy Columbia. Columbia Management is expected to fetch as much as $600 million. Royal Bank of Canada officials would not comment, except to say that they were looking to beef up their money management business, which has about $11 billion in assets. Columbia has $18.1 billion in assets under management.

title: Colombian President Urges Devaluation
description: The President of Colombia, Ernesto Samper, urged the central bank yesterday to devalue the country's currency, the peso, to help make exports more attractive in the global market. The central bank has insisted that the country's exchange rate system, which is intended to keep the currency within a narrow range against the dollar, will not be changed. The bank has spent more than $300 million from its international reserves this year to defend the peso.

title: Frank Whittle, 89, Dies; His Jet Engine Propelled Progress
description: Sir Frank Whittle, the British inventor of the jet engine, whose revolutionary concept encountered resistance from his country's Government for more than a decade before finally transforming the 20th century, died on Thursday in his home in Columbia, Md. He was 89.

title: Fashion Victims
description: How many women have donned the latest fashion trend only to meet with snickers that it looks outrageous or inappropriate on them? Such women have long been victimized by designers who make clothes for mythical creatures who are impossibly tall and thin and carry fat wallets.

title: More Previews Than Performances
description: Largely sold out since its previews began on July 25, ''Hughie,'' the Eugene O'Neill revival directed by and starring Al Pacino at Circle in the Square, has extended its run by two weeks, to Sept. 14.

title: Anyway, Crawfish And Jazz Are There
description: It took nine years for the film ''The Big Easy'' to turn up as a television series, and that's probably just as well. At this distance, viewers are less likely to recall the vast difference between the steamy, stylish original and this pallid copy. Like the film, the series (which begins tomorrow) is about a sexy, quasi-honest New Orleans detective named Remy and a strait-laced northern lawyer, Anne, who is a blond bombshell waiting to explode. The series is shot in New Orleans, and the first episode loads on the local color, with boats on the bayou, crawfish and (the series' best touch) terrific blues and jazz music.

title: Race Can't Be Used To Decide Layoffs, Appeals Court Says
description: In a ruling that goes to the basic philosophy of affirmative action, a Federal appeals court declared yesterday that a school district facing layoffs should not have used race as the sole reason to lay off a white teacher.

title: Bomb Hoax at White's Church
description: A suspected bomb that proved to be a hoax was found yesterday morning at REGGIE WHITE's community investment bank in Knoxville, Tenn., an offshoot of the Inner City Church that was firebombed in January.

title: CHECHNYA REBELS ENTRAP AND SHELL MOSCOW'S TROOPS
description: The siege of Grozny intensified today when Chechen rebels surrounded as many as 7,000 Russian troops who had been lured into the center of the devastated city and began to bombard them with grenades, mortars and automatic weapons fire.

title: KELSO AND GROUP LED BY GWM DROP BID FOR INTERMET
description: Kelso & Company and a group led by GWM Inc. have dropped their bid to acquire the Intermet Corporation for $263.9 million. The bidders, in a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, cited an increase in the price of Intermet stock as one reason for calling off the acquisition. Intermet shares closed yesterday at $13, up 25 cents for the day and about 15 percent higher than they traded just before the offer was announced in October. At that time, Intermet rejected the bid. The group headed by GWM, a major shareholder in Intermet, included Intermet's founder, George W. Mathews Jr. Kelso is an investment bank in New York.

title: Crash Investigators Settle In for Long Haul
description: With the only sign of progress the steady flow of wreckage raised from the ocean floor, Federal investigators looking for the cause of the destruction of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 said today that they expected no quick answers.

title: Economic Worry On South Africa Again Hits Rand
description: The South African rand is getting its second hammering of the year as foreign investors and currency traders worry that President Nelson Mandela's Government may be losing its will to force through the economic-liberalization measures it has proposed to increase growth and curb the country's mounting social ills.
