title: Mr. Kemp's Return
description: He could not get Colin Powell, and he apparently felt that neither the new-generation Midwestern Governors like John Engler nor the low-recognition Senators like Connie Mack and John McCain could help him close President Clinton's 20-point lead. So after a last-minute courtship, Bob Dole is said to have settled on Jack Kemp as his running mate. Given the relative obscurity of those who were still on the leader board as of mid-week, it was not a dumb choice.

title: Affirmative Action Ruling
description: In a ruling that goes to the basic philosophy of affirmative action, a Federal appeals court in Philadelphia declared yesterday that a school district facing layoffs should not have used race as the sole reason to lay off a white teacher. The Board of Education of Piscataway cited its policy of seeking a diverse workplace in choosing in 1989 whether to lay off a black teacher or a white one who was equally experienced and qualified. The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit found the district's policy to be unlawful because it was not put into place to remedy past discrimination and because it unnecessarily violated the rights of a nonminority employee. $(Page 1.$)

title: When Grieving Really Begins
description: ''You have competition now,'' someone remarked to me the day after Trans World Airlines Flight 800 crashed off Long Island. I did not immediately understand what she meant, and when I did, I was appalled.

title: BRADLEES PLANNING TO CLOSE 14 UNPROFITABLE STORES
description: Bradlees Inc., the bankrupt discount retailer, said yesterday that it would close 14 unprofitable stores in the Northeast within the next few months, as it moves to shore up its losses and tries to complete its Chapter 11 reorganization. In a related move, Bradlees said it would cut its operating divisions to 9 geographic market areas from 10, allowing it to focus more on improving store productivity and customer service. The stores that are being closed are in Newington and Meriden, Conn.; Seekonk, Mass.; Burlington, East Hanover, Jersey City and Paramus, N.J.; Latham and Troy, N..Y.; Levittown, Montgomeryville and Philadelphia, Pa., and Providence and Warwick, R.I.

title: Ethiopian Army Attacks 3 Towns in Border Region of Somalia
description: Ethiopian troops, tanks and helicopter gunships have crossed the border into western Somalia and attacked three towns, killing scores of people, a Somali Muslim fundamentalist faction charged today. Workers for a Kenya-based Western relief organization confirmed the attack.

title: Looking Shaky, Yeltsin Takes Oath of Office
description: Boris N. Yeltsin was sworn in today as the first democratically elected President of an independent Russia during a brief, scaled-down inauguration ceremony that seemed focused more on conserving his strength than on flaunting his power.

title: New Turkish Chief's Muslim Tour Stirs U.S. Worry
description: Turkey's new Prime Minister, the leader of the country's growing Islamic party, heads off on his first foreign visit on Saturday to fundamentalist Iran, the Clinton Administration's least favored nation, and then proceeds on a kind of Muslim world tour: to Pakistan, Malaysia and Indonesia.

title: Domingo Cavallo's Achievement
description: Few people get the chance to play so constructive a role in their country's history as Domingo Cavallo, who resigned last month after five years as Argentina's Finance Minister. Applying his own powerful intellect and personality, and enjoying the unflinching political support of President Carlos Saul Menem, Mr. Cavallo guided an economy desperately sick with hyperinflation and corruption back to vitality and international respectability.

title: Sir Nevill Francis Mott, 90, a Pioneer Physicist
description: Sir Nevill Francis Mott, a British physicist whose spadework for a new branch of solid-state physics was crowned with a Nobel Prize, died on Thursday at a hospital in Milton Keynes, England. He was 90 and lived in the nearby village of Aspley Guise.

But that was not a new experience for Dr. Reding. He had helped people die nearly a half century ago, when he was just out of medical school and working with his father, a doctor, in their native Belgium.

title: Granny, Get Your Gun
description: The National Rifle Association has to like Representative Gerald Solomon. During last spring's House debate over repealing the ban on assault weapons (the House voted to repeal; the Senate has yet to act), the New York Republican scolded a political opponent. ''My wife lives alone five days a week in rural area in upstate New York,'' he said. ''She has a right to defend herself when I'm not there. . . and don't you ever forget it.'' We're glad the Congressman's wife can handle herself, but the outburst also made us worry about the larger population of isolated rural women. When ruffians call, do they have the tools for adequate defense?

description: The New Jersey Pest Control Association doesn't usually review movies, but then again, most movies do not portray cockroaches as adorable allies of mankind. ''Joe's Apartment,'' this summer's comedy about a young man and his hundreds of six-legged housemates, does. And the Kenilworth-based assocation, which represents 350 exterminators around the state, has a bone to pick with ''Joe's Apartment.''

Whether it was chatting with the mailman or helping an elderly passer-by burdened with groceries, Ms. Van Epps was a familiar, welcomed face around West 82d Street and Columbus Avenue, the neighborhood she called home since arriving from Beloit, Wis., 22 years ago.

The 8 o'clock program at Saugatuck Congregational Church lists works of Bach and Vivaldi, but it also stretches to encompass ''The English Nightingale'' by the early 17th-century Dutch master Jacob van Eyck, and one of Haydn's ''London'' Trios.

title: A Bird-Dog Conflict Divides a Park
description: Every morning just after dawn, Way Yee totes a flock of songbirds from his Mott Street apartment to Sara D. Roosevelt Park, setting his nine cages in the recently created Wah Mei Bird Garden, a fenced-in slice of lush greenery that until last year was a litter-strewn patch of weeds. Along with a growing clique of elderly Chinese men who follow a centuries-old tradition, Mr. Yee uncovers the cages, and the birds, known as hua mei, stir and begin to sing. ''When my birds are happy, I am happy,'' said Mr. Yee, 69, as the warbling of a dozen dun-colored hua mei nearly drowned out the whoosh of traffic from nearby Delancey Street.

So had airlines, which are responsible for the security of the aircraft, including the screening and loading of luggage. The stricter security measures grew out of the explosion aboard T.W.A. Flight 800 on July 17, which killed all 230 people aboard the Paris-bound 747.

title: Fresh-Looking Work From Six Veterans With a Wealth of Experience
description: FOR all the youthful implications of its title, ''Six Artists: The 1990's,'' at the State Museum here, is a show about maturity. The work, three-quarters of it produced in the last two years, is certainly new. The artists -- Emma Amos, Bill Barrell, John Goodyear, Gary Kuehn, Patricia Lay and George Segal -- are anything but, Mr. Segal being the eldest, at 72, and Ms. Lay the youngest, at 55. Besides, all are well known in the state, and most have seen the limelight in Manhattan, in particular Mr. Segal, who has been a fixture in the Sidney Janis stable since 1967 in addition to starring at numerous museums, domestic and foreign.

title: Planning Arrangement of Furniture
description: MOST people arrange their furniture by trial and error. They simply move the various pieces around until everything fits. This approach, however, is time-consuming and tedious, and the final arrangement may not be the best solution. It's more practical and much easier to work out a furniture plan on paper before attempting to lift the heavy sofa or armoire. A good plan can help to reveal the best possibilities for space allocation, and it can also be a guide for making furniture purchases.

title: Corrections

The picture, which showed a man shopping for dinner on the Upper East Side while his wife was in East Hampton, was taken by Ozier Muhammad of The New York Times.

The curriculum includes 50 books, ranging from ''Leaves of Grass'' to ''The Color Purple'' to ''On the Road.'' Recently, I've added a new title: ''America Day by Day,'' a forgotten gem by Simone de Beauvoir, long out of print.

title: My Shortstop Is Better Than Yours
description: New York is not the easiest place in the world to break in as a major-league shortstop, but a pair of rookies are doing it this summer with enough finesse on the field to turn the city's notoriously stiff-necked fans into true believers. Never before have both the Mets and Yankees brought up rookie shortstops in the same year. And not since 1944 have any two clubs in the city simultaneously introduced new guys at short (Buddy Kerr for the Giants and Mike Milosevich for the Yankees). The Met's Rey Ordonez is an acrobatic fielder who defected from Cuba three years ago and who, at 24, still looks like the bat boy. He is modest off the field and reckless on it. Derek Jeter of the Yankees is a 22-year-old string bean from Kalamazoo, Mich. Athletic and affable, he finds it weird to see his snazzier plays lauded on television.

title: Life on Mars? So What?
description: The textbooks of my youth designated our current epoch as the Age of Man. Current linguistic preferences favor an Age of Mammals. More generous people, with fewer parochial inclinations, often choose to honor a truly dominant multicellular group of more than a million described species (compared with a paltry 4,000 for mammals): the Age of Insects. But all these proposals represent little more than multicellular prejudice. We are now, as our planet has been for 3.5 billion years, in an Age of Bacteria.

Actually, there is no need to wonder: Ford, a company known to harbor engineers who would rather be Indy drivers, has been doing just that with the Taurus SHO since the mid-1980's. And the all-new 1996 model, featuring a 235-horsepower V8 built in collaboration with Yamaha, is a pure delight.

It can only be: John Gotti. Yes, America's most ostentatious, best-dressed (and most bugged) Mafia boss is back, reappearing Saturday night in a two-hour HBO movie titled, eloquently enough, ''Gotti.''

title: Wedgies Walk Again
description: A World War II favorite, the wedge-sole shoe, is enjoying a revival. The style was a comfortable, long-wearing solution for women when leather was rationed and Americans were limited to two pairs of leather shoes a year. Europe knew even worse scarcities. The designer Salvatore Ferragamo, who pioneered the wedge as orthopedic footwear in the mid-1930's, sculptured wood and cork into baroque wedgies that would last for the duration. An early American example was the 1937 play shoes of a California manufacturer, Joyce Casual. The company used soles of wood, cork, raffia and rope for its espadrille styles. Gertrude Lawrence, the English actress, created a sensation on the streets of London with her bare legs and painted toenails, to go with the informality of her open wedge shoes. She presciently prepared women to accept an era when nylon went into parachutes instead of stockings. One of the newest wedgie styles, bottom right, has a hollowed metal or plastic frame with thin rubber soles.

title: Where Real Windmills Add a Countrified Touch to Suburbia

At various spots on the 750-acre subdivision here, with its 1950's split-level and Colonial-style houses, its manicured lawns and manmade lakes, are five windmills. Although no longer truly functional, these structures are the real thing: 60-foot-high, stone-and-wood towers topped with big rotating blades.

title: An Aptly Timed Tale of Rebirth and Renewal . . .

The perennial Shakespearean puzzlement, with its obstructions to rationality, is part royal tragedy, part rustic idyll, part romantic fable, none coalescing, all confounding. During these severe mood swings, a child and his mother die of grief; a king goes bonkers and comes around; time flies; a bear exits, and a statue lives. All ends well, but no one of sound mind is going to fall for those trumped-up reconciliations, no matter what the oracle at Delphi says.

title: It's His Party

He championed small government so successfully that even President Clinton must now pay it lip service. He made conservatism such an honored term that Democrats had to flee its antonym, the liberal label. He made possible the Republican revolution that is at stake in San Diego. One could say of the convention site what Sir Christopher Wren's tomb says of the cathedral built over it: Don't look for his monument; you are in it.

But a closer look behind the new plasterboard, windows and other renovations at 6 Manor Lane reveals a charred entryway, blackened bricks and a flickering faded yellow tape, which reads, ''Fire lane -- do not cross.''

title: Conceptualism, Russian Style
description: When Ilya Kabakov was a young student at the Moscow Art School during World War II, Government restrictions meant that the only way his mother could obtain permission to stay in the city with her son was for her to work at the school. She became a janitor. Chronically poor, she surreptitiously took up residence for a time in the school's linen closet, a former lavatory. Mr. Kabakov repaid his mother for her sacrifices; he joined the artists' union and became a successful children's book illustrator. In the 1970's, the illustrator turned into a dissident artist, the leader of a group of young painters including Erik Bulatov, Vitaly Komar and Alexander Melamid, commonly known as the Moscow Conceptualists. He used his innocuous colored-pencil technique to narrate absurdist tales like that of ''Decorator Maligin,'' a bureaucrat who ruins documents with obsessive doodling. In ILYA KABAKOV: The Man Who Never Threw Anything Away (Abrams, $65), the art critic Amei Wallach describes the key developments in Mr. Kabakov's art, from his goofily naive works of the 70's to his preoccupation in the 80's with ''total installations,'' works involving text, sound, drawing, garbage, kitchen equipment and photographs. In 1991, Mr. Kabakov was included in a show at the Museum of Modern Art, organized by Robert Storr, the museum's curator of contemporary painting and sculpture (who contributes an excellent introduction exploring the artist's philosophical bearings). The next year, Mr. Kabakov represented Russia at an international art exhibition in Kassel, Germany, with his installation ''Toilet,'' which recast his memories of his mother's struggles. Inside ''Toilet'' was a crudely built latrine that was designed as a shelter; in it the artist placed simple furniture, dishes, washing, arranged as if the occupants had just stepped out -- or had been evicted, as his mother had been. Here, as always, Mr. Kabakov's art -- by turns comic, chilling and purposefully stressful -- offers no answers, only poignant intuitions about the vulnerability of human life. Siri Huntoon

It would have had nothing to do with the look or the fit of the team's green-and-metallic-silver shirts. Considering the problems the Mariners have had with their pitching, Belcher could have been a stabilizing force on the staff.

But among Greenwich Village residents, they are some of the fighting words hurled at the new McDonald's on the Avenue of the Americas at Eighth Street.

Easily reached from the big downtown hotels are a bevy of sophisticated yet relaxed restaurants where a tie is optional and portions are geared to hearty Midwestern appetites. Service is generally congenial and informed without being fussy.

The coxswain, a well-mannered gent, knows that when two ladies stand he is also supposed to stand, so he does. The bombardier, 9, feeling left out, stands as well. We quickly learn that four people standing in a canoe is four too many.

Campbell of Essex, Conn. The Rev. John Bishop, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy Spirit in Orleans, Mass.

title: THE NEXT PRO-LIFERS
description: According to its opponents, physician-assisted suicide seems to be about doctors persuading helpless people to die. To someone who has been there, it is about taking death out of impersonal hospitals and returning it to the home. It's about the end of fear and greater heartache because a doctor has prescribed the right dose of the right medicine for a final cure. It is about honoring the courage and moral seriousness of those who chose a responsible death. It's about a proper respect for freedom of conscience and personal dignity.

title: A Sculptor's Obsession, A Model's Devotion
description: Aristide Maillol had a lifelong fixation: young, nude women. This is not so uncommon, mind you, but Maillol (1861-1944) cast his idee fixe in bronze with sufficient conviction to have it lodge in museums and art history books and on the pedestals of monuments all over France. His monument to Cezanne is a female nude, his monument to Debussy another one, his monument to Auguste Blanqui (a revolutionary who spent most of his life in prison) yet another. Then there are a couple of female nude monuments to the dead. You are free to guess just how he represented the Ile-de-France, the Mediterranean, the seasons, air, the river.

description: The protracted investigation into the downing of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 has spawned an unusual ritual, one that has brought refreshing moments of humanity to the rigidly scientific hunt for clues. title: U.S. Airlines Expand Electronic Ticketing
description: Carnival, Delta and Northwest are among the airlines that have recently expanded their electronic ticketing service. With electronic ticketing, there is no paper ticket that needs to be picked up or can be lost: Passengers make reservations as usual, either directly through the airline or with a travel agent who has access to the reservations systems, and pay with a credit card. Generally, the passenger receives a confirmation number and a written receipt; the itinerary is faxed or mailed. At the airport, boarding passes are usually obtained by showing identification to an agent at the gate.

title: THE GARDEN PATH
description: I would like to give Louise Erdrich a grateful kiss for the sweet strength and wisdom of her essay ''The Garden Path'' (Style, July 21). At 16, my friends and I are acutely susceptible to the plethora of products that claim to make you gorgeous if you follow the directions on the bottle. Replacing the regimens dictated by Clinique and Cover Girl with the ritual of tending a garden is a lovely idea. I'd say that planting roses is a safe, natural and 100-percent-guaranteed way to feel and look more beautiful.

description: America Online, the nation's largest on-line commercial computer network, went abruptly off-line last week, leaving its 6.2 million subscribers stranded in cyberspace for nearly 19 hours.

title: If Robby the Robot Had Little Brothers . . .
description: IN 1981, Matthew Wyse, then a 42-year-old book dealer, came across a wind-up tin robot from the 1950's at a collectibles show. He was so transfixed by the vivid green and orange toy robot, which looked like a blank-eyed Martian, that he willingly paid $12 for it. ''The price seemed high to me at the time,'' he said. ''So I didn't tell my wife, Karen, what I'd paid for it.'' He quickly discovered that the robot, called the Interplanetary Explorer Spaceman, was worth about $1,000.

title: This Man Does Everything for His Movies but Write the Reviews
description: TOM NOONAN'S RESUME coming through a fax machine looks like a sight gag. There's a page for ''Tom Noonan, Actor.'' There's a page for ''Tom Noonan, Composer.'' There's a page for ''Tom Noonan, Writer/Director.'' At the bottom of that page there's a heading that says ''Other.'' Under ''Other'' it says: ''Tom Noonan has written 3 unproduced plays, 19 unproduced half-hour teleplays, 7 unproduced screenplays, 1 unproduced sitcom pilot, an unpublished book of 16 short stories ('Agog') and an unpublished novel ('Must Have'). All available for reading.''

Only 18th-century satins and silks, which took, a program insert says, ''many, many hours of stitching, altering and trimming.''

title: The Movies Miss Another Opportunity
description: WHEN WORD OF Robert Altman's new film, ''Kansas City,'' started to filter down into the jazz world, there was almost unparalleled excitement. What we had known all along, we hoped, had at last been certified by Hollywood. The camera had found a cast of charismatic musicians -- the saxophonists Joshua Redman, Craig Handy and James Carter, the pianists Cyrus Chestnut and Geri Allen, the trumpeter Nicholas Payton -- that it could lavish its attentions on.

description: SINCE 1931, the South Shore Long Island communities of Woodmere, Lawrence, Hewlett, Cedarhurst and Inwood have been known as the Five Towns. Close to the Queens border, John F. Kennedy International Airport and public beaches, they earned their separate identities long ago.

description: Barry Mark was piling gear into the cabin of his boat, the 40-foot Deena-R. He tossed bedding down a hatch, stowed food in the galley, checked the barometer and the fuel gauge and got set for an eight-day solo run in the Dixon Entrance to try to catch some salmon.

title: The Color Purple
description: Black women are very particular about their lips. If you don't believe me, take a random sample of any five black women, show them a picture of Whoopi Goldberg and watch them go off. Everybody has made peace with Whoopi's hair; after all, dreadlocks and braids have been worn by everyone from Toni Morrison to Vanessa Williams. But Whoopi's lips, and in particular her lipstick, are a whole other story. As I watched the Oscars earlier this year with a group of sister-girlfriends, Whoopi hadn't been on stage five minutes before someone laid into her lips. ''I like the dress,'' said Lisa, ''but I don't like that black lipstick.'' As much as it has been said that Whoopi is not a symbol of black womanhood, for many black women, she's a more realistic role model than, say, Naomi Campbell. Besides, we like Whoopi and we want her to look pretty, so we fuss about her lipstick.

title: Soldiers of Gulf War Trace Their Ailments
description: Members of an Army engineering battalion that blew up 33 captured Iraqi bunkers during the Persian Gulf War in 1991 believe they were exposed to chemical weapons as a result. Many have had serious illnesses since the war ended.

title: Prominent Downtown Vacancies Worry Bronxville
description: ON summer evenings a sparse, but steady stream of people can usually be seen strolling the streets of this quaint village's downtown. They stop, often with ice cream cones in hand, to look in the lighted shop windows or they linger to talk on their way to or from the village's several restaurants, two coffee bars or triplex movie theater.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article last Sunday reported that Time and Newsweek magazines were planning to publish college guidebooks later this year for the first time. surveying the field of other college guides, the article noted that Money magazine, which has published one in the past, had decided this year to devote a 45-page section of its page section of its September issue to surveying colleges, instead of publishing a separate book.

description: THE DANCING COLUMNOn Order in Architecture.By Joseph Rykwert.Illustrated. 598 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:The MIT Press. $75.

title: THE NEXT PRO-LIFERS
description: Paul Wilkes's ''The Next Pro-Lifers'' (July 21) is a magnificent article and long overdue. I am 23 years old and am fearful of the rising tide of efforts to legalize doctor-assisted suicide, an act that may be an acceptable option by the time it is my generation's turn to die. Thanks for bringing to light the possibility that, as Yale Kamisar has written, in a climate in which doctor-assisted suicide is the ''rational'' thing to do, it may also become the unreasonable thing not to do.

title: Please Raise Your Tray Tables. You Won't Be Needing Them.
description: WHEN Trica Jean-Baptiste flew from Newark to New Orleans in April on business, she fended off hunger during her five-hour trip with a hot dog and bag of chips she bought at the Cincinnati airport before boarding her connecting flight. ''Otherwise I would have been famished,'' said Ms. Jean-Baptiste, the director of public relations for the Parker Meridien hotel in Manhattan, ''because food wasn't served on either one of the flights.''

title: A GOOD NEWS/BAD NEWS AIDS JOKE
description: Having recently returned from the 11th international conference on AIDS in Vancouver, Canada, I read with great interest Larry Kramer's cogent discussion of the dilemmas facing our nation as we look for ways to assure access to the powerful new AIDS drugs known as protease inhibitors (''A Good News/ Bad News AIDS Joke,'' July 14) As Kramer noted, under its accelerated approval system, the Food and Drug Administration approved the first three protease inhibitors in record time. He is also correct about the need to work with insurance companies and managed-care organizations to assure access to protease inhibitors and other drugs for people with private insurance. In February, Vice President Gore met with the leaders of 11 pharmaceutical manufacturers to begin a discussion on that subject.

title: Gulf Veterans Ascribe Ailments to Toxic Weapons
description: After years of Pentagon denials, a group of veterans of the Persian Gulf War are offering the most compelling evidence to date that American troops were exposed to Iraqi chemical weapons. The veterans say nerve gas and other chemical agents have begun to ravage their bodies.

title: Inconsistent Wilson Fails In Mets' Loss
description: This was supposed to be the time of year when Paul Wilson started to shed his rookie skin and learned how to find success consistently. But consistency remains an elusive quest for the right-hander, who continues to be more erratic than dramatic.

title: Leith Brooks, John Hockin

One, Vuitton Tower, is suave, seductive; the other, the Austrian Cultural Institute, is aggressive, menacing. Both are first-rate pieces of architecture that make most of the city's recent buildings look feloniously compliant. No doubt that's the admission this twosome wants to extract from New York. When did your buildings become frightened of their own shadows? Why haven't they done more to disturb the peace?

title: Hopping a Trolley In Vienna
description: THE classical Vienna of music, coffeehouses and monumental Romanesque architecture is also, surprisingly, the Vienna of trolleys. The Viennese take their trolleys, part of one of the finest public transportation systems in the world, for granted. Most visitors, on the other hand, see the constant flow of red and white streetcars only through the viewfinder of a camera. Which is a mistake, for it really pays to hop a trolley and ride the rails just as the Viennese do. It's by far the best way to see the city that stretches toward the hills and plains beyond its compact, walkable medieval core.

title: The Yellow Couch
description: IN A MOMENT OF PERSONAL CRISIS, HOW much help can you expect from a New York cabby? I began studying this question after watching HBO's ''Taxicab Confessions,'' a series of documentaries (the third installment is being shown this month) in which hidden cameras record the secrets of unsuspecting cab riders. One girl tells the driver that she shot her boyfriend; a transsexual discusses her orgasms; a young man cruising for hookers explains how his father murdered his mother. The tales are riveting, but what's most amazing is the reaction of the drivers, all working New York City cabbies. In every instance, the driver listens sympathetically and offers helpful comments in perfect English.

title: Kenny Albert, Barbara R. Wolf
description: Barbara Renee Wolf, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Wolf of Parsippany, N.J., was married last evening to Kenny Albert, a son of the sports announcer Marv Albert of New York and Benita Oberlander of Sands Point, L.I. Cantor Jacob Yaron performed the ceremony at the Livingston (N.J.) Country Club.

title: Roenick And Isles Talking
description: The Islanders' chances of obtaining Jeremy Roenick have improved, his agent said yesterday, but no deal is in place to move the disgruntled Chicago Blackhawks star to Long Island. ''It's not done,'' Neil Abbott said in a telephone interview, ''but we're working on it. We're on the same page.''

title: Arthur E. Bisson, Antisubmarine expert, 55
description: Dr. Arthur E. Bisson, an expert in antisubmarine warfare who had been director of science and technology in the Office of Naval Research since 1992, died on Aug. 3 at his home in McLean, Va. He was 55.

title: Celebrator of Fun, in All Its Many Guises
description: THE COSTUME DESIGNER Howard Crabtree spent the last weeks of his life hot-gluing toilet bowl brushes and garden hoses to showgirl outfits. His Off Broadway musical revue ''When Pigs Fly'' was opening in a matter of weeks and, AIDS be damned, the costumes would be finished. Talk about deadlines.

title: The Movies Discover The Teen-Age Girl
description: NO ONE HAS YET CALLED IT such, but if 1996 is to be christened anyone's, it ought surely to be named the year of the teen-age girl. Consider the evidence: Alanis Morissette packs concert venues with thousands of ululating 13-year-olds who thrill to her hit ''Ironic'' the way their mothers swooned over ''Love Me Do.'' ''Reviving Ophelia,'' a therapist's account of her work with young women, is at the top of the paperback best seller list. ''My So-Called Life,'' a drama about a 15-year-old girl and her angst, plays in perpetual reruns on MTV. Time magazine recently named the psychologist Carol Gilligan, who first brought girls' faltering sense of self to public attention, one of the country's most influential people. And in the ultimate Zeitgeist test, a slew of films are being released this summer centering on the lives of adolescent (and preadolescent) girls.

title: A Niche in Importing Specialty Produce
description: IN a 30,000-square foot warehouse here on the Saw Mill River Road are all the makings of a movable feast. Prized Galia melons from Spain, blood oranges, cippolini onions and porcini mushrooms from Italy, yellow, red, orange, purple and white peppers from Holland, shallots from France, fresh herbs and dates from Israel and tomatoes on the vine from the Netherlands are but a sampling of the vast inventory of fruits and vegetables imported by the Merex Company.

title: Where Austrians Find Austria
description: LIGHT-FOOTED, I left the Michaelerplatz one afternoon last August and entered the historic precincts of Vienna's Imperial Hofburg. I was off to see Montezuma's headdress, the feathered masterwork that the Mexican monarch had offered the Hapsburg King of Spain in hopes of buying him off. As I approached the Imperial Treasury, I discovered a mass of humanity surging in the door ahead of me. Cortes took Mexico with less. I withdrew in disappointment.

title: Idiotika
description: LINES OF FATE

title: Officially Absolved, Colombian Still Gets No Respect
description: PRESIDENT ERNESTO SAMPER entered the third year of his presidency last week, trailed by the ghost of charges that drug money financed his election. The absolution from the Colombian Congress that he fought so hard for last June is doing little to clear his name, while a new indictment against drug traffickers in Miami is kindling talk of his possible extradition. Lacking support in familiar quarters, Mr. Samper is launching a desperate, at times embarrassing, drive for respectability abroad and post-presidential survival at home.

title: First a Band. Then a Summer Festival. Next, the World?
description: IN THE FADING LIGHT OF A summer afternoon at the Long Island National Cemetery in Farmingdale, a production assistant is performing the mighty task of spinning a chair in which the 350-plus-pound John Popper sits while he plays ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' on a silver harmonica. In a few days, Mr. Popper and his band, Blues Traveler, will open the fifth annual Horde summer music festival, which he founded in 1992.

title: Howard Will Remain a Bullet, After All
description: Juwan Howard will play for the Washington Bullets next season, after a settlement announced last night between the National Basketball Association and the Miami Heat.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Residential Sales column last Sunday omitted a broker in the purchase of a town house at 266 West 12th Street. The purchaser was represented by Douglas Elliman.

title: THE GARDEN PATH
description: Erdrich sets up another ''either/or'' for judging the best kind of woman. Whether it's working mothers versus stay-at-home mothers or virgins versus whores or women who try to look 25 and women who don't, the result is the same: women bashing women.

title: Quaker Project Offers Inmates Alternatives to Violent Actions
description: WHEN Fernando Serrano enrolled in the Alternatives to Violence Project, he had to wait almost a year before taking the course because there were more than 700 men on the waiting list. His patience was tempered because time was something he had plenty of: he is serving a life sentence for murder.

title: A Broadsword Bash, or 'Braveheart'-in-the-Square
description: The clang of metal stops passers-by in their tracks. Or perhaps it is the sight of a masked, armored figure pointing a sword at his opponent, who is on his knees. After only a few minutes, a circle of tourists, in-line skaters and other people have gathered in Union Square, all transfixed by the anachronistic sight.

title: From Regional Brokers, Bets on Local Businesses
description: PEOPLE have long searched their own neighborhoods for investment ideas that have yet to show up on the radars of Wall Street analysts. A new coffee bar or a child's favorite store can be a most promising stock tip. But searching someone else's backyard for such ideas -- now that's a neat trick.

title: Connors Outlasts a Little-Known Player
description: In a milieu of former Grand Slam champions like Jimmy Connors, John McEnroe and Bjorn Borg on the 35-and-over Nuveen Challenge Tour, Mansour Bahrami seems out of place, to say the least.

title: In Sunken Tugboat's Wake, A Full Cargo of Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Equal to 32 Football Fields, New Center Is Hotly Debated
description: When completed, the Palisades Center mall here is expected to boast an ice-skating rink, a 2,100-seat amphitheater, a 21-screen cinema complex, a carousel, a ferris wheel, more than 15 restaurants and a 2,000-seat food court. Not to mention 225 stores, from Lord & Taylor and JCPenney to Nobody Beats the Wiz and Bed Bath and Beyond, which would make this a shopper's Eden second in size only to the Mall of America in Bloomington, Minn.

title: Cape May-Lewes Car Ferry Gets Some Style
description: Passengers who drive their vehicles onto the newly refurbished ferry Twin Capes, for the 70-minute crossing of Delaware Bay between Lewes, Del., and Cape May, N.J., are not likely to mistake it for a cruise ship. But neither will they confuse it with an ordinary ferry -- not with two of its three air-conditioned passenger decks fully enclosed, an outdoor cafe with a bar, two elevators connecting the car deck to the passenger deck, a children's play room, a food court and a 100-seat glass-enclosed dining area linked to a mezzanine lounge by a spiral staircase.

title: Family Education, Preschool to Parenthood
description: NANCY W. NEWMAN retired in June after 33 years as head of early childhood education at the Bridgeport Jewish Center for Community Services. Ms. Newman, of Fairfield, became the program's first teacher, was asked to be a part-time director the following year and was named full-time director the third year.

title: These Stalkers Are Really Just People Who Love Too Much
description: ''THE FAN'' OPENS ON FRIDAY WITH ROBERT DE NIRO as a baseball fanatic who'd kill to see his favorite player do well. Mr. De Niro plays a modern stalker, one who adores or idolizes his victims. (Neither version of ''Cape Fear'' qualifies as a modern stalker movie, because the ex-con -- Robert Mitchum in 1962, Mr. De Niro again in 1991 -- is motivated by revenge, not love.)

title: Baerga's Mission
description: Carlos Baerga thought he was the heart and soul of the Cleveland Indians, an inspirational leader loved by his fans and his team. Or at least that's what he thought until July 29, when he was traded to the Mets.

title: For Sale: Zambia's Rich Copper Mines, All of Them
description: It's easy to tell where the real money in Zambia is. Just look underfoot.

title: Sometimes, It's All in the Showiest Leaf
description: IT all began with a spot in the garden that needed a bit of color, but was too shady for flowering plants. While thinking about a variety of ways to handle the situation, coleus came to mind.

title: 4000 Insults
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: On West 17th, a Little Bit More of West 17th
description: A stark white building in Chelsea whose porthole-like window design was adopted by its former owners, a maritime union, to evoke links to the sea is being given a partial new face, a sort of 20-foot-high stage set designed to link it visually with its neighbors.

title: Meeting the Girl in the Picture
description: FOR four years I had been writing to the Bongbonga family, who live in the middle of the jungle on an island in the Philippines. It was somewhat eerie to walk down a narrow dirt path and finally arrive at their thatch-roofed bungalow beside a banana tree. ''Joy,'' my escort called out. ''Joy Bongbonga! Your foster father is here!''

title: A Nation in Arms
description: Out of Afghanistan

title: Wilson and Weld, Citing Restrictions, Say They Won't Speak at Event
description: In a last-minute snag that spotlighted Republican efforts for tight control of the proceedings at their convention here, two Governors, Pete Wilson of California and William F. Weld of Massachusetts, have told convention organizers that they will not speak at the event rather then accede to conditions for their participation.

title: Hyberbole Rolls on 46th Long Before Crosstown Buses Can
description: In the shadow of the United Nations, a territorial dispute is simmering. Crosstown buses might now roll through 46th Street, instead of 47th Street, which is being narrowed. And 46th Street residents are angry.

title: Broadway: His Middle Name
description: THE 19th-century merchant Charles Baltzell Rouss liked Broadway so much he adopted it as his middle name -- and ran the words ''Charles Broadway Rouss'' across the front of the two-part store he built at 555 Broadway, between Prince and Spring Streets.

title: Unseal CD's Without Coming Unglued
description: CAN a two-inch trapeziform plastic tool with a tiny razor blade hidden between two rounded wings find its way into the pantheon of indispensable everyday objects? Brian McCracken thinks it has a shot, at least in households where extracting a compact disk from its packaging results in broken fingernails and unprintable epithets.

title: Security at Kennedy Airport Called Porous, Even After Crash
description: Shortly after Trans World Airlines Flight 800 crashed on July 17, the airline said that only about 40 employees had had direct contact with the airplane in the three hours that it had waited on the ground at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph of the Louis Heinsheimer mansion in Far Rockaway, Queens, with the Streetscapes column last Sunday carried an erroneous credit. The picture was from the collection of Vincent Seyfried.

title: Class Warfare? The Rich Win by Default.
description: YOUR chance of running into a low-income delegate among the Republicans gathering in San Diego this week is 50 to 1, only a bit higher than the chances that the next time Congress considers legislation affecting poor people, it will hear much from any of them. The Democratic National Convention will offer better odds of finding a delegate with a family income under $25,000: they'll be just 14 to 1.

title: Wendy Crumbine, Jed Ferdinand
description: Wendy Jordan Crumbine, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Crumbine of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Edmund John Ferdinand 3d, the son of Nancy Ferdinand Chwasky of New York and Mr. Ferdinand Jr. of Hazelton, Pa. The Rev. Karen Forester performed the ceremony at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich.

title: Sandra Bregman And Jose A. Toro
description: Sandra Kneifl Bregman, the chief executive of BKB Pharmaceuticals in Washington, and Jose Angel Toro, a lawyer in Washington, are to be married this evening at their home in Bethesda, Md. Molly Ruhl, the Clerk of the Montgomery County Circuit Court in Rockville, Md., is to officiate.

title: A QUESTION FOR: Lucy Lawless
description: Lucy Lawless, a New Zealander, stars in ''Xena: Warrior Princess,'' the top-rated new syndicated television show in the United States.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Bottoms Up, Arboreally

title: League Looking Into Favre's Pill Supplier
description: The National Football League plans to investigate claims that the former Green Bay Packers tackle John Jurkovic gave painkillers to quarterback Brett Favre. The Packers had not been contacted as of Friday, but expected to hear from the league, General Manager Ron Wolf said.

title: Patricia Traub, Luke Sheridan
description: Patricia Ann Traub, a daughter of Mary Traub of Yonkers and the late Philip Traub, was married yesterday to Luke Francis Sheridan, a son of Margaret and Robert Sheridan, also of Yonkers. The Rev. Dawson J. Ambosta performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: E-Mail, Voice Mail, Telephone, Whatever
description: Visitors to the Macworld convention in Boston last week tried out Internet Phone, which allows computer users to make long-distance phone calls over the Internet. Last year, some 400,000 people regularly used the Internet to make calls, but that number may jump to 16 million by 1999, according to a forecast by the International Data Corporation.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: The Chechen Situation Looks Bad; So Does Yeltsin
description: Russia often gives the appearance of going to hell in a handbasket. Then things get worse.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: WHITE SMOKE

title: Beyond the 'Winey, Cheesy, Dippy Thing'
description: WHEN Steven Fuentes was a child, food was his life. The savory smell of collard greens and the mouth-watering aroma of cornbread seeped through the walls of his family's West Harlem apartment. A pudgy child who began cooking as soon as he could reach the stove, Mr. Fuentes's love for tasty morsels showed on his puffy cheeks and thick stomach. He often sat in the kitchen and marveled as his grandmother cooked habichuelas rosadas and arroz amarillo, or created a special spice using herbs she grew in a clay pot and ground herself.

title: Mad at Your Modem? History Is on Your Side
description: I SENSED trouble the moment I heard those fateful words, ''no problem.'' The salesman was referring to the modem he had just sold me. ''Installs in minutes,'' he promised. ''It's a snap.''

title: 'That's a Nice Compliment'
description: When Ruben Sierra, the former Yankee, said Friday that all the Yankees care about is winning, he meant it as a criticism. But that is not how George Steinbrenner took it.

title: What's So Funny About the Conventions?
description: WITH the Democratic and Republican conventions looming, cynicism duels with apathy as the prevailing mood among American voters. Comedy Central, however, in a touching display of faith in the political system, is sticking to its core belief: Republicans and Democrats alike can be counted on to deliver a daily quota of stupidity, pretension and hypocrisy. ''There are some laughs there, we think,'' said Doug Herzog, Comedy Central's president and chief executive officer.

title: A Yale Professor's Enduring Romance With Bugs
description: YOUNGSTERS have been collecting bugs for as long as anyone remembers, but for most part the habit lasts no longer than the first shoe box. Charles L. Remington, however, who netted his first butterfly before he was 10, has, six decades later, amassed a collection that wouldn't fit in most shoe stores.

title: What to Wear, What to Touch, What to Say, What to Tuck
description: THEY can't be pregnant. They will sweat. Latches for the inside of their doors will cost $11 each (installed). They will suffer during their initiation. (But it isn't called hazing. It's ''adversative treatment,'' please.)

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: BLACK MAPS

title: Connected, But To What?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A table last Sunday with an article about the dual roles of Linda J. Wachner as chief executive of the Warnaco Group and the Authentic Fitness Corporation misstated the Cabinet position in the Carter Administration held by Joseph A. Califano Jr., who is a director of both of Mrs. Wachner's companies. He was Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, not Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Jazz Enters Litchfield
description: MENTION the Northwest Hills and most Connecticut residents think of stately Colonial mansions, winding country roads and quaint villages. But jazz? Well yes. Next weekend, the first Litchfield Jazz Festival will take place at White Memorial Conservation Center, a 4,000-acre nature preserve off Route 202.

title: Mariela Ferro And Scott Meyer
description: Mariela Ferro, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francisco M. Ferro of Buenos Aires, was married last evening to Scott Barnett Meyer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Meyer of Bryn Mawr, Pa. Rabbi Benjamin Rudavsky performed the ceremony at Hammersmith Farm in Newport, R.I. The Rev. George S. Salzmann, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Born That Way?
description: QUEER SCIENCEThe Use and Abuse of Research Into Homosexuality.By Simon LeVay.364 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:The MIT Press. $25.

title: An English Obsession
description: Shakespeare

title: On High Achievers And College Decisions
description: It was painful to read in ''Top L.I. Students Fall Victim to Colleges' Balancing Plans'' $(July 30$) that many Long Island school districts ''suffer from an excess of excellence,'' that students who do excel can expect to be rejected, that mediocrity is O.K. as long as it's diverse. Better, in fact. We've come far along indeed in the sociologists' master plan I first learned about when sociology was my major back in the early 70's. It was all so interesting then. But I didn't know then what it would mean for my children's futures and how it affects their view of the world. I now despise this penchant for viewing people in blocs, who have set characteristics decided on by these sociologist-demigods who also decide how best to arrange these groups.

title: Repairing the Road To a Secure Retirement
description: To the Editor:

title: Jocelyn Tainsky, Scott M. Sontag
description: Jocelyn Amy Tainsky, the daughter of Steven and Judith Tainsky of New City, N.Y., was married on Thursday evening to Scott Marshall Sontag, a son of Libby Root of Woodbury, L.I., and the late Harold Sontag. Rabbi Howard Jaffe officiated at the Tamcrest Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: Football? Why Are You Here?
description: STEAMY August, lush August, languid August, a dreamy time for lolling on the beach, sailing sailboats, reading and drowsing under the shade of a king-size frond. If there is to be any frolicking on a ball field in the thick of summer, it should be confined to a baseball game.

title: Riding Two Highways: Information and Real
description: ON my two-month excursion from Maine to New Mexico, I decided to live by the Internet. Equipped with an Apple Powerbook and credit-card-sized modem, I'd be a wildcatter on the information frontier, sinking wells into the electronic reservoir as I went along. I'd tap the wisdom of locals, cranky adventurers and fellow travelers on the World Wide Web, turning up obscure but superb restaurants and offbeat attractions along the way. I'd cast off the chains of outdated guidebooks. I'd ignore those weird hardcover glossy magazines, found in upscale hotel rooms, pasted with stern warnings against theft. I had been successful using the Internet planning for shorter trips from home, why wouldn't it work on the road? Jack Kerouac, meet Bill Gates!

title: Hugo de Neufville Dies at 90; Advocate for Conservation
description: Hugo de Neufville, a retired mining executive and conservation advocate who helped obtain protected status for thousands of acres of open land in New Jersey, died on Aug. 3 at his home in Mendham, N.J. He was 90.

title: Alice Johnson, Michael Kelly
description: Alice Steck Johnson, a daughter of Berda Stout Rittenhouse of Milford, N.J., and the late J. Van Wirt Johnson, was married yesterday to Michael Wilson Kelly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Leslie Kelly of Keswick, Va. The Rev. Curtis A. Sandrock, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at Cavallo's Country Inn in Easton, Pa.

title: Christine Lutton, David E. Foster
description: Christine Lin Lutton, the daughter of Elizabeth and Lyle David Lutton of Manhattan Beach, Calif., was married yesterday to David Edward Foster, the son of G. David Foster of Troy, N.Y., and Virginia Foster of Schenectady, N.Y. The Rev. Robert Cornner performed the ceremony at the St. Cross Episcopal Church in Hermosa Beach, Calif.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-19

title: Lara E. Vapnek, Derek A. Denckla
description: Lara Elizabeth Vapnek, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Vapnek of Santa Barbara, Calif., is to be married today to Derek Anthony Denckla, a son of Dr. Martha Bridge Denckla of Bethesda, Md., and Dr. W. Donner Denckla of Franklin, W.Va. Rabbi Arthur Gross-Schaefer is to perform the ceremony at the Biltmore Hotel in Santa Barbara.

title: The Nature of Water and of Farm Animals
description: AT the moment, the Stamford Museum and Nature Center is almost all nature. In the art gallery, there are two exhibitions, both focused on the natural world. The venerable American painter Milton Avery (1893-1965) is represented by a bevy of works on paper: drawings, prints and watercolor. The exhibition is titled ''Ebb and Flow,'' and the most striking works feature water. Along with Avery's works are disarming photographs of barnyard animals by Hank Meirowitz, who lives in New Milford.

title: Swooping the Stoops: The Quest for Tchotchkes
description: IT was a Sunday made for a stoop sale. The sun was hiding behind the gauze of gray clouds, knocking out that devil of a competitor, the beach. A breeze blew down the tree-lined side streets, stirring air that was wet but not humid enough to discourage the regulars, a home-shopping network of bargain seekers bouncing through another day's worth of Brooklyn buys.

title: Amish Going Modern, Sort of, About Skating
description: Andrew Herschberger's girlfriend lives in Delta, almost 25 miles across the gentle hills of the Susquehanna Valley. But as a member of the Amish community, he may not drive a car, ride a motorcycle or even hop on a bicycle to go there.

title: Condo Associations Applaud Law Restoring Powers
description: TWO years ago court rulings virtually stripped condominium associations in New Jersey of their ability to impose fines and late fees on owners who did not pay monthly common charges on time or comply with the rules governing their developments, causing discord in some and a bit of chaos in others.

title: Free of Debt, Flush With Savings, and Ready to Diversify
description: WITH a master's degree in finance from Johns Hopkins University, Pam Williams thought she was well prepared to invest the savings that she and her husband, Andrew, were accumulating. She was in for a shock.

title: Dina Shapiro, Darren Glassman
description: Dina Shapiro, the daughter of Jack and Lucy Shapiro of Baltimore, was married last evening to Darren Glassman, a son of Robert and Iris Glassman of New York. Rabbi Rex Perlmeter performed the ceremony at the Engineering Society of Baltimore.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Two $9 Whites

title: Marked Women
description: A LAZY EYE

title: Kemp Will See Familiar Faces in the Dole Camp
description: Jack F. Kemp should feel right at home in Bob Dole's campaign. Some of Mr. Dole's senior advisers are veterans of Kemp campaigns past, starting with the campaign manager and including Mr. Dole's recently hired communications director and chief policy advisers.

title: Salsa for the High-Tops Generation
description: IT'S NOT THE CROWD YOU WOULD expect to see at a salsa concert: teen-agers in baggy jeans and T-shirts, many of them wearing beads with pendants in the red-white-blue tricolor of the Puerto Rican flag. Though salsa has long been associated with elegant dance clubs guarded by burly bouncers whose sole job is to bar the sneaker-shod, this audience flaunts its high-tops. And although salsa is sung mostly in Spanish, these Latino fans speak mostly English. They are the new face of salsa, a music that after a decade or more of stagnancy has come back home to where it began -- the rhythm-savvy streets of New York -- and is once again burning up the charts and the airwaves.

title: Must-Sneer TV
description: In a speech last month, ABC's Jeff Greenfield pondered this question: What if today's smart-alecky political jokesters had been around to heckle the Roosevelts? A scary thought. Could F.D.R. have weathered four terms of Don Imus's calling Eleanor ''ol' fish face''?

title: Seat Selection: Musical Chairs
description: THE assigning of airline seats, often a contentious matter, is entering a new phase. British Airways, which styles itself the world's most popular airline on the basis of international passengers carried -- 23.9 million in 1994 by International Air Transport Association figures -- is taking a new approach, with the goal of satisfying its best customers even at the risk of alienating its occasional customers.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: STYLE, strong drama, chills and thrills (plus a few laughs) beckon the film devotee in the week ahead.

title: PHOTOGRAPHER'S JOURNAL
Mars Rocks Earth
description: About 13,000 years ago, a 4.2-pound chunk of rock fell onto the ice of Antarctica, where it was picked up in 1984 by American scientists. Someone eventually recognized it as a meteorite almost certainly from Mars. And last week scientists, deciphering the rock's sensational clues, concluded this was compelling evidence for primitive life on early Mars.

title: They Laughed at Galileo Too
description: IT WAS DATA THAT PUSHED DEAN RADIN TO the fringe of science, and it is data that keep him there, out on the edge, in that hard country where researchers in less controversial fields will often give him the Look. The Look is delivered by other scientists and fellow rationalists and even his ophthalmologist cousin, Barry, who bug one eye and clamp the other and twist their lips around as if trying to decide, in light of his data, whether to rethink space, time and causality or to get someone from the dean's office to verify his Ph.D. (University of Illinois, 1979, educational psychology.)

title: At Nasdaq, Time to Repent and Grow Up
description: When I was growing up in Los Angeles in the 1960's, every teen-ager knew what a ''Chinese fire drill'' was. At a stoplight, teen-agers would leap out of every door, then get back in a different one before driving off.

title: A Summer's Learning, on a 2-Way Street
description: Wrapped in towels, five young children snacked on nachos and drank pink lemonade as they relaxed on the sun deck after spending the afternoon in the backyard swimming pool. For three of the children, it was a typical summer day. For the other two, it was a special occasion.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Adrift at the Naval Academy
description: The United States Naval Academy brought an end to one of its more embarrassing scandals last week when officials said that 15 midshipmen would be expelled for involvement with illegal drugs.

title: Helicopter or No, How Quiet Is Bedford?
description: I sympathize with the neighbor disturbed by Nelson Peltz's helicopter, but you are all wrong about Bedford being quiet. From dawn to dusk, Bedford residents all live with the constant whine of lawn/leaf blowers.

title: KEMP FISCAL VIEWS WIN PARTY'S HEART
description: It was Jack F. Kemp's long and passionate advocacy of tax cutting as the best way to stimulate greater prosperity for both rich and poor that brought him to the Republican Presidential ticket alongside Bob Dole.

title: Have Muscle, Will Travel: 2 New Ways to Play With Power
description: MY first moments behind the wheel of a 1997 Pontiac Grand Prix GTP were on my frequently traveled route to the video store and dry cleaners. After a long wait at a congested intersection, I spotted a slight opening in the steady stream of cars, punched the gas pedal and quickly made a left turn.

title: A Plea to Designate New Artist Districts
description: To the Editor:

title: Elevating Tunes Not His Own
description: WHAT MAKES A great melody? Take, as a not quite random example, ''Danny Boy.'' The tune is a very old Irish folk song whose original words have long been lost. It has some of the cardinal virtues you often find in great melodies: a mesmerizing repetition of a short pattern (four rising notes); an undulating, wavelike structure (vaguely similar to the lush second theme of Tchaikovsky's ''Pathetique'' Symphony), and a moment of breakthrough, when the tune leaps to the top of the scale, actually two notes above, before falling haltingly back down. (Several haunting melodies share this upward leap and stepwise descent: ''We Shall Overcome,'' for example, and Bob Dylan's ''Sad-Eyed Lady of the Lowlands.'')

title: Yea for Hunt
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: John F. Ross, Heather A. Greenagel
description: Heather Arling Greenagel and John Francis Ross were married yesterday at Lamington Presbyterian Church in Bedminster, N.J. The Rev. David D. Miles performed the ceremony.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: August 11, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 6 FROM POTTER'S FIELD, by Patricia Cornwell. (Berkley, $6.99.) Dr. Kay Scarpetta tracks a serial killer in Central Park. 2 6 THE GREEN MILE: THE BAD DEATH OF EDUARD DELACROIX, by Stephen King. (Signet, $2.99.) The fourth installment of a serial thriller set on death row at Cold Mountain Penitentiary. 3 8 BEACH MUSIC, by Pat Conroy. (Bantam, $7.99.) An American living in Rome returns to South Carolina and tries to cope with his past. 4 5 LIGHTNING, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $7.50.) The happy marriage of a lawyer and her husband is changed after she gets a routine checkup. 5 44 SNOW FALLING ON CEDARS, by David Guterson. (Vintage, $12.) A murder trial recalls the wartime internment of Japanese-Americans. (+) 6 3 A PLACE CALLED FREEDOM, by Ken Follett. (Fawcett, $6.99.) Two Scots, fleeing the injustices of their native land, find romance and freedom in 18th-century America. 7* 5 COMING HOME, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $7.99.) A British woman comes of age during World War II. 8 4 DARING TO DREAM, by Nora Roberts. (Jove, $6.50.) title: The Ethiopian Olympics As Played in Atlanta
description: When Ethiopia's Abebe Bikila ran barefoot at the 1960 Olympics in Rome, becoming the first black African to win an Olympic marathon, Amsale Ayele was a student in Paris. She still remembers the words that came over the radio in the apartment she shared with friends: ''Near the same piazza where Mussolini declared he had invaded Ethiopia,'' the breathless announcer intoned, ''Ethiopia's Abebe Bikila has conquered not only Italy, but the whole world.''

description: Their nighttime sounds can be heard and their enormous glowing eyes seen in cemeteries, wide-open meadows, suburban backyards and city parks. In all, eight species of the nocturnal owl make their homes in New Jersey.

title: Where Does Mondello Stand on Abortion?
description: The Nassau County Republican chairman, Joseph N. Mondello alleges in his letter $(''Mondello's Stand on Abortion,'' July 28$) that he is pro-life on the abortion issue.Such a contention should be seriously questioned. For instance Mr. Mondello states in his letter that he believes ''the so-called 'partial-birth' abortion procedure to be abhorrent and a tragic flaw in the moral fabric of the American society.'' Yet he has continued to heap praise on a litany of abortion-rights Republicans, who support this horrific proposal, including three prominent top governors -- Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, William Weld of Massachusetts and Pete Wilson of California -- all of whom have ''publicly'' endorsed President Clinton's veto of the partial-birth abortion ban.

With the tax rolls straining to support the city's government and residents shouldering most of the burden for making those ends meet, Ms. Kershner's recent decision to reverse the tax-exempt status of a retirement community has been met with cheers, at least in most quarters.

title: Corrections
description: An answer to a question in the Quiz in the special Education Life section last Sunday misstated the setting of the scene in the film ''Thelma and Louise'' in which a car flies off a cliff. It was filmed at Fossil Point, in Moab, Utah, not the Grand Canyon. Another question in the Quiz misstated the era of the film ''Spartacus.'' It was the Roman Republic, not the Holy Roman Empire.

title: Cases of Depression Need Proper Treatment
description: Colette Dowling's letter $('' 'Behavioral' Problems Are Physical Conditions,'' July 21$) expressed a dilemma that faces all psychotherapists, the question of whether to treat people who are depressed with medications, psychotherapy or a combination of both. If we treat this condition with medication alone, we reinforce the belief that the individual carries no responsibility for her or his own behavior, that depression is an unavoidable physical condition for which she or he can take a pill and lay back to wait for amelioration. The individual is disempowered, and since a feeling of helplessness is a primary symptom of depression, her or his denial of power becomes reinforced.

title: Behind the Victorian Facade, The Servants Who Made It Work

In ''Beyond the Velvet Curtain,'' on view through Sept. 8, the roles of servants, the industrial revolution and rapidly changing social mores of Victorian America are interpreted.

title: Grilled Food to Serve at Room Temperature
description: IT seems that only a few years ago the grill was reserved mainly for steaks and hamburgers. But now I find myself using it for almost everything in the summer, from pizza to potatoes. Vegetables can be grilled and served Italian style, at room temperature, garnished with herbs from the garden. Zucchini is good sliced in long strips, marinated in olive oil with garlic and grilled and served sprinkled with basil and peppers, which have been grilled and skinned. I also like to slice potatoes and brown them on the grill or cut them in cubes, steam them and finish them on the grill.

Under a canopy of ancient trees, the deck and inside dining areas remain cool in the lingering warmth; and from the deck, diners can take in the still shimmer of pretty Long Pond.

title: Vengeance for Polly
description: There were all sorts of small things that drew public attention to the killing of Polly Klaas. Her quiet, suburban hometown of Petaluma, Calif., had been seen in the movie ''American Graffiti.'' The actress Winona Ryder had grown up there, too, and joined in the search after Polly was taken at knifepoint from a slumber party at her home. And there was always the shy, innocent smile of a 12-year-old girl that kept connecting to people for weeks after she was kidnapped in October 1993 and for months after her body was found. When jurors decided the fate of Polly's confessed killer last week, they, too, seemed to have had that photographed smile in mind.

They're staying at the San Diego Sheraton Harbor Island, where the host California delegation also has rooms. ''It's who you know,'' admitted Jo McKenzie, the former Connecticut restaurateur. His Government has been less successful in unraveling a political assassination case and a financial scandal that may involve misconduct at the highest levels of Mexican politics.

title: A Man Out of Time
description: Fernando del Paso's PALINURO OF MEXICO (Dalkey Archive, paper, $14.95) reads like a hypertext novel -- filled with digressions, asides, flashbacks and embellishments within which the plot can be disassembled and reconstructed almost at whim. The result is both lively and somewhat intimidating. In an interview, Mr. del Paso called the novel's hero ''not just one character but several, as well as all the characters at once.'' Further, according to the novel itself, Palinuro is someone who ''lived simultaneously in several periods,'' while the narrator both is and is not the protagonist (''Often I adopted his name and lent him mine''). Why has Mr. del Paso traveled to such extremes of obfuscation? He is constructing a universe here and, as God discovered when He tried the same thing, such a project begins with chaos. But instead of quarks and neutrinos, the author's building blocks are human body parts. Palinuro and many of his friends are medical students, while his lover (and cousin), Estefania, is a nurse; much of their time is spent attending dissections or reconstructing skeletons from a random collection of old bones. Meanwhile, Palinuro and Estefania embark on a life of discursions and explorations. Mr. del Paso's new world spreads out in all directions from the lives of Palinuro and Estefania until at last the novel is situated in time (the Mexican student uprisings of 1968, expressed in dramatic form as a rare example of surreal social realism). By then, though, time itself has become meaningless and each life has become all lives. With sly references to (among others) Proust, Swift, Virgil, Sterne, Faulkner and Dante, Mr. del Paso, aided by the inventive translation of Elisabeth Plaister, has written a memorable book. ''Reality,'' he notes near the end, ''will never be the same.'' Nor will readers who persevere. James Polk

The major parties will each be looking for four days and nights of free air to accomplish 15 minutes of preordained political business. Although the major networks are finally cutting back, they continue to waste precious time and money on the least important phase of the Presidential campaign. America needs to overcome this nostalgia for smoke-filled summer drama. It's in October that we need a major fix.

title: Beating the Clock
description: There never seems to be enough money or time, but at least money offers some flexibility. We can try to earn more or spend less. Time is unyielding. All we can do is try to fit more of our day into 24 hours. So we juggle. We pay bills on the bus while commuting to work, hem our pants as we watch a video with the children, and learn to do other things while on the phone that would have amazed Alexander Graham Bell. What tricks do you have to manage your time? Send your story to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. There are the berets and bad poetry of the 1970's, when he aped the avant-garde and genuflected before Andy Warhol. There are the hard drinking and the hard-driving bargains of the 1980's, when he clawed his way into the pantheon of powerful literary agents with the hunger and cunning of a scavenger come late to a feast.

title: Favoring Dairy Farmers Over the Poor
description: The decision last week by Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman to approve creation of a compact -- make that a cartel -- among dairy farmers in the Northeast amounts to the imposition of a tax on milk. The decision strikes a callous blow to poor families, who are hit three times harder by dairy price hikes than other families. Coming one week after President Clinton signed onto a welfare bill that would cut food stamps for poor families by 20 percent, it can only be described as cruel. The dairy compact would allow dairy farmers to jack up prices, perhaps 25 percent, above current Federal guidelines. That is fine for the 3,600 dairy farmers who control Senator Patrick Leahy of Vermont, but not for the 13 million other New Englanders.

title: Bridge
description: The final of the Spingold Knockout Team championship began here this afternoon at the conclusion of the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals with teams headed by Nick Nickell of Manhattan and Richard Schwartz of East Elmhurst, Queens, in opposition. At the midpoint of a 64-deal match, Scwartz led Nickell by 36 imps.

title: Looking Back in Time
description: Attention former teen-agers: the New Jersey Historical Society wants your bobby socks, your platform shoes and your souvenir ashtray from the old Palisades Amusement Park. The first show at the museum the society is building in Newark will be ''Teen-Age New Jersey: From Frank Sinatra to Bruce Springsteen.'' The society is asking for donations that help tell the story of what it was like to come of age in New Jersey from the 1940's through the mid-1970's. To help round up such memorabilia, the society has planned a beach party at the Seagull's Nest restaurant in Sandy Hook from noon to 2 P.M. on Thursday. ANDY NEWMAN

title: New ways of sending radio over the Net promise more sound and less static.
description: IN the last two years, hundreds of pioneering radio broadcasters, from ABC News to the cyberstation KPIG, have begun making their programming available over the Internet. But so far, listening to your computer via the Net has been much like listening to shortwave radio. A tinny speaker emits static-filled broadcasts that seem to come from the other side of the Atlantic.

title: Court Backlog Reduced
description: The backlog in New Jersey's courts decreased for a fifth year, judiciary officials have said. For the year ending June 30, the number of civil cases more than a year old was 67,578, down from more than 81,000 three years ago. The backlog of criminal cases, which make up about 5 percent of court filings, was 6,075, down from nearly 14,000 in 1990. Robert Seidenstein, a spokesman for the courts, said that more judges (361, up from 322 in 1991) and greater efficiency were reducing the backlog.

title: Declaring a Triumph of Ideas, Buchanan Calls for a G.O.P. Truce
description: Declaring a temporary ''Truce of San Diego,'' Patrick J. Buchanan tonight ended his wilted Presidential campaign for 1996 with a speech that seemed to launch his campaign for the year 2000. Mr. Buchanan forswore a third-party candidacy but stopped well short of endorsing Bob Dole, the presumed Republican nominee.

title: Reform Party, Full of Fervor, Opens Session
description: Former Gov. Richard D. Lamm of Colorado, who is challenging Ross Perot for the Reform Party's Presidential nomination, opened the first stage of its bicoastal convention here tonight with the charge that the major parties ''are recklessly driving this country into bankruptcy.''

title: DOLE, IN SAN DIEGO, QUICKLY ZEROES IN ON THE PRESIDENT
description: With a colorful spectacle of boats, afternoon fireworks and partisan politics, Bob Dole arrived today for his long-awaited convention with his new running mate, Jack Kemp, and a rousing pitch for his centerpiece plan to cut taxes.

title: How a U.S. Marine Became Leader of Somalia
description: One of the many oddities in this battered capital is that a son of Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, the Somali faction leader who humiliated the United States in 1993, is a naturalized American citizen, not to mention a United States marine who had served in Somalia briefly.

title: Muster at New Haven
description: Second-ranked THOMAS MUSTER has accepted a wild card into the doubles competition at this week's Pilot Pen International in New Haven. Muster, winner of the 1995 French Open, will play doubles with his training partner, ANDREA GAUDENZI. (AP)

title: How Awkward (and Hopeful) First Dates Are
description: If the Dole-Kemp ticket hopes to be the Astaire and Rogers of politics, it is getting off to a somewhat awkward start.

title: Today's Schedule
Studio executives are alarmed by a surge in the costs of marketing movies.
description: MOVIE stars' salaries are climbing into the stratosphere. So are production costs. But the steepest increase in studio budgets may be for marketing -- an increase that distresses, even frightens, Hollywood executives who say that the costs of promoting a movie on television and in newspapers and magazines seem to be galloping out of control.

title: Soaring Emotions of Hope and Despair
description: Ray Charles likes to lower expectations, then soar far beyond them. At Radio City Music Hall on Saturday night, his set started with a full 20 minutes of muddled, ineptly mixed music from his big band while the audience grew restive. Mr. Charles's first song, ''Ridin' Thumb,'' was a choppy, perfunctory warm-up. And then, with ''Georgia on My Mind,'' Mr. Charles was once again the grandmaster of American song.

title: Man Stabs Four Others In a Subway Argument
description: A subway rider who went to the aid of a woman being harrassed yesterday after she told five men to turn their radio down got into a brawl with the men, and ended up stabbing four of them, the police said.

title: Remember '92
description: To the Editor:

title: RUSSIANS FAILING TO WREST GROZNY FROM INSURGENTS
description: On one of the most violent days of the 20-month war in the secessionist republic of Chechnya, Russian troops fought desperately but in vain today to regain control of the regional capital, Grozny.

title: People
description: * Mel Hioki was named senior vice president and associate creative director at Citigate Albert Frank, New York, a unit of the Citigate Group Ltd. Mr. Hioki was vice president and senior art director at the New York office of Young & Rubicam Inc.

title: U.S. Reaches Airline Accord On Venezuela
description: The United States and Venezuela have agreed to allow continued air service between their two countries for 30 days as Venezuela tries to meet international safety standards.

title: Happy in the East ( -- ) or Smiling :-) in the West
description: When Yukihiro Furuse first began prowling international computer networks in the mid 1980's, he was perplexed to encounter emoticons, the strange combinations of punctuation and accent marks and letters that Westerners used in electronic mail to indicate happiness, sadness and other emotions.

title: On-Line Access to G.O.P. Convention
description: Laptop computers, cellular phones and digital cameras will be passed around the floor of the Republican National Convention this week to capture delegates' views and beefs for instant posting on the party's World Wide Web site.

title: Cantona Gets Physical
description: ERIC CANTONA returned to his volatile ways yesterday at Wembley Stadium, during Manchester United's 4-0 victory over Newcastle in the Charity Shield, the opener of the England's soccer season.

title: No Record, No Excuses, but Cigar Does Have His Health
description: It was the morning after. Cigar had been outrun as he stood on the brink of racing history, and now he was being loaded onto a van by his trainer, Bill Mott, for the trip to the airport and the 3,000-mile flight back to Saratoga.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: St. Martin's Settles Suit With Booksellers
description: St. Martin's Press quietly settled its legal squabble with the American Booksellers Association last week, becoming the fifth publisher to agree to revise pricing policies that the association charged had unfairly favored large chains over small independent bookstores.

title: Examining Adelphi President's Perks, From a Mercedes to a Million-Dollar Condo
description: Last October, the growing storm over Adelphi University's president, Peter Diamandopoulos, prompted an emergency meeting of the board of trustees. He used the occasion, and his presidential expense account, to wine and dine some of his board allies at the Links club on East 62d Street in Manhattan.

title: Equity and Debt Offerings Scheduled for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: How a Radio Station Turned the Beat Around
description: Wayward country music fans who are trying to return to the fold should be advised not to set their clock radios to 103.5 FM for a soothing wake-up call. Today such listeners in the New York area would hear:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Maya Renaissance in Guatemala Turns Political
description: On a set of Maya ruins at the outskirts of this capital, the Vice President of Guatemala last month swore in 21 Maya priests as members of a new Government-sponsored Council of Elders. Throwing flower petals and sugar into a crackling fire as they chanted and danced, the shamans in turn bestowed their official blessing on him.

title: A Double Standard On Abortion Choice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Popeye's Chicken Narrows Review
description: The Popeye's Chicken and Biscuits division of the America's Favorite Chicken Company in Atlanta has narrowed the review on the creative part of its national account to 4 agencies, from 25. The account, with billings estimated at $11 million, had been handled by the Glennon Companies in St. Louis for the last year, until they were eliminated in the review.

title: Considering a Ball Park
description: Minor league baseball is threatening to become a major growth industry in New Jersey. New ball parks have opened in Trenton and Sussex County in the last three years. Tomorrow, the Bridgewater Planning Board will hear a proposal to build a 7,500-seat stadium on the old grounds of a pharmaceutical plant. The stadium, proposed by the Kramer Development group, would be part of a project that includes a 650,000-square-foot mall at Route 287 and Route 28, former home of an American Home Products factory. A local car dealer, Steve Kalafer, would lease the stadium and is negotiating with minor league organizations for a team franchise.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Rhythm-and-Blues Hits Don't Just Fade Away
description: For all the anguished hand-wringing by diehard pop nostalgists decrying the supposed decline of American songwriting in the age of rock, the canon of popular standards keeps growing. Just tune into any soft-rock radio station, or visit the Rainbow and Stars cabaret, when one of the revues produced by Steve Paul is in residence, and you'll discover how many hits of the 1960's and 70's have congealed into today's pop standards.

title: The Delegates: Where Image Meets Reality
