description: The Republican Party is taking great pains to present an image of diversity at its convention here, of ''real people living real lives in the real world,'' in the words of Haley Barbour, the party's chairman.

title: Voices Revel In the Joys Of Singing
description: In some ways ''Born to Sing!'' recalls the musicals of the 1930's, the days when the book of a show was no more than a slip of a plot on which to hang some songs and dance routines. This gospel musical at the Union Square Theater, the third part of a trilogy, continues the story of a fictional gospel superstar, Doris Winter, as she recruits a chorus of singers to accompany her on a World Peace and Harmony tour. The plot teeters uneasily between soap opera and slapstick.

title: Williams Is Back As Big Blue
description: The first law of sequels is: Always try to get the star back. But Disney so alienated Robin Williams after ''Aladdin,'' using his voice in the merchandising against his wishes, it couldn't pay him enough to come back as the shape-shifting, comically dazzling Genie in the made-for-video sequel, ''The Return of Jafar.'' That mediocre sequel was a gigantic best seller anyway, a triumph of marketing over creativity.

title: G.O.P. Summer Stock: a Look at The Numbers
description: With the Presidential nomination long foregone, the San Diego convention offers little suspense. But there remains spectacle, logistics and expense.

title: Fourth Luggage Bin Found in Air Crash As Mystery Deepens
description: Divers have recovered the last of four luggage containers that Trans World Airlines Flight 800 had been carrying in its forward cargo hold and have found that the large metal box, like the others retrieved earlier, showed no visible evidence of damage from a bomb, investigators announced this afternoon.

title: Rafael Kubelik Dies at 82; Championed Czech Music
description: Rafael Kubelik, a conductor who was renowned for his eloquent, deeply personalized interpretations and who directed the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra for nearly 20 years after brief, unhappy tenures with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, the Royal Opera at Covent Garden and the Metropolitan Opera, died yesterday in Lucerne, Switzerland, The Associated Press reported. He was 82 and lived in Lucerne.

title: Arce and McPeak Are a Winning Combination on Sand
description: Beach volleyball in Manhattan? It's not the first sport that comes to mind. No beach, for one thing.

title: 2 From GSD & M Open a New Shop
description: Two vice presidents at GSD & M in Austin, Tex., Mark McGarrah and Bryan Jessee, have left that agency to open their own shop that will provide full agency services on a project basis. The new shop, McGarrah/Jessee, opens with two undisclosed projects. For the last four years, Mr. McGarrah, 33, and Mr. Jessee, 35, were account director and creative director, respectively, at GSD & M, a unit of GGT P.L.C.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a Federal appeals court ruling that a New Jersey school district should not have laid off a teacher solely because of race misstated the status of a related case in Texas. That case, in which another Federal appeals court nullified the affirmative-action program at the University of Texas School of Law, is not awaiting review by the Supreme Court. The court declined to review the case in July.

title: New Reports Point To a Sharp Division In the Khmer Rouge
description: Signs have emerged of a severe split in one of the world's most brutal guerrilla groups, the Khmer Rouge, blamed by some researchers for the deaths of as many as two million Cambodians during their four-year rule in the late 1970's.

title: Worth Watching
description: Colin L. Powell

title: Renew Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Settle on Brown And Turn to the Defense
description: While all eyes were watching the on-field disintegration of Giants quarterback Tommy Maddox against Baltimore on Saturday -- a performance that may have ended his career as a Giant -- defensive end Ray Agnew was getting a finger on his right hand untangled.

title: AT&T's Cards Caught in Shift To Deregulation
description: Deregulating the telephone industry may usher in lower prices and a wealth of new services, as Government officials and telephone executives promise. But for people who own telephone calling cards from AT&T, this new era is starting not with a bang, but a busy signal.

title: No Apologies From Celester
description: William R. Celester, the ousted Newark Police Director who pleaded guilty to fraud charges last month, says that Mayor Sharpe James knew he was misappropriating police funds and had instructed him to do so. In his first extensive interview since his guilty plea, Mr. Celester told The Boston Globe that Mayor James had asked him to entertain dignitaries from China using money from a fund to finance undercover drug investigations.

title: G.O.P. Plank Errs on Immigrant Citizenship
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: A Leatherneck Runs Somalia

title: Avantel of Mexico Entering Long-Distance
description: Yearlong efforts by Avantel S.A. to build a long-distance telephone network in Mexico will bear fruit on Monday when the company opens its fiber-optic phone lines for public use.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GLENN WEIN, the director of ''Grandma Sylvia's Funeral,'' the Off Broadway play about the relationships between members of a Jewish family burying its matriarch, sees no reason why all its actors must be Jewish.

title: Iowa's Annual Fete for the Fat of the Land
description: For several steamy days every summer, Norma Lyon puts on a heavy sweatshirt or two, steps into a refrigerated room with a picture window and becomes a star in the state's biggest show -- the Iowa State Fair, a time machine back to a slower-paced America.

title: Give Me Your Rich . . .
description: The Republican Party has a problem. Too many Americans see it as uncaring, intolerant, mean.

title: Arthur Dock Fon Toy, Chemist, 80
description: Dr. Arthur Dock Fon Toy, an industrial chemist whose research in phosphorus chemistry earned him more than 80 patents, died on July 31 at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 80. The cause was pancreatic cancer, his family said.

title: Redskins Must Pick A Starter
description: It is one of the most hotly contested races in Washington and it has nothing to do with the White House. Who will be the Redskins' starting quarterback for the season opener against the Philadelphia Eagles?

title: High-Technology Dog Tags For More Than Just Dogs
description: Every day in and around Washington, post offices get letters containing a piece of electronic gadgetry the size of a greeting card, sent by the Postal Service to trace the flow of mail through its system. Each electronic card can be read from radio-frequency scanners in the ceilings of the mail rooms, even if the envelope containing the card is buried in a heap of letters and parcels.

title: Pataki Rejects Speaking Role Over Script
description: In another indication of how efforts to control the Republcan convention tightly has been rejected by some party leaders, Gov. George E. Pataki of New York has refused an invitation to address the convention after party officials instructed him to follow a specific script about immigration.

title: Election Rehearsal in Mostar
description: Concerted, high-level diplomatic pressure by the United States and the European Union, including the intervention of President Clinton, has prevented a breakdown of peace efforts in the Bosnian city of Mostar.

title: Fight Over Holidays Expected
description: A bill that would bar teachers from taking paid leave on state holidays that are not school holidays (such as Election Day or Veterans Day) is likely to face opposition from the state teachers union. The bill, which the State Senate passed on July 25, was inspired by several incidents in which unions involved in contract disputes had their members stay home on such holidays, forcing schools to close, said its sponsor, Senator Gordon A. MacInnes, Democrat of Morris Township. But Lynn Maher, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Education Association, said that one or two bad experiences did not a merit a change in the law. The Assembly will address the bill when it reconvenes in September.

title: Profanity Can Be a Joy. Why Take It to Court?
description: BLUE STREAK

title: Talks Slow As Sides Think Over Labor Deal
description: As feverishly as labor representatives of baseball players and owners worked for 33 hours Friday and Saturday in making remarkable progress in their long-running dispute, they moved in relatively slow motion yesterday. So work was not completed on a new collective bargaining agreement.

title: Wealthier School Districts Chafe at Whitman's  Spending Plan
description: When Sharon Kiss and her husband, Robert, were looking for a larger home three years ago, they scoured northern New Jersey's suburbs in search of a town with a fairly easy commute to Wall Street and good schools for their three young children.

title: Reviewing Roadwork Policy
description: After the second nighttime death of a highway worker in two months, the Department of Transportation will review police reports to learn what, if any, safety procedures might be added or changed, said John Dourgarian, a department spokesman. Richard Sabat, 51, of Brick Township, was painting markers on the Palisades Interstate Parkway in Alpine just after dark on Thursday when he was struck and killed by a car. Mr. Sabat's death and that of a New Jersey Turnpike Authority worker on June 12 have fueled criticism of a new Transportation Department policy seeking to minimize traffic delays by having nonemergency maintenance done at night.

title: 2d Power Failure in 6 Weeks Creates Havoc for the West
description: Utility company officials scrambled today to explain a far-flung power failure that cut off electricity to millions of people across the West on Saturday afternoon, snarling traffic, stopping elevators and shutting off air conditioners in patches from Klamath Falls, Ore., to El Paso, Tex.

title: Life on Mars? Let's Not Jump the Gun
description: To the Editor:

title: A Couple of Ex-Indians Carry the Day for Mets
description: The Mets should send a thank-you card to the Cleveland Indians, offering a note of appreciation for helping them beat the Florida Marlins at Joe Robbie Stadium today.

title: Abbott Gets the News
description: The California Angels, perplexed by pitcher JIM ABBOTT and his 1-15 record, took a decisive step yesterday. General Manager BILL BAVASI informed the left-hander of the club's intention to assign him to the minors.

title: Platform Ban on Abortion Veers to Right of Dole's Stand
description: The platform the delegates to the Republican National Convention will adopt Monday night is a rigidly conservative document that in some instances goes well beyond Bob Dole's positions.

title: Credit Offerings Scheduled During the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a one-year bill being auctioned on Thursday.

title: Supply-Side Seducer
description: Jack Kemp always seems to be there, whispering his wacky economic notions into the ear of some President or near-President, and the next thing you know some President or near-President is buying Mr. Kemp's brand of madness hook, line and sinker.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-7

title: Chasing Away the Tigers' Travails
description: IF you don't watch out,'' someone said to Buddy Bell, in his office yesterday morning in the visitors' clubhouse in Yankee Stadium, ''you'll be manager of the year.''

title: Independence A Likely Help For Giuliani
description: NEW YORK being New York, it has had a Republican governor who antagonized his own party (Nelson A. Rockefeller). And a Democratic mayor who flirted with Republicans (Edward I. Koch). And even a mayor who left the Republicans for the Democrats (John V. Lindsay).

title: With a Push Toward Work, Florida Gets a Jump on Welfare Overhaul
description: This month, Sophia de Jesus will start training at the Mount Sinai Medical Center here for a low-paying job, but one that the hospital has reserved for welfare recipients like her. The 36-year-old single mother dreams of becoming a nurse one day.

title: Behold! A Hot New Star! But Who Said It First?
description: The maxim ''leave 'em wanting more'' apparently does not count for much in the magazine business. Indeed, after the last few weeks of seeing the faces of the actors Matthew McConaughey and Gwyneth Paltrow on what seems like just about every magazine cover in the country, readers could be forgiven for wanting to be left with considerably less.

title: A House of Worship, A Sign of Permanence
description: Little remained intact in Alka Desai's world after she arrived in the United States from India a year ago to marry a man she did not know. With the arranged marriage and the 7,000-mile trip came a new life, a town she had never heard of, a language she still struggles with and, three months ago, a baby.

title: Renaissance Hotels Names 3 Finalists
description: Renaissance Hotels and Resorts, which is based in Cleveland, has further narrowed the review on its account to three agencies, from six. The account, with billings estimated at $10 million to $12 million, had been handled by Wyse Advertising, also in Cleveland.

title: Ossie Clark, 54, Icon of 60's; British Designer Defined Mod
description: Ossie Clark, the British fashion designer whose whimsical romantic designs and frenetic life-style helped set trendy London ablaze in the 1960's, was stabbed to death last Tuesday night in his West London apartment, the police said. He was 54, and his 28-year-old former companion, Diego Cogolato, was arrested and charged with murder.

title: Ki-Jana Carter Puts Injury behind And Prepares for His Pro Debut
description: Ki-Jana Carter is surprised, and amused, when he turns on MTV and sees rap artists wearing his No. 32 jersey. Other than a hip-hop fashion statement, Carter doesn't know what to make of it.

title: Ex-Policeman's Jail Term Hailed by Women in India
description: The conviction of India's best-known police officer last week for slapping a woman's backside at a party eight years ago, and his sentencing -- to three months in jail and a $20 fine -- have been hailed by women's groups as a landmark in the struggle for women's rights.

title: Europe's Shrinking Coffers Impact Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Struggling to Raise The Curtain Once More On a Russian Legacy
description: In the wood Victorian house where the great Russian avant-garde theater director Vsevolod Meyerhold grew up and first took to the stage, the actors' studio that bears his name is performing P. G. Wodehouse plays and ''The Nutcracker.''

title: Trying to Shore Up the PC's Immune System
description: The narrow, windowless room is guarded by electronic locks and the red-beam light rays of motion detectors. The room is ringed by two dozen computers, blinking as programs run. A couple of filing cabinets have bars and locks.

title: Q & A / Kim Jong U : North Korea's Bid for Investment
description: HONG KONG  Buffeted by food shortages and serious flooding, political isolation and poverty, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea hopes to convince foreign investors that it is open for business despite being perhaps the world's most rigid remaining Communist regime. The establishment of the Rajin-Sonbong Free Economic and Trade zone in the Tumen River area along the country's northeast border with China and Russia is Pyongyang's strategy for attracting investment without opening much of country to other influences.

title: Machine Tools Get New Report
description: United States orders for machine tools were estimated at $643.1 million in June, the industry said today.

title: Fielder and Rogers Help to Restore Order in the Bronx
description: For two days, the baseball world -- at least the American League East part of it -- had been turned on its head. The last-place Detroit Tigers had come to town and beat up on the first-place Yankees.

title: Connecticut Congressman, a Star in Washington, Trips at Home
description: United States Representative Gary A. Franks had set aside the afternoon to mingle with constituents, and things were not exactly going like clockwork.

title: Clinton's New (Double) Deal
description: Most of my adult life has been devoted to electing Democrats to the White House. I spent the 1984 and 1988 campaigns on the road for Gary Hart, and then in 1992 on behalf of Senator Bob Kerrey. Neither prevailed. Still, seeing friends and colleagues join the Clinton Administration after 12 years of Reagan-Bush was the realization of hopes and dreams of a lifetime.

title: Where the Grants Are: College Aid On Line
description: Although she had tried for months, Cheri Nielsen, a medical engineering student at Johns Hopkins University, had virtually no luck finding private scholarships to help pay for medical school.

title: In Rockets' Red Glare, It's Party, Party, Party
description: The wine supply was bottomless, the Star Spangled Banner was the wild Jimi Hendrix version and the fireworks exploded in such miraculous chrysanthemums of light that one young, T-shirted Republican, high-fiving his friends, was simply overcome by what a great party his party could inspire.

title: Dole's Kemp Strategy
description: Introducing Jack Kemp on his way to the Republican convention, Bob Dole unabashedly adopted John F. Kennedy's 1960 campaign theme: ''Let's get America moving again.''

title: N.F.L., Sullivan Settle
description: The former New England Patriots owner WILLIAM SULLIVAN will receive $11.5 million in a settlement of his lawsuit against the National Football League, The Boston Globe reported Sunday. Sullivan sought $116 million when he sued the league in May 1991, claiming its refusal to allow him to sell public stock forced him to sell the team to VICTOR KIAM in October 1988 for what Sullivan considered to be a low price, $84 million. (AP)

title: Good Peer Pressure
description: To the Editor:

title: Bob Dole's Convention Rewrite
description: The stage for the Republican convention could not be more set if they had glued the folding chairs to the floor. Dress codes have been issued, speeches choreographed. The overall goal will be a sort of reverse Olympics broadcast -- a live event that looks as if it were on tape. The organizers drove off the program's last potential wild card, Gov. William Weld of Massachusetts, by assigning him to introduce a video of Morry Taylor. Mr. Taylor is a Michigan tire salesman who ran briefly for the G.O.P. nomination by promising to run government like a tire business.

title: Excerpts From Remarks by Kemp and Dole on Arrival in San Diego
description: Excerpts from remarks by Jack Kemp and Bob Dole yesterday as they arrived in San Diego, as transcribed by The New York Times.

title: Tourist Is Robbed In Times Sq. Hotel
description: A 27-year-old tourist staying at a Times Square hotel was robbed Saturday night by a man who pushed into her room, the police said.

title: Bozell Files to Offer Stock in Its Poppe Unit
description: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt has, as expected, filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $50 million initial public offering of stock for its Poppe Tyson unit that specializes in interactive communications.

title: Six Sex Attacks Reported Over Weekend
description: In a series of unrelated incidents across the city, six women and girls reported that they were the victims of sex attacks over the weekend, the police said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Utility Executives Scramble To Explain New Blackout

title: Cuba's Top Junior Pitcher Defects During Tournament
description: Another highly touted teen-age Cuban baseball player defected from the national junior team in Illinois today, joining catcher Yalian Serrano, who defected eight days ago.

title: Accounts
description: * Einstein/Noah Bagel Corp., Golden, Colo., to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, to handle advertising for its Einstein Bros. Bagels brand, previously handled by Fallon McElligott, Minneapolis. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $4 million.

title: Novelist Knows Hollywood's Bleak Houses
description: At the age of 8, Bruce Wagner moved with his family to a home on Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills. The next year, a neighbor died of a drug overdose. ''That was the beginning of the Hollywood Babylon for me,'' he said.

title: Dr. George A. Carden Jr., Malaria Researcher, 89
description: Dr. George A. Carden Jr., a Manhattan internist who was awarded a Presidential Certificate of Merit for his role in research about malaria during World War II, when Americans fought in malaria-ridden lands, died on Saturday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 89 and also had a home in Peapack, N.J.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: New York's Welfare Meltdown
description: New York State must always provide for its truly needy residents, but we must act soon to adapt our social welfare programs to the new financial reality prescribed by President Clinton and Congress.

title: Excerpts From Lamm and Perot
description: Following are excerpts from the speeches delivered yesterday by Richard D. Lamm and Ross Perot to the convention of the Reform Party in Long Beach, Calif., as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: Japanese Stocks Off a Bit
description: Japanese stocks were trading slightly lower here early today. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 9.35 points -- one-twentieth of 1 percent -- to stand at 20,541.70. On Friday, the Nikkei index fell 180.26 points, or nearly nine-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Kemp Brings Sense of Relief And Hope for Ohio's G.O.P.
description: From Bill Ovecka, a salesman who had just finished 18 holes at the Bob-O-Link golf course, and Harold Ebert, a tree surgeon carrying a new shovel out the front door of Frye Servistar Hardware, to Norman Dick, polishing off his usual Sunday morning coffee and glazed at the Donut Kettle, and Dale Holwick Jr., an usher at the United Methodist church where President William McKinley used to worship, Republicans here had nothing but hopeful things to say about the choice of Jack Kemp as their Vice-Presidential candidate.

title: Jacqueline Susann Territory Revisited
description: You've read the book. You've seen the movie. And now, if you really have to, you can see the stage version of ''Valley of the Dolls.''

title: After Smoke Settles, The Questions Surface
description: The Miami Heat can throw out those Juwan Howard jerseys.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ISAAC MIZRAHI has been the subject of a movie, ''Unzipped,'' and in the coming months he will give television viewers the chance to see some of his favorite films. He will be the host of a film festival on the American Movie Classics cable channel that begins on Oct. 28 and runs through December.

title: No Headline
description: Radical measures must now be taken to settle this problem. -- VIKTOR S. CHERNOMYRDIN Prime Minister of Russia, on the fighting in Chechnya. $(A1:1$)

title: On Small Screen, Tone Will Be Reagan Redux
description: Almost everything that television viewers will see during the 1996 Republican National Convention defies convention, from its five-minute speechettes to its live broadcasts from remote sites. Almost, but not quite.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Masur Wades Intrepidly Into an Unruly Sea of Jazz
description: The formidably Teutonic Kurt Masur would seem to be just about the least likely classical musician to conduct Leonard Bernstein's jazzy Symphonic Dances from ''West Side Story.'' His performance with the New York Philharmonic on Friday night, the third and last of the orchestra's Lincoln Center Festival '96 programs, was at least a brave effort.

title: A Lovely Library in Ruins, but With a Will to Live
description: Eerie with shattered beauty, the burned ruins of Bosnia's national library have stood for the last four years as a wrenching symbol of an attempt to destroy a city and its culture.

title: Speeches Are Friendly But Crowd Is Partisan
description: Were it not for the very public disputes between Ross Perot's aides and Richard D. Lamm's over the condition of the Reform Party Presidential playing field, tonight's convention speeches would suggest that the wealthy Texan and the former Governor of Colorado were card-carrying members of the same mutual admiration society.

title: Swing and Sorrow in Elusive Styles
description: The pianist Muhal Richard Abrams is drawn to the large and substantial. An intellectual heir to omnivore composer-performers like Charles Mingus, he's a natural consolidator. That's why his most important recent recorded work has been in suite form; and it's probably why he approached his Brooklyn Museum duet concert with Marty Ehrlich on Sunday afternoon not as a series of short pieces but as one 70-minute-long entity.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: New Era of Phone Competition in Mexico
description: With a video-and-telephone call that turned into a breezy chat with a state governor, President Ernesto Zedillo today opened a new era of competition in long-distance telecommunications in Mexico.

title: Bayer's Profit Rose 13% in First Half
description: The German drug and chemical maker Bayer A.G. said yesterday that its pretax profit rose 13 percent in the first half of the year as foreign sales more than made up for sluggish performance in Germany. Bayer earned 2.7 billion marks ($1.8 billion) in the first half of 1996, up from 2.4 billion marks in the 1995 period. Sales were up 7 percent, to 24.8 billion marks ($16.5 billion).

title: Maradona to Quit Boca
description: DIEGO MARADONA, under fire from fans in Buenos Aires for missing five consecutive penalty kicks, is quitting his club, Boca Juniors. Maradona, 35, announced the decision before Boca's final home game of the season Sunday. (AP)

title: Protecting Beach Access
description: A group of Point Pleasant Beach residents who say a developer is trying to keep them off a stretch of beach is gearing up for a battle. Edward Sirchio, one of 100 beachgoers who held a protest in the sand on Sunday, said yesterday that the group planned to lobby local and state officials to keep the block-long beach open. Mr. Sirchio said that private security guards for the Bay Point Dunes development, which is being built at the southern end of town, have been telling people they cannot sit on the beach, even below the high water mark. In New Jersey, the public is guaranteed access to all beachfront below the high water mark.

title: Cowboys' Millions Keep Smith In Dallas
description: Emmitt Smith is arguably the best running back in football. He is unquestionably now the game's highest paid.

title: Perot and Lamm Press On in Search of Reform Nomination
description: One day after Ross Perot and his rival for the Reform Party Presidential nomination, former Gov. Richard D. Lamm of Colorado, competed for the hearts and votes of party supporters here and via C-Span at the first of two national convention sessions, the Texas billionaire returned to Dallas while Mr. Lamm hit the road and the airwaves.

title: Powell Outlines Vision of Party For All Views
description: Retired Gen. Colin L. Powell presented himself tonight to the Republican National Convention, declared himself to be a good and faithful party member -- and then managed in a much-applauded speech to build an ideological tent seemingly big enough to hold the whole deeply riven party.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NEWPARK RESOURCES INC., Metairie, La., completed its purchase of the marine waste-collection business of Sanifill Inc., Houston, for $70.5 million.

title: Bosnian Serbs End Standoff By Allowing an Inspection
description: After a day of increasing pressure from the NATO-led peacekeepers here, the Bosnian Serb military agreed today to allow an inspection of the bunker thought to be the former headquarters of Gen. Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb military chief who has been indicted for war crimes but who remains free.

title: Zapatista Tour Offers Mud, Sweat and Radical Chic
description: This is the place to be, although you would never know from looking at it.

title: Mining Companies Increasingly Look Abroad
description: As President Clinton announced the cancellation of a $650 million gold mine in Montana, gold mining executives here recalled a presidential message more to their liking.

title: Mars and Its Meteorites Targets of New Research
description: A PIECE of rock no bigger than a potato has awakened a somnolent American space program and inspired planetary scientists, spacecraft designers and the NASA leadership with what may become a new sense of mission. Tantalizing clues in the meteorite have emboldened them to think that if they are clever and persistent, they may yet find on Mars the first evidence of extraterrestrial life.

title: Town Where Dole's Life Changed Backs Candidate as a Friend
description: In case there was anyone left in this tiny hilltop town who had never heard of Bob Dole, his friends here plan to throw him a party on the main piazza on Aug. 16, under a giant ''Dole for President'' banner, before a crowd decked out in Dole baseball hats, with entertainment that will include a jazz band, a Sherman tank and perhaps a touring troupe of majorettes.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Terror Suspect Boasted Of Bomb Plan, Agent Says
description: A Secret Service agent testifying in the terrorism trial of Ramzi Ahmed Yousef said yesterday that Mr. Yousef boasted during his extradition from Pakistan last year that he would have blown up several jumbo jets within a few weeks if his plan had not been discovered.

title: Richard M. Goodwin, Economist, 83
description: Richard M. Goodwin, an economist who developed a technique to model economic activity, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Siena, Italy, where he had been vacationing. He was 83 and lived in Ashdon, England.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Sunday about a judge's ruling that nearly $1 million in political contributions made in 1994 must be returned to the Democratic National Committee incorrectly described the entity that must turn over the money. It is a campaign committee that was set up by the national committee; it was not the New York State Democratic Party.

title: Zito's Confidence in Storm Song Pays Off in Adirondack Victory
description: Charging five wide on the turn, Storm Song gave the trainer Nick Zito his first juvenile winner of the meet at Saratoga Race Course, pulling clear in the stretch to post a six-length victory over Last Two States today in the $125,000 Adirondack for 2-year-old fillies.

title: Worth Watching
description: George W. Bush

title: Corrections
description: A picture with a brief profile of Representative Bill Paxon of New York yesterday, part of the coverage of the Republican National Convention, was published in error in some editions. It showed Senator Spencer Abraham of Michigan, not Mr. Paxon. Mr. Abraham's picture was correctly published in other editions with a brief profile of him. Mr. Paxon was wearing glasses in his picture; Mr. Abraham was not.

title: KIMBERLY-CLARK TO SELL TISSUE MILL TO A RIVAL
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its Lakeview tissue mill in Neenah, Wis., to the American Tissue Corporation for an undisclosed sum. Kimberly-Clark, which is based in Dallas, said expenses tied to the sale would lower its earnings for the current quarter, which ends on Sept. 30. The Justice Department required Kimberly-Clark to sell one or two tissue mills as well as to license the use of the Scotties name for facial tissue as part of the company's merger in December with the Scott Paper Company. In June, the company sold one mill and licensed the use of Scotties tissue to Irving Tissue Inc. of Canada. American Tissue is based in Hauppauge, L.I.

title: New York Girding for Surge in Workfare Jobs
description: New York City and State officials are scrambling to prepare for the largest public jobs program since the Depression -- in their effort to meet the requirements of the Federal welfare bill passed by Congress this summer. The program could create a statewide work force of welfare recipients as large as New York City's municipal payroll at a cost that may exceed $1 billion a year.

title: Today's Media
description: All times are Eastern.

title: Getting Onto the Green In Just 2 Mouse Clicks
description: NO scent of new-mown grass. None of the salubrious aerobic benefits of traveling 7,263 yards in an electric cart. No enterprising local urchins offering to sell you the lost balls of your predecessors. Why play golf on your computer?

title: Jupiter's Moon Europa Could Be Habitat for Life
description: LAST week's release of clues that Mars may once have harbored primitive microbes has lent new energy and excitement to a call for close exploration not only of the red planet itself, but of Europa, a moon of Jupiter that some scientists had been independently and quietly examining as a possible home to alien life.

title: Yanks Get Bad Case Of Deja Vu From Sox
description: John Wetteland watched the ball narrowly vanish over the left-center-field fence in the 10th inning and then looked at Harold Baines as he trotted around the bases. But Baines had not even reached second base when Wetteland turned his head and marched toward the dugout.

title: The Question That Matters Is Who Came To the Festival, Not How Many
description: The numbers are coming in on the Lincoln Center Festival '96, but numbers may be the most ephemeral yardstick of all. Who came to these events, not how many, is the question to be asked. Where are these people from? Were they frolicking Belgian tourists experiencing a sudden and unaccountable lust for culture? Or maybe holiday visitors from Saskatchewan dropping by on a night most of Broadway was dark? Were they Manhattanites weathering the summer in town? Did serious music lovers and music professionals make pilgrimages to be there?

title: Crew Blocks a Bronx Board's Choice of Superintendent
description: Seeking to rein in another troubled school district, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew last night invalidated a community school board's appointment of a new superintendent, saying the board's choice was not the best candidate to overhaul a district that is the lowest-performing in the city.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day yesterday with an article about a turnaround at a New York radio station, WKTU (103.5 FM), showing the 10 top stations in the New York market this spring, misidentified the No. 4 station. It was WCBS-FM (101.1 FM), not WCBS (880 AM).

title: 'Simple' Equaling 'Effective'
description: Aside from the fact that they have the tenor saxophonist Ellery Eskelin in common, these recordings document how three of New York's downtown jazz improvisers matured through immersion in basic black American rhythms. Trying to reduce jazz to its essences doesn't always make it great, but it's notable that for these three musicians, who have been working around the edges of the avant-garde, simple means effective.

title: No Headline
description: ''Should hundreds and thousands of lives be sacrificed to achieve this Pyrrhic victory?''

title: D'Amato Touts Unity As Antidote to 1992
description: Scurrying to find the staircase up to his opening podium appearance at the 1996 Republican convention, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato darted in one direction, then the other, part Mad Hatter, part power broker wincing at his own dark memories of the raucous gathering of 1992.

title: Kirtland's Warbler Finally Finds Lots of Burned Forest to Call Home
description: NINE years ago, the Kirtland's warbler, one of North America's rarest songbirds, appeared to be on the ropes. A survey of its nesting grounds in northeast Lower Michigan turned up only 167 singing males, which translates into a roughly similar number of breeding pairs.

title: In Bid for Airline Security, Echoes of Unmet Promises
description: On April 3, 1989, the 103d day after a bomb destroyed Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, President George Bush met with families of the victims and pledged that the Government would take dramatic action to keep such a tragedy from happening again.

title: Festival '96 Gives Itself A Preliminary Grade: A-Plus
description: After 21 days and 64 events that included everything from Vietnamese water puppets to a Samuel Beckett marathon, the Lincoln Center Festival '96 rang down the curtain Sunday on its first season. Now the reckoning begins.

title: Fitch Is Improving
description: Los Angeles Clippers Coach BILL FITCH, who underwent triple-bypass surgery last week, is expected to be released from the hospital this week and be ready for training camp in early October.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SWIMMING

title: INSIDE
description: Assessing Festival '96

title: Energetic Johnson Motivates Dolphins
description: Watch Jimmy Johnson cut a creative swath through his workday and you understand that the new Miami Dolphins coach was paying rapt attention in class when he majored in psychology at the University of Arkansas. There usually is a calculating mind at work when Johnson threatens, cajoles, orders, preaches, commiserates, even cheerleads.

title: Organized Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: Bonds Steady In Advance Of New Data
description: Prices of Treasury securities were largely unchanged yesterday, as market participants awaited today's reports on consumer prices and retail sales before committing themselves to long positions.

title: Hard-Edged Platform Is Swiftly Approval After a Soft Sell
description: Dissent over abortion was muted, other sharp edges were rounded, and the Republican platform was officially presented to and adopted by the Republican National Convention today during broad daylight when most Americans who were free to watch television were watching Oprah or the soaps.

title: Reeves Looks Ahead, And Shares the Result
description: While some people may be pessimistic about the coming Giants season, Coach Dan Reeves cannot be. But his prediction for how he thinks the Giants will do this season may surprise some.

title: BANYAN HOTEL FUND TO ADD 150 SHOPPING CENTERS
description: Banyan Hotel Investment Fund, a real estate investment trust, agreed yesterday to buy 150 shopping centers in the Southwest for $80 million. Banyan, which is based in New York, did not disclose the name of the company from which it was buying the centers, though it said that the seller was privately held. The shopping malls are mostly in Texas and Oklahoma, Banyan said. The company said it would finance the deal, which is expected to close by the end of the year, through loans and sales of stock and debt securities.

title: Poles Have Yet to Face Their Postwar Past
description: To the Editor:

title: A Peaceful Weekend in Ulster
description: Summer is the marching season in Northern Ireland, when militant members of the province's Protestant majority traditionally flaunt their forebear's military triumphs over Roman Catholic forces three centuries ago.

title: A New Arena for Ads and Political Influence
description: United is the official airline, General Motors provides the official car and AT&T is the official long-distance provider, but this is not the Olympics.

title: WPP Posts 40% Jump In Pretax Earnings
description: WPP Group P.L.C., the world's biggest advertising and marketing company, reported a 40 percent jump yesterday in pretax profit for the first half of the year and said it was studying ways to use its surplus cash. WPP, parent of the J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather advertising agencies, said profit rose to $:68.1 million ($105 million) from $:48.5 million in the corresponding 1995 period. Revenues gained 12.7 percent, to $:833.2 million ($1.28 billion) from $:739.4 million.

title: Photographer Found Guilty In Wiretapping
description: His lawyers depicted young Carlos Hugo Arriazu Sanchez as just an honest, hardworking paparazzo, caught up with bad company while taking pictures of celebrities.

title: An Angry Pat Riley Insists the Heat Broke No Salary Cap Rules
description: Angry after losing Juwan Howard to the Washington Bullets, Pat Riley said yesterday that the Miami Heat was treated unfairly by the National Basketball Association. Riley also said that the league wanted Howard in Washington, not Miami, and that the Heat did not break any salary cap rules in its attempt to sign him.

title: Chrebet: From Good Catch to Fair Catch?
description: These are tough times for Wayne Chrebet, the popular Jet who made it last season against all odds. As the Jets' receiving corps has filled up with high-profile draft choices and free agents, Chrebet suddenly finds himself returning punts and trying to stay in the mix of pass catchers.

title: Splits Among Cambodian Guerrillas Appear to Widen
description: Splits in Cambodia's Khmer Rouge appeared to widen today as the guerrilla group appointed loyal officers to replace high-ranking defectors, and the Government announced that its troops had made friendly contact in the field with the renegade faction.

title: On Rare Fox, Geneticists Catch Up to Darwin
description: WHEN it comes to Darwin's fox, who would know better than Charles Darwin? No one, it seems.

title: Father Indicted In Baby's Death That Provoked A Court Battle
description: A Queens doctor has been indicted by a grand jury in the death of his 5-month-old daughter, who was the object of a bitter court battle when her parents fought a hospital's efforts to remove her from life support.

title: CHRONICLE
description: What do WENDY WASSERSTEIN and TIPPER GORE have in common?

title: Apple's Best Hope: On-Line Sales
description: AFTER six months on the job, Heidi Roizen, a former software developer who is now Apple Computer Inc.'s head of developer relations, says she has identified Apple's biggest problem.

title: F.B.I. Doesn't Need More Power to Wiretap Terrorist Suspects
description: To the Editor:

title: A Young Lawmaker Is Set for Her Moment in the Spotlight
description: Just before giving away his only daughter, Susan Molinari, at her first wedding, in 1988, Guy Molinari stopped on his way down the aisle to shake hands with Bob Dole.

title: Skater Listed as Brain Dead After Crash With Park Cyclist
description: An in-line skater who smashed her head on the pavement after colliding with a bicyclist in Central Park on Sunday was pronounced brain dead yesterday, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Bloomberg Business News in Business Day on Friday about trading in the stock market on Thursday misstated the fourth-quarter earnings of the KLA Instruments Corporation, whose stock fell sharply that day. It earned 61 cents a share, up from 47 cents a share in the quarter a year earlier, but several cents below analysts' expectations.

title: Young & Rubicam executives aren't ruling out the possibility of an initial public offering
description: THE top executives of Young & Rubicam Inc., after selling a minority interest to outside investors for the first time in the 73-year history of the privately held agency company, are not ruling out further ownership changes that might include an initial public offering.

title: Former Newark Police Chief Ties His $30,000 Theft to Department Tradition
description: William R. Celester, the former Newark police director who has remained silent since he pleaded guilty last month to stealing almost $30,000 from a police account, has now given his version of his tenure, painting himself as a victim of circumstances.

title: Midas Settles an Inquiry
description: The Midas Muffler and Brake Shop chain agreed to pay the state $175,000 after consumer officials accused the company of encouraging unnecessary repairs at some of its 74 New Jersey stores, Midas officials said yesterday. Mark S. Herr, director of the State Division of Consumer Affairs, said the money would pay for a consumer education program and offset the cost of the state's investigation. Midas also agreed to hire an ombudsman to review consumer complaints, Mr. Herr said.

title: A Big Mac Strategy At Porterhouse Prices
description: Jerome Greenbaum, meat eater, inhaled the aroma of beef at his table in a bustling midtown Manhattan restaurant on a recent evening.

title: A Deal Near, Talks Linger Another Day
description: Negotiators in baseball's longest, most destructive labor dispute were so close to agreement yesterday that one of them said, ''We're within kissing distance, not even spitting distance.''

title: Casino Looks at Iowa
description: Casino America Inc. said today that it would build a $70 million casino on the Raccoon River near Des Moines if voters there approve riverboat gambling. Casino America, an operator of riverboat casinos that is based here, said it must get enough voter signatures to place a riverboat gambling referendum on the ballot in Dallas County, Iowa.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Advance Modestly,

title: Fleeing the Ghost of 1992
description: This is a convention run by revisionists, determined to obscure if not rewrite recent history, to the electoral advantage of the Republican Party.

title: Health Care Assignments
description: Mothers on welfare in four New Jersey counties who did not select a health maintenance organization by a state deadline yesterday will now have the state choose for them. As part of the state's effort to move Medicaid patients into managed care, welfare clients in Mercer, Union, Passaic and Cumberland counties had 16 weeks to sign up for an H.M.O. State human services officials told The Associated Press yesterday that about 90,000 of the 98,000 welfare recipients in the four counties had beat the deadline. The enrollment program has been completed in Essex, Hudson and Camden counties, which have the state's largest welfare populations.

title: Magellan Fund Says Assets Fell $3.5 Billion in July
description: The assets of the Fidelity Magellan mutual fund fell $3.5 billion in July as a result of losses in the stock market and shareholder redemptions, the mutual fund company said today.

title: Saudi Banker in B.C.C.I. Scandal  Counterattack
description: A Saudi financier who paid hundreds of millions of dollars to escape fraud charges in an international banking scandal has quietly reassumed control of his family's banking empire and enlisted Prof. Laurence H. Tribe of Harvard University Law School to rehabilitate his name in the United States.

title: A Far-Ranging Tribute To a Musical Explorer
description: When plans for the Lincoln Center Festival '96 were announced, the organizers were understandably nervous about attracting audiences to these adventurous summer programs. The final festival event on Sunday night, a benefit tribute to Yehudi Menuhin, conducting the Orchestra of St. Luke's and a distinguished roster of soloists, must have been rewarding to all involved.

title: David Previant, 85 Lawyer for Teamsters
description: David Previant, a labor lawyer who was a top adviser to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters for more than three decades, died on Saturday at his home in Milwaukee. He was 85.

title: The Boot Cut in Pants
description: Pants are an integral part of many women's wardrobes, though for variety the shapes change a little from time to time. Right now the favored style is the flat-front straight-leg version with a slight flare at the hem. Called the boot cut, it looks just as good over the tops of shoes.

title: Sumitomo Sells Seat on Comex
description: The liquidation of the Sumitomo Corporation's United States futures business took another step forward last week with the sale of its membership on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, according to a Sumitomo executive.

title: Russians Continue to Pound Devastated Chechen Capital
description: This desperate city continued to shake under the relentless aerial assault of Russian forces today, despite an urgent overnight visit to the region by the Kremlin's chief security official, Aleksandr I. Lebed.

title: Hearst in British Deal On Drug Data Bases
description: The Hearst Corporation acquired Multilex, Britain's leading supplier of drug data bases for health care professionals, yesterday for an undisclosed amount. Multilex, which was formed in 1984, supplies drug data bases for doctors, pharmacists and other health care users, Hearst said. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Clinton Unveils Plan to Halt Gold Mine Near Yellowstone
description: Declaring that ''Yellowstone is more precious than gold,'' President Clinton came to a pristine corner of the country's oldest national park today to announce a halt to development of a nearby gold mine that environmentalists had warned would damage the park's waterways and wildlife.

title: Lonrho to Offer Stock In 2 Hotel Divisions
description: The British conglomerate Lonrho P.L.C. said yesterday that it planned to sell its Princess and Metropole hotel divisions through an initial stock offering. Money raised from the stock sale would be used to pay off Lonrho debt. The Princess division, managed from New York, has 10 luxury resort hotels in the United States, Caribbean and Mexico. The Metropole division, managed from Birmingham, England, runs five hotels in Britain.

title: EVERGREEN TO BUY 4 STATIONS IN 2 CITIES
description: The Evergreen Media Corporation of Irving, Tex., agreed yesterday to buy three radio stations in Detroit and one in Philadelphia from Secret Communications L.P. for a total of $237.8 million. Evergreen also agreed to swap one of the stations in Detroit for Greater Media Inc.'s WWRC-AM in Washington plus $9.5 million in cash. Evergreen agreed to buy the stations WMXD-FM and WJLB-FM in Detroit for $168 million and WFLN-FM in Philadelphia for $37.8 million from Secret Communications. And Evergreen agreed to buy WQRS-FM in Detroit for $32 million and then swap it to Greater Media. The swap agreement modifies an agreement in June under which Evergreen was to buy the station in Washington. Under that deal, Evergreen will also swap WKLB-FM in Boston for WEBR-FM in Washington.

title: A Nice, If Not Spectacular, Year
description: Now that the major championship season has ended with Mark Brooks becoming the third straight first-time major winner and emerging as the leading candidate for player of the year -- Mark Brooks? Player of the year? -- it's as good a time as any to look back on the endless summer.

title: Excerpts From Platform Adopted by Republican National Convention
description: Following are excerpts from the platform adopted yesterday by the Republican National Convention.

title: CHRONICLE
description: What do you do as a follow-up to winning an Olympic gold medal and signing a multimillion-dollar contract?

title: CHRONICLE
description: LARRY BELL, the sculptor, is clearly not intimidated by size. He has created a statue of a seated figure that he said ''measures 23 feet from the top of its head to its seat with its legs stretching out 37 feet.''

title: Don't Wish for Cliffhanger Conventions
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Convention Begins With Display of Unity
description: Republicans opened their 36th annual convention here today with a meticulously choreographed pageant of unity that evoked the glories of their party's past and sought to convince voters that they were sensitive enough to the nation's needs to be trusted not just with Congress but also with the White House.

title: Murder-Suicide at Rowan
description: A student at Rowan College in Glassboro was fatally shot at the school yesterday afternoon by her estranged boyfriend, who then killed himself, the authorities said. Cindy Nannay, 22, was so afraid of Scott Lonabaugh, 27, that when he arrived on the campus to see her, she asked friends to accompany her to the parking lot, the Gloucester County Prosecutor's office said. As her friends looked on, Mr. Lonabaugh shot Ms. Nannay twice with a shotgun and then shot himself in the head, prosecutors said. Both died at the scene.

title: Is that a crack in the tobacco industry's legal wall, or a shadow?
description: AS last week's startling liability verdict against a major tobacco company an aberration? Or does it represent a fundamental shift in the nature of tobacco litigation that could permanently devastate tobacco stocks?

title: Chess
description: Anatoly Karpov, after five unsuccessful world championship matches against Garry Kasparov, is supposed to play a sixth one, if the two competing organizations, the International Chess Federation and the Professional Chess Association, can agree on terms and acquire sufficient financial backing. Karpov continues to perform on a very high level.

title: Of Knishes, Soulfulness and Kemp
description: Seven years ago, when Jack F. Kemp quietly switched his official residence from New York to Maryland, it seemed a merciful end to what had become little more than a political pretense.

title: Yeltsin Security Aide Denounces Russian War Effort in Chechnya
description: Russia's new national security adviser, Aleksandr I. Lebed, returned appalled and angry today from secret talks with rebel commanders in Chechnya, but his rage was not directed at the enemy. At a news conference, Mr. Lebed, a former general and Afghan war hero, expressed horror at the condition of Russian troops and disgust over the conduct of bureaucrats leading the war effort.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a chart yesterday comparing Republican convention delegates with voters misstated the percentage of registered voters who called themselves conservative. It was 32 percent, not 11.

title: Voluntary Relegation For an English Coach
description: The former Barcelona, Tottenham Hotspur and English national team coach, TERRY VENABLES, moved down the scale yesterday when he took over Division 1 club Portsmouth as the director. Division 1 is one rung down from the Premier League, the top professional level in England. Portsmouth barely avoided relegation to Division 2 last season and is currently losing $83,700 a week.

title: Cardinal Aims For New Unity For Catholics
description: Warning that a ''mean-spiritedness'' among Roman Catholics of differing opinions threatened the church's unity, Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, Archbishop of Chicago, said yesterday that he and 23 other prominent Catholics would begin a broad effort to promote dialogue and a sense of shared purpose within the church.

title: Detection Machine on Front Line
description: Over and over in the last month, the explosives experts examining the wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 have repeated the same dispiriting drill, cycling quickly from exciting discovery to disappointment to dispute.

title: CINERGY SAYS IT IS IN TALKS ON A POSSIBLE MERGER
description: The Cinergy Corporation, an electric and natural-gas utility in Cincinnati, said yesterday that it was in preliminary merger talks with undisclosed natural-gas pipeline companies. The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that Cinergy was in separate talks with the Williams Companies of Tulsa, Okla., and with the Panenergy Corporation of Houston. Cinergy declined to identify the potential merger candidates, and Williams and Panenergy declined to confirm or deny the report. Cinergy said it was ''continuously in the process of exploring, identifying and discussing possible strategic opportunities.'' Cinergy's shares rose 25 cents, to $31.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. Panenergy stock rose 75 cents, to $33.625, and Williams shares rose $1.625, to $49.75.

title: Team Wins 4th Straight Bridge Event
description: A team headed by Nick Nickell of Manhattan on Sunday became the first ever to achieve four straight victories in the Spingold Knockout Championship.

title: Bridges in Need of Repair
description: The state of New Jersey's 6,209 highway bridges is not a happy one, according to Federal data cited yesterday by the American Automobile Association. Forty-six percent of New Jersey's bridges were deemed either ''structurally deficient'' or ''functionally obsolete'' in a Federal Highway Administration survey that used 1994 bridge statistics, The A.P. reported. Only six states had a larger percentage of problem bridges, among them New York, which had the highest, 63 percent. ANDY NEWMAN

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-7

title: A Bittersweet Moment Brings Tears
description: Dressed in white, her voice hushed and shaking, her eyes glistening with tears, Nancy Reagan silenced the Republican National Convention tonight with a tribute to her husband, too ill to attend, and a quiet recitation of the words he delivered at the party's convention four years ago.

title: Ogilvy & Mather Gets ITT Accounts
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that it had selected Ogilvy & Mather New York to handle most of its Sheraton hotel chain account and its entire Four Points hotels account, with combined billings estimated at $20 million. Wells Rich Greene BDDP in New York, a unit of BDDP Worldwide, previously handled the Sheraton business, while a sibling agency, Moss/Dragoti in New York, had handled advertising for Four Points.

title: FIRST BRANDS STOCK HIT BY RUBBERMAID PLAN TO COMPETE
description: The shares of First Brands Inc., the maker of Glad trash bags, fell 10 percent yesterday after Rubbermaid Inc. said it was getting into the trash-bag business. Rubbermaid said it would begin shipping a line of bags, to be made by the North American Plastics Corporation of Aurora, Ill., in the fourth quarter. The shares of First Brands, which is based in Danbury, Conn., fell $2.625, to $22.375. A Rubbermaid spokeswoman said the company would initially focus distribution on mass merchandisers, hardware stores and home stores where the company's plastic containers are sold. First Brands dominated the trash-bag market with a 31 percent share in the 52-week period that ended on June 16, according to Information Resources Inc.

title: AMERADA HESS TO BUY BACK UP TO $250 MILLION IN STOCK
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation said yesterday that it would buy back as much as $250 million worth of stock. The shares of Amerada Hess, which is based in New York, rose 12.5 cents, to $48, on the New York Stock Exchange. Amerada Hess, the petroleum products company, had an average of 93.1 million shares outstanding during the quarter that ended on June 30.

title: Kvaerner Has 83% Drop In Quarterly Results
description: Kvaerner A.S., Europe's largest shipbuilder, said yesterday that its second-quarter pretax profit fell 83 percent as it acquired the money-losing Trafalgar House P.L.C. Kvaerner, which recently moved its headquarters to London from Oslo, said quarterly pretax profit fell to 169 million kroner ($26.5 million) from 1.018 billion kroner in the second quarter of 1995.

title: Elliott Sees New York From Both Sides Now
description: Soon after leaving the Giants to sign with the Jets, Jumbo Elliott found himself in Morristown, N.J., in a parade, of all things. As he went down the long street, he was given a warm welcome by everyone. That is, until he came to a man holding a little girl in his arms.

title: Patterns
description: Reconfiguring Donna Karan

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A MONTANA BANK PLANS A STOCK SWAP WITH ANOTHER
description: Glacier Bancorp Inc., a bank holding company in Kalispell, Mont., has agreed to buy Missoula Bancshares Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $22.9 million. In the deal, Glacier will issue 1.1 million shares to Missoula Bancshares. Should the transaction be broken off, Glacier has an option to buy up to 19.9 percent of the shares of Missoula Bancshares. Missoula Bancshares, which is based in Missoula, Mont., is the parent of First Security Bank of Missoula, a state-chartered commercial bank with $110 million in assets. A combined Glacier and Missoula Bancshares would have more than $520 million in assets, Glacier said when it announced the deal on Friday.

title: Indonesia Arrests Top Dissident In Crackdown
description: As a crackdown continued on independent groups after rioting last month, Indonesian authorities arrested a young dissident leader on Sunday night and interrogated a prominent writer today.

title: For Quick Skips to the Tropics
description: It has been many years since fashionable people took leisurely Caribbean cruises in winter or holed up in Palm Beach, Fla., from Christmas to Easter. So the designers who cater to them have turned their resort collections into an indecisive mixture of summery resort and springlike citified clothes.

title: Accounts
description: * Eddie Bauer Inc., Redmond, Wash., a unit of Spiegel Inc., to Frankel & Co., Chicago, to handle strategy and retail promotions for the sportswear retailer, which had been handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

title: Convention Summary
description: WELCOMING EVERYONE, KEEPING SOME QUIET

title: 2 New Deals Continue Wave Of Mergers in Energy Utilities
description: The recent wave of consolidation in the energy utility industry continued yesterday as two utilities in Houston and two that serve New Jersey and the Eastern Shore of the Chesapeake Bay agreed to merge in deals worth a total of $3.37 billion.

title: Maria Telkes, 95, an Innovator Of Varied Uses for Solar Power
description: Maria Telkes, an advocate of putting the sun's energy to use and one of the first researchers to do so in an experimental residence, died last Dec. 2 in Budapest on her first visit to her native Hungary in 70 years. She was 95 and lived in North Miami, Fla.

title: Final U.S. Approval for Big Rail Merger
description: The Union Pacific Corporation's proposed $5.4 billion acquisition of the Southern Pacific Rail Corporation gained final approval today from Federal regulators, clearing the way for the creation of the largest railroad in North America.

title: A Raise for Prosecutors
description: New Jersey's 21 county prosecutors got a 15 percent raise yesterday, to $115,000 a year, when Attorney General Peter G. Verniero, their supervisor, signed his first bill as Acting Governor. Prosecutors' salaries have risen 35 percent since 1991. The raise brings the prosecutors' pay in line with that of Superior Court judges, who are traditionally paid the same but received their raises in January. Mr. Verniero is filling in for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman while she attends the Republican National Convention in San Diego.

title: Allianz Sells Its Stake In Credit Insurer
description: Allianz A.G. Holding, Europe's largest insurer, said yesterday that it had sold its 12.5 percent stake in the credit insurance company Allgemeine Kreditversicherung A.G. to the retail company Rewe Handelsgruppe, which already owned 75 percent of the company. Terms of the deal, which was carried out in response to a demand from European antitrust authorities, were not disclosed.

title: Don't Wish for Cliffhanger Conventions
description: To the Editor:

title: With Friends Like These
description: Bob Dole found them at last the elation and bounce that go with the feeling that maybe he can do this thing after all, actually carry it off. They come from his knowledge that picking Jack Kemp as his Vice-Presidential candidate was exactly the right thing for him to do. Elation and bounce do not win elections, but they can be contagious and nobody wins without them.

title: MetroStars Sign Colombian
description: The MetroStars announced the signing of the veteran Colombian forward ANTONY DE AVILA during their 2-0 victory over the Colorado Rapids in Denver on Sunday.

title: Strange Extraterrestrial Attraction Lures Tourists Into Desert!
description: Trey Hatton, 13, who has seen ''Independence Day'' twice, persuaded his parents to drive 75 miles out of their way on a cross-country vacation to check out evidence that aliens really did crash-land in the New Mexico desert nearly five decades ago.

title: Baseball's Unsettling Situation
description: BASEBALL'S vernacular was once so quaint, thanks to the wit and wisdom of Casey Stengel and Branch Rickey. It was so illustrative, with its ''Tinker to Evers to Chance'' and its ''Spahn and Sain and pray for rain'' ditties. And some of its most famous monikers -- Joltin' Joe, Hammerin' Hank, the Splendid Splinter -- brought only joy, not pain.

title: A Curse on Both Tents
description: Despite the last-minute compromise that seems to have avoided a floor fight over abortion at the Republican National Convention, Democrats can scarcely conceal their glee at the sight of the Grand Old Party once again shooting itself in the foot in the effort to placate pro-life hard-liners. Republicans have declared their abortion tent to be a big one, but, just as in 1992, they approved a platform last night that on this troubling subject made clear there is only one acceptable view.

title: A Twist on Term Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Quick: Name a Film by Wellman
description: Ask anyone except the most fanatical movie buff to name a William Wellman film, and you're likely to get a blank look, or at best confusion with William Wyler (''Wuthering Heights'') or Billy Wilder (''Sunset Boulevard''). But start to name some Wellman movies, and the response is more likely to be, ''He did that?'' It was Wellman who directed James Cagney as he smashed a grapefruit in Mae Clarke's face in ''The Public Enemy'' and Wellman who directed Carole Lombard in ''Nothing Sacred,'' one of the greatest screwball comedies of all time. He directed ''Beau Geste,'' with Gary Cooper, and the original ''A Star Is Born.'' And early in his career he choreographed a sky full of planes in the silent movie ''Wings,'' winner of the first Academy Award for Best Picture ever given out. So why is his profile so low?

title: Brain Images Of Addiction In Action Show Its Neural Basis
description: SOME neuroscientists are experiencing what amounts to a natural high. For the first time, they have captured images of the brains of addicts in the throes of craving for a drug, revealing the neural basis for addiction.

title: Homer's First Yuppie
description: After Aphrodite bribed Paris by making the beautiful Helen love him, the happy couple settled in Troy. There was a difficulty. Helen was already married to a Greek king, one Menelaus.

title: N.F.L. TRAINING CAMP REPORT
description: Washington Redskins

title: Bishop Adriano Hypolito, 78, Ally of Brazil's Poor, Is Dead
description: Adriano Mandarino Hypolito, a retired Bishop persecuted during Brazil's 21-year military dictatorship for criticizing oppression of the poor, died at a hospital outside Rio on Saturday. He was 78.

title: A Joyful Dole Begins Bringing a Disparate Party Together
description: As he prepared to accept the Republican Presidential nomination on Wednesday night, an upbeat Bob Dole today emphasized his party's sense of compassion and began to fold the disparate factions of his party under his wing.

title: Yanks' Boss Should Reward Coaches
description: George Steinbrenner has already received support here for executive of the year, most valuable player and comeback of the year. In the blush of such commendation, the Yankees' owner should take notice of others who deserve recognition and reward them for jobs well done.

title: HEALTHSOURCE (HS, N)
description: Healthsource Inc. of Hooksett, N.H., said yesterday that second-quarter earnings fell 52 percent as the cost of drugs and medical services for its members rose.

title: Thanks for Keeping San Diego's Big Secret
description: To the Editor:

title: Crucial Testimony
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkey-Iran Gas Deal: A Test of U.S. Law on Terror?
description: Turkey's new Prime Minister signed a $23-billion, 23-year agreement today to purchase natural gas from Iran, raising the awkward possibility of the United States' invoking sanctions against a NATO ally.

title: Gannett Cleared on Sale of Billboard Unit
description: The Justice Department said today that it had approved the sale by the Gannett Company of its billboard business to Outdoor Systems Inc. for $690 million after Outdoor agreed to sell its outdoor-sign operations in Denver.

title: U.S. HOME AND GARDEN IN $26.5 MILLION ACQUISITION
description: U.S. Home and Garden Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired Weatherly Consumer Products Inc., a maker of lawn- and garden-care products, for $26.5 million in cash and stock. For its most recent fiscal year, which ended on Sept. 30, 1995, Weatherly, which is based in Lexington, Ky., had revenue of about $20 million, about what it expects for the latest fiscal year, U.S. Home and Garden said. That company, a maker of home, lawn and garden products with annual sales of about $19.7 million, also said it intended to buy an undisclosed company that makes decorative products for the home. U.S. Home and Garden is based in San Francisco.

title: The Stealth Platform
description: The Republican convention yesterday approved a platform that the party's candidate for President says he never read and is not bound to follow. It was dispensed with quickly, in order to make way for a parade of prime-time speakers, most of whom represented exactly the kind of moderate Republicanism the platform was designed not to represent.

title: At Cornell Medical, Stay Away a Year And Get One Free
description: Like an airline trying to lure bargain-conscious passengers off an overbooked flight, Cornell University Medical College has offered to waive tuition for first-year medical students who agree not to enroll until next year.

title: New York Stock Exchange Considers a Move, but Not From Manhattan
description: Trying to accommodate strong growth in recent years, officials at the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that they were thinking about relocating to expanded headquarters somewhere in Manhattan.

title: Please Don't Book These Guests
description: With convention theatrics in full cry, talk-show producers are putting together their A lists for the campaign to come. Most of the prospective guests have done long service before the camera, and their faces are as tired as their phrases.

title: Outrage Over a Long Delay in Justice
description: In July, Paul Touvier, the only Frenchman convicted of crimes against humanity, died in a prison hospital in France at the age of 81. A fictionalized version of Mr. Touvier is the central character in ''The Statement,'' a harrowing new novel by Brian Moore. Speaking about the coincidence of Mr. Touvier's death and the publication of his book, Mr. Moore said coolly, ''He couldn't have timed it better.''

title: Q&A
description: Sand

title: American Express Names Financial Chief
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it had named Richard K. Goeltz vice chairman and chief financial officer.

title: Victory at Yellowstone
description: President Clinton's announcement yesterday that a Canadian company has agreed to abandon plans to build a huge gold mine near the border of Yellowstone National Park is a victory for the environment. The proposed mine and its toxic waste would have threatened not only America's first and foremost national park, but also the ecosystem surrounding it.

title: Microsoft Acts To Enhance Web Package
description: Raising the competitive stakes to a rich new level in its World Wide Web browser war with the Netscape Communications Corporation, the Microsoft Corporation announced deals today providing for two of the Internet's most popular financial news and sports services to be bundled free into a new version of Microsoft's browsing software.

title: Confessions of a Big Mouth: Political Gab and Gossip
description: BARE KNUCKLES AND BACK ROOMS

title: For Teen-Agers, A Court's Ruling Is an Off Ramp
description: John Viglione is 17 and the kind of in-line skater others call awesome because of his bumps, jumps and grinds.

title: Isringhausen Knocked Onto Mets' D.L.
description: There were umbrellas everywhere, popped out and ready -- as if anything could have slowed the free fall of Jason Isringhausen last night.

title: Today's Schedule
description: All times are Eastern.

title: Area Near Wings of 747 Is New Focus of Investigators
description: Nearly four weeks after Trans World Airlines Flight 800 crashed off Long Island, half of the plane's tangled wreckage is spread out on the floor of a former Grumman hangar in Calverton, L.I., and investigators poring over it yesterday began focusing on the center of the airplane, where the wings meet.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Thomas J. Cavanagh Jr., a retired New York City police detective, on Aug. 4 inaccurately characterized his relationship to the origin of the ''Kojak'' television series. The fictional character of Kojak initially appeared in the 1973 television movie ''The Marcus-Nelson Murders,'' which in effect served as the pilot film for the series. The character was a composite, based on a number of detectives, lawyers and reporters -- including Mr. Cavanagh -- who were involved in the 1963 Wylie-Hoffert murder case. He was not its sole inspiration.

title: BEACON PROPERTIES PLANS TO ACQUIRE 10 OFFICE BUILDINGS
description: The Beacon Properties Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 10 office buildings in the Midwest and the Northeast for a total of $227 million. Beacon said the buildings encompassed about 1.55 million square feet. Six of the buildings are in suburban Chicago, three are in Fairfax County, Va., and one is in Washington. Beacon is a real estate investment trust based in Boston.

title: New Assistant at Fordham
description: Fordham University named GEOFF COLLINS as an assistant football coach yesterday. Collins, a 1995 graduate of Western Carolina, where he was a three-year starter at linebacker, will serve as the defensive assistant this season. He joins Fordham after coaching receivers and defensive backs at a Franklin High School in North Carolina. He also served two seasons as a student assistant at Western Carolina. Fordham went 4-6-1 last season, which was its best record in seven years at the Division I-AA level. The Rams open their season on Sept. 7, when they will play host to the University of Maine.

title: Russell's Values
description: To the Editor:

title: Savarese Is Unbeaten, Untested and Unnoticed
description: His critics say that he is talented but untested, and they point to his record as proof.

title: Connors Comes Back To Win Title On Clay
description: Organizers of the $200,000 Citibank Champions tennis tournament had high hopes that Jimmy Connors would be playing his longtime rival John McEnroe in tonight's final. Or at least the top-seeded Andres Gomez, the youngest and hottest player on the 35-and-over Nuveen tour.

title: Cone Pitches to Batters In 15-Minute Workout
description: David Cone did not notice the 45,000 empty seats, the splashy sunshine, the pitching coach stationed five feet behind the mound or the manager peering at him from along the first-base line at Comiskey Park this afternoon. All Cone noticed were the living, breathing batters in front of him. Finally.

title: Refurbishing a Closed Station
description: The train may not stop in Berlin any more, but that did not deter two volunteers from renovating the town's boarded-up train station. Roy Schmidt, a retired chef, and Daniel Pomponio, a semiretired electrical engineer, worked for two years refurbishing the station, built in the mid-1850's, Mr. Pomponio said. The station will be opened as an ''informal museum'' next month.

title: Hunger-Striking Africans Are Briefly Ejected From Paris Church
description: The Paris police at dawn today swept into a church occupied by about 300 illegal immigrants from Africa and took to nearby hospitals 10 men who were in the 39th day of a hunger strike aimed at forcing the authorities to grant the immigrants permission to stay in France.

title: Gain at General Accident Better Than Expected
description: General Accident, a Scotland-based insurer, reported a better-than-expected interim profit yesterday, despite a big hit from winter weather damage claims in the United States and Britain. First-half operating profits slid to $:194 million, or $300 million, from $:257 million, or $398.1 million, as the company was knocked by increased weather losses of $:56 million. But the result beat market forecasts, which ranged from $:165 million to $:186 million, or $255.6 million to $288.1 million.

title: A Lockup To Prevent A Breakup
description: As sitcoms go, ''House Arrest,'' opening today, is more sit than com.

description: Dallas Cowboys

title: Personal Health
description: WHEN it comes to knees, women are indeed the weaker sex. The very design of their bodies makes them more vulnerable than men to serious knee injuries and chronic knee problems that cause pain and disability.

title: Consumer Prices Show a Bit of an Upturn
description: Steep price increases for food and vacation lodging helped drive up the Consumer Price Index three-tenths of 1 percent in July, lifting inflation for the last 12 months to 3 percent, Labor Department figures showed today.

title: Follow-Up Survey Reports Growth in Internet Users
description: The growth in the number of Internet users appears to be coming from newcomers who are older, have less money, are less educated and spend less time on line than longtime users of the computer network, according to the most recent attempt to discern the size and habits of the Internet-user population in North America.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day on Friday with an article about the sentencing of three former executives of C. R. Bard Inc. for selling faulty artery-clearing catheters misstated the judge's action in the case. The sentences, 18 months in prison for each of the three men, were delayed pending the executives' appeals. The three men are free; they were not jailed.

title: Lehman Brothers, on an efficiency drive, sublets part of its headquarters site for 16 years.
description: THE Global Financial Information Corporation has sublet 80,000 square feet -- the 27th and 28th floors -- at 3 World Financial Center, the 51-story, 2.2-million-square-foot office building that is headquarters to American Express and Lehman Brothers.

title: Japan Mourns an Actor, and a Lost Way of Life
description: Long after most of the old-fashioned shops in the Shibamata neighborhood of Tokyo had closed and people in kimonos began heading toward the nearby temple for a festival, customers were still flocking to the Takagiya shop this evening to buy rice cakes and rice crackers, or simply to sit inside and reflect.

title: Professor Barred From China
description: A Princeton University professor and critic of China's human rights record was detained at the Beijing airport, held overnight and barred from entering the country. Perry Link, a Chinese language and history scholar, said yesterday from his home that he was never told why border officials blocked his entry last Thursday.
