But Asia Watch, the human rights group of which Mr. Link is a trustee, contends that China keeps a list of foreigners who are not to be allowed in. An official at the Chinese consulate in New York said he did not know about Mr. Link's case.

title: Central Park Hazard
description: To the Editor:

title: Venture in Accord to Buy 7 TV Stations From Aflac
description: In another step to build a small broadcasting empire in the South and the Midwest, two executives of an Alabama television station and a Boston lawyer agreed yesterday to buy seven stations.

title: When Savings Run Out, Some Shun Lifesaving
description: THERE are many reasons why seriously ill patients choose to forgo intensive care, including the desire to avoid futile treatment and to die surrounded by loved ones rather than machines. But another reason may be that they have run out of money, a large study suggests.

title: UNITED IS EXPECTED TO ORDER BOEING PLANES
description: United Airlines is expected to announce a multibillion-dollar order for Boeing planes as early as today, according to people familiar with the order. Analysts estimated the order could be worth more than $3 billion. The order by United, a unit of the UAL Corporation, was expected to include Boeing 747 planes and several Boeing 777's, Boeing's latest model. It may also include the smaller 737's. United has said that it plans to buy 97 aircraft in the next five years, replacing 93 aging planes and expanding its fleet by four.

title: Don't Limit Airlines' Disaster Liability
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Security' at J.F.K.
description: To the Editor:

title: A United, Feel-Good Party Meeting Does Not an Election Success Make
description: There comes a time at every convention when it helps to step back from the hullabaloo and recall some hard-learned truths about Presidential politics.

title: Tea Party Special: English Scones
description: It isn't easy to compete with the charm and tradition of downtown Concord, Mass., the historic well-to-do suburb of Boston. But Judy Fersch is drawing scores of proper Concordians over to Concord Teacakes, a popular bakery and cafe in West Concord, several miles from the town center.

title: (1) Scholars Desert an Old Tradition in a Search for Wider Appeal
description: In a celebrated spoof of scholarly writing a generation ago, the humorist Frank Sullivan quipped, ''Give a footnote an inch, and it'll take a foot.'' Academicians were not amused.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday of William J. Green, who was credited with helping achieve full integration of black troops into the United States Army, misspelled the name of the general who commanded American forces in the China-Burma-India theater in World War II. He was Gen. Joseph W. (Vinegar Joe) Stilwell.

title: A Train Trip for Clinton
description: President Clinton plans to come to Chicago for the Democratic National Convention later this month by way of a three-day whistle-stop train tour and a boat ride across Lake Michigan.

title: Sigmund Koch, Psychologist And Philosopher, Dies at 79
description: Sigmund Koch, a psychologist and philosopher who put together a widely recognized multivolume work assessing the state of psychology at mid-century, and then turned from those mainstream theories to espouse a less reductionist and more humanistic approach, died on Saturday in a nursing home in Brookline, Mass. He was 79 and lived in nearby Wellesley, Mass.

title: Inflation Fears Send Stocks Down Sharply
description: Stocks suffered sympathy pains yesterday after the bond market was bruised by unexpectedly strong retail sales and higher consumer prices. A broad decline resulted, leaving the major stock market barometers down about 1 percent for the day.

title: Behind Bright Smiles, Specter of a Svengali
description: A redeeming truth of convention politics is that there can be more candor over a good meal than there is in the carefully managed photo opportunity of grinning aspirants. In this spirit was the name of ''President Morris'' being firmly invoked over some post-session pasta by Governor George E. Pataki of New York.

title: Films by 2 Ex-Dancers
description: A 20-year retrospective of film and video by Pooh Kaye and Amy Greenfield, film makers who began as dancers, will be shown on Sunday at 6 and 8:30 P.M. at Anthology Film Archives, 32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, in the East Village. The work, shot in Super 8 film and Hi-8 video, will include new versions of Ms. Kaye's ''Wild Girl'' studies and an untitled new film by Ms. Greenfield that she describes as an ''erotic cabaret.'' The program will also include live video and dance experimentation and a discussion period with the film makers. Tickets are $7. Information: (212) 505-5181.

title: To be or not to be? To young people, it's no question, Klein says.
description: SMELL nice. Smell naughty. Just smell.

title: Magnificent Seven: Giants' Draft Picks Are All Making the Grade
description: You know it is a pretty successful draft when the seventh-round pick is making a lot of noise. Defensive back Conrad Hamilton is that player, and his solid training camp is a symbol of how well the Giants seemed to have drafted this year.

title: Police Evict Squatters From Three City-Owned Tenements in the East Village
description: In a quick pre-dawn raid yesterday, New York City police officers evicted a group of squatters from three city-owned tenement buildings in the East Village that officials have sought for two years to reclaim from the small band of artists and activists who lived there.

title: Accounts
description: Intersolv, Rockville, Md., to Mullen Advertising, Wenham, Mass., to handle advertising for the software company, which had been handled by various agencies on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Isringhausen, on Disabled List, Is Hoping to Regain His Focus
description: It seemed as if the Mets were throwing at his head, trying to aim at the mind of Jason Isringhausen when they placed the pitcher on the disabled list yesterday.

title: As American As Mango Pie
description: Lake Superior whitefish, with mango. Roast lamb chop, with mango. Duck prosciutto, with mango. Mango-and-ricotta tarts, with mango sauce. There's a theme here, one that has to do with the passion inspired by a certain tropical fruit.

title: Royal Ahold Buys Stake In Thailand Venture
description: Royal Ahold N.V., the Dutch company that is one of the world's largest food retailers, said yesterday that it would pay at least $100 million to take a 49 percent stake in a supermarket venture with Central Group, Thailand's largest retailer. The venture will operate 30 supermarkets inside department stores throughout Thailand. The supermarkets will be renamed Tops, the same name as one of Ahold's five supermarket chains in the United States.

title: CRESCENT REAL ESTATE ACQUIRING CANYON RANCH RESORTS
description: Crescent Real Estate Equities Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired two resorts for a total of $84 million. Crescent said it bought Canyon Ranch-Tucson, a health and fitness resort in Tucson, Ariz., for $27 million in partnership units and $30 million in assumed debt. The company also agreed to acquire Canyon Ranch-Lenox, a resort in Lenox, Mass., for $19 million in cash and $8 million in assumed debt. Crescent, based in Fort Worth, is a real estate investment trust.

title: Earnings at Deere Climbed By 13.3% in Third Quarter
description: Deere & Company said today that earnings rose 13.3 percent in the third quarter, bolstered by strong demand for agriculture equipment.

title: Portfolios and Menus: Wall Street Invests in Fine Dining
description: IN the 1980's, doctors, lawyers and other amateurs were the eager backers of fine restaurants. Perhaps it was love of food. Or the allure of always getting a table. Now, Wall Street, once tempted mainly by fast-food chains, is acquiring a taste for fine dining as an investment.

title: The Ballot's in the Mail? Not for Lamm
description: Former Gov. Richard D. Lamm, Ross Perot's only rival for the Reform Party Presidential nomination, cannot cast a paper ballot for himself, because he has yet to receive one in the mail.

title: Suspect Had Bomb Details, Prosecutors Say
description: Prosecutors in the terrorism trial of Ramzi Ahmed Yousef yesterday introduced what they said were bomb-making instructions found in his possession and a draft of a letter threatening to poison the air and drinking water in the Philippines.

title: Pride and Joy on Staten Island
description: Staten Island has long been the epicenter of Republican politics in New York City, so hundreds of party members gathered last night at a local catering hall to watch the ascendancy of their Congresswoman, Susan Molinari, to the national spotlight.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: F.D.A. APPROVES MARKETING OF NEW GENZYME MEMBRANE
description: The Genzyme Corporation received approval yesterday from the Food and Drug Administration to market Seprafilm, a bioengineered membrane that surgeons can use to prevent internal scar tissue from forming after abdominal or pelvic surgery. The approval was broader than expected, making Seprafilm eligible for use in about three million surgeries a year. An F.D.A. advisory committee recommended in March that Seprafilm be used only in operations to remove the large intestine or benign uterine tumors. That recommendation caused Genzyme's shares to plummet. After the approval, shares of Genzyme surged $3.25, or 14 percent, to close at $26.50.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Sir Frank Whittle, the inventor of the jet engine, misstated the history of jet airplanes in warfare. The first jet-versus-jet combat took place during the Korean War, not World War II. Britain's first jet warplanes, Gloster Meteors, powered by engines of Sir Frank's design, never encountered the first German jet warplanes, the Messerschmitt ME-262's.

title: Mets See Good Rookie Pitching: For the Cubs
description: Todd Hundley jammed his batting helmet into the dugout rack like it was a stubborn grocery cart in the seventh, huffing and puffing and acting as if he wanted to hit something -- anything -- hard.

title: Hartford Restricts Social Services to Stem Flow of Poor People
description: In an effort to stem the flow of social service agencies -- and poor people -- into Hartford, the City Council has approved zoning ordinances that severely restrict where homeless shelters, soup kitchens and other social services can operate.

title: Tourists Win Cultural Shootout in Jackson, Wyo.
description: A pickup truck hit a polo pony here last week.

title: Biscuit Recipes (the Dog May Lick the Bowl)
description: IF you are willing to make an educated commitment to cooking for your dog, that's fine, veterinarians say. Otherwise, use a good commercial brand, picked by reading labels carefully.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The mood was festive, and the 125 guests relaxed at a party Saturday evening at the East Hampton, L.I., home of CALVIN and KELLY KLEIN. They were there in honor of EDWARD KLEIN and his book ''Too Human: The Love Story of Jack and Jackie Kennedy,'' which is being published tomorrow by Pocket Books.

title: 3 Ex-Army Officers Seized in 1975 Slaying of Bangladesh Founder
description: Two months after winning power in a general election, the new Prime Minister of Bangladesh has begun fulfilling a pledge to bring to justice the army officers who stormed her family's home, killing her father and 15 family members in a coup in 1975.

title: CHRONICLE
description: AMY CARTER, who spent part of her childhood in the White House, will be married next month, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MADELEINE M. KUNIN, who fled Switzerland as the Nazis swept through Europe, is returning to her native country tomorrow as the Ambassador from the United States.

title: Only Compromise Wins
description: To the Editor;

title: Gun Charge in Robbery Case
description: According to prosecutors, Clifford Hill seemed to have what it takes to be a police officer: pistols, hollow-point bullets, a Newark police uniform, badges, handcuffs and flashing lights and sirens. But Mr. Hill is not a police officer, and the Newark police are investigating whether he was connected to a string of robberies committed by men posing as Newark officers. He was charged yesterday with illegal weapons possession after a search of his apartment.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Ray W. Fuller, 60, Biochemist And Co-Discoverer of Prozac
description: Dr. Ray W. Fuller, a co-discoverer of the most widely used antidepressant drug, Prozac, died on Sunday at his home in Greenwood, Ind. He was 60.

title: Genes That Protect Against AIDS
description: The discovery that a genetic mutation can protect certain individuals from the AIDS virus despite repeated exposure solves a puzzling medical mystery and opens new pathways toward treatments and possibly a vaccine.

title: Dance Notes
description: Bringing Home Ballet Gold

title: Early Warning About Nasdaq Wasn't Heeded
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission was told about possible broker collusion on the Nasdaq stock market as early as December 1992, but did not open a formal investigation for nearly two years, S.E.C. documents show.

title: Rape Victim Tells Of a 'Nightmare'
description: One of the most moving moments at the Republican National Convention on Tuesday came when the talk turned to law and order and a rape victim, Jan Licence of Philadelphia, took the stage.

title: COMPANY SEEKS NATURAL GAS LIQUIDS BUSINESS OF ENRON
description: The Enron Corporation said yesterday that it would consider an unsolicited indication of interest to buy its natural gas liquids business. Enron did not disclose what company made the unsolicited approach. Enron said that the interest includes the stock of the Enron Liquids Pipeline Company, which is the general partner and owner of a 15 percent interest in Enron Liquids Pipeline L.P. It also includes a 2,400-mile natural gas gathering system in the Hugoton field in Kansas; a natural gas processing plant in Buston, Kan., and the stock of the Enron Louisiana Energy Company. On the New York Stock Exchange, the stock of Enron Liquids Pipeline L.P. rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $27.125, giving the entity a market capitalization of more than $176 million.

title: Dell Earnings Up 58% in New Sign of Vigor In PC Market
description: In the latest indication of new strength in the personal computer market, the Dell Computer Corporation reported a 58 percent increase in earnings for its second fiscal quarter late yesterday, far exceeding Wall Street expectations,

title: Risky Walk in Rebel-Held Chechen Capital
description: There is only one open road left into this city. It is a long series of bomb craters, really, mixed with dirt, mud and occasionally some asphalt. The road starts in the deep woods just southwest of town and runs straight toward the ravaged center.

title: For $2, Air-Conditioned Ride To a Day of Sun and Surf
description: The rattle of the elevated No. 7 train was the only thing that broke the quiet on Roosevelt Avenue early Sunday morning in Woodside, Queens. Expectant storeowners near 61st Street waited for the end of Mass to set the local Irish and Hispanic worshipers free.

title: Minority Focus Raises Some Doubts
description: With Jack Kemp, an advocate for minority concerns, as the Vice-Presidential nominee, Colin L. Powell as the opening night headliner and black and Hispanic Republicans given visible roles at the convention, the Republican Party is trying to convey an image that it is a party where minority voters will find a welcome.

title: No Headline
description: ''This is our city. Why should we leave it again?''

title: A security consulting company has begun a monthly bulletin on air travel safety issues.
description: IN the wake of last month's T.W.A. crash, Kroll Associates, a security consulting company based in New York, has begun publishing a monthly bulletin that reviews air travel safety issues worldwide.

title: John W. King, 79, Governor Who Instituted State Lottery
description: John W. King, a former Governor of New Hampshire who created the first modern state lottery in 1963 and later served as Chief Justice of the state's Supreme Court, died on Aug. 9 at a nursing home in Manchester. He was 79.

title: Hard Times for Minority Municipal Bond Firms
description: If times are hard in municipal finance for the biggest and best-known firms on Wall Street, they are particularly tough for the nation's minority-owned municipal bond houses. Aided by Government set-aside programs, these minority firms prospered in the early 1990's in one of the few areas on Wall Street that was relatively open to blacks.

title: Simms Sees Brown as No. 1
description: Phil Simms has been involved in his share of quarterback controversies, but he doesn't see the one that was brewing recently in Giants camp as being too significant.

title: Friendly Ice Cream Reviewing Account
description: The Friendly Ice Cream Corporation said yesterday that it had placed in review the account of its Friendly's chain of restaurants, which had been handled by Elkman Advertising and Public Relations in Bala- Cynwyd, Pa., since 1988. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: TBWA Chiat/Day: Another Departure
description: For the second time in 10 months, a top executive responsible for overseeing the creative output of the New York office of TBWA Chiat/Day has unexpectedly resigned.

title: Metro Digest
description: THE CONVENTION

title: Avon and Mary Kay Create Opportunities for Women
description: There are more than 15,000 Avon ladies in Russia, and not one of them rings the doorbell.

title: Powell Seeks Distance
description: A day after a rousing speech to Republican delegates, Colin L. Powell tried to stake out independent ground, while Dole aides tried to pull him into their camp. Page A17.

title: Funds for Terrorists Traced To Persian Gulf Businessmen
description: Much of the financial support for terrorists who attack Americans, Israelis and others sympathetic to the West comes from wealthy individuals from Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf countries allied with the United States, former and current American officials say.

title: Home Sales at 9-Year High
description: Sales of single-family homes in New Jersey reached a nine-year high in the second quarter of the year, the New Jersey Association of Realtors said yesterday. About 44,700 homes were sold in April, May and June, the most since the third quarter of 1987 and a 12.6 percent increase over the corresponding period last year. The average price of a home increased to $154,000 from $146,900. Robert L. Kinniebriew, the president of the association, said that increasing employment and rising consumer confidence were fueling the market.

title: APPLE COMPUTER TO LOWER ITS SPENDING ON RESEARCH
description: Apple Computer Inc. planned to cut the percentage of revenue it spends on research, according to Ellen Hancock, vice president for research. The cost control measures include freezing research staffing and possibly charging customers for software that is now given away free. Ms. Hancock said yesterday that Apple's president, Gilbert F. Amelio, had given senior executives orders to lower research spending. ''He has given us specific targets,'' she said, while declining to elaborate on the targets. Unlike most personal computer makers, Apple designs its own hardware and operating system software. Analysts estimate Apple, based in Cupertino, Calif., spends about 6 percent of total sales on research. In the quarter that ended in June, Apple's sales were $2.2 billion.

title: Supporting Cast
description: Among the speakers on this evening's program:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LATEX RESOURCES INC., Tulsa, Okla., agreed to acquire control of Alliance Resources P.L.C. of London in a $26 million stock swap. Latex would have a 72 percent interest in the combined company.

title: Thought You Had Heard The Last of That Trial?
description: ''The Trial of O. J. Simpson: Anatomy of a Verdict'' is aimed at all the Americans who were on another planet during last year's television orgy. Here again are the white Bronco, the 911 calls, the glove that didn't seem to fit. Here yet again are Detective Mark Fuhrman, Judge Lance Ito and the defense lawyer Johnnie Cochran. Here are echoes of months of jabber about DNA evidence and legal strategies, and about the racial composition of the jury.

title: People
description: Duncan Pollock, chairman and chief executive of the New York office of Ammirati Puris Lintas, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., was promoted to the additional position of zone chairman for North America, a new post, and will join the agency's worldwide executive board.

title: G.O.P. OPENS FIERCE ATTACK ON CLINTON OVER CHARACTER AND HANDLING OF ECONOMY
description: Republicans melded homespun family images with hardball politics at their national convention tonight, as a line-up of speakers exploited what party leaders believe are President Clinton's two biggest vulnerabilities: his character and the economic anxieties of the middle class.

title: Today's Schedule
description: WEDNESDAY, AUG. 14, 1996

title: Lawyer Misconduct Deserves Public Airing
description: To the Editor:

title: Splurging on Soft-Shell Crabs
description: The price of soft-shell crabs makes them a luxury now, so you may want to think of them for a special-occasion dinner.

title: The Carpenter in the Bullpen
description: John Wetteland hustles into the clubhouse every day, his arms swinging, his chest out, his steely eyes gazing forward, and immediately transforms himself from the dude in blue jeans and T-shirt to the dude who looks like a long-lost extra from ''Rollerball.''

title: Keyshawn Shows Poise For a Rookie
description: THE way Keyshawn Johnson reasons it, he has been brought to the Jets for his hands, not his voice. When he reported to camp last week, he was asked if he would render his college fight song for the entertainment of the older Jets, but he declined.

title: 49 Years of Goodbyes
description: Forty-nine years after he became a college basketball coach, DICK BALDWIN decided yesterday that it was time to retire. Baldwin, who will turn 75 next week, was 879-290 at Broome County Community College in Binghamton, N.Y., from 1946-47 until 1986-87, and 82-51 the past five seasons at Division III Binghamton State.

title: Legislature's Intent in Backing the 'Primacy of English'
description: Following is the text of the legislative intent section of the proposed law making English the official language of Suffolk County:

title: Tele-Communications Says 2d-Quarter Loss Jumped
description: Tele-Communications Inc. said today that its second-quarter loss had nearly doubled compared with last year, because of higher costs for refinancing debt and losses from investments in other cable companies, but that cash flow had improved.

title: Food Notes
description: Soup Explosion

title: De Beers Reports Profit Rise of 18%
description: De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd., the giant South African diamond producer, said yesterday that it had strong profits in the first half of the year, reflecting good retail demand in the United States and a drop in the proportion of Russian gems on the world market. The company's income rose 18.4 percent, to $482 million in the six months ending June 30 from $407 million a year earlier.

title: Building a Business With Bars of Gold
description: It's 10 A.M., and Fran Bigelow, the owner of Fran's Chocolates in Seattle, knows where her caramel is. As it is every weekday morning, the fragrant, thick, amber nut-studded mixture is about to be poured from its copper caldron onto a vast worktable, where it will be scored and, once cool, cut into tiny bricks.

title: STOCK UP AT ARGYLE AS IT STUDIES SALE
description: The shares of Argyle Television Inc. rose 23 percent yesterday after the company said that it was exploring the possibility of selling the company or taking other strategic steps. The stock of Argyle, which owns seven television stations, rose $5.25, to $28.25, in Nasdaq trading. Argyle, based in San Antonio, generated revenue of $46.9 million and broadcast cash flow of $20.4 million last year. It owns stations in markets that include Grand Rapids, Mich.; Buffalo; Providence, R.I., and Fort Smith, Ark. Broadcasters have been buying stations since the signing of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 in February, which allowed them to own stations covering 35 percent of the nation's television viewing population, up from 25 percent.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: GENCOR INDUSTRIES TO ACQUIRE UNIT OF INGERSOLL-RAND
description: Gencor Industries agreed yesterday to buy the process equipment division of the Ingersoll-Rand Company for about $72 million. Gencor's shares jumped $4.75, or 45 percent, to $15.375, on the American Stock Exchange. Ingersoll-Rand's stock was down $1.125, to $45.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. The division, which makes equipment for oil production, sugar production and minerals extraction, has annual revenues of $100 million and operating profits of $10 million. Gencor, based in Orlando, Fla., makes highway construction machinery, equipment to remove contaminated soils, combustion equipment and heaters.

title: What Productivity Gap?
description: Sometimes it is very hard for the rest of the world to understand why the United States is so down on itself. One of the clearest examples of this malaise is the fretting over its supposedly weak productivity growth.

title: Party Seeking to Transform Harsh Image of Its Congress
description: When Speaker Newt Gingrich made his first appearance before the Republican National Convention tonight, the first words out of his mouth were about beach volleyball. This new Olympic sport, Mr. Gingrich said, ''is an example of what freedom is all about.''

title: Daewoo Plans More Uzbekistan Investment
description: The Daewoo Group of South Korea said yesterday that it would invest $2.5 billion in Uzbekistan to build telecommunications networks. Daewoo already has plans to invest $658 million to produce cars in Uzbekistan. Its auto-making unit is already producing 200,000 passenger cars and light vans a year.

title: Canadian Youths Born Prematurely Reveal Rosy View of Quality of Life
description: AS Kim Harbroe reached into an incubator to touch an infant the same size she had been at birth -- 1 pound, 7 ounces, or 640 grams -- Dr. Saroj Saigal, the pediatrician who took care of her 16 years ago, snapped her picture.

title: Turkey's Troubling Deal With Iran
description: When Turkey's new Islamic-led Government came to power last month, the Clinton Administration anticipated no sharp shifts in Ankara's generally pro-American foreign policies. Washington reasonably expected that Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan's dependence on a secular coalition partner and his reluctance to offend Turkey's military commanders would keep relations between the two NATO allies on course.

title: Prosecutor Says Rage-Filled Shaking Killed Baby
description: Mariah Scoon, the 5-month-old girl whose parents fought a court battle to keep her on life support after she was declared brain dead, died of injuries ''consistent with a repetitive, forceful, rage-filled shaking'' at the hands of her father, the Queens District Attorney said yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: Girls' School to Proceed

title: Brisk Pace Means the Watching Is Easy
description: For weeks before the event, viewers were assured that this Republican convention would be made for them, that, in Peter Jennings's inevitable image, it would be ''totally focused'' on making a good television show. On Monday evening, with the superinfomercial under way, Michael K. Deaver, one of the producers, told a reporter that his party's message was ''scripted for television.''

title: Inquiry Into Crash Proceeds on Course
description: One day it was the front cargo hold, an obvious place to conceal a bomb. Another day it was the cockpit, where an explosive device might have been hidden in a cooler. Then there was the possibility that an engine came unhinged, touching off a catastrophic mechanical failure.

title: Just Another Season In Hot Seat for Fontes
description: Wayne Fontes was working his way through one of the largest salads in captivity -- a crisp bed of iceberg lettuce, buried under a pile of turkey, tomatoes and mushrooms and covered with french dressing -- while recalling one of his more delightful gastronomic experiences.

title: Missing Funds Imperil Group In Harlem
description: BOB MARLEY'S ''No Woman No Cry'' echoed through the near-empty offices of Landmarks Harlem, offering lilting consolation to Marcella Bowens.

title: D Train Derails on Tracks Under Repair in Brooklyn
description: A Brooklyn-bound D train running on tracks that were undergoing repairs derailed yesterday as it was pulling out of the DeKalb Avenue station in Brooklyn. There were no injuries, as 350 commuters were safely escorted to the platform.

title: NATO Team Visits Bunker Used as HQ By the Serbs
description: Ending a tense standoff between peacekeeping forces and Bosnian Serbs, NATO military inspectors today toured the sprawling mountainside compound here that served as the central command for the Bosnian Serb army during the four years of war.

title: Police Evict Squatters, With Little Resistance
description: In a quick pre-dawn raid, New York City police officers evicted a group of squatters from three city-owned tenement buildings in the East Village that officials have sought for two years to reclaim. On Aug. 8, a New York State appeals court cleared the way for the eviction by lifting an injunction preventing the city from removing the squatters. Although the police said they arrested five people, the eviction was carried out without injuries and largely without the angry confrontations that characterized the evictions from two other East 13th Street buildings in 1995.

title: VW Profits Climbed In First Half of Year
description: Volkswagen A.G. said yesterday that its profit more than doubled in the first half of the year because of higher sales and earnings from financial services. Volkswagen earned 282 million marks, or $192 million, in the first half of 1996 compared with 113 million marks a year earlier. Revenue for the first half rose to 50.5 billion marks, or $34.35 billion, from 44.5 billion marks a year ago.

title: Reprieve for Utility Regulator
description: Edward H. Salmon, the Board of Public Utilities commissioner who faces removal on ethics charges, can remain on the board pending his appeal, the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday. The state Commission on Ethical Standards has charged that Mr. Salmon accepted free dinners and had personal relationships with employees of two regulated utilities.

title: Mel Taylor, 62, Who Furnished the Ventures' Rolling Drumbeat
description: Mel Taylor, a drummer for the surf music group the Ventures, one of rock's most popular and prolific instrumental acts, died on Sunday in a hospital in Tarzana, Calif. He was 62.

title: Executive Of Sanyo Is Kidnapped In Mexico
description: The president of a Japanese electronics company has been kidnapped in Tijuana, and Mexican officials said today that the company had decided to negotiate with the abductors rather than call in the police. Executives of the company said it was preparing to pay a ransom.

title: A Green Haze at Crash Site
description: A truck full of spray-on grass seed spilled its contents onto the Garden State Parkway yesterday afternoon, cloaking the road in an eerie green fog that caused a two-car accident and backed up traffic for close to an hour, the state police said. The substance, called Hyperseed, is often sprayed on embankments along highways. ANDY NEWMAN

title: Zigzag Inquiry of Flight 800 Is Said to Be on Course
description: One day it was the front cargo hold, an obvious place to conceal a bomb. Another day it was the cockpit, where an explosive device might have been hidden in a cooler. Then there was the possibility that an engine came unhinged, touching off a catastrophic mechanical failure.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Prices Rose 0.3 Percent In July, Above Estimates

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-8

title: Johnson to Miss Zurich
description: The richest track meet in the world, loaded with Olympic champions, will have to do without MICHAEL JOHNSON.

title: Fuel Tank's Condition Makes Malfunction Seem Less Likely
description: Investigators examining the wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 have concluded that the center fuel tank caught fire as many as 24 seconds after the initial blast that split apart the plane, a finding that deals a serious blow to the already remote possibility that a mechanical accident caused the crash, officials said yesterday.

title: Alice Waters: Food Revolutionary
description: ALICE WATERS was nervous. In less than an hour she would be receiving an award celebrating the 25th anniversary of her restaurant, Chez Panisse, and she had not prepared an acceptance speech. The next day she was cooking dinner for the President of the United States and 30 of his top California contributors, each paying $25,000 for the privilege of breaking bread with him.

title: This Welfare Reform Is Best We Can Achieve
description: To the Editor:

title: Sir Anthony Parsons, British Diplomat, Is Dead at 73
description: Sir Anthony Parsons, who capped a distinguished diplomatic career in the Middle East with the tough job of representing Britain at the United Nations during the Falkland war with Argentina in 1982, died on Monday at the age of 73, the British Foreign Office said yesterday.

title: Seeking Identity of Passengers
description: Steve Rothman, the Democratic Congressional candidate for the Ninth District, yesterday called on the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and his Republican opponent, a former chairwoman of the agency, to identify the passengers on 1,100 nonemergency Port Authority helicopter flights last year. The cost of the flights, at $822 an hour, or about $2 million, was reported in The Daily News on Monday. Kathleen A. Donovan, who resigned as chairwoman in November but is still a commissioner, agreed yesterday that the agency should disclose the names. Ms. Donovan was on 17 flights.

title: Further Photos of Jupiter Moon Add to Evidence of Water There
description: More close-up pictures of Jupiter's satellite Europa, with its fractured icy crust resembling the pack ice of a polar sea, were made public yesterday, and scientists said the images provided even stronger evidence that the large moon has had, and may still have, a global ocean, meaning it could have the liquid water necessary to support life.

title: In Bosnia, a Prelude to Partition
description: Amonth before the Sept. 14 elections in Bosnia, the conventional wisdom among international officials and diplomats charged with overseeing the postwar settlement is that if the voting goes smoothly, a corner will have been turned and the chances of a durable peace vastly increased. If anything, the reverse is likelier to be the case.

title: 2 Sheriff's Officers Charged
description: Two Essex County sheriff's officers were indicted on assault and conspiracy charges yesterday after prosecutors said they beat a man in a bar and then detained him to keep him from reporting the incident. Ray Weiss, a spokesman for the Essex County Prosecutor, said that Detective Cyrus Little and Investigator Darryle Millar took the man into the bathroom of a bar in Irvington last November and beat him because he objected to their dancing with a friend of his. The man and the female friend, whom prosecutors declined to identify, left to report the incident. But the officers, who were off duty, pulled over the couple's car, handcuffed them and took them in for questioning, Mr. Weiss said. Both officers were suspended without pay yesterday, said the Essex County Sheriff, Armando B. Fontoura.

title: Of Dazzling Dead Ends And Hermetic Hypnosis
description: What might possess the parents of a little girl, seemingly no more than 5 or 6 and wearing a pretty white party dress, to haul her off to the John Jay Theater for the Gate Theater of Dublin's triumphant performance of Samuel Beckett's ''Endgame'' on Saturday night?

title: On the Air -- On Line
description: All times are Eastern

title: In Which Crime Is the Life's Work of Careerists
description: DOG EAT DOG

title: For German Athletes, New Training Systems Fall Short of the Gold
description: Nearly six years after reunification, the legacy of elite sports academies developed under Communist East Germany could still be felt on the German Olympic team. More than half of the 491 German Olympic athletes attended one of the 21 schools, according to information released by the German Olympic Committee.

title: Miscellany
description: Bonnie Carlson, president and chief executive of Carlson Communications Inc., Westport, Conn., and Sue Draddy, a partner there, opened Carlson, Draddy & Associates, Westport, a marketing communications agency specializing in promotion. At the new shop, Ms. Carlson becomes chairwoman and chief executive, and Ms. Draddy becomes president and chief operating officer. Carlson Communications will be phased out by the end of the year.

title: Study Says Nitric Oxide Protects Against Worst Form of Disease : A New Weapon Against Malaria
description: SINGAPORE  A study indicates that cheap and widely available drugs containing nitric oxide may offer protection against cerebral malaria, the deadliest form of the tropical disease and for which there is no effective treatment, scientists said Tuesday.

title: Needed for Center: $13 Million and Faith
description: It's 14 months and $13 million to go at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, the $180 million colossus astride culture and commerce here in this state's largest and long-downtrodden metropolis.

title: Dole's Wife and Daughter Push for Their Candidate
description: Brows raised, eyes crinkling kindly, nodding her encouragement, the would-be First Lady of the United States radiated supportive warmth today as Cathy Ramsey, a San Diego mother of three, described her efforts to clean up the gangs in her neighborhood.

title: A Bit of Steel Whisks Odors Away
description: THE employees in Zabar's kitchen are crazy about the Odor Steeler, said Melen Ham, a buyer for the food and housewares store on the Upper West Side. ''Finally, they can go home without their hands smelling like fish,'' she said.

title: A Rare Chance To Study The Sweet Art of Dessert
description: MAIDA HEATTER, one of the country's favorite dessert-cookbook authors, will be in New York to give one of her rare classes in September. Polka-dot cheesecake, South Beach biscotti and palmiers are among the recipes she will demonstrate Sept. 17 from 6:30 to 9 P.M. at Peter Kump's School of Culinary Arts, 50 West 23d Street. Admission: $80. Information: (212) 242-2882.

title: Don't Leave Brooklyn Out of Landfill Equation
description: To the Editor:

title: From Mischief to Murder: A Boy Learns the Hard Way
description: For a boy growing up in a rough neighborhood, the line between serious mischief and heinous crime -- between getting into fights and arranging executions -- can seem as slippery as the line between adolescence and adulthood.

title: Dole Tells New Yorkers the Ticket Is Just 2 Guys from Brooklyn and Buffalo
description: Jack Kemp, the party's pick for Vice President and longtime Buffalo celebrity -- he represented the city both as a Congressman and a quarterback for the Bills -- was the scheduled speaker this morning at a meeting of New York's convention delegation.

title: Saved by a Bear (He Owes Them One)
description: ''Pull, Cubby, pull!'' shout two exhausted teen-agers at the baby polar bear who has followed them to a remote Alaskan peak, appearing in the nick of time to help them rescue their critically injured father. The bear, who the teen-agers have been told by a wise old Indian is really their spirit guide, takes a rope between its teeth and obligingly begins heaving the man up the side of a precipice.

title: Momentum Could Push Owners Into Agreement
description: A week ago today, the baseball owners' labor policy committee authorized its chief negotiator to go to court if necessary to establish that the two sides had reached an impasse in their effort to get a new collective bargaining agreement. A whirlwind weekend of talks and progress dramatically altered that state, and seemingly left the owners with no alternative but to make a deal, like it or not.

title: Legislators Back English As the Official Language
description: Brushing aside the strong objections of Hispanic groups, the Suffolk County Legislature approved a resolution today that would make English the county's official language.

title: Religion and Morals
description: To the Editor:

title: Residents Reclaim Their Old Way of Life
description: As an original tenant in the Ruth L. Bennett Homes, Yvonne Carrington never forgot what the rows of modest brick town homes in her community looked like when she moved in 43 years ago. ''It was a lovely place to live,'' she said.

title: In the Dark, Illuminated By Miracles And Music
description: For its 30th annual tour of outdoor presentations in all five boroughs and several New Jersey locations, the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater teams up with the Pregones Theater in a rousing production of ''El Apagon'' (''Blackout''), adapted by the director, Rosalba Rolon, from a short story, ''La Noche que Volvimos a Ser Gente'' (''The Night We Became People Again'') by the New York writer Jose Luis Gonzalez.

title: History is worth some scrutiny on this rebounding stock.
description: DURING the last few weeks, the stock of Retirement Care Associates Inc. in Atlanta has been on the move, with investors cheering a recent acquisition and proposed spinoff. Since Aug. 1, the stock has climbed 25 percent, closing yesterday at $11.875, down 12.5 cents for the day, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Germans Back on U.S. Base, Now as Tenants
description: If the 300 German prisoners of war interned here half a century ago could have attended a military ceremony held here last May, they would have stared as if looking at a desert mirage.

title: Take the No. 7 to the Andes (Come Hungry)
description: ALONG Roosevelt and 37th Avenues from 74th to 102d Streets, in the Jackson Heights, Elmhurst and Corona sections of Queens, there is a little Latin America, where Spanish is the language of currency, and the sign ''Cuy ahora'' (''Guinea pigs today'') makes the heart of an Ecuadorean or a Peruvian beat a little faster. For the guinea pig advertised on a recent Sunday at Casa America La Dispensa Ecuatoriana, at 102-04 Roosevelt Avenue, was not a little squealing fur ball on four legs. It was turning slowly on a spit, cooking until its skin was crisp and golden and the meat tender, with the texture of dark-meat chicken and the sweetness of pork.

title: Cynicism's High Price
description: To the Editor:

title: To Mother Hubbard: Forget the Bone, Fetch Me Some Soy
description: WHAT do dogs really want?

title: Harassment Case Settled
description: A sexual harassment case against KEN BEHRING, the multimillionaire Seattle Seahawks owner, has been settled behind closed doors and nobody is talking about the terms. The two sides reached an agreement Monday, ending months of legal sparring between attorneys representing Behring and a former employee.

title: Men's Health Picks Martin
description: Men's Health magazine, a publication of Rodale Press, has named the Martin Agency in Richmond to handle its account, with billings estimated at $1 million. The account had been handled for four years by the Santa Ana, Calif., office of Foote, Cone & Belding, a unit of True North Communications.

title: The Future of Tolerance
description: Shortly after addressing his fellow Republicans here, Colin Powell told NBC News that he did not want to be regarded as a ''poster boy'' for Republican tolerance. No one can blame him for that, but you have to assume, based on the political skill with which he managed his career, that Mr. Powell understands how great a gap there is between his nostalgic vision of the ''party of Lincoln'' and the modern party as defined by the delegates to this convention. The majority of these delegates have no intention of belonging to a party that believes what Mr. Powell believes about abortion, affirmative action and immigration. So in explaining his vision of Republicanism, Mr. Powell was defining a party that does not exist and that will never exist if the activist core of this convention has its way.

title: Israeli Settlements Are Barred by Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Videotaping at U.S. Base in Bosnia Raises Terrorist Alert
description: American troops in Bosnia have been placed on the highest state of alert after people in civilian clothes were apprehended while videotaping American bases there, and intelligence reports suggested a terrorist attack might be in the planning, the Defense Department said today.

title: Jets' Smith Required To Share His Corner
description: It was not so much a command as it was a plea:

title: Despite the Dole Camp's Efforts, Powell Seeks to Distance Himself
description: After a rousing reception by cheering Republican delegates, Gen. Colin L. Powell tried to stake out independent ground today, while Bob Dole's senior campaign aides plotted ways to pull General Powell deeper into their camp.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Aug. 6 about a merger between U.S. Order Inc. and Colonial Data Technologies Corporation misstated the background of William F. Gorog, the chief executive of U.S. Order. He was a former member of the board of Verifone Inc.; he was not the company's founder.

title: Dole Turns to a Pet Cause: People With Disabilities
description: Bob Dole, the man of the hour who is basking here in sun and limelight, used his prestige today to turn the national spotlight on his cherished cause: people with disabilities.

title: Pact Reached on Abortion In Arkansas Medicaid Case
description: Federal and state officials and a local abortion provider have agreed to rely on private money to pay for some abortions until their battle over Medicaid financing of abortions in Arkansas is resolved.

title: Networks vs. the Organizers: Early Rounds Go to G.O.P.
description: When Colin L. Powell spoke about Republican diversity here on Monday night, at least a fifth of the faces the major broadcast networks focused on were black, though only 3 percent of the delegates are.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: APPLIED MATERIALS TO REDUCE ITS WORK FORCE BY 7%
description: Applied Materials Inc. said yesterday that it would cut 830 jobs, or 7 percent of its work force, citing continued weak industrywide demand for chips. The company, which makes semiconductor manufacturing equipment, planned to take a charge of $28 million to $32 million before taxes in the fourth quarter, which ends on Oct. 27, for the job reductions. Its directors also planned to take a 10 percent pay cut. The company planned to dismiss some 390 workers at its operations in Santa Clara, Calif.; another 340 workers in Austin, Tex., and the remainder at other locations worldwide. It also planned to discontinue about 870 temporary and contract jobs around the world.

title: This World Revolves Around the Indy 500
description: There are calendar years, fiscal years and academic years. Starting this Sunday, you can add Indy-car years to the ways of measuring the Earth's rotation about the Sun.

title: A Day of Soft Landings for Zabriski
description: Few courses in the metropolitan area come tougher than the Stanwich Club. The 7,133-yard, par-72 course has one of the most difficult ratings of any course in the area, and extremely fast greens.

title: G.O.P. Nixes Nets
description: The upbeat TV mini-series that the Republicans call their convention may or may not persuade you that they should be running the country. But what viewer would dispute that they should at the very least be running the Oscars? In the hands of Paul Manafort, Bob Dole's convention manager, Hollywood's annual telecast would run a flab-free 45 minutes, with plenty of time for tears (think Kirk Douglas instead of Nancy Reagan) and cheers (Tom Hanks instead of Colin Powell) -- and maybe some abject perkiness, too (Sally ''You-really-like-me'' Field in the Susan Molinari role).

title: Convention Summary
description: 'MAIN STREET' COMMENTS AND CRITICISM OF CLINTON

title: Wine Talk
description: ONE of George Meredith's heros, Richard Feverel, I recall, in the Victorian novel ''The Ordeal of Richard Feverel,'' looks forward happily to laying down some good Burgundy for his newly born son. It's one of the earliest references, literary or journalistic, that I can think of that acknowledges the aging potential of the pinot noir grape.

title: Skater Dies Of Injuries After Collision
description: A 28-year-old in-line skater who collided with a bicyclist in Central Park on Sunday died yesterday morning at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.

title: Bonds Tumble As Price Index Shows Upturn
description: Signs of strength in yesterday's economic reports heightened fears of inflation among investors and caused a sharp selloff of Treasury securities, even as some analysts wondered whether the fears were justified.

title: Ventura's Grand Slam Cuts Into Yanks' Lead
description: The count to Robin Ventura was 3-0 and the bases were crammed with White Sox, so David Weathers naturally threw a fastball. The Yankees would have been better off letting Ventura hit the ball off a batting tee. The result could not have been any more devastating.

title: Learning Disabled Man Gains N.C.A.A. Victory
description: An 18-year-old swimmer was granted a partial waiver of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's academic standards yesterday in a landmark case for student athletes with learning disabilities.

title: All-Girls Public School to Open Despite Objections
description: Over the objections of civil rights advocates, the first single-sex public school in New York City in a decade will open its doors to 50 seventh-grade girls when the school year begins in September, a Board of Education official said yesterday.

title: Accounts
description: Seagate Software Storage Management Group, Orlando, Fla., a unit of Seagate Technologies, to Partners & Simons, Boston, the creative part of its account, and to Freeman Associates, Wellesley, Mass., the media part. Both part of the account, with billings estimated at $1 million, had been handled in-house.

title: For Thirsty Athletes, An Easier Way to Sip
description: ROGER FAWCETT began to rethink the sports water bottle after a friend rode in a 100-mile bike ride in Wichita Falls, Tex. The temperature reached 106 degrees that day, and water bottles did not carry enough water or keep it cool. Reaching for a water bottle while pedaling among other riders sometimes meant veering into another cyclist. Mr. Fawcett thought there had to be a better way.

title: People
description: Janet L. Klineman was named to the new post of senior vice president and senior account planner at Wells Rich Greene BDDP, New York, a unit of BDDP Worldwide. She had been senior account planner at Fallon McElligott Berlin, New York, an affiliate of Fallon McElligott, Minneapolis.

title: On the Air - On Line
description: All times are Eastern

title: Oklahoma Appoints a Star Supporter
description: STEVE OWENS, who since winning the Heisman Trophy as a running back at Oklahoma in 1969 has been one of the program's most passionate and influential supporters, became the school's new athletic director yesterday.

title: The Case That Rocked Crown Heights
description: On a warm summer night five years ago, a 7-year-old black boy stopped to adjust the chain on his bicycle near an intersection in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn. The boy, Gavin Cato, was the first person to be in the wrong place at the wrong time in a series of events that destroyed two lives, blighted many others and did lasting damage to relations between uneasy neighbors.

title: Nearby Queens Residents Unite to Take On Airports
description: Bill Mulcahy, a retired city firefighter, was enjoying the warmth of a recent sunny morning in his backyard in Queens. His father-in-law sat at a table under an umbrella and his niece lazily dangled her toes in a shallow, plastic pool. This, Mr. Mulcahy said, is the good life.

title: Dollar Surges Against Mark On Hint of German Rate Cut
description: The dollar posted its biggest one-day gain against the mark in almost four months yesterday, after comments from the Bundesbank's chief economist encouraged expectations for lower interest rates.

title: Broad Silence Order Issued in Simpson Trial
description: The judge in the civil suit against O. J. Simpson has issued a far-reaching nondisclosure order barring the lawyers, clients and witnesses from discussing the wrongful death case in public or with the news media during the trial.

title: USAir Issues a Gag Order About In-Flight Problems
description: In addition to the obligatory beverages and bags of peanuts, passengers aboard a few USAir airplanes now have access to a new in-flight telephone system. But if the airplane experiences an ''in-flight anomaly'' -- industry jargon for potential disasters -- the company recommends that pilots disconnect the telephone service to protect its image.

title: Clinton Looks At Job Ideas For Inner City
description: As President Clinton prepares to sign legislation ending the 60-year Federal guarantee of assistance to needy children, Administration officials are considering proposals to encourage the creation of jobs in the inner cities, possibly including new tax breaks for businesses.

title: Truce That Never Was: Chechens Tricked
description: The latest truce in the war for Chechnya began today at noon.

title: Perot Insures That Lamm, His Rival, Gets a Ballot
description: Thanks to Ross Perot's personal intervention, Richard D. Lamm, Mr. Perot's rival for the Reform Party's Presidential nomination, was able to to vote today in the balloting that will decide which one of them will become the new party's nominee.

title: Less Torrid Initial Offerings: An Opportunity for the Savvy
description: Get 'em while they're cold. Investors who are longing for the hot new-issue market of last summer, when initial public offerings like Netscape Communications shot up during their first day of trading, should learn to enjoy the cooler weather. The decidedly tepid temperature of the current market offers buyers greater opportunity to snatch up stock in solid companies at reasonable prices.

title: Abortion Barely Mentioned, Its Opponents Are Offended
description: Elaine Hawkins, a self-described happy homemaker from San Antonio and an alternate delegate to the Republican National Convention, is surprised, confused -- and angry. Mrs. Hawkins said she could not even recall hearing the word ''abortion'' mentioned from the podium.

title: Morgan Stanley Will Pay West Virginia $20 Million
description: Morgan Stanley Group Inc. agreed yesterday to pay $20 million to settle a lawsuit brought against it by West Virginia over a failed investment strategy that ultimately cost the state $280 million and forced it to raise taxes.

title: Closing Arguments on Ellis I.
description: Closing arguments in the first phase of New Jersey's lawsuit against New York over control of Ellis Island will begin today after five weeks of hearings. Paul Verkuil, the special master who is hearing the case in the United States Supreme Court building, is expected to make recommendations to the court by September. New Jersey claims that 24 acres of landfill added to the immigration center over the last century belong to New Jersey.

title: INSIDE
description: Clinton Writes Book

title: Mexico's New Press Boldness Stops at Leader's Desk
description: President Ernesto Zedillo was seated on a wooden throne in the National Palace recently, taping an interview with Jacobo Zabludovsky, Mexico's No. 1 television anchor, when he suddenly interrupted his questioner.

title: A Wife Takes a Star Turn
description: In a twist that was part spectacle, part salesmanship, Elizabeth Dole glided onto the floor of the Republican National Convention tonight, talk-show-host style, to mingle among the delegates and evoke tender images from her husband's past.

title: '86 A.T.M. Robber Arrested Again in Holdups
description: In 1986, the police thought they would no longer have to worry about Carl H. Brown and the string of automated teller machine robberies he carried out in Manhattan. After they linked him to a series of holdups, a judge sentenced him to 8 1/2 to 17 years in prison.

title: Heart Group Issues Guide for Young Athletes
description: With the beginning of the school year approaching, the American Heart Association yesterday issued the first national recommendations for screening high school and college athletes for fatal heart ailments.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the observance of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin holy day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Teaming Up to Perform as a Consort of Viols
description: Because the pool of players is comparatively small, the performance opportunities are plentiful and the repertory is varied, the musicians who specialize in period instruments tend to shuffle from one ensemble to the next with extraordinary rapidity. A viola da gamba player, for example, might work in a Baroque orchestra one week, as a continuo player in a chamber group the next and in a consort of viols the week after that.

title: Of Politics And News: Two Films From Life
description: Hollywood has never been too sure how to treat politicians and journalists, portraying them as either heroic or contemptible, either utterly decent and selfless or recklessly ambitious and back stabbing. But now two movie projects -- a big-budget adaptation of the best-selling novel ''Primary Colors'' and a drama about Janet Cooke, the disgraced Washington Post reporter -- are seeking to redefine the worlds of politicians and journalists as more ambiguous and morally complex.

title: Tom Mees, 46, ESPN Broadcaster, Drowns
description: Tom Mees, one of the original broadcasters on ESPN, the 24-hour sports cable network, drowned yesterday in an apparent swimming accident in Southington, Conn. He was 46.

title: Convention Summary
description: IT IS BOB DOLE'S NIGHT

title: Bonds Close Session Mixed
description: Prices of government securities were mixed yesterday, as fresh economic data somewhat reassured investors. While the data indicated some strength, the signs were not as strong as the market's consensus forecast.

title: N.F.L. TRAINING CAMP REPORT
description: New England Patriots

title: Economists are wary of Dole's promise to reduce taxes.
description: WHILE economists are not lining up to congratulate Bob Dole on his plan to cut taxes even as he proposes a constitutional amendment to balance the budget, many do admire his skill in snaking a path between the deficit hawks in the Republican Party and the what-me-worry supply-siders.

title: Russia's Humiliation in Chechnya
description: Few great powers have ever looked as helpless as Russia does today in Chechnya. An explosive offensive by Chechen fighters over the last week has left Russian military forces shattered and has badly rattled the Government of Boris Yeltsin. Neither the military nor the Government is likely to recover soon.

title: William S. Weinberger, 83, Host to Big Gamblers
description: William S. Weinberger, a casino host who knew most of the world's biggest gamblers, died on Thursday in Las Vegas, Nev. He was 83.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB TO DIVEST ITSELF OF 2 BUSINESSES
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that it intended to sell the infection-control and contamination-control businesses of its Convatec division. Bristol-Myers Squibb, the New York-based pharmaceutical and health products concern, acquired the businesses in its January 1995 purchase of Calgon Vestal Laboratories from Merck & Company. Products of both of the businesses are marketed under the Calgon Vestal name. Bristol-Myers Squibb said the businesses had performed well but had not met its strategic objectives.

title: Thefts Might Imperil Pilots
description: Transportation officials are worried by the theft of the colored glass globes that cover the runway lights at Trenton-Robbinsville Airport. About 30 of the red, green, blue and orange markers have disappeared this year, and without the complete system of colored lights, officials say, pilots of small planes could misjudge an approach and crash. Gil Maupin, chief of inspection and aircraft operations for the State Department of Transportation, told The Associated Press yesterday that he believes teen-agers are stealing the globes on a dare.

title: The Jack Kemp Reverse
description: Welcome to the N.F.L. By tradition, that is what rookies are told by way of introduction to the brutal realities of professional sport. Surely the phrase must have flashed through the mind of the old footballer Jack Kemp when he was told the price he would have to pay to be on the Republican ticket with Bob Dole.

title: NASA Shuttle Program Waylaid Mars Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: J. S. Graettinger, 75, an Educator of Doctors
description: Dr. John Sells Graettinger, a Chicago physician and medical educator, died on Tuesday at Rush Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center in Chicago. He was 75 and lived in Chicago.

title: Milbury Frustrated With Blackhawks
description: Like a poker player, Islander General Manager MIKE MILBURY is holding onto his cards as he attempts to pry the restricted free agent center JEREMY ROENICK from the Chicago Blackhawks. But Milbury is not too happy that Blackhawks management decided to go public and say that the Islanders' trade offers are severely lacking.

title: Extraterrestrial Piffle
description: To the Editor:

title: Grizzlies Sign Rogers to 3-Year Pact
description: ROY ROGERS, one of Vancouver's two first-round draft picks, signed a three-year contract with the Grizzlies yesterday worth close to $2 million. The 6-foot-10-inch forward from Alabama will earn $553,000 in the first year, $635,900 in the second and $718,800 in the third.

title: Auto Industry Struggles to Satisfy the Tastes of First-Time Buyers on a Budget
description: Kristin M. Anson, a 31-year-old radiology technician, and her husband, Bill, a 35-year-old truck driver, really want to buy a new full-size, option-laden Dodge pickup for upward of $25,000. But after carefully reviewing their pinched budget, they have decided instead to keep the 1989 Mercury Cougar they bought in 1992 for $9,900.

title: A Master of Process, Not Philosophy: Robert Joseph Dole
description: It was his last campaign swing before coming here to accept his party's nomination, and Bob Dole had just risen from his knees at the flower-strewn memorial in Atlanta for the victims of the Olympic park bombing. Surrounded by a forest of cameras and microphones, he was asked what his thoughts had been as he laid down his bouquet of sunflowers.

title: PHYSICIANS RESOURCE EXPANDS EYE-CARE HOLDINGS
description: Physicians Resource Group Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired seven eye-care practice groups for about $91 million in stock. The Dallas-based manager of eye-care clinics said five of the groups are in Florida, one is in Ohio and one is in Texas. Physicians Resource also said it had completed the acquisition of five other eye-care practices for about $5.5 million. Two of those groups are in California; the others are in Illinois, New Jersey and Tennessee.

title: White House Is Given Plan to Ban Cigarette Sales to the Young
description: The Food and Drug Administration has given the White House its proposed rule to ban the marketing of cigarettes to young people, an important, if interim, step in the Federal regulation of nicotine as a drug.

title: A Last Leaf on a Family Tree Remembers
description: WHEN I was a little boy, in the 1950's, my grandfather gave me a history lesson in a way that was repeated all through my childhood.

title: A Top Steel Executive Is Demoted
description: In a move that surprised some analysts as well as some company insiders, the National Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would strip V. John Goodwin of the post of chief executive, but would ask him to stay on as president and chief operating officer.

title: U.S. Needs to Act On Genital Mutilation
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Pays Some Women From War Brothels, but Many Refuse
description: With Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto expressing his ''sincere apologies and remorse,'' Japan made its first payments today from a private fund to compensate Asian women who were forced into army brothels during World War II.

title: Disabled Adults at the Fair
description: The Warren County Farmer's Fair is now in full swing. And despite early indications to the contrary, a group of mentally disabled adults were able to attend. Diane Lachemayer, assistant director of a home for mentally and physically disabled adults in Clinton, said that when she called the fair last week to arrange for her group's customary free passes, officials told her the group was not welcome.

title: India Deadlocks Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty
description: Plans by the Clinton Administration and dozens of other governments to finish work this week on a treaty banning all nuclear explosions collapsed in Geneva today as India, supported by Iran, blocked all efforts to close negotiations and open the pact for signing.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Federal Farm Credit Banks is selling $100 million of medium-term notes due in 1999 through Morgan Stanley. The notes are callable in a year, carry an interest rate of 6.540 percent and are priced at par.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column yesterday about a party Calvin and Kelly Klein gave on Saturday in honor of Edward Klein and his new book misstated the book's title. It is ''All Too Human: The Love Story of Jack and Jackie Kennedy.''

title: Executive Changes
description: CONVERSE INC., North Reading, Mass., said Michael C. Bell, its president, had resigned to pursue other business interests. His duties will be assumed by Glenn N. Rupp, the chairman and chief executive.

title: Prickly Creatures, but They Pierce English Hearts
description: Mavis Righini had always liked tortoises, but when she was suddenly entrusted with five sickly baby hedgehogs a decade ago, she found what may well be her life's calling.

title: Canine Candor
description: To the Editor:

title: Proving Incitement Is Complicated Task
description: In using a Federal civil rights statute to charge a second Brooklyn man with the 1991 death of a Hasidic student, prosecutors may have a tough time. They must persuade a jury that a man who utters anti-Semitic invective can be held as responsible for a homicide as the man who does the stabbing.

title: Genta Warns That It Will End Operations if It Cannot Raise Funds
description: Genta Inc., a biotechnology company, warned today that it would have to cease operations if it could not raise additional funds.

title: Profits at Hoechst Triple in Quarter
description: Hoechst A.G. said yesterday that its pretax profit in the second quarter rose nearly threefold to 3.08 billion marks, or $2.08 billion, which was within expectations. It said most of the increase had come from the sale of assets, including its stake in SGL Carbon A.G., a maker of carbon and graphite products.

title: Loner Is Thrust Into Spotlight In Latest Case
description: In the five years since racial violence shook Crown Heights, Charles Price has lived a troubled life, battling drug addiction and repeatedly landing in prison.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: IMPERIAL CREDIT INDUSTRIES, Torrance, Calif., a financial services company, agreed to acquire as much as 49 percent of Dabney-Resnick Inc. of Beverly Hills, Calif., as part of a strategic alliance between the two.

title: Judge in Oklahoma Bombing Bars Statements Made by One Defendant About the Other
description: The Federal judge in the Oklahoma City bombing case ruled yesterday that statements made by a defendant about his co-defendant, Timothy J. McVeigh, could not be used as evidence against him at trial. The judge also refused to suppress Government evidence against both men.

title: Kurri Leaves Rangers for Anaheim
description: A week ago, NEIL SMITH, president of the Rangers, did not profess much optimism about re-signing JARI KURRI, or that he even wanted to. Two weeks earlier, Smith had signed WAYNE GRETZKY to a two-year contract, winning out over a number of suitors that may or may not have included the Anaheim Mighty Ducks.

title: Civil Rights Lawyers Hope to Use Hartford Schools Case as a Model
description: In the weeks since Connecticut's high court ruled that de facto racial segregation in Hartford's public schools violates the state's Constitution, telephones of the civil rights lawyers who brought the case have rung with congratulations from colleagues across the country.

title: Yeltsin Gives Aide Free Rein to End Fighting in Chechen War
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin's national security adviser, Aleksandr I. Lebed, who recently expressed scathing contempt for the Kremlin's handling of the Chechen war, was given broad powers today to take over the efforts to end the fighting.

title: An 'Amish' Bench for Sitting, Not for Sale
description: ON the sidewalk in front of a construction site on Seventh Avenue between 42d and 43d Streets, there sits a humble, unadorned, handmade wooden bench -- perfectly proportioned, 48 inches long, 12 inches deep and 36 inches tall from the ground to the top of its back.

title: Yankees Dust Themselves Off and Have a Blast
description: When Frank Thomas belted a majestic homer over the center-field fence off Andy Pettitte today, the ball traveled so straight, so far and so fast that it turned Comiskey Park into Comiskey Party. The huge scoreboard erupted in a cacophony of lights, sound effects and fireworks. The White Sox were celebrating, and the Yankees were not invited.

title: Louise Talma, Neo-Classical Composer, 89
description: Louise Talma, a composer whose music combined a Neo-Classical spareness, clarity and lyricism with the structural rigorousness of the 12-tone school, died on Tuesday at Yaddo, the artists' colony near Saratoga Springs, N.Y., where she was composing a song cycle with chamber accompaniment. She was 89 and lived in Manhattan.

title: DOLE HAILED AS AN HONORABLE, 'QUIET HERO' AS REPUBLICANS GIVE HIM THEIR NOMINATION
description: The Republican Party tonight nominated Robert Joseph Dole as its candidate for President of the United States after an evening of tributes in which his friends, family and former colleagues presented him to Americans not as the familiar Washington politician but as a quiet, dignified war hero.

title: Don They Now Their Drag Apparel
description: ''Howard Crabtree's When Pigs Fly,'' which opened last night at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater, is an exceptionally cheerful, militantly gay new musical revue that comes close to living up to its own billing, ''the side-splitting musical extravaganza.'' No sides are ever in serious danger of splitting. Yet there's enough hilarity, wit and outre humor here to evoke that era, more than 40 years ago, when bright, irreverent revues were as commonplace on Broadway as today's stately Cameron Mackintosh spectacles.

title: Novo Nordisk Profit Is Better Than Forecast
description: Novo Nordisk A.S., a Danish company that produces insulin and industrial enzymes, said yesterday that its pretax profit was better than expected, surging 19 percent in the first half on increases in operating income and profit from investments.

title: Divers Resume Search for Plane Wreckage
description: Divers searching for wreckage from Trans World Airline Flight 800 went back to the ocean floor this morning, after a one-day break imposed by rough seas. Today began the fifth week of picking up pieces of the Boeing 747 that exploded off the coast here on July 17.

title: Museums and QVC find they can do business together by going beyond the typical art crowd.
description: IF politics make strange bedfellows, then commerce makes some pretty strange ones, too. A good example is the recent alliance between QVC, the cable shopping channel, and several major museums.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about zoning changes in Hartford that will restrict where social service agencies can operate misstated the terms of aid provided for such agencies by an organization called Share Our Strength. It has given them $250,000 since 1989, but it has not yet given any money specifically to help the agencies fight the zoning changes.

title: General Mills To Add Chex In Cereal Wars
description: Bowing out of the price wars raging among name-brand breakfast cereals, Ralcorp Holdings Inc. agreed yesterday to sell Chex and other cereal and snack brands to General Mills Inc. for at least $330 million in stock.

title: Indonesia Keeps Labor in Line by Repression
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Tough Guys on Familiar Ground
description: CHANCE

title: More Movies for Turner
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. said this week that its Turner Classic Movies channel on cable television had acquired exclusive rights to show ''It Happened One Night'' and 35 other films owned by the Columbia Pictures unit of the Sony Corporation. The deal includes the films ''Dr. Strangelove,'' ''Suddenly Last Summer'' and ''The Harder They Fall.''

title: Seeds of 2000 Abound, But Which Will Grow?
description: Each convention is father to the next, even if the child denies its patrimony, as San Diego 1996 has done with Houston 1992.

title: The Artificial Grass Helps MetroStars to Real Victory
description: Giants Stadium lost a great deal of its soccer majesty with artificial turf taking the place of grass tonight, but the MetroStars have rarely looked better.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS TO SELL DEBT SECURITIES
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell as much as $2 billion of debt securities. The sale of such debt would help the newly independent company finance a long-expected expansion. Electronic Data, a computer-services provider, split off from the General Motors Corporation in June. Under its former parent company, E.D.S. needed approval from General Motors to make acquisitions and could not use its stock for such deals. In the filing, Electronic Data, based in Plano, Tex., said it planned to use the proceeds from the sale for general corporate purposes, which may include debt reduction, acquisitions and capital expenditures. Shares of E.D.S fell $1.25 yesterday, to $51.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-16

title: The Pop Life
description: Escalation in the Music Wars

title: Way Set for Time Warner to Buy Turner
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it had signed a consent order with the staff of the Federal Trade Commission, clearing the way for completion of its $6.7 billion acquisition of Turner Broadcasting System Inc.

title: WOOLWORTH CORP. (Z,N)
description: The Woolworth Corporation yesterday reported earnings for the second quarter that exceeded Wall Street expectations, reflecting lower costs, improved profit margins and the sale of some businesses.

title: In Crown Hts., Elusive Quest For Justice
description: THERE is a timelessness about Crown Heights, a weary grittiness broken only by a flash of humor or an attempt at optimism from people who live apart even as they live together.

title: In New Role, Kemp Fights With His Past Over Ideology
description: After spending most of his political career as a fiscal conservative but social moderate, even maverick, Jack Kemp has publicly reversed himself on issues as touchy as immigration and affirmative action, and is now caught up in an ideological wrestling match with himself to mesh his brand of Republicanism with Bob Dole's more right-leaning brand.

title: Mets Find Their Offense and Avoid a Sweep by the Cubs
description: The crowd should have known they were going to catch Bobby Jones on a high hop, at the very top of his pitching ability. It wasn't his turn to struggle, whether he had shoulder pain or not.

title: Bridge
description: The gods of bridge had made up their minds about the final of the Spingold Knockout Championship in Miami Beach on Sunday. They would make it exciting, for the benefit of 300 enthusiasts watching intently, and at the end of a long day they would give victory to the Nick Nickell team, which set a record by taking four straight titles.

title: Haves and Have-Nots Sharing Space on Sea
description: Of all the opulent venues used by the conventioneers, none is more stunning than the delegate hall's neighboring marina, with its bobbing fortune in yachts and its sailor-owners arriving by limousine, some with lap dogs bearing designer pooch-coiffures. And none of the boats glittering dockside is more misleading than a 71-foot catamaran called Canvasback used for news conferences by eager Republican interest groups, from gun owners to forestry lobbyists.

title: Credit for Service Time Holds Up Labor Talks
description: Baseball club owners opposed to crediting players for service time lost during their two-season strike either (a) have enough votes to block a new labor agreement that includes service time or (b) don't have enough votes to block a new labor agreement that includes service time.

title: Injured Mathis Is Out of Bout
description: Buster Mathis Jr. has pulled out of his Aug. 20 fight against Lou Savarese at Madison Square Garden after injuring his neck and jaw in a sparring session on Monday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: LITTLE LEAGUE

title: Jets Then, Jets Now And Jets Forever
description: They spanned a time of Jets yesterdays. For players and fans, that often was better than the team's todays. But the team that has been energized this season with an infusion of new players on offense is for the first time making an effort to remember its past.

title: 'Nightline' Pulls the Plug on Convention Coverage
description: Saying there was too little news here, Ted Koppel and most of his staff left town today, leaving about 15,000 other members of the news media behind.

title: Getting a Second Look
description: The tightly scripted television gala being beamed from San Diego has reached into Canton, Ohio, and won over some, though by no means nearly all, of the women whom the Republican Party is trying hard to attract.

title: Conflicting Signals On Nintendo Results
