description: Trading in the Nintendo Company was suspended yesterday in Tokyo, after Nihon Keizai Shimbun, an economic newspaper, said the company's pretax profit would tumble 70 percent for the fiscal year. Nintendo denied the report and said its pretax profit might exceed its forecast of 27 billion yen, or $250 million.

title: Stars Come Out and the Mile Record Falls
description: Watching the Weltklasse track and field meet unfold over the course of a single evening is like eating too many Swiss pastries at a single sitting. There is too much rich fare to digest comfortably.

title: Supporting Cast
description: Among the speakers on this evening's program:

title: Police in California Fight Citizen Complaints
description: After years of headway by groups pushing for wider latitude in the pursuit of citizen complaints against the police, law-enforcement officers in California have begun to push concertedly back.

title: Metaphorical Blitz
description: There has been so much football talk this week that you half-expected to see a helmeted Bob Dole and to hear a 50-yard-run wheeze from Jack Kemp. ''We're both suited up,'' Mr. Dole proclaimed on Saturday upon introducing his choice for Vice President in Russell, Kan. ''We're both going to cross the goal line ahead of the other side on November 5.''

title: Stars Of Style Satirized Stylishly
description: CHRISTIAN LACROIX thinks your home is worth a laugh. Especially if your sense of style was established between 1960 and 1995 and says more about fads than fancy. But do not take the fashion designer's mirth personally. Mr. Lacroix wants to educate the world with a knowing smile, not wound it.

title: 'Party Pitch' and 'Politically Incorrect' Put Their Spin on Convention
description: There was moshing not far from the Republican National Convention. Not noshing, as in eating, but moshing, as in people at rock concerts tossing each other's bodies overhead. You would not have noticed this unless you were watching MTV.

title: Man Is Killed and Family Injured in an Arson
description: A church deacon was killed and his wife and three young children critically injured in an arson at a Brooklyn housing project yesterday morning, police and fire officials said.

title: Plowshares Into Pacifiers
description: I am put in mind of a Dorothy Parker phrase, as I watch the Republicans nurture, cuddle, swaddle and practically lactate on prime time. It makes me want to fwow up.

title: Life in Ice
description: To the Editor:

title: Keynoter's Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Flextech and BBC Discuss TV Venture
description: Flextech P.L.C, a British television programmer, is in talks with the British Broadcasting Corporation about creating as many as six cable and satellite television channels.

title: Paralyzed Police Officer Supports Dole
description: Steven McDonald, a New York City police officer who was grievously wounded in a Central Park shooting in 1986, called tonight from his wheelchair for the election of Bob Dole as a man who understands the sacrifices that must be made to overcome pain.

title: Valujet Seeks Easing of Debt From Its Banks
description: Valujet Inc. is trying to renegotiate its bank debt in an effort to avoid default, according to the company's quarterly filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Why G.O.P. Tolerates Powell and His Message
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Did the daughters of the women who shaped the feminist revolution of the 1960's follow in their mothers' footsteps? That question intrigued CHRISTINA BAKER KLINE, 32, and her mother CHRISTINA LOOPER BAKER, 56, so they decided to write a book.

title: Achilles Wasn't Trojan War's Yuppie
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about trading in the stock market on Tuesday referred incorrectly to the status of quarterly reports from the Chantal Pharmaceutical Corporation, whose stock fell that day. The National Association of Securities Dealers has allowed Chantal to file results for the first and second quarter as part of the company's cumulative nine-month figures in its third-quarter report. The reports for the first and second quarter are not overdue.

title: 72d District: A Political Puzzle
description: On paper, it would seem that Assemblyman John Brian Murtaugh's days in office are numbered.

title: In One Town, Some Women Begin Giving Dole a Second Look
description: A national political convention always gives a party a bounce in the polls, and there is evidence that the tightly scripted television gala being beamed nightly from San Diego this week is reaching into this Middle American place and winning over some of the women the Republicans are striving so hard to attract.

title: OSI HOLDINGS TO ACQUIRE PAYCO AMERICAN
description: The Payco American Corporation agreed yesterday to be bought by the closely held OSI Holdings Corporation for about $150 million in cash and debt. The deal will create the largest accounts-receivable management company in the United States. Payco stockholders will receive $14 in cash for each common share. The shares rose $1.8125, to $13.5625. Payco, which had revenue of $175.6 million last year, provides accounts-receivable and customer-service management through 37 offices in the United States and Puerto Rico. The Atlanta-based OSI Holdings was formed in 1995 by McCown De Leeuw & Company, a New York-based investment firm.

title: Jack Kemp's Rainbow Party
description: Bob Dole's selection of Jack Kemp as his running mate has not only excited the handful of black Republicans at the convention here this week. His nomination has strong appeal to other black Americans as well. No other choice, except for retired Gen. Colin Powell, would have been greeted with more enthusiasm.

title: October Surprises
description: An ''October surprise,'' in political parlance, is the making of big news to affect a November election. Because such manipulation of events by government officials is unfair, the opposing party seeks to impugn the surprise's motive.

title: Braves Deal Whiten to Mariners
description: The Atlanta Braves traded outfielder MARK WHITEN to the Seattle Mariners for a minor league pitcher, ROGER BLANCO, yesterday and recalled the heralded 19-year-old outfielder ANDRUW JONES from Class AAA Richmond.

title: Graf Defeats Williams But Offers Compliments
description: Her father touted the match as No. 1 in the world versus No. 1 in ''the ghetto,'' and a funny thing happened: suspense.

title: Welcoming the Disabled, Atlanta Lets the Games Begin, Again
description: Bestirring itself from a profound Olympic weariness, Atlanta will begin its stint Thursday night as host to the 1996 Paralympics -- 10 days of competition involving 3,500 athletes from 127 countries who have disabilities ranging from blindness to quadriplegia.

title: PRICE OF SAVOY ACQUISITION REDUCED TO $126 MILLION
description: Silver King Communications Inc. and Savoy Pictures Entertainment Inc. said yesterday that they had agreed to reduce the amount of stock Silver King would pay for Savoy because of poor financial results at Savoy television stations. The price of the stock swap would be cut to 0.14 Silver King share, from 0.20 share, for each Savoy share. The transaction is currently valued at about $126 million, compared with $210 million when it was announced on Nov. 27. Silver King, based in St. Petersburg, Fla., said it lowered the price because revenue and cash flow at Savoy's four TV stations have suffered since their network-affiliation was switched to the Fox network. Shares of Savoy fell 62.5 cents, to $4, while Silver King rose $2.1875, to $28.

title: Calendar: A Show, Tours And Fairs
description: Futurism of 1939

title: Achilles Wasn't Trojan War's Yuppie
description: To the Editor:

title: South Bronx Board Backs Superintendent
description: Defying an order from Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, a majority of the members of a South Bronx community school board voted to retain the district's new superintendent, whom the Chancellor considers unqualified for the job.

title: Unemployment in Britain Dips to a 5-Year Low
description: British unemployment fell in July to a five-year low. The jobless total fell 24,100, to 2.13 million, taking the unemployment rate to 7.6 percent from 7.7 percent in June. The figure was the lowest since March 1991.

title: DELUXE CONSIDERS SALE OF NONCORE BUSINESSES
description: The Deluxe Corporation, the nation's largest printer of bank checks, said yesterday that it might sell its health-care forms, credit-card processing and other businesses as it moved to focus on more profitable operations like check printing. The company also said that it had formed a joint venture in India to provide electronic payment and fund-transfer systems to banks in that country and in Southeast Asia. Deluxe said it had been talking to prospective buyers for its Colwell division, a health-care forms provider, and Financial Alliance, a credit-card processing unit. Deluxe also said it had hired Merrill Lynch & Company to assess its Deluxe Direct business, which includes its direct-mail, tax services and greeting card divisions.

title: Today's Schedule
Garden Q.&A.
description: Repotting Orchids

title: Giants' Upstate Retreat Brings Team Together
description: Giants quarterback Dave Brown says he thinks this team is closer-knit than any Giants team he has been with. Maybe it is because no one expects much of the team, so it has come together to try to prove people wrong. Maybe it is because training camp was held in Albany this season, putting the players hours away from their homes and forcing them to spend their free time with each other.

title: Joe Cubas Helps Cuban Ballplayers Defect
description: Joe Cubas called a news conference here earlier this week to introduce his latest Cuban defector -- a star 16-year-old pitcher named Osmani Fernandez -- whom Cubas was able, as he put it, ''to pull out'' from under the noses of Cuban security officials.

title: A Master, and Still the Student
description: The alto saxophonist Lee Konitz, who has taken part in or been touched by swing, be-bop, early cool jazz and several varieties of avant-gardism, is still searching out subtle, subcutaneous challenges. Nearly 70 now, he is one of jazz's great saxophone improvisers, though his self-effacing art seems to resist such pronouncements. In an early set on Tuesday night at Smalls, backed by two young musicians -- Ben Monder, a guitarist, and Matt Wilson, a drummer -- Mr. Konitz was the perpetual student, throwing himself into continuous three-way improvisations with no predetermined chord sequence.

title: A Blow to Affirmative Action in Schools
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld the complaint of a white teacher who was laid off in favor of an equally qualified, equally experienced minority colleague. Although the teacher who was retained was the only minority in an otherwise all-white department, the court said that race should not have been a factor in the layoff decision.

title: Acquisition by Grace
description: W. R. Grace & Company said today that it had bought a Mexican maker of can coatings and sealants from Grupo Zapata of Mexico to increase its access to the rapidly growing soft drink market in Latin America. Terms were not disclosed. Bayem, the unit acquired by Grace, has annual sales of about $10 million; it operates a plant near Mexico City that employs 130 people. The shares of W. R. Grace & Company gained $1.375 yesterday, closing at $66.75 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: President Discloses a Project: A Book on His Vision for U.S.
description: In a surprise announcement that ended one of the best kept secrets of his Administration, the White House and Random House disclosed today that President Clinton has written a book about his vision for the future, and that a first printing of 400,000 copies will be shipped to stores next Wednesday.

title: No Headline
description: Baseball

title: David Tudor, 70, Electronic Composer, Dies
description: David Tudor, a composer and performer of avant-garde electronic music who was closely associated with John Cage and who succeeded him as the music director of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company in 1992, died on Tuesday at his home in Tomkins Cove, N.Y. He was 70.

title: Meldrum Resigns Revco Account
description: Meldrum & Fewsmith Communications in Cleveland said yesterday that it had resigned the Revco Drug Stores account after eight and a half years. As a result, the account, with billings estimated at $8 million to $10 million, has been placed in review.

title: Corrections
description: A jazz review on Saturday of a performance by the pianist Geri Allen at the Village Vanguard on Aug. 6 misidentified the composers of the song ''A Beautiful Friendship.'' They are Stanley Styne and Donald Kahn, not Jule Styne and Sammy Cahn.

title: Runway Gunmen, Announcing a Stickup, Loot an Air France Jet
description: In what a crew member compared to a stagecoach holdup, gunmen have robbed a fully loaded Air France airliner at the end of a runway in southern France.

title: Platform Scrutiny
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pitfalls in Home-Care Policies
description: IT sounds indispensable: long-term care insurance that covers domestic help and personal-care services so that frail elderly people can remain in their own homes.

title: Robin Dole Forsakes the Quiet Life, for Now
description: Robin Dole's speech tonight praising the Republican nominee as only a daughter could marked the latest, most visible stop on a campaign trail that began when she was just five and turned up on the stump in a skirt with a homemade elephant patch emblazoned with the pitch, ''I'm for my Daddy -- are you?''

title: Wetteland Is Bristling At Thought of a Hiatus
description: With each bite into a corn muffin and each swig of water, John Wetteland grew more agitated. Even talking about his strained right groin muscle and the possibility of being put on the disabled list seemed to cause him more pain, both mentally and physically.

title: HUMANA INC. (HUM, N)
description: High medical costs and a corporate widened a second-quarter loss for Humana Inc., the company said yesterday.

title: Composers Who Feel Rock's Pull
description: Composers have always subverted the distinctions between the vernacular and the refined. Renaissance masses were built around popular love songs, and just about every major composer from Bach to Mahler drew on rustic dances. Composers in the first half of the 20th century saw jazz as a liberating force. For today's young composers and those entering middle age, the vernacular is rock, and, increasingly, rock's musical moves, instrumentation and attitudes are informing concert works.

title: Charges Result in Loss For Half at BICC Group
description: BICC Group P.L.C. of Britain reported yesterday that it had a first-half loss of $:2 million, or $3.1 million, after its operating profits were wiped out by charges linked to the elimination of 180 jobs in Germany and the writing down of assets.

title: Attacks by Russians Mar Chechen Truce
description: Minutes after the latest cease-fire began in Chechnya yesterday, Russian attack planes fired rockets at a line of refugees who were taking advantage of the announced truce to flee Grozny, capital of the secessionist region. And local Russian military leaders -- contradicting assurances from the Government in Moscow -- denied that a cease-fire had been struck with the Chechen separatists.

title: Muslim and Croatian Leaders Approve Federation for Bosnia
description: Trying to save the Dayton peace accord, Secretary of State Warren Christopher announced today that two Balkan leaders had finally agreed to create a federation to jointly govern Muslims and Croats in half of Bosnia.

title: Big Reinsurers In Merger Deal, Providing Boon To Kohlberg
description: In a consolidation of two giants in the reinsurance industry, Munich Re agreed yesterday to pay $3.3 billion in cash for American Re, tripling the German company's business in the United States.

title: Viktor A. Ambartsumyan, 87, Expert on Formation of Stars
description: Viktor A. Ambartsumyan, an internationally known astrophysicist, died on Monday at the Byurakan Observatory near Yerevan, the capital of Armenia. He was 87 and lived on the grounds of the observatory, which he headed until 1988.

title: All Chatter Opens Some Eyes in Saratoga
description: Kelly Kip, the undefeated star of the 2-year-old class who won the first of three stakes for juveniles at Saratoga, was back in the barn today resting his streak until they run the Hopeful in two weeks. But in his absence, a freshman named All Chatter won the second race in the series, the Saratoga Special, and joined the group of colts already fixing their eyes on distant goals.

title: Fidelity Cut Its Stake in Chrysler Last Month
description: Fidelity Investments cut its holdings of the Chrysler Corporation's shares by more than a third last month, perhaps contributing to a large selloff in Chrysler shares.

title: Saudi Rebels Are Main Suspects In June Bombing of a U.S. Base
description: The Government of Saudi Arabia now believes that native Saudi Islamic militants, including many veterans of the Afghan war, carried out the June 25 bombing that killed 19 American servicemen at a base in Dhahran, Saudi officials said today.

title: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC. (FD,N)
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. lost $27.2 million in the fiscal second quarter, mostly because of costs associated with integrating the Broadway Stores Inc. group into Federated, the company said yesterday.

title: Jersey City Latest on Curfew
description: A curfew is falling over New Jersey's big cities. The Jersey City Council gave preliminary approval yesterday to a law banning youths under 17 from being on the streets after 10:30 P.M. unless accompanied by an adult or on their way to work or school. On Tuesday, Paterson's City Council voted to put a similar curfew on the November ballot. More than 200 New Jersey communities have curfews.

title: No Headline
description: ''They're wonderful creatures, even though they're not overblessed with intelligence. You can't really teach them to do anything, but if you put out food at the same time each night, they can work out where the food is.''

title: Panel Supports Volvo Commercial
description: The National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus ruled yesterday that while some complaints made by BMW of North America about a TV commercial for Volvo Cars of North America had merit, the acceleration test that was the focus of the spot was ''conducted in a reasonable manner.''

title: Why G.O.P. Tolerates Powell and His Message
description: To the Editor:

title: State Weighs In on Sidewalks
description: Perhaps coming soon to a subdivision near you: sidewalks. A state rule now being drafted would require all new housing developments to install sidewalks on both sides of the street. Environmental and community groups have pushed for the rule to be included in the new Residential Site Improvement Standard Regulations. They say more sidewalks mean fewer collisions between cars and pedestrians. A four-month public comment period on the regulations ends today. The Department of Community Affairs is expected to enact the regulations in about two months.

title: MAN HELD IN ROLE IN CROWN HTS. CASE
description: Nearly five years after the violent racial clashes that tore through Crown Heights in Brooklyn, Federal law enforcement officials said yesterday that they had arrested a 43-year-old man whom they described as a prime instigator in the unrest that led to the fatal stabbing of a Hasidic scholar.

title: Paging Company Names 2 Agencies
description: The Arch Communications Group, a paging services provider, said yesterday that it had named the Richards Group in Dallas and Lippincott & Margulies in New York as the first agencies to handle advertising and brand strategy, respectively. Billings have not been determined.

title: Blossoms From Rust in Red Hook
description: WHEN you grow tired of stylish gardens and stylish garden magazines, when you find yourself wanting to set fire to a Smith & Hawken garden bench, then go down to the sea, to Red Hook, Brooklyn.

title: Move to Overturn Gun Ban
description: Gun advocates who have failed in several attempts to overturn New Jersey's 1990 ban on assault weapons are trying again. The Coalition of New Jersey Sportsmen has filed suit in Federal court charging that the ban is unconstitutionally vague and thus open to selective enforcement. Gary J. Needleman, the group's attorney, said the law covers not only 34 specific models but also any other weapons like them. Chuck Davis, a spokesman for the State Attorney General's office, said yesterday that the state is preparing its response to the suit, which was announced by the coalition Tuesday. The group claims more than 300,000 members statewide.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Technology Stocks Rise, Leading Markets Higher

title: U.S. Sets Terms for State to Shift Medicaid to Managed Care
description: New York State's ambitious proposal to move almost all of its 3.5 million Medicaid recipients into managed care plans took a major step forward yesterday as the Federal Government announced the terms under which it would approve the plan. State officials immediately called the conditions generally acceptable, predicting that the plan would be in place by the end of the year.

title: Metro Digest
description: THE CONVENTION

title: In Possible Suit, Prudential and S.E.C. Seek Delay
description: Prudential Securities Inc. and the Securities and Exchange Commission asked today for a one-month extension to respond to a potential lawsuit stemming from a settlement reached between the two parties almost three years ago.

title: Teacher Masters Greens
description: Teaching and playing at Winged Foot Golf Club and Westchester Country Club has helped Bruce Zabriski get a feel for the type of greens golfers struggle with at the Stanwich Club. This week, those greens have caused problems for the vast majority of the players in the first two rounds of the Met Open.

title: Scott Simpkinson, 76, Engineer Who Worked on Space Program
description: Scott H. Simpkinson, an engineer who worked in the United States space program from its birth and finally oversaw the technical safety of its flights, manned and unmanned, died last Thursday at St. Luke's Hospital in Houston. He was 76 and lived in nearby Pasadena.

title: Earnings Increase 34% At Swiss Bank Corp.
description: The Swiss Bank Corporation reported yesterday that it had a 34 percent jump in profits in the first half. Its profit rose to 722 million Swiss francs, or $601 million, from 540 million francs in the first six months of last year.

title: Richard Upton Dies at 81; Put Primary in the Spotlight
description: Richard Upton, the man credited with turning the once sleepy New Hampshire primary into a quadrennial political extravaganza and a make-or-break test for Presidential hopefuls, died on Monday in Concord, N.H. He was 81 and a former speaker of the state's House of Representatives.

title: Hoop It Up: Free Agents, Costly Errors
description: THE National Basketball Association has a salary cap, but nobody puts a cap on Pat Riley's mouth, particularly when he is angry.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption about Speaker Newt Gingrich at the Republican National Convention in some copies yesterday created an erroneous impression about the timing of the photograph. The picture was from earlier in the day, when Mr. Gingrich visited the podium for a rehearsal; it was not taken when he was speaking to the convention Tuesday evening.

title: After Months of Fine-Tuning, Dole Gives Some Final Honing to the Speech of His Career
description: Bob Dole signed off on his acceptance speech this afternoon after almost four months of editing and redrafting and a last-minute scramble for a new ending.

title: Japan's Factory Output Dropped 4.3% in June
description: Japan's industrial production fell 4.3 percent in June from the previous month, in the second-steepest decline this decade, the International Trade and Industry Ministry said yesterday. The decade's largest month-on-month decline was last March, when output fell 4.7 percent. The June figures were revised from a decline of 3.9 percent reported on July 29.

title: As Gaza Airport Expands, Israel's Alarm Grows
description: The uneven Arabic writing spray-painted in black across a bare cement wall reads ''Temporary Airport Entrance,'' with an equally crude arrow indicating a rutted sand track. The few passenger vehicles pulling off the far southern end of the Gaza Strip's main roadway negotiate the route with difficulty, fishtailing to a halt beside the old car seat and tattered umbrella that constitutes the Palestinian police checkpoint.

title: Fund-Raiser Switches Course
description: Assemblyman Joseph Suliga had booked a fund-raiser on board the sightseeing boat Sandy Hook Lady for today. But that was before marine police cited the operators of the Lady, a 63-foot paddle wheel, for discharging its thousand-gallon sewage tank into the Atlantic Highlands harbor last Thursday. So Mr. Suliga, a Democrat from Elizabeth who serves on a commission called the Clean Ocean and Shore Trust, decided against a party aboard the Lady. ''They're polluting the environment that they make their money off,'' he said. He is holding today's event aboard the River Queen, docked in Brielle. ANDY NEWMAN

title: 25 Are Arrested in Protests Over the City's Eviction of Squatters on the Lower East Side
description: One day after the Giuliani administration evicted squatters from three city-owned buildings on the Lower East Side, protesters took to Tompkins Square Park and occupied a nearby building where squatters were evicted two years ago. Twenty-five people were arrested in the two incidents, the police said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GRACE MIRABELLA, the former editor in chief of Vogue and the founder of Mirabella, is taking another turn in the magazine world. She will write a monthly column, ''Speaking of Style,'' for Quest magazine.

title: Back of the Book
description: To the Editor:

title: India Ruefully Takes Stock of 49 Years
description: As India relaxed today on the holiday marking the start of the country's 50th year of independence, a group of old men gathered at a monsoon-stained apartment block here to reminisce about having been ''freedom fighters'' in the struggle that led Britain to end its days of empire in India. And they reflected, for the most part ruefully, on what has become of the India they helped to found.

title: With an Eye for Nature And Its Exquisite Forms
description: As an artist, Titian Ramsay Peale (1799-1885) made all of nature his subject. He could depict the intricate structure of a butterfly's wing, the subtle shadings of a bird's plumage, the glowing insides of a volcanic crater. A gifted youth in a hive of 16 siblings (three of his brothers, Rubens, Rembrandt and Raphaelle Peale, were also painters), he was the youngest son of the celebrated Charles Willson Peale, a portraitist and scientist who founded the nation's first natural history museum, in Philadelphia.

title: King's Ire Brings Hashish Down From Its High
description: On its high mountain perch, the fortress town of Chechaouen is celebrating the bounty of the Moroccan summer. The donkeys hobble through the medieval gates under loads of coriander and onions. The melons are swollen and the olives are getting plump.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Debt and Executive Turmoil Keep Danskin Hobbling
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Martin Pleads No Contest in Cocaine Case
description: The former Dallas Cowboys defensive star HARVEY MARTIN pleaded no contest yesterday to felony cocaine possession in exchange for probation, a fine and participation in a drug treatment program.

title: Hewlett-Packard Names Saatchi Unit
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said yesterday that as expected it had named the San Francisco office of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide to handle its Pavilion line of home multimedia personal computers. The account, with billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million, had been handled by the agency on a project basis since June.

title: . . . And Another Is Indicted
description: A fugitive New Jersey businessman being held in an Italian jail was indicted yesterday on Federal charges that he bribed Defense Department officials to win contracts worth about $400,000. Roger C. Day Jr. of Wantage is fighting extradition from Italy. Federal prosecutors say Mr. Day and his wife, Christine, gave the bribes from 1990 to 1995 to win contracts to supply tools to a military depot. Mrs. Day pleaded guilty to passport fraud in May and has agreed to testify against her husband, United States Attorney Scott Christie said.

title: PC Supplier To Be Sold for $1.5 Billion
description: Masayoshi Son has struck again.

title: Life as Football?
description: To the Editor:

title: KOHLBERG PLANS STAKE IN SPALDING AND EVENFLO
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a majority stake in the Spalding and Evenflo Companies, a maker of sporting goods and infant and juvenile products. Terms were not disclosed. Spalding and Evenflo, based in Tampa, Fla., is part of the Cisneros Group of Caracas, Venezuela. In May, Cisneros said that it was exploring the sale of all or part of the company to concentrate on its telecommunications business. Kohlberg Kravis, the New York buyout firm, said the Cisneros Group and management would continue to hold minority interests in Spalding and Evenflo, which is expected to report sales exceeding $1 billion for its current fiscal year.

title: N.F.L. Training Camp Report
description: Falcons Top Raiders

title: Convention Role Set For Hillary Clinton
description: When the Democratic National Convention opens in her hometown of Chicago later this month, Hillary Rodham Clinton will have a prominent role as a surrogate for President Clinton and will almost certainly address the convention itself.

title: 'Truths' of Hiroshima Justified Dropping Bomb
description: To the Editor:

title: Ancient Objects in Odd Juxtaposition
description: As a miscellany of arresting objects from the distant past, ''Ancient Art From the Shumei Family Collection'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is in a very high class. As a reasoned survey of a particular point of view, on the other hand, it makes very little sense.

title: $25 and Under
description: When Odeon, the classic TriBeCa restaurant, opened 16 years ago, not many people were saying, ''What this neighborhood really needs is a family restaurant that serves good meatloaf.''

title: New Hint of German Rate Cut Leaves Dollar Largely Steady
description: The dollar was steady against most leading currencies yesterday, as comments from German central bank officials reinforced perceptions that the bank might soon lower interest rates.

title: Development of a 200-unit residential hotel for the elderly is set to get under way in Riverdale.
description: IF Jeffrey E. Levine, architect turned builder turned developer, had a motto, it would be: ''Go with the flow.''

title: Zabriski Prevails by 12 Strokes
description: With his background on the PGA Tour, Bruce Zabriski is a fearful sight to the rest of the metropolitan area's premier players when he gets atop the leader board, as he has done in this week's 81st Met Open.

title: A Family Looks in Vain for Answers
description: The family and friends of Nathaniel Levi Gaines Jr., the 25-year-old Yonkers man who prosecutors say was shot in the back by a New York City police officer, said that more than a month after his death, they are still mystified as to why he was killed. To them, he was a quiet, considerate and compassionate man, a Persian Gulf veteran who volunteered at a local community center when he returned home from the war.

title: A Land of Civilities, Achievements and 'Chumley'
description: NOTES FROM A SMALL ISLAND

title: Is It Early For a Movie On Gooden?
description: GRANDIOSITY. The word is used at addiction treatment centers. It describes the giddy state of walking with your nose in the air, and not noticing the hole in the sidewalk.

title: People
description: * Ron Lawner, vice chairman at Arnold Communications, Boston, was named a managing partner; he continues as chief creative officer. Tom Lawson, a managing partner, was named to the additional position of chief operating officer, assuming responsibilities from Rick Britton, who was named a partner and also becomes director for technology and information resources, a new position. Two other executives also become managing partners: Dick Emerson, executive vice president and chief operating officer for integrated marketing, and Fran Kelly, executive vice president and chief marketing officer.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALLEGHENY LUDLUM CORP., Pittsburgh, a maker of stainless steel, said its acquisition of Teledyne Inc. for $2.25 billion in stock was approved by shareholders of both companies. The combined company, Allegheny Teledyne Inc., is expected to have more than $4 billion in annual sales.

title: Pitcher Is Convicted of Murder
description: JULIO MACHADO, a pitcher who reached the major league with the Mets in 1989 and spent two seasons with Milwaukee after being traded to the Brewers in 1990, has been convicted of murder and sentenced to 12 years in prison, authorities in Venezuela said yesterday.

title: No Complications
description: To the Editor:

title: Flute in the Foreground, By Design and Virtuosity
description: With typical profligacy, the Mostly Mozart Festival presented not only the superstar flutist James Galway, on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, but also two other soloists in the main concert, and a third in recital. Still, it was Mr. Galway who made the program memorable, with his deft virtuosity in Bach's Second Orchestral Suite and his haunting way with a tune in Mozart's Concerto for Flute and Harp.

title: GIULIANI DEMANDS MORE BUDGET CUTS
description: Only a month and a half after his current budget took effect, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ordered $500 million in new cuts yesterday, saddling virtually all city agencies with another round of sharp reductions.

title: The Jets' New Gunning Game Should Help Their Running Game
description: Last year the Jets started off with all the makings of a team devoted to a power running game. They signed fullback Brad Baxter to a long-term deal and selected tight end Kyle Brady in the first round of the draft. Unfortunately, what started out as a grand plan materialized as a monumental disaster.

title: About Actors Acting the Marx Brothers Acting
description: Even in a culture where sequels, spinoffs, low-cal substitutes and fat-free imitations are commonplace, you still might feel queasy as you watch the American Jewish Theater's revival of ''The Cocoanuts,'' in which three actors impersonate the major Marx Brothers for two hours. This isn't chutzpah, which might be bracing; it's a second-rate idea whose time has apparently come.

title: When Golf Is Life And Life a Game
description: GOLF: It's a four-letter word, and definitely not one associated with sex appeal. Yet Ron Shelton accomplishes the unimaginable with his bright, stylish, ridiculously alluring new film. Hard as it may be to believe, Mr. Shelton's ''Tin Cup'' is a flirty, funny comedy set right there on the links, with all the right raffish echoes of his earlier ''Bull Durham.'' ''Tin Cup'' has such unexpected flair that the game takes on new cachet, to the point where even golf clothes look good.

title: Brash Capitalist Enters Kremlin's Inner Circle
description: Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin announced a new Cabinet today that looked remarkably like the old one -- with one striking exception.

title: F.B.I. Hoping for Little Clue in Big Ocean
description: The chief Federal law-enforcement official who is investigating the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 said yesterday that the piece of evidence needed to prove that a criminal act brought down the plane is probably no larger than a football and lost in the sand at the bottom of the Atlantic.

title: Banking on the Appeal of an Adopted Son
description: Mark Twain was born in the small, backwater town of Florida, Mo., grew up in nearby Hannibal, and achieved fame writing about life on the Mississippi River. A world traveler, lecturing from London to Sydney, he insisted that he be buried in Elmira, N.Y., where he and his wife, Olivia, spent many summers.

title: Fastpitch Event Has 12 Olympic Medalists
description: Twelve of the 15 members of the gold medal-winning United States Olympic softball team will be among more than 300 players participating in the national women's fastpitch tournament, which begins here Friday.

title: Amputee Takes Sheer Speed and Will to Atlanta
description: Todd Schaffhauser sat in the far lane of the track and stretched, pretending not to hear the whispers of the joggers as they went by. As he does every evening, he sat quietly, focusing on the day's workout.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Substitute

title: Treasury Securities Sag in Price
description: Prices of Treasury securities sagged under a combination of manufacturing and labor data yesterday. While there was strength in the numbers, the reports did not indicate that the manufacturing sector was about to race ahead in the third quarter, as some investors fear.

title: Sarajevo's Airport, Once a Symbol of City's Isolation, Reopens
description: The airport here closed to civilian air traffic for good in 1992, but for a year it remained the only way out. Thousands of people, some carrying luggage, risked their lives in crazed sprints across the runway to a Muslim-held suburb on the other side. Dozens were killed by sniper fire. Then Sarajevans dug a tunnel beneath the runway, another route out, but not an easy one.

title: Versed in Postwar Piano And in the Building of Tunes
description: The young pianist Eric Reed plays with many styles, but the most frequently displayed is one with ''classic'' branded all over it. It's the widely accessible strain of postwar piano history that runs through Nat (King) Cole, Red Garland and Ahmad Jamal: a tidy, quiescent swing with regular space-breaks, at times so evenly mathematical that a listener can anticipate them four bars in advance.

title: A Hotel, San Diego, 9:10 P.M.: The Moment of Bob Dole's Life
description: When the big moment came, there was Bob Dole, playing Presidential hopeful as couch potato. All he needed was a remote control.

title: Sears to Pay $308 Million For Hardware Store Chain
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company agreed yesterday to buy the Orchard Supply Hardware Stores Corporation for $308 million as part of a rapid national expansion of its chain of hardware stores.

title: Corsica's Tourism, Stunted by Strife, Puts Hope in French Aid
description: A car bomb, presumed to be part of a long-running vendetta among groups that want independence for this French Mediterranean island, has strangled the summer tourist season most Corsicans depend on to earn a living, business leaders, hotel keepers and officials here say.

title: Deputy Mayor, a Key Adviser to Giuliani, Resigns to Join Company
description: Peter J. Powers, who has been Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's best friend since high school and his top aide since 1994, announced yesterday that he would leave City Hall at the end of the month to return to private business and would eventually manage the Mayor's re-election campaign.

title: Phone Rings Nonstop for Selig
description: The telephone in Bud Selig's office rang busy yesterday, offering the best indication that a new labor agreement between the owners and the players will come to fruition.

title: Estrogen May Reduce Alzheimer's Risk in Women, Study Says
description: Taking estrogen after menopause may reduce a woman's risk of developing Alzheimer's or delay onset of the disease, scientists said yesterday.

title: Recognition Steers Clear Of the Giants' Calloway
description: Chris Calloway has heard it, oh, dozens of times. He's one of the more underrated wide receivers in the league. He's not that fast. He's not that big. Still, somehow, he gets open and makes plays.

title: Hanson Reports Tripling of Profits
description: The British conglomerate Hanson P.L.C. said yesterday that its profits had almost tripled to more than $1 billion in its third quarter, helped by the sale of several of its businesses. The company, in the midst of a four-way breakup, said profits for the three months ended June 30 soared to $:713 million ($1.1 billion) from $:252 million. The company said sales for the third quarter were up 11 percent, to $:3 billion ($4.6 billion).

title: Line of Work, Ma'am? Chief Judge
description: What was striking about the woman in the patent leather pumps, double-breasted blazer and impeccable coif who reported for jury duty yesterday at the Manhattan Criminal Courts was not how obviously she stood out, but how she actually -- well, almost -- blended in.

title: Blood And Guts, And Blood, And Blood
description: Vampires aren't the only things in ''Bordello of Blood'' that can't stand up to daylight. Neither can the plot.

title: Insurers' Next Scam
description: To the Editor:

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Mr. Wrong

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-15

title: Times Square a la Mode
description: SOME days it seems that everybody in Times Square is speaking German, or Spanish, or Japanese or any of a dozen other languages. As a tourist destination, Times Square is flourishing again.

title: Steven D. Gold Is Dead at 52; Expert on Government Financing
description: Steven D. Gold, an authority on state and local government financing, died on Wednesday night at George Washington University Hospital Center in Washington. He was 52 and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Bob Dole's Mixed Message
description: In his acceptance speech last night, Bob Dole demonstrated both the strengths and the weaknesses of his candidacy. It was moving to hear him describe his memories of the past, but he faltered in elaborating a vision for the future. Once again, he remained unable to integrate his newly adopted tax-cut plan into his own traditional economic views.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: AT&T to Seek Wide Arbitration on GTE
description: AT&T said yesterday that it would seek arbitration in 20 states to allow it to offer local phone service in areas served by the GTE Corporation

title: Hotel Lets Out-of-Towners Mix With Downtowners
description: ''HAVE you been to New York before?'' asked the woman taking reservations for the SoHo Grand Hotel, the new hotel at 310 West Broadway, below Grand Street. I mumbled something noncommittal into the phone. ''Well,'' she continued brightly, ''we are located in the heart of SoHo, accessible to Greenwich Village, Chinatown, Little Italy and Wall Street. Right in the neighborhood, there are 248 art galleries, 14 bookstores, 87 restaurants, 5 museums and a whole host of other things you can do to entertain yourself.''

title: No Headline
description: ''Let me be the bridge to a time of tranquillity, faith and confidence in action. And to those who say it was never so, that America has not been better, I say, you're wrong: And I know, because I was there. And I have seen it. And I remember.''

title: GENERAL MOTORS DECISION ON PLANT TO BOLSTER EARNINGS
description: The General Motors Corporation's third-quarter earnings will increase by $250 million because of the company's decision to keep open an assembly plant in Wilmington, Del. G.M. said last week that the plant would build a new midsize Saturn car beginning about 1999. The plant had been scheduled to close, and the company had set aside money for costs related to the shutdown. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing this week, G.M. said it would remove $250 million from its plant-closing reserve fund and apply it to the bottom line because of the new production plans for Wilmington.

title: Top New York Judge Has Her Day in Court
description: New York State's Chief Judge, Judith S. Kaye, turned up at 8:30 A.M. yesterday in the jury assembly room at Manhattan Criminal Courts in lower Manhattan. But she was not there to preside. Along with nearly 200 other people who had been summoned, she was there to serve on the jury, and Judge Kaye submitted eagerly to that long-maligned exercise of civic duty that so many fellow citizens have learned to dread.

title: Ike's Nixon Remark: Inept, Not Venomous
description: To the Editor:

title: Christopher in Sarajevo, Pressing the Flesh
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher returned today to the ravaged capital of Bosnia, stumping to encourage citizens and candidates to take part in elections that he concedes will be far from perfect but are a vital first step toward recreating a unified nation.

title: FUSION TO SELL ULTRAVIOLET BUSINESS TO FAIREY GROUP
description: Hoping to burnish its image with investors by concentrating on semiconductor-making tools, the Fusion Systems Corporation agreed yesterday to sell an unrelated business to the Fairey Group P.L.C. of Britain for $126 million in cash. Fairey, a maker of electronic and other equipment, would buy Fusion's ultraviolet curing systems unit. The unit's technology is used to dry photosensitive coatings and adhesives. Fusion said the division, which had sales of $51.1 million last year, had been undervalued by investors. Shares of Fusion, based in Rockville, Md., rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $19.625.

title: School Settles Bias Case On Girls' Sports Programs
description: A New Jersey high school that last year was accused of discriminating against female athletes has reached a settlement with the Federal Department of Education to give girls' sports as much attention, support and money as boys' sports.

title: Fugitive Suspect Caught . . .
description: A man on trial for attempted murder who jumped bail on the last day of his case was found yesterday hiding under a pile of laundry in an apartment in Jamaica, Queens, officials said. The fugitive, Mauricio Aceves, was tracked down by a pair of professional bounty hunters for the company that issued his $150,000 bail bond. In his absence, a Superior Court jury in Hackensack had convicted him Wednesday of repeatedly stabbing Gabriella Rojas Sanchez in June 1994 along the Garden State Parkway in Paramus, said James P. Kimball, an assistant Bergen County prosecutor. Mr. Aceves, 26, an illegal immigrant from Mexico, faces up to 25 years in prison at his September sentencing.

title: Teen-Agers Charged In Rapes at Park Pool
description: Two Harlem teen-agers were arrested yesterday in a double rape and robbery at a swimming pool in Marcus Garvey Park last week, the police said.

title: Another agency creates ads for McDonald's adult burger, raising eyebrows on Madison Avenue.
description: A SECOND agency is suddenly taking a bite out of the Arch Deluxe.

title: Officers Unite in Prayer For Wounded Colleague
description: As they struggled to come to grips yesterday with the shooting of their colleague, 70 police officers packed a small Roman Catholic church across the street from the 33d Precinct station house to pray for the speedy recovery of Officer Francis Latimer.

title: U.S. World Cup Team Taps Leetch as Captain
description: On his National Hockey League team, the Rangers, Brian Leetch wears only the A, for alternate captain, on the front of his jersey. The C, for captain, belongs to Mark Messier, and probably will for a while.

title: Runaway Girl Is Found Dead After Torture, Police Say
description: A 13-year-old who ran away from her Long Island home in March has been found slain in Easton, Pa., where she had taken a new name and lied about her age but could not flee her troubled past, the authorities said yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: SOUTHMARK CORP., Dallas, said Glen Adams had resigned as its chairman and chief executive as the company continues to liquidate under a reorganization plan. The company named Charles Brewer, executive vice president, as president and chief executive and a director.

title: A Last Blast Of the Whistle Coming Soon
description: This city was so charmed by its old train depot, and so enchanted by the mystique of locomotive travel, that it mounted a $1.5 million campaign to buy the station.

title: Divers Retrieve 4th Engine of Jet
description: Divers in the effort to recover wreckage from T.W.A. Flight 800 yesterday retrieved the fourth and last engine from the Boeing 747. Some turbine blades were missing, but the damage may have been caused by the impact. Divers also brought up the bodies of two more victims, putting the total at 201, with 29 still missing.

title: So Beautiful, So Relaxing, So Far From San Diego
description: Here in the crystalline splendors of the Tetons, President Clinton has played many roles on his vacation this week: golfer, hiker, horseback rider, armchair astronomer. But none has he played with more apparent relish or conviction than that of studied ignorer of the Republican National Convention.

title: New Jobs for Two Agency Executives
description: Corporate communications executives at two agencies are getting new assignments.

title: DOLE, 'THE MOST OPTIMISTIC MAN IN AMERICA,' VOWS RETURN TO NATION'S ENDURING VALUES
description: Bob Dole accepted the Republican Party's Presidential nomination tonight and sought to turn his age and his temperament into virtues by urging Americans to embrace him as ''a fighter by principle and the most optimistic man in America.''

title: Pretax Profit Rises 31% at Ericsson
description: LM Ericsson A.B., the Swedish telecommunications company, said yesterday that its pretax profit rose 31 percent in the first half of the year on continued growth in demand for mobile telephones. The pretax profit totaled 4.22 billion kronor ($634 million) in the first six months of 1996, up from 3.22 billion kronor in the corresponding period last year. First-half sales climbed 16 percent, to 50 billion kronor ($7.51 billion) from 43.2 billion kronor.

title: Two Women With a Strong Bond: Fragile Psyches
description: It's no surprise that when actors turn to directing they usually get good performances. But few of them also have the visual grace and subtlety that Kevin Bacon brings to ''Losing Chase,'' an exquisite small film about a friendship between two women who have more in common than they know.

title: Democrats Previewing a Dole Administration
description: This is a new 30-second advertisement being broadcast nationally on behalf of the Clinton/Gore '96 campaign.

title: Home Video
description: With the flow of big movies down to a trickle, August hasn't been an auspicious month for video rental. This week, in fact, new titles that have been shown in theaters are few and far between, ranging from a small, well-received Chinese film, ''The Day the Sun Turned Cold,'' to ''Barb Wire,'' an action vehicle for Pamela Anderson Lee, the ''Baywatch'' star.

title: Aesop's Party
description: If Bob Dole is elected President, in what ways would he and a Republican Congress really change public policy? The party platform gives us important clues.

title: Australian Frustrates And Upsets Courier
description: At the age of 19, Mark Philippoussis already carries the pressure of being the next Australian superstar on the tennis court.

title: For Children
description: 'Playday'

title: Americans Are Still Voting for J.F.K.
description: WHY make do with just Bill Clinton and Bob Dole? If Americans could pick a President, any President, which one would they choose to run the country today?

title: So Little to Report, So Little to Watch
description: By fashioning a political convention that is a virtual news-free zone and exhibits less conflict than an episode of ''Gilligan's Island,'' Republicans believe they produced the perfect television show.

title: Quilts That Cover a Span of Cultural History, Not Just Beds
description: Think of Jasper Johns's paintings of the American flag from the mid-1950's, their stroke-by-stroke encaustic surfaces as meticulous as stitch work, the very opposite of Abstract Expressionism's gestural largess. They turn a celebratory public icon into an ambiguous cold war emblem that sucks in energy like a black hole.

title: Park Sprayed for Disease-Bearing Mosquitoes
description: Suffolk County officials have closed a park in Yaphank and begun aerial and ground spraying of insecticide after mosquitoes there were found to be infected with Eastern equine encephalitis, a virus that can cause paralysis in humans.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Art in Review
description: Marc Wilkins

title: Sylvan Levin, 93; Championed Music In Philadelphia
description: Sylvan Levin, a pianist and conductor who served as Leopold Stokowski's associate at the Philadelphia Orchestra and the New York City Symphony, died on Saturday at his home in Great Neck, L.I. He was 93.

title: Lendl's Swing Not Confined to Tennis
description: When he was younger, IVAN LENDL once dismissed golf as a ''pseudosport for retired folks.'' Now the former tennis star is a 2-handicap golfer, and yesterday he was a wild-card entry in the Czech Open, a European PGA event.

title: Public Figure, Private Person: The Nominee Is Ever Reserved
description: Bill Clinton arrived on the national scene four years ago with so many self-described soul mates that a new acronym entered the American lexicon. Mr. Clinton's innumerable intimates became known collectively as F.O.B.'s, or Friends of Bill.

title: BASF to Sell Its Tape Division
description: The German chemical conglomerate BASF is getting out of the video and audio tape production business and reducing its stake in a mining company, BASF officials said yesterday. The moves are part of the effort to concentrate on core businesses in chemicals, pharmaceuticals, plastics and crop protection.

title: Soured Cyclist Explains Early Exit From Atlanta
description: Most athletes would have done anything under the sun to participate in this summer's Olympics. But not Rebecca Twigg. On the night of July 29, the six-time world champion cyclist left Atlanta even though she was scheduled to compete in the individual time trial five days later.

title: Ex-Partner Of Clintons Offers to Aid Investigation
description: James B. McDougal, a partner with President and Mrs. Clinton in the Whitewater real estate development, has offered to assist investigators from the Whitewater independent counsel's office in exchange for leniency in his sentencing on fraud and conspiracy charges, lawyers involved in the investigation said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economy's Growth Slows As Output Gains Just 0.1%

title: Bob Dole's Life, the Movie: No Frills, and a Bit Tired
description: ''The folks in Hollywood will be happy to know that I finally saw a movie I like,'' Bob Dole said at the start of his acceptance speech, referring to the little biographical film that was meant to introduce him.

title: Same Charge, New Suspect, Five Years After Murder
description: When law enforcement officials announced the arrest of the man they called ''the key person'' in inciting racial unrest in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, in 1991, they described the suspect as a sturdily built bald black man who had been identified from television video footage.

title: Kenny Walker Sentenced to 1997 Jail Term
description: A judge in Lexington, Ky., gave the former Knick KENNY WALKER a seven-day jail sentence, but agreed to allow him to serve the time when he returns from playing professionally in Japan.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOAN DIDION, the author, will go to the MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, N.H., this weekend to receive the prestigious Edward MacDowell Medal for outstanding contributions to the arts.

title: Chechen Rebel Leader Savors Triumph in a Shattered City
description: It takes less than two hours to find the most wanted man in Russia. Shamil Basayev spends most of his time these days in a bunker the size of a jail cell, but more heavily guarded, only a few hundred yards from the center of the nearly demolished city he has just seized from the Russian Army.

title: Mets Enjoying the Scenery in Mexico
description: If you didn't know any better, you would have thought the Mets were taking a siesta, going on break from the rigors of a major league baseball season to enjoy a resort-like setting. John Franco, Todd Hundley, Doug Henry and a few other players sat around a lounge table with bottles of Corona coming one after another.

title: Ban on Political E-Mail
description: The American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey urged Princeton University yesterday to reverse its ban on discussion of political campaigns on its computer system. ''Especially in an election year, you don't want to censor students' ability to communicate and obtain information on political issues,'' said Ann Beeson, a lawyer with the A.C.L.U.

title: How Baseball Becomes An Irrational Pastime
description: In the harrowing early scenes of ''The Fan,'' Robert De Niro burrows so deeply into the soul of Gil Renard, an unstable baseball nut whose life is coming apart, that you share his panic and helpless fury, even while loathing him for the emotionally stunted bully that he is. These unnerving scenes, in which Gil is fired from his job as a salesman of hunting knives and his bitter ex-wife obtains a court order barring him from seeing his young son, are directed by Tony Scott in a style that hurls Gil's humiliations in your face like pitchers of ice water.

title: Delayed Approval
description: To the Editor:

title: Carramerica Expansion
description: Carramerica Realty has bought properties in Austin, Tex., for $107 million, operating partnership units and the assumption of debt.

title: Corporate Receptions Provide Lawmakers With Loophole in Ethics Rules
description: No self-respecting, ethics-rules-abiding member of Congress at the Republican Convention here would be caught accepting a fancy restaurant meal in the company of a lobbyist.

title: Swiss Prosecutor Investigates CS Holding
description: Zurich's prosecutor for economic crime said yesterday that he had begun an investigation into suspected insider trading in shares of CS Holding, the Swiss banking company, before it announced revamping plans in July. The prosecutor, Christian Weber, said a preliminary investigation had strengthened suspicions that investors had cashed in on advance knowledge of the revamping.

title: Bets on a drop in Medaphis stock zoom before the company's warning of an earnings loss.
description: THE stock market apparently was stunned when the Medaphis Corporation, a medical information company, disclosed after trading ended Wednesday that it would report a loss. But trading in the options market makes it appear that someone had advance knowledge that problems were on the horizon.

title: George Kolstad, 76; Managed Research In Nuclear Physics
description: George Andrew Kolstad, who launched and managed Federal research programs in nuclear physics, applied mathematics and geosciences, died on Aug. 7 at Johns Hopkins University Hospital in Baltimore. He was 76 and lived in Laytonsville, Md.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about people who complain about airport noise in New York City misstated where Bill Mulcahy, the founder of an anti-noise group, was standing. He was in a street on the Rockaway peninsula in Queens, not in his yard.

title: Dreaming of Gangsters In a Hotbed of Jazz
description: Robert Altman's buoyant film ''Kansas City'' has a fine time playing with the notion that the gangster movies Hollywood cranked out by the dozen in the early 1930's exerted the same romantic tug on America that gangsta rap does today. For footloose rebels like the film's central character, Blondie O'Hara (Jennifer Jason Leigh), dazzled by celluloid fantasies of gun molls fiercely clinging to their outlaw boyfriends, they codified an attitude of sneering defiance and made antisocial behavior look glamorous.

title: THE CONVENTION
description: Parties for Lawmakers

title: The Future Is Now For Rivera As Closer
description: The ninth inning arrived in Chicago on Wednesday and Mariano Rivera was not asked to give the baseball back. Instead of retreating to the dugout in favor of John Wetteland, Rivera was called upon to save the tense game for the Yankees against the White Sox, and he adeptly secured the 3-1 victory. Get used to this new scenario.

title: If Elvis Is Alive, He'll Be Eating This Up
description: Been longing for the recipe for fried peanut butter-and-banana sandwiches? Here it is, along with tributes to barbecue pizza (''It tastes better than it looks,'' says its inventor), banana pudding, cheeseburgers, hot dogs with sauerkraut and the other mouth-waterers that sustained Elvis Presley through his life and no doubt contributed to his early death 19 years ago today. ''He liked his food real rich,'' his cook of many years recalls, and he liked it at all hours.

title: Wanted In Vietnam: Tourists Who Spend
description: Some people say the government is destroying this charming seaside town with gentrification in order to save it.

title: Corrections
description: The Key Rates table on the Credit Markets page of Business Day yesterday misstated two rates from Wednesday. The yield on the 10-year Treasury bond was 6.56 percent, not 6.44 percent, and the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond was 6.78 percent, not 6.56 percent.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PETER DUCHIN has played for every President since John F. Kennedy, so it will be no surprise to see him leading the band on Sunday at a party to celebrate President Clinton's 50th birthday at the Waldorf-Astoria. The dinner, for 700 guests, will follow a gala show at Radio City Music Hall, at which Tony Bennett, Aretha Franklin, Kenny Rogers and Jon Bon Jovi, among others, will entertain. Both events, as well as a reception at the Sheraton New York, are fund-raisers for Democratic candidates. The President's birthday is on Monday.

title: The Spoken Word
description: A DIFFERENT LIGHT BOOKSTORE, 151 West 19th Street, Chelsea. ''Surface Tension: Love, Sex and Politics Between Lesbians and Straight Women,'' a book edited by Meg Daly, will be discussed by the Social Activities for Lesbians Book Group. Sunday at 1 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 989-4850.

title: Dole Presents the Future As Tale of Two Candidates
description: In Bob Dole's acceptance speech tonight, two characters sprang forth larger than life.

title: Hewlett Stock Tumbles as Earnings Fall Despite Alert
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, confirming an earlier warning of bad financial news, reported a 26 percent decline in its fiscal third-quarter earnings today.

title: Roenick Bid Has 'Hit a Wall'
description: General Manager Mike Milbury would neither confirm nor deny it. But a highly placed individual in the Islanders organization said yesterday that Milbury was told not to tender an offer sheet to Jeremy Roenick. That appears to leave a trade as the only avenue Milbury has to acquire the restricted free agent from the Chicago Blackhawks.

title: Stephan Kuttner, 89, a Scholar Who Traced the Origin of Law
description: Stephan George Kuttner, a Catholic scholar, author, lawyer and authority on legal history and medieval canon law, died on Monday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 89.

title: The Hobbled Mariners Are Trying to Dig Their Way Out of a Hole
description: Seeking some positive element from a perfectly disastrous nine days in the discomfort of home, the Seattle Mariners could claim they were only trying to position themselves for a run at the division championship from a more familiar spot.

title: Gunman Escapes After Shootout That Critically Injures Officer
description: A New York City police officer pursuing a stolen livery car through Washington Heights was shot in the head and critically wounded yesterday by the driver, who left the car and ambushed the officer and his partner as they drove around a corner, the police said.

title: Don't Rush to Demonize Managed Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Fidelity Seeks to Insure Its Money Market Funds
description: Fidelity Investments has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to set up an affiliated insurance company to guarantee its money market mutual funds against certain losses of up to $100 million.

title: Inside Photography
description: By selling his work on Manhattan streets, a photographer dares the elements, self-appointed critics, doubters and, occasionally, thieves. But he also knows that the street can have its rewards.

title: After 50 Years, German Court Exonerates Anti-Hitler Pastor
description: In a ruling seen by many Germans as righting one of the great wrongs of postwar history, a Berlin court has formally exonerated Dietrich Bonhoeffer, a Lutheran theologian who joined the resistance against Hitler and was executed for his activities in the closing days of World War II.

title: Restaurants
description: What could a restaurant possibly offer that would be worth $150 a person?

title: U.S. Goalie Goes to England's Top Division
description: The United States goalkeeper KASEY KELLER moved up to England's Premier League yesterday when Leicester City acquired his contract from second division Millwall for $1.39 million.

title: Does Williams's Father Know Best?
description: She has two hands on the backhand, and her father has two hands on the calendar. Venus Williams drops in just five weeks out of the year -- with her braces, her beads and her books -- eager to test-drive the women's tennis tour. This particular week, she got the Maserati (Steffi Graf), but somehow never had to assume the crash position.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Day the Sun Turned Cold

title: Footnotes Find a Successor in Hot Links
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Marriages Whose Magic Has Become Misery
description: ''The Wife,'' Tom Noonan's bleakly funny evisceration of modern marriage, is not a film to gladden the hearts of young lovers looking forward to decades of cuddly connubial oneness. The film, which originated two years ago as a theatrical workshop under the title ''Wifey,'' takes roughly the same view of the institution as Edward Albee's ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' Over a long, booze-soaked evening, two unhappy couples, both childless and in their 40's, strip their marriages bare until the floor is littered with quivering heaps of emotional wreckage.

title: Ideals and Grit, and a Vast Imponderable
description: It is hard to say what more the Republicans could have done here.

title: In Playground of Rich, Clock Is Ticking for a Camp That Withstood Time
description: For as long as people can remember, there have always been songs on summer nights filtering through the trees from the camp at continent's end. Today, the children, from Japan to New York, gathered as always to get a four-week imprint of the Pacific Northwest on their souls, are singing a Camp Nor'wester classic.

title: True, False or Fog? Speeches Are All of the Above
description: In her keynote address to the Republican National Convention on Tuesday night, Representative Susan Molinari told of ''a grandmother in St. Louis who was hit hard by Bill Clinton's tax increase on Social Security benefits.''

title: Dole Follows in Footsteps of Wife, Who Stars Again
description: Bob Dole took his place today before another lectern, in another hotel ballroom, at another luncheon, before another audience of Republicans, and did something completely different: He abandoned his microphone.

title: Art in Review
description: 'On/In/Through'

title: Dole's Budget Fiction
description: ''I want a balanced budget by 2002,'' said Bob Dole. This was the new Bob Dole. He was exuberant, riding the bounce that had come with the addition of Jack Kemp to the ticket.

title: The Constancy Gap
description: A couple of days before the Republican Convention, I arrived with my undecided vote jingling in my pocket. I was getting a little impatient to throw it into the struggle. A week later I made my decision -- to leave it resting for awhile longer right there in my pocket.

title: Fierce Competition for the Scraps
description: ''They cheated again!'' raged Bob Furnad, CNN's senior executive producer, as one of about 60 television screens in front of him -- the one marked NBC -- blossomed with the image of Maria Shriver interviewing Elizabeth Dole.

title: Eagle's Killer Is Sought
description: The state is offering a $5,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of whoever shot a bald eagle that was found on Saturday in Cumberland County. The eagle, an 11-year-old male, was found wounded by a road in Greenwich Township and died the next day. The eagles are endangered in New Jersey; the bird was one of 56 imported from Canada in the 1980's to revive the state's nearly extinct population, which stood at 13 nesting pairs at last count. Killing an endangered species carries penalties of up to $25,000.

title: Sometimes, the Law Rhymes
description: The parties in a lawsuit over pay-per-view broadcasts received an unusual decision yesterday from Judge Nicholas H. Politan of Federal District Court: It rhymed. All four pages of it. Judge Politan's ruling rejected a request by Passaic County bar owners to dismiss charges of illegally showing a boxing match. The bar owners cited the refusal by an investigator, Jimmie Mesis, to turn over tapes from his inquiry. The judge rejected that claim in cadences that appeared to have been influenced by the eminent jurist Dr. Seuss. His ruling ended: ''That Mesis shall testify, the court does not doubt/ And the truth, by the jury, shall be fully made out./The jury will know if there's something to hide;/ Accordingly, motion for sanctions denied.'' ANDY NEWMAN

title: Newark to Fertilize Ohio
description: Farmers in Ohio may nourish their fields with sludge from New Jersey's largest sewage treatment plant, Ohio's Environmental Protection Agency ruled yesterday. The agency granted a permit to Wheelabrator Clean Water Systems of Illinois to truck 50,000 tons of sterilized sludge a year from the Passaic Valley Sewerage Commission plant in Newark to Ohio for use as fertilizer. Until now, the plant has sent the waste of 1.3 million residents of Bergen, Essex, Hudson and Passaic counties to landfills in Texas, Illinois and Ohio.

title: Quality Television for Children
description: Children's television may finally improve in quality now that the Federal Communications Commission has unanimously adopted a rule requiring broadcasters to provide three hours of educational programs for children each week. Broadcasters' acceptance of the requirement ends their two-year stalemate with Government officials seeking to fulfill the promise of legislation passed in 1990. The agreement resulted partly from pressure from the White House, which hopes to identify itself with family values in the Presidential campaign.

title: Speech Writer Quit in Huff Over Rewrite, An Aide Says
description: The question is: did he leave angry, or did he just leave?

title: Former Hearst Executive Wins Bidding for Petersen Publishing
description: After several months of hotly contested bidding, a former president of Hearst Magazines won an auction for the Petersen Publishing Company yesterday.

title: Richard B. Lillich, 63, Professor And Expert on International Law
description: Prof. Richard Bonnot Lillich, an authority on international law, particularly in the field of human rights and the adjudication of international claims, died on Aug. 3 at his farm in Charlottesville, Va. He was 63.

title: Metro Digest
description: THE CONVENTION

title: Art in Review
description: 'Different Sides'

title: Saks Narrows Loss Beyond Forecasts
description: Saks Holdings Inc. said yesterday that its loss narrowed in the fiscal second quarter, to less than Wall Street analysts had estimated, on better-than-expected sales.

title: A Viacom Unit In Station Swap
description: Paramount Stations Group, a unit of Viacom Inc., has agreed to acquire WTOG, a station in Tampa, Fla., that is affiliated with Paramount's network UPN, in exchange for the NBC affiliates WNYT in Albany and WHEC in Rochester.

title: INSIDE
description: Talk of Whitewater Deal

title: Making Up the Law
description: The high-profile conviction of Mark S. Ferber, a former whiz kid of municipal finance, should cause concern among everyone who cares about civil liberties.

title: Mr. Christopher's Balkan Mission
description: In his trip to Geneva and Sarajevo this week, Secretary of State Warren Christopher displayed the kind of firm diplomacy that will be needed as Bosnia moves toward critical elections. The vote and its aftermath will go far to determine whether the Dayton peace agreement succeeds.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and headline yesterday about a Federal judge's decision in the Oklahoma City bombing case misstated the scope of the ruling. Judge Richard P. Matsch ruled that statements made to Federal agents by one defendant, Terry L. Nichols, cannot be used as evidence against his co-defendant, Timothy J. McVeigh. But the judge denied a defense motion to bar the statements altogether, saying the prosecution may try to use Mr. Nichols's statements against himself.

title: Judge Backs Order Barring Religious-School Vouchers
description: A Circuit Court judge today upheld an injunction that bars Wisconsin from expanding the Milwaukee school voucher program to allow low-income inner-city students to attend religious schools at public expense. This will be the second school year that the plan has been halted.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Aug. 4 with an article about nightclubs in New York City misstated the circumstances of a group of motorcyclists outside Irving Plaza, a Manhattan club. The motorcyclists were not observed leaving the club; according to one of Irving Plaza's owners, Andrew Rasiej, they had not been in the club.

title: Hors d'Oeuvres Heated With Spices
description: SUMMER tidbits to accompany a drink can be anything from a few peanuts, carrot sticks or a dip to elaborate hot hors d'oeuvres. But hot does not have to connote temperature.

title: DU PONT FINANCE CHIEF MOVES TO TOP JOB AT SCHULLER
description: The chief financial officer at E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, Charles L. Henry, will leave his job at Du Pont, the nation's largest chemical company, to take the top spot at the Schuller Corporation, the companies said yesterday. The 55-year-old Mr. Henry was named chairman, president and chief executive of Schuller. That company, a building products concern that is based in Denver, changed its name from the Manville Corporation in March. It had 1995 sales of $1.4 billion. Mr. Henry is scheduled to assume his post on Sept. 9; Du Pont said it would name a new chief financial officer soon.

title: Convention Summary
description: DOLE'S RECURRING THEMES

title: Indonesia Plans War Games to Caution China
description: SINGAPORE  A large-scale Indonesian military exercise in the South China Sea next month is intended to warn Beijing that Jakarta will strongly resist any Chinese attempt to assert control over a huge natural gas project being developed by Indonesian and U.S. companies, analysts said Thursday.

title: COMPANY PLANS A $22.4 MILLION CHARGE
description: The Raytheon Company, based in Lexington, Mass., said yesterday that it would take an after-tax charge of $22.4 million in the third quarter as its Amana appliance division tried to sell a manual-cleaning-oven business. Amana said that if it could not find a buyer for the business it would close the plant in Delaware, Ohio, dismiss 265 workers and dispose of the assets. Raytheon said the charge would be about 9 cents or 10 cents a share. The company said it was getting out of the business because more consumers favor self-cleaning ovens.

title: Prosecution at Thyssen Roils German Executives
description: Charges of fraud at Thyssen A.G., the sprawling steel and construction company, underscore what some analysts here regard as new vigor by German prosecutors willing to break the country's taboos by investigating allegations of corporate corruption.

title: PROTEIN DESIGN STOCK FALLS ON DRUG TRIAL'S HALT
description: The shares of Protein Design Labs Inc. fell almost 33 percent yesterday after the company said a research group had ended clinical trials of its compound to treat an eye condition in people infected with the virus that causes AIDS. The disease, cytomegalovirus retinitis, is an inflammation of the retina that occurs in patients with weak immune systems. The biotechnology concern, based in Mountain View, Calif., said the clinical research group ended trials for the company's Protovar antibody because the tests failed to show that the compound was effective. Protein Design's stock fell $7.625, to $15.50.

title: A Study Sees a Down Side to Going Overseas as an Executive
description: Nearly everywhere you go in corporate America, ''globalization'' is on the lips of executives seeking ways to grow. But in the eyes of the managers they send overseas to develop new business, the talk is full of lip service. Many return from international assignments feeling, not like conquering heroes, but like disillusioned victims of an ''out-of-sight, out-of-mind'' syndrome who have damaged their careers.

title: Don't Let Marina Slip Into History
description: To the Editor:

title: Bored With Big Tent? Then Go to Sideshow
description: In the final hours of the convention's punctiliously managed television show, wanderers craving surcease could find reassuring traces of the old carny-barkered sideshow charm of conventions past.

title: One Officer Injured, Another Is Indicted
description: A police officer pursuing a stolen livery car through Washington Heights yesterday was shot in the head and critically wounded by the driver, who left the car and ambushed the officer and his partner, the police said. After a wild shootout, the gunman fled and eluded a police manhunt that included helicopters and roadblocks.

title: Kemp Gives Early Look At Strategy
description: Jack Kemp accepted the nomination for Vice President tonight by previewing the attacks he will offer against Democrats, characterizing his opponents as ''elitists'' who have resisted Republican efforts to cut taxes and regulations in favor of an intrusive government that ''runs our lives.''

title: Official Embrace of Khmer Rouge Leader Roils Cambodia
description: One of Cambodia's tandem Prime Ministers, Hun Sen, said today that a top Khmer Rouge leader implicated in the mass killings of his countrymen should be welcomed back into society, and he personally guaranteed his safety.

title: Indicted Doctor Suspended
description: A doctor charged with shaking to death his 5-month-old child has been suspended without pay at Woodhull Hospital in Brooklyn.

title: Two New Jersey Postal Workers Arrested
