description: Two United States Postal Service employees in New Jersey have been charged with crimes involving guns in the last two days.

title: If It Was a Good Week for Dole, It Wasn't Bad for Whitman
description: She was on national television every night during the Republican National Convention, appearing at the rostrum as both convention co-chairwoman and prime-time speaker. She was interviewed by many network talk-show hosts. And although she is not running for office this year, on her way to San Diego she made what can be described only as a series of campaign stops across the country.

title: Policeman Is Indicted in Killing Of Unarmed Man in Subway
description: A Bronx grand jury has indicted a New York City transit officer on a manslaughter charge, prosecutors announced yesterday, accusing him of intentionally shooting an unarmed man in the back as the man fled down a deserted subway platform.

title: Bridge
description: The American Contract Bridge League has a regulation, little known and quite unenforceable, against betting on the results of its events. But it has never thought of barring betting on opening leads, and some of the Vugraph commentators took advantage of this oversight at the conclusion of the Spingold Knockout Team Championship final played on Sunday in Miami Beach.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Deal Made for Cruise Ship
description: The British leisure and travel concern Airtours P.L.C. said today that it bought a cruise ship from Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd. for $40 million. Airtours said the purchase of the ship, the Song of Norway, would enable it to keep pace with strong demand for cruise vacations. The first Airtours passenger cruise on the Norway, the third ship in the Airtours fleet, is set for May 1997.

title: Hitchcock More at Home in Seattle
description: One school of thought regarding Sterling Hitchcock goes something like this: The young left-hander has all the potential one could possibly hope for. But maybe it took leaving New York to bring it out in him.

title: Payment Accord For Joint Venture
description: British Aerospace will pay $:80 million ($123 million) to Lagardere Group of France as part of a previously announced agreement to form a joint venture that the companies said would be Europe's biggest guided-weapons business.

title: Russian Safeguards
description: To the Editor:

title: SMITH CORONA IS SELLING STAKE TO MARAFUND
description: The Smith Corona Corporation said yesterday that Marafund Ltd., a New York-based investment firm, had agreed to buy 15 percent of the reorganized company for $5 million through a stock purchase. Marafund also has an option to buy an additional 70 percent stake for $15 million. The $5 million stock purchase will increase the cash recovery of Smith Corona's unsecured creditors from $10.3 million to $15.3 million and decrease the amount of the company's new stock they are to receive from 85 percent to 70 percent. Smith Corona said Marafund is a private company that invests in telecommunications, health care and technology companies. The stock purchase agreement is subject to court approval.

title: Tradition of the West
description: To the Editor:

title: A Revival of Interest In the Virgin Mary
description: Popular interest in matters spiritual, so much a feature of life in the 1990's, has provided publishers with a ready audience for all sorts of books about angels, miracles and visions of an afterlife. But it has meant a market for more serious work, too, like studies of the life of Jesus, and, most lately, the religious significance of the Virgin Mary.

title: Boardwalk Site Is Purchased
description: Mirage Resorts, whose plans for a $750 million casino resort have helped spur a second wave of casino development in Atlantic City, has purchased an $8 million piece of property on the south end of the Boardwalk that, when combined with an adjacent two-acre lot it already owns, could house a 1,000-room hotel, company officials said.

title: Suffolk County Executive Signals He May Block English-Only Bill
description: In a signal that he may veto a bill to make English the official language of Suffolk County, County Executive Robert J. Gaffney issued a statement today saying that he would oppose the measure if he concluded that it singled out Hispanic people.

title: A Presidential Cake Is Not a Piece of Cake
description: The recipe for the cake for President Clinton's 50th birthday celebration tomorrow was a snap: beat 432 eggs and combine with 96 pounds of butter, 98 pounds of sugar and 100 pounds of flour. Top with 15 pounds of buttercream frosting and 15 pounds of seedless raspberry preserves.

title: Is There No Escape From Noise Pollution?
description: To the Editor:

title: Saab Automobile Records a Loss
description: Saab Automobile said yesterday that it had lost 428 million kronor ($66 million) in the first half of 1996, blaming adverse foreign-exchange rates and rising costs for product development and marketing. The loss contrasts with a profit of 195 million kronor for the first half of 1995. Revenue fell 7.8 percent, to 10.13 billion kronor ($1.56 billion) from 10.99 billion kronor.

title: Electronic Data for All the People
description: About once a century, America gets the chance to have its libraries advance our democracy significantly. Such a moment has arrived for the third time in our history.

title: U.S. SURGICAL'S OFFER FOR CIRCON BECOMES HOSTILE
description: The U.S. Surgical Corporation's $235 million offer for the Circon Corporation turned hostile yesterday as the company said it would proceed even after Circon rejected the bid. U.S. Surgical made the $18-a-share offer for Circon on Aug. 2. The medical-device maker wants to acquire Circon to increase sales of minimally invasive surgical products, using its marketing force to sell Circon's line of laparascopes. Last Thursday, Circon called the offer inadequate, saying it did not reflect its long-term value. Circon also approved a ''poison pill'' anti-takeover plan set off by any tender offer for 15 percent or more of its common stock. Circon's shares rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $18, in Nasdaq trading, while U.S. Surgical shares fell 25 cents, to $35.50.

title: A Historic Contest, but Hardly a Classic
description: Dallas Green didn't know whether to laugh or cry. He chose to laugh.

title: George Starbuck, Wry Poet, Is Dead at 65
description: George Starbuck, a poet who explored profound themes with such a dazzling display of pun, parody and pyrotechnic wit that critics sometimes seemed too busy laughing out loud to take him seriously, died on Thursday at his home in Tuscaloosa, Ala. He was 65.

title: Jury Acquits Air Force Major Accused of Lesbian Affair
description: A seven-member jury at Lackland Air Force Base in San Antonio has acquitted a female Air Force major charged with sodomy and conduct unbecoming an officer.

title: Dollar Rises Against the Mark As German Rate Cut Is Seen
description: The dollar rose against the German mark yesterday, bolstered by growing speculation that Germany's central bank will reduce interest rates when its policy council meets on Thursday.

title: Citizen Action Stopped Gold Mine Venture
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Council Votes Air Embargo on Sudan
description: Reuters

title: Three Tied for Lead in Northville Classic
description: Virtually ideal conditions led to low scores in today's opening round of the Northville Long Island Classic, with three players shooting six-under-par 66's to share the lead in the $800,000 Senior PGA Tour event.

title: Making and Unmaking Of a Made Man: Gotti
description: While sitting around a huge polished table loaded with food, some Mafia bigwigs decide that a small-time cheater named Nick has to be eliminated. The impeccably dressed John Gotti says he shouldn't have to do the job; it's not his turf. So Sammy (the Bull) Gravano jumps in. ''Nick's my brother-in-law, he's my embarrassment,'' says the rough-and-tumble Gravano. ''I'll whack him nice and easy.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Gains 23.67 Points, As Bond Yields Drop

title: Mauro V. Vincenti, 53, Owner Of Famed Italian Restaurants
description: Mauro V. Vincenti, a paragon of la cucina italiana in the United States and proprietor of two of its best-known outposts in Los Angeles, died of cancer on Wednesday at his Los Angeles home. He was 53.

title: 2 Charged in Rape Said to Admit Other Crimes
description: Two teen-agers charged in a rape and robbery at a swimming pool in Marcus Garvey Park on Aug. 9 have confessed to committing four other armed robberies in the last 10 days, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Coming: 20 New Principals
description: In the latest shake-up of the Newark school system, Dr. Beverly L. Hall, the state-appointed Superintendent, has announced that she will replace 20 of the city's principals, a quarter of the total. Of the 20, 17 resigned or retired over the last school year, many after receiving unsatisfactory evaluations. The other three agreed to job transfers, officials said.

title: Bosnian Heritage Lost in Library Ruins
description: To the Editor:

title: Joe Seneca, a Character Actor In 'Ma Rainey's Black Bottom'
description: Joe Seneca, a character actor who played one of the four musicians in August Wilson's ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom'' on Broadway in 1984, died on Thursday at his home on Roosevelt Island.

title: G.O.P.'S NOMINEES TAKE TO THE ROAD, MESSAGES IN TOW
description: With one last display of fireworks and burst of confetti, Bob Dole and Jack Kemp bounded out of their nominating convention in San Diego this morning, launching a campaign to change voters' views of the Republican Party and to turn the Presidential election into a referendum on tax cuts.

title: 2 Yeltsin Aides In a Showdown Over Chechnya
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin's national security adviser, Aleksandr I. Lebed, launched his boldest challenge to the Yeltsin administration today by demanding the dismissal of the Interior Minister, who was reappointed to the Cabinet only a day earlier.

title: San Diego Unplugged
description: Everyone agrees, so it must be true: There was no news at the flawlessly scripted, relentlessly ''inclusive'' Republican Convention. So said most of the 15,000 journalists who covered it, most famously Ted Koppel, who split town after two nights. But there was epochal news being made by this convention -- if not in San Diego, then in millions of homes around the nation, where Americans elected to stay away from the show in droves.

title: Onward to a Cacophony of Futures
description: If history is a fable agreed upon, as the saying goes, what story are we to invent that describes music at the end of the 20th century? Chronicle implies chronology and chronology direction. Direction, in turn, dares to call itself progress, though it would take some artful fiction or hopeful imagining to make anyone believe that at the century's close a new and progressive lingua franca will soon be coaxed down from music's Tower of Babel.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the German Luftwaffe training program at Holloman Air Force Base in New Mexico misstated the home base of the United States' radar-evading Stealth bomber fleet. The B-2 Stealth bomber is based at Whiteman Air Force Base in Missouri; Holloman is home to the F-117 Stealth fighter.

title: For the Networks, This Was the Week That Was Mostly Forgettable
description: Television news met its enemy this week, and it was television.

title: A Coke Coup in Venezuela Leaves Pepsi High and Dry
description: The global cola war between The Coca-Cola Company and Pepsico Inc. heated up in Venezuela yesterday, as Coke raided Pepsi's venerable bottling company there, and Pepsi threatened legal action.

title: The Ghost of San Diego
description: If you are a Republican and trailing in the polls, it makes no sense to revive the dark memories of Watergate, especially if you plan to make an issue of Bill Clinton's character. The ghost of Richard Nixon was therefore not much in evidence here this week. Haley Barbour, the Republican National Chairman, paid brief tribute to Mr. Nixon's foreign policy successes and recognized Tricia Nixon and her husband at 10 A.M. on opening day, when the convention hall was half-empty and the TV cameras were off.

title: Guns Approved, Man Says
description: A United States Postal Service worker who was charged with possessing 18 illegal assault weapons said yesterday that the police in Plumsted Township, where he lives, permitted him to own the guns. But state officials said they had yet to find the paperwork that would verify his claim. Rodger J. Johnson, 44, a letter sorter at the Trenton Processing and Distribution Plant in Hamilton Township, was arrested after the police raided his apartment and confiscated 85 weapons and fireworks, pepper spray and thousands of rounds of ammunition.

title: State Bank of India Looks Overseas to Raise Capital
description: Under increasing pressure from India's leftist parties to halt sales of public-sector companies to foreign investors, Government institutions like the State Bank of India are finding novel ways to raise capital abroad while still sidestepping criticism.

title: Hopeful Signs on Juvenile Crime
description: For the first time in nearly a decade, there are encouraging signs that soaring rates of juvenile crime may be tapering off. According to the latest data from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the homicide arrest rate for teen-agers dropped in 1994 and 1995 and the overall rate of juvenile violent crime dropped in 1995. While it is difficult to know whether this is only a blip or a longer-term trend, the decline gives some experts hope that efforts to crack down on guns and to prevent teen-agers from committing crimes are beginning to work.

title: The Republicans Are Fractured by 'Unity'
description: The buzzwords at the Republican National Convention were diversity, tolerance and inclusiveness. And to many people it was a success, raising hopes that Bob Dole can win in November.

title: Acquisition by State Street
description: The State Street Boston Corporation has agreed to acquire the corporate trust business of the Mercantile Bancorporation.

title: New Haven Champions Take Their Yearly Dive
description: From the time it moved here in 1990, this tennis tournament has earned a reputation as ''a graveyard of champions.''

title: Is There No Escape From Noise Pollution?
description: To the Editor:

title: SHARES OF FOXMEYER HEALTH TUMBLE BY 14%
description: The shares of the Foxmeyer Health Corporation fell 14 percent yesterday after the company said it was in talks to sell its primary drug-distribution business to stem huge losses. Foxmeyer shares fell $1.125, to $6.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Foxmeyer said it was in ''active negotiations with several interested parties'' to sell its wholesale drug-distribution business, which has racked up heavy losses because of price competition and computer-related problems. Foxmeyer executives declined to say who they are talking with, although the company has been trying without success to sell the distribution business for several months. Foxmeyer Drug generated most of the company's $5.5 billion in revenue last year.

title: Conservative Critics Adopt A New Cause: Dole-Kemp
description: This was the week conservative talk radio learned to love Bob Dole.

title: Latest Data Hint Fed Will Hold Rates Steady
description: Despite signs of a tight labor market and an uptick in consumer inflation, Federal Reserve policy makers are expected to leave short-term interest rates unchanged when they convene on Tuesday, economists said today.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: Aliens, Earthlings and Stolen Brains
description: Just when it seemed safe to assume that the new evidence of past Martian life posed no immediate threat to earthlings, along comes the Adobe Theater Company with ''Possible Worlds,'' a sci-fi thriller romance that begins with a series of murders in which the victims' brains are stolen.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: Bond Prices Post Their First Gains in a Week
description: Treasury bond prices gained yesterday for the first time in a week, aided by a report on housing starts that pointed to a slowing economy.

title: Khmer Rouge's No. 2 Denounces No. 1
description: Branded a traitor by his comrades and now suing for peace with his longtime enemies, Ieng Sary -- a founding member of the brutal Khmer Rouge insurgency -- leveled a harsh attack today on his oldest comrade in arms, the Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot.

title: Incentive Has Earnings Decline
description: Incentive A.B., a Swedish holding company controlled by the Wallenberg family, said yesterday that its first-half pretax profit fell 9 percent as sales growth slowed and a stronger krona eroded earnings in its biggest unit, Gambro A.B. Pretax profit fell to 1.989 billion kronor ($300 million), from 2.190 billion in last year's first half. The pretax figure includes 670 million kronor the company made in capital gains from selling off a number of subsidiaries.

title: Autism No Handicap, Boy Defies Swamp
description: Taylor Touchstone, a 10-year-old autistic boy who takes along a stuffed leopard and pink blanket when he goes to visit his grandmother, somehow survived for four days lost and alone in a swamp acrawl with poisonous snakes and alligators.

title: No Progress On Labor Deal
description: The chief negotiators in baseball's labor dispute met yesterday in Manhattan for the first time since Monday, but movement in the talks was not up to them.

title: Genetic Systems To Get New Owner
description: The German chemical company Hoechst A.G. said yesterday that Agrevo G.m.b.H., its crop-protection-chemical joint venture with Schering A.G., had agreed to take control of the Dutch-Belgian company Plant Genetic Systems International N.V. Agrevo will initially buy a stake of at least 75 percent in Plant Genetic Systems for $550 million, Hoechst said in a statement. It added that Agrevo planned eventually to buy all the shares in the company.

title: BARRY PETROLEUM AGREES TO BUY TANNEHILL OIL
description: The Berry Petroleum Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Tannehill Oil Company and its affiliated general partnership for $25.2 million. Berry Petroleum, based in Taft, Calif., said the acquisition included 600 acres that are currently producing 1,400 barrels of oil a day, oil reserves of 7.1 million barrels, and a power plant. Dow Jones

title: HOMELESS PARENTS IN NEW YORK FACE A WORK MANDATE
description: In a significant expansion of New York City's workfare program, homeless adults living with their children in city shelters will now be required to work for the city in exchange for their welfare benefits, aides to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.

title: Peace, Then Justice in Cambodia
description: After blood-soaked decades of internal conflict and outside interference, Cambodia is struggling to regain political and economic equilibrium. With so many of its political leaders associated with the violence, Cambodia cannot make a completely fresh start. But as political alliances shift, the killings should not be forgotten or excused. Justice may have to wait, but its time must come.

title: Old Foe of Atom Arms, India Now Blocks Test Ban
description: For those who remember the days when Indian leaders led the world in condemning the moral evils of nuclear weapons, there was a special irony in the moment this week when Prime Minister H. D. Deve Gowda slammed the door shut on efforts to persuade the New Delhi Government to go along with a worldwide ban on nuclear testing.

title: Mets Are First Major League Team to Lose in Mexico
description: Major League Baseball wants to be a league without borders, and the Mets and Padres knocked one down tonight when they played the first regular-season game outside the United States or Canada.

title: Win for Health Company
description: A state judge ruled yesterday that the Corrections Department can continue using a private company for prison health care services. The company, Correctional Medical Services of St. Louis, took over health care services at the state's 12 prisons in April, under a $62 million-a-year contract. But the company has been under attack from the Communications Workers of America Local 1040, which complained that it was planning to use unlicensed workers to perform psychological services in the prisons. Assignment Judge Philip S. Carchman of Superior Court in Mercer County allowed the company to proceed after it promised to have only licensed psychologists conduct psychological services. SARAH KERSHAW

title: Cone Is Still on Track; Wetteland Goes on D.L.
description: John Wetteland was deflated and David Cone was elated yesterday on an afternoon of pitching updates at Yankee Stadium. Cone will start a minor league game next Wednesday; Wetteland will be reduced to throwing a ball while sitting down after being placed on the 15-day disabled list with a strained right groin muscle.

title: For a Rabbi, Doing Good Is Doing Well
description: RABBI ISRAEL SHEMTOV seems to pop up in the right place at the right time. Three years ago in his Crown Heights neighborhood, he rescued a woman who, bleeding profusely from nearly a dozen bullet wounds, was crawling out of a basement. He hauled her into his car and sped to a nearby hospital. On Monday, three years to the day, he was driving over the Brooklyn Bridge when he stopped and talked a distraught man out of jumping.

title: For Blacks in Peru, There's No Room at the Top
description: Black doormen in elegant colonial uniforms stand guard at most luxury hotels in Lima.

title: Responding to Turkey's Eastward Drift
description: Fifty years ago, a Turkish philosopher raised a question that captured the anxieties of the young republic's modernizing classes: Are we moving toward the West, or are we merely running westward on the deck of a ship that drifts steadily to the East?

title: For 2d Time In a Week, Jet Piece Falls Over Queens
description: An eight-foot section of a wing flap broke off a Trans World Airlines Boeing 727 approaching Kennedy International Airport late Thursday and plunged onto a Queens street, leaving deep gashes in the roadway.

title: Mollen Commission Report Is Quoted in Civil Rights Suit
description: In an unusual civil rights lawsuit being heard in Federal District Court in Manhattan, three current and former officers in the corruption-ridden 30th Precinct are accused of punching, hitting, kicking and wrongly arresting a mother and her son in Harlem in 1991.

title: Giants-Jets: Honestly, It's No Big Deal. Really.
description: It is only preseason, so please don't overdo it.

title: For Now, One Goal, One Spirit
description: IN the spirit of the Olympic Games -- gone but not forgotten -- and in the spirit of good faith -- strained but not lost -- I've decided to change my method of judging the Jets this season.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Barbara S. Brier, 73, A Bridge Champion
description: Barbara Srenco Brier, a former world bridge champion, died yesterday in Allegheny University Hospitals Center City in Philadelphia. She was 73 and a resident of Miami.

title: Bosnian Rulers Are Terrorizing The Opposition
description: Opposition party members are being terrorized and beaten by agents of the Muslim-dominated Government in a campaign of intimidation that further erodes any pretense of fairness in the coming local and parliamentary elections, according to opposition leaders, senior NATO officers and international monitors.

title: INSIDE
description: The Reason for India's Veto

title: Permanent Revolution Of Rant and Paradox
description: Hours passed without a tune, and nobody minded, when Rage Against the Machine started its sold-out five-night stand at Roseland on Thursday, with the Jesus Lizard sharing the bill. Both bands are more riff and rant than rock-and-roll; their music is all propulsion, crunching and pounding as vocalists chant and growl.

title: Taiwan Company Suspends China Project
description: Formosa Plastics Group, Taiwan's largest business group, suspended a planned $3 billion power project in China yesterday under pressure from Taiwan's Government. Formosa Plastics signed a contract in May with the southern Chinese province of Fujian to build a thermal power plant before applying to Taiwan's for approval.

title: Match Those Bags
description: To the Editor:

title: Commuter Planes Must Now Increase Distance From Jets
description: Under rules taking effect today, hundreds of commuter planes in service around the country will have to fly farther behind jet airliners when approaching or leaving airports to reduce the risk of crashes. But the change will probably also increase delays.

title: Stock Market Posts Gains, Led by Advances in Bonds
description: Forging ahead for only the second time this week, the stock market took its lead from Treasury securities yesterday, with traders heartened by economic signs that suggested the Federal Reserve Bank would not raise short-term interest rates at next week's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee.

title: Shift in Tax Policy Leaves Argentine Markets Uneasy
description: Markets in Argentina are expected to show increasing volatility in the coming weeks as a new economic policy team struggles to put into effect some unpopular tax measures intended to close a huge budget deficit.

title: News in The Nick Of Time
description: The news that Ted Koppel had walked out of the Republican Convention hit while I was working out on the home eyeball exerciser. I had been at it for days, getting the orbs in shape for a reading bout with old Mister Homer, so when Sanderson phoned to report the Koppel walkout, its impact did not immediately register.

title: OBITUARY : Celibidache, a Painstaking Conductor, Dies
description: PARIS  Sergiu Celibidache, 84, the Romanian-born conductor known in the musical world for outstanding performances of a wide repertory achieved with painstaking rehearsal, died Wednesday at his home in Paris.

title: Wait Is Over for Jets: Johnson Ready to Start
description: Keyshawn Johnson knows, and deep down, his Jets teammates know, too. The people out there in the seats, to paraphrase Al Jolson, ain't seen nuthin' yet.

title: To T.W.A. Crash Investigators, Not All Witnesses Are Equal
description: Staring out from the beach at a point in the sky over the shimmering Atlantic Ocean today, Michael Russell grew reflective. ''I wish I hadn't been here,'' he said. ''I wish I hadn't seen it.''

title: Western Claims Victory in Bid To Acquire Kansas City Power
description: Western Resources Inc. claimed a victory today in its hostile takeover bid for the Kansas City Power and Light Company, saying Kansas City Power shareholders rejected a plan to buy out Utilicorp United Inc.

title: Nothing 'Extraordinary' Is Found in 747's Engines
description: Preliminary examination of all four engines from Trans World Airlines Flight 800 shows ''nothing really extraordinary,'' according to the official in charge of the investigation, largely ruling out the idea that engine failure caused the Boeing 747 to crash offshore here a month ago.

title: Yankees Hearing Footsteps, and It's Not Just the Dancing
description: The raucous fans started waving the free pairs of white socks they had been given in the first inning and never stopped, tossing hundreds of them on the field. They started the derisive chants about Ken Griffey Jr. even earlier, but mercifully did stop those. They even laid claim to a world record for the largest Macarena line dance with 50,724 people supposedly participating.

title: Kevorkian Goes From Making Waves to Making Barely a Ripple
description: For Dr. Jack Kevorkian, Thursday was a fairly normal day in the life of one of the Detroit area's most recognizable celebrities. He played a little golf and appeared at a popular lunch hangout to auction off his well-known powder-blue polyester cardigan for the Children's Leukemia Foundation.

title: Unilever in Talks To Sell a Unit
description: Unilever P.L.C., the British-Dutch consumer-products concern, said yesterday that it was negotiating to sell its H. Leverton Ltd. unit to Finning Ltd. The Leverton business operates Caterpillar Inc. equipment dealerships in Britain and has sales of about $:250 million ($388 million). Finning, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, is a heavy-equipment company that also owns Caterpillar dealerships in Britain. (Dow Jones)

title: A Roenick Trade Is Made, but Not to Isles
description: Don't count on Jeremy Roenick playing for the Islanders this season. The Phoenix Coyotes made sure of that yesterday.

title: One Town Left the G.O.P. Alone During the Convention Spectacle
description: Jean Kuhn is an early riser and hadn't stayed up to see much of the Republican convention on television this week, but Thursday night the retired Hoover Company worker sat down to watch the acceptance speeches by Jack Kemp and Bob Dole. She is a longtime Republican and voted for George Bush in 1992.

title: In Wisconsin, a Rarity Of a Fetal-Harm Case
description: On a cold night last March, Deborah J. Zimmerman, drunk and nearly nine months pregnant, was wheeled into a local hospital for an emergency Caesarean section.

title: Wounded Officer in Surgery for 2d Day
description: A police officer who was ambushed and shot in the head in Washington Heights on Thursday underwent a second round of surgery yesterday. Hospital officials said his condition was deteriorating and then stabilizing from one hour to the next.

title: Mexico to Dismiss 737 From National Police
description: Responding to criticism of persistent corruption in Mexico's one of national law enforcement agencies, Attorney General Antonio Lozano said today that he was dismissing more than 700 commanders and agents -- about one in every six officers.

title: A Cause Evolving Into Art
description: The Dallas Black Dance Theater was founded 20 years ago to provide dance opportunities for minorities. Most of the pieces the company presented on Thursday night at Damrosch Park, the opening dance attraction in the three-week Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival, were created by black choreographers. But the Dallas troupe has moved beyond simple social activism. The vocabulary, style and themes of the three dances contributed by Darryl B. Sneed, the company's resident choreographer, were proof of that.

title: A Big Weekend for Top Fillies at Saratoga
description: Only prize fillies need apply. And, with the exception of Serena's Song, who will run next week at Monmouth Park, 13 of the most formidable fillies in the country will take the track at Saratoga Race Course this weekend for the Alabama Stakes and the Ballerina, with championships on the horizon.

title: Clinton Aides Cast G.O.P. As Intolerant
description: Democrats responded to the Republican Party's four-day show of moderation and unity today much as they have responded to Republicans all year: by branding the party a radical, intolerant institution bent on siphoning Federal largesse from ordinary folk to the rich.

title: Postal Gunman Ordered Held
description: In a case that the police said was unrelated to the arrest of the postal worker in Plumsted Township, a Postal Service employee accused of shooting his supervisor at the main post office in Paterson was ordered held without bail yesterday by a Federal judge in Newark. Danny Isku, 38, a mechanic, shot his supervisor in the hand Thursday morning with a .22-caliber handgun he pulled out of a paper bag, the authorities said. Mr. Isku, a nine-year employee in the post office garage, belongs to the Paterson postal workers' gun club, the authorities said.

title: Cleanup Bills Are Assessed
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has ordered three former owners of a mercury-contaminated building to help pay for the building's cleanup and the relocation of its 37 residents, who were evacuated in January after a tenant discovered mercury under the floorboards. E.P.A. officials did not say how much the former owners, the General Electric Company and David and John Pascale, a son and father from Hoboken, would have to pay.

title: Where a Child Was Seized, a Garden Grows
description: For more than two years after little Kali Ann Poulton disappeared outside her home in this Rochester suburb, people hoped, or prayed, or at least pretended, that she was still alive.

title: In Kiosks Of London, Card Game Gets Dirty
description: Having tried for years to persuade prostitutes to stop littering telephone kiosks with small cards advertising their services, Britain's telephone company, in partnership with London's largest borough, Westminster, has decided to crack down on the likes of ''Domination Mistress Nancy'' and ''Cuddly Elana.''

title: Governor Sets Up Panel To Seek Funds For a '98 Run
description: Gov. John G. Rowland has moved a step closer toward declaring his candidacy for a second term, establishing an official campaign committee to accept contributions.

title: U.N. Plans to Hold Spending And Cut Staff by 30 Percent
description: Under pressure from Washington to cut costs and streamline itself, the United Nations today released the outline of its 1998-1999 budget that projects no overall growth in expenditures for the rest of the century while staff reductions continue.

title: Indian Adoptions Aren't Blocked by Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Korean Air Had Loss in First Half
description: Korean Air Lines said yesterday that it lost 253.82 billion won ($309 million) in the first half of the year, compared with a profit of 77.54 billion won a year earlier. Sales rose 7.8 percent, to 1.705 trillion won.

title: Fire Island Fund-Raiser Is Criticized Over Drug Use Linked to Unsafe Sex
description: Every year they gather on a wood-plank dance floor built in the sand, dressed -- but not too dressed -- in swim suits, gym shorts, kilts or costumes.

title: Obsolescence in the Age of Air Guitar and the Copying Machine
description: The melody that matches Ruth Binzer's mood these days is something in a minor key. That rules out two of her favorites, Mozart's ''Eine Kleine Nachtmusik'' (second file cabinet on the right) and the ''Exultate'' from Verdi's ''Otello'' (fourth file cabinet on the right). Her brother-in-law, Norbert Grunau, suggests Chopin's ''Funeral March'' Sonata (first file cabinet on the left). But there is a problem.

title: Scooter Sales Thriving From Rome to Delhi
description: Jean-Baptiste Gaube du Gers says he's found a foolproof antidote to stress, and it is built in a factory a short drive from this central Italian city.

title: 'Gaelic Gotham' Exhibition Ignores an Irish Family of Influence
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ''I guess God was looking for something to do. I guess he looked down and said, 'Let's fix things up a little bit.'''

title: Company Briefs
description: AKZO NOBEL N.V., Arnhem, the Netherlands, a chemical company, said its prescription drugs unit, Oragon, had agreed to collaborate on drug research with Signal Pharmaceuticals of San Diego, a biopharmaceutical company. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Squatters' Eviction
description: To the Editor:

title: Dole's Speech Wins Praise Of Executives
description: From Wall Street to board rooms around the country, business executives praised Bob Dole yesterday for displaying energy, decisiveness and even youthfulness in his speech accepting the Republican Presidential nomination. But many questioned whether his economic program could work.

title: CS Holding Sets Job Reductions
description: CS Holding said yesterday that it had reached agreement with employee organizations on how to eliminate 3,500 Swiss jobs that are to be cut as part of the bank's reorganization ''almost entirely'' without dismissals. The bank said an early-retirement program would account for about 1,500 jobs, while the rest would be cut by increasing the share of part-time jobs to 20 percent from 16 percent.

title: Clinton to Celebrate Birthday With Millions for the Coffers
description: Bill Clinton, the nation's highest-profile baby-boomer, is not going quietly into that sixth decade that he says signifies he has ''more yesterdays than tomorrows.''

title: For 3,000 Fanatics of the Flute, A Meeting of Many High Notes
description: ''The great thing about this is that you get to rub shoulders with the whole gamut of flute-playing fanatics.'' That was the reason James Galway gave for attending the National Flute Association's 24th annual convention. Some less famous players waiting to register the other day listed Mr. Galway himself as an attraction, and there was a ripple of excitement when he was spotted crossing the room.

title: Crossing a Border
description: Mexico is interested in getting a Major League Baseball franchise and baseball is interested in expanding, so two interests were served in Monterrey last night when the Mets played the Padres in the first game outside the United States and Canada. A jovial crowd of 23,699 watched the Padres win a wild game, 15-10. Article, page 27.

title: As an Orator, Dole Ranged From High to Dry to Muddled
description: Aristotle, Cicero and Quintilian -- the ancient masters of oratory -- would give Bob Dole no more than a beta for his acceptance speech in San Diego on Thursday night.

title: N.F.L. TRAINING CAMP REPORT
description: Bengals Rip Redskins

title: Pricey Sip
description: To the Editor: Regarding the letter from Anne Powell (''Coke at a Price,'' July 21), who was charged $19 for a large bottle of Diet Coke at a cafe in Paris, I would advise American travelers to sample, for their few weeks abroad, the more common beverages of the countries they are visiting.

title: Medical School Offers Students A Tuition-Free Year
description: It sounds like an offer that should have Ed McMahon's picture on the envelope: Cornell University Medical College said it would waive a year's tuition, worth $24,000, for first-year students who agree not to enroll until next year.

title: THE NEXT PRO-LIFERS
description: Thank you for Paul Wilkes's eloquent and powerfully argued ''The Next Pro-Lifers'' (July 21). In my case, he was preaching to the converted. I am in my late 60's, an age when the idea of one's trusted doctor offering this option is not necessarily reassuring.

title: Anna M. Nieves, Ralph P. Bryant
description: Anna Maria Nieves, a daughter of Genaro Nieves of White Plains and the late Carmen M. Coll, was married yesterday in Manhattan to Ralph Peter Bryant, a son of Linda Bryant of Manhattan and the late Ralph Henry Benjamin. The Rev. Alfonso Wyatt, an African Methodist Episcopal minister and a vice president of the Fund for the City of New York, performed the ceremony at the home of Ann Bloch, a friend of the couple.

title: Vivian Lan, C.M. Crosby
description: Dr. Vivian En-Wei Lan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Lan of New Milford, N.J., was married yesterday to Christopher Michael Crosby, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Crosby of Milford, Conn. The Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: Guardian Angel
description: THE WRECKED, BLESSED BODY OF SHELTON LAFLEURBy John Gregory Brown.257 pp. Boston:Houghton Mifflin Company. $21.95.

title: Northwestern Star to Have Chemotherapy
description: The junior fullback MATT HARTL, a starter on Northwestern's Rose Bowl team, will miss the 1996 season after being diagnosed with Hodgkin's disease. ''Doctors are very optimistic that he will have a complete recovery,'' Wildcats Coach GARY BARNETT said Friday. Hartl begins 12 weeks of chemotherapy next week. (AP)

title: Where Goethe Settled In With His Muse
description: WALKING through the streets of Weimar, where German culture has flowered as nowhere else, I like to imagine a day in its fabled past: Martin Luther is admiring a newly completed painting by Lucas Cranach at Cranach's studio on the Marktplatz. Johann Sebastian Bach plays one of his organ works at the SS. Peter and Paul Church while the resident preacher, Johann Gottfried von Herder, one of Germany's most brilliant philosophers, prepares his sermon. A couple of blocks away, Goethe and Schiller discuss poetry over lunch at their favorite restaurant, the White Swan. Franz Liszt composes a symphony at his house adjoining the magnificent Park on the Ilm, while at the Bauhaus across the street, students are under the direction of Walter Gropius, Paul Klee, Wassily Kandinsky and Lyonel Feininger. Unseen by all, Friedrich Nietzsche is closeted in his hillside retreat on the edge of town.

title: Whitewater Defendant Offers Help for Leniency
description: Hoping to be treated with leniency tomorrow when he is sentenced for the 18 felonies he committed, James B. McDougal has offered to help Whitewater prosecutors who have spent years scouring the financial and political dealings of President Clinton and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: A 'Must See' for Foreigners: Harlem
description: IT'S Sunday morning, and Harlem's streets are quiet as men and women in their go-to-meeting finery make their way to church. But the morning calm is periodically pierced by the rumble of tour buses carrying scores of European and Japanese tourists curious about the world's most fabled African-American community.

title: Emphasizing Pomp
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Wealthiest? Who, Us?' L.I. Villagers Exclaim
description: When Worth magazine published a list of the 300 richest towns in America this summer, people in this tiny enclave on Long Island's South Shore were surprised and a little dismayed to learn they finished second.

title: Judging the Entries, Then Asking for More
description: THE procedure for jurying an art exhibition is simple: separate the wheat from the chaff and hang the wheat. But it is anything but foolproof. Take the show by the Trenton Artists Workshop Association on view at the Trenton City Museum.

title: Yanks Music Flies by My Flag
description: The legendary house of upsets claimed a major one today when the filly My Flag was outrun in the Alabama within sight of a division championship, while Yanks Music won the race and staked a claim of her own.

title: Real Warhols On the Big Screen
description: To the Editor:

title: J. F. Fleming, 81; Helped Launch 'Today' Program
description: James F. Fleming, a pioneer in television news who helped start the ''Today'' show on NBC and later produced many award-winning documentaries, died on Aug. 10 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 81.

title: Elegant Dining In the East 50's
description: BICE**

title: A Hot Tub, A Golf Club And Thou
description: YOU can tell a lot about a place by its bathroom reading. First, by the very fact of it. During a recent sojourn through three of the toniest hotels on the Monterey Peninsula, two of the three featured racks in their water closets that were well stocked with magazines.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Cygnet

title: High in Colorado's Rockies, a Golf-Housing Complex
description: DR. TED HILTY, a retired orthodontist, and his wife, Joanne, have owned a condominium in Vail for 30 years and not long ago bought property in Arizona.

title: REFORM PARTY NAMES PEROT ITS PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE; 49,000 PARTICIPATED IN VOTE
description: Ross Perot has won the Presidential nomination of the Reform Party, the organization's officials announced here today, setting the stage for another unpredictable campaign that supporters hope will establish an enduring third party in American politics.

title: New Haven Final to Pit Underdogs
description: Officials and sponsors of the Pilot Pen International Tennis Tournament would have been delighted to have a reprise of last year's finale between Andre Agassi and Richard Krajicek, when the event was known as the Volvo International.

title: Judge Says Benefits Must Cover Partners of Gay State Employees
description: For the first time in the United States, a judge has required a public agency to extend to homosexual couples the medical, life and dental insurance benefits that married couples often have.

title: Between the Elegant and More Casual
description: WHEN Orlando's, an Italian landmark in Huntington for more than a quarter of a century, suddenly closed this spring, the staff was at sea. A few have now found safe harbor.

title: Border Crossing
description: THE PAPER WIFE

title: A Murderous Burden
description: ''EXTERMINATE ALL THE BRUTES''By Sven Lindqvist.Translated by Joan Tate.Illustrated. 179 pp. New York:The New Press. $20.

title: Reburying War's Dead, A Liberian Honors Life
description: Nearly every morning, Dr. Isaac Moses waits at his downtown apartment for a team of gravediggers who set out with him to do what virtually everyone else in this war-torn society long ago wearied of: giving proper burial to the dead.

title: Sleeping Over During A Layover at de Gaulle
description: Aviation buffs can get a thrill at Charles de Gaulle -- and a night's sleep. The new 254-room Sheraton, which opened earlier this year, is actually inside Terminal 2. The bow-shaped interior has been designed as a ship by Andree Putman, who designed the interior of the Concorde and Morgans Hotel in New York. Rooms have ''jet lag'' massage chairs, fax ports and a trouser press. Other amenities include free laundry service, saunas, meeting rooms and a spa. Soundproofed rooms look out on runways. Rates range from about $100 to $300. Call ITT Sheraton at (800) 325-3535.

title: Compromising on Abortion Views Isn't Easy
description: To the Editor:

title: Of the TV, By the TV, For the TV
description: TO appreciate the truly surreal quality of last week's Republican Convention, it helps to know two statistics:

title: When (Nobody's) In Rome ...
description: MANY cities have seasons immortalized in song -- ''April in Paris,'' ''Autumn in New York,'' ''September in the Rain'' (London) -- but nobody, so far as I know, has sung the praises of August in Rome. Until recently I assumed there just weren't enough people rattling around town who could strike the right note. Or perhaps the heat had so unhinged the poor souls that they couldn't carry a tune. Now I know better. Now I know that August in Rome is a secret shared by a small discerning congregation of sun worshippers, sybarites, sightseers and nocturnal prowlers.

title: Seattle
description: After taking a breather following the buildup of a new skyline, Seattle has gone on another one of its remodeling and self-improvement binges. This time, the city has turned to its waterfront, expanding a large pier on Puget Sound into one of the biggest and liveliest public spaces in the city. It opened early this summer. And the downtown retail core has become more of an entertainment center, with additions like Niketown and Planet Hollywood just a few blocks from the daytime heart of city shopping at Westlake Center.

title: Subjects From Many Angles, a Photographer's Work
description: Eleanor Parke Custis (1897-1983) was once a well-known photographer. In her lifetime she participated in more than 880 exhibitions. But these days her name is barely recognized. Beginning the deserved restoration of Custis's reputation is an exhibition of her work from the mid-30's at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich. It has the seductive title, ''Port of Dreams,'' and the specific port in question is Gloucester Harbor in Massachusetts. It's the locale of most of the show's 45 photographs, which were lent by the Greenwich Gallery, but the exhibition also reveals that Custis also felt at home in remote corners of the world.

title: Stewart, the People's Choice Quarterback, Awaits the Call
description: If Pittsburgh fans had their way, Kordell Stewart would be the starting quarterback for the Steelers when the regular season opens in two weeks. But they are not making the decision. Steelers Coach Bill Cowher is. And when he decides, chances are he will go with the veteran Mike Tomczak over Stewart and Jim Miller, a third-year veteran.

title: Today's Headlines, Tomorrow's Funds
description: A FEW years from now, when earthlings no longer need leave their homes because they can perform every conceivable task over the Internet, today's skeptics might look back and see that July 1996 was exactly the right time to start an Internet mutual fund.

title: Of War Crimes and Sanctuary
description: Brian Moore's recent fiction has offered timely investigations of political and moral issues -- the conflict between Ireland and England, the problems of a highly principled Roman Catholic Cardinal in Communist Poland -- but his new novel may ruffle more feathers. In the guise of a thriller, ''The Statement'' (Dutton) is a searing indictment of the long delay in prosecuting Frenchmen accused of collaborating with the Nazis during World War II. Mr. Moore's protagonist is a fictionalized version of Paul Touvier, the only French citizen convicted of crimes against humanity. Last month Mr. Touvier died at 81 in a prison hospital outside of Paris, a month after the book was published in the United States.

title: My Tryst With Anonymous
description: SAY it ain't so, Joe. Say it isn't over. What we had together was so beautiful. The delicate negotiations, the clandestine faxes, the meaningful silences. I loved it that you weren't a gold digger: you were interested in me, not my money. And you responded so pliantly to my requests, submitting to them all except one -- you know, the demonic one -- and I respected you for that, too, for so firmly digging in your heels. We even shared the same taste in music. I thought of you every time I listened to Iris DeMent, in her clear Missouri twang, sing ''Sweet Is the Melody'' -- and, well, I sometimes pictured you as looking like Iris, blond and soulful. I even used to think that, who knew, maybe we'd get together again sometime. Only now it turns out that all the while you weren't soulful at all. You were just Joe Klein, a guy I used to see across the room at parties, whose bearded mug is there every week in the front of Newsweek or chatting on TV. I liked you better the other way.

title: Skirmishes on the Borders of Civility
description: THE small civil wars of summer reach their frenzy about now. On fuming streets packed with strangers happy to be here and natives with nowhere else to go, you can see the mean, subtle scuffles between ostentatious smokers and those who find such behavior a personal affront, between defiant wheelies and soft-shelled peds, between a breed of macho dog owner and everyone else.

title: Partnerships Work For the Economy, Too
description: In areas where ''Long Island Sound Shows Signs of Renewed Life'' $(July 21$), success is the result of seemingly disparate interests' working together. A case in point: Oyster Bay remains one of the few harbors on the Island open to shellfishing. Its economic importance is as great as its environmental significance; 90 percent of the oysters harvested in the state come out of these waters.

title: Miami, the Hollywood of Latin America
description: EVERY WEEKNIGHT AT 10 O'CLOCK sharp, a boyishly handsome young Peruvian named Jaime Bayly enters a darkened television studio in Miami Beach and sits at a desk that is bare except for two glasses of water. Thousands of miles away, in Caracas and Buenos Aires and Mexico City and Santiago, viewers are tuning in, waiting for the affable talk-show host to begin another of his deft interviews with one of the actors, singers, athletes, models, writers and other celebrities who make up the world of Latin American show biz -- known in Spanish as la farandula.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and headline yesterday about the condition of a wounded New York City police officer, Francis Latimer, described his treatment incorrectly. Officer Latimer had surgery, as well as a less serious medical procedure to bind arteries behind his nasal passages, on Thursday, the day he was shot; he did not undergo additional surgery on Friday.

title: Herman Badillo and Gail Roberts
description: Gail Roberts, a schoolteacher in New York, was married yesterday to Herman Badillo, the lawyer and New York City political figure who is the special counsel to the Mayor for Fiscal Oversight of Education. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani performed the ceremony at Gracie Mansion.

title: Uptown and Out of Town
description: Dancing the nights away at Lincoln Center's Midsummer Night Swing and celebrating 25 years of service to Long Island.

title: Amtrak Rejuggles Its Routes Nationwide
description: Amtrak recently announced a restructured schedule, to begin Nov. 10, that ends service at 42 stations nationwide while increasing it at 131 stations. Although Federal appropriations for fiscal year 1997 (beginning this October) have not been finalized, Amtrak anticipates receiving only $200 million of the $250 million it sought.

title: Mayhem Man
description: Standing next to a steep canyon in his Boulder, Colo., backyard, Peder Lund blasts clay pigeons out of the sky. Lund would rather be fishing in Montana, but troubles are keeping him close to home. ''These days, my principal leisure activity,'' he says in clipped tones, ''consists of writing checks to lawyers.''

title: Why the Choice of '96 Will Remain a Bafflement
description: BOB DOLE'S fellow Republicans extolled him last week as a man of convictions rooted in the sturdy heartland of America. He presented himself to the convention that nominated him (and the electorate to which he was appealing) as the champion who could restore to government old values like ''restraint, honor and trust in the people.''

title: Notes From the Underground
description: Moody black clothes from designers on the edge.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: SEARCHING WITH YAHOO . . .

title: Birding For a Song In Maine
description: THERE are 4,500 islets in the Gulf of Maine, caught in the arms of Cape Cod and Cape Sable, Nova Scotia. In mid-July I chose to visit just one -- 333-acre Hog Island near the neck of Muscongus Bay, about 60 miles northeast of Portland. My selection process was far less sophisticated than that of the tern, a seabird that often nests on rocky outcrops off the Atlantic coast, and then migrates to Africa, Antarctica and South America, before coming home to the precise island of its birth. I migrated to Hog Island because I was looking for an economical Down East vacation, and found it in an Audubon Society Ecology Workshop in Maine, lasting six nights and five days, with 35 hours of field trips and classes on the area's physical and biological environment, evening programs devoted to conservation themes, rustic accommodations and meals included, for $700.

title: Slogans and Images, With Talking Heads Bending Your Ears
description: David Byrne has finally happened upon the perfect post-modern calling: Acoustiguide artist.

title: What Price Glory?
description: To the Editor:

title: Outsiders
description: To the Editor: The ''summer people'' syndrome that Suzanne Berne describes (''Strangers in a Familiar Land,'' July 21) is not limited to Cape Cod, but extends west at least as far as Lenox, Mass., where my wife and I recently vacationed.

title: At 82, a Bargain Hunter Leaves No Stone Unturned
description: Seth Glickenhaus arrived on Wall Street in 1934, when he went to work for Salomon Brothers as a municipal bond trader. After serving in the Army during World War II, he set up his own investment management company and made several million dollars by 1960, when he quit investing to take pre-med courses. But he was soon drawn back to his first love, finding undervalued stocks, and has been on the Street ever since.

title: Cultivating Blackfish Far From the Sea
description: WEIGHING in at less than a pound, Tony is not a particularly impressive year-old tautog, or blackfish. But to scientists at the National Marine Fisheries Service Laboratory in Milford, Tony's voracious appetite and accelerating growth are signs that New Englanders may some day be able to farm blackfish far from the ocean, for profit, and to allow overfished stocks in local waters to recover.

title: Karl Would Like to Coach North Carolina
description: Seattle SuperSonics Coach GEORGE KARL said he wouldn't mind being the next coach of the University of North Carolina men's basketball team -- if and when the current coach, DEAN SMITH, ever leaves. Both coaches were at Hudson Valley Community College in Troy, N.Y., Friday to pay tribute to the SuperSonic SAM PERKINS. Karl, who graduated from North Carolina, told The Albany Times-Union on Friday that returning would be ''a dream.'' (AP)

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: THE SOLDIERBy R. C. Binstock.Soho, $24.

title: Fascinating Rhythms
description: Inspired by the rhythms of jazz, Stuart Davis painted witty, ebullient works for 50 years until his death in 1964. In STUART DAVIS (National Museum of American Art/Abrams, $45), Patricia Hills, a professor of art history at Boston University, takes the reader on a straightforward tour of the artist's career. Born in 1892 to two Philadelphia artists, Davis spent most of his life in New York City. Besides making art and trying to sell it, for 30 years he also organized artists in support of causes ranging from socialism to a new urban American esthetic. Ms. Hills's well-researched book gives ample space to Davis's theoretical writings and political work, with an emphasis on the historical context. But she skimps a bit on the last 20 years of his life, when his style simplified and jelled. After being influenced by artists as different as Picasso, Lger, Mir and van Gogh, Davis discovered his ''swing,'' as in the Duke Ellington lyric he once incorporated into a painting: ''It don't mean a thing if it ain't got that swing.'' His mature works employed boldly painted words and symbols taken from advertisements and everyday life, set amid chunky, collagelike blocks of bright colors. Davis prided himself on the loose and improvisational nature of his art. But if his work swings, Ms. Hills's book - well done though it is - tends to drag. Ted Loos

title: Reducing Legal Costs In a Co-op
description: IN the never-ending struggle to keep maintenance charges manageable, co-op and condominium boards are always looking for ways to trim their buildings' operating budgets.

title: Splits in the Khmer Rouge Bring Threats of War
description: Cambodia's Khmer Rouge guerrilla movement appears to be cracking after nearly 30 years in the jungle and four years of brutal rule in the late 1970's.

title: Doctor's Radio Show Takes Serious Tack
description: DON'T call Dr. Joseph A. Deltito's radio show expecting to find out how to handle your love life or deal with an annoying neighbor. But if you or someone you know has a serious mental illness like depression, anxiety or a sleep disorder, his show may help you.

title: If You Build It They Will Watch
description: THE imagination knows no bounds when it comes to creating sculpture from sand and water on the beach on a warm summer day.

title: Behave Yourself This Season, Giants Warn Ticket Holders
description: Look out, sports fans: Giant Brother is watching you. The New York Giants informed season-ticket holders last week that grandstand surveillance at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford would be stepped up to prevent a repeat of last December, when a flurry of fan-made snowballs nearly forced the team to forfeit a game.

title: Local Pick for Cosmopolitan Chief
description: Bonnie Fuller is not exactly a swinging Cosmo girl. She lives in a house in Hastings-on-Hudson, has a devoted husband and two children whose drawings adorn her office shelves. She's up every day at 7, works until 8 at night. Her drink of choice is carrot juice.

title: Annual Reports, Translated
description: IN an ideal world, children respect their parents, politicians tell the truth and annual reports set forth candidly what's happening at the company.

title: When a Magazine Isn't Afraid to Look in the Mirror
description: SMART MONEY'S September issue is a prime example of why this personal finance magazine has succeeded in a very crowded field.

description: ''Ladies and gentlemen, boys and girls, children and elders, welcome to the show!''

title: Jennifer Ozols, Thomas K. Tracy Jr.
description: Jennifer Anne Ozols, the daughter of Leona Ellen Ozols and Edward Leigh Ozols, both of Mount Kisco, N.Y., is to be married today in Bedford, N.Y., to Thomas Kit Tracy Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Tracy of Atlanta. Rabbi David Greenberg is to perform the ceremony at Temple Shaaray Tefila of Westchester.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: THE NIGHT IS LARGE

title: Managing the Unmanageable

And whenever your office phone rings, it is usually someone giving you another job to do. How do you deal with it all and still get home to see the children before they go to bed? You learn to do several things at once. While on the phone getting that new assignment, you put the finishing touches on your report and refill the paper-clip tray. You don't waste a hand or a moment. How do you manage your time? Send your story to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: More Sense, More Sensibility
description: Writing sequels to Jane Austen's novels is obviously a formidable task. Most crucial is the ability to mimic Austen's language and tone without resorting to parody, while still managing to echo her subtle wit and subversive feminism. And then there is the challenge of finding enough loose ends for another story within the neat bundles of marital bliss in which Austen ties up her plots. In THE THIRD SISTER: A Continuation of Jane Austen's ''Sense and Sensibility'' (Donald I. Fine, $22.95), Julia Barrett manages the first challenge with easy and elegant phrasing. While her wit is not cloaked in Austen's constant good manners, Ms. Barrett (who is also the author of ''Presumption,'' a sequel to ''Pride and Prejudice'') excels at re-creating the polite scorn with which Austen women treat Austen men. As for the second hurdle, Ms. Barrett simply steps around it by concentrating on Margaret Dashwood, Elinor and Marianne's largely ignored sibling. This is a wise decision, for dedicated Janeites would be sorely disappointed if Elinor were unfulfilled by life as a parson's wife or Marianne deserted loyal Colonel Brandon for a more dramatic romance. Ms. Barrett contemplates no such blasphemy. Instead, Elinor and Marianne remain where they belong - in wedded bliss, in bit parts. The spotlight belongs to Margaret, an adventurous beauty wise beyond her years, stifled by the tedium of Barton Park's confined society. Fans of the original novel will enjoy juicy cameo appearances by such favorites as Mrs. Ferrars and the former Lucy Steele. They'll also enjoy a good new story, tight writing and a heroine with brains and charm. Rebecca Boggs Roberts

title: Stealing Comfort From the Men's Department

The image created a fashion revolution that swept the country and mirrored the American woman's liberation from centuries of fashion bondage. At midcentury, when Dior's corseted 1947 New Look tried to return women to a pedestal, many young women ignored the dictate and invaded Brooks Brothers to buy inexpensive, well-made cotton shirts. Today, as dress-down Friday spreads to other workdays, the men's shirt has again become an alternative style.
