title: Correction
description: A letter to the editor last Sunday about treating depression misspelled the surname of the writer. She is Nancy Loeb, not Lowb.

title: Coattails? What Coattails? Balance of Power Is at Issue
description: It is easy to forget during this convention season, but there is also a campaign for Congress this year, which is inextricably linked with the Presidential election whether the candidates like it or not.

title: Leo McLaughlin, Jesuit Teacher, Dies at 84
description: Leo Plowden McLaughlin, a onetime Jesuit priest who spent four heady years as an innovative president of Fordham University in the 1960's, died on Thursday at an infirmary on the Fordham campus in the Bronx. He was 84 and had ended his academic career as a teacher at Ramapo College in New Jersey.

title: Owners Think It Over As Time Bomb Ticks
description: One week after negotiators for the owners and the players made the most dramatic movement on the baseball labor front in six years, if not 30 years, a new collective bargaining agreement remains elusive. The negotiators sit and wait while Bud Selig canvasses and cajoles the owners.

title: Saddam's Page Turner
description: MEMO TO: LITERARY AGENT

title: Residents Gripe That Their Hideaway Has Become Too Much Like Beverly Hills
description: Yes, it gets more crowded every year. And no, it isn't the way it used to be. Even in this summer of disgruntling weather and too-close-for-comfort tragedy, the complaint is ongoing in the Hamptons, ubiquitous, boring: People keep coming here!

title: Saddled With a Problem? Try Horse-Sitting
description: FROM the board room to the barn. When Monika Klein, the former chief executive officer of a software development company in Manhattan, left the corporate fast track, she drew upon her business background to make a longtime dream become a reality.

title: Hooked on Smoking
description: The tobacco industry has suffered blows in the courtroom and the laboratory in recent weeks that strengthen the case for regulating nicotine as an addictive substance. The accumulating evidence supports the latest efforts by the Food and Drug Administration to curb smoking by teen-agers, who are most likely to become hooked for life.

title: Forty Years Later, the Laughter's Still Loud
description: IT WAS A DATE THAT WILL LIVE IN INFAMY. On May 25, 1957, after three years of delivering comedy gold into America's living rooms, ''Caesar's Hour'' was forced off the air, done in by the unbeatable magnetism of Lawrence Welk. ''Caesar's Hour,'' the successor to ''Your Show of Shows,'' which had run for four years, was losing the ratings battle, and the curtain rang down to the sound of champagne music.

title: The Johnny Appleseed of a Biotechnology Forest
description: IT was a typical workday for Howard C. Birndorf at Nanogen Inc., the biotechnology company he helped to found here three years ago. As he showed a visitor around, he met three new employees he had never seen before; introduced Harry Leonhardt, the general counsel hired a few days earlier from Allergan Inc.; wound through rooms of brand-new lasers, microscopes and beakers to a basketball court about to be turned into more laboratory space, and showed off an empty cubicle.

title: Staying Alive
description: Polyester suits. Platform shoes and mirro balls. The dance floor pulsates to the beat of Donna Summer's ''Love to Love You, Baby.'' Get the picture? Disco, one of the enduring legacies of 1970's pop culture. Toss in punk and progressive rock, and now, two decades later, all but the most dedicated partisans would agree that things were a bit of a mess back then. But wait a second. Punk is back; can disco redux be far behind? So much for the lessons of history.

title: Airport Restaurant With Some Views
description: BY now, most county dwellers are aware that the one-story, tin-roofed shelter, the county's old airport terminal, has been replaced by a new multi-level brick structure. That the parking fees are exorbitant, that directional signs are unclear or nonexistent (for simple drop-offs or pickups, for the entrance to the parking lot, for the cross-walk bridge), that the view from the ''observation deck'' is obstructed are among mishaps and impediments for detailed discussion elsewhere. But Skytop, the airport's longtime restaurant-tenant, is part of the new complex, and sad to say that for the moment, anyway, the thrill of dining here is gone.

title: Ms. Goldsmith And Mr. Rothman
description: Jennifer Elizabeth Goldsmith, the daughter of Ingrid and I. Gordon Goldsmith Jr., of Germantown, Tenn., was married last evening to Eric Scott Rothman, the son of Diane Rall of Summit, N.J., and Dr. Lawrence J. Rothman of Berkeley Heights, N.J. Rabbi Harry K. Danziger performed the ceremony at the Peabody Hotel in Memphis.

title: Masterkova to Run in Fifth Avenue Mile
description: SVETLANA MASTERKOVA of Russia, Olympic gold medalist in the 800 and 1,500 meters and world record-holder in the mile, will run in the Discover Card Mile on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan on Sept. 28. Masterkova set the mile record in Zurich on Wednesday. (AP)

title: Day Camp as a Youthful Serenade for Strings
description: WHAT kind of child is drawn to the string family, in which a player's formidable tasks are to create a precious sound, learn the right posture, play on pitch and carefully judge the minute distances between the strings as if groping for a light switch in the dark? A precocious child, certainly, but one who might also like having in his hands a small object that can produce a highly expressive sound, one like no other.

title: Dispute Over Indian Casinos in New Mexico Produces Quandary on Law and Politics
description: There was a time not long ago when a gambler here would have to travel 600 miles to Las Vegas, Nev., to wrestle with Lady Luck.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Putting Aside Differences to Go Rescue Dad
description: Alaska

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: BATTERY PARK CITY

title: Cantering Into Sunset For a Beer
description: Rumor has it that the three men who mosey single file through Brooklyn in the thick of the night astride horses and dressed in cowboy hats, boots and vests were grand prize winners of the Lotto jackpot.

title: Superpowers Lace Up To Take On the World
description: It is disorienting enough for National Hockey League players to begin training camp in mid-August, a scant two months after the Stanley Cup finals. The confusion increases when they arrive to prepare for the World Cup tournament and realize that many of their regular teammates are scattered among eight national teams pitted against one another.

title: Dr. Lyubisheva And Mr. Casey
description: Dr. Lyudmilla Valereyevna Lyubisheva, a daughter of Svetlana and Valery Lyubisheva of Nizhny Novgorod, Russia, was married yesterday to Lukas Casey, a son of Pam Lewis of West Hartford, Conn., and Robert E. Casey of Stonington, Conn. John Raabe, a Connecticut justice of the peace, performed the ceremony at the Lake Waramaug Club in New Preston, Conn.

title: Maximum Leader
description: PROPHET OF RAGE

title: Dole Preaches Lower Taxes to an Audience of Firm Believers
description: Following the campaign trail laid down 10 years ago by another Republican Presidential candidate, Bob Dole came today to one of Ronald Reagan's favorite campaign stops, the Illinois State Fair, to preach one of Mr. Reagan's favorite messages: tax cuts.

title: Metamorphosis in Suburbia
description: AMERICA is going global. America is going gray. How do the two trends play out -- and off -- against each other in suburbia?

title: Beyond-the-Beltway Bandits
description: National and local television-news producers recently received a vexing letter from Turner Construction, a company working for the Democratic National Convention Committee. News organizations covering next week's big gathering in Chicago had expected to pay the company between $10,000 and $15,000 to transform the United Center's skyboxes into 14-by-14-foot anchor booths and work spaces. Instead, they were hit with bills three times as high, up to $45,000. ''Conventions are rip-off-the-media time,'' says a senior network producer. Among the Pentagon-style line items:

title: Megan A.E. Ring, Jeffrey S. Maningo
description: Megan Ann Elizabeth Ring, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Patrick Ring of Sea Girt, N.J., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Scott Maningo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rom Maningo of Littleton, Colo. The Rev. Robert Kaeding performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Roman Catholic Church in Sea Girt.

title: A Parisian Delight
description: To the Editor: Add to the joys of Paris a brand new park, the Promenade Plantee.

title: Descendants of Slave and Master Work to Save a Common Heritage
description: When John Hanson Briscoe joined her on the Sotterley Plantation Board of Directors in 1994, Agnes Callum reached the end of a journey lasting almost 150 years.

title: Simply Camping
description: AT 9:30 in the morning, a wholly typical summer day at this wholly typical day camp, about 80 children are hanging out in the Boys and Girls Club gym on Maitland Avenue.

title: 4-H Clubs Move Beyond 'Cows and Cooking' Image
description: Eleven-year-old Emily Wunderlich took her heifer, a Polled Hereford named Reba, to the Sussex County fair. They came home 4-H champions. To many people, that image -- a little girl leading a big animal and clutching a prize ribbon -- is what 4-H is all about.

title: Teaching Themselves to Teach Others Better
description: REMEMBER when high school theater meant the big spring musical? Maybe it was ''Oklahoma!'' Maybe ''Bye, Bye Birdie.''

title: Monterrey Is Feeling Like a Big-Leaguer
description: Joe McIlvaine, the general manager of the Mets, sat in Monterrey Stadium, chatting up fans in fluent Spanish and drinking in the scene of major league baseball, Mexican-style.

title: The Death of Sherman McCoy
description: TO REREAD ''THE Bonfire of the Vanities,'' Tom Wolfe's glittering portrait of 1980's New York, is to notice that something has changed since its publication nine years ago. In many ways, the book remains a brilliant description of urban America. In the depictions of white guilt, black rage and the life styles of rich New Yorkers, there isn't much any visitor to our planet would fail to recognize. What rings false in 1996 is the character of Sherman McCoy, the Wall Street bond salesman at the center of the novel. The Big-Time Financier today has about as much resonance as the yippie; he has become a social archetype from the distant past.

title: The New World That Darwin Didn't See
description: DARWIN should have packed a face mask.

title: Jack Kemp: A Director With No Shares
description: What would you say about a corporate director who was unwilling to invest one penny in the company whose shareholders he represented?

title: Q. and A.
description: The Status Of a Co-op In Divorce

title: Is This Fingerprint Company In for a Dusting?
description: WHEW, boy!

title: What's New in Japan? Old American Cars
description: THE Japanese have long looked down on American cars as oversized gas guzzlers that break down a lot. But to Kyoko Takahashi, those attributes just add to the charm of her 1965 Chevrolet Impala.

title: Punchless Jets Beat Punchless Giants in Wan Exhibition
description: To all those fans who worried about the Jets first team not being able to score, take heart: the Giants can't do much of it, either.

title: Rachel K. Laser, Mark S. Davies
description: Rachel Karen Laser, a daughter of Joan and Gary Laser of Chicago, is to be married today to Mark Simon Davies, a son of Naomi Davies and Dr. Terry Davies of New York. Rabbi Arnold Wolfe is to officiate at K.A.M. Isaiah Israel Congregation in Chicago.

title: A Remnant of the 1930's, and Its Sky, Will Fall
description: THE Landmarks Preservation Commission has twice designated as a landmark the 1935 Hayden Planetarium on West 81st Street. But the American Museum of Natural History is moving ahead with plans to demolish its mild, moderne structure -- with the landmarks commission's blessing, but amid dismay and suspicion by some preservation groups.

title: Helping Single Women to Become Homeowners
description: AFTER being turned down by two mortgage companies and discouraged by two others, Michele D. Van Horn thought her nearly year-long search to buy a house was an exercise in futility. But last May she moved into a four-bedroom colonial split level in Somerset that she had bought for $170,000.

title: Women's Views Count
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding Solace Through Music
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats' Plan for Convention: Keep It Positive, and Presidential
description: Acknowledging that the Republicans put on a well-staged spectacle, Democrats have set two goals going into their own national convention: to raise doubts about the tax-cut plan and moderate image the Republicans touted, and then use the President's aura of incumbency to reach out to independent-minded voters.

title: A Hard Habit to Break
description: GLOBAL HABIT

title: A Recluse and His Long-Hidden Trove of Cars
description: Alexander Kennedy Miller was always something of an eccentric and miser. The son of a wealthy stockbroker from Montclair, N.J., he attended Rutgers University on a scholarship to study mechanical engineering. An anecdote alongside his yearbook picture recounts an occasion on which he zoomed down the street on a motorcycle coatless in the dead of winter, heading to the barber shop ''for his quarterly haircut.''

title: A Window Onto A Swparate Realm
description: THE Monterey peninsula is wonderfully rich with views of the Pacific: Carmel's curve of sheltered beach; the serpentine cliffside road toward Big Sur; the expensive, traffic-clogged, still beautiful 17 Mile Drive; Point Lobos, with its rocky outcroppings from which to watch the springtime migration of gray whales heading north from Mexico.

title: Rudeness for Fun and Profit
description: IF you're looking to buy a copy of ''Hannah Does Her Sisters,'' you won't find it on 42d Street. The last porn business on the strip between Seventh and Eighth Avenues closed this spring. Times Square's cleanup is a source of pride for Mayor Giuliani, but why stop there?

title: On the Inside Looking Out
description: TRUMP'S World's Fair Casino is a hit, and nobody is blaming the weather.

title: Lisa H. Shapiro and Murry Gunty
description: Lisa Hope Shapiro, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip M. Shapiro of Newington, Conn., was married last evening to Murry Gunty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard D. Gunty of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Charles Lipman performed the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Break-In Brings Calls for Tighter Security at Center for Juveniles
description: At first, Robert Glessman didn't realize that the sound he had heard at midnight on his street was a human shriek.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: THE INNER ELVISA Psychological Biography of Elvis Aaron Presley.By Peter Whitmer.Hyperion, $22.95.

title: A New Look For Chinese Capitalism
description: The Mori Shanghai, shown in an artist's rendering, is to be built as the second of three towers in the emerging financial center in Shanghai. The 95-story, 1,509-foot-tall building, designed by Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates of Manhattan, will hold offices, stores and galleries, and, on the top floors, a hotel. When it is completed in a few years, it will be the tallest skyscraper in the world.

title: Fluorescent Lighting to Best Use
description: IN 1938, the first practical fluorescent light fixtures were introduced in the American marketplace. These lights used less power and lasted longer than incandescent bulbs so they quickly became the standard in offices, stores, and industry.

title: Only the Ages Are in Single Digits
description: I HAVE a 4-year-old and an 8-year-old, so that means I have given 12 children's birthday parties in my life. At least I will have when my 8-year-old actually turns 8 in a few weeks. Right now, it's birthday party No. 12 we're working on.

title: Christine Colavita, Peter Latartara
description: Christine Anne Colavita, the daughter of Margaret and Anthony J. Colavita of Eastchester, N.Y., is to be married today to Peter William Latartara, a son of Anne and Peter Latartara of Westfield, N.J. Msgr. Edward M. Connors is to perform the ceremony at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Republican Convention Showed Insensitivity on Child Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Carolyn L. Blume, Joerg D. Hoehne
description: Carolyn Leigh Blume, a daughter of Michael and Gail Blume of Lake Grove, L.I., is to be married this evening to Joerg Dietmar Hoehne, a son of Heinz and Lissi Hoehne of Talkau, Germany. Rabbi Michael Irlich is to perform the ceremony at the Roslyn (L.I.) Country Club.

title: Crime
description: CADILLAC JUKEBOX (Hyperion, $22.95) may be the most incoherent of the crime stories that James Lee Burke has set in the Louisiana bayou country of the Atchafalaya Basin. At the outset, Dave Robicheaux, the melancholy sheriff's deputy who broods over this series, seems to have a hard but unambiguous mission: to find out whether a redneck named Aaron Crown actually killed a civil rights leader back in the 1960's, and to figure out what this old crime, for which Crown has only recently been arrested, has to do with the upcoming gubernatorial election. But the investigation is soon mired in the violent history of New Iberia and the complicated relationships of its politically inbred families. A subhuman beast of a hit man crawls out of the swamp to silence police informants, and everyone from the New Orleans Mafia to Dave's wife warns him off the case.

title: From a Smoker
description: To the Editor: I noticed a lack of the personal perspective in the various articles about smoking (''No Smoking: A Travelers' Status Report,'' June 30).

title: Potholes and Bridges Put Parking Lot Beyond the Back Burner
description: A dirt lot on Emmons Avenue that has been proposed as a municipal parking center has a city councilman and a city commissioner engaged in a political dogfight.

title: When Summer Stock Is Not Enough
description: YOU MIGHT THINK THAT A lovely old summer theater like Theater-by-the-Sea would be able to get by on charm, high production values and success. These days it's not that simple.

title: Wee Burn Country Club Turns 100, Discreetly of Course
description: WHEN 27 former head golf pros and assistants at the Wee Burn Country Club in Darien returned for a three-day reunion in early May to mark the club's centennial, only club members, staff workers and a few others knew about it. No press releases were sent out, nor were photographers or television crews invited to record the event.

title: 'Becoming Modern'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lesson in Inner City Tennis
description: At first glance, the GHI Bronx Open Classic Tennis Tournament, which opened on Aug. 10 at Crotona Park, seems an odd bridge between genteel English lawn tennis traditions and Bronx street codes.

title: By Jupiter, a Watery Moon
description: Reports of possible life on early Mars have encouraged scientists in their theory that Europa, one of Jupiter's moons, may also seethe with alien microbes in a global sea of water. The theory got a boost last week with new pictures by the Galileo spacecraft showing the moon's icy surface looking like pack ice in a polar sea on Earth.

title: Painful Metaphors
description: To the Editor:

title: Report on Gingrich Ethics Case Is Turned In
description: The special counsel investigating tax law charges against Speaker Newt Gingrich has filed a preliminary report with the House Ethics Committee, a lengthy document sure to test the committee's ability to overcome months of absolute partisan deadlock.

title: Was the Plague of Athens Really Ebola?
description: MORE than 2,400 years ago this summer, a mysterious plague swept through ancient Athens. In five years flat, it killed perhaps a quarter of the population of the city-state, then under siege by Sparta. Thousands of Athenians died a dreadful death -- first suffering a maddening fever, then bloodshot eyes, inexplicable vomiting and bleeding, followed by skin lesions and diarrhea.

title: In Custody
description: Crows Over a WheatField

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: WEST 47th

title: Father's Goods Sold at Auction to Pay Child Support Debt
description: A crew of auctioneers today sold off most of the worldly goods of Jeffrey Nichols, one of the country's best-known deadbeat dads, as he sat in a jail cell in the Bronx House of Detention.

title: THE NEXT PRO-LIFERS
description: For me, the most ethically compelling requests for doctor assistance in dying come from the victims of such neurological conditions as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Lou Gehrig's disease) or Alzheimer's disease. Inadequate pain management is not the issue with these patients. The issue is suffering that they judge to be unendurable.

title: Seeing Was Believing
description: VISIONARIESThe Spanish Republic and the Reign of Christ.By William A. Christian Jr.Illustrated. 544 pp. Berkeley:University of California Press. $39.95.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Democracy Isn't What You Think
description: BETWEEN FACTS AND NORMSContributions to a Discourse Theory of Law and Democracy.By Jrgen Habermas.Translated by William Rehg.631 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $40.

title: Youth Isn't Eternal
description: To the Editor:

title: Plenty to Eat, On Foot
description: To the Editor:

title: Passing the Torch
description: Cities rise and fall, and the fashion pack picks up and relocates accordingly. The spontaneous combustion that occurs when creative people converge on one place dies out after a time, and then reignites somewhere else. If there is a single word that nearly all the photographers, agents, makeup artists and models use to sum up what they're looking for, it's ''energy.'' In the 80's, they found it in Paris; now they find it here in New York.

title: Clinton Says Dole Tax Cut Could Inflate Deficit Woes
description: President Clinton swung back hard today at Bob Dole's proposed 15 percent income tax cut, arguing that the Republican proposal would either balloon the deficit or force deep cuts in programs like Medicare and that his own proposed tax breaks were better and more affordable.

title: WAGE VOLATILITY FAR MORE COMMON THAN EVER BEFORE
description: Cole Grady was earning $52,000 a year as a technician at a herbicide plant in Muscatine, Iowa, including $15,000 in overtime. But then the overtime disappeared, and the Grady family abruptly entered the growing and uncertain world of fluctuating pay.

title: Where Summer School Isn't Just Remedial Course Work
description: SUMMER school has usually carried a faint punitive aroma. While their peers are indulging in leisurely activities like swimming at the beach or relaxing in the backyard, those students whose lackluster academic performance during the school year required them to catch up on course work during summer vacation must do time in classrooms, relegated to the monotony of work sheets and relentless quizzes.

title: Lost at the Movies
description: I'M LOSING YOU

title: Not With a Whimper but a Bang
description: THE END OF THE WORLD

title: Atsumi Ichida, Patrick S. Marsh
description: Atsumi Vanessa Ichida, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Koji Ichida of New York and Tokyo, was married yesterday to Patrick Schaeffer Marsh, a son of Dr. and Mrs. James Milton Marsh of Steubenville, Ohio. The Rev. John Duffell performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York. The Rev. Robert Marsh, a Presbyterian minister who is the bridegroom's cousin, took part in the service.

title: Restaurant Offers Ultimate Outdoor Meal
description: IT'S the ultimate outdoor meal. The old-fashioned seaside clambake was intended to be served with the sky, not a ceiling, overhead. Although hundreds of these seafood feasts are offered on the Island, perhaps the most elaborate, expensive and esthetically pleasing of them all is the Monday lobster and steak night meal served at Starr Boggs Dune Deck in Westhampton Beach (288-5250). It even has a healthful 90's spin, but more about that later.

title: Journey to the Top of the Earth
description: FEW Alaskans refer to the James W. Dalton Highway by its official name. It's the highway part that trips them up. The 414-mile agglomeration of dirt, gravel and mud, one and a half lanes wide with nary a convenience store the entire way, seems beyond the elasticity of the word highway. Instead, the route is widely known in Alaska as the Haul Road. And, utilitarianly speaking, that's precisely what it is -- a road, built in 1974, to haul equipment for the trans-Alaska pipeline, which it roughly parallels, and the oil fields at Prudhoe Bay, on the frigid shores of the Beaufort Sea.

title: Andrea Wilson, 73, Investment Analyst
description: Andrea Ungar Wilson, a former investment analyst, school administrator and labor arbitrator, died on August 11 at her summer home in Wainscott, N.Y. She was 73 and a resident of Manhattan.

title: A Rift Opens Over 'Other Victims' at Holocaust Memorial
description: A city-funded Holocaust memorial under construction in Sheepshead Bay has become the focus of a debate about how to note the various groups who fell victim to the Nazis.

title: U.S. Effort To Replace U.N. Chief Gets Nowhere
description: The Clinton Administration's plan to find a replacement for Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali before the Presidential election in November has run into a wall of resistance in the Security Council.

title: Laurie E. Falk, James Davidowitz
description: Laurie Ellen Falk, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George Falk of Longmeadow, Mass., is to be married today to James Philip Davidowitz, a son of Acting Justice Edward M. Davidowitz and Mrs. Davidowitz of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Gershon Sonnenschein is to officiate at a party space, Chez Josef, in Agawam, Mass.

title: Jennifer Scheer, Gary J. Lieberman
description: Jennifer Holly Scheer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth Scheer of Brookline, Mass., was married last evening to Gary Jay Lieberman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Pincus Lieberman of Wyckoff, N.J. Rabbi Paul Cohen performed the ceremony at Dr. and Mrs. Scheer's house in Castine, Me.

title: Fly-Fishing? On Long Island Sound?
description: We put in at midnight, by the dark of the new moon. I could hear, but not see, stripers feeding with abandon on newly hatched cinder worms carried by the falling tide. We moved silently with the current and very soon our guide, Bob Robl of Dix Hills, L.I., spoke softly. ''Some anglers over to our left,'' he said.

title: The Falling Out
description: THE black woman was calling the white woman ''massa'' and the crowd was going wild.

title: Sweeping Views and a Brand New Menu
description: THE dining room at the Gelston House in East Haddam is now called Gelston House River Grill. The name is not the only change in this handsome Victorian Italianate building, now a property of the equally ornate Goodspeed Opera House, just a hop, skip away.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 2

title: Larchmont, Where Gold Medals Flower
description: If a swimming coach had three different Olympic champions amass five gold medals over the last four Summer Games, the natural assumption would be that he or she was from California or Florida. Or perhaps Indiana University or the University of Michigan.

title: Buying vs. Renting
description: WHEN Grace N. Chen walked into the apartment she is about to buy on East 53d Street, she stood near the entrance, hand on hip, staring toward the front windows.

title: Finding a Friendly Face in a New Place
description: JAMIE DUNN remembers her first few weeks as a new resident of Norwalk as ''lonely.''

title: Spanish Caves
description: To the Editor: In a Q & A column on June 16 (''Altamira Cave Paintings''), a reader was told of a yearlong waiting list for visiting the caves of Altamira, Spain, and the small chance of getting a ticket.

title: The First Champions Of the Little League
description: I can't believe that nearly 50 years have gone by so fast since that hot and humid August day in Williamsport, Pa., when a group of scrawny 11- and 12-year-old boys played in and won the first Little League World Series. I was the center fielder on that team.

title: One Artist Imitating Another
description: ''SOMETIMES, IN ORDER TO PLAY A CHARACTER, you have to wear their shoes, and sometimes you have to wear their hair,'' said Jeffrey Wright, referring to the title character he plays in the film ''Basquiat,'' a portrait of the 80's art star Jean-Michel Basquiat directed by another 80's art star, Julian Schnabel. It's the first major screen role for the 30-year-old actor, who won a Tony Award in 1994 for his performance as the flamboyant nurse Belize in Tony Kushner's ''Angels in America.''

title: Officer in Rape Case Resigns From Force
description: A Bronx police officer who was charged earlier this month with raping a 17-year-old girl whom he had arrested in a domestic dispute has resigned, the police said.

title: Quietly, Officials Seek Clues In Lives of Flight 800's Dead
description: With the underwater inquiry into the explosion of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 failing to yield definitive answers about the cause of the crash, investigators say their best hope for a break in the case may lie above ground in the other, seldom-discussed prong of their inquiry -- the hunt for human suspects.

title: Field Dispatcher Program Is Tested In an Effort to Lure Bus Riders Back
description: Transit Authority officials call it ''bunching'' -- the urban phenomenon in which would-be passengers wait interminably at a bus stop, then two or three buses show up at the same time. Bus riders just call it annoying.

title: Keeping Track of Cancer in the State
description: AS many as one out of three Connecticut residents may get cancer. Few, however, know that details of their cancer, its treatment and outcome are recorded in the oldest population-based cancer registry in the United States.

title: Market-Rate Rents In Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: Plumbing Panel Swirls in Controversy
description: THE Westchester County Plumbing Board, established last year to provide countywide licenses to plumbers and hailed at the time as a model for future legislation, has become mired in controversy in recent months, prompting County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke to deliver a public ultimatum to the board he appointed.

title: Putting Aside Differences to Go Rescue Dad
description: Jack

title: Ritchie Patterson, Lawrence Gibbons
description: Juliet Ritchie Patterson and Lawrence Kent Gibbons, both physicists, were married yesterday in Alpine, N.Y. The Rev. Gurdon Brewster, the chaplain of Cornell University, performed the ceremony at the Lawrence Chapel.

title: In a New Detective Series, One Star Is the Spirit of a City (New Orleans)
description: Correction Appended

title: Julie B. Gluck, Gregory D. Hirsch
description: Julie Beth Gluck, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin H. Gluck of New Springville, S.I., is to be married today to Dr. Gregory Davis Hirsch, a son of Joyce Davis and Dr. Gerald P. Hirsch, both of Suffern, N.Y. Rabbi David Azen is to perform the ceremony at the Livingston (N.J.) Country Club.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: HISTORY, eerie mystery, quirky comedy and memorable drama enliven the week ahead.

title: Footnotes Get the Boot
description: Footnotes, the badge of scholars, the bane of students, are fast fading from the published margins of academia where they have served not only to edify (op. cit., ibid., daggers!) but sometimes to bring the nimble flow of thesis and thought to a full stop. Attribute them to the anti-Cartesians (they noted, therefore, they were), who seemed to argue that sourcing, not reasoning alone, was knowledge.

title: Places Teen-Agers Can Call Their Own
description: MEGAN CLARK talks about Simsbury the way many teen-agers refer to their hometowns. The operative word is boring.

title: Should a Person Be Auctioned Off?
description: Am I overreacting or was Diane Ketcham's item (''Long Island Journal,'' July 28) about the Swartzes' of Old Field auctioning off the services of their butler-chauffeur, John ( who was not even dignified with a last name) as offensive as it seems on first reading?

title: The Risk of In-Line Skating
description: According to the U.S. Consumer Products Safety Commission, of C.P.S.C., there have been 42 deaths of in-line skaters since January 1992; of these, 9 occurred in New York, the most of any state. Nearly all of these deaths were of people not wearing helmets, as was the case with 28-year-old Liora Natelson, who died on Wednesday of massive head injuries after colliding with a bicyclist last Sunday.

title: A Candidate Cites His Race As Credential
description: James T. Conolly, an immigrant from the Cayman Islands, is running for the State Assembly seat in the 42d District on the premise that a predominantly Caribbean immigrant and African-American district is best represented by a black and not a white person.

title: A Tour to Poland With Focus on Culture
description: Poland's historical legacy is the subject of a 12-day tour sponsored by the Kosciuszko Foundation, a New York organization. The Cultural Heritage of Poland tour will leave from both New York and Chicago on Oct. 3.

title: Prague
description: To the Editor: For travelers to ''Prague's Historic Cemeteries'' (June 2), an essential literary companion is Jiri Weil's absurdist Holocaust novel ''Life With a Star.'' Because of a bureaucratic error, the book's protagonist is sent to the Jewish cemetery on a labor crew (cum Greek chorus), rather than to his death. An ironic tale, it is filled with black humor.

title: Pollen Count
description: THE FORGOTTEN POLLINATORS

title: His Lessons In Living Will Endure
description: Virgil Thomson is never far from our minds, he perhaps more than his music. Never has anyone written and composed so much and said so little about himself, and still it is the man that we most remember: the charm, wit and sly iconoclasm. We love that reflective shield of his, shining on the world around him but never on himself. The Thomson public persona was an artwork, art by deflection.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: 'Seedy' Label Doesn't Fit Eighth Avenue
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Wollman, Anthony G. Gomes
description: Susan Lynn Wollman, the daughter of Louise Wollman of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Barry Wollman of Los Angeles, was married last evening to Anthony George Gomes, a son of Ann Marie Gomes of Bedford, N.Y., and George Gomes of New York. Town Justice Francis J. Navarra of Cornwall, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the University Club in New York.

title: How to Put Fluorescent Lighting to Its Best Use
description: IN 1938, the first practical fluorescent light fixtures were introduced in the American marketplace. These lights used less power and lasted longer than incandescent bulbs, so they quickly became the standard in offices, stores and industry.

title: The 00's
description: PEOPLE MAY DIFfer about the adjective that best describes the last decade -- greedy, gaudy, self-absorbed -- but there's no question about the noun: it was, of course, the 80's, just as this decade, though yet uncharacterized, is indisputably the 90's. What remains lamentably unclear is the name of the next decade -- a question that has suddenly gone from being academic to being, well, academic. In a few days, all across the country, the Class of '00 will enter its freshman year. It's none too soon to marshal a consensus for what to call the years 2000 through 2009.

title: Chechnya Foes Agree to Truce as Envoy Fails to Oust General
description: Top Russian and rebel field commanders in Chechnya said today that they had agreed to give cease-fire orders to their troops. If a truce holds, it would be a victory for the Russian national security adviser, Aleksandr I. Lebed, who last week traveled twice to the region to seek peace.

title: Summer Concerts End With Double-Headers
description: TWO major classical festivals, Caramoor in Katonah and Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, both call it a summer this afternoon, and the Croton Point Park Concerts bow out with a double-header next weekend.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: More Than Mere Trinkets

title: A Wry Poet To the Devoted
description: OFTEN WHEN MUSICIANS ARE SAID TO have cult followings, it simply means they don't sell many records. The British singer-songwriter Robyn Hitchcock, however, is a cult artist in the truest sense. For nearly two decades his fans have displayed a loyalty rare in the fickle world of popular music.

title: Fantasy Land
description: CHILDISH THINGS

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: AND THE ANGELS SING

title: In Secaucus, Pride in the Lure and Lore of 'The Man on the Roof'
description: On a clear night in downtown Secaucus, a silhouette of a man standing on a rooftop pierces the suburban skyline.

title: Maria McCann, Jay C. Ghazal
description: Maria Christina McCann, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William P. McCann of Andover, Mass., was married yesterday to Jay Chabou Ghazal, a son of Mrs. and Mrs. Chabou Ghazal of North Providence, R.I. The Rev. Fritz Cerullo performed the ceremony at St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church in Boston. The Very Rev. A. G. Doumato, the dean of the Syrian Orthodox priests in North America and the bridegroom's uncle, took part in the ceremony.

title: His Life Is His Mind
description: DR. JAMES HALL LAY ON A hospital bed unable to move or speak. A respirator pumped oxygen into his lungs. Doctors were talking to his wife, Suzanne, and his best friend, Bill Walker. He could comprehend every word. During occasional waves of paranoia, he was convinced that he was about to be sold for body parts.

title: Sure, Play Sports Moderately -- but Play!
description: To the Editor:

title: A View From the 20's
description: Children of the information age, these photographers are hyper-aware that everything has been photographed before. But looking at this series of pictures, from a collection edited by Alice Rose George, a distinct esthetic emerges, one that is familiar from movies and television. Like the current generation of independent film makers, these photographers have turned inward, to their immediate environments, shooting intimate, everyday images with wry distance and self-conscious kitsch. Objective reality is not the aim: whether portraying characters at a strip mall or the local Motel 6, these pictures evoke more than they document, feeling raw and detached at the same time.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: TODAY

title: Last Year's Heroes Still Feel Pain
description: LAST October, Randy Johnson and David Cone watched each other commit sport's most unnatural act: throwing a baseball from 60 feet 6 inches. They have great respect for how the other man suffered. ''We've both been humbled this year,'' Cone said.

title: For the Boomer in Chief, It's the A.A.R.P. Birthday
description: TOMORROW morning, in the hour after dawn, William Jefferson Clinton will mark a milestone that mortals have dreaded and celebrated for generations: he is turning 50. ''Considering the alternative,'' Mr. Clinton said ruefully at an end-of-vacation party here Friday night, ''I think I will.''

title: A Snapshot Of Influence Of Caribbean
description: At a celebration of Jamaican independence in Prospect Park the other day, the seating arrangement offered a snapshot of the political heavyweights of Caribbean Brooklyn.

title: A Promise of Deficits
description: To the Editor:

title: Cold Water Thrown On 'North Slope Fever'
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Seedy' Label Doesn't Fit Eighth Avenue
description: To the Editor:

title: Jerry Lewis: The Good, the Bad, the French Farces
description: Tonight, the Arts and Entertainment Network presents a special two-hour ''Biography'' on America's favorite brilliantine-haired comic, Jerry Lewis. Unfortunately, the otherwise-fine program -- produced with Lewis's cooperation -- ignores or scarcely mentions various projects that Lewis would rather forget. Fortunately, Jerry still has fervent fans who (meaning no harm) want it all. A case in point is Frank Reda, a 45-year-old devotee from Yonkers who obsessively collects anything Jerry. Here's his tour of the forbidden zone.

title: Camp Helps To Prepare Poor Youths To Get Jobs
description: As Andre Mitchell sat on a small slope of grass and stared at the impressive view, he tried to sum up his three years in the Career Awareness Program at Camp Mariah in Fishkill, N.Y.

title: A Common Voice for the Municipalities
description: THE Connecticut Conference of Municipalities was formed 30 years ago this fall with 16 cities and towns as members. Today 142 of the state's 169 towns belong, representing more than 90 percent of the population.

title: It's Nostalgia Time on Team Canada
description: With each crisp pass of the puck, you could see the familiarity beginning to return. Mark Messier would swoop across the blue line, snap a pass onto the tape of Wayne Gretzky's stick, and make a beeline for the net, anticipating the return pass.

title: A Touch of the JapaneseIn Leaf, Bloom and Setting
description: THE distinctive styles of Japanese plants and gardens have long held a fascination for Western gardeners.

title: The Politics Of Me
description: Is it just me, or is somebody else out there sick of hearing Bob Dole yak about himself?

title: Colossal Figures, Both Otherworldly And of the Earth
description: TO GET TO ''Olmec Art of Ancient Mexico,'' the hypnotic display of pre-Columbian sculpture at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, you descend underground, leaving daylight far behind.

title: Realty Institute Gets First Director
description: The architect and developer Henry Wollman, a proponent of cooperation between the private, public and not-for-profit sectors in real estate activities, has been named the first director of the year-old Steven L. Newman Real Estate Institute at Baruch College of the City University of New York.

title: Persuading Nature to Perform Its Stormy Weather Dances
description: FOR DAYS Ned Kahn has been tinkering with a 40-foot-high tornado that is obstinately refusing to happen. The four-story vortex was supposed to be the star attraction in ''Turbulent Landscapes,'' Mr. Kahn's farewell show at San Francisco's Exploratorium, where he has been an artist-in-residence for more than a dozen years. But instead of whirling into a clearly defined funnel, the mist pouring from the top of the tornado tower forms an occasional flabby spiral and, most of the time, no particular shape at all.

title: Kimberly Short, R.W. Morgner Jr.
description: Kimberly Kirsten Short, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald F. Short of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there on Friday evening to Richard Walter Morgner Jr., a son of Louise A. Morgner of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Mr. Morgner. The Rev. Joseph L. Dietz performed the ceremony at Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church.

title: WORK
description: The disappearance of work in the ghetto cannot be ignored, isolated or played down. Employment in America is up. The economy has churned out tens of millions of new jobs in the last two decades. In that same period, joblessness among inner-city blacks has reached catastrophic proportions. Yet in this Presidential election year, the disappearance of work in the ghetto is not on either the Democratic or the Republican agenda. There is harsh talk about work instead of welfare but no talk of where to find it.

title: These Ugly Ducks Swim in a Shallow Pond
description: WHEN I WAS GROWING up, mothers told their daughters ''beauty is as beauty does.'' It was at the Gloria and the Riviera, two movie palaces in Charleston, S.C., that I learned honesty about beauty.

title: A Postgraduate Lesson in Borscht
description: Once I grimaced at the taste of what passed as borscht in my college dining hall. Not to worry, said a suite mate of mine who was from Poland; you will know good borscht when you taste it.

title: Carl A. Beam, 76, Biology Professor
description: Carl Adam Beam, a professor of biology at Brooklyn College for 25 years, died on Aug. 2 at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 76 and lived in Brooklyn. The cause was cancer, his family said.

title: Kidnapped
description: The Deep End of the Ocean

title: Giants Express Concerns Over Traffic
description: The owners of the New York Giants are expressing concerns that a $265 million complex of theaters and shops planned for the Meadowlands Sports Complex will worsen the already congested game-day traffic.

title: Finding Drama in Music Itself
description: MOST CELEBRATED conductors bring distinctive musical personalities to their performances. Think of Wilhelm Furtwangler's organic spaciousness, Leonard Bernstein's hormonal expressivity, Herbert von Karajan's inexorable grandeur or, in his prime, Georg Solti's kinetic energy.

title: INSIDE
description: Panel Has Gingrich Report

title: Helping Bosnian Students Go to School
description: WHEN Alisa Mujagic talks about camp, she is not remembering canoe trips by moonlight or pillow fights with bunk mates in a rustic New England cabin. Ms. Mujagic, a 23-year-old junior at Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, spent more than two months at Trnopolje, a concentration camp in Bosnia. Her hometown, Kozarac, near Banja Luka in northwest Bosnia, was destroyed in a Serbian attack in 1992.

title: Question of Family Violence Arises in a Kevorkian Suicide Case
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian said today that he was ''surprised and startled'' by press reports that a Massachusetts woman who committed suicide on Thursday night with his aid had accused her husband of assaulting her last month.

title: A Family's Children Blend Old and New
description: AT the intersection of Head of Pond and Deerfield Roads in the Hamptons lies Tom and Dot Halsey's 75-acre farm, where life and work has changed with the times and where the true constant is family.

title: Surviving a Crash
description: Twenty-three years ago this summer, two of my sisters were killed in a plane crash at Logan Airport in Boston, victims of pilot and tower error and, ultimately, the pea-soup fog that blankets the coastline in July. For years my father, a career Marine Corps pilot, had flown hundreds of people thousands of miles. As a result, we five kids grew up regarding planes as ordinary magic: we got on them, went someplace and got off. In fact, the day after my sisters died, the youngest one and I would both land at Logan, cruising low over the crash site as my parents and brother waited.

title: Youths Learn How to Farm The Hard Way
description: ''DON'T eat me, I'm not food!'' protested Kara Rothschild, an 8-year-old camper, holding a New Hampshire hen. Being a camper at Cliffdale Farm has its hazards. The geese attack; the hens sometimes bite, and the stables have to be mucked out. But the rewards include countless nuzzles and licks from the pony Chocolate Kisses.

title: He's a Real Detective. And He Plays One on TV.
description: DURING his 25 years as a New York City police officer and homicide detective, many of them in the East Village, James Pelliccio has seen his share of bloody endings.

title: John D. Delafield, Cecile H. Roach
description: Cecile Howland Roach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Thurston Roach 2d of Seattle, was married there yesterday to John Dennis Delafield, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Dennis Delafield of New York. The Rev. Whitney Devine performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of the Epiphany.

title: The Remedy
description: IN JUNE, WE ASKED READERS TO COMPLETE A SHORT STORY BEGUN BY THE NOVELIST NICHOLSON BAKER -- AND THEY DID, more than 2,000 of them. As we read through the responses, we were struck by their similarities. A handful of common fantasies -- Revenge of the Nerds, the Treachery of Women, Love Conquers All -- were played out by Baker's characters Plunket, Sturm and Bilbane. As the deadline approached, we faced down crates of Federal Express packages and envelopes, from lawyers, homemakers, research scientists, a class of seventh graders and at least one prison inmate. Stories were sent in from Australia, South America, Europe and down the block on 43d Street.

title: Payton and Bradshaw Join Hall of Famers
description: A year after opening its new home, the College Football Hall of Fame in South Bend, Ind., let in its first class of small-college players. Fourteen former players and coaches from schools in National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I-AA, II, III and the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics were inducted yesterday, including WALTER PAYTON and TERRY BRADSHAW.

title: An Ex-Model Now, Wearing No Makeup
description: Alison Elliott's favorite extracurricular activity is sleeping, 12 hours a night, schedule permitting. She has even done 18-hour marathons. One natural byproduct of all this sleeping is a lot of dreaming, and on a spring afternoon she was wrestling with a particularly vivid episode from the previous night. The plot had her trying to go to London having forgotten her passport. You don't have to be Jung to figure out this anxiety bout. Ms. Elliott, 26, was in fact on her way to London in a few days to begin shooting ''The Wings of the Dove,'' based on the Henry James novel, a film starring Helena Bonham Carter and Linus Roache.

title: The Speed of Arbitration
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SEX OFFENDER NEXT DOOR
description: Peter Davis reports that E. B., ''a model inmate,'' was released on parole after serving only 16 years of his combined 53-year sentence (''The Sex Offender Next Door,'' July 28). One presumes that he had no access to young boys during his prison stay. The ability to adhere to rigid guidelines for behavior in a highly structured setting is not predictive of adequate functioning outside.

title: THE SEX OFFENDER NEXT DOOR
description: I was disturbed and infuriated by Peter Davis's article. It is an insult to the parents of those murdered children to hear E. B.'s former therapist, Kay Jackson, ask him on the phone how he's holding up under the ''pressure,'' and then sympathize by saying, ''Jeez Louise, it must be tough.'' Tough? Tough is when your child is raped and buried alive by the likes of an E. B. to suffocate to death.

title: Retirement Plan for Small Business Would Help the Boss, Too
description: AT the Auto World repair shop near here, a co-owner, Charles Sullivan, is constantly clipping how-to articles to help train his mechanics.

title: Dead Reckoning
description: For fans of Quincy and Kay Scarpetta, there's a new doctor in town. She is Samantha Ryan, a Belfast-born forensic pathologist, the protagonist of a new crime series that begins with SILENT WITNESS: BURIED LIES - TUESDAY at 9 P.M. on A&E. In her debut, Sam deals with the seemingly accidental drowning of a young girl. As the case unfolds the girl's death turns out to have links to an earlier murder and to a young woman serving a prison term for killing her baby. Amanda Burton stars with John McGlynn as Detective Inspector Adams and Clare Higgins as his boss, Detective Superintendent Farmer. The mystery series is co-produced by A&E and the BBC.

title: THE NEXT PRO-LIFERS
description: Advocates of assisted suicide overlook the fact that creating this ''right'' creates a new obligation for doctors. Asking doctors to perform ''assisted suicide'' means asking them to kill. Even those of us who would choose to avoid the procedure must in some way participate, in efforts to teach, supervise and regulate any practice that becomes standard in our profession.

title: Putting Aside Differences to Go Rescue Dad
description: House Arrest

title: A Sting and a Warning about Selling Cigarettes to Teen-Agers
description: At Katrina's Korner Variety, Doris Merino sold a pack of Newport Lights to a customer she figured was 20 years old.

title: Road to Good Intentions Is Paved With Pate
description: ''THE worst thing in America today,'' Betty Friedan, enthroned in a wooden chair on a rolling lawn, was saying on Aug. 10, ''is the growing disparity between the rich and everybody else.''

title: Immigration Service Keeps a Wary Eye on Its Newark Office
description: When agents from the Immigration and Naturalization Service's office here swooped down on a private cleaning company at Newark International Airport in March 1995, they detained scores of illegal immigrants, recovering a trove of more than 60 fraudulently issued green cards and other work papers.

title: If Right Is Center, Where Is Left?
description: FREE-MARKET capitalism seems triumphant worldwide, the new consensus at the end of the century. So with President Clinton heading to his convention sounding like George Bush and Republicans now complaining about economic injustice, what's left of the left?

title: Sunnyside Is Setting For First Jazz Festival
description: THE charming, pastoral setting where Washington Irving once enjoyed parlor music will swing next Saturday and Sunday from noon till 8 P.M. Called the First Sunnyside Jazz Festival, the planners are hoping for 2,000 to 3,000 visitors during the weekend.

title: Tuning Out the Campaign Will Be Difficult for Voters
description: Buoyed by their peaceful convention here this week, Republicans say the White House is within Bob Dole's grasp if he succeeds in a two-pronged strategy of convincing voters that his economic prescriptions would be a boon to all taxpayers and that President Clinton is so tainted by ethical questions that he should not be re-elected.

title: Remembering a Hero, A Man Who Would 'Light Up a Party'
description: JOHN WILLSHER died a hero's death. On Feb. 11, 1995, a blustery cold day, two boys decided to explore the wide spot of a frozen river where New Haven meets Woodbridge. The ice broke. Across the street, John Willsher was telephoning the husband of a stranded motorist when he heard the screams. He ran to his truck to fetch strong rope, and although he crawled carefully across the ice, it gave way, plunging him into the frigid water. He grabbed one of the two boys, 7-year-old Brian Bates. Another boy, Kerone Smith, 9, wrapped the rope around himself and was dragged to the bank. The exertion plus the bitter cold was too much for Mr. Willsher. Just four days shy of his 58th birthday he had a heart attack and, despite efforts of paramedics, Mr. Willsher died on the river bank.

title: Are Two Tests Enough? Are Four Too Many?
description: Newark may not be the only school district to cut back on specialists who evaluate disabled students this year. State Commissioner of Education Leo F. Klagholz has proposed a plan that would allow students to be evaluated by two specialists instead of four.

title: Julie A. Knight, Karl A. Maier
description: Julie Ann Knight, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Knight of Hingham, Mass., was married yesterday to Karl Anthony Maier, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Maier of Ketchum, Idaho. The Rev. John Morgan performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Snows Roman Catholic Church in Sun Valley, Idaho.

title: A Funky Renewal Transforms Fifth Avenue
description: Along Fifth Avenue, what was once a strip of empty storefronts, bodegas and Chinese restaurants with bulletproof windows is changing into one of Brooklyn's most eclectic commercial thoroughfares.

title: Americans Are Still Voting for J.F.K.
description: WHY make do with just Bill Clinton and Bob Dole? If Americans could pick a President, any President, which one would they choose to run the country today?

title: What to Do When the Surf's Up
description: Surfers say it violates their civil rights to beach them for safety reasons when storms create big waves. What do you think?

title: Sizing Up Dole and Company: Voices From the East Coast to the West
description: With the end of the Republican National Convention, Republicans, Democrats and independent voters around the nation reacted to the four-day event.

title: Making the C.I.A. Accountable
description: Nowhere has the Central Intelligence Agency dishonored America more thoroughly or consistently than in Guatemala. Last year, allegations that a C.I.A.-paid Guatemalan agent was involved in the 1990 murder of an American innkeeper, Michael DeVine, set off a series of investigations and led to significant changes in the agency's policies and practices. Many of these show a welcome new spirit of reform, but the C.I.A. must be more accountable still to prevent the recurrence of misconduct.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: So What's New?
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: Eagle's Plume

title: Deepak's Days in Court
description: In Deepak Chopra's 1995 best seller, ''The Seven Spiritual Laws of Success,'' the mind-body theorist from India advocates bestowing a prayer or flower on every person you meet. But Chopra uses much tougher tactics when he gets slammed in the media: the multimillion-dollar lawsuit, or threat thereof. Late last month, Chopra sued The Weekly Standard -- a Washington-based conservative magazine owned by Rupert Murdoch -- over a July cover story that criticized Chopra's work and personal life. The $35 million claim says that the writer, Matt Labash, libeled Chopra by alleging, among other things, that he hired a San Francisco prostitute in 1991.

title: The G.O.P.'s Back Stairs
description: In the end, the Buchanan ''peasants,'' as Patrick Buchanan likes to call his delegates, went to San Diego, and, like the proverbial disappointed tourist, all they got was this lousy pro-life plank.

title: In Britain, Medical Drama at a Mannerly Pace
description: THE PATIENT WAS SLIPPING away, her worried husband told Dr. Erica Matthews. Her breathing was shallow, her temperature high, her strength dwindling. But when Dr. Matthews went to help, she found an even bigger problem than she had imagined: the dying patient turned out to be a figment of the old man's imagination.

title: Doing a Star Turn for the Home Team, at Last
description: BY THE time Tab Ramos was in high school, at St. Benedict's Prep in Newark, he was a popular, friendly student. Yet he rarely went out partying, never had to be given a curfew, and always did his schoolwork.

title: Borders Fall To Trade in Classic Autos
description: COLLECTIBLE cars live in their own economic world. In the late 1980's, when the Japanese yen was strong and the American dollar was weak, buyers flocked from Japan to snap up vintage Ferraris, Maseratis and other exotic autos in the United States. They also filled their garages with huge American-made gas guzzlers from the 60's.

title: Floyd Takes Narrow Lead In Northville
description: Ray Floyd has trouble hiding his pride about the way he has been playing golf lately. In his last four tournaments, Floyd has won once, finished third once and fourth twice. And he will go into Sunday's final round of the Northville Long Island Classic as the man to catch.

title: Enchanter at the Crossroads Of Pop and Sacred
description: HE is one of the world's biggest stars. Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan has spent three decades turning an esoteric form of music -- qawwali, the singing style of Pakistan's Sufi Muslim mystics -- into an international buzzword. He has been interviewed on MTV and VH1 and collaborated with Eddie Vedder of Pearl Jam and Peter Gabriel.

description: A MAN and an older woman have been driving from Manhattan every Wednesday, Friday and Saturday for the last two and a half years to eat at Il Tulipano.

description: With the end of the Republican National Convention, Republicans, Democrats and independent voters around the nation reacted to the four-day event.

title: Coming-Out Party
description: HOUSE AND HOMEBy Steve Gunderson and Rob Morris with Bruce Bawer.327 pp. New York: Dutton. $24.95. The political autobiography of Steve Gunderson, Republican member of Congress from Wisconsin, and his companion, Rob Morris, an architect-builder in Washington, with assistance from the writer Bruce Bawer, has a double-edged title, ''House and Home.'' Told largely in Mr. Gunderson's voice - though Mr. Morris's chapters are vital - the book opens with the vituperative conservative Congressman Robert Dornan of California outing Mr. Gunderson on the floor of the House in the spring of 1994 and takes off from there.

title: Herman's the Boss in This Harbor
description: HE'S the most talked about guy in Milford these days, old Herman. At the ice cream stand, the diner, the corner grocer, most everybody has something to say about Herman: He's protective and loyal. A curmudgeon. The best thing that ever happened to Milford Harbor. The worst.

title: Meggan Towell, Mitchel Friedman
description: Meggan Morgan Towell, the daughter of Mimi and Thomas Towell of New York, was married yesterday to Mitchel Spencer Friedman, the son of Diane and Ivan Friedman of Westport, Conn. description: In the summer nights, soft floodlights bathe the pale limestone walls of this medieval city in the most obvious gesture that the welcome sign is up and normality is returning after war.

It was the the American women's gymnastic team, at an exhibition days after the group won the gold medal, wiggling with giggly teen-age verve, arms akimbo, to the dance craze of the summer of 1996: macarena.

title: Robyn Minter, Bertrand Smyers
description: Robyn Marie Minter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steven A. Minter of Shaker Heights, Ohio, was married yesterday to Bertrand Hunter Smyers, a son of Delores M. Smyers and Thomas B. Smyers, both of Glenshaw, Pa. The Rev. Kent Organ performed the ceremony with the Rev. Martin Amos, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Fairmount Presbyterian Church in Cleveland Heights, Ohio.

title: In the Guatemalan Civil War, Some Glimmers of Peace
description: After squandering a generation in a 35-year civil war that has killed more than 100,000 people, Guatemala is suddenly trying to make up for lost time. A de facto cease-fire between guerrilla and Government forces is now in place, and the two sides last week promised a final peace accord before the end of the year. The mere prospect of peace is already producing profound changes in Guatemalan society, the most far-reaching of which has been the re-emergence of the country's Mayan majority. Freed from the fear of repression, they have in recent months begun asserting themselves as a political, cultural and religious force. LARRY ROHTER

title: Katya Chorover And John Grandt
description: Katya Sarah Chorover, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stephan L. Chorover of Brookline, Mass., is to be married today to John Stein Grandt, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward J. Grandt of Elmira, N.Y. Rabbi Theodore H. Stainman is to perform the ceremony at Kiana Lodge in Poulsbo, Wash.

description: Rachel Aliza Levine, a daughter of Sybil and Leon Levine of Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., is to be married today in Cherry Hill, N.J., to Andrew Jay Ceresney, the son of Elinor and Ian Ceresney of New York. Rabbi Abraham I. Levene is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Sons of Israel.

title: Labor and Clergy Are Reuniting To Help the Underdogs of Society
description: More than at any other time in decades, religious leaders are making common cause with trade unions, lending their moral authority to denounce sweatshops, back a higher minimum wage and help organize janitors and poultry workers.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Catherine Bunis, J.J. McDonough
description: Catherine Poe Bunis, the daughter of Ann and Alvin W. Bunis of Cincinnati, was married yesterday to Joseph James McDonough, the son of Isabel and James J. McDonough of Fishkill, N.Y. The Rev. Paul Long, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Indian Hill Episcopal-Presbyterian Church in Cincinnati. The Rev. Francis Bellew, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Yorktown Marks Anniversary Of Rochambeau's Encampment
description: NEXT Wednesday the town of Yorktown will mark a special date: Rochambeau Day. On Tuesday, the French Ambassador to the United States, Francois Bugon de L'Estang, is sending his deputy chief of mission, Hughes Pernet, to deliver his personal congratulations to the Yorktown Town Board at a public meeting in Downing Park. Town Supervisor Linda G. Cooper is issuing a proclamation formally commemorating Aug. 21, the day 215 years ago when 3,500 Frenchmen stayed the night in what is now Yorktown Heights.

title: Security a Patchwork At Europe's Airports
description: The crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 off Long Island last month has set off a new round of security discussions, inside the United States and on the international level after a meeting of G-7 countries on security held in Paris at the end of last month.

title: For Doctors, Togetherness Is the New Way of Life
description: DR. MICHAEL KRAMER is an internist and cardiologist who practices on the Upper East Side on Manhattan. But lately he has been spending as much time managing his Manhattan Primary Care medical group and physicians' network as he does with patients.

description: Threshold

title: In Newark, a Hard Look at Special Education and Social Workers
description: When more than 4,000 children with physical and mental disabilities return to school here next month, most of the 69 social workers who kept tabs on them last year will not be waiting. Some will be out of a job, and others will be reassigned to different departments as part of a plan to cut administrative costs and improve instruction in New Jersey's largest school district.

description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: North Dakota Ranches Riding High on the Return of Buffalo
description: In this table-flat corner of the Northern Plains, where wheat fields and barbed wire stretch to the horizon, a shiny new, eight-foot-high chain-link fence has been built under the watchful eye of sanitary inspectors from the faraway European Union.

title: Giants Are Uncertain, But Jets Have a Plan
description: FIRST blood flows tomorrow.

title: O'Brien Goes From Wild Card To Winner
description: The early 1990's were heady times for Alex O'Brien. A four-time all-American at Stanford, he became the only player ever to pull off the collegiate tennis hat trick when, during his senior year in 1992, he won the singles and doubles titles in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament and also led Stanford to the team title.

title: Israel's New Poor: Foreign Laborers
description: A Romanian worker is sprawled across the curb, beer slopping from the bottle he knocked over as he passed out. He does not stir when a haggard, elderly woman swats him with a broom and yells about sleeping elsewhere.

title: USA Today, the Fast Food Of Dailies, Is Expanding Menu
description: Tom Curley was the hotshot young director of market research for USA Today when the Gannett Company began publishing the paper in 1982. From time to time, he circulated pleading memos showing that sales jumped whenever the new national daily put hard news on the front page, instead of the standard stories with happy endings or pictures of children washing their pets.

title: Welfare Bill: Legislating Morality?
description: IN passing its new welfare bill, Congress abandoned the New Deal's guarantee of cash assistance to the nation's poorest children and cut the welfare budget so deeply that even Republican advocates of welfare reform, like Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki, voiced serious reservations.

title: People
description: * Darryl Lindberg, president of DDB Canada Advertising and chairman and chief executive of DDB Group Canada, Toronto, units of the Omnicom Group, was named to the new position of president at DDB Needham South America, New York, effective Oct. 1. Succeeding Mr. Lindberg at DDB Canada will be Stephen Thursby, who will continue as creative director. And Norman Rigg, president at Anderson Advertising, Toronto, part of DDB Group Canada, will be promoted to chairman and chief executive at DDB Group Canada. Graham Avery, group assistant director at Anderson Advertising, will succeed Mr. Rigg there.

title: Kemp Attacks Clinton's Abortion Veto
description: Ending a cross-country sweep marked by huge and enthusiastic crowds, many cheering Bob Dole's selection of Jack Kemp as a running mate, Mr. Kemp stepped forward today and attacked President Clinton's opposition to the ban on certain abortions after 20 weeks. He called such late-term abortions a ''tragedy'' that tarnished the nation's reputation across the world.

title: A Soccer Goal
description: A children's soccer field? Not in my backyard, some Princeton Township residents say. The township wants to buy a 38-acre farm for a youth soccer league, which is losing access to fields at Princeton University because the university now needs them for its own students. The township has lined up $1.8 million in state grants and loans to buy the farm, and an anonymous donor has offered $1 million to get the fields in shape, said Jack Roberts, recreation director for Princeton Township and Borough. But neighbors are worried about noise and crime at the site, as well as bond debt and increased traffic. Tonight they will state their case to the Township Committee, said T. Burnet Fisher, head of the group that opposes the plan.

title: Bridge
description: It has been recognized since the early days of the game that a player must be on very sure ground to double a confidently bid slam. The reason is purely mathematical.

description: Baseball

title: Coldwell Banker Reviews Account
description: The Coldwell Banker Corporation, the residential real estate brokerage that was acquired in May by HFS Inc., has placed in review its account, which has been handled since 1990 by the Los Angeles office of Grey Advertising.

title: Disney Names New Chairman of Movie Group
description: The Walt Disney Company has promoted Richard W. Cook, its domestic distribution and worldwide marketing chief, to chairman of its motion picture group, as part of a reorganization that will cut film production in half.

title: 'Earnest' Goals: First Times Under Ochs
description: One hundred years ago today -- C Vols. and 36,484 Nos. ago -- The New-York Times brought forth an edition of 12 pages, the fourth of which carried a one-paragraph announcement that Adolph S. Ochs of Chattanooga, Tenn., had become publisher and general manager of that moribund newspaper. The modest notice sat atop the day's only signed article, an editorial credo expressing Ochs's ''earnest aim'' to give the news concisely, clearly, promptly and impartially, without fear or favor.

description: Having shared a classroom with a boy or two over the course of her 11 years, Kara Benson has come to an important conclusion:

title: Season of the Grasshopper
description: This is a good hopper year in the West, if you happen to like hoppers. In an unscientific study conducted late one recent afternoon, it was discovered that if one walks with two dogs across a level 60-acre Wyoming pasture, one kicks up a gross of grasshoppers with every step, never mind what the dogs dislodge. When horses walk through the tall, dry grass, they lower their heads and weave them back and forth, watching the insects fan out, listening to the sudden eruption, which sounds like high wind on brittle leaves or a kingfisher's distant call.

title: 'Honest, Guys'
description: To the Editor:

title: No More Free Cells?
description: Chuck Rohde, a Clifton City Councilman, says the city jail is a nice, comfortable place. He doesn't have a problem with that. He just doesn't think anyone should be allowed to stay there at public expense. Mr. Rohde, inspired by a new law in New Mexico, has proposed that Clifton become the first town in the state to charge prisoners for a night in jail. He says $60 to $100 -- payable only upon conviction -- should cover the city's costs. Most Clifton prisoners are drunken drivers or domestic violence suspects, Mr. Rohde said, and ''are not indigent people.'' Assemblyman Gerald H. Zecker of Clifton plans to introduce a bill in September that would clear the way for the town to pass the measure.

title: Maybe Forgetting a Detail, but Never a Punch Line
description: Can those old Sid Caesar shows -- shades of live television -- have been as funny as memory holds? Impossible! But ''Caesar's Writers,'' tonight's happily chaotic reunion of the star and nine of his sometime accomplices, can turn you into a believer. The writers -- who include Neil Simon, Mel Brooks, Carl Reiner and Larry Gelbart -- have lost a certain amount of hair since the 1950's, but they retain the zest that went into the making of ''Your Show of Shows'' and ''Caesar's Hour,'' those vaudevilles of the tube that entered television lore.

description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Theater Seizes Days or Nights At Edinburgh
description: The 50th Edinburgh International Festival began with a loud hiccup this week when a mechanical failure forced the last-minute cancellation of ''Elsinore,'' Robert Lepage's one-man multimedia reworking of ''Hamlet.'' Brian McMaster, the festival's director, was shaken; Mr. Lepage apologized profusely, and British newspapers made sure the embarrassment did not go unnoticed.

title: The Musical Gifts: From 'Respect' to 'Happy Birthday'
description: President Clinton got ''Respect'' for his 50th birthday, when the 1960's hit was sung with sanctified fervor by Aretha Franklin. At Radio City Music Hall last night, it was an oddly appropriate song for an all-star campaign fund-raiser; its lyrics talk back to a man whose kisses are ''sweeter than honey,'' reminding him, ''So is my money!''

title: Home Improvement: On TV, on Line
description: In recent years, the do-it-yourself craze has not only fostered the success of hardware store chains like Home Depot, but has also created a vibrant side industry in programming. Television shows like ''This Old House,'' ''Hometime'' and ''New Yankee Workshop'' have extremely loyal followings, drawing weekend contractors and armchair home-improvement enthusiasts who relax by watching others do the work.

title: Without Fear or Favor
description: Exactly 100 years ago today, Adolph S. Ochs, the founding father of the modern Times, published a declaration of principles in these pages setting forth his goals for the respectable but failing newspaper he had just taken over. The 38-year-old publisher, who had already rescued a dying paper in Chattanooga, Tenn., now found himself pitted in New York against powerful, sensationalistic competitors in the heyday of yellow journalism. His statement envisioned a dignified and responsible alternative that would provide trustworthy news and opinion. One especially elegant and inspirational goal -- ''to give the news impartially, without fear or favor, regardless of party, sect, or interests involved'' -- has held a place of honor at The Times ever since. Ochs's statement, reprinted below, was widely quoted at the time and remains a worthy credo for journalists everywhere, however difficult to fulfill.

title: 9 Die in Crash of C-130 Carrying Clinton Cargo
description: A military plane carrying a Secret Service agent and an Air Force crew of eight crashed into a mountain minutes after taking off from President Clinton's Wyoming retreat late Saturday night, killing everyone on board, officials said.

description: One man is the incumbent and the other the challenger, but in many ways, the two candidates are strikingly similar. description: The condition of a police officer shot in the head during an ambush in Washington Heights last week was improving yesterday as investigators continued to search for the gunman, officials said.
