title: Article 1996081900000921904 -- No Title
description: The art of the footnote suffers only in part from lazy or fame-seeking scholars. Rather, market forces -- which have cut off state funding to accessible libraries, enabled the power of book chains and impelled university presses to package pulp scholarship -- alter the presentation of scholarly inquiry for the sake of commerce.

title: The Exuberance of Jazz, Translated Into Motion
description: Danny Buraczeski danced out onto the stage of the Studio Theater here at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival on Saturday afternoon looking very unlike the American jazz dancer that he is. Dressed in dark pants, shirt, shoes and vest, Mr. Buraczeski resembled a small, worn tailor or shoemaker just off the boat at Ellis Island. The solo that opened his ''Swing Concerto,'' danced to klezmer music by Brave Old World, was full of folk shapes and inflections, of careful verticals and sudden optimistic tilts into the wind.

title: Television Stations, Always Lucrative Ventures, Are Suddenly Hotter Than Ever
description: Who would have guessed that this year television stations, once thought to be the antique technology of the communications world, would prove the hottest properties in the media world.

title: Accident or Mass Murder? India's Food-Poisoning Mystery
description: With the death toll at 52 in what has been described as India's worst food poisoning case in many years and with 18 more patients still in intensive care, investigators in a textile town north of Bombay say they are still unsure whether the episode was a case of mass murder or an accident.

title: Padres' Fireworks End Mets' Mexican Journey
description: A weekend clothed in historic significance and immense possibilities for the future of major league baseball may have provided a festive atmosphere for ''La Primera Serie.'' But the bands, the clowns and the appreciative fans still couldn't mask Paul Wilson's tailspinning rookie season.

title: Advocate Editor Departs After 4 Years at the Helm
description: Jeff Yarbrough, who served for four years as editor in chief of The Advocate, has left the gay news magazine. Word in the industry has it that Mr. Yarbrough was discharged, but Mr. Yarbrough said he had resigned.

title: As Printer Sales Slide, Accessories Are Pushed
description: As prices of PC printers continue to fall and profit margins shrink, manufacturers are taking a cue from the fashion industry: sell accessories.

title: For Sonny Rollins, Time Is Not of the Essence
description: The legend, often stated, is this: When Sonny Rollins is on, he's the greatest living jazz improviser. When he's not so on, he's fascinatingly eccentric. It is a specialist's game to document the welter of be-bop, Tin Pan Alley and movie-musical tunes he plays whole or quickly passes through, but his tenor-saxophone discourse throughout is oversized and self-confident, a sustained act of gallantry, which still retains the elegant declamations of Coleman Hawkins and the fast-firing rhythms of Charlie Parker.

title: Hispanic Players Get Their Day in the Sun
description: The whole premise of the series between the Mets and Padres that unfolded in the heart of Mexico this weekend was to tap the markets of Latin America.

description: From the altar steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral, John Cardinal O'Connor offered a message of trial and redemption yesterday to the families and friends of the 230 people who died aboard Trans World Airlines Flight 800 a month ago.

title: Seymour Osborne, Theatrical Voice Coach, 93
description: Seymour Osborne, a theatrical voice coach who worked with Broadway stars for four decades, died on Tuesday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 93 and lived in Manhattan.

description: Anyone looking for a hint of reconciliation in the deadlocked Cyprus problem will not find it at the main checkpoint to the 112-mile-long buffer zone that divides this island's Greek and Turkish communities.

title: Nat Bassen, Fabric Chain Founder, 66
description: Nat Bassen, the founder and chief executive of a chain of fabric stores and an important donor to charitable causes, died on Aug. 11 at his home in Melville, L.I. He was 66.

title: Train Victim a Suicide
description: A New Jersey Transit train struck and killed a man standing on the tracks yesterday morning in what authorities said was a suicide. Steve Coleman, a spokesman for the railroad, said the train was heading west toward Newark at 60 miles an hour when the engineer noticed something that looked like debris on the tracks. As the engineer slowed the train the man stood up, but the train did not stop in time. Mr. Coleman said the man might be identified after an autopsy today.

description: They are 1-2 in exhibition play, the players that matter most still have not scored a touchdown and it is only two weeks from the regular season.

title: Massachusetts Miracle
description: President Clinton's elaborate fund-raising effort last night, the latest event in a record-breaking year for fund-raising for both parties, is a reminder that Congress has failed to reform the campaign financing system to limit the power of money. In Massachusetts, by contrast, Gov. William Weld and Senator John Kerry have struck a remarkable agreement to limit spending in their fiercely competitive Senate race. Their pact sets an honorable example for politicians nationwide.

title: Scaros & Casselman Gets a Bass Account
description: Crowne Plaza Hotels and Resorts, a unit of Bass P.L.C., has named Scaros & Casselman Advertising in Stamford, Conn., as agency of record for international advertising. The duties on that account, with billings estimated at $20 million, had been handled by various agencies since September 1994, when Crowne Plaza left Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York, which had also handled the account of a sibling, Holiday Inn Worldwide.

title: Calls Home From Bosnia Can Shell a G.I.'s Wallet
description: Pfc. Eddie Waiters had been wooing the same woman since the ninth grade and, on a recent leave from Bosnia back home in Chicago, he finally won her heart. Like any good boyfriend, he calls often. But being here in Bosnia presents a problem that became evident the other day after he had chatted with her, happily, for about two hours.

title: The Yaak's Last Stand
description: I love my valley. I love the last few dark, shadowy corners of national forests that have not had roads built into them. But now the Washington politicians (over the efforts of a courageous few) have turned vast new acreages of our public wildlands over to the timber industry, and I am watching truckload after truckload of healthy green timber roll out of the valley, while the last roadless areas are threatened as never before.

title: Turkey's Iran Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Curbing Nursing Costs

title: Clams Are Clean Again
description: For the first time in more than 25 years, clams in the Navesink River are clean enough to eat right from the water, at least from November to April. Officials from the Department of Environmental Protection are to declare 623 acres at the eastern end of the river open today to unrestricted commerical and recreational clamming during those months.

title: Reveling in Retro Pop (Ear Piercings Only)
description: There is an old adage that defines wisdom as being able to see both sides of an argument. The same is true of music. Having a true appreciation of music means not listening to one style exclusively, but listening to and understanding good music no matter what genre it belongs to. Most of the package tours that have come through the area this summer have catered not to music fans but to exclusionary listeners obsessed with a certain style, like hip-hop, heavy metal or disco.

title: Stocks Higher in Japan
description: Stocks were trading sharply higher here today. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 270.50 points, or 1.30 percent, to stand at 21,104.50. On Friday, the Nikkei index lost 134.25 points.

title: As Cuts Near, Signs Indicate Maddox Is Gone
description: The Giants have apparently decided to release the beleaguered backup quarterback Tommy Maddox, a move that was approved by Coach Dan Reeves and would finally sever a relationship between the coach and the player that goes back almost five years.

title: Science and scientists are facing some rough going as the millennium approaches.
description: THE millennium is close upon us, and science and technology are not going to have it easy. There have been polemics against scientific inquiry and technological advances -- Luddite arguments made by critics like Kirkpatrick Sale and maniacs like the Unabomber.

title: A Family's Bonanza in Yukon: The Contented Life
description: ''We did a whole bunch of dumb things but managed to survive the game,'' said Bernard Oud, a youthful-looking 56-year-old describing his last 20 years prospecting for gold in the Klondike.

title: Licenses for Home Inspectors
description: Home inspectors would have to be licensed under a bill approved on Thursday by an Assembly committee. The measure comes in the wake of several well-publicized cases in the state in which inspectors, who are hired by prospective buyers, signed off on homes that turned out to have serious structural flaws. ''The current law in New Jersey is so weak that it does little to prevent a huckster with a flashlight and clipboard from passing himself off as a house inspector,'' said Assemblyman Anthony Impreveduto, Democrat of Secaucus, the bill's sponsor. The Assembly may consider the measure when it reconvenes in September. ANDY NEWMAN

title: CHRONICLE
description: THEODORE C. SORENSEN's new book is titled ''Why I Am a Democrat,'' and though the lawyer who was special counsel to President Kennedy is a staunch party loyalist, he will miss the Democratic National Convention in Chicago next week.

title: Executive Changes
description: SAVOY PICTURES ENTERTAINMENT INC., New York, said it named Steve Carlston, general manager at KSTU, a television station in Salt Lake City owned by Fox, to the position of president of its four television stations. He replaces Tom Herwitz, who left Savoy to rejoin News Corp.'s Fox Television Stations Inc. unit. Mr. Horwitz had been vice president and general manager of WTTG, the Fox-owned-and-operated television station in Washington, from 1989 to 1993.

title: What's a 4-Byte Word for Puzzlers' Friend?
description: Puzzlers, take note: the biggest clue to doing crosswords in the 90's may be a nine-letter word that starts with a ''C'' -- computers.

title: Spies, Patriotic Ladies and Generals Who Contrived to Save the Union
description: THE SECRET WAR FOR THE UNIONThe Untold Story of Military Intelligence in the Civil WarBy Edwin C. FishelIllustrated. 734 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $35.

title: Wedding With a Difference
description: Fred Hochstrasser and his fiancee, Darlene Logan, did not want a church wedding, but they did not want a sterile town hall ceremony, either. They wanted a place with class. And they found it at the Thomas L. Shinn Funeral Home. The couple were wed in the funeral home's new chapel Saturday by Mayor James J. Mancini of Long Beach Township. The groom, owner of a local marina, and the bride, a yacht broker, plan a December honeymoon. The funeral director, Bill O'Brien, said yesterday that there would be no more weddings at the chapel. ''To try to schedule things like that in our business is difficult,'' he said. ''You never know when somebody is going to pass away.''

title: The Question for Woods: Is It Time to Go Pro?
description: Once again, Tiger Woods is standing on the precipice of golf history. This is a comfortable position for him, one he has occupied almost since the day he first picked up a golf club at the age of 11 months and became the game's version of Mozart.

title: Against the Best, Chaposa Springs Is Better
description: They called it the best field of fillies assembled this year, a test of champions and contenders, and they produced a rousing race at Saratoga today that ended with Chaposa Springs running down Capote Belle in the final strides to win the Ballerina Stakes by half a length for her sixth straight victory.

title: PEROT BEGINS HIS CAMPAIGN; VOWS TO END 2-PARTY SYSTEM AS HE RECALLS HIS '92 THEMES
description: Ross Perot, who four years ago won more votes than any independent Presidential candidate in 80 years, launched his campaign as the 1996 nominee of the Reform Party tonight with a denunciation of the two-party system and the promise to ''kill that little snake this time.''

title: 43 Booming Shots, And Still Swinging
description: He homered in his first Little League at-bat a tape-measure job of 175 feet -- and no ball park has held him since. Mark McGwire has everything Babe Ruth had, except 60 home runs, and Babe Ruth had everything Mark McGwire has, except a goatee, a Gold's Gym membership and a son. Both were former pitchers, both would never turn down a T-bone steak and both have swung desperately for the moon.

title: The Wrong Goal On Affirmative Action
description: To the Editor:

title: Footnotes Remain Part of Scholarly Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Credit Offerings Expected for the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: A New Executive At Merkley Newman
description: Three days after leaving TBWA Chiat/Day in New York, where he had been executive creative director, Marty Cooke has joined Merkley Newman Harty in New York as a partner and executive creative director, a new position.

title: Talked About but Unseen, '68 Stones Film Emerges
description: The Rolling Stones have made audiences wait before. But nearly three decades is a long time, even for a stadium concert.

title: Election-Year Posturing on Drugs
description: Elections invariably bring political maneuvers to help politicians look tough on drugs. This year is no exception. President Clinton has asked Congress for a 67 percent increase in American financial support for Latin American counternarcotics programs. By a close vote, the Senate recently agreed, paying for part of the $92 million increase by transferring $53 million that had been designated to aid the world's poorest citizens. The shift is doubly shameful, and should be reversed.

title: Q & A / John P. Ferriter : Asia's Growing Oil Requirements
description: Emerging as a major economic force, Asia is increasingly reliant on oil imports from outside the region. At a recent oil conference in Kuala Lumpur, John P. Ferriter, deputy executive director of the International Energy Agency based in Paris, discussed the issue with Michael Richardson of the International Herald Tribune.

title: Storm in St. Kitts, as a Cocaine Case Churns Politics
description: It started with a large shipment of cocaine into this tiny Caribbean country two years ago. The resulting scandal helped bring down one government, which was criticized for having done too little to combat drug trafficking, and now threatens another, which is suddenly under attack for supposedly having done too much.

title: Accounts
description: * Web TV Networks, Palo Alto, Calif., to Rubin Postaer & Associates, Santa Monica, Calif., as the first agency to handle the account of the on-line television service. Billings were estimated at $6 million to $8 million.

title: Clinton Can't Resist Conservative Drift
description: To the Editor:

title: Billion-Dollar Enigma
description: Outside the private office of Ross Perot in Dallas sits a bust of Theodore Roosevelt inscribed with these words, uttered by the 26th President in 1910:

title: Post Office Works on Image
description: After two gun incidents involving New Jersey postal workers last week, including one in Paterson, postal officials are considering closing down the 35-year-old Paterson Post Office Gun Club. ''It may be prudent at this time to ask them not to continue,'' William Ferry, Paterson's postmaster and a club member, told The Record of Hackensack. ''We may ask them to reincorporate under a new name, erasing any reference to the post office.''

title: Breaking the mold again, Whole Earth Review is asking subscribers for charity.
description: WHEN magazines hit the financial skids, they are generally either sold or killed; there is very little hope of finding an alternative. One tactic that would likely never occur to big magazine companies like Conde Nast or Hachette Filipacchi is to canvas subscribers for contributions.

title: Clinton Can't Resist Conservative Drift
description: To the Editor:

title: A pharmacist offers an alternative to progesterone injections for treating infertility.
description: ANY women being treated for infertility undergo twice-a-day injections of progesterone, a hormone that along with estrogen is essential for preparing the womb for a fertilized egg. The shots are painful and can have side effects ranging from skin boils to depression.

title: Clinton Has $10 Million Wish for Birthday Bash
description: Bill Clinton, the youngest President since John F. Kennedy, led his generation into its sixth decade last night with the ultimate in boomer birthday bashes: a Radio City fund-raising extravaganza of self-celebration and reflection drenched with more Top-40 nostalgia than ''The Big Chill.''

title: Bland's 6-Under Final Round Sinks Floyd in L.I. Classic
description: Eagle-birdie-birdie on three consecutive holes can get any golfer on the right track. John Bland of South Africa accomplished the feat starting at the third hole of the Meadow Brook Club this afternoon and went on to capture the Northville Long Island Classic by three shots.

title: A New Form of Wireless Phone Service Is in the Works for New York City
description: Sprint has Candice Bergen and MCI has Whoopi Goldberg. So why shouldn't Omnipoint go for the Princess of Wales?

title: Tax Man Blues
description: Bob Dole has called for ''ending the I.R.S. as we know it.'' In so doing, he joins a long list of distinguished bashers of the Internal Revenue Service. While the tax man will never be popular, why are so many people so angry with the I.R.S.?

title: Netscape Moves To Raise Stakes In Browser War
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation, striking back against last week's aggressive challenge from its archrival Microsoft, is expected to release a new version today of its Navigator Internet software that will include free ''home delivery'' of a broad array of news and sports information to an audience that could include millions of computer users.

title: Franklin Avenue Shuttle Derails
description: One car of a subway train derailed along the Franklin Avenue shuttle line in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon after it struck a piece of concrete that appeared to have been deliberately placed on the tracks, transit officials said.

title: Using One's Own Anguish to Help Others
description: Joan Dater has been consumed by the news since the first bulletin about the fiery crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800. She keeps track of every piece of wreckage recovered and every body, the ones that have been found and the ones that may never be found.

title: Sharp Captures Indy 200, Right Side Up
description: Twelve years ago, Scott Sharp started his racing career here and won. Two years ago, he raced here and wound up on his head. Today, he kept his wheels pointing down, and won again.

title: Bridge
description: It has been recognized since the early days of the game that a player must be on very sure ground to double a confidently bid slam. The reason is purely mathematical.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Western Power Blackout Underlines System Flaws

title: Gulf War Syndrome
description: To the Editor:

title: Colin's Dream
description: I felt a sense of uneasiness, and a sharp and unexpected disappointment, as I stood, notebook in hand, and watched Gen. Colin Powell deliver his feel-good speech to the Republican National Convention last week.

title: A British agency gets the Sebastiani account, while a French one expands in Mexico and Brazil.
description: TWO agencies, one based in Britain and the other in France, are making news in North and South America.

title: Support Plane For President Crashes in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  Rescue teams on foot and horseback searched through smoldering wreckage Sunday after an air force transport plane that was part of President Bill Clinton's support team slammed into a rocky and barren mountainside overlooking Jackson Hole, Wyoming.

title: I Navigate, You Explore, They Make Money
description: Software for the Internet, and the private-network versions of the Internet known as ''Intranets,'' can be divided into two broad categories: ''client'' software for desktop computers, and ''server'' software for network-controller computers.

title: Dumber and Dumber
description: To the Editor:

title: Blackout May Be Caution Sign on Road to Utility Deregulation
description: As a handful of electrical lines in southern Oregon sagged in the summer heat last weekend and then began shutting down in a chain of short circuits that blacked out power to more than four million people in nine states, there was a brief telephone call that engineers at the Federal power authority in Oregon neglected to make.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MILTON ESTEROW, the editor and publisher of Artnews, has received an award not usually given to journalists: a shofar, or ram's horn, which is sounded in synagogues as part of Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur services.

title: Playoff Atmosphere, Playoff Result: Mariners Edge Yanks
description: Darryl Strawberry had just grounded out with the tying run on first base in the bottom of the 12th inning, the conclusion to an intense, frustrating 13-12 loss to the Seattle Mariners. An afternoon in which the Yankees had climbed out of a huge hole had ended with them falling right back into the depths of a slump that is now reaching alarming proportions.

title: Louis Berger, 82, Who Built Engineering Concern
description: Dr. Louis Berger, an engineer whose expertise in soil conditions enabled him to build highways and even airport runways effectively on soft ground, died in Manhattan on Wednesday after a short illness. He was 82 and lived in Delray Beach, Fla., and Verona, N.J.

title: Rivalry Survives The Heat
description: The only thing missing was a sweater. It was only last fall when the sight of Seattle's Randy Johnson strolling in from the bullpen looked this odd, when the desperation of extra innings had this much intensity, when the strategy of managers had so much riding on every move.

title: Lester Cruzan Is Dead at 62; Fought to Let His Daughter Die
description: Lester Cruzan, a sheet-metal worker who figured in a ground-breaking 1990 Supreme Court ''right-to-die'' ruling that involved his daughter Nancy Beth Cruzan, was found dead on Saturday at his home in Carterville, Mo. He was 62.

title: A Mix of Good Times, Ecology and Outer Space
description: The field next to the Garden State Arts Center became a muddy dance floor when the first Enit Festival settled in for an all-night music marathon, live and electronic, on Saturday. From 4:30 P.M. to about 6 A.M., performers and disk jockeys supplied pulsating and sometimes swinging music to a sold-out crowd of 10,000 people.

title: Humanities Grants Announced
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities has announced 105 grants totaling $14.5 million for the third quarter of 1996. The grants, which range from $3,800 to $800,000, will support public programs and research fellowships, as well as seminars for public school and college teachers.

title: San Diego Speech Scorecard
description: ''And guess what?'' Jack Kemp asked, trying to shoosh the enthusiastic crowd. When some in the audience started shouting back guesses, he had to say ''That was a rhetorical question -- you don't have to answer.''

title: Celebration, and Eyes on the Future
description: Max Shaffer, an Illinois construction worker and part-time impersonator of Uncle Sam, loved every minute of the Reform Party National Convention here, although his cheering on behalf of Ross Perot will cost him a day's pay, or about $150 after taxes.

title: Fraud Measure Proposed
description: In an effort to cut down on fraud, the State Insurance Department has proposed that a doctor who treats the victim of an auto accident be required to file a report with the insurance company within 21 days. Previously, a doctor could wait up to two years before making the report, making it more difficult for a company to detect fraud, said Kathleen Bird, a spokeswoman for the department.

title: Profits Increase 46% At British Retailer Argos
description: Britain's leading discount retailer, Argos P.L.C., said yesterday that its profits jumped in the first half of the year, helped by the company's strategy of rock-bottom pricing. The profits surged 46 percent, to $:31.8 million ($49.3 million). The company sells goods in no-frills stores using a catalogue system.

title: Toys 'R' Us Records 72% Jump in Earnings
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc. said yesterday that its fiscal second-quarter earnings jumped 72 percent, as efforts to simplify its stores and focus on best-selling toys paid off.

title: Maurice Natanson, A Philosopher, 71
description: Maurice Natanson, a philosopher who helped introduce the work of Jean-Paul Sartre and Edmund Husserl in the United States, died on Friday at his home in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 71.

title: Russia Outstrips U.S. as Chief Arms Seller to Developing Nations
description: Russia, eager to bolster its economy with the hard currency it earns from the sale of everything from bullets to jet fighters, surpassed the United States and France last year as the largest arms seller to the developing world, according to a new Congressional report.

title: O'Neill Is Itching To Return To Lineup
description: The first pitch of the Yankees-Mariners game was three and a half hours away, but Paul O'Neill was already wearing new batting gloves and gripping a new bat. O'Neill was ready to hit, but Joe Torre was not ready to play him because the right fielder was being benched for the second straight game. Manager's decision.

title: The Republican Riverboat Gamble
description: When Bob Dole decided to make a 15 percent across-the-board tax cut the centerpiece of his campaign, he must have been banking on a serious case of collective amnesia. America ran a huge supply-side experiment in the 1980's. The ''riverboat gamble,'' as it was called by Howard H. Baker Jr., then the Senate majority leader, proved to be a losing one. The big tax cuts increased the deficit rather than economic growth.

title: Q & A
description: Unseen Pests

title: Chase Names A New Chief For Its Credit Card Division
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation yesterday unexpectedly replaced the veteran head of its credit card unit, Charles R. Walsh, with another executive, Michael Urkowitz, who has virtually no experience in credit cards.

title: Green Says Young Pitchers Were Called Up Too Soon
description: The same manager who predicted in March that Jason Isringhausen and Paul Wilson were capable of winning 15 games apiece this year has come to the conclusion that they were not ready to pitch in the major leagues after all.

title: Stock-Option Palaces
description: To the Editor:

title: Profits Rise 12.8% At Schwarz Pharma
description: Schwarz Pharma A.G., a drug company based in Mannheim, Germany, said yesterday that its first-half pretax profit rose 12.8 percent, propelled by foreign sales and United States acquisitions. Pretax profit climbed to 95.1 million marks ($64.25 million), from 84.3 million last year. Sales rose 29 percent to 588.3 million marks, from the corresponding period last year. Foreign sales accounted for 49.9 percent of that total.

title: Final Push for the Test-Ban Treaty
description: Some hope has emerged in recent days that the impasse blocking completion of a treaty banning all nuclear weapons tests may yet be overcome. India, though determined to preserve its own freedom to test, now suggests it might withdraw its threat to prevent the largely completed treaty from being sent to the United Nations next month. In return it asks for some difficult adjustments in treaty language on disarmament and ratification requirements, but may be willing to settle for guarantees that New Delhi will not face penalties for its refusal to sign the treaty this year.

title: More Charges Announced Against Nightclub Owner
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn widened their drug case against the Manhattan nightclub owner Peter Gatien yesterday, adding cocaine distribution charges to an earlier indictment, and arresting two of his top aides, including the general manager of his largest club.

title: The Horsy Set
description: Gucci has won fashion's sweepstakes this year as the most influential (read most copied) collection. The house's signature horse bit, which has adorned loafers and belts for at least five decades, is now turning up on all manner of accessories.

title: Building a Better Nasdaq
description: The new Nasdaq stock market, arising from a price-fixing scandal that has humiliated both brokerage firms and regulators, is likely to be very different from the one that promoted itself as ''the stock market for the next 100 years'' and that grew faster than any other market in the last quarter-century.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about ethics complaints against Speaker Newt Gingrich misstated the timing of a complaint filed with the House Ethics Committee about an official from a telecommunications company who worked as a volunteer in the Speaker's office. The complaint was filed last November. It was dismissed in March, and refiled in April.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the 50th Edinburgh International Festival misidentified the actress who appeared in a German-language production of ''Orlando,'' staged by Robert Wilson. She is Jutta Lampe, not Ute Lemper.

title: Arbitrager in a New Battle With Anti-Takeover Forces
description: Sometimes just saying no is not enough.

title: No Headline
description: ''There is no economy in Bosnia, because there is a general feeling here that broken-down state companies are an asset when in fact they are a liability.''

title: To Market Men's Wear, Key Word Is 'Casual'
description: The biggest maker of pants and the biggest maker of shirts are shaking up their wardrobes in a big way.

title: Mannesmann Reports 28% Gain in Profits
description: The German engineering company Mannesmann A.G. said yesterday that its profits rose 28 percent in the first half of 1996, as strength in its telecommunications business more than offset losses in industrial operations. Profits rose to 180 million marks ($120.8 million) in the six months that ended on June 30, from 141 million marks last year. Sales rose more than expected, to 15.5 billion marks ($10.4 billion), compared with 15.2 billion.

title: Marriage of Necessity: Nonprofit Groups and Drug Makers
description: In the latest marketing marriage of a drug maker and a nonprofit health care association, SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. of Britain will pay $1 million a year to the American Cancer Society and put the society's name on SmithKline's Nicoderm smoking-cessation patches, which can be purchased without a prescription.

title: Genuine Reward Back on Farm
description: It is not the kind of ending that Hollywood would write, but it is typical of the regret and the reality of horse racing: Genuine Reward, first son of the filly who won the Kentucky Derby 16 years ago, is back on the farm in Virginia with his third case of bucked shins and won't go to the races this year, if ever.

title: Everybody Wants Rights To the King Of the Blues
description: In 1947, Riley B. King, 22 years old and with guitar in hand, hitchhiked north from his home town of Itta Bena, Miss., aiming to make a name for himself here on Beale Street, the mecca of the blues.

title: HUDSON BAY PARTNERS IS BUYING 72% OF BAY MEADOWS
description: Hudson Bay Partners L.P. reached an agreement yesterday with the California Jockey Club to buy 72 percent of the Bay Meadows Operating Company for $300 million. The sale now must seek the approval of Bay Meadows, which operates the Bay Meadows horse racing track in the San Francisco suburbs and which leases the land from California Jockey. The shares of Bay Meadows and California Jockey are traded as a single unit on the American Stock Exchange. While the companies have the same shareholders and report consolidated financial statements, they have different boards whose interests do not always coincide. Hudson Bay, which is based in New York, is a real estate investment fund.

title: The Spoiler Returns
description: The political party that Ross Perot created one year ago to find and bankroll ''someone who could really be a great President but doesn't have the financial resources'' has located its man. He is Ross Perot, who has never doubted his potential for greatness but has chosen, this time around, to use less of his own money and more of the taxpayers' to achieve his goal. That may be a wise move on Mr. Perot's part, since his already slim chances have presumably been diminished by the fact that he is no longer a novelty.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Dolphins Win Sloppy Tuneup
description: Just as the national anthem was being sung before tonight's Miami Dolphins exhibition game against the Minnesota Vikings, it began raining. It was hard enough to make the Joe Robbie Stadium field slippery and miserably muddy.

title: Pioneer Electronics To Offer Early Retirement
description: Reporting a return to profitability, the Pioneer Electronic Corporation said yesterday that it would offer early retirement to 650 workers in an attempt to cut costs. Pioneer, Japan's top maker of audio equipment, earned 804 million yen ($7.5 million) in the quarter ended on June 30. The company lost 1.82 billion yen in the period last year. Despite the quarterly success, Pioneer expects to lose 11.60 billion yen ($107.4 million) in the current fiscal year.

title: Checkup For Your Hard Disk
description: IF you want to see what a mess your hard disk is in, here is a program that produces a colorful map of it. I ran Disk Mapper 1.0 on the old 486 and saw on the screen nested sections containing program files (170,557,440 bytes), Windows (158,990,336), Corel (95,584,256) and even the Recycle bin (105,971,712), along with dozens of others. Moving the cursor within a section gives you information on the files in it. For instance, in the program files rectangle a smaller subsection shows Microsoft Works taking up 20,643,840 bytes.

title: Store Labels Gain Designer Cachet
description: The designer private label is the latest development in the constant search of retailers for ways to lure customers. Several stores have hired bona fide designers to create special collections to be sold only in their stores under the store label.

title: Pettitte's 18th Victory Is Also Another Save
description: The incorrect element of the tale of the collapse of the 1996 Yankees has already been established. It was only three weeks ago that the Yankees had their biggest lead of the season -- 12 games -- but, in an ESPN weekend telecast, it was reported as 12 1/2 games.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BALLY ENTERTAINMENT CORP., Chicago, the casino and resort hotel operator, agreed to buy 24 acres of Las Vegas land from Bally's Grand Inc. for $60 million in cash and stock.

title: She Just Promised to Write, Not Make Sense
description: Tonight Court TV offers a droll account of the unsuccessful effort by Random House, the large and respectable publisher, to get back a $1.2 million advance from Joan Collins, star of ''Dynasty'' and best-selling author of steamy novels with titles like ''Love and Desire and Hate.'' The case is of no great legal consequence, but it provides some insight into the way things are done or left undone in the junk-fiction industry.

title: Making Peace in Chechnya: So Who's in Charge?
description: Ever since the war in Chechnya began nearly two years ago, Aleksandr I. Lebed always insisted that it would end in disaster for Russia. He often told President Boris N. Yeltsin that the people running the war were fools and that it would take someone special, someone like himself, to end it.

title: Bay Inhabitants Are Mostly Aliens
description: FROM the vantage point of the Berkeley Marina one recent morning, San Francisco stood sharply etched against a fog bank nestling along the Pacific shore like a gigantic roll of cotton candy, a recurring tableau essentially unchanged since Tony Bennett first left his heart in the city across the bay.

title: Brilliant Or Merely Bizarre?
description: In the mid-1960's, the psychiatrist R. D. Laing wrote of a new way to look at madness. He described insanity not as a breakdown but as a breakthrough, one that those who deem themselves normal could learn from. Today, madness may not be an asset in the business world (except for megalomania, perhaps) but in the nebulous world of the arts, the output of a mind we can't understand is often taken for genius.

title: Sanyo Executive Is Freed For a Ransom in Mexico
description: A Japanese executive who was kidnapped for ransom in Tijuana was released early this morning, Mexican justice officials said, ending an abduction that shook business confidence all along the United States border.

title: An Alter Ego Who Plays Quarterback
description: THE coach-quarterback relationship is a strange and wondrous thing. Sometimes it will drive coaches to behave in bizarre ways.

title: Teachers Endorse Torricelli
description: The New Jersey Education Association has endorsed Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of Englewood, in his Senate race against Representative Richard A. Zimmer, a Delaware Township Republican. The state's largest teachers union made the endorsement at its meeting in Somerset.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about Ross Perot's acceptance speech as the Reform Party candidate for President misstated the date of the winter George Washington's troops spent in Valley Forge, Pa., a few miles from the convention site. It was 1777-78, not 1977-78.

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Stocks traded lower here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 91.54 points -- almost one-half of 1 percent -- at 21,014.87. On Monday, the Nikkei gained 272.41.

title: Two Linked by Humor and Lapped by Rock
description: There was an agreeable lesson on Sunday afternoon in the fine distinctions between rock and jazz esthetics at the Brooklyn Museum's sculpture garden. The teachers were Terry Adams, shaggy-haired keyboardist from the peripatetic American roots-music band NRBQ, and Marshall Allen, the alto saxophonist and flutist who leads the Sun Ra Arkestra and wears the Arkestra's trademark gold-and-red sequined skullcap even on side projects like this one.

title: Social Strife May Have Exiled Ancient Indians
description: UNTIL very recently, the most perplexing mystery of Southwestern archeology -- what caused the collapse of the ancient empire of the Anasazi -- seemed all but solved. Careful scrutiny of tree-ring records seemed to establish that in the late 1200's a prolonged dry spell called the Great Drought drove these people, the ancestors of today's pueblo Indians, to abandon their magnificent stone villages at Mesa Verde and elsewhere on the Colorado Plateau, never to return again.

title: Development Zones Program Corrected Flaws
description: To the Editor:

title: The Profits of Milk
description: To the Editor:

title: Brodeur Has Success, if Not Seniority
description: Martin Brodeur has his oversized blocking glove opened wide. He is ready to catch the torch that is about to be handed his way.

title: Real Estate Venture By 2 Swiss Companies
description: The Union Bank of Switzerland and Swiss Life, its insurance joint venture partner, said in a statement yesterday that they would merge their real estate management units to cut costs. The companies said Livit A.G., a Union Bank unit, would take over the management of both companies' real estate units and would become independent.

title: Baritone at the Met Wins Anderson Award
description: Nathan Gunn, a 25-year-old baritone on the roster of the Metropolitan Opera, is the winner of the 1996 Marian Anderson Award, a $20,000 prize given annually to a promising singer.

title: Polish Underground Didn't Plan Pogroms
description: To the Editor:

title: Alexander Hammer, 79, Financial Reporter
description: Alexander R. Hammer, a financial reporter whose career at The New York Times spanned more than 40 years, died on Saturday. He was 79 and lived in Melville, L.I.

title: Criminal and Welfare Rules Raise New Issues of Fairness
description: Telephoning her small children from jail, Elisa Ortiz used to sing their favorite song in hopes that they would remember who she was. She still cries over the chorus: ''We are a happy family.''

title: Filipino Foes Meet at Talks To End Muslim Rebellion
description: After 26 years of war waged with Muslim separatists that has left more than 150,000 people dead, President Fidel Ramos traveled today to the battle-torn island of Mindanao where he embraced the principal rebel leader, Nur Misuari, in what many say is the last step in the quest for lasting peace in the Philippines.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: Economy Grew 7.2% in Mexico Last Quarter, a Sign of Revival
description: In its latest and strongest indication that a long-awaited recovery was solidly under way, Mexico announced late Sunday that the economy grew by 7.2 percent in the second quarter.

title: Crude Oil Prices Are Climbing On Expected Winter Demand
description: Crude oil prices continued to climb on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, surging past $23 a barrel.

title: Teen-Ager Accuses Officer of Injury
description: An off-duty police captain driving his private car struck a Brooklyn teen-ager riding his bicycle and left the scene earlier this month, the youth alleged in a complaint filed with the Internal Affairs Bureau.

title: Bosnia Election Will Validate Separatism
description: To the Editor:

title: MOBIL IS SELLING 13 OIL AND NATURAL GAS FIELDS
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 13 oil and natural gas producing fields in the Gulf of Mexico to Flores & Rucks Inc. for $139.3 million. Mobil, which is based in Fairfax, Va., said the fields produce the equivalent of about 10,000 barrels a day of oil. The 13 fields are in shallow waters off Louisiana's shore. Flores & Rucks is an independent oil and gas company based in Baton Rouge, La. Mobil said the sale was part of its planned realignment of its Mobil Exploration and Producing affiliate. The properties have low productivity and limited development potential, the company said.

title: Patterns
description: Casual Corner Branches Out

title: Hostetler's Goal: Keep Team Together
description: After the Oakland Raiders jumped to an 8-2 record last season, there was seemingly nothing that could keep them from the playoffs.

title: Kemp's Legacy as Housing Secretary: One of Ideas, Not Accomplishments
description: As President Bush's Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Jack Kemp was known as an innovative thinker and virtually the only voice for the inner-city poor in an Administration with priorities elsewhere.

title: Vindicating Ives on Dates and Music
description: The annual summer music festival at Bard College goes by the name Rediscoveries because its usual practice is to put canonical figures like Brahms, Schumann and Dvorak into new contexts or to scrutinize them by way of lesser-known repertory. But this year's festival, which ended on Sunday, entered the different world of Charles Ives, the still imperfectly understood American master. Amid the customary boisterous panel discussions and odd programming juxtapositions, there were some certifiable first discoveries. An immense but shadowy presence in American music moved a little more into the light.

title: Trade Surplus Falls in Japan
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus fell by 38 percent in July, compared with July of last year. Growth in imports more than made up for expanding exports, the Finance Ministry said yesterday. Last month's surplus was 504 billion yen ($4.6 billion), compared with 808.3 billion yen in July 1995. The figures are not seasonally adjusted.

title: Suffolk Medical Examiner Urges Fingerprinting Law
description: Putting motorists' fingerprints on driver's licenses, as is done in California, would help in identifying disaster victims, the Suffolk County Medical Examiner said today as he told a committee of the County Legislature about his work on the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800.

title: Electronic Public Libraries Must Remain Free
description: To the Editor:

title: E. Digby Baltzell Dies at 80; Studied WASP's
description: E. Digby Baltzell, a sociologist widely known for his analytical writings about his fellow white Anglo-Saxon Protestants, sometimes known by the acronym WASP's, died on Saturday at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He was 80 and had homes in Philadelphia and Wellfleet, Mass.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: North Wildwood Plays Ball
description: The beach resort of North Wildwood yesterday became the latest New Jersey city to announce plans to build a stadium for a minor league baseball franchise. The $10 million, 5,000-seat stadium would be financed with bonds and grants from the state and the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, said Bob Heal, the city's business administrator. The owners of the Delaware Blue Rocks in the Carolina League are negotiating to buy a team -- whose identity has not been disclosed -- and move it to North Wildwood in time for the 1998 season, Mr. Heal said.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article in Business Day on Aug. 8 about a proposal by Bob Dole to change the nation's automobile insurance system referred incorrectly to the stance of the Consumers Union. The organization has not adopted a position on Mr. Dole's plan to give car owners the option of buying less expensive injury coverage solely for medical bills and lost wages. The Consumers Union opposed a related California state initiative, which would have limited the right of the injured to go to court.

title: Metropolitan Life Deal Cleared by New York
description: New York State officials have approved a merger of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company, removing the last significant hurdle the deal faces.

title: Chess
description: Alex Yermolinsky is the United States champion for the second time. The 38-year-old grandmaster of Euclid, Ohio, shared the title in 1993, but now he has won it solo.

title: Catherine East, 80, Inspiration For National Women's Group
description: Catherine S. East, a little-known Government researcher who became the quiet inspiration for the National Organization for Women and a persistent goad to the nascent feminist movement, died on Saturday at Kendal at Ithaca, a retirement community in Ithaca, N.Y. She was 80.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day yesterday misstated a move by Times Mirror Magazines. The company named Scott Kabak senior vice president for operations and multimedia. He was not replaced by Nancy Walker; she was promoted to senior vice president.

title: A Season in the Life Of the St. Paul Saints
description: In ''Baseball, Minnesota,'' a series starting Sunday at 7 P.M. on the fX cable network, all-seeing cameras capture a pitcher smashing a bat against a clubhouse wall after a dreadful outing, the manager calmly releasing players, a pig named Tobias delivering baseballs to the plate umpire, players relaxing in a local bar, the bar's night manager ruminating over her nose job and a pitcher proudly calling his dad to tell him he has made the team.

title: Analysts Say Profits Will Lag Behind at Viag
description: Earnings growth for the first half at Viag A.G., the third largest of Germany's diversified energy producers, will not even come close to last year's performance, when one-time gains helped performance, analysts said yesterday. In the first half of 1995, pretax profit at the diversified utility was 1.492 billion marks ($1.01 billion), nearly triple that of the first half of 1994.

title: A Jazz Club, A Lingerie Shop And the Gap Vie For Harlem Aid
description: For Melba Wilson, a Harlem restaurateur, it means a chance to resurrect Minton's Playhouse jazz club, where be-bop was born. For John Bolt, manager of the Dyckman Street Marina, it could mean 105 new boat slips at the northern tip of Manhattan.

title: AT&T's No. 2 Quits To Run Tiny Venture
description: The No. 2 executive of AT&T resigned yesterday to run a tiny communications company, a move that stunned his colleagues and Wall Street.

title: Balkan Economies Stagnate In Grip of Political Leaders
description: When Western powers look at the Balkans these days, they often gauge progress by the number of weapons stilled, roads opened and refugees trudging home.

title: 'The Hebrew Hammer' Is Poised for Next Bout
description: SUDDENLY, there is a glut of Jewish prizefighters. Well, two.

title: AVANT BUYING ANAGRAM FOR $76 MILLION IN STOCK
description: The Avant Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the privately held Anagram Inc. for $76 million in stock. Both companies make computer-circuit design software and are based in Sunnyvale, Calif. Avant said that it would issue about 2.4 million common shares in exchange for all of Anagram's stock. Avant stock closed yesterday at $31.50 a share, up 50 cents, in Nasdaq trading.

title: A Downgrade Hurts Shares Of Harrah's
description: Shares of Harrah's Entertainment Inc. fell as much as 14 percent yesterday to a 52-week low after an analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc. cut his rating on the stock two notches to ''hold'' from ''strong buy.''

title: Japan's Micro-Machine Project Draws Envy and Criticism
description: JAPANESE companies made their mark in the world automobile industry with the compact car. Now they are hoping the ''micro-car'' will position them as leaders of one of the most promising industries of the future.

title: Surely He Is Spoofing
description: Children, believe me: Things were not better in the old days. I was there too, just like Bob Dole, and I was shocked to hear him say things were better back then.

title: COLONY CAPITAL TO INVEST IN SANTA ANITA COMPANIES
description: The Santa Anita Companies said yesterday that Colony Capital Inc. would invest $138.3 million in Santa Anita in the next two years to become a large shareholder and help the race track owner expand into other areas. Under the agreement, Colony Capital, a real estate investment firm in Los Angeles, would immediately acquire an 8 percent stake in Santa Anita for about $12.7 million. The remaining $125.6 million would be invested as Santa Anita identifies acquisition targets like other race tracks, amusement parks or other entertainment ventures. Colony Capital's investors could ultimately hold a 45 percent interest in Santa Anita. Santa Anita is a real estate investment trust in Arcadia, Calif. It operates the Santa Anita horse-racing track.

title: High Grades, Again
description: For a second consecutive year, Mountain Lakes High School in Morris County has been awarded first place in the New Jersey Monthly magazine survey of the state's 75 top public high schools. The survey, published yesterday, rated schools according to such criteria as the amount of instruction time per day, average standardized test scores and the number of graduates who go to college. Most of the top-scoring schools are situated in the state's wealthier communities.

title: Clintons and Gores Leave Glitz Behind for Birthdays
description: A world away from the Radio City birthday extravaganza that netted $10 million for the Democrats on Sunday night, President Clinton and Tipper Gore observed their actual birthdays here today by donating sweat labor to rebuilding a rural church.

title: A Pepsi Challenge To Coke Agreement
description: Pepsico Inc. formally petitioned the Government of Venezuela yesterday to block the Coca-Cola Company from forming a joint venture with the Cisneros Group, which had been Pepsi's bottling company in Venezuela for the last 47 years.

title: The Victorian Secret
description: Visitors may well be impressed by the prodigious talents on display in a fascinating show, ''Being William Morris,'' at Manhattan's Morgan Library. Shown in several galleries are the works and memorabilia of this British poet and artist who died a century ago. His attending physician remarked at the time that he died ''simply being William Morris and having done more work than most ten men.''

title: Tiny Transmitters Make It Possible To Track Peregrines Day by Day
description: FOR years as they watched peregrine falcons fly south each fall, biologists could do little more than wonder what paths they took to reach their winter haunts in the tropics.

title: Clash in Detroit Over How Ill a Kevorkian Client Really Was
description: The medical examiner here and associates of Dr. Jack Kevorkian sharply clashed again today over the latest suicide the doctor attended.

title: Bond Prices Slip as Traders Wait on Fed
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly in a quiet session yesterday, as market participants awaited today's Federal Reserve meeting on interest rates.

title: Air Security Device Didn't Pass Muster
description: To the Editor:

title: Season Ends; Debate Doesn't
description: The fishing season for bluefin tuna was ended by officials on Saturday, but fishermen are complaining that the season stopped prematurely because the National Marine Fisheries Service overestimated the number of anglers and the size of their catch. This year, recreational fishermen in New Jersey were allowed to catch 95 tons of small-school bluefin tuna, which the fisheries service estimated occurred on Saturday. The fisheries service has agreed to meet this month with the fishermen and the boat owners who cater to them, said Ted Loud, a spokesman for Representative Frank Pallone, Democrat of Long Branch. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Jets Do Some Cutting But Keep Three Kickers
description: The Jets have decided that three kickers are better than two. So today they waived Pat O'Neill, who punts and kicks off, and kept Brian Hansen to punt and Don Silvestri to kick off. Nick Lowery, at age 40, remains the field-goal kicker.

title: Review Narrowed By United Airlines
description: The United Airlines unit of the UAL Corporation narrowed a review on its account yesterday to five agencies from eight. The account, with billings estimated at $100 million, has been handled by the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago for 31 years.

title: Woods Breezes Through First Step
description: Tiger Woods began his defense of the United States Amateur title today with a smooth 69, a two-under-par round that was almost as lucent as the day that framed it here in the Willamette Valley.

title: Tale of the Tape: Slow Lightweight
description: I USE tape to back up my system. I hate it.

title: Judge Assails Overcrowding Of Homeless
description: A State Supreme Court justice castigated city officials yesterday for what she called continued overcrowding and dangerous conditions at a center in the Bronx where families go to enter the shelter system, warning that she might order the city to open a second center in Manhattan to relieve the crowding.

title: After Maddox Is Cut, Reeves Goes on the Defensive
description: The Giants solidified their quarterback situation this morning with the release of Tommy Maddox, but Coach Dan Reeves showed this afternoon how sensitive the issue is with him.

title: Atlanta Bombing Suspect Mostly Just Stays Home, Many Eyes Glued on Him
description: Shortly after 8 A.M. today, Richard A. Jewell, the security guard being investigated in the bombing at Centennial Olympic Park, left his apartment, hopped into his blue Toyota pickup and sped off.

title: Perot Gets Ready to Run a Familiar Race Under New Rules
description: Invigorated by the start of his second bid for the Presidency here, Ross Perot flew home to Texas today to turn to the unfinished business of selecting a Vice-Presidential running mate, developing a campaign strategy and learning how to operate under Federal fund-raising rules.

title: A French Icon's 'American Dream'
description: His face is as familiar and as instantly recognizable in this country as his name: Johnny Hallyday, the eternal French rock star.

title: INSIDE
description: Bringing Peace to Mindanao

title: Dole's Plan and Its High Hurdles
description: Since unveiling his plan to slash taxes and still balance the Federal budget by 2002, Bob Dole has argued that overcoming the economic and political hurdles in its way is simply a question of Presidential will. ''I have it,'' he said. ''I will do it.''

title: Ochs Honored by City With Street of His Own
description: The occupation of 43d Street off Times Square by The New York Times is a nightly affair as oversize delivery trucks groan and grind their way into narrow bays at the newspaper's loading dock to carry away bundles of the next day's issue.

title: Brazil Plant Seen For Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation will announce today that it plans to build a Dakota pickup truck factory in Brazil, according to a person familiar with the plans.

title: Ralph Nader Is Nominated for President, but Vows He Will Ignore His Party's Platform
description: In a political development with a long-shot potential to cause President Clinton some re-election trouble, the Green Party, an offspring of the anti-nuclear and environmental movements, today nominated Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, to carry its banner in the fall.

title: 4 Premieres by Flutists, Performing for Flutists
description: For a flutist, performing before an audience of some 2,500 other flutists has got to be intimidating. Still, a festive atmosphere prevailed during a concert on Sunday night in the Broadway Ballroom of the Marriott Marquis Hotel, the final event of the four-day annual convention of the National Flute Association.

title: Lincoln Center Plans Screenings for the Deaf
description: The Film Society of Lincoln Center is to present first-run films with subtitles for the deaf and hard of hearing at the Walter Reade Theater one day a month, beginning today at 3, 6 and 9 P.M. To start the series, Time Warner has agreed to supply the society with three subtitled films from the Warner Brothers releases this summer and fall.

title: Gen. Witold Urbanowicz, 88, Polish Fighter Ace in World War II
description: Gen. Witold Urbanowicz, who flew on three fronts to become Poland's foremost fighter ace of World War II, died Saturday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan. He was 88 and lived in Glendale, Queens.

title: New Setback on Death Row
description: In another setback for John M. Martini, the New Jersey death row inmate who wants to be executed, the United States Supreme Court yesterday denied his request to halt further appeals on his behalf. The court refused to temporarily block Judge Bruce A. Gaeta of the Superior Court in Hackensack from hearing an appeal, known as post-conviction relief, filed against Mr. Martini's wishes by the state Public Defender's office. Mr. Martini, who was convicted of the 1989 kidnapping and murder of Irving Flax, had sought to prevent Judge Gaeta from hearing information he wants to keep secret.

title: Deal Is Set To Buy Casino From Griffin
description: Sun International Hotels Ltd. said yesterday it had agreed to acquire Griffin Gaming and Entertainment Inc. for about $210 million in stock and to assume $127 million in debt. The acquisition, which the boards of both companies approved unanimously, would give Sun ownership of the Resorts Casino Hotel in Atlantic City, as well as 10 undeveloped acres in Atlantic City.

title: Elvis, From the Kitchen to the Couch
description: THE INNER ELVIS

title: CHRONICLE
description: POPE JOHN PAUL II is continuing his recovery from the abdominal problem he suffered last week and is now in good condition, the Vatican said yesterday.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: CHRONICLE
description: The 3-year-old boy rescued by a protective female gorilla when he tumbled into her zoo habitat is recovering and may be released from the hospital this week, his doctor said yesterday.

title: Man Is Convicted, Again, of Killing a Wife
description: A retired Army master sergeant who last winter was convicted of killing his wife 18 years ago was today found guilty of murdering another wife, this one a mail-order bride from the Philippines who disappeared in 1994.

title: MENTOR GRAPHICS PLANS TO ADD INTERCONNECTIX
description: The Mentor Graphics Corporation, a maker of chip-design software, said yesterday that it had acquired Interconnectix Inc. for about $32.2 million in stock. Interconnectix, which is based in Beaverton, Ore., develops software for the design of high-speed digital systems. Mentor Graphics, based in Wilsonville, Ore., said that it acquired Interconnectix for 2.3 million shares. The stock closed yesterday at $13.75, down 25 cents on the Nasdaq.

title: When the Prelate Was Buried, Ogres Came Alive
description: Every few days, Zoya Gorpeniuk, a 44-year-old former secretary to Patriarch Volodymyr of Kiev, visits his grave in the sidewalk just outside the walls of the Cathedral of St. Sofia.

title: China's Ambitious President Wants Mao's Title: Chairman
description: At a leafy seaside resort northeast of here, where China's Communist Party leaders gather each summer for a kind of collegial brawl over ideology and occasional adjustments to the Politburo pecking order, President Jiang Zemin has unveiled a vision of China's future with himself as a Mao-like figure at the top of the party.

title: Animals for Humans?
description: To the Editor:

title: PROSECUTOR GAINS SENTENCING DELAY IN ARKANSAS TRIAL
description: A Federal District judge delayed sentencing for James B. McDougal in the Whitewater case today, suggesting that Mr. McDougal has agreed to cooperate with prosecutors and that they hope he has information that will move the case forward.

title: ABITIBI-PRICE ACQUIRING A COMPUTER SUPPLIES COMPANY
description: Abitibi-Price Inc., a leading Canadian forest products company, said yesterday that it had acquired the Tenex Data Corporation, a maker and distributor of computer supplies and data storage products. Terms were not disclosed. Privately held Tenex had sales of $100.5 million last year. Abitibi said the acquisition was part of a plan to expand its office products division, which had revenue of about $346 million last year. Abitibi hopes to triple the division's sales volume by the year 2000. Both companies are based in Toronto.

title: LOCKHEED MARTIN UNIT RECEIVES A $304 MILLION CONTRACT
description: Lockheed Martin Federal Systems, a unit of the Lockheed Martin Corporation, received a contract worth about $304 million to modernize combat support systems at 93 Air Force bases worldwide. In a statement, the company said the 15-year Global Combat Support System-Air Force program has a potential value of more than $900 million. The first combat support system slated for modernization is the Air Force's supply information system. Lockheed Martin Federal Systems in Owego, N.Y., provides advanced solutions in systems integration, program management, hardware and software development, manufacturing and logistics support.

title: Search Is Pressed for Center Section of Jet
description: They have the cockpit. They have the baggage containers. They now have all four engines, most of the right wing and thousands of fragments. What they don't have is the answer.

title: For Convention-Week Polls, Timing Can Be Everything
description: Polls taken during and after political conventions often tell very different stories about just how much a candidate might have gained from his four days in the national spotlight. This year is no exception.

title: Bonds Helps Pin a Loss On Mets and Harnisch
description: Their lineup is manned by a group of no-names like Bill Mueller, Tom Lampkin, Rich Aurilia, Marvin Benard and Jay Canizaro. Who are these guys, you ask? They are the patchwork Giants that Manager Dusty Baker has stitched together to keep a semblance of his injury-riddled team. Tonight their collective effort was good enough to beat the Mets, 5-4, thanks primarily to a huge lift from a familiar name.

title: Cuba and U.S. Trade Expulsions of Diplomats
description: Cuba is expelling a United States diplomat, charging her with activities ''incompatible with her diplomatic status,'' the State Department said this evening. The United States will respond by expelling a spokesman for the Cuban mission here.

title: Five Years and Two Suspects Later, a Call for Justice in Crown Heights
description: Five years after a Hasidic Jew was fatally stabbed during racial violence in Crown Heights, the streets of the Brooklyn neighborhood are no doubt quieter. But the killing continues to reverberate through the city, and yesterday -- the anniversary of the attack -- some of New York's top political leaders returned to the scene, saying that justice still had not been achieved.

title: Experts' Study Says Attacking U.N. Hurts U.S.
description: A group of American foreign policy experts with a variety of political views warned in a report today that Washington's hostility to the United Nations is damaging not only the organization but also the national interests of the United States.

title: Garden Debut: Female Fighters on Card
description: Andrea DeShong is used to working on people with her hands. But her job as a certified massage therapist was becoming monotonous the last two years. She could not take it any longer. She launched a comeback. She missed boxing.

title: Mugger Sentenced for Robbing Mother of Reputed Crime Boss
description: His shirt said ''Boss'' across it, and maybe it was a gesture to his victim. Maybe it was unwitting bravado. Or maybe it was just another misstep by Willie King, the man called ''the world's dumbest mugger'' by the tabloids.

title: Anticipting the Fed: Moods Swing With the Data
description: Maybe the inflation wolf wasn't baying at the door after all.

title: New Lineup Lifts Yanks' Low Spirits
description: It was natural for Joe Torre to revise his lineup last night in an effort to shake the Yankees from their doldrums. It was also natural for the manager to leave Andy Pettitte alone because starting pitchers are on a strict schedule. Guess what? Those developments made it look natural for the Yankees to squash the Mariners, 10-4.

title: Haitians Jittery After Gunmen Attack Police Site, Killing One
description: In the latest indication of what the Haitian Government describes as destabilization led by sympathizers of the former military dictatorship, two carloads of armed men early today opened fire on the police headquarters here, just behind the National Palace, killing a shoeshine boy and wounding a policeman.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sunday summarizing fatalities and injuries among in-line skaters misstated the date on which Liora Natelson, a skater in Central Park, died. It was last Tuesday, not Wednesday.

title: Chess Computer Seeking Revenge Against Kasparov
description: It was in the fifth game of the landmark six-game series in February when it all fell apart for the challenger. Rejecting the champion's offer of a draw, which would have kept the match tied, the upstart newcomer stepped almost immediately into a lethal trap. There went the game, the match, the adulation.

title: AT&T President Quits to Run Tiny Company
description: In a move that stunned his colleagues and sent AT&T's stock tumbling, Alex J. Mandl resigned yesterday as the No. 2 executive of the giant long-distance carrier to run a tiny start-up company.

title: Executive Changes
description: CHANTAL PHARMACEUTICAL CORP., Los Angeles, named Yvette Lamprecht its new chief financial officer. This is the second time since June that Chantal has named a new chief financial officer.

title: Interest Groups Take New Route To Congressional Election Arena
description: At first glance, the battle for control of the House this year is between the Democrats and the Republicans. In reality, it is a far more complicated struggle between the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the United States Chamber of Commerce, the League of Conservation Voters and the National Federation of Independent Business, the National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League and the Christian Coalition.

title: F.D.A. Approves Inhaler
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company has won approval from the Food and Drug Administration for the first asthma drug inhaler of its type that is free of a propellant thought to harm the ozone layer. The inhaler made by 3M delivers the drug albuterol without using chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's. The Schering-Plough Corporation will market and distribute the so-called metered dose inhaler in the United States under the brand name Proventil HFA on behalf of 3M's pharmaceutical division.

title: So Much Mozart, So Many Trade-Offs
description: Few people expect concerts by the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra to be hallmarks of incisive playing and probing interpretations. The programs are mostly offered as a chance to spend some diverting summer evenings with Amadeus and friends. The demanding schedule, with sometimes three or four different programs to prepare each week, seldom allows for truly finished or involving performances, even with orchestra players as generally strong as these.

title: President Dole's Duty
description: ''And when I am President, every man and every woman in our armed forces will know the President is their Commander in Chief,'' said Bob Dole in his acceptance speech in San Diego. The next words were underlined in his text and voice. ''Not Boutros Boutros-Ghali or any other U.N. Secretary General.''

title: Malpractice Retrial Ordered
description: Rima Samo, a Hawthorne Township woman who unsuccessfully sued two doctors for malpractice in the delivery of her brain-damaged daughter, was granted a new trial yesterday when an appeals court ruled that three black women and a Hispanic man were improperly removed from the jury pool because of their race, The Associated Press reported.

title: Oh Yes, There Was News at Convention
description: To the Editor:

title: Disney Takes On Broadway And Bible
description: Boy Kills Giant With a Single Stone! Yes, the tale of King David is coming to 42d Street. Not the old 42d Street of violence, sleaze and porn, but the new 42d Street of family entertainment and the Bible via the Walt Disney Company.

title: POLL SHOWS DOLE SLICING AWAY LEAD CLINTON HAD HELD
description: After a week in the limelight at the Republican National Convention, Bob Dole has sliced President Clinton's lead in half, and more than twice as many people have a clear view of what he would do as President, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Terrorists Among Us
description: America faces a new kind of threat: networks of terrorists, mostly foreign, working within its borders. Yet the Federal Bureau of Investigation is handcuffed in its efforts to stop them.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Sun International in Deal For Merv Griffin's Concern

title: T.W.A. Pathologist Says He Did What He Could, When He Could
description: EARLY in the investigation of the explosion of T.W.A. Flight 800 on July 17, Dr. Charles V. Wetli drew heavy fire for the way he carried out the medical examiner's credo of learning from the dead to help the living.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A Buckingham Palace spokeswoman said yesterday that QUEEN ELIZABETH II and other members of the royal family are discussing possible changes in Britain's 1,200-year-old monarchy. The palace refused to specify what issues the 70-year-old queen, her husband, PRINCE PHILIP, and the heir to the throne, PRINCE CHARLES, have taken up in their talks with senior aides.

title: Sam Zell Bids for a Rival Mobile-Home Maker
description: Manufactured Home Communities Inc., a real estate investment trust controlled by Sam Zell, the Chicago investor, has offered to buy a rival, Chateau Properties Inc., for $387.3 million in cash.

title: Golden Knight Acquisition
description: Golden Knight Resources Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired an additional 12.5 percent interest in Gold Fields Ghana Ltd. for about $47 million. Gold Fields Ghana holds mining rights in Ghana. Golden Knight, based here, had held a 5 percent interest in Gold Fields Ghana since October 1995.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In his prime, BOB HOPE could play close to par golf on a good day. On Sunday, he played a round in Vail, Colo., on the eve of a concert for former President GERALD R. FORD.

title: Health Care and the Mob
description: In what the authorities described as evidence that organized crime had infiltrated the health care industry, New Jersey officials said yesterday that they had smashed a ring that siphoned money from group health care programs serving a million patients. Twelve men were arrested on state charges that they were linked to a Genovese crime family gang that defrauded medical programs. State investigators said that in 1994 the ring gained control of Tri-Con Associates, a Hasbrouck Heights company that arranged and managed group medical, dental and optical programs for employers and unions with networks of health care providers. $(Page A1.$)

title: Wine Talk
description: A BUNCH of wine experts got together on Sunday to taste some pinot noirs -- on the Internet. It was, they said, the first cybertasting ever.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ARTISTIC GREETINGS INC., Elmira, N.Y., promoted Joseph Calabro, its senior vice president of manufacturing, to president and chief executive, succeeding Stuart Komer, who continues as chairman. The company sells personalized goods like address labels, bank checks and luggage tags through ads in newspapers, magazines and direct mailings.

title: Ellis Island, N.J.
description: Like friendly neighbors who sometimes argue over property lines, New Jersey and New York have from time to time disagreed over their boundary in the Hudson River. Such is the case now with Ellis Island.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: 2d Sister, 2d Transplant
description: Encouraged by her sister's successful heart transplant in May, Ingrid Marchlowitz underwent a heart transplant yesterday in Philadelphia, The Associated Press reported. Doctors at the Center City branch of Allegheny University Hospitals said that all goes well, Ms. Marchlowitz could return home to Medford within 10 days. In January, Ms. Marchlowitz, 22, and her sister, Krista O'Brien, 26, of Pennsauken, were both diagnosed with cardiomyopathy, which can be triggered by something as harmless as a virus and afflicts people who are genetically predisposed to it.

title: Summer Pleasures From a Tuscan Farmhouse
description: HENRY JAMES and Bernardo Bertolucci notwithstanding, summertime in Tuscany is not just a lush, languid vista of hillsides thick with olive trees and rich, handsome expatriates striking artistic attitudes on the sun-dappled terraces of Renaissance villas.

title: Reeves's Boohooing Is Jeered By Giants
description: Dan Reeves had heard Tommy Maddox booed before, so the Giants coach's reaction should have been no surprise when it happened again in New York.

title: Missing T.W.A. Seats Suggest Site of Blast
description: Many of the coach seats from rows 17 to 28 on the right side of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 are still missing, although salvage workers have recovered seats from every other area of the passenger cabin, strongly suggesting to investigators that the explosion on board took place there.

title: Missing T.W.A. Seats Suggest Site of a Blast
description: Many of the coach seats in a section of T.W.A. Flight 800 are still missing, strongly suggesting to investigators that an explosion on board took place in that part of the passenger cabin. Salvage workers have recovered seats from every area of the cabin but from rows 17 to 28 on the right side of the airplane.

title: Under the Hood With Perot's Data
description: Ross Perot's statistics are generally accurate. But their relevance is sometimes less than clear.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROY ROGERS, the cleanest cut of cowboys, is back home in Apple Valley, Calif., after being hospitalized for a heart attack at the beginning of the month.

title: Workfare Screening of Homeless Starts, Then Stops
description: With blankets scattered on the floors and babies screaming in the background, city workers at a crowded housing center in the South Bronx began interviewing homeless women yesterday for a new workfare program. But only hours later, the Giuliani administration abruptly halted the interviews, yielding to a judge's order barring the enrollment effort at the center because of the chaotic conditions there.

title: Lifesaving Medical History Coming in a Flash
description: ''IMAGINE you've been in a serious accident. You can't breathe. You are about to black out.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: In-Line Skater Fatally Hit
description: A teen-ager who was in-line skating died in a hit-and-run accident after being struck by a delivery truck in Brooklyn yesterday, the police said.

title: From 'Good Cop' to Suspect in Fraud
description: A central figure in what investigators say is mob infiltration of the health care industry was recalled yesterday as a man who was once on the right side of the law, and proud of it.

title: Miscellany
description: McDonald's Corp., Oak Brook, Ill., and the Walt Disney Co. are joining for a promotion commemorating the 25th anniversary of the opening of Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla. The promotion features Disney glassware, sold with purchases of menu items, and a contest giving away vacations.

title: Irvin Sued by Car Dealers He Endorsed
description: Another speed bump developed yesterday in MICHAEL IRVIN's year of living dangerously. Alleging that the Dallas Cowboys wide receiver had misrepresented his ''image and reputation,'' a consortium of North Texas Toyota dealers sued Irvin and his agents for damages they claim to have suffered as a result of Irvin's recent cocaine-possession trial.

title: Pulsipher Seeking Help for Sore Elbow
description: Bill Pulsipher watched the Mets' 7-3 victory over the Giants this afternoon from his team's dugout. But his mind was not on the game. It was on his sore left elbow, the same elbow that underwent reconstructive surgery on April 17.

title: HUNTSMAN ENDS TAKEOVER OFFER FOR REXENE
