description: The Huntsman Corporation said yesterday that it had ended its $281.6 million cash offer to acquire the Rexene Corporation, a chemical maker. Rexene shares fell to $10.50 each in after-hours trading after closing at $12.75 on the New York Stock Exchange. The offer would have paid $16 a share. Huntsman's bid had been rejected by Rexene, which is based in Dallas, on Aug. 5. Huntsman would have assumed $175 million in Rexene debt, in addition to the cash portion of the offer. Rexene would have provided Huntsman, which is based in Houston, with a source of styrene for planned expansions of its plastics manufacturing business and with low-density polyethylene to use in its packaging-film operations.

title: Getting Even and Then Some as the Best Revenge
description: In ''Girls Town,'' Jim McKay's provocative ode to teen-age sisterhood in the hip-hop generation, Lili Taylor etches a type too rarely seen in the movies. As Patti, a tough-talking, hyperactive daredevil in a clique of four, she embodies the kind of motor-mouthed tomboy most likely to be named class clown in the high school yearbook.

title: Officials Across Europe Watch Bundesbank Talks
description: The meeting Thursday of Germany's Bundesbank central council is being watched by politicians, government officials and bankers across Europe with the hope that a rate cut could spur the Continent's economies.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: LITTLE LEAGUE WORLD SERIES

title: Survey Reports More Drug Use by Teen-Agers
description: Admitting they had not pushed hard enough for drug-abuse prevention programs, Federal officials disclosed yesterday that marijuana smoking among American teen-agers had jumped 141 percent from 1992 to 1995 and that overall teen-age drug use more than doubled.

title: Aide to Yeltsin Disputes Orders Over Chechnya
description: Directly challenging the authenticity of a major presidential directive, Aleksandr I. Lebed, the blunt, determined Russian national security adviser, said today that he did not believe that President Boris N. Yeltsin had actually written or signed a series of harsh new orders on the Chechen war that he received this week.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS AND SANO TO MAKE NEW VERSION OF DRUG
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company and the Sano Corporation said yesterday that they had agreed to collaborate to make a skin-patch version of Bristol-Myers's Buspar, a drug used to treat anxiety. Under the agreement, Bristol-Myers Squibb will develop and test Buspar so the drug can be delivered through the skin by means of an adhesive patch. Sano, which is based in Miramar, Fla., will make the patches and will get a percentage of the net sales. The companies said Sano could also get up to $40 million in payments during development. Sano's shares rose 50 cents, to $15.50, on Nasdaq. Bristol-Myers stock slipped 62.5 cents, to $88.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Downtown's Denizens: Fear, and Fearless Vendors
description: For decades apartheid laws kept downtown Johannesburg an island of pristine European order in the midst of Africa. White temples of economic power -- headquarters of the mining houses, the banking towers, the stock exchange, the media conglomerates -- dominated the skyline, and blacks moved shyly, as if furtive visitors.

title: Dole, Kemp and Their Tax Plan Make First Commercial Foray
description: Armed with a straightforward theme, a Vice-Presidential candidate and Federal financing, the Dole campaign today began broadcasting a new commercial featuring the Republican ticket and its tax plan, while attacking President Clinton on the state of the economy.

title: Geoffrey Dearmer, 103, Poet Whose Muse Was World War
description: Geoffrey Dearmer, a poet of such abiding modesty that he had to live to a hundred to see himself lionized as one of England's poetic voices of World War I, died on Sunday at his home at Birchington-on-Sea, on the Kentish coast. He was 103.

title: Rebate Errors, and Returns
description: Some 63,000 New Jersey residents who got homestead rebate checks by mistake are being asked to return the money, officials said yesterday. The checks -- averaging $208 -- were sent to people who incorrectly marked their rebate applications so that they appeared to qualify for the rebate program by being disabled or at least 65 years old. The discrepancies were found when the rebate applications were compared with income tax forms. People who fail to comply will not receive further rebates or income tax refunds until the money is recovered, said Mary Lou Murphy, a spokeswoman for the state Treasurer's office.

title: Lie Detector Clears Atlanta Bomb Suspect, His Lawyers Say
description: In their latest effort to pressure Federal investigators, lawyers for Richard A. Jewell released the results of a lie detector test today and produced a polygraph examiner who said he was convinced that Mr. Jewell had no involvement in the July 27 bombing at Centennial Olympic Park here.

title: CHAMPION ENTERPRISES AGREES TO BUY REDMAN INDUSTRIES
description: Champion Enterprises Inc. said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to buy a competitor, Redman Industries, in a $357 million stock swap that would create one of the nation's largest makers of manufactured housing. Champion will exchange 1.24 of its common shares for each of Redman's 13.3 million shares outstanding. The deal values Redman shares at about $26.80. They rose 43.75 cents yesterday, to $26.175, in Nasdaq trading. The companies disclosed last week that they were discussing a merger. Redman's board has approved the transaction, which is subject to approval by its shareholders. Champion, which is based in Auburn Hills, Mich., is the second-largest producer of manufactured homes after Fleetwood Enterprises Inc. Redman, which is based in Dallas, is the third largest.

title: Personal Health
description: BETSY JACOBSON of Brewster, N.Y., had grappled with the crippling effects of depression and a deflated ego almost her entire life. Reared in a domineering family with a controlling father, she was unable to fulfill her ambitions and use her talents as an actress.

title: New Zealand Sells State Forestry Business
description: The New Zealand Government said yesterday that it had sold its state-owned Forestry Corporation to a consortium led by Fletcher Challenge Ltd. for $2.03 billion (New Zealand), or about $1.4 billion. The consortium said it would invest $260 million (New Zealand) the next eight years to upgrade the company's wood-processing operation.

title: '96 Election Represents Last Hurrah of Generational Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a recently resurrected concert film by the Rolling Stones misidentified the shooting location. It was a television studio at Wembley in London, not Wembley Stadium. The article also referred incorrectly to the 1969 Woodstock festival. The Stones did not play there.

title: New Jersey Officials Say Mafia Infiltrated Health-Care Industry
description: In what authorities described as evidence that the Mafia had infiltrated the health-care industry, New Jersey officials said yesterday that they had smashed a ring that siphoned money from group health-care programs serving a million patients.

title: Ann Taylor Reports a Profit As Sales Rose in 2d Quarter
description: The Ann Taylor Stores Corporation reported a small second-quarter profit yesterday, compared with a loss in the second quarter of last year, as sales improved.

title: A Big Signing Bonus
description: The Chicago Bulls will pay Michael Jordan over $20 million next year to stuff basketballs through hoops. Associated Communications agreed this week to pay Alex Mandl about $20 million to quit AT&T, where he was a likely heir to the top job, and take over the start-up telecommunications company. Mr. Jordan, the world's best basketball player, has brought Chicago four world championships. Mr. Mandl will be running a new business with few employees and an unproven product.

title: Cambodia's Dual Premiers Are Split on Khmer Rouge
description: Is the Khmer Rouge dissident leader, Ieng Sary, a mass murderer beyond redemption, or should he be welcomed back into society with guarantees for his safety? It depends on which of Cambodia's two Prime Ministers is talking.

title: The Sting Of Tear Gas And Regret
description: It may be fitting that for all the nostalgia about to be unleashed in Chicago next week, when the Democrats return to the scene of their infamously discordant 1968 convention, no one has bothered to invite former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy.

title: Man Held in Ambush
description: Thanks to a blend of determined detective work and plain good luck, police officials announced the arrest of a man who they said had ambushed and critically wounded a police officer in Washington Heights. The arrest came as the officer's condition was said to improve markedly.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Computers column in Science Times yesterday misstated the advertised capacities of some tape cartridges and drives. Drives using 1.6-gigabyte tapes are often labeled 3.2-gigabyte units (or 3,200-megabyte).

title: Who Put the @ in Your E-Mail? Find Out Here
description: WHERE WIZARDS STAY UP LATE

title: Golden Night for Fernandez
description: The moment could hardly have been more dramatic and more pressure-packed for Lisa Fernandez.

title: On State Street, that great street, a couple of old pillars and a prospering wave of discounters.
description: AN Old Navy store is scheduled for construction on State Street here, a development that is expected to further the revival of retailing in Chicago's downtown shopping district.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN, whose ''New York Philharmonic Young People's Concerts'' brought classical music to the baby-boomer generation of television watchers in the 1950's and 1960's, is getting a place in cyberspace. His heirs have signed a licensing agreement with N2K Inc., an entertainment company that will develop and manage a new site on the World Wide Web. The address will be http://www.leonardbernstein.com.

title: ROGERS COMMUNICATIONS TO SELL CHECK PRINTING UNIT
description: Rogers Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell its Davis & Henderson unit, a check-printing business, to the MDC Communications Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. Rogers, a diversified communications company based in Toronto, acquired Davis & Henderson as part of the purchase of Maclean Hunter Ltd. in 1994. Davis & Henderson has a nearly 50 percent share of the Canadian check market, and it is expected to generate revenue in excess of $80 million (Canadian) in the current fiscal year. It employs more than 750 people at seven plants in Canada and one in the United States. Through its United States subsidiary, Check Gallery Inc., Davis & Henderson is also involved in the check business in the United States. MDC is also based in Toronto.

title: Metaphor! Hut, Hut ... Go, Team, Go!
description: His vocabulary is often cribbed straight from a play book. His frame of reference is frequently bounded by the gridiron, with football serving as a metaphor for everything from race relations to economic policy. An imaginary football forever in his hand, he throws not air kisses but air passes to the crowds.

title: Fed Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged
description: Federal Reserve policy makers met yesterday and, as had been widely expected, left the central bank's short-term interest rate target unchanged at 5.25 percent.

title: Brightest Stars at Garden Are the Women
description: Kathleen Collins looked across the ring and saw her disheveled opponent standing a few feet away. The woman's hair was matted and her face was puffy, swelling by the moment.

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR TO CUT 170 ADDITIONAL JOBS
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 170 jobs, mostly in California, as it struggles with falling sales of its computer chips. The cuts are the third in three months, bringing the number of jobs to be eliminated to 590. The company has 20,000 employees. The company also expects to take a charge of $280 million to $320 million against earnings in its current quarter. National Semiconductor is based in Santa Clara, Calif.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MEL TORME, the singer known as the Velvet Fog, suffered a stroke on Aug. 8 and was listed in guarded condition in an unidentified hospital in the Los Angeles area yesterday. The stroke left his speech slurred and weakened his left side, said his spokesman, Rob Wilcox. Mr. Torme has also been fighting pneumonia.

title: A Golfer's Choice
description: To the Editor;

title: Invitation Gives Graves Wealth of Opportunity
description: Wayne Gretzky and Mark Messier had just left the ice after skating on the same practice line here at Team Canada's training camp and were sharing a laugh on the bench. Sitting next to them, transfixed, was their new Team Canada linemate, Adam Graves.

title: Negotiations May Resume
description: After a week of intense telephone conversations among owners, negotiators for baseball's club owners and players appear to be ready to resume their efforts to complete a new collective bargaining agreement.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about promotional agreements between drug companies and nonprofit health care associations misidentified the marketer of the over-the-counter version of Nicorette chewing gum. It is SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., not Johnson & Johnson.

title: Disorder in the Kremlin
description: An air of anarchy grows daily about the Russian Government. President Boris Yeltsin is ill and absent. His aides appear to be waging a fierce struggle for power. Military commanders may be preparing a counterattack against Chechen rebels without authorization from Mr. Yeltsin and in defiance of his top military adviser. It is a deeply disheartening and disturbing turn just weeks after Mr. Yeltsin's decisive election victory.

title: CENTURY COMMUNICATIONS TO ACQUIRE 3 CABLE SYSTEMS
description: Jones Intercable Inc. and one of its managed partnerships said yesterday that they had agreed to sell three cable television systems in Southern California to the Century Communications Corporation for $140 million. Jones Intercable will sell two cable systems, serving about 59,000 customers in Diamond Bar, Calif., and in parts of Los Angeles County, for about $104 million. Separately, the partnership, Jones Growth Partners II L.P., agreed to sell a system serving about 17,000 people in Yorba Linda and in parts of Anaheim and Orange Counties for about $36 million. Jones Intercable is based in Englewood, Colo. Century is based in New Canaan, Conn.

title: In Liberia, Life Returns to a Grim Normality
description: With petty commerce cluttering the sidewalks, peacekeeping forces all over town and militia leaders flirting with the art of politics rather than warfare, life is slowly returning to this city battered by two months of savage fighting that broke out in April.

title: Slater Hanft Martin Gets a New Name
description: Slater Hanft Martin in New York, citing its new management team, has changed its name to Hanft Byrne Raboy Abrams Partners.

title: The Cassoulet Lacked One Ingredient
description: IT was the moment everyone dreams of. Lying on a beach in Martinique, George and Helen Studley, who had owned La Colombe d'Or, a New York fixture near Gramercy Park since 1976, turned to each other and laughed.

title: Amtrak Shows Favoritism in Service Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: B. F. GOODRICH CO., Akron, Ohio, said Westlake Monomers Corp. had canceled its agreement to buy Goodrich's remaining chemical operations in Calvert City, Ky., for $170 million.

title: A victory may be near in efforts to end the liability limit for international airline passengers.
description: VICTORY finally appears in sight after a decades-long battle by United States airlines to raise or eliminate the $75,000 liability limit for passengers killed or injured on international flights to and from this country.

title: Curriculum and Culture: New Round Is Opened In a Scholarly Fistfight
description: In 1987, Allan Bloom, then an obscure translator of Plato and Rousseau, touched a raw nerve when he argued in his book ''The Closing of the American Mind'' that the surrender of college and university administrations and faculties to the demands of student, feminist and Black Power movements in the 1960's and 1970's had fatally compromised American higher education.

title: Dole Attacks Foe on Military And Defends Own Tax Plan
description: With Gen. Colin L. Powell at his side, Bob Dole today went before the Veterans of Foreign Wars to assail President Clinton as being weak on defense and to pledge that veterans would not be hurt by his own plan to cut taxes while still balancing the budget by 2002.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Sprint to Offer Internet Service to Residential Customers
description: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that it would gradually begin offering low-cost Internet service to its residential customers later this year, becoming the third and last of the country's large long-distance telephone companies to expand into what has been a treacherous consumer Internet market.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: INSIDE
description: Minimum-Wage Bill Signed

title: No Headline
description: ''I get these invitations to speak on some campus and find that the students don't really want me, don't know what it's all about. But there's always about 10 faculty people who invited me and want me to talk about the old days.''

title: Channel 4 Tests a 7:30 P.M. Newscast
description: In a move that could interest many commuters who don't get home early enough to watch the 6 P.M. local news, WNBC-TV/Channel 4 will broadcast an additional half-hour local newscast at 7:30 P.M. on the four weekdays after Labor Day, the station announced yesterday.

title: 1. Boil Water 2. Pick Tomatoes
description: For a simple summer dinner, turn tomatoes into an uncooked sauce and spoon it over hot pasta. This version calls for a sauce with olives over cheese-filled tortellini. Add an ear or two of corn, if you like.

title: A Buttery Cake to Please a President
description: ALMOST every New Yorker knows that William Greenberg Jr. Desserts and Cafes is one of the most delicious places in town to get your fat fix. So it isn't surprising that it came to the attention of Hillary Rodham Clinton as a logical place to get a cake for the President's 50th birthday party, on Sunday night at the Sheraton New York.

title: Giuliani Installs Managers for Little Italy Fair in New Move on Mob
description: The Giuliani administration yesterday stepped up its efforts to rid the Feast of San Gennaro in Little Italy of organized crime, announcing that it would install new managers to run the street fair, which is the city's largest and most famous.

title: Neil Young in Concert: How to Get to the Point
description: Neil Young sang his credo as one of his encores at Madison Square Garden on Monday night. ''People tell us that we play too loud/But they don't know what our music's about,'' he declared in ''Prisoners of Rock 'n' Roll.'' He continued, ''That's why we don't want to be good.''

title: How Snap Analysis Spurred an AT&T Slide
description: In academic debates, getting the last word is crucial. But on Wall Street, where stock traders make split-second decisions based on snap impressions, the first word is often what matters.

title: India's Test-Ban Opposition Isn't Strategic Ploy
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about an effort by a New York money manager to force Wallace Computer Services Inc. to eliminate certain anti-takeover provisions, after the Moore Corporation dropped a bid for Wallace, referred incorrectly to the amount of that bid. It was $30 a share, not $60. It had been $60 before Wallace split its stock, 2 for 1, in July.

title: Backup Runner for Jets Feels Grounded at Last
description: Life in pro football, says Reggie Cobb, has been a roller coaster. He is a running back with proven talent, but everywhere he has gone, something has fouled him up -- an injury, a change in philosophy, an attitude.

title: Debating Workfare: Mayor's Effort Raises Questions Over Impact on Poor
description: When a State Supreme Court justice interfered on Monday with the Giuliani administration's plans to put homeless mothers to work for their welfare benefits, the resulting brushfire quickly illuminated some of the issues raised by workfare's swift expansion through New York.

title: Lions Plan a New Den In Downtown Detroit
description: The Detroit Lions football team announced today that after more than 20 years in the suburbs, it planned to move back into its namesake city.

title: Lineup of Speakers for Convention: Citizens, Both Famous and Not So
description: The prime-time speakers at the Democratic National Convention next week will blend Hollywood heartbreak, human drama and spousal support in a lineup featuring Christopher Reeve, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Tipper Gore, campaign officials disclosed today.

title: U.S.C. Runner Is Suspended
description: Delon Washington, Southern California's leading rusher last season, was suspended by the school yesterday and will miss Sunday's Kickoff Classic against Penn State at Giants Stadium.

title: A British agency aims at 'street furniture' contracts in the U.S.
description: MORE O'FERRALL P.L.C., one of the world's largest outdoor advertising companies, is opening its first American office, in New York. The expansion by the company, which operates in Europe and Asia as well as its home market of Britain, is part of plans to enter the urban out-of-home advertising field in the United States.

title: Does Reeves Entertain Death Wish?
description: THERE are times when Dan Reeves almost seems to be looking to be run out of town. Here is a diabolical suggestion: Make him stay and coach the Giants a while longer.

title: Users Leave, Contributing to Financial Loss At Compuserve
description: The Compuserve Corporation said yesterday that it had been losing customers this summer, contributing to larger-than-expected losses in its most recent quarter.

title: Benefits to Education Stressed Over Wealth
description: Jami Armstrong's life did not change all that much after she won a New York State lottery game. No yachts, mansions or other great riches came her way.

title: Defying U.S., India May Resume Long-Range Missile Tests
description: SINGAPORE  India is likely to resume long-range missile testing after a halt of more than than two years despite pressure from the United States for a permanent cessation, a senior Indian official indicated Tuesday.

title: Planning for '97 Campaign
description: The Presidential race is just heating up, but W. Michael Murphy Jr., a former Morris County Prosecutor and the stepson of former Gov. Richard Hughes, is looking ahead to the 1997 governor's race. Mr. Murphy, who lives in Chatham and practices law in Summit, said yesterday that he was forming a committee to explore a run for the Democratic nomination. ''Frankly, if I wait until November, the candidates of the well-oiled political machines would have a great advantage on me,'' Mr. Murphy, 47, said. Others mentioned as possible candidates are State Senator James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge, former Gov. Jim Florio, and Representative Robert Andrews of Haddon Heights.

title: Clinton Signs a Bill Raising Minimum Wage by 90 Cents
description: Ending a political battle Democrats had played to their advantage for months, President Clinton signed legislation today raising the minimum wage by 90 cents an hour over the next year, saying the measure would give 10 million workers ''a chance to raise stronger families and build better futures.''

title: Operating Profit Rose In First Half at Wella
description: Wella A.G., the German hair-care company, reported yesterday that it had healthy growth in sales and earnings in the first six months.

title: CHINA HAS BECOME CHIEF CONTRIBUTOR TO U.S. TRADE GAP
description: For the first time on record, China has surpassed Japan as the largest source of the American trade deficit, a development that could further strain relations with Beijing over what the Clinton Administration contends are unfair limits on products made in the United States.

title: Cabbies Help Police Find Suspect in Shooting of an Officer
description: Thanks to a blend of determined detective work and plain good luck, police officials yesterday announced the arrest of a Brooklyn man who they said had ambushed and critically wounded a police officer in Washington Heights last Thursday.

title: Large Search For 3 Youths Last Seen On Monday
description: The police were searching yesterday for three young boys -- two of them brothers living in foster care -- who have been missing since they went out to play in their Bronx neighborhood on Monday afternoon.

title: Government Ends Its Case In Scheme to Bomb Planes
description: After a dozen weeks of testimony from 47 witnesses and the introduction of more than 1,000 exhibits, Government prosecutors yesterday rested their first terrorism case against Ramzi Ahmed Yousef. But while some of the evidence directly incriminated him in a plot to blow up American jetliners in Asia, other parts of it were less conclusive.

title: McSorley Traded to Sharks
description: The Rangers freed themselves of a big salary, and a disappointment, by trading Marty McSorley to the San Jose Sharks yesterday for defenseman Jay More, center Brian Swanson and a 1998 fourth-round pick.

title: ABB Switzerland Sees Weaker Results in '96
description: ABB Switzerland, the Swiss unit of Asea Brown Boveri, said yesterday that it expected lower full-year profit after first-half earnings fell 7 percent. In the first half, profits totaled 139 million Swiss francs ($115 million), compared with 150 million francs a year earlier.

title: Photographer's Ex-Wife Sentenced in Theft of Work
description: The former wife of O. Winston Link, the 81-year-old photographer known for his black-and-white images of America's last railroad steam engines, was sentenced here today to 6 1/3 to 20 years in prison for stealing more than $1 million worth of his photographic prints.

title: Clinton Friend Gets Sentence Of Two Years
description: Susan McDougal, a former business partner of President and Mrs. Clinton, was sentenced to two years in prison today in a Whitewater-related fraud case, a decision that one of Mrs. McDougal's lawyers denounced as politically motivated.

title: Teachers Back a Republican
description: The New Jersey Education Association, which on Monday endorsed a Democrat, Representative Robert G. Torricelli, in his bid for the Senate, is backing a Republican, Kathleen A. Donovan of Lyndhurst, to succeed him, a union spokeswoman said yesterday. Ms. Donovan, a former member of the State Assembly, won the union's endorsement because of her opposition to private school vouchers and her record on school spending, said the spokeswoman, Karen Joseph. Her Democratic opponent, Steve Rothman of Englewood, also opposes vouchers, a spokesman said.

title: Genie Online Is Acquired
description: The IDT Corporation has bought Genie Online Service, a small Internet company that provides electronic discussions and games, from the Yovelle Renaissance Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. The sale comes seven months after Genie's founder, the General Electric Company, sold the service to Yovelle. Genier was one of the first companies to offer Internet services when it was created in 1985. The service had about 20,000 customers in the United States.

title: SFX BROADCASTING AGREES TO BUY 4 STATIONS IN RICHMOND
description: SFX Broadcasting Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy ABS Communications L.L.C. for $37.5 million. With the deal, which is expected to close in late October, SFX will acquire four radio stations in Richmond, giving it about 80 stations across the country. The stations affected by the deal are WVGO-FM, WLEE-FM, WKHK-FM and WBZU-FM. WKHK-FM is the top-ranked station in Richmond in terms of revenue and audience share, SFX said.

title: When Convention Speeches Soared
description: Television, along with other cultural triumphs, now gives us the prefabricated Presidential convention. Or, rather, political managers have given the prefabricated convention to television. This development portends the end of the convention as we know it.

title: In Jordan, Bread-Price Protests Signal Deep Anger
description: As soldiers in armored personnel carriers maintained a sullen peace under the jagged ramparts of the Crusader fort here, Jordan's attention shifted to sorting out the reasons and the consequences of the food riots that erupted last week in a kingdom that is usually held up by the West as a paragon of stability and steadfastness in the Middle East.

title: Yankees Have the Runs and Hits, Angels the Errors
description: A flushed and frustrated David Weathers meekly handed Joe Torre the baseball in the first inning last night and probably wished he had a shovel instead of a glove so he could dig a hole and hide. Decent starters are not supposed to rouse their manager by allowing five runs in the first.

title: A Visit From Dole and Kemp
description: Bob Dole and Jack Kemp are to hold a rally at Lincoln Park in Rutherford tomorrow, campaign officials said. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, whose come-from-behind victory in 1993 was attributed to her pledge to cut the state income tax, will join the nominees as they explain their proposed tax cut, said Jack Mozloom, a spokesman for the Dole campaign in New Jersey. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Here's the Call: Interference. And the Mets Will Take It.
description: Dallas Green is looking for anything that will jump-start his team into a pattern of consistent success: a come-from-behind victory, a great pitching performance, a scolding from the manager.

title: The Familiar Giacometti And the Unfamiliar, From a Fresh Angle
description: So familiar are Alberto Giacometti's bronzes of narrow heads and pencil-thin bodies that it may be pardonable to think he did little else. Certainly, without these signature works from the second half of his career, the Swiss-born sculptor would not be listed today among this century's most important artists.

title: Geulah Abrahams, Choreographer, 65
description: Geulah Abrahams, a modern dancer and choreographer, died on Saturday at the Princeton Medical Center in Princeton, N.J. She was 65 and had homes in Princeton and New York.

title: The Vision Thing
description: The Republican Party has been bush-whacked on foreign policy. Still scarred by the fate of George Bush, whom the public faulted for his focus on crises abroad at the expense of problems at home, the G.O.P. has been inarticulate about one of its cardinal strengths.

title: Woods Advances With High Honors
description: Just as Tiger Woods was taking his practice swing on the 14th tee in the second round of qualifying for the United States Amateur today, a cock crowed. It served as a symbolic, late-afternoon wake-up call for Woods, who was coming off two straight birdies. Just a little reminder to be vigilant because -- even though it did not seem so at the time -- he is human, after all.

title: Who Lost Turkey?
description: Not ''Who lost Russia?'' Not ''Who lost Bosnia?'' Not ''Who lost China?'' Not ''Who lost Saudi Arabia?'' No, the most heated foreign policy debate this election might turn out to be: ''Who lost Turkey?''

title: Letterman Stars In Coke Film Ad
description: The Coca-Cola Company has recruited David Letterman and a group of mediagenic youngsters for a 90-second sponsored message that will begin appearing Friday before films shown at 9,000 movie theaters.

title: Progress at 49
description: To the Editor:

title: Perot and Populist Group See Benefits in an Alliance
description: In a loft in downtown Manhattan scattered with mementos of Che Guevara, Dr. Fred Newman paid tribute to a new revolutionary hero, a man he would like to see in the White House next January.

title: Food Notes
description: From Pelts to Pasta

title: Berman to Pick Up Halftime Highlights
description: For its first 14 seasons, the hallmark of ''Monday Night Football'' halftimes was Howard Cosell's idiosyncratic narration of game highlights. The tradition, which ended with Cosell's departure in 1983, will be revived this season on ABC with the arrival of CHRIS BERMAN from ESPN as the halftime host.

title: Giants and Strahan Back to Business
description: The Giants have reopened contract talks with defensive end Michael Strahan and plan to make a big push to sign him during the next few weeks.

title: Corrections
description: The diagram with the Chess column yesterday, about Alex Yermolinsky's victory over Nick DeFirmian in the course of winning this year's national championship, reversed the players' positions. As noted in the list of moves, Mr. Yermolinsky played the white and Mr. DeFirmian the black.

title: Who Says Women Can't Play Football?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Long Island Store Fuses Two Concepts
description: LAST year's marriage between Sutton Place Gourmet, the Washington-based chain of eight fancy-food markets, and Hay Day, a group of five markets in Connecticut and Westchester, has spawned the first store that combines the concepts of both companies. A new Sutton Place Gourmet, as future stores will be named, opens tomorrow in 21,000 square feet at 8063 Jericho Turnpike (east of Route 135), Woodbury, L.I.

title: John A. McDermott, 70, Editor And Advocate for Civil Rights
description: John A. McDermott, an urban affairs and civil rights advocate who made waves in Chicago with a gadfly newsletter he founded and edited for 13 years, died on Saturday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. A Chicago resident since 1960, he was 70.

title: A Late Entry, CBS Jumps In With A Cable TV Channel
description: After a conspicuous absence from cable television that several senior executives called an embarrassment to the network, CBS formally announced a new cable channel yesterday, called Eye on People.

title: Exercise Meets Entertainment on a Virtual-Reality Bike
description: IT used to take discipline for Cheryl Bailey to get up at 6 o'clock for her morning workout. Now, Ms. Bailey, 34, an executive vice president at a Manhattan advertising agency, can't wait. For years, Bill Schreitmueller, 36, the executive producer of a television production company in Manhattan, went to the gym three days a week. Now, he goes every weekday.

title: The Next Republican Revolution?
description: Even before his first appearance on the stump, Jack Kemp had altered the optics of race in American politics. Mr. Kemp's appointment as Bob Dole's running mate has provoked a flurry of Democratic strategy meetings, with the leadership scrambling for ways to counteract a Republican who is as comfortable in Harlem or South Central Los Angeles as he is in corporate circles.

title: Cone Set to Start in Norwich
description: David Cone drove to Norwich, Conn., last night to prepare for his first start in more than three months for the Class AA Norwich Navigators against the Binghamton Mets tonight at 7:05. Cone, who is slated to throw 60 pitches, has not pitched since defeating the Chicago White Sox, 5-1, with a complete game on May 2.

title: Chess
description: Alex Yermolinsky is the United States champion for the second time. The 38-year-old grandmaster of Euclid, Ohio, shared the title in 1993, but now he has won it solo.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: B Sky B's Earnings Up 66% for Year
description: The satellite broadcaster B Sky B, the dominant force in the pay-television market in Britain, reported yesterday that it had a 66 percent increase in its profit to $:257.4 million ($398 million), in the year ended June 30. Revenue climbed to more than $:1 billion, as the number of subscribers in Britain and Ireland rose to 5.5 million.

title: U.N. Hardly Views Clinton as 'Follower'
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Overrules Order by Crew Suspending School Board in the South Bronx
description: The leadership of a South Bronx community school district was plunged into uncertainty yesterday when a state judge overruled an order by Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew suspending the district board and removing its new superintendent, just two weeks before the opening of school.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the News Summary yesterday about the Whitewater case in Little Rock referred incorrectly in some copies to the sentence given to former Gov. Jim Guy Tucker of Arkansas. He received four years' probation, not a four-year prison term.

title: Cancer Research Venture Forged By Sloan-Kettering and Sequana
description: Sequana Therapeutics Inc. and the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center said yesterday that they had agreed to form a venture in the field of cancer genetics.

title: U.S. May Halt Sale of Jets To Indonesia
description: The Clinton Administration, which has agreed to sell Indonesia at least nine F-16 fighter jets, is now debating whether to delay or cancel the sale as a response to a serious crackdown on political dissent.

title: Results at S.A.S. Show Some Improvement
description: Scandinavian Airlines System said yesterday that its first-half pretax profit rose 1 percent, to 1.05 billion kronor ($159 million), helped by a narrowing of losses on investments, currency fluctuations and income from the sale of assets. In the first half of 1995, S.A.S. had a pretax profit of 1.04 billion kronor.

title: DEMOTED CHIEF EXECUTIVE RESIGNS FROM NATIONAL STEEL
description: The National Steel Corporation said late yesterday that V. John Goodwin, who was stripped of his chief executive post last Wednesday, had resigned. The demotion of Mr. Goodwin, by the NKK Corporation of Japan, which owns 51 percent of National Steel, had surprised some analysts and company insiders. At the time, National Steel, the nation's fifth biggest steel maker, asked Mr. Goodwin, who is 53, to stay on as president and chief operating officer. Osamu Sawaragi, National Steel's chairman and the senior management counsel for NKK, has taken over as chief executive. Mr. Goodwin could not be reached for comment.

title: Graf Tops Open Seeding
description: The defending champion, Steffi Graf of Germany, was seeded No. 1 in the women's singles championship of the United States Open, which starts Monday and runs through Sept. 8, at the U.S.T.A. National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens. In the seedings announced yesterday, Graf was followed by Monica Seles, at No. 2; Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, No. 3; Conchita Martinez, No. 4; Iva Majoli, No. 5; Anke Huber, No. 6; Jana Novotna, No. 7, and Lindsay Davenport, No. 8.

title: How Venezuela Is Becoming Coca-Cola Country
description: Roger A. Enrico, now chief executive of Pepsico Inc., and Oswaldo Cisneros, whose family ran Pepsi's oldest and most highly respected bottling operation, were close. Among other things, they and their wives traveled together on business. Indeed, Mr. Enrico was taking a turn on the dance floor with Mr. Cisneros's wife, Ella, in a nightclub in Istanbul, Turkey, on the eve of a safari they were to take, when he suffered the heart attack that sidetracked him, for a time, from reaching the summit of Pepsico.

title: Texaco Seeks Approval For India Methane Plan
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it was seeking approval from the Indian Government to proceed with a $1 billion coal-bed methane gas plan.

title: Long Lost Melodrama With a Twist at Every Turn
description: Two lines from an overripe torch song that serves as the epigraph for ''Aventurera'' come close to distilling the essence of this 1949 Mexican melodrama, which has enough plot to fill several verismo operas: ''And he who wants the honey from your lips/ Must pay the price in diamonds for your sin.''

title: Del Miller, Legendary Driver In the Sulky, Is Dead at 83
description: Del Miller, the Hall of Fame harness racing driver who competed in eight decades and the man who steered his sport through the Iron Curtain, died Monday at his home in Washington, Pa. He was 83.

title: U.N. Hardly Views Clinton as 'Follower'
description: To the Editor:

title: Not How You Start, But How You Finish
description: KWEISI MFUME was running late for a dinner meeting.

title: It's a Not-So-Simple Father-Son Story for the McCutcheons
description: The Deion Sanders youth are upon us.

title: Senator's Warning on Taxes
description: A proposal by the Whitman administration to phase out a special utility tax could lead to increased property taxes, John A. Lynch, the State Senate minority leader, said yesterday. Last March, state officials announced plans to eliminate the energy tax and proposed instead to subject the utilities to corporate income tax and sales tax. Senator Lynch, a Democrat from New Brunswick, said he had established a commission to study the effects of the proposal. State Senator James E. McGreevey, Democrat of Woodbridge, who will head the commission, predicted that municipal governments would lose $480 million in revenue by 2002 if the tax cut goes through.

title: Galindo Charged With Drunken Driving
description: The defending national figure skating champion, RUDY GALINDO, ''drank way too much'' before he was arrested for investigation of drunken driving early yesterday, his agent said.

title: Love, From a Villa to a Dentist's Office
description: Love may well be where you find it, and the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts is offering it in widely divergent locales with productions of Eduardo De Filippo's ''Filumena'' and Clifford Odets's ''Rocket to the Moon'' as season finales on its two stages. De Filippo's delicious confection on love, marriage and parenthood takes place in a sunlit villa in Naples in 1946, while Odets set his play in a Manhattan dentist's office in 1938 during a heat wave.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Trade Deficit Shrinks, But Gap With China Surges

title: N.F.L. TRAINING CAMP REPORT
description: San Francisco 49ers

title: In Die-Hard Kiev, Hotels Are Houses of Horrors
description: ''Three hundred and twenty five dollars. Pay now.''

title: Can't Beat Woodstock? Join It
description: THERE is still a flock of Woodstock faithful, perhaps several thousand strong, who believe the spirit of the '69 festival is a peace-, love- and rock-and-roll-spreading force too powerful for mere mortals to suppress.

title: INDIA VETOES PACT TO FORBID TESTING OF NUCLEAR ARMS
description: Rejecting pleas from the United States and other nuclear powers not to block consensus on an international treaty banning nuclear testing, India formally vetoed the pact today, effectively derailing more than two years of negotiations in Geneva.

title: Natural Gas Prices Decline; Copper and Wheat Also Fall
description: Natural gas prices fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday as worries eased that Hurricane Dolly would disrupt production at offshore platforms in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: With Triborough Bridge Debut, A Test for E-Z Pass Toll System
description: In the biggest test yet of its new electronic toll system, the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority introduced the E-Z Pass today on the Triborough Bridge, the agency's busiest crossing in the city.

title: 'Ethnic Particulars'
description: To the Editor:

title: $700 Million Deals By Cemex of Mexico
description: Cemex S.A., the Mexican company that is the world's third-largest cement maker, has paid a total of $700 million to buy a majority share in two Colombian cement companies.

title: Yanks Leave Lots of Ducks on the Pond in Loss to Angels
description: The Yankees littered the bases with runners throughout the damp afternoon, inexplicably leaving them to loosen mud from their cleats and yawn as they waited to scamper home. None did.

title: New Ramp for Exits 14-14C
description: A new ramp for Exits 14 through 14C will open Friday on the New Jersey Turnpike's southbound outer roadway, the Turnpike Authority said yesterday. The new ramp leading to Newark, Newark Airport, Bayonne, Jersey City and the Holland Tunnel is half a mile north of the one it replaces, and drivers who miss it will have to continue south to Exit 13A to turn around.

title: Garden of the Slightly Macabre
description: ON summer mornings here, when thick gray fog billows off the Pacific Ocean and settles in for a few cool, moist hours, it is easy to imagine a time when dinosaurs roamed the earth. Especially behind the walls of Lotusland, the extraordinary, largely unknown garden that is the jewel of this manicured suburb east of Santa Barbara. Here are 37 densely planted, willfully wild acres that look left over from ''Jurassic Park.''

title: Louis Quatorze Preps For Wet Travers Track
description: The leading contenders for the 3-year-old championship were gathering today for Saturday's $750,000 Travers Stakes, the mile-and-a-quarter race that often decides issues left unresolved by the Kentucky Derby.

title: MINNESOTA POWER ACQUIRES REST OF ADESA CORP.
description: The Minnesota Power and Light Company said yesterday that it had acquired the 17 percent of the Adesa Corporation that it did not already own. Financial terms were not disclosed. Adesa, which is based in Indianapolis, operates an auto-auction business. Minnesota Power, based in Duluth, Minn., is a utility holding company.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the Edinburgh Festival referred incorrectly in some copies to the nationality of the pianist Yevgeny Kissin, who played there. He is Russian, not Israeli.

title: AT&T turns to its core agencies in awarding additional responsibilities.
description: THE AT&T Corporation awarded key additional responsibilities yesterday to two of its four roster agencies, Young & Rubicam Inc. and FCB/Leber Katz Partners.

title: Harley M. Jones, 60, Architect Who Taught at the Pratt Institute
description: Harley Morton Jones, a community-minded architect who was a former chairman of the Department of Interior Design at the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, died on Sunday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 60.

title: New Jersey Script for Dole's Tax Cut
description: The Republican challenger, far behind in the polls, promised to slash taxes and reinvigorate the economy, then stormed back to defeat an incumbent Democrat who had raised taxes.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: PAN AMERICAN COULD GET FLIGHT CLEARANCE SOON
description: The new Pan American World Airways Inc. has won tentative Government approval to resume operations. The United States Department of Transportation issued a ''show cause'' order on Tuesday, giving interested parties 15 days to comment on the plan to resume service, Bill Mosely, a department spokesman, said yesterday. If no serious objections are raised, Pan Am could be cleared to fly immediately, he said. Pan Am must still earn certification from the Federal Aviation Administration. An airline spokesman, Jeff Kriendler, said the carrier expected to begin service in September. In January 1991, Pan Am filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

title: Liability Injustice
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Still Leads Field in Arms Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: Bond Yields At Highest In 3 Weeks
description: The prices of government securities fell yesterday, sending the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond up to its highest point in three weeks, as concern persisted that the Federal Reserve might still raise interest rates this year.

title: Surprise Winner in '94 Becomes a Target in '96
description: Decked out in cowboy boots and blue jeans and carrying a pitcher in each hand, Dr. Greg Ganske, the Representative of Iowa's Fourth Congressional District, was looking to harvest a few votes recently by playing waiter at the pork tent at the Iowa State Fair.

title: Giants Waiting for Their Running Game
description: If the Giants are to have any success this season -- and even an 8-8 record would be a success given their youth and trouble spots -- their running game must carry the offense. And Rodney Hampton, their tailback, must carry the running game.

title: Anti-Missile Issue
description: One month after Russia's first democratic election, a most undemocratic power struggle is ripping apart the Kremlin.

title: How America Unsexes the Asian Male
description: THE Japanese-American actor Marc Hayashi once said to me: ''Every culture needs its eunuchs. And we're it. Asian-American men are the eunuchs of America.'' I felt an instant shock of recognition.

title: Sun Communities Bid Creates a Battle for Chateau Properties
description: Sun Communities Inc. offered yesterday to buy rival Chateau Properties Inc. for $370 million in stock, setting the stage for a showdown among the largest owners of mobile-home parks.

title: 2 More Executives Leave Sunbeam
description: Two more senior managers have left the Sunbeam Corporation in the latest management shake-up by Albert J. Dunlap, the chairman and chief executive.

title: Mets Show True Grit As Giants Just Win
description: It was one of those maddening games that have defined the Mets' season, where the shouldas, couldas, wouldas left a bittersweet taste even in defeat. The Mets were beaten, 12-11, by the San Francisco Giants this afternoon at 3Com Park, but there were more reasons to admire their effort than ridicule it.

title: PATRIOT AMERICAN DEAL WITH DOUBLETREE HOTELS
description: Patriot American Hospitality Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy as much as $200 million worth of hotels from the Doubletree Corporation in the next two years. Under the deal, Doubletree will continue managing and retain a 10 percent stake in each of the hotels sold to Dallas-based Patriot. The transaction would give Patriot the inside track on any hotels Doubletree planned to sell later and would give Doubletree the money to expand hotel management operations. Patriot owns 35 hotels nationwide and has agreed to buy 7 more in the next 90 days. Phoenix-based Doubletree manages more than 170 hotels in 37 states, the District of Columbia and Mexico.

title: Paul Tishman, 96, a Developer And a Collector of African Art
description: Paul Tishman, a member of the long established New York construction and real estate family whose independent development company did major projects in the New York area, died at his home in Manhattan on Monday. He was 96.

title: Drivers Give Passing Grade To E-Z Pass In Major Test
description: E-Z Pass, the electronic system designed to speed traffic at tollbooths, was introduced at the Triborough Bridge yesterday morning and lived up to its name, allaying fears that it would cause wicked headaches for commuters there as it had on other roadways.

title: 2 Suicides on Train Tracks
description: For the second time this week, a man has apparently taken his life on a New Jersey Transit train track, officials said yesterday. The latest case occurred yesterday morning about two miles from Pennsylvania Station in Newark when a man jumped in front of a Trenton-bound train, said Steven Coleman, a spokesman for the transit agency. Trains were blocked for three hours, forcing passengers to ride buses, he said.

title: Helter-Shelter: New Look for Dream Books
description: TWO teen-age girls in short white dresses on a sofa, lips slightly pouting, present themselves to the camera, their tennis-tanned limbs entwined like ivy. The photograph, by Dewey Nicks, with its provocative closeness, hints at forbidden sex.

title: Justice Freedman Is Right
description: At New York City's Emergency Assistance Unit in the Bronx, homeless families with toddlers and newborn infants sleep in a crowded, filthy office for days at a time while waiting to be processed into the shelter system. The crowding became severe again this summer despite a decade-old court order requiring the city to provide timely and humane housing. Then the Giuliani administration took a foolish step that could only prolong the delays. It started screening the mothers for workfare jobs even while they were in crisis and anxious about finding their children a decent place to sleep.

title: Demolishing the Projects
description: A 13-story building in a public housing project is scheduled to be demolished today, and various dignitaries, including Mayor Sharpe James of Newark and Henry G. Cisneros, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, will be on hand to celebrate. The structure to be razed is one of four remaining buildings in the Edward W. Scudder Homes.

title: Queens Woman Slain in Subway Stabbing
description: A Rego Park woman was stabbed to death in a busy Queens subway station yesterday morning in a dispute with a man investigators believed was her former live-in companion, police officials said.

title: Germany's Search for Libya Suspect Finds Ties to Its Own Spies
description: German authorities announced this week that three businessmen had been charged with selling the Libyan Government advanced equipment that can be used to manufacture nerve gas.

title: Holiday Inn Chooses Fallon McElligott
description: Holiday Inn Worldwide, a unit of Bass P.L.C., has named Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis to handle national advertising. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Bridge
description: The Greater New York Bridge Association organizes three double knockout team championships whose names recall three of its leading personalities. The open division is named for Waldemar Von Zedtwitz, the middle division for Sol Seidman, and the bottom division, for those who are not life masters, for Alice Harter.

title: WARNER-LAMBERT SHARES JUMP AFTER INVESTOR MEETING
description: The shares of the Warner-Lambert Company hit a record high yesterday amid speculation that Roche Holdings A.G. of Switzerland would make a bid for the company. Shares of Warner-Lambert, which makes Halls cough drops and Cognex, a drug treatment for Alzheimer's disease, rose $2.875, to close at $62.75, on the New York Stock Exchange after trading as high as $63.375. Warner-Lambert, based in Morris Plains, N.J., is often mentioned as a takeover candidate. Still, some analysts discounted the latest speculation, saying the price jump was partly caused by renewed interest in Warner-Lambert's new drug pipeline after a Boston meeting between the company and investors on Tuesday. Roche and Warner-Lambert declined to comment.

title: Woods Takes First Step Toward 3d Straight Title
description: One down, five to go.

title: Ad Spending Rises In Gay Publications
description: Advertising spending in publications aimed at gay and lesbian consumers rose significantly during the last year, an annual survey reported.

title: Profits Decline 17% At Fried. Krupp
description: The German steel and engineering company Fried. Krupp A.G. said yesterday that its profits tumbled 17 percent in the first half of 1996 as the weak German economy hurt the company's steel business. Pretax earnings fell to 185 million marks ($124.2 million) in the first six months of the year, from 223 million marks in the 1995 period, even though all six of its business divisions were profitable. Sales edged up 1 percent, to 11.7 billion marks.

title: A Long Fight Looms For Indy-Car Rivals
description: Last May 26, the day of the dueling 500's, was supposed to be Armageddon in the battle between Championship Auto Racing Teams and the new Indy Racing League. But, as last weekend proved, the fight for control of Indy-car racing will be long, with several smaller skirmishes deciding the winner.

title: A Lovely Bit of Old China, Languishing in the New
description: At the edge of this tiny mountain village, an old woman sits on a stone wall each afternoon and nods to anyone who comes along the mud path that is the only way to or from the world beyond.

title: N.F.L. TRAINING CAMP REPORT
description: Cincinnati Bengals

title: German Business Index Jumped in July
description: Germany's Ifo institute said yesterday that its business-climate index for July jumped to 94.1 from 90.4 in June, far exceeding economists' expectations for a figure of around 91. The index had been hotly awaited in financial markets. Many traders had looked for a weak figure, which would make it more likely that the German central bank would cut its main money market interest rate, the securities repurchase rate, today.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Saving Sunflower Seeds

title: Operating Loss Narrows At Klockner-Humboldt
description: The German engineering company Klockner-Humboldt-Deutz A.G. said yesterday that it had narrowed its operating loss in the first half of 1996, after a net loss in 1995 that was six and a half times the amount previously reported. Last year's net loss was 1.13 billion marks ($760 million), restated from the 174 million mark loss reported in April. The revision follows the disclosure in June of concealed losses at the company's KHD Humboldt Wedag A.G. plant.

title: Sanders Acquitted in Scooter Case
description: DEION SANDERS was acquitted yesterday of charges he injured a security guard while leaving Riverfront Stadium on a motor scooter two years ago. The jury in the personal injury lawsuit said Sanders, then with the Cincinnati Reds, did not injure the guard, Detective HERB KOHUS of the Cincinnati police. Sanders, now a defensive back with the Dallas Cowboys, was acquitted last year of criminal charges stemming from the confrontation. (AP)

title: Desks Go West
description: TWO makers of office furniture have left the International Design Center, New York, in Long Island City, Queens, for Manhattan.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-16

title: Agency Is Accused of Eroding Welfare Cuts
description: One of Congress's Republican authors of the overhaul of the welfare system accused the Clinton Administration today of trying to ''undermine'' provisions of the bill that would cut off cash assistance to recipients who do not get jobs. President Clinton plans to sign the bill on Thursday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Missing Boys Found on Their Way Home
description: Three young boys who disappeared Monday afternoon after going out to play in their Bronx neighborhood were found unharmed on a subway train early yesterday morning, apparently on their way home from a mischievous journey to Coney Island, the police and child welfare officials said.

title: Many Women On Workfare Express Hope
description: IT seems that everybody has an opinion on whether welfare mothers should work. The Mayor and Congress do. So do social workers, welfare advocates and an occasional judge.

title: Groups Debate Sponsorship Of AIDS Fund-Raising Party
description: A drug overdose at a party to raise funds to fight AIDS has intensified the debate on whether a leading AIDS group should end its sponsorship of the annual event on Fire Island.

title: Proposal Is Made On Credit For Service
description: For more than a week, some baseball club owners lobbied hard against granting players service time for days they missed during the 1994-95 strike. Players, they argued vehemently, should not get credit for something they did not earn. Those owners were so adamantly opposed to the idea that they threatened to block a new labor agreement with the players.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ROLLS-ROYCE P.L.C., London, said it had received an order worth more than $:60 million ($92 million), to provide jet engines to United Parcel Service of America Inc.

title: NEW REPORT CITED ON CHEMICAL ARMS USED IN GULF WAR
description: The Pentagon has acknowledged in a new report that chemical weapons were detected as many as seven times in the first week of the 1991 Persian Gulf war near staging areas in northern Saudi Arabia, where tens of thousands of American troops were housed.

title: Rankings and Egos Ignored in Draw
description: It seems like a flavor saver of sorts, a preservative method that could keep the United States Open's most colorful, most popular, most goatee-loving figures in the tournament as long as possible. It's the 1996 United States Open draw.

title: In Corporate Bonds, These Are the Good Old Days
description: Happy days are here again. Or at least they are getting close.

title: Where Collectors Start Their Dance
description: ONE is likely to stumble across just about anything at the Madison-Bouckville Outdoor Antique Show -- except pretension.

title: U.N. Hears Conflicting Views on What to Do About Burundi
description: Highlighting the Security Council's increasing attention to internal conflicts in unstable countries rather than threats of war between nations, leaders of opposing political parties in Burundi came to New York today to brief the Council and try to influence what course it will take.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Aug. 11 about Gabriel Levine, a Connecticut manufacturer, omitted a survivor. She is a sister, Judith Gurian of Lawrence, L.I.

title: Parolee Is Charged in 3 Queens Slayings
description: A convicted drug dealer who had been classified as nonviolent and had served his sentence in boot camp before being released on parole was charged last night in the slayings of three women and the bludgeoning of a fourth in a vicious attack during a robbery in Queens last month, the police said.

title: Fires of Providence Dance to Music
description: IN Providence, R.I., tomorrow night from 8 to 11, 35 river bonfires will burn once again. Eleven of the bonfires are lined up on a strip of granite ledge, while 24 float individually farther along. The lights stretch from Memorial Park to Waterplace Park. A boat crew will be there to stoke the flames, and music will play from sound stations hidden beneath bridges.

title: Garden Wants Jones On October Fight Card
description: The day after they salvaged a lackluster card at the Theater, Madison Square Garden officials were at work trying to put together two more shows in the next several weeks, including one that will most likely involve Roy Jones Jr.

title: INSIDE
description: Election Anxiety in Bosnia

title: Corrections
description: A report on Sunday about the wedding of Gail Roberts and Herman Badillo, the previous day, included an outdated reference to the official who presided. He was Milton Mollen, a former deputy mayor of New York and former presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who was to perform the ceremony, was delayed by a helicopter problem after attending a memorial service in Pennsylvania for victims of the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800.

title: Running the Empire
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey's Script May Be Dole's Map
description: Looking at a battle plan adopted three years ago by a Republican who was behind in the polls but campaigned vigorously by calling for a stiff tax cut, Bob Dole seems to be hoping that following that same map can bring him the same sort of victory it did for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

title: French to Run Trains For London Commuters
description: The French utility Compagnie Generale des Eaux has agreed to run most of southeast England's commuter train services into London in return for spending $:400 million ($619 million) on new trains. Britain's Office of Passenger Rail Franchising said yesterday that it had decided to award a 15-year franchise contract for the South Eastern Train Company to the French company's CGEA division. (Reuters)

title: Coffee Prices Rise as Colombia Increases Payments to Farmers
description: Coffee prices rose yesterday after Colombia raised the amount it paid to farmers by 17 percent in response to heavy rains that cut this year's crop.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Living Section yesterday with an article about virtual-reality fitness equipment misspelled the surname of a man using a Sit-Up Master at Crunch Fitness. He was Tom Heavey, not Heavy.

title: CHRONICLE
description: On the day DENNIS RODMAN was supposedly settling down, he brought chaos -- and his autobiography -- to midtown Manhattan.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KOO STARK is in the headlines in London again. In the 1980's PRINCE ANDREW of Britain was nicknamed Randy Andy after his affair with the American-born actress, who had appeared in a soft-porn film. Now Ms. Stark, 40, has told a London magazine that she is expecting.

title: Santa Fe Opera Tales: Too Wet, Too Dry
description: You can learn a lot about an opera company and its audience in the moments when everything seems to be going wrong, and this month the Santa Fe Opera had one of those acid-test evenings. During the auction scene in the second act of ''The Rake's Progress,'' a thunderstorm that had been threatening in the distance all evening finally washed over, and into, the theater.

title: Dole Camp Seeks Disclosure Of Clinton's Medical Records
description: The Bob Dole campaign said today that President Clinton should make all of his medical records public, as Mr. Dole has, and not just summaries of his annual physical examinations.

title: Growing Fears in Britain Of Single-Currency Isolation
description: British financial executives and business economists are growing concerned about the consequences of being left out of the European Monetary Union if it comes into being 28 months from now, as planned.

title: No Headline
description: ''We do not know the limits of God's grace. And not knowing that, how can we possibly say we know these people are going to heaven, and these are not?''

title: F.C.C. Eases Equal-Time Rule for 3 Networks
description: The Federal Communications Commission said today that it would permit some television networks to pick and choose which candidates they would grant free broadcast time to this fall.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: After a Less Than Grand Old Time
description: With lawn mowed, shirts laundered and kitchen restocked after a 10-day trip, Steve Gunderson, Wisconsin Congressman, and Rob Morris, Virginia architect, treated themselves to a quiet dinner on their back porch, as crickets ushered in a tranquil twilight.

title: People
description: Connie Pettit was named managing director at the Multichannel Advertising Bureau International, New York, a new arm of the Cabletelevision Advertising Bureau. She had headed her own consulting company, Pettit & Associates, Laguna Niguel, Calif., which is now to close.

title: 'Barn-Raising' to Wire Schools for the Internet
description: Hoping to become one of the first states to connect all its schools and libraries to the Internet, Connecticut will be rounding up 5,000 volunteers to install the wiring on Sept. 28.

title: Angel Manager Is Hospitalized
description: Bothered by a painful right calf, John McNamara, the California Angels' manager, was admitted to Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan yesterday morning and was found to have a blood clot in his calf. The 64-year-old McNamara is undergoing further testing and will remain in the hospital for at least four days while he is monitored.

title: In Russian, Even Words Hold Music
description: When spoken by natives, the Russian language, with its slurred vowels and throaty consonants, can sound like some elemental kind of music. Many Russian songs are characterized by the way they bond vocal lines to the musical shape and rhythms of this strangely beautiful tongue. Three recent CD's of Russian songs provide some remarkable examples.

title: French Aide Talks With Immigrants but Hunger Strike Goes On
description: The French Government retreated today from its refusal to negotiate with several hundred illegal immigrants from Africa who have spent the last five months demanding permission to stay, but it was not enough to get 10 of them to call off a 48-day hunger strike.

title: If Cows Don't Pay Off, a Cornfield Maze Might Do the Trick
description: IT'S easy to lose your way in a cornfield because of those towering green stalks that obscure everything but the sky.

title: Survival of the Kindest
description: Does one need to be human to be humane? Last week, people around the world were startled to hear about a female gorilla that saved a 3-year-old boy. The child, who had fallen 18 feet into the primate exhibit at Chicago's Brookfield Zoo, was scooped up and carried to safety by Binti Jua, an 8-year-old western lowland gorilla. Binti was reared by humans who rewarded her for parental behavior. But no one had ever taught her how to react to an unconscious boy invading her space.

title: Value Judgments
description: Democrats planning their convention in Chicago may be as puzzled as I am about the party's record. Democrats have come to opposite conclusions on two issues dear to liberals: affirmative action and welfare reform.

title: Story of Punk: More the Ugly Gossip Than the Music's Impact
description: PLEASE KILL ME

title: Clinton Signs Bill to Give Portability In Insurance
description: In a South Lawn ceremony filled with both celebration and the ghosts of unmet goals, President Clinton signed a bill today to expand access to health insurance. And though the bill falls far short of his hope of insuring all Americans, he called it ''a long step toward the kind of health care reform our nation needs.''

title: Another Push for Airport Security
description: The sluggish start of President Clinton's new commission on airline safety and security gives scant hope that it will provide the kind of muscle needed to protect passengers from terrorists. The President, after meeting on July 25 with the families of those who lost their lives on Trans World Airlines Flight 800, was quick to announce that Vice President Gore would head a new commission to look at security threats and the broader issue of aviation safety. In an effort to reassure travelers that prompt steps would be taken to protect them, Mr. Clinton gave the panel an extremely short deadline of 45 days to make an initial report on airline and airport security, including a plan to deploy new machines to detect explosives.

title: Tobacco Shares Lead Drop As Dow Falls 31.44 Points
description: Stocks were generally lower yesterday for the first time in nearly a week, hurt by rising interest rates and a slump in tobacco shares.

title: CHRONICLE
description: If anyone said the traditional ''Break a leg'' at the beginning of the first dress rehearsal at the Globe theater in London on Tuesday night, it brought no luck to the actor GEORGE INNES. Mr. Innes landed badly and broke his left leg as he climbed down a rope ladder onto the stage at the Globe, a replica of the 16th-century theater where Shakespeare's plays were first performed. The original burned in 1613.

title: I.R.S., Now Meet the Reasonable Man
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Minors, a Major Step Is Taken by Cone
description: David Cone's thoughts were on much more than balls and strikes tonight in this picturesque little ball park in the heart of eastern Connecticut.

title: News Corporation Reports a Decline of 25% in Net Profit for Year
description: The News Corporation, the global media company, said today that its net profit fell 25.3 percent, to $807 million (United States) in the fiscal year that ended on June 30, mainly because of higher newsprint costs and a loss on the sale of its educational books division.

title: Japan's New Latin Look
description: Japanese leaders do not often visit Latin America, a region historically more attuned to the United States. But Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto is now on a 10-day trip to Mexico, Peru, Chile, Brazil and Costa Rica.

title: For States, Complications Only Begin When Welfare Bill Is Signed
description: The welfare bill that President Clinton is expected to sign on Thursday creates such complicated questions for the states that officials here have yet to determine how much Federal aid New York will lose, even after spending five weeks studying the legislation.

title: Reginald Cabral, 72, Who Tended Provincetown's Past, Dies
description: Reginald Cabral, a Cape Cod impresario who made his Atlantic House inn into such a magnet for artists, writers and other offbeat revelers that he founded an art and literary collection simply by presenting his bar chits for payment, died on Tuesday at his home in Provincetown, Mass. He was 72.

title: Board Votes to Endorse New All-Girls School
description: The Board of Education has voted to endorse the all-girls middle school that is about to open in an East Harlem community school district and to expand it soon into an all-girls' high school that the board and district will operate jointly. The statements by the board, and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, were the strongest yet in support of the school, which has drawn criticism from civil rights advocates who contend that the all-girls school violates Federal and city anti-discrimination laws by excluding boys.

title: It's a Loyal Ally but May Dig Up Trouble
description: Now that Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan has demanded that Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern keep his popular golden retriever Boomer, at home, she has triggered far more than egregious puns about fur flying in the dog days of August. Ms. Messinger's attack is, in fact, the latest reminder of a tradition as rich and deep as it is unexplored: political dogs that get their owners in the doghouse.

title: Clinton Set to Approve Curbs On Cigarette Sales to Youths
description: In a move that would showcase one of his familiar family issues, President Clinton is expected to announce as early as Friday the final approval of Federal regulations cracking down on the marketing and sale of cigarettes to young people, White House officials said today.

title: Mentally Ill, Too Get Hooked on Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title: Common Drug for Prostrate Is Ineffective, Study Finds
description: The first direct comparison of two main drugs approved for treating an enlarged prostate gland, a common condition in older men, has shown that one is no better than a dummy pill or placebo. But the other relieves the urinary symptoms caused as the swollen gland constricts the urethra.

title: Nurse Layoffs Lower Quality of Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Linwood Tice, 87, Pioneer in a Plasma Substitute
description: Linwood Franklin Tice, a pharmaceutical chemist who pioneered the development of special gelatins as a blood plasma substitute in World War II, died on Sunday at his home in Salem, N.J. He was 87.

title: Oil Companies Buying an Army To Ward Off Rebels in Colombia
description: Emboldened by the political disarray in Colombia, guerrilla factions have been increasing their attacks against oil exploration and production sites, leading foreign oil companies operating here to begin directly paying the Colombian military to deploy its best-trained officers and soldiers for protection.

title: Cost-Cutting Pays Off as Kmart Reports a Profit
description: After 13 disappointing quarters, the Kmart Corporation has taken some baby steps toward profitability.

title: Accounts
description: Keds Corp., Lexington, Mass., a unit of the Stride Rite Corp., to Foote, Cone & Belding, San Francisco, a unit of True North Communications, for a line of children's footwear to be introduced early next year. Billings have not been determined.

title: Israeli Settlements Policy Breaks No Agreement
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Corning Narrows Review
description: The Dow Corning subsidiary of the Dow Chemical Company has narrowed a review on a new worldwide corporate image account. Billings have not been determined.

title: Clinton Writes Yeltsin on Grozny
description: In a letter that arrived in Moscow this morning, President Clinton appealed to President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia not to allow a major military attack on the Chechen capital and to pursue a negotiated settlement, senior White House officials said today.

title: Economists' anti-regulatory rationale is facing a change.
description: IT is hardly news that mainstream economists think regulation often does more harm than good. After all, liberals joined conservatives in efforts to deregulate the airline, trucking and rail industries. And economists have been the most constant allies of trade liberalization. What may come as a surprise, though, is how their rationale is changing.

title: U.S. Bound: Lloyd Webber Show
description: Sir Andrew Lloyd Webber's new musical ''Whistle Down the Wind'' will open at the Martin Beck Theater on April 17, 1997, after making its world premiere in Washington this December. The announcement came yesterday after weeks of behind-the-scenes maneuvering among theater owners. The Martin Beck is a Jujamcyn house.

title: State Works on Tobacco Suit
description: New Jersey will wait until next month to join the list of states suing several large tobacco companies to recoup Medicaid costs related to smoking, a lawyer preparing the suit said yesterday. Michigan filed suit yesterday, becoming the 13th state to do so. Michael L. Testa, one of the lawyers hired in July for this case, did not say how much money New Jersey would seek. In New Jersey, the annual health care costs of smoking amount to about $2 billion, said John Shaffer, a spokesman for the Medical Society of New Jersey.

title: Kobrand Puts Account in Review
description: The Kobrand Corporation in New York, an importer and marketer of alcoholic beverages, has placed its account in review. With billings estimated at $2 million, the account had been handled for seven years by Angotti, Thomas, Hedge in New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, until that agency and Kobrand parted ways last month.

title: Before He Starts, Johnson Must Learn
description: The quarterbacks tell him to go this way and that. The other receivers point to where he's supposed to line up. All of that noise sometimes confuses Keyshawn Johnson, he confessed today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a new drug indictment of Peter Gatien, the Manhattan nightclub owner, misstated the relationship between Mr. Gatien and some of the 18 other people indicted. Only some, not all 18, were employees of Mr. Gatien's clubs.

title: Two More Bodies Recovered From Flight 800 Crash Site
description: On a day when little progress was made in determining why Trans World Airlines Flight 800 exploded off the coast of Long Island last month, investigators did report an encouraging development: The remains of two more victims were recovered from the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean.

title: $100 Million Fund Will Finance Java-Based Ventures
description: A leading venture capital firm has formed a $100 million fund to invest in companies that will create software and related products based on the Java programming language developed by Sun Microsystems Inc.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Falls 31.44 Points, As Tobacco Shares Skid

title: Kremlin Jousts With the Army Over Chechnya
description: The dangerous chasm between Russia's civilian and military leaders persisted today as President Boris N.
