Yeltsin's national security adviser and his Defense Minister rebuked their commanders in Chechnya for issuing ultimatums to the rebels in Chechnya that, as the Defense Minister put it, ''they had absolutely no right to give.''

title: In Classroom or Home, Notebook Computers Come of Age
description: ALONG with Rollerblades and maybe nose rings, students are packing notebook computers as essential accessories for the coming term. These days, class notes are much more likely to be taken electronically than in anything spiral-bound.

title: Christian Split: Can Nonbelievers Be Saved?
description: After 25 years in the pulpit, at the head of a congregation of nearly 1,000 people, the Rev. Richard A. Rhem would seem fitted more for a role as a denominational leader than as a denominational lightning rod.

title: Dole's Capital-Gains Tax Plan Aims to Woo the Middle Class
description: As the self-proclaimed candidate of a financially squeezed middle class, Bob Dole is proposing a drastic cut in a tax that he says hits hard at the very core of the American work force -- the small, growing businesses that create most of the nation's new jobs.

title: Will Players Still Believe In Reeves?
description: AFTER the fallout on Tuesday, Dan Reeves had a little talk with his team.

title: Volvo's First-Half Profits Topped Expectations
description: The Swedish auto maker Volvo reported yesterday that it had a pretax profit in the first half of 3.86 billion crowns ($585.3 million), which was slightly higher than expected, and said its restructuring was continuing. Volvo said positive net interest income and share sales improved profit in the first six months of 1996 by 453 million crowns ($68.7 million).

title: Renovation Of Museum Opens Door For Director
description: There are places in the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, in the elaborate and gloomy Carnegie mansion at Fifth Avenue and 91st Street, that Dianne Pilgrim, the director, can go only if carried. Just to enter the mansion, Ms. Pilgrim has to wheel herself through a back entrance.

title: Income at CS Holding Rose 20% in First Half
description: CS Holding A.G. announced yesterday that its first-half profit rose 20 percent, helped by a 56 percent gain in its CS First Boston brokerage unit. But the gain was held back by a 60 percent increase in money set aside to cover doubtful loans. Credit Suisse, the company's main banking unit, posted a 17 percent profit gain.

title: In Bosnia's Voter Registration, Portents of Trouble
description: Razija Hergic and her mother are Muslim refugees who moved into a comfortable house here that was abandoned late last year by a Serb family. The stove and refrigerator work, there is a decent yard and two cats who had no trouble switching their allegiances. It is a much nicer house, she said, than her old one, which she was driven from in 1992 when Bosnian Serbs began their ''ethnic cleansing'' of the city of Prijedor, just north of here, of all Muslims.

title: Horse-Trading by a Hospital Union Is Sidestepping the Brunt of Downsizing
description: Last January, Caren Brown, an effervescent woman, got the bad news that many people are hearing in this age of downsizing: she was being laid off from her job transporting patients at Long Island Jewish Hospital's psychiatric wing in Queens.

title: The Pop Life
description: Ike Turner's Return

title: Financial Misconduct Gets Its Just Deserts
description: To the Editor:

title: Fine Shape Sake Is In
description: LIKE wine from fine crystal, sake from Makoto Komatsu's subtly asymmetrical porcelain bottle and cup will become all the more delectable. Mr. Komatsu, a ceramicist in Japan, glazes the inside but polishes the exterior to the texture of an eggshell. The bottle is $100, the cup $50 (dishwasher- and microwave-safe) at Wolfman Gold and Good Company, 117 Mercer Street (Prince Street), and the Museum of Modern Art design store, 44 West 53d Street. Colors include white, gray-green, cream and lavender.

title: Atlanta Mayor Says a 911 Delay Did Not Worsen Bomb Toll
description: While acknowledging that Atlanta's 911 emergency response system did not work well on the night of the bombing at Centennial Olympic Park, Atlanta's Mayor, Bill Campbell, maintained today that the Police Department's failure to relay word of a 911 bomb threat did not contribute to the damage caused by the explosion.

title: A Jumbotron Successor, as Big as the Law Allows
description: As if the Times Square Jumbotron were not jumbo enough, executives of NBC and Panasonic said yesterday that they plan to replace the oversize screen with something bigger and brighter.

title: JENNY CRAIG SAYS WEIGHT-LOSS DRUGS HURT BUSINESS
description: The shares of Jenny Craig Inc. fell 33 percent yesterday after the company said publicity about new weight-loss drugs had hurt its business. Shares of the company, which operates or franchises 777 weight-loss centers, fell $5.625, to $11.50, in New York Stock Exchange trading of almost 1.8 million shares. Although new prescription weight-loss drugs like Redux, made by Interneuron Pharmaceuticals Inc., had hurt business, Jenny Craig said it intended to incorporate the drugs into its diet programs. Leads for prospective clients fell about 31 percent in July and early August, Jenny Craig said, and the number of active customers fell 12 percent from last year.

title: Amid Memories and Profit, Mantle's Legend Lives On
description: In the year and nine days since Mickey Mantle's death, the commerce surrounding his name has barely diminished. Mantle remains a formidable icon with a long future through a spate of new books, a reissue of all his baseball cards, strong sales of his widely dispersed memorabilia, an organ donation awareness program sustained by the former Yankee's family, and the Manhattan restaurant in his name.

title: Against Saudis, Dominicans Play by the No-Mercy Rule
description: After being bullied by Taiwan pitcher Yang Chia-chen and his 77-mile-an-hour fastball on Tuesday, the team from the Dominican Republic did what embarrassed 12-year-old boys often do: they took their frustration out on somebody else. Unfortunately for the players from Saudi Arabia, they were the smaller and weaker team standing in the Dominicans' way today at the Little League World Series.

title: School Enrollments Rise
description: New Jersey has one of the fastest-growing public school student populations in the country, the United States Department of Education reported yesterday. The state's enrollment is expected to rise by 109,000 during the next decade, more than in all but six other states, according to the department's projections. Much of this growth can be attributed to immigration, said John Henderson, associate director of the New Jersey School Boards Association. The Washington-based Center for Immigration Studies recently identified five northern New Jersey counties as among the 50 nationwide most affected by immigration. TERRY PRISTIN

title: MetroStars Give Officials Some Credit for D.C. Victory
description: The MetroStars are developing quite a rivalry with D.C. United, the team they will have to scrap with for second place in the Eastern Conference. United got the upper hand tonight with a 3-2 victory at Giants Stadium in what the losing coach said was one of the most poorly officiated games in Major League Soccer's inaugural season.

title: Accord Closer on Security In the Public Schools
description: With the opening of school only two weeks away, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani raised the possibility yesterday of a compromise in his long-running battle with the Board of Education over control of security in the public schools.

title: Clinton Book Repeats His Speeches
description: Theoretically, President Clinton's new book is 178 pages of earnest discussion of the problems and opportunities facing late 20th-century America, and his view of how best to confront them. In fact, it is a patchwork quilt of three dozen political speeches from the last 15 months stitched together with chapter headings.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Official Says Man Told Mob To 'Get a Jew'
description: Shouting ''Let's go get a Jew'' and ''I'm going to get a Jew; who's with me?'' Charles Price whipped a group of blacks in Crown Heights into a murderous frenzy five years ago, a prosecutor charged yesterday, also suggesting for the first time in court that Mr. Price directed the mob to kill a Hasidic scholar.

title: Australian Sentenced in Fraud Case
description: The failed Australian businessman ALAN BOND was sentenced to three years in jail Tuesday for fraud involving the multimillion-dollar sale of a French Impressionist painting.

title: Some Features of Wage Bill Help Ease Pain for Business
description: While business lost its top-priority battle against the higher minimum wage with President Clinton's signature on Tuesday, Republican allies managed to get various pro-business financial benefits added to the wage bill, as well as several tax breaks for consumers.

title: But Questions Persist On Risks of Reinsurance
description: Lloyd's of London, the grande dame of the insurance business, is on the brink of getting a new lease on life.

title: Traffic Island Gardens for the East Village
description: TWO gardens will be sprouting on East Ninth Street. Next spring, the odd intersection where Third Avenue meets Ninth Street and Stuyvesant Street goes its own way will be abloom with two triangular gardens. They will be lush with cherry, dogwood and magnolia trees, ginger, plumbago and hyacinths. What are now wedges of asphalt will become places of sweet smells and reverie. But the reveries will have to be at arm's length -- the gardens are for viewing and sniffing and will be bordered with cast-iron fences. Lampposts of the kind seen in Manhattan more than 100 years ago will light them.

title: Fernandez Plays Hero Once Again
description: Inspired by the pitching star of the Olympics, Lisa Fernandez, the California Commotion won its first national women's fastpitch softball championship tonight.

title: Ted's Excellent Idea
description: When Ted Turner forked over $200 million to charity two years ago, he felt a tremor.

title: Ciba-Geigy to Close Plant
description: A troubled Ciba-Geigy dye plant that once was Ocean County's largest private employer will close by the end of the year, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Ciba-Geigy said it would lay off 170 workers, while retaining 30 people to monitor cleanup efforts at its landfill. In 1992, the Swiss-based pharmaceutical giant paid a $3.5 million fine as part of a plea agreement related to illegal dumping.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Parties Try to Exploit Teen-Age Drug Rise
description: The two parties continued to spar yesterday over a new report showing a sharp jump in drug use among teen-agers.

title: Errant Wheels Kill Driver
description: A woman who had been driving east on Interstate 80 was killed yesterday morning when two wheels separated from a westbound tractor-trailer, bounced over the concrete divider and crashed through her windshield, the police said. Michele Presbruhi, 28, of Clifton, died instantly of head injuries, said Trooper Al Della Fave, a state police spokesman.

title: Residents Wanted for Island. It's Not for Everybody
description: The rent on Linda Russano's one-bedroom apartment in New York City was about to go up to $1,600 a month. So last March she left the island of Manhattan (population about 1.5 million) and became a pioneer of sorts on Frenchboro Island, where last winter the population never topped 18.

title: Short Interest in Sunbeam Surges, Big Board Reports
description: Wall Street loved it when Albert J. Dunlap, who gained fame for dismissing employees at Scott Paper, was hired by Sunbeam as the new chief executive of the small appliance maker. The stock rose to $18.625 from $12.50 the day he was hired last month, and has kept on moving since then, closing yesterday at $21.50.

title: Child Rapist Stuns Belgium: What Punishment?
description: It is a horror story told many times in many places. A convicted child kidnapper and rapist serves time in prison. He is let off early for good behavior. The pedophile, unable or unwilling to control his demons, strikes again.

title: With Judge's Gentle Help, Terror Suspect Starts Case
description: The man accused of masterminding the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center stood before a Federal jury yesterday and defended himself against charges of plotting to blow up American jetliners in Asia.

title: Auto Dealers Fail to Hear From Irvin
description: MICHAEL IRVIN apparently reneged on a deal to return a $50,000 sport utility vehicle to car dealers who are suing the Dallas Cowboys receiver, the dealers' lawyer said.

title: Electronic Library Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: In Some States, Planning Ahead Paid Off
description: Faced with new Federal welfare legislation that has many other states scrambling, Connecticut's response was somewhat unusual: ''What took so long?'' Gov. John G. Rowland asked last month when the bill passed the House.

title: Another Cuban Player Defects
description: Another Cuban baseball player abandoned the country's national team yesterday, defecting for a chance to play in the majors. A spokesman for the Miami sports agent JOE CUBAS said second baseman JESUS RAMON VALDIVIA and other players contacted the agent from Guatemala, saying they wanted to defect.

title: A Warm and Cuddly Census
description: AMERICANS don't like providing census data -- especially if they have to wrestle with the forms themselves. So in 1991, the Census Bureau decided to design a more user-friendly form for the 2000 Census. The agency has tried to make the questions clearer and easier to answer. Where the old form had little circles to fill in (shades of the S.A.T.'s), the new one, designed by 212 Associates in Manhattan, can be answered by putting an X in each box or by printing in large-size boxes. It even has little drawings and text to tell Americans what they get for supplying census information: housing, schools and roads.

title: Central Board Backs All-Girls School
description: The Board of Education voted last night to endorse the all-girls junior high school that is to open in an East Harlem community school district and to expand it into an all-girls' high school that the board and district will operate jointly.

title: 'Primary Colors': Second Thoughts
description: Why did Tom Hanks abruptly turn down the role of the candidate in the film version of ''Primary Colors''? For months, the Academy Award-winning actor had just about committed himself to making what is expected to be a high-profile and expensive film from the best-selling novel. The book was based on the 1992 Clinton Presidential campaign and rang true enough, at least in spots, that insiders assumed that only another insider could have written it.

title: Seles Is Hoping U.S. Open Will Redeem Her Season
description: With shoulder surgery looming in the near future and two nondescript Grand Slam results -- not to mention a quarterfinal Olympic stumble -- in her rearview mirror, Monica Seles can't help hoping the United States Open provides an immediate distraction of two weeks' duration.

title: Events: Folk-Art Study And a Privy's Secrets
description: Fall Crafts Classes

title: Chase Forms Venture Fund With Softbank
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Softbank Corporation of Japan have agreed to invest $25 million each in a new venture-capital fund focused on Internet companies that are based in New York, an executive close to the deal said yesterday.

title: Revenge of the Bad Girls And Other Fantasies
description: When the camera first notices Legs Sadovsky (Angelina Jolie), the catalytic central character of ''Foxfire,'' it mythologizes her with the kind of worshipful shot traditionally reserved for the grand entrances of macho gunfighters. Focusing on her black motorcycle boots, it travels slowly up her body, appreciating her black leather jacket, then settling on a face that is beautiful enough to stop traffic.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about political advertising misstated the amount that the Dole campaign expects to spend on commercials through the Presidential election. It is $25 million, not $2 million.

title: Restaurants
description: Cool and lovely, filled with flowers and the perfume of wealthy women, La Serre does not look like the greenhouse of its name but like a French farmhouse redone by an expensive interior decorator eager for a spread in Metropolitan Home.

title: Trade groups square off against tobacco restrictions, but not all agencies agree.
description: MADISON AVENUE is officially a fierce and aggressive opponent of the regulations to restrict selling and marketing tobacco products that President Clinton is expected to announce today. Yet many agency executives support the curbs, particularly if they are aimed primarily at minors -- and some seek even more severe sanctions.

title: Philadelphia Signs Cage
description: The Philadelphia 76ers signed MICHAEL CAGE to a free-agent contract yesterday in an attempt to fill a gaping hole in the middle of their lineup. The 6-9 Cage averaged 8.9 rebounds last season with the Cleveland Cavaliers. But the 34-year-old veteran has not averaged more than 6.1 points a game since 1993. (AP)

title: A Hum Anchors the Action
description: There is a deep, consonant hum at the core of Dave Holland's music. His bass lines, played with a commandeering power, are pitched down low on the instrument, and lean more toward pure resonance than melodic invention. But the hum is also figurative -- it's in the balance of his musicians, who play at the top of their power but obey group dynamics, each one containing himself so as to indicate limits without actually reaching them. The end result is the sort of serenity that seems to be the point of so much post-Coltrane jazz, yet isn't achieved all that often.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10

title: INSIDE
description: New Draw for U.S. Open

title: Messiah Turning Up in the Oddest Spots
description: Deb Margolin's restraint, and her expressed doubt that she may have anything new to say about being Jewish, make her writing and her performance fresh and amusing in ''O Wholly Night and Other Jewish Solecisms.'' The one-woman show, commissioned last spring by the Jewish Museum in Manhattan for its ''Too Jewish?'' exhibition, has moved to the Interart Theater under the direction of Margot Lewitin.

title: Songs of Divine Love Convey Earthly Exuberance
description: Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan's concerts are religious celebrations and dance parties, virtuoso showcases and master classes. At Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday night, Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan and Party, his 10-man group, sang about Allah, divine love and Sufi saints to a crowd that danced in the aisles despite the ushers' best efforts.

title: Unconventional Wisdom
description: The cozy and mutually beneficial relationship between television journalism and political conventions inevitably and thankfully has turned sour.

title: At New Jersey Rally, Skeptical Talk of Dole's Tax Plan
description: Asking the mostly Republican, mostly middle-class people at a rally for Bob Dole here about their appetite for lower taxes was like asking the patrons in a Haagen-Dazs shop for their opinion of ice cream.

title: Rights Groups Seek to Bar Girls-Only School
description: The battle over the new all-girls public school in East Harlem shifted yesterday from the New York City Board of Education to the United States Department of Education, as three civil rights groups filed a joint complaint charging the school with discriminating against boys.

title: Dole Promises To Strengthen Medicare And Benefits
description: Accusing President Clinton of using fear to stir opposition to his tax cut plan, Bob Dole today came to the state where Gov. Christine Todd Whitman rode tax cuts to victory three years ago to assert that he, too, could reduce taxes without hurting popular programs.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BOB BARKER, celebrating 25 years as the host of the CBS show ''The Price Is Right,'' says spontaneity has been the key to his longevity and that of the show, which chooses contestants from the audience.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The divorce between the restaurateur PINO LUONGO and Barneys New York took a nasty turn yesterday for employees of Mad.61, the restaurant that Mr. Luongo manages in the Barneys store on Madison Avenue at 61st Street.

title: States Express Anxiety
description: Although the states will be getting block grants and sweeping authority to assist poor people, many state officials across the country say they are far from being ready for the task.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Mary Reilly

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Japanese stocks traded lower here early today. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 155.64 points at 21,207.60. On Thursday, the Nikkei gained 88.22 points.

title: Metro Digest
description: THE CRASH

title: Labor Talks Move Beyond A Debate on Service Time
description: The baseball players union, as expected, formally rejected the owners' proposal on service time yesterday, clearing the way for the two sides to complete their negotiations on a new collective bargaining agreement.

title: With Welfare Overhaul Now Law, States Grapple With the Consequences
description: Even as President Clinton signed the welfare bill, the biggest shift in social policy since the Depression, many state officials across the country say they are nowhere near ready to assume the greater control the measure grants them of the nation's vast welfare system.

title: Man Admits Repair Fraud
description: Nader Emusov energetically sought customers for his home improvement business, often stopping at homes uninvited and recommending repairs, the authorities said. Yesterday, Mr. Emusov, of Haledon, pleaded guilty to fraud and admitted that he took in more than $150,000 from 58 homeowners in Passaic and Morris counties by either failing to complete the work or never doing it, said Cissy Rebich, an assistant Morris County prosecutor.

title: Clinton and the Daleys: Friends Again
description: There is no better index of the shifting political fortunes of Bill Clinton than his up-and-down relationship with the Daleys of Chicago, his hosts for the Democratic National Convention next week.

title: The Control Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Devils Trade Richer Back to Canadiens
description: Stephane Richer got his wish yesterday, and now the question is whether Lou Lamoriello still has a move or two remaining under his sleeve.

title: Pacino's Star Turn in a Pipe Dream
description: AS much as is possible for an actor appearing before a paying audience, Al Pacino likes to protect his privacy in the workplace. He doesn't appreciate kibitzers. He also has the box office clout to sell tickets no matter what the professional opinionmongers say. Thus it wasn't until Wednesday night that he invited critics to see his production of Eugene O'Neill's ''Hughie'' at the Circle in the Square, where the two-character, one-act play has been in previews since July 25, following an engagement at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven.

title: The Jets Still Have So Much to Do, and So Little Time
description: The Jets expect their first-team offense to score a touchdown somewhere west of the Mississippi. If it doesn't happen Friday against the Raiders, in the final preseason game, then there is still the season opener at Denver on Sept. 1.

title: NBC Apologizes to China
description: NBC has apologized to Chinese groups for BOB COSTAS's mention of China's human rights record -- and other sources of United States-China tensions -- during the opening ceremony of the Olympics. China's state-run news media and Foreign Ministry officials had criticized the sportscaster for the remarks, made during the July 19 broadcast. ''We wanted to make it clear that we didn't intend to hurt their feelings,'' ED MARKEY, an NBC Sports vice president, said yesterday.

title: New Building May Be Last of Its Kind
description: The latest response to Manhattan's hearty rental market is the Strathmore, a slender 43-story apartment tower now nearing completion at 400 East 84th Street and First Avenue.

title: Drug Use by Teen-Agers
description: Drug use among teen-agers, once on the wane, is again rising sharply. A Federal report issued this week found that the percentage of adolescents currently using drugs more than doubled in four years, from a low of 5.3 percent in 1992 to 10.9 percent in 1995. That is still well below the high levels of the 1970's, when usage rates topped 16 percent, but the trend line is worrisome. More vigorous efforts by Federal, state and local governments are clearly needed to turn the rates back down.

title: 7 Agencies Compete For Mall Account
description: The Wells Park Group, a shopping-mall management company in Newton, Mass., has invited seven agencies to compete for its account, which had been handled by Houston Herstek Favat in Boston. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $7 million.

title: Woods Halfway Home To Third Amateur Title
description: Tiger Woods is halfway there, on what seems to be an inexorable march toward history. After brief early scares in both of his matches in the United States Amateur today at the Witch Hollow Course at Pumpkin Ridge Golf Club, Woods, 20, turned things around and prevailed once again.

title: Leonard A. Gentine, Cheese Maker, 81
description: Leonard A. Gentine, who turned a mail-order cheese business behind his funeral home into the Sargento Cheese Company, one of the country's largest cheese makers, died on Monday at the Valley View Medical Center in his hometown, Plymouth, Wis. He was 81.

title: Lost, but Still Cutting Loose
description: ''This is so weird,'' Jimmie Dale Gilmore said with an awkward gulp, as he looked into the stage lights of the Westbeth Theater Center three songs into his concert on Wednesday night. He started to explain himself, but then turned shy and promptly began playing a song by his former band, the Flatlanders. It was unclear whether he was bewildered by the theater, the tremendous applause of the audience after a shaky beginning, or the fact that after 25 years of playing more minimal, sensitive country and folk, he was now fronting a roots-rock band.

title: The Dumbing Down of American Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Forget Haiti
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about a deal between Patriot American Hospitality Inc. and the Doubletree Corporation misstated its terms. Patriot will spend as much as $200 million to buy hotels in the next two years, and Doubletree will manage them and take a 10 percent stake in each. Doubletree is not selling hotels to Patriot.

title: Finding a Lover in an Unlikely Place
description: Never underestimate the capacity of opposites to attract. That hopeful message reveals itself only gradually in Chris Newby's exquisitely photographed film ''Madagascar Skin,'' lifting what begins as a depressive reverie into a surreal comic ode to unlikely erotic fulfillment.

title: Living Room For Jazz, Uptown Again
description: THE jazz musicians who perform at Marjorie Eliot's concert hall are all household names. Every one of them. That's because the gigs are in her living room.

title: Behind a Calm Facade, Chaos, Distrust, Valor
description: From the outset, the daily news conferences giving updates on the recovery and investigation of the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 were unfailingly confident and practiced. There was a sense of control in the measured answers, the technical knowledge of the safety experts, even in the top F.B.I. man's tough talk about ''collaring the cowards who did this.'' Always, caution was urged.

title: Probation in Shooting
description: A police officer who pleaded guilty to shooting at a prostitute was sentenced yesterday to five years' probation. The officer, George Clark, 30, had tried to withdraw his plea, but a judge denied the motion.

title: Perot Asserts 2 Opponents Are Beholden To Others
description: Taking his third-party Presidential campaign to a national veterans convention, Ross Perot said today that both the Democratic and Republican Presidential tickets were so captive to special interests that they could not look after the national interest.

title: Milbury Gets Tough With Two Stars
description: With training camp just two weeks away, Mike Milbury, the Islanders' general manager and coach, announced a new strategy in his unsuccessful contract negotiations with his top two scorers from last season, Zigmund Palffy and Travis Green.

title: Life Through the Peephole of a South African Cell
description: In contemporary South Africa, an unnamed black man (Louis Gossett Jr.) is searching for the truth about the torture of a political prisoner nearly a decade earlier. Though his official role is not identified, the man presumably stands for the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which since spring has been investigating atrocities committed under apartheid.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Things to Do in Denver

title: U.A.W. Delays Picking Target Of Negotiations On Contract
description: The United Automobile Workers union abruptly postponed plans today to select a Big Three auto maker as the first to face the latest round of labor negotiations, while the union's president demanded meetings with the chief executives of the companies.

title: Touching on the Breadth Of Hispanic Art Today
description: Like most exhibitions built around roomy, broad-spectrum themes, ''Ceremony of Spirit: Nature and Memory in Contemporary Latino Art'' at the Studio Museum in Harlem cannot count sharp conceptual focus among its virtues. What it offers instead is a gathering of strong individual artists whose work is helping to define the complex range of contemporary Hispanic art flourishing in the United States today.

title: Dead Fish Hit Beaches
description: Beachgoers were warned to stay out of the water yesterday after a commercial fishing vessel's net broke, causing thousands of fish to wash up on Long Beach Island. Beaches in Ship Bottom, Surf City, Brant Beach, Beach Haven and Beach Haven Crest were affected, The Associated Press reported.

title: MARINE MIDLAND TO BUY S.& L. IN ROCHESTER
description: Marine Midland Bank agreed yesterday to buy the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Rochester from CT Financial Services Inc. of Toronto for $620 million. The acquisition would add $7.2 billion (United States) in assets to Marine Midland, which has $22.7 billion in assets and is a unit of HSBC Holdings P.L.C. of London. CT Financial is 98 percent owned by Imasco Ltd. of Montreal. B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. of London, which owns 41.5 percent of Imasco, said CT Financial would realize a pretax gain of $232 million from the sale. B.A.T. would receive a pretax profit of $77.5 million.

title: MATTEL SELECTS ITS NEXT CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Mattel Inc. said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Jill E. Barad, would succeed John W. Amerman as chief executive, effective Jan. 1. The move had been expected and settled the succession question at the toy maker, which is based in El Segundo, Calif. In her 15-year tenure, Ms. Barad has risen from product manager to become Mr. Amerman's top lieutenant, and has overseen United States and international sales of the company's trademark Barbie dolls. Mr. Amerman, who will be 65 next year, remains chairman.

title: Kevorkian Held Briefly After 2d Suicide in Day
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian left the bodies of two people at a hospital here today after helping them commit suicide, his lawyer said. They were the 37th and 38th people he has so assisted.

title: Man Vowed All Week to Kill Companion, Neighbors Say
description: The man being sought by the police in the stabbing death of his estranged companion in a Queens subway station on Wednesday had been telling neighbors for a week that he was going to kill the woman he had lived with for more than 20 years.

title: Bird Lives
description: Charlie Parker Jazz Festival, Tompkins Square Park, Seventh Street and Avenue A, East Village, (212) 449-9609. Now in its fourth year, this outdoor festival has become one of New York's must-attend jazz events. Sunday's well-programmed tribute features some musicians who played with Charlie Parker and is otherwise studded with interpretations of his music. The pianist Randy Weston and his quintet open the long afternoon at 3. The alto saxophonist and clarinetist Marty Ehrlich, who balances neatly between the forward-looking and the traditional, leads a trio at 3:55. The Joe Lovano Quartet, led by one of the moment's most important tenor saxophonists, follows at 4:25. Max Roach will deliver one of his highly evolved solo drum performances at 5:20, and the tenor saxophonist and be-bop era legend Jimmy Heath leads a big band through a closing set at 6. Admission is free. BEN RATLIFF

title: The Incarceration-Minded Meet to Buy Mobile Cells, Ballistic Batons and More
description: For the warden who has run out of room, there are temporary cells at $40,000 apiece. For hard-to-handle inmates, there is the latest in restraining chairs, ballistic batons and plastic handcuffs. And for those who prefer to delegate, there are companies that do it all, from designing cellblocks to determining staffing, from setting up a dispensary to beefing up security.

title: Readily Available, PETN Is Easily Molded and Hidden
description: PETN, the explosive found by investigators on wreckage from Trans World Airlines Flight 800, is an extremely powerful and commonly available explosive that is a favorite of commercial blasters and weapons designers, as well as terrorists.

title: Citing Fraud, Judges Bar 2 Lawmakers From Ballot
description: Citing rampant fraud in the collection of their ballot petition signatures, a New York State appeals court ruled yesterday that two Bronx politicians -- Assemblyman Pedro G. Espada and his father, State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. -- would not be on the ballot in next month's Democratic primary.

title: $25 and Under
description: August is a blue time at Maridaki, a little Greek seafood restaurant that opened in June on the northern edge of Astoria, Queens. Sadly, it is no longer maridaki season.

title: Teen Smokers, Read This
description: Anyone who doubts the potency of nicotine's addictive qualities should listen to Dr. William G. Cahan, senior attending surgeon at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, as he talks about desperately ill patients whose cravings for a cigarette are not diminished by even the most macabre circumstances.

title: Black Broker Making Inroads in Insurance
description: Four years ago, Aaron Richardson, a San Francisco insurance broker, made a startling discovery: while public utilities, government agencies and big corporations were seeking to buy a sizable amount of insurance from minority-owned companies, no minority-owned companies were bidding for the business.

title: More Chips? Don't Get Up
description: Gamblers who exhaust their supply of chips will no longer have to get up from their chairs to buy more. Now, because of a regulation change approved Wednesday by the Casino Control Commission, they can make credit-card purchases right at the gambling tables or slot machines. The new policy is certain to raise industry revenues, said Marvin B. Roffman, a Philadelphia-based gambling industry analyst. Edward Looney, executive director of the New Jersey Council on Compulsive Gambling, predicted the change would be disastrous for gambling addicts and their families. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Local Votes In Brazil Are a Test For Leader
description: Local races scheduled across the country in October, which will involve more than half a million candidates, are being considered a litmus test for the one issue that has come to absorb President Fernando Henrique Cardoso more than any other: his own re-election in 1998.

title: C.I.A. Gives Little Hope of Being More Candid
description: To the Editor:

title: Espinoza 'Happiest Guy' on the Mets
description: Alvaro Espinoza was given only token attention when the Mets and the Cleveland Indians completed their four-player trade on July 29. Carlos Baerga was the name that rang throughout Flushing.

title: Art in Review
description: 'In Search of Identity'

title: Art in Review
description: AC2K

title: People
description: * Jeanne M. Cluess was named to the new post of sales development director at the Magazine Publishers of America, New York. She had been marketing and sales strategies director at the Hearst Magazines corporate marketing and sales division of the Hearst Corp., New York.

title: N.F.L. TRAINING CAMP REPORT
description: Storm Stops Bears-Chiefs

title: Judge Faults Housing Plan For Homeless in the Bronx
description: Seeking to relieve overcrowding at a Bronx center where homeless families enter the shelter system, New York City agreed yesterday to open about 180 housing units for the homeless in the next six weeks. But a judge said the city's efforts were not enough.

title: Students Continue to Improve, College Board Says
description: In what educators say is a sign that more rigorous courses of study in high school have started to pay off, the College Board announced yesterday that American students continued to improve their scores on the Scholastic Assessment Test, with their math scores the best in more than two decades.

title: Left and Right Turn Up Heat On Netanyahu About Hebron
description: The conflicting pressures on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to decide whether to honor an Israeli pledge to withdraw its troops from most of the West Bank town of Hebron were turned up a notch today when his predecessor, Shimon Peres, met with the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, and urged a withdrawal, while leaders of his conservative Likud Party met to resist.

title: The Dumbing Down of American Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ''Our schools are doing a much better job than they used to. Our dropout rates are down. Our graduation rates are up. The percent of kids taking advanced placement and S.A.T. exams is going up. And this is despite the fact that there are many more at-risk kids in the schools.''

title: PRIME EVIDENCE FOUND THAT DEVICE EXPLODED IN CABIN OF FLIGHT 800
description: After a prolonged, confounding search of the ocean floor, investigators have finally found scientific evidence that an explosive device was detonated inside the passenger cabin of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, senior Federal officials said yesterday.

title: ICN WINS A ROUND IN SHAREHOLDER LAWSUIT
description: ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc. won a legal round this week when a Federal jury rejected seven claims of securities fraud in a class-action shareholder lawsuit pending since 1987. The jury in Federal District Court in New York deadlocked on the remaining six claims. Daniel Berger, the lead counsel for the investors who brought the suit, said he planned to pursue those claims in a new trial. Shares of ICN, which is based in Costa Mesa, Calif., rose $1.50, to $22.375. The suit, filed in March 1987, involved public statements made in 1986 and early 1987 about one of ICN's drugs, Virazole, an antiviral compound used to treat infants.

title: That Bunch Is Back, and Life's a Bowl of Cabbages
description: Now that Brady is an adjective, we may as well quit resisting and enjoy the polyester pop tastes of the 1970's at their most satirically pure. How Brady is ''A Very Brady Sequel,'' the second sneaky, affectionate feature spun off the goody-two-shoes television show? Well, it's Brady with a vengeance. Colors are candy bright, music is zippy, exclamation points are everywhere (''Hey, great idea!''), and potato-sack racing is all the rage. It's enough to make the angrier 90's look as if they never happened, which is mostly what brings sunny, oblivious Brady-think back into style.

title: Stowaways Found on Ship
description: A cargo ship from Buenaventura, Colombia, was carrying at least six stowaways from Ecuador when it docked in Elizabeth yesterday, said William Bittner, acting deputy district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service's Newark office. Officials said they were investigating whether a seventh man on board the ship was a dockworker who had been held hostage by the stowaways. The man, who was not identified, was being treated for a broken leg.

title: Effort in U.N. To Salvage Test-Ban Pact
description: Australia, taking the lead in an international campaign to keep alive the hope of a nuclear test-ban treaty, asked today that a special session of the United Nations General Assembly be convened on Sept. 9 to act on the agreement.

title: Yanks Get Sojo To Back Jeter
description: The Yankees' search for a backup shortstop apparently ended yesterday when they claimed Luis Sojo off waivers from the Seattle Mariners. The 30-year-old Sojo is expected to join the Yankees today, when the rookie Andy Fox will probably be sent to Class AAA Columbus to open a roster spot.

title: Accounts
description: * Acquion Inc., Greenville, S.C., an affiliate of Fluor Inc., to Renegade Marketing Group, New York, a unit of Dentsu Inc., as the first agency to handle integrated marketing for the electronic commerce company. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $4 million.

title: Why a $120 Million Contract Makes Sense for Lakers
description: To be successful in professional basketball these days, you have to master the fundamentals: shooting, passing and marketing. Mostly marketing.

title: Reform Party Leaders See High Stakes in No. 2 Post
description: As Ross Perot seeks a running mate, Reform Party leaders around the country are wondering not only whom he will choose, but also whether the person will give the ticket the credibility that Mr. Perot's choice in 1992, Adm. James B. Stockdale, seemed to lack.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Jury Bribery Try Charged
description: A grand jury has accused the brother of a murder defendant of offering a juror $1,800 in March to vote for his brother's acquittal. The incident was disclosed by another juror minutes before the verdict was to have been read, prosecutors said. A mistrial was declared and the defendant, Sean Barge of Camden, pleaded guilty in May to aggravated manslaughter in the 1994 slaying of David Perry of Pennsauken. His brother, Quincey Barge, was indicted Tuesday on charges of bribery and corrupting a juror. The juror, Heather Ross, was charged with not reporting the bribery attempt. The authorities do not know if she took the money, Greg Reinert, a spokesman for the Camden County Prosecutor's office, said yesterday.

title: Judge Faults Plan For Housing Homeless
description: Seeking to relieve overcrowding at a Bronx center where homeless families enter the shelter system, New York City agreed yesterday to open about 180 housing units for the homeless in the next six weeks. But a judge said the city's efforts were not enough.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: All Dogs Go to Heaven 2

title: Deep Sea Yields a Clue to Life's Origin
description: Scientists have the dullest of creation myths: no Adam made from lifeless dust, no Aphrodite born of foamy seas, just some conjectural watery womb where life began as a chemical accident.

title: Taylor a No-Show for Speech
description: LAWRENCE TAYLOR, the former Giants star, did not show up for an anti-drug talk to high school students in Myrtle Beach, S.C., yesterday because of personal problems, his lawyer said. Taylor was to make the speech as part of a pretrial program to clear his record of a charge of trying to buy crack cocaine. He was arrested in an undercover drug operation on May 3.

title: Israeli Settlements
description: To the Editor:

title: For Children
description: Fashion Clinic

title: Ellsworth Raymond Dies at 84; Kremlin Watcher of Stalin Era
description: Ellsworth Lester Raymond, a Soviet-era Kremlinologist who served at the United States Embassy in Moscow during World War II and taught for 29 years at New York University, died on Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 84 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LOCKHEED MARTIN CORP., Bethesda, Md., said its Federal Systems unit had received a seven-year contract worth up to $368 million to maintain the satellite control system of the United States Air Force.

title: Scoring Low on S.A.T.
description: Figures released yesterday by the College Board showed that New Jersey ranked 34th in the nation in Scholastic Assessment Test math scores and 40th in verbal scores. But state education officials pointed out that the average math and verbal scores rose two points over the previous year. And the rankings were skewed by the relatively high proportion of New Jersey students -- 69 percent last year -- who take the test, compared with other states, said Peter Peretzman, an Education Department spokesman. New Jersey's mean scores remain below the national average of 505 on the verbal portion of the S.A.T. and 508 on the math portion, the College Board said. $(Related story on page A16.$)

title: Pazienza Lets Fly With a Few Jabs Before Entering Ring
description: The movie is called ''The Good Life.'' It is to be filmed in New Orleans in September. In the words of Sylvester Stallone's co-star, it is about ''a crazy bunch of Italian men and their upbringing.''

title: Art in Review
description: Bing Wright/Jenny Saville and Glen Luchford

title: Biggest Rally in 3 Weeks Lifts Dow 43.65
description: The stock market staged its biggest rally in three weeks as an unexpectedly large cut in German interest rates promised faster economic growth in Europe and a jump in orders for American exporters.

title: Keep Green: He Deserves To Finish Job
description: IT hurts.

title: Supply-Side Policy Wrecked U.S. Exports
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding Redemption Among Spuds
description: ''The Spitfire Grill'' arrives with a reputation that precedes it: as the slickest drama at this year's Sundance Film Festival, as a small film purchased by its distributor for a disproportionately large sum ($10 million, a Sundance record) and as an inspirational drama initially financed by an order of Roman Catholic priests. But this contrived, studiously quaint New England tale is less notable for any of that than for the glowing performance of Alison Elliott, its lovely young star.

title: Supply-Side Policy Wrecked U.S. Exports
description: To the Editor:

title: ARCHER DANIELS TO BUY STAKE IN MEXICAN COMPANY
description: The Archer Daniels Midland Company said yesterday that it would buy a 22 percent stake in the Mexican corn products company Gruma S.A. for $258 million. The purchase would allow Archer Daniels to expand into the swiftly growing tortilla market in the United States as well as the Mexican corn flour market. Both markets are now dominated by Gruma. Archer Daniels, based in Decatur, Ill., would receive 74.7 million new Gruma shares for its cash payment. Under the agreement, Gruma will manage the companies' combined United States corn flour operations and the Mexican wheat-milling business of Archer Daniels.

title: DURA PHARMACEUTICALS BUYS RIGHTS TO TWO LILLY DRUGS
description: Dura Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that it would pay $100 million to Eli Lilly & Company for exclusive rights to sell two oral antibiotics, Keftab and Ceclor CD, in the United States. Keftab is expected to have sales of about $15 million this year. Ceclor CD, approved by the Food and Drug Administration in June, is expected to be on the market this fall. Both drugs are used to treat respiratory infections. Shares of Dura Pharmaceuticals, which is based in San Diego, rose $5.75 yesterday, to $32.50, on the Nasdaq stock market. Shares of Eli Lilly, based in Indianapolis, rose 37.5 cents, to $59.75.

title: A Step Slow in the Spring, Skip Away Is Summer's Star
description: Hubert (Sonny) Hine, once an Army counterintelligence expert and shrewd in the ways of the backstretch, checked Skip Away at 4:30 this morning at his barn on the New Jersey Shore. Then he drove north to Saratoga in time to attend the draw for the Travers Stakes and to defend the proposition that his horse may not have won any of the Triple Crown races but was still the favorite for the summertime Derby.

title: Islamic Movement's Niche: Bringing Order to Somalia's Clans
description: Around north Mogadishu, Sheik Ali Sheik Mohammed has earned the reputation of a no-nonsense lawman who has cleaned up a lawless town. Most folks see here him in much the same way as Americans saw marshals in the Old West.

title: The Spoken Word
description: FICTION READING GROUP, Barnes & Noble, 33 East 17th Street, Union Square. A discussion of Tolstoy's ''Master and Man,'' ''Hadji Murat'' and other stories, led by Brendan Larson, a writer and staff member at the bookstore. 6 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 727-4810.

title: A Little Weirdness Can Help an Artist
description: ''IT'S hard for me to think of artists who weren't influential on me because I'm such an obsessive thief,'' says Wayne Thiebaud, striding through the lobby of the Metropolitan Museum of Art to the Greek and Roman rooms. ''One thing I'm cranky about is that people don't realize painting is all one tradition. I hate dividing it. It's like saying there's something called California mathematics. The conventions of painting have always been the same, and they're the same with abstract and realist painting. I can think of nothing that can't be expressed abstractly and also realistically -- grandness, fear, whatever.''

title: Germans Cut a Major Rate; Other Europeans Follow
description: Germany's central bank reduced a principal short-term interest rate more than expected yesterday, setting off rate cuts elsewhere in Europe and sending the dollar higher.

title: Top Executive at Dreyfus Has Resigned Posts
description: Howard Stein, who in 26 years as the chairman and chief executive of the Dreyfus Corporation oversaw the growth of one of the country's biggest mutual fund companies, resigned yesterday, effective Aug. 31.

title: Abortion Debate Isn't Fueled by Economics
description: To the Editor:

title: Brando Plays a Madman, More Apocalyptically
description: John Frankenheimer's nasty new screen version of ''The Island of Dr. Moreau'' brings fur-bearing special effects to H. G. Wells's century-old novel about a mad scientist melding humans and animals on a remote island. Talk about out-of-control experiments: the film combines the subversive high jinks of Val Kilmer, playing a jaded young scientist in full Lizard King mode, with those of Marlon Brando. Mr. Brando's performance will be deemed interestingly audacious only by those who found ''Apocalypse Now'' too sane.

title: Nynex Fined $4.1 Million For a Year of Poor Service
description: New York State's top utility regulators have ordered the Nynex Corporation to pay $4.1 million in rebates because of the telephone company's recent record of deteriorating customer service.

title: Bound by Tradition
description: Roots of American Music Weekend, Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5108. This may be one of the vaguest ideas for a festival this summer, but it's also free. Lincoln Center has put together a handful of acts that have very little to do with one another except that the music they will be playing today through Sunday is somewhat traditional. The only bill that has any unity is tonight's rockabilly lineup, with the riveting bass voice of Sleepy LaBeef, the whisper-to-a-yelp singing of Rosie Flores and the warbling Sun Records-style cool of Sonny Burgess. Otherwise, it's a pretty good grab bag, with the soul balladeer Percy Sledge singing about when a man loves a woman, the Canadian folk impressionist Ferron singing about when a woman loves a woman and the Irish belters the Clancy Brothers (just two brothers and a nephew nowadays) singing about when a man loves a drink, all on Sunday. Tomorrow, Taj Mahal, Doug Kershaw, Front Range and others perform. The concerts start at 8 tonight, and at 3:30 tomorrow and Sunday afternoons. NEIL STRAUSS

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Woman in Question

title: Just Beyond the Placid Images, Brutal Death Waits
description: One of the blurriest pictures in ''The Illegal Camera: Photography in the Netherlands During the German Occupation, 1940-1945,'' now on view at the Jewish Museum, is also one of the saddest and most baffling.

title: T.A. Can't Disguise Declining Bus Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Trouble in Fly Fishermen's Paradise
description: The deep and quiet stretch of the Missouri River that flows near this town is heaven on Earth to fly fishermen, one of the streams that give Montana as many fish per mile as anywhere in the world.

title: TOP YELTSIN AIDE AND CHECHEN FOES SIGN A PEACE PACT
description: In the most promising step yet toward the resolution of the 20-month war between Russia and the secessionist region of Chechnya, the Russian security chief signed a detailed peace agreement today with his Chechen counterpart.

title: Rhode Island and Taiwan Make the Final
description: One by one, the Cranston (R.I.) players filed out of the stands late Wednesday night. They had seen enough, and besides, these 11- and 12-year-olds needed to get to bed and calm their nerves: They had a championship game to play the next day.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: In Open, the U.S.T.A. Sows Seeds of Doubt
description: This isn't the first time the revolving autocrats who run the United States Tennis Association have woven a tangled web, and it probably won't be the last. Yesterday they only half-untangled the apparently patriotic, apparently CBS-friendly concoction that briefly masqueraded as the men's United States Open draw at Wednesday's unveiling.

title: At Archdiocesan Gala, No Room for Clinton or Dole
description: For 50 years, it has been New York's most prestigious nonpolitical political event. And since John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon took off their campaign gloves to attend the glittering dinner three weeks before the 1960 presidential election, most candidates for the nation's highest office have made the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Dinner a mandatory stop on the road to the White House.

title: Elusive Germ Sows Panic in Japan
description: Sitting unhappily in his silent warehouse, Yoshinori Minamino reflected uneasily on how he had suddenly become a national villain.

title: Secession for Northern Italy Goes Forward, Symbolically
description: With less than a month to go before Umberto Bossi and his green-shirted followers declare symbolic independence for the mythical state of Padania in northern Italy, several local magistrates say they are ready to prosecute him for violating the Italian Constitution.

title: Reeves Ready to Face Panthers and, Worse, Giant Fans
description: It may be payback time Friday night when the Giants play the Carolina Panthers at 8 o'clock in Giants Stadium in their final preseason game.

title: Oil Rises as Storm Threat in Gulf Shuts 3 Big Mexican Installations
description: Crude oil prices jumped yesterday after a tropical storm forced ports to close on the Gulf of Mexico, temporarily delaying Mexican oil exports. On other markets, natural gas fell while coffee rose.

title: S.A.T. Scores Rise, College Board Says
description: The College Board announced that American students continued to improve their S.A.T. scores, with their math scores the best in more than two decades. Educators credited high schools that have instituted more rigorous courses of study.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Frequent Job Losses Cited, Even as Economy Expanded

title: Blood Pressure Drug Linked to Cancer Rise
description: Use of calcium channel blockers, one of the most widely prescribed classes of medications for high blood pressure and other ailments, has been tentatively linked to higher rates of cancer among older people in a federally financed study.

title: The College Football Crew at CBS Includes a Point-Spread Maven
description: When CBS marches back into college football on Sept. 7 in prime time, after a six-year hiatus, Jim Nantz, Terry Donahue, Sean McDonough and Mike Mayock will call the games, Pat O'Brien will be host of the studio program and Craig James, after a great run on ESPN's preview show, will be the analyst.

title: ICAHN GROUP RAISES STAKE IN RJR AND AGAIN URGES SPINOFF
description: An investment group that includes Carl C. Icahn raised its stake in the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation to 5.8 percent from 4.8 percent and repeated a call for an immediate spinoff of the company's Nabisco food unit. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said it had met with RJR management and discussed a spinoff, but was told that such a move should not be undertaken now. But the group, apparently alluding to a Florida verdict against the Brown & Williamson Tobacco earlier this month, said that ''after the recent loss by another tobacco company in a smoking damage case,'' a spinoff should be put into effect immediately. Earlier this year, Mr. Icahn and Bennett S. LeBow, the investor, failed in an effort to force a spinoff. Mr. Icahn and Mr. LeBow parted ways in June.

title: Despite Drop, Rate of Layoffs Remains High
description: The layoff rate in the mid-1990's declined slightly from the early years of the decade but remained well above a comparable period a decade earlier, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Very Much A New Yorker
description: ELEANOR ROOSEVELT may have been the First Lady of the World, but she was also very much a New Yorker. Her parents lived in a town house on West 37th Street in Manhattan at her birth in 1884, and she made her debut at the Waldorf-Astoria in 1902. Three years later, she married her distant cousin Franklin at her aunt's house on East 76th Street, and then shared a home with Franklin's formidable mother, Sarah, at 47-49 East 65th Street, where she raised five children.

title: AVANT IN $153 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR META-SOFTWARE
description: The Avant Corporation, a maker of computer design software, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Meta-Software Inc. of Campbell, Calif., for about $153 million in stock. Under the agreement, Avant, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., will issue up to 5.1 million shares in exchange for all outstanding Meta-Software equity. The deal was announced after the stock market closed. Shares of Avant rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $30.125. Shares of Meta-Software, which makes software for the design of integrated circuits, rose $1.50, to $12.25.

title: SOUTHERN NATIONAL TO BUY FIDELITY FINANCIAL
description: The Southern National Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Fidelity Financial Bankshares Corporation for $59.4 million in stock. Southern National, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., said its offer valued Fidelity Financial at $24.68 a share. Shares of Fidelity, which is based in Richmond, rose $6.75, to $22.625. Shares of Southern National slipped 25 cents, to $30.875. Under the deal, Fidelity shareholders would receive 0.7931 Southern National common shares for each Fidelity share held.

title: Rewarding Indonesian Repression
description: President Clinton should heed those in his Administration who counsel against the planned sale of F-16 fighter jets at bargain prices to Indonesia. Financial terms for the sale were recently completed and the Administration need only notify Congress now before going ahead with the transfer.

title: Experts Say Plot Suspect Showed Signs Of Torture
description: Two medical experts testifying in defense of one of the three men accused of plotting to blow up American jetliners overseas said yesterday that his behavior supported his claim that he had been tortured while in Philippine police custody.

title: Officials Draw Criticism and Redo Men's Open
description: This was about appearances, about the very perception that a United States Open men's draw was rigged to favor the Americans, altered for good television ratings and crowd-pleasing matchups.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: It's Not a Real Bull Unless Investors Jump On
description: The Dow Jones industrial average is within one good day of setting a record, having wiped out nearly all of the sharp fall in prices that took place in early July. But the stock market is not nearly as healthy as that would indicate.

title: Must Elderly Serve Lifetime of Jury Duty?
description: To the Editor:

title: Petroski Jumps To a Victory
description: Petroski, a 6-year-old son of Polish Navy, won the most prestigious steeplechase race at Saratoga, the New York Turf Writers Cup, by 2 1/2 lengths today over T.V. Gold.

title: What the Welfare Law May Mean for Certain Recipients
description: The new welfare law will abolish the Federal guarantee of welfare benefits, principally Aid to Families with Dependent Children, and instead give states block grants they may use as they wish to aid the poor. Eligibility criteria and benefit levels, which already vary from state to state, could vary even more. The new law also establishes work requirements for most people seeking welfare or other benefits; states that do not mee these requirements may lose some of their Federal grant. Pie chart figures are for 1994, except where noted.

title: The Beauty of Life, Including Snakes
description: IN SEARCH OF NATURE

title: Nebraska's Peter in Jail
description: The former Nebraska football player CHRISTIAN PETER was in jail in Kearney, Neb., yesterday serving a 10-day sentence for grabbing a woman at a bar last March. Peter began serving his sentence Tuesday night.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Back Porch Languor
description: G. Love and Special Sauce, Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800. Using laziness as an instrument, G. Love harnesses 50's rock-and-roll to 80's hip-hop, two of popular music's more raucous styles, to come up with a laid-back summer sound for the 90's. He sits onstage with a harmonica and a Dobro as if he were practicing the blues on his back porch in Philadelphia and sleepily raps about his favorite fried foods and nostalgia items. Also on the bill are the Dirty Dozen Brass Band and John Hammond. The concert is tomorrow at 8 P.M., and admission is $14.

title: A 2d Movie Is a Reprise Of a Debut, With Cash
description: For Edward Burns, the director, writer and star of ''The Brothers McMullen,'' the perks of success are very tangible indeed. Mr. Burns's second film, ''She's the One,'' has been made with enough of a budget for varied sets, legal shooting permits for New York City street scenes (which were filmed on the sly for his debut film) and lunches supplied by someone other than his mother. And Mr. Burns's first flush of success has allowed him to surround himself with several films' worth of beautiful, funny young actresses the second time around.

title: STATES IN NEW ROLE
description: In a sweeping reversal of Federal policy, President Clinton today ended six decades of guaranteed help to the nation's poorest children by signing into law a vast welfare overhaul requiring the 50 states to deal more directly with the social burdens and the budget expense of poverty.

title: A Swarm of Cabs, All Making a Beeline for Fares
description: When Pedro Conde went into the taxi business 15 years ago, he had to buy a long black Chevy Caprice, dress in three-piece suits, pass a rigorous professional driver's exam, obtain a letter from the police certifying his good conduct, and prove that he knew his way around Lima's most obscure barrios.

title: Giuliani Says City May Sue Car Insurers
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani attacked insurance companies yesterday, saying that automobile insurance rates for New Yorkers have not kept pace with falling rates of car thefts, which dropped 50 percent in the city from 1990 to 1995. Mr. Giuliani said the city was considering suing the insurers to obtain better rates for residents.

title: First Inning A Disaster For Yankees And Rogers
description: Leave your house early, do not stop to buy a T-shirt at Yankee Stadium and do not wait in line at the concession stand before the Yankees play because if you miss the first inning you might miss the most important action.

title: Incinerator Prompts Suit
description: The township and borough of Princeton sued Mercer County on Wednesday in an attempt to block construction of a $200 million incinerator, officials said. The township and borough, which oppose the incinerator for environmental reasons, contend that the county began the work without adequately assessing public opinion, said Mary Henifin, a lawyer for the municipalities. Robert Prunetti, the Mercer County Executive, said a sufficient number of hearings took place.

title: Flaw Said to Be Found in Microsoft's Browser
description: A group of Princeton University computer researchers said yesterday that they had found a potentially serious computer flaw in Microsoft's Internet Explorer 3.0 Web Browser.

title: John Binnington, 82, Library Chief at Lab
description: John Binnington, the man who started the Research Library at Brookhaven National Laboratory in 1947 and built it into a prime repository of scientific and technical knowledge on Long Island, died of pneumonia Tuesday at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital. He was 82 and lived in the hamlet of Brookhaven.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The publicity surrounding the advertising mogul MAURICE SAATCHI's elevation to a British barony was not the type he would have orchestrated for himself.

title: ON BASEBALL
description: The newspapers were stacked beside David Cone's hospital bed three months ago, filled with accounts of his mysterious arm problem and the surgery he would have to remove an aneurysm from under his right armpit. Privately, the Yankees doubted that Cone would pitch again in 1996. Publicly, Cone told his wife, his parents and the friends who surrounded him that he would indeed pitch again. Sounding more like Steve Austin, the $6 Million Man, than David Cone, the $19.5 million question mark, he said he would become even better.

title: Betrayal Of the Kids
description: The newspapers and TV tell us we are in a new teen-age drug crisis. The deeper truth is that it is an adult moral crisis.

title: Last Chance to Experience Summer's Heat
description: Today will be a day to remember, one way or another.

title: The Return of Voodoo Politics
description: While waging the most successful Presidential re-election campaign in modern history, Ronald Reagan would celebrate the accomplishments of his first term and declare, ''You ain't seen nothin' yet!'' Audiences whooped with delight, but 12 years later we learn that at least one top White House aide listened to that old show-business line and wondered whether anyone would realize its unintended double meaning. In fact, he argues, Mr. Reagan accomplished nothing like the ''revolution'' he is given credit for.

title: Dole's Plan for Economy Could Be Hard to Fulfill
description: Many voters say they doubt that Bob Dole can fulfill his pledge to cut taxes while still balancing the budget, but his economic plan makes another promise that could prove even more difficult to keep: to improve the nation's growth capacity to 3.5 percent a year from its current level of less than 2.5 percent.

title: Home Video
description: Out of the Starting Gate

title: Barrooms and Bottles
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Sign College Hero
description: WARREN MORRIS, a College World Series hero and starting second baseman on the United States Olympic team, signed with the Texas Rangers yesterday. Morris, whose two-run homer in the bottom of the ninth inning gave Louisiana State a 9-8 victory over Miami in the College World Series title game in June, was drafted in the fifth round. (AP)

title: Virginia Corwin Brautigam, 95, Pioneer in Comparative Religion
description: Virginia Corwin Brautigam, a scholar who helped pioneer the field of comparative religion and who traveled the world in search of knowledge about Eastern faiths, died on Monday at a retirement community in Newtown, Pa. She was 95.

title: Tobacco Curbs Face Legal Fight
description: The Clinton Administration faces a tough legal battle to defend its new tobacco regulations in a Federal court in North Carolina, the heart of tobacco country.

title: A Struggle and a Death
description: A 40-year-old man died early yesterday during a struggle with three Garfield police officers in the apartment where he was staying, the authorities said. A relative of the man, Jan Vida, had called the police to complain that he had been drinking heavily when he banged on her bedroom door demanding beer, said Frank Puccio, the first assistant Bergen County prosecutor. Mr. Vida attempted to strike the officers with a chair, but they used pepper spray to subdue him and then pinned him face-down on the kitchen floor, Mr. Puccio said. Mr. Vida kept struggling and smashing his head against a cabinet before he lost consciousness, the prosecutor said. The names of the officers and the results of an autopsy conducted yesterday were not made public.

title: G.O.P. Right's Success Spurs Democrats' Hopes for Senate
description: Control of the United States Senate, which seemed safely Republican a year ago, is now in play in November's elections after a series of primaries where Republican voters chose very conservative candidates over moderates whom Democratic politicians feared more.

title: Benefit of Dole Tax Plan Is Hotly Debated
description: Do tax cuts stimulate growth?

title: Pazienza Pummels Foe and Referee
description: Vinny Pazienza added another wild chapter to his sometimes successful and always chaotic career, dropping Dana Rosenblatt with a monstrous right hand in the fourth round tonight to capture his fourth world title at the age of 33.

title: After 45 Years, Director of Circle in the Square Quits
description: After 45 years as artistic director of Circle in the Square, Theodore Mann has resigned.

title: F.B.I. Says 2 Labs Found Traces Of Explosive on T.W.A. Jetliner
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation confirmed today that its crime lab in Washington had found traces of plastic-explosive residue on a piece of wreckage from Trans World Airlines Flight 800 and said that the findings had been backed up by tests at an independent laboratory.

title: Now Woods Has Another Advantage: Age
description: Throughout his amazing amateur golf career, Tiger Woods always has had more -- more game, more attention, more length off the tee and more victories than his opponents. But today in the quarterfinals of the United States Amateur at Pumpkin Ridge Golf Club, he added one that he has never had before: more years.

title: Taiwan Cuts Forecast For 1996 Growth
description: Taiwan cut its forecast of economic growth in 1996 to its lowest in six years amid slower gains in export sales and a decline in private investment. And Taiwan's central bank announced its fifth reduction in bank reserve requirements in just over a year to stimulate economic activity.

title: Judge Says Lloyd's Can't Impose Rescue
description: In a serious setback for the financial recovery of Lloyd's of London, one of the world's premier insurance organizations, a Federal judge yesterday ordered Lloyd's to delay putting its plan into effect for two months to give American investors time to obtain more details on the deal.

title: Southern Cal Is Without a Top Tailback
description: There's no point in worrying because there's no time. As the Southern California Trojans began to complete their preparations for the earliest opening game in their history, the Kickoff Classic against Penn State on Sunday afternoon at Giants Stadium, the loss of the suspended tailback Delon Washington sounded like just another minor complication.

title: Bonds Fall After Durable Goods Orders Surge
description: Probably the last thing investors wanted to see yesterday, was strong economic data showing the manufacturing sector expanding at a brisk pace, even though there were suspicions. But it happened, and prices of government securities fell sharply as a result.

title: As Insurers Cut Fees, Doctors Shift to Elective Procedures
description: Dr. Phillip Haeck, a Seattle plastic surgeon, used to spend half his working hours rebuilding the breasts of cancer patients and performing other reconstructive procedures. Then managed-care companies started to cut his fees by 60 percent or more.

title: Bomb Blast Damages Synagogue In Moscow
description: A bomb exploded at Moscow's busiest synagogue on Thursday night, shattering windows, collapsing part of the roof and toppling Torah scrolls to the floor. The building was empty at the time, and no one was injured.

title: Cigarette Makers Win Verdict In Suit by a Smoker's Family
description: In a victory for the tobacco industry after a week full of grim news, an Indianapolis jury ruled in favor of major American cigarette companies last night, barring damages asked by the family of an Indianapolis man who died of lung cancer in 1987 at the age of 52.

title: Marine Invaders Stay
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Plaid
description: There's a certain giddy optimism to fashion this fall that lends itself to plaid. Whether it's bell-bottoms, short jackets or ankle-grazing dresses, the silhouette is minimal, but not the mood.

title: Italy Treats a Top Mafia Leader's Repentance With Caution
description: Giovanni Brusca, a top Mafia boss who was arrested in May after six years as a fugitive, is cooperating with Italian prosecutors, offering a rare high-level glimpse into the activities of the Sicilian mob.

title: As the West Hesitates on Burundi, Leaders in Africa Make a Stand
description: Outsiders have often criticized African governments for doing little to halt disasters in their midst, such as the large-scale massacres in Rwanda and Burundi, let alone to oppose military coups and support democracy. But now in East Africa, regional leaders are making a serious effort to confront the leaders of the recent coup in Burundi by imposing a trade embargo on the country.

title: Police in Paris Smash Immigrants' Sit-In
description: As the church bells sounded a tocsin and the priest frantically tried to start a Mass, police officers in riot gear swarmed into a church occupied by illegal immigrants from Africa early this morning, using axes to break down the doors and hauling off more than 200 immigrants to a detention center.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 21 by Fareed Zakaria incorrectly identified Robert Kagan. He was a State Department policy planner in the Reagan Administration.

title: In a Barn at Jacob's Pillow, History Is Another Show
description: For visitors to the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., there has always been the extra dividend of small exhibitions of photographs, programs and other mementos associated with Pillow performers over the festival's six decades.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page chart yesterday about evidence of an explosive device on T.W.A. Flight 800 gave an incorrect date in some copies for the preliminary test on a wing fragment. It was in July, not August.

title: Investigators Look at History of Terrorism to Compile a List of Suspects in Crash
description: In June, a few weeks before the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 off Long Island, leaders of several Middle Eastern terrorist organizations backed by the Iranian Government met in Teheran to plan terrorist acts, intelligence officials said yesterday.

title: West Plans to Correct Bosnia Vote Abuses
description: Western election monitors said today they are likely to take action soon to correct what they call ''massive'' manipulation of the rules for next month's elections, especially the evidence that Bosnian Serb refugees now living in Serbia have taken advantage of loopholes in the voter registration rules to register in great numbers in a few important towns that formerly had Muslim majorities.

title: Scrutiny of Terrorists
description: Although investigators are still looking for conclusive proof that an explosive device destroyed T.W.A. Flight 800, they are investigating a number of terrorist organizations as well as the possibility the attack could have been a domestic criminal act. Included in their inquiry, officials say, is a meeting in June in which terrorist groups backed by Iran gathered in Teheran.

title: Yanks, Seeking Relief, Trade for a Left-Hander
description: Yankees General Manager Bob Watson had been trying all season to land a proven left-hander for his bullpen. Yesterday Watson pulled the trigger, sending Gerald Williams and Bob Wickman to the Milwaukee Brewers for Graeme Lloyd and Pat Listach.

title: Mark Gains on Dollar as Traders See an End to German Rate Cuts
description: A day after rallying strongly against the German mark, the dollar retreated yesterday, hurt by speculation that a cut in interest rates by the Bundesbank might be its last for a while.

title: The Way We Live Now
description: The car is obsolete. The vehicle is king now. I intend to buy one. I go to a vehicle dealer.

title: Toddler Hurt in Pool Fall
description: An 8-year-old girl found her 2-year-old cousin submerged in a backyard pool Thursday and pulled him out of the water, the police said. The toddler, Ryder Sturr, remained in critical condition yesterday at Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune. After the girl, Killeen McCaughey, rescued the boy, people in the house called the police, said Dover Officer Scott Kenny. A police dispatcher talked them through cardiopulmonary resuscitation procedures, but the efforts were unsuccessful, he said. Police officers took over the rescue efforts when they arrived, and were able to get a pulse, Officer Kenny said.

title: Going Plaid
description: Correction Appended

title: Nothing Goes Right in an Ugly Exhibition by the Giants
description: The phrases ''correctable mistakes'' and ''it's only preseason'' can be excuses for just so long. Now that preseason is officially over, the Giants may need to add a new phrase to their repertory: ''It could be a long season.''

title: Crackdown on Teen Smoking
description: Determined to grab the values issue from the Republicans, President Clinton signed an executive order this week aimed at teen-age smokers. The plan would limit the availability of cigarettes and should help save teen-agers from their own bad habits.

title: Beating Up on Charter Schools
description: Publicly financed charter schools, praised by both the Republican platform and President Clinton as a promising reform, are becoming one of the fiercest battlegrounds in education.

title: Cambodians to Seek Amnesty For Khmer Rouge Defector
description: Cambodia's two Prime Ministers announced today that they would seek amnesty for Ieng Sary, a founding leader of the Khmer Rouge, which is blamed for mass killings while it ruled Cambodia from 1975 to 1979.
