title: Hot but Hardly Bothered: August Allows 90degrees Day
description: Everyone knows that the summer of 1996 has turned out to be like the party that never happened, a foggy, sodden downer of empty beaches and late tomatoes. But yesterday, at precisely 3:41 P.M., for 20 bright, shining minutes, the temperature at last hit 90 degrees in Central Park for the first time since May.

title: Democrats' Left Wing Keeps Its Power Dry
description: Haunting the Democratic Presidential convention next week in Chicago will be the liberal impulse of stormy conventions past.

title: Out There
description: From the desolate canyons of the Southwest to the crowded ones of Manhattan, the maxi coat, in all its outsized glamour, is sweeping the nation.

title: Croatia and Yugoslavia Reach Accord to End 5-Year Struggle
description: In a move that formally ended five years of hostilities, Croatia and Yugoslavia signed a mutual recognition accord today that is viewed by many in the region as vital to heading off a resumption of war in the Balkans.

title: Welfare Law Could Bring A Windfall
description: While some other states, notably New York and California, are sounding alarms about the new Federal welfare law's dire effects, state officials here are cautiously anticipating a windfall of as much as $90 million in Federal aid for the poor over the next year. That would mean at least a 50 percent increase over what the state would have received under the old system.

title: Reno Casino Project
description: The Boyd Gaming Corporation has bought 100 acres in Reno for a $92 million casino, hotel and entertainment complex. The project will be called Sam's Town Reno, according to Boyd, which is based in Las Vegas. It will include a casino, a 211-room hotel, an indoor events center and an outdoor arena. The purchase price of the land was not disclosed. Boyd operates casino-entertainment properties in Nevada, Mississippi, Louisiana and Missouri.

title: IOMEGA SET TO CHARGE CUSTOMERS FOR ASSISTANCE
description: The Iomega Corporation said yesterday that it would begin charging customers $15 to $20 for assistance provided over the phone, in response to a flood of calls from customers seeking help installing and servicing its disk drives. The company said it would charge customers per incident, meaning that repeated calls about the same problem would be billed as one call. Internet and fax-based support will continue to be offered free of charge, the company said. The new charges are intended to reduce the number of calls and shorten callers' waiting times, said A. Cory Malloy, a spokesman for the company. Iomega is based in Roy, Utah.

title: Compass Group Buys Unit of Service America
description: Compass Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the dining and vending food service assets of the Service America Corporation for $119.2 million. The deal is expected to be completed next month.

title: Metro Digest
description: THE CRASH

title: Dole, in Change of Focus, Appeals for Black Votes
description: In a direct and explicit appeal for black support, Bob Dole today declared that the Republican Party had needlessly abandoned black voters to the Democratic Party, and he promised to challenge President Clinton for a bloc of voters who have reliably supported Democrats for more than a generation.

title: Triple Bill of Reggae Voices
description: It was difficult to determine if the music at the ''Reggae Madness'' concert on Thursday night at Radio City Music Hall was a corruption of reggae or a return to its origins. Three of the most successful reggae singers of this decade performed: Maxi Priest and Shabba Ranks from England, and Shaggy from Brooklyn. Each performed in a style that borrowed directly from Western pop and rhythm-and-blues while maintaining various degrees of connection to Jamaican music. That, of course, is how ska and reggae started when bands tried to make a homegrown version of the American rhythm-and-blues hits that infiltrated the island in the 40's and 50's.

title: New Jersey Shouldn't Rewrite Ellis I. History
description: To the Editor:

title: Qantas and Union Reach a Pay Deal
description: Qantas Airways Ltd., Australia's main international airline, has reached an agreement with the Transport Workers Union of Australia for an 8 percent wage increase over two years for 5,500 Qantas workers. The agreement must be approved by the staff, who include baggage handlers, ramp service providers and caterers. The deal is dated back to July 1.

title: Parking Bans Keep Outsiders From Queens Sand and Surf
description: Eda Cawthon reclined on a plastic chaise longue, her eyes obscured by sunglasses and her toes wriggling and pointing at the Atlantic Ocean as she waited for her husband, Craig, to schlep back half a mile from the parking lot.

title: VENEZUELA TO STUDY CHARGE BROUGHT BY PEPSICO
description: Venezuela's Antimonopoly Commission said yesterday that it would study a motion submitted by Pepsico Inc. that a proposed joint venture between its former bottler -- the Cisneros Group -- and the Coca-Cola Company would create a soft drink monopoly, in violation of Venezuelan law. ''We have decided to open an investigation into the Pepsi complaint,'' said Francisco Suniaga, a commission official. ''We will ask the Cisneros Group and Coca-Cola to defend themselves against Pepsi's charges.'' Pepsi had filed suit with the commission on Monday, charging that the proposed joint venture between the Cisneros Group, and Coke constituted an ''illegal attempt by Coke to control the Venezuelan market by creating a soft drink monopoly.''

title: Saving the Fish
description: When the Senate returns to work in little over a week, it will have a glorious opportunity to improve its mediocre record on environmental issues. At the top of its calendar is a sound bill reauthorizing and strengthening the Magnuson Act, the basic statute governing the management of fisheries off the coasts of the United States. The House has already passed the bill. It is up to the majority leader, Trent Lott, to resist last-minute efforts by large commercial fishing interests to weaken it, and to resist as well whatever attempts his Senate colleagues make to add extraneous amendments that could trap the bill in ruinous debate.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a Government report tabulating the rate of layoffs in the mid-1990's referred incorrectly in some editions to the percentage change between two periods -- 1991-93 and 1993-95. The decline in job elimination was 7 percent, not 16.

title: Bertelsmann Not Selling Pay-TV Channel Stake
description: Bertelsmann A.G., a German media company, has ended an apparent truce in the battle to dominate Germany's digital television market by saying that it was unwilling to trim its stake in Premiere, a pay-TV channel that is also owned by its German rival, Kirch Group.

title: A Wild Ride
description: Extreme sports don't require extreme clothes - just the right ones.

title: To Families, Finding Is Saddening, but No Surprise
description: All along, Eitan Sobel had held out hope for a mechanical failure. He could not accept that someone could possess the evil necessary to bring down an airliner with 230 people on board. So when he heard that investigators had the first scientific evidence of an explosive device on T.W.A. Flight 800, it put a sharper edge on his cousin's death in the crash.

title: The End of Everything
description: The End it's everywhere, and we can't get enough of it. By ''the end,'' I do not mean ''They lived happily ever after.'' I mean, ''That's it; it's over.'' The shelves of bookstores are lined with books declaring that the end of everything has come.

title: Company Briefs
description: UNITED TECHNOLOGY CORP., Hartford, Conn., said its Pratt & Whitney division had received an engine order from UAL United Airlines Inc. worth about $680 million in conjunction with the carrier's order of Boeing wide-body planes valued at $3.5 billion.

title: Beliefs
description: For most Americans, the only good tax is a smaller one. Not only is it every American's unalienable right to speak evil of taxation, in election season it is every politician's duty.

title: Fed Proposal Would Ease Some Regulations for Banks
description: The Federal Reserve proposed new rules yesterday that would make it much easier for banks to make acquisitions and enter new lines of business, but could make it much harder for community groups to press banks to increase doing business in low-income areas.

title: 2 Nightclubs Linked to Drugs Are Shut Down
description: The police shut down and seized two of New York's best-known nightclubs, the Limelight and Tunnel, in Manhattan early today under the city's nuisance abatement law. Both the clubs are owned by Peter Gatien, who had been charged earlier this year in a Federal drug case.

title: Two Errors In Infield Put Mets In a Hole
description: The Mets came into tonight's game with the Dodgers leading the National League in errors with 125, well ahead of their nearest rivals, the Colorado Rockies, who had kicked it away 118 times.

title: Dole Rejects a Party Plank
description: Publicly repudiating a portion of his party's platform for the first time since the Republican National Convention, Bob Dole told a convention of black journalists here today that he would not support a constitutional amendment to deny automatic citizenship for children who are born in this country to illegal immigrants.

title: A Healing Truth in South Africa
description: This week South Africans were treated to the spectacle of former Prime Minister F. W. de Klerk calling the apartheid policies he once served ''deeply mistaken'' and apologizing for the pain they caused. The next day, Deputy President Thabo Mbeki apologized for the African National Congress's far more limited crimes, including the execution of 34 men in A.N.C. training camps.

title: A Period Style of Playing, Using Modern Hardware
description: I Solisti Veneti has made recordings by the cartload since 1959, when Claudio Scimone founded it, and although its repertory runs from the 18th century to the present, the recordings have conveyed the impression that this Paduan ensemble is a full-time Baroque music factory. In its Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday evening, the group did not stray far from that reputation, offering works by Vivaldi and Albinoni but also edging into the Classical era for the meat of the program, a pair of rarities by Boccherini.

title: INSIDE
description: Setback for Lloyd's Plan

title: In a Surprise, Ann Taylor's Chief Resigns
description: Sally Frame Kasaks, who won Wall Street's praise for building up the Ann Taylor Stores Corporation and then its displeasure as the women's clothier teetered, resigned as chairwoman and chief executive, the company said yesterday.

title: A Public Offering Set for Abercrombie
description: The Abercrombie & Fitch Company, which outfitted Teddy Roosevelt and Ernest Hemingway for safari and is now a unit of Limited Inc., has filed to sell seven million shares for $14 to $16 each in an initial public offering that could raise as much as $112 million.

title: Pink Slips for State Workers
description: Pink slips were mailed to 239 employees of the Department of Human Services, including 85 at the Marlboro Psychiatric Center, which is scheduled to close by 1998, and 67 at the Vineland Developmental Center, The A.P. reported. It is not known exactly how many of these workers will lose their jobs because civil service rules allow laid-off employees to ''bump,'' or replace, those with less seniority. The layoffs -- the second set since the new state budget took effect last month -- is slated for Oct. 11. Half the Marlboro employees who received notices were nurses, state officials said.

title: Plane-Crash Families Credit Mayor's Presence
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Oddly Familiar Guys in a Diner
description: By the end of September television viewers may feel they've been locked in a room with Felix and Oscar, kept after school for detention and overcome by aliens. The new season's trends include ''Odd Couple'' wannabees, classroom series and ''X-Files'' clones. And as if that thematic overload wasn't enough, there is a monstrous scheduling battle coming, with the three major networks planning premieres of most new shows during the third week of September (at last count, 16 premieres in 6 days). With this traffic jam among major networks, what's a netlet to do?

title: Royal Matches for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Water Alert for 250,000
description: Thunderstorms knocked out power to a water treatment plant in Boonton last night, causing nearly 250,000 residents in three cities to boil water before using it, The Associated Press reported. The outage occurred about 8 p.m., affecting a water treatment plant in Boonton that is owned by Jersey City and serves Jersey City, Hoboken and Lyndhurst, said Rich Henning, a spokesman for the United Water Company, which manages the system. Mr. Henning said residents should boil their water until further notice. The Jersey City system normally services West Caldwell, too. But West Caldwell switched to another water system and closed off the intake from Jersey City, Mr. Henning said

title: Testimony Ends in Bombing Plot Trial
description: After less than a week of testimony by five witnesses, the defense rested its case yesterday in the trial of three men charged with plotting to blow up American jetliners in the Far East. The prosecution case took a dozen weeks of testimony from 47 witnesses and was completed on Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about John Binnington, who developed the research library at Brookhaven National Laboratory, omitted a survivor. She is his widow, Julia Binnington of Brookhaven, L.I.

title: The Guns Fall Silent in Chechnya's Capital
description: The cease-fire brokered by President Boris N. Yeltsin's national security adviser went into effect at noon today, bringing an edgy quiet to the embattled capital of secessionist Chechnya for the first time since a devastating rebel offensive began 17 days ago.

title: BORLAND'S FINANCIAL OFFICER TO RESIGN
description: Gary Mullin, the chief financial officer of Borland International Inc., said that he would leave the troubled software company in mid-September after 10 months on the job. His departure marks the third senior executive change this year at the company, which is based in Scotts Valley, Calif. Borland said Mr. Mullin, who had come to Borland from Conner Peripherals Inc., a disk drive maker now owned by Seagate Technology Inc., planned to take a similar position at another company.

title: Dead Fish, Closed Beaches
description: Some beaches on Long Beach Island were closed part of the day yesterday when dead fish washed ashore, said Elaine Makatura, a spokeswoman for the Department of Environmental Protection. Thousands of bunker fish were released into the ocean on Thursday when a net on a commercial bait fishing boat came apart. Some fish were still floating about 100 yards offshore near Surf City and Ship Bottom yesterday and could cause further beach closings during the weekend, depending on the tides and the direction of the wind, Ms. Makatura said. The New Jersey Bait Fishery Alliance, an organization of commercial bait fishermen, has agreed to pay the cost of the cleanup because the net that broke belonged to one of its members.

title: Acquisition by Eye Care
description: Eye Care Centers of America Inc. has agreed to acquire Visionworks Inc., an optical retailer with 49 stores in the southeastern United States. The acquisition of Visionworks, which has annual sales of $61 million, would increase Eye Care Center's sales to more than $200 million a year, the San Antonio-based company said. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Mississippi Governor Bans Same-Sex Marriage
description: Gov. Kirk Fordice of Mississippi has issued an executive order banning same-sex marriages in the state in a move he said was intended to strengthen the state's existing anti-sodomy law while a legal review of the issue is proceeding in the courts and in Congress.

title: Bankers Trust Paid Ex-Chief $2 Million
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation gave its former chief executive, Charles Sanford, a $2 million payment after he retired in April. In exchange, Mr. Sanford agreed not to criticize his former employer.

title: Selling Success, Blockbuster Style
description: Here's a riddle. What do Mario Cuomo, Larry King, Margaret Thatcher, Bonnie Blair, George Bush, Zig Ziglar and Charlton Heston have in common?

title: Why Make Visitors Pay for Detroit Stadium?
description: To the Editor:

title: Arthur J. Moore, Chronicler Of Church Milestones, Dies at 74
description: Arthur J. Moore, a journalist and lay theologian who edited a major Methodist magazine for 34 years, died suddenly of heart disease on Thursday in the Brooklyn Hospital Center. He had suffered for many years from a blood disorder. He was 74.

title: Replenishing Beaches Protects Mainland
description: To the Editor:

title: Curtains for Dance Club
description: In a victory for city officials seeking to purge their beach resort of nude entertainment, a bar has promised to get rid of its go-go dancers by November. The owners of the dance bar, C. R. Fannies, agreed in a settlement with the city and the state Division of Alcoholic Beverage Control to turn the bar into a family restaurant, Mayor Fred Wager said yesterday. The settlement, reached last month, also requires the owner, Albert Thame Jr., to give up control of the establishment and to pay $40,000 in penalties. Mr. Thame had been accused of violating state liquor laws by operating and working at the bar even though he had previously been convicted on drug charges, Mayor Wager said. He said the city would continue to fight the community's remaining nude dance club.

title: Lost and Found
description: To the Editor:

title: Mommy Dressing
description: There is a photograph of her wearing my favorite of all her costumes: a long, shining robe that rippled with light when she moved. Cloth of silver was the material, quilted and stitched with a delicate tracery of birds and flowers -- trapunto, she called it. Not the name of a fairy tale princess shut up in a tower, who let down her hair for her lover to climb, but it might as well have been. The buttons were iridescent moonstone clusters, and though my mother's hair was neither long nor golden like that of a princess, it shone above the cloth of silver like a wreath of dark feathers.

title: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS TO SELL 5 MILLION SHARES
description: ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc. filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell five million shares of new common stock, valued at more than $110 million, just one day after winning a legal round as a Federal jury rejected seven claims of securities fraud in a class-action shareholder suit pending since 1987. ''We have ambitious growth plans that require a source of funding,'' said Jennifer Openshaw, a spokeswoman for the company, which markets both prescription and over-the-counter drugs in more than 60 nations. ''We've been looking at acquisitions, particularly in Eastern Europe.'' The filing said that the company, which is based in Costa Mesa, Calif., may sell the shares ''from time to time.''

title: Lillian Clark, 70, Big-Band Singer
description: Lillian Clark, a singer who performed with many stars of the big-band era and helped preserve the work of her husband, the composer and arranger Sy Oliver, died on Tuesday at her home in New York City. She was 70.

title: New Yank And Rivera Close Out The A's
description: Mariano Rivera was ready. More than ready.

title: Take That, Europe: Maiden Names for Every Child
description: In Italian family affairs it may be Mamma who, by venerable tradition, calls the shots, but it is Papa who, by law, still gives the child his name.

title: Chang Stunned At Hamlet Cup
description: Ranked 86th in the world and with barely a smidgen of credentials as a professional, Karol Kucera stamped his name in the tennis world tonight.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK

title: News Summary
description: International 2-6

title: Bonding as New Political Theater: Bring On the Babies and Cue the Yellow Dog
description: Call it the Skutnik Syndrome: Working politicians tend to date the now ubiquitous practice of candidates and incumbents rushing to seize the perfect visual initiative to that moment during President Ronald Reagan's 1982 State of the Union Message when he suddenly pointed up to the House gallery and identified a man sitting there, Lenny Skutnik, as a public hero for having leapt into the frigid Potomac to rescue survivors of a plane crash.

title: Roadblocks To Profits And Pleasures
description: FORGET about good intentions. Jack Fishman swears -- and how -- that the road to Hell is paved with asphalt and runs right past his service station on East Tremont Avenue. From summer 1994 until last winter, his gas sales plummeted when huge orange and white barricades blocked easy access to the pumps while construction crews renovated the overpass spanning the Amtrak rails near West Farms Square in the Bronx.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Wednesday about the cause of death of the actress Margaux Hemingway referred incorrectly to the drug Klonopin, which was found in her apartment. It is an anticonvulsant used in the treatment of epileptic seizures; it is not a barbiturate.

title: Traffic Rules Will Make Park Safer
description: To the Editor:

title: Cotton Prices Surge on Concerns About Rainfall From Hurricane
description: Cotton prices surged yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange over concern that Hurricane Dolly could bring unwanted rain to southern Texas and Arizona, possibly hurting crops.

title: Cosmetics Heir Reopens His Wallet to Back Term Limits for City Officials
description: Ronald S. Lauder, the billionaire cosmetics heir who in 1993 spent millions of dollars in a successful campaign to limit all elected city officials to two terms, vowed yesterday to spend whatever it took to stop the City Council from scaling back the measure.

title: Cyber-House Financing
description: To the Editor:

title: 36 Indicted in Scheme That Cost Investors $265 Million
description: Three years after the collapse of what law-enforcement officials call one of the largest fraud operations in the country, a Federal grand jury here has returned a 169-count indictment against 36 people accused of bilking investors of an estimated $265 million.

title: 2 Win Suit Against Police In Beating
description: A Federal jury in Manhattan awarded $500,000 this week to a Harlem woman and her son who said they had been harassed, beaten and wrongly arrested by several police officers from the 30th Precinct, the so-called Dirty 30.

title: CLINTON APPROVES A SERIES OF CURBS ON CIGARETTE ADS
description: Calling ''cigarette smoking the most significant public health hazard facing our people,'' President Clinton today unveiled a long list of restrictions meant to stop tobacco companies from encouraging children to take up smoking.

title: To Relieve Bronx Homeless, Dozens Are Sent to Brooklyn
description: Under orders from a state judge to relieve severe overcrowding at a Bronx homeless center, city officials moved at least 68 people yesterday to another shelter in Brooklyn, where residents said cots had been set up in day rooms, the kitchen and a children's day-care area.

title: The Knit Parade
description: Long, sexy sweater dresses are in perfect harmony with the times: the comfort of a T-shirt with the slim silhouette of a well-cut dress.

title: AMTRAN'S AIRLINE UNIT IN SWEEPING CHANGES
description: Amtran Inc. said yesterday that its American Trans Air unit would discontinue some scheduled flights and trim its fleet size in an effort to cut costs and concentrate on its charter service. Citing a ''depressed pricing environment,'' particularly in Boston, and ''an increasingly competitive marketplace,'' the company said it would eliminate scheduled flights serving Boston, San Diego and Miami. It also said it planned to cut service to Grand Cayman in the Cayman Islands and Montego Bay, Jamaica. The carrier, which has been in business for 23 years, also signed a letter of intent to cancel leases on five Boeing 757-200's, reducing its fleet of aircraft to 44.

title: No Headline
description: ''I can't think of two better outcomes of this election -- not just for the black community, but for all Americans -- than to have Bill Clinton and Al Gore, and Bob Dole and Jack Kemp, compete, truly competing, for the votes of African-Americans.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: First Rock-and-Roller Is Giving the Open a Try
description: It's him. It's the guy in the bandana, the one with the earring dangling, the guy who is more heavy metal than Sinatra, more down under than over the hill. It's him, the one tennis fans will approach anytime, anywhere.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Orders for Durables Surge, Raising Interest Rate Fears

title: N.F.L. TRAINING CAMP REPORT
description: Lions 24, Bengals 17

title: Will's Way Can't Be Dismissed in Travers
description: On the eve of the Travers Stakes, the key to the scrambled championship picture among 3-year-old horses, James Bond was asked if he had any last-minute preparations before sending out Will's Way, and he replied: ''Yes, I will be going to church tonight.''

title: Welfare's Drug Connection
description: Substance abuse and addiction have changed the nature of poverty in America. But the welfare reform legislation that the Republican Congress passed and that President Clinton signed Thursday ignores this grim truth.

title: Perot Displays No Gift for Teamwork
description: To the Editor:

title: Cardinal Opposed in Effort To Find 'Common Ground'
description: An unusual, public disagreement has developed among the nation's Roman Catholic cardinals, over plans by Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, Archbishop of Chicago, to lead an effort to find ''common ground'' among Catholics of different opinions and try to decrease polarization in the church.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about trading in the currency markets on Thursday referred incorrectly in some editions to a high rate touched by the dollar against the German mark that day. It was 1.4960 marks, not 149.60 marks.

title: Citadel Adopts Positive View of Its Female Cadets
description: The trumpets will blare across The Citadel's stark campus on Monday, just as they have since the mid-1800's. But to some, this year's starting reveille may sound more like taps. As The Citadel prepares for another school year, the small but defiant South Carolina military college that spent three years and many millions in a fight to keep one woman out will execute an abrupt about face to embrace co-education.

title: A Hijacking Teaches The Joys of Parenthood
description: Tom Arnold's star turn in ''Carpool'' is enough to explain why this comedy opened yesterday without benefit of advance screenings. Wide-eyed and mirthlessly peppy, Mr. Arnold soon wears out his welcome as a bumbling would-be bank robber who commandeers a group of young hostages. The children and Mr. Arnold compete madly for the honor of being most adorable person in the hijacked mini-van. But it's a contest nobody wins.

title: An Android With Heart
description: Although it isn't saying much, the macho techno-bluster sprinkled through ''Solo,'' starring Mario Van Peebles as a rebellious military robot acting up in the jungles of Central America, occasionally approaches the ''Terminator'' level of wit. ''Wake up and smell the hydraulic fluid!'' snaps one military bigwig early in the film. And when the title character works up an overload of angry electronic wattage, he growls, ''Delete this!'' before wreaking the kind of havoc that only an android 15 times stronger and 10 times faster than the average man could manage.

title: YPF Reaches a Deal With Ecuador
description: YPF S.A., an Argentine oil company, said yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agreement with the Government of Ecuador over a disputed oil production contract. A definitive agreement, which would grant the state-owned oil company Petroecuador a stake in production from a YPF field in Ecuador's Amazon region, should be reached within 30 days, YPF said in a statement.

title: 'Better' Americans?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cranston Craves Upset
description: To say that the baseball team representing Taiwan is pretty good would be an understatement. But to say that the team from Cranston, R.I., hardly stands a chance in the championship game of the Little League World Series on Saturday would be downright wrong.

title: 2 H.M.O. Shifts Are Further Indications of Consolidation
description: Humana Inc., one of the nation's largest health maintenance organizations, announced yesterday that it was pulling out of its health care plans in the Washington area. Another H.M.O., Pacificare Health Systems Inc., said that it was considering the sale of its Florida operations.

title: Fire on 34th Street Snarls Traffic and Shuts Library
description: A fire in a fur vault in the vast palazzo that once housed the B. Altman department store and is now home to a new $100 million arm of the New York Public Library snarled traffic in midtown Manhattan yesterday morning and temporarily shut down the library but left its collections unscathed.

title: Bridge
description: The hardest-working bridge journalist in the world, in the view of many, is a quiet man living in Memphis, Tenn. His name is Henry Francis, and for the last 25 years he has been the editor of the American Contract Bridge League's Bulletin, a major monthly magazine.

title: The Backup Quarterbacks Show Some Promise in a Jets Defeat
description: The Jets ended their exhibition season in curious fashion tonight, alternating fumbles and sloppy special-teams play with occasional flashes of offense -- the one commodity they seemed to have bought in abundant supply.

title: If Only Shakespeare Had Been in the House
description: England being England, the main topic of conversation was the weather. So when years of dreaming, fund-raising and construction climaxed in the first staged play at the replica of Shakespeare's Globe Theater here this week, it seemed almost as significant that ''The Two Gentlemen of Verona'' was performed on a warm evening under clear skies.

title: Dispute Continues On Aid to Volkswagen
description: Germany and the European Commission failed to resolve a dispute concerning state aid payments to Volkswagen A.G., Europe's biggest auto company, making it likely the deadlock will have to be broken in court.

title: The Giants Are Kitchen Friendly
description: GIANTS fans were on their best behavior last night.

title: Strong Durable Goods Data Revive Fear of Higher Rates
description: Orders for durable goods surged in July, jumping 1.6 percent. That was considerably more than analysts had expected and cast new doubt on assumptions that the economy was slowing from its unsustainable fast pace of the spring.

title: Kemp, Going Solo, Hawks Fiscal Remedies
description: In his first solo campaign appearances since becoming Bob Dole's running mate, Jack Kemp struck out for the West today, visiting an isolated prairie town in South Dakota and later addressing several thousand Republicans at a party barbecue on this island suburb of Seattle.

title: Victory for a Shoe Shine Man
description: In his 81 years, Anthony Avena lived through two world's fairs held in Queens, and shined shoes for two mayors -- La Guardia and Giuliani. Now, Mr. Avena can add another chapter to his list of accomplishments. In this one, he is the little guy who fought the powerful Metropolitan Transit Authority. And won.

title: Jennifer Dwinell And Peter J. Scala
description: Jennifer Church Dwinell, a daughter of Carolyn Mitton Ford of Sarasota, Fla., and the Rev. Michael Dwinell of Cape Elizabeth, Me., was married yesterday to Peter John Scala, a son of Rosemary Scala of Gloucester, Mass., and C. George Scala of Beverly, Mass. The Rev. Diana Phillips, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated with the bride's father, an Episcopal priest. The wedding took place at the home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Albert F. Ford 2d, in Marion, Mass.

title: Plush Puppies
description: This fall's boot is a democratic animal: it goes from a flat spat all the way up to the top of the knee, with velvet its common denominator.

title: A Rebuilding Year for Osborne's Reputation
description: TOM OSBORNE has written a book. He is also writing a legacy - for himself, for the football players under his supervision at the University of Nebraska and for all the ones that have come before. The legacy extends beyond the victories, the academic achievement, the community outreach, the decades of effort and even the national championships that were once so agonizingly elusive.

title: To Be Young and in Love And in Paris
description: PARIS was founded in 53 B.C. Nothing much happened until I got there in 1948. I arrived as a student on the G.I. Bill of Rights. There were several thousands of us would-be artists, would-be writers and would-be revelers who were out to have a good time. We didn't realize it then, but we arrived at the Golden Age for Americans in France. The dollar was the strongest currency in the world, and the franc was one of the weakest.

title: Despite Complications, Big 12 Is Instant Commercial Hit
description: If you've run into the elephant statues, you're in the wrong place. The newest conference in America will be easy to spot on autumn Saturdays. For now, Mondays through Fridays present the only problem. Someday soon, the Big 12 Conference will occupy 16,500 square feet of 28th-story office space, a cost-free testament to the newfound collective clout of its membership, with 30-foot windows providing views of the Dallas skyline.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: PSALM AT JOURNEY's ENDBy Erik Fosnes Hansen.Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.

title: Palestinian Security Agents Ban Books by a Critic of Arafat
description: Security agents acting in the name of Yasir Arafat's leadership have banned the sale of books by one of Mr. Arafat's most vocal Palestinian critics, Edward W. Said, adding to the lengthening list of human rights abuses by the Palestinian Authority.

title: Gay America Depicted Through a Gay Lens
description: THIS WEEK, ''Network Q: Out Across America,'' a news omnibus that focuses on gay Americans, will begin its second season on public-television stations in certain spots around the country, and WNET in New York will be one of those stations. Garrison Botts, a programming associate at WNET, said Channel 13 had renewed the program because it ''is visually captivating and sexual and fun.''

title: The Effects of Money, as Felt in the Hamptons
description: OLD money is the stranglehold of fathers over sons. But new money can set anyone free.

title: First Fix the Structure
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Country Lessons For a City School Year
description: For 12-year-old Maleeva Elliott of Canarsie, blaring car alarms and screeching firetrucks are like a lullaby. So falling asleep was no easy task at camp this summer, what with all that racket made by nature: those chirping cicadas, hooting owls, pounding rain on the cabin's wooden roof. There was the rustle of leaves in the wind, too.

title: Ask Directions? Not When His Car's Got All the Answers.
description: ONE of the enduring mysteries of 20th-century society is why men refuse to stop at gas stations to ask directions, choosing to drive on and on, becoming more and more lost, as women in the car grow madder and madder.

title: International Velvet
description: It's only fitting that the starring fabric of the fall collections gets to caress the biggest movie stars in India.

title: Julie Hughes, James O'Connor Jr.
description: Julie Marie Hughes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bradley James Hughes of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to James John O'Connor Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Connor of Chicago. The Rev. Otto Hentz performed the ceremony at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in New Canaan.

title: Hoping for Green in the Pink Sheets, but Seeing Red
description: THEY have names like pink-sheet stocks or penny stocks, and many investors have been drawn to them during this bull market. But the quaint names -- for various types of unlisted stocks -- can mask big dangers.

title: Cezanne Gives a Boost To Philadelphia Tourism
description: O.K., Atlanta got all the attention -- for two Olympic weeks. But for month after non-Olympic month, day in and day out, another city has been America's most surprising summer magnet for tourism: Philadelphia.

title: The Heart of Europe, in Brooklyn
Going for a Gold Medal as an Ironman
description: TODAY in Cleveland, Jim Quinn of Pleasantville will be swimming, biking and running for a gold medal in the Triathlon World Championships. There will be national television coverage and a field of 2,700 athletes from 70 countries.

title: Wresting a Life From the Grip Of Addiction
description: TALL, blond, limbs still slightly awry, he looks like the kind of classic suburban teen-ager who models loose-fit Levi's in Sears ads. He comes from Lincoln Park, a town where children start the road to college early, on the Ivy path. At 17, he describes himself as a pretty typical kid. He is also a drug addict.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer entry error, a letter to the editor on Aug. 11 from Beth Feuerstein, commenting on the need for counseling of children on medication, omitted a key word. The affected sentence should have read, ''A student who is put on medication is not done so capriciously.''

title: I'M SORRY, I WON'T APOLOGIZE
description: Deborah Tannen's article ''I'm Sorry, I Won't Apologize'' (July 21) is first-rate in its approach to current social and power relations. I think that there is a parallel question: Why do so many people all along the chain of corporate and household command find it impossible to say, ''I do not know''?

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Beata Soong And John Mueller
description: Beata Yee-Hwa Soong, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Y. Soong of New York, was married yesterday to John Philip Mueller, a son of the Rev. Fred Mueller of Willmar, Minn., and the late Lorraine Mueller. The bridegroom's father, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations in New York.

title: John Paul Barringer, 93, Envoy Who Owned a Meteorite Crater
description: John Paul Barringer, a business executive and former Foreign Service officer, died on Aug. 15 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 93.

title: In Columbus, 320 Pounds And a Huge Cloud of Dust
description: If his command of a game could ever be calculated in the way that a quarterback's can, or a running back's, or a wide receiver's, Orlando Pace would be capable of closing the 1996 Heisman Trophy polls before the arrival of sweater weather. But that is not the way the balloting treats an offensive tackle, not even the only sophomore winner of the Lombardi award as the outstanding lineman in the nation.

title: Susan Butler, John Massey 3d
description: Susan Claire Butler, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Joseph Butler of New York, was married yesterday to John Andrew Massey 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Massey Jr. of San Clemente, Calif. The Rev. Robert A. Johnson performed the ceremony at the Windham United Methodist Church in Windham, N.Y.

title: A Cordial Oasis: The Gentle Line For Shakespeare
description: On most sunny summer days, the line in front of the Joseph Papp Public Theater on Lafayette Street is long by midmorning. Just before 1 P.M., when free tickets for Shakespeare in Central Park are first handed out, the line often goes around the corner.

title: Patients Gaining More Say In Surgery
description: TWENTY years ago, Dr. Philip Allmendinger performed heart surgery on a woman in her 70's at Hartford Hospital. The operation went well, but in the recovery room the woman began bleeding massively. Dr. Allmendinger told members of the woman's family that she would die without a blood transfusion. But they were Jehovah's Witnesses, whose religious beliefs forbid the use of blood, even though they may die without it, and they refused to allow the transfusion. Dr. Allmendinger watched the woman die.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: LOVE in war, love in peace, love gone wrong and love mob-style furnish the fun this week for lovers of movies.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: IT'S A GIRL THINGHow to Stay Healthy, Safe, and In Charge.By Mavis Jukes.Illustrated by Debbie Tilley. 136 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Paper, $12. (Ages 10 to 14)

title: Vroom! Women Hit the Open Road
description: JAMIE ELVIDGE'S parents didn't like the sounds of it. ''They'd heard about Sturgis and these big, hairy tattooed guys, and here was their little girl riding in on a Japanese bike,'' she said.

title: Donna L. Jobe, Gary Muldoon
description: Donna Lynne Jobe and Gary Muldoon were married yesterday on the Erie Canal aboard the excursion boat Colonial Belle. The Rev. Lance D. Robbins, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: PRESIDENT BRACES FOR SOME DISSENT AT THE CONVENTION
description: On the eve of the Democratic National Convention, President Clinton acknowledged that ''there is some tension and it is fresh'' in his party, particularly over welfare, but he drew a sharp contrast with Republicans, whom he accused of squelching dissent at their convention in San Diego.

title: No More Room For the Odd Genius
description: To the Editor:

title: Abinanti vs. Spano
description: In what could be the most interesting local race for the State Senate, County Legislator Thomas J. Abinanti, a Democrat from Greenburgh, announced last week that he will challenge the Republican incumbent Nicholas A. Spano.

title: F.Y.I.
description: A Critter Shortage

title: Turtle Soup
description: Stick your neck out, America. The turtleneck is being served up, in many tasty variations.

title: A Cathedral Soars and Students Dance
description: I ARRIVED in Uppsala, 25 miles northwest of Stockholm, courtesy of an Iraqi refugee now teaching advanced physics at the university in that town, after hundreds of suspicious Saab and Volvo drivers had whooshed past me as I waited on the roadside for a bus.

title: They're the Bradys, but Who's the Other Guy?
description: She's the One

title: Resettled Indonesians Find Hard Life
description: ''Hopefully,'' said Mujiati, ''we can still hold out.'' But she can list the names of nearly a dozen friends who have given up and fled.

title: Election Scandal in Bosnia
description: Suspicions deepened last week that the Serbs are rigging the Bosnia elections, scheduled for Sept. 14. Carl Bildt, the Western official who is in charge of overseeing the civilian aspects of Dayton peace agreements, said he felt ''deep disquiet'' over evidence that Bosnian Serb refugees in Serbia were being asked to register to vote in cities where Muslims were in the majority before they were driven out and killed during the war. The registration figures for Brcko and Srebrenica were particularly suspect. After learning of the manipulation, the Muslim party threatened to boycott the elections if the registration process isn't changed.

title: Regional Theater as Yellow-Brick Road

To judge from reservation-only crowds on weekends, a large number of diners appreciate the subtle, sophisticated East-West hybrid-cooking style of Shigenori Fujieda. Ingredients are impeccably fresh and carefully timed; sauces, well-balanced; presentations, artistic. And in the front of the house the formally attired Masaji (Mark) Naito could not be more accommodating and thoughtful.

He wears a crown of pink feathers, and his entreaties mix with the roar of a nearby tractor on the edge of this boom town: ''Go find a good road; chase away the evil spirits,'' he calls out.

description: How some things change over the years. As a graduate student in New Haven (''A Tale of Federal Dollars at Work,'' Aug. 4) I remember being perceived as part of the problem -- Yale was New Haven's biggest employer but also had its lowest salaries, it was New Haven's biggest landowner but paid few taxes, it was New Haven's revolving door, bringing in thousands who used city services but gave little back.

description: ''I WAS BORN IN THIS CENTURY, but I belong much more to the 19th century,'' says Balthasar Klossowski, known to the world as the painter Balthus.

title: The Daleys of Chicago
description: On a rainy spring night early in May, a somber, wood-paneled reception room in the Rayburn House Office Building is decked out for a party billed as ''A Taste of Chicago.'' Balloons hang from the ceiling and a blues band is riffing in the corner. The bar is jammed. In the center of the room is a long table heaped high with platters of Vienna hot dogs, spareribs and deep-dish pizza -- indigenous Chicago cuisine. The party is being given to introduce Washington to the host city of its forthcoming Democratic convention, the first to be held there since the debacle of 1968.

title: It's Taught at Yale: No Cleavage During Speeches

And they have, to judge from modern political vernacular: battleground states, attack ads, Republican revolution.

title: Stepping Straight Out of the Front-Page Headlines
description: ON A SMALL, DARK STAGE, faintly glimpsed figures shovel coal into a red-hot foundry oven as sparks fly from a welder's torch nearby. A woman sits working at a sewing machine, her feet immersed in a sea of billowing silk.

title: Cliveden
description: To the Editor: My June 1995 visit to Cliveden, the former Astor estate west of London, was a very mixed experience. When we arrived at Cliveden at 7 P.M., later than planned, we were told quite ungraciously that our 7:30 dinner reservation in their excellent Waldo's restaurant could not be advanced to 8 or 8:30. We therefore had 30 minutes to settle into our luxurious room where we were served by a chambermaid and two young men who set a fire to cut the chill. We rushed off to an outstanding dinner at 7:45.

title: Grand Funk
description: EARLY MORNING IN A Greenwich Village apartment. Light and sound are as thick as jelly. The living room is awash in a haze of cobalt blue. A tape by Morphine roars from the speaker, and the visitor feels as if he is floating through a lava lamp. The young woman in residence -- a television producer by day, an electric-bass player by night (she recently opened for Courtney Love) -- has decorated this 1848 brownstone to look (in her words) like ''a Viennese salon on STP.'' Her design guru is Christopher Alexander, the Berkeley architectural theorist who emphasizes process over plan, color as order and feelings as an objective standard. He is the prophet of ''user design,'' believing that people who use the space should design it.

title: Russia War Dead Lie in Filth, Awaiting Claim by Their Kin
description: At the sprawling military hospital here, fruits and vegetables are tenderly stored in a vast, cool cellar for the winter.

title: All Connected
description: To the Editor: In ''Alas! We're All Connected'' (July 28), Ralph Schoenstein describes many unusual sites where cellular phones have been seen. I would like to add to that:

title: In Nigeria, Skeptics Place Faint Hopes in a '98 Vote and Civil Rule
description: Almost a year after Nigeria's military Government announced the latest plan for a transition to democracy, many civilian politicians are back on the streets organizing for national elections scheduled for 1998.

title: The Perennial Candidate
description: NO one would call Samuel D. Morell a sore loser. As a pesky perennial candidate who has run for the Council from the Upper East Side nine times in 20 years, Mr. Morell has been roundly trounced, ridiculed and just plain ignored by a political system that favors well-connected candidates over cash-strapped outsiders. After each bruising loss, Mr. Morell, an itinerant liquor salesman who is seldom without his trademark cowboy boots and BMW motorcycle, just gets up, brushes himself off and does it all over again. ''What can I say?'' he asked. ''I'm a glutton for punishment.''

Newman of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Richard Jacobs is to perform the ceremony at Lyndhurst Castle, the Gould house, in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: On Bleecker, a Different Kind of Drug War
description: FIVE Saturday nights ago, Edison Lim, the manager, watched ''in trauma'' as Bleecker Drugs' pharmacist, Gary Rosenthal, led a group of perhaps a dozen people into the store to inventory the tubes, bottles and boxes of prescription drugs, then carry them across the street to the new CVS pharmacy.

title: Cowboys Manage a Victory Without Their Missing Parts
description: Dallas Cowboys Coach Barry Switzer told his players tonight in an emphatic post-game speech that it is time for them to quit worrying about a handful of key players who will not be in uniform when the regular season opens.

title: Balkanization
description: David Albahari writes in the rich Balkan tradition of urbanity and multiculturism that stands in opposition to the region's strident, often mournful nation-building literatures. Set in his native Serbia, the short stories in WORDS ARE SOMETHING ELSE (Northwestern University, cloth, $49.95; paper, $15.95) are less about the particularities of place than about the universal riddles of language, especially the failure of words to bridge the spaces between people. Opening one tale, he warns the reader: ''What I'll describe is unknown to you; you will never learn what it is I meant to say.'' This is a daunting threat, but an exaggerated one. Sensitively translated by Ellen Elias-Bursac, most of Mr. Albahari's stories are quite accessible, as well as playful and good-natured, recalling the metafictions of Robert Coover and Mr. Albahari's countryman Danilo Kis. In the early stories of this retrospective collection, Mr. Albahari writes about a stiflingly close Jewish household in the Belgrade suburb of Zemun; as the members of the family struggle to love one another, their conflicts are sometimes comic and often absurd. In his later stories, Mr. Albahari peers into the chasms that gape between a husband and wife -- and, even more dizzyingly, between a writer and his reader. Ken Kalfus

Coaching parties were very much a part of Newport's gilded age. They were revived in 1968 and are held every three years. This year, 12 ''whips,'' as the owners and drivers are called, arrived with their coaches, teams of horses and impeccably uniformed grooms. They took daily drives around the island, ending in lunches, cocktail parties and balls at private mansions. Below, from left, the Marquis de Brantes, the president of the French Coaching Club; the Marquise de Brantes, and John M. Seabrook, president of the Coaching Club of America. Top center, coaches stop at Rosecliff, a turn-of-the-century mansion.

But this welfare reform will do nothing of the kind. It will terminate welfare benefits after five years -- throwing perhaps a million children into poverty -- while doing little to create jobs in distressed areas where work does not exist. Having revoked Federal support, the country has an obligation to find or help to create jobs.

He is marginally articulate and blissfully unaware of things like shopping malls and ''Oprah'' and rap music. He probably has a silly nickname. He is keen on golf, sailing and tennis. description: SOMETIME around 3 A.M., with crumpled Snickers wrappers and the remains of a Magic card game scattered on the small table near our ship cabin window, a pumpkin moon peeked in at us as it sprinkled light on an ebony sea.

title: Saratoga Surprise: Will's Way Captures Travers
description: Will's Way, a chestnut son of Easy Goer who did not run in any of the Triple Crown races, threw the sweepstakes for the 3-year-old championship into total confusion today when he won the 127th Travers Stakes by less than a length over Louis Quatorze.

title: Pact Could Quiet Helicopter War
description: The air war between helicopter operators and Manhattan residents appears to be on the verge of an armistice. After nearly six months of sparring, the main operators, National Helicopter and Liberty Helicopter, have drafted a tentative agreement to make their routes higher than before, mainly over water and away from most Upper West Side, Upper East Side and midtown residential areas.

title: Again, Connors Defeats Time
description: THE Jimmy Connors-Dorian Gray story continued to unfold here as the third annual Citibank champions-men's-over-35 tournament rolled into the Westchester Country Club two weeks ago. The soon-to-be 44-year-old Connors turned back the clock again to win his third consecutive Citibank tournament, defeating 38-year-old Jose-Luis Clerc on Aug. 12.

title: For Star Power, Democrats May Have Trouble Matching the G.O.P. Show
description: As they say in basketball, the Democrats have strengths, but they do not match up very well against the Republicans.

title: Out on a Limb
description: In a season of pattern upon pattern, a pair of textured stockings, in bright colors, can add just the right note of playfulness.

title: Again, Ordonez's Errors Reap Bad Consequences
description: When the Mets penciled in Rey Ordonez as their starting shortstop this spring, they knew he had liabilities. His offensive production figured to be mediocre at best, and they knew that as a rookie he would be prone to the mistakes caused by inexperience and exuberance.

title: False Memory
description: The Day Before YesterdayReconsidering America's Past, Rediscovering the Present.By Michael Elliott.320 pp. New York:Simon & Schuster. $24.

title: From 'Saturday Night Live' to Jane Austen
description: IT IS 10 O'CLOCK IN THE morning, and Douglas McGrath is still waking up. ''Any time before noon is a shock for me,'' he says genially as he contemplates the breakfast menu in the sunny dining room of the Four Seasons Hotel in Georgetown. ''Then again, I've been in a state of shock for a year.''

title: I'M SORRY, I WON'T APOLOGIZE
description: Tannen's piece on apologies -- and what they lack -- hit home with me. One of the reasons that my ex-husband is my ex is because he found it easy to say, ''I was wrong,'' but next to impossible to say, ''I'm sorry.'' The former is an intellectual acknowledgment of error, but the latter shows remorse and empathy for a fellow human being.

title: Big Voice, Big Dreams and All of 13
description: LEANN RIMES AND HER mother, Belinda, are disagreeing. About to turn 14, LeAnn, whose first album, ''Blue,'' an unabashed nod to Nashville's mournful, torch song past, has completely overtaken the country charts this summer, is forbidden from dating boys. ''We'll let you go out with friends,'' Mrs. Rimes says.

title: A Stretch of Neon Glows Again in Los Angeles
description: The dazzle of neon signs has been restored along a two-mile stretch of Wilshire Boulevard in Los Angeles, which last glittered with colored lights just before World War II. Nearly two dozen hotels, theaters and apartment buildings in the MacArthur Park neighborhood west of downtown glow again at night with restored vintage signs.

title: The Upper Hand
description: Gloves are the easy way to brighten up an all-black wardrobe. These, in patchwork, look like something by Mondrian.

title: Savile Row's Ambassador to the Court of Kings
description: NAPOLEON MAY HAVE LOST THE Battle of Waterloo to the British, but he permanently revolutionized men's fashions across the English Channel by inventing elaborate dress at court. Having destroyed the ancien regime, the Emperor had created the trappings of his new one by assigning richly braided civil uniforms to his inner circle.

title: More Smoke
description: To the Editor: It is heartening that the majority of letters on smoking were from smokers who can't take it anymore -- fascistic restrictions against smoking, that is.

title: Dr. Harold Diner, 77, Special-Care Dentist
description: Dr. Harold Diner, an expert in dental care for children with disabilities, died on Monday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 77 and lived in Astoria, Queens.

title: A Terrorist Weapon: Silence as a Menace
description: The investigation of the explosion on Trans World Airlines Flight 800 has turned up no credible claim of responsibility by any terrorist group. But that does not rule out the possibility of terrorism, experts say. For many terrorists, the goal of undermining governmental authority can be accomplished, and even enhanced, behind a cloak of anonymity.

title: Boo to Baseball
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Boomers Hit a Bump: Wrinkles
description: THE generation that smeared its face with mud at Woodstock is at it again -- only this time using jars, bottles and tubes. Yes, the 76 million Americans between ages 31 and 50 have seen the enemy, and it is their reflections in the mirror.

title: THE SEX OFFENDER NEXT DOOR
description: For 10 years I worked as a lawyer representing the rights of child abusers, rapists, torturers and killers at a maximum security hospital in New York City (''The Sex Offender Next Door,'' by Peter Davis, July 28). Most of my clients have been adjudged insane; a number of them have been released and have reintegrated into society without ill effect. Among those, the really brave ones make no bones about identifying themselves and their crimes.

title: Rachel Leon, David P. Bauder
description: Rachel Leon, the daughter of Mabel S. Leon of Schenectady, N.Y., and Raymond I. Leon of Penobscot, Me., was married yesterday to David P. Bauder, a son of Pauline C. Bauder of Darien, Conn., and the late Burton Bauder. The Rev. James Murphy of the Federation of Christian Ministry officiated at the Montauk Point Lighthouse in Montauk, L.I.

title: Susan Perlmutter, Russell Epstein
description: Susan Lynne Perlmutter, a daughter of Vivian and Jerome A. Perlmutter of Greensboro, N.C., is to be married today to Russell Andrew Martin Epstein, a son of Rhoda and Jacob J. Epstein of Jeffersonville, N.Y. Rabbi Barry Friedman is to perform the ceremony at Temple B'nai Abraham in Livingston, N.J.

title: A New CD Marvel Awaits, But the Horizon Recedes
description: YOU MAY BE UNAWARE OF IT, BUT Hollywood, in league with most of the world's major computer and consumer electronics companies, is about to make you a proposition. Sometime in the near future -- no one is exactly sure when -- you will be offered a new super CD called digital video disk, or DVD. On the disk, it is said, will be a two-hour movie, complete on one side.

title: For Investors, an Initial Public Offering of English
description: ''Any statement contained in a document incorporated or deemed to be incorporated by reference herein shall be deemed to be modified or superseded for purposes of this Prospectus to the extent that a statement contained herein or in any other subsequently filed document which also is or is deemed to be incorporated by reference herein modifies or supersedes such statement.''

title: After a Decade of Tolerance, 'Nimby' Comes to East Harlem
description: Over the past decade, as neighborhoods greeted new social services with ''not in my backyard,'' East Harlem quietly accepted a succession of soup kitchens, methadone clinics and homeless shelters. ''There's no denying that these facilities serve our brothers, friends and cousins,'' said Councilman Adam Clayton Powell 4th, who represents the neighborhood.

title: A City in Need Of the Extraordinary
description: To the Editor:

title: New Small Satellite to Study Auroras' Mysteries
description: A satellite launched last week will monitor the aurora, the undulating curtains of light in the polar night sky, in an effort to explain its mysteries.

title: Rebecca Markus, William McIntosh
description: Rebecca May Markus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Markus of South Natick, Mass., was married last evening to William Douglas McIntosh, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald McIntosh of Toronto. The Rev. Brian Bostwick, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Advent in Boston.

title: Jessica Nedd, Quincy B. Troupe 3d
description: Jessica Elaine Nedd, a daughter of Jean L. Nedd of New York, is to be married this evening in Brooklyn to Quincy Brandon Troupe 3d, a son of Fanita Jones of Salt Lake City and Mr. Troupe of La Jolla, Calif. The Rev. Herbert Daughtry, a Baptist minister, is to perform the ceremony at the Akwaaba Mansion, an inn.

title: Alison R. Gerry, Kevin J. Rodney
description: Alison Russell Gerry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elbridge Thomas Gerry Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., was married there yesterday to Kevin James Rodney, a son of Sharon Rodney of Norwalk, Conn., and Dennis Rodney of Danbury, Conn. The Rev. Jeffrey Krantz performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Church.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, the ''On the Map'' article last Sunday, about a silhouette atop a Secaucus house known to residents as ''The Man on the Roof,'' misidentified the county for Secaucus. It is Hudson, not Bergen.

title: Koren's Realism
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan's Lifetime Jobs: Foreigners Qualify, Too
description: IN a quiet change of culture, more Japanese companies have been extending to their foreign workers the special status of lifetime employment, which for the most part had been the exclusive right of Japanese-born employees for at least 30 years.

title: Landscapes That Call for Saving Nature
description: THE pictures at the Katonah Museum of Art here are of or about landscape and as such they promise nothing but pleasure. Still, this is no time to relax for, buried in the show, which is organized by the museum's director, George King, is a message that can neither be ignored nor acted upon. The warning is in the title, ''Changing Horizons: Landscape on the Eve of the Millennium.''

title: Ghouls at Play
description: Cheery Christmas carolers sing outside the walls of a decaying mansion. Above them on the roof, the Addamses are about to pour steaming liquid on their heads. And so begins Barry Sonnenfeld's lavish and funny film, THE ADDAMS FAMILY (1991), based on the Charles Addams characters. Morticia (Anjelica Huston is a scene-stealing delight) and Gomez (Raul Julia, above with Ms. Huston) adore each other and dote on their demonic children. The think plot revolves around the return of Uncle Fester (Christopher Lloyd) and a scheme to defraud the family of money and their estate, leaving them temporarily housed in a motel where Gomez becomes addicted to ''Gilligan's Island'' reruns - SUNDAY at 9 P.M. on NBC.

title: Teen Drug Use Is Up
description: Clinton Administration officials disclosed that American teen-agers' use of illegal drugs -- mainly marijuana -- had more than doubled between 1992 and 1995. The survey, released by the Department of Health and Human Services, found that 10.9 percent of the 12- to 17-year-olds surveyed had used drugs in the month before the survey. That figure is below the peak of the late 1970's, but up from the 10-year low in 1992.

title: Honey, What's Your Name Again?
description: My friend is in the throes of terminal word-grope. Always a fluent conversationalist, she is stalled midsentence, frustration mottling her face like a heat rash. ''Damn it, it's on the tip of my tongue,'' she says, fuming. ''What's the word for bringing contradictory things together?''

title: Democrats to Borrow (and Add to) a Page
description: Make no mistake. Democratic officials here say they have not scripted their convention for prime-time television the way the Republicans did theirs. No indeed. Nope.

title: The Perils of Consulting
description: To the Editor:

title: Russians Mix and Match for World Cup
description: Sergei Nemchinov had ice bags strapped to his 32-year-old body and a big smile spread across his mature, veteran face.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Congressman Sees Hunger On Rare Tour In North Korea
description: An American Congressman who ended a four-day trip to North Korea today said that North Koreans were in desperate need of food and that the Communist Government had asked the United States for more aid.

title: An Angel-Crested Mystery Solved
description: DESIGNED by Louis Sullivan in 1897, the Bayard Building, at 65 Bleecker Street, has always been a destination address for architectural pilgrims. Now the soaring lines and angel-topped facade of the 12-story structure at Crosby Street, completed in 1899, are about to get a new kind of restoration treatment -- one that may attract even more of the faithful.

title: Reeves Tries A Little Tenderness
description: Usually, when Giants Coach Dan Reeves speaks to the team at the end of a game, players stand at their lockers and listen. But drastic times call for drastic action. So after the Giants had their doors blown off by the Carolina Panthers on Friday night in their final exhibition game, Reeves did something a little different.

title: Paterno Brings Young Team and Questions to Kickoff Classic
description: The full house at Giants Stadium, plus a parking lot jammed with all those buses coming from the west, will make everything about the 14th Kickoff Classic appear to have the look and feel of a big game.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Simmering Residents Meet Barbecue Spot's Owners
description: After two years of escalating ill feeling, more than a dozen residents of West 72d Street had their first face-off last week with the owners of Dallas BBQ Restaurant.

title: In This Garden, Hardy Cyclamens Are the Muses
description: Nancy Goodwin saw her first hardy cyclamen in Surrey, England, more than 20 years ago.

title: Advisers See Bright Side To Criticism of First Lady
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton returns to her hometown of Chicago for the Democratic National Convention this weekend as, by every available index, the most controversial, unpopular First Lady in modern American history. No one in the White House argues that is a good thing. But as it turns out, they have come to think that it may not be such a bad thing, either.

title: And May You Always Hit the Fairway
description: To the Editor:

title: The Spoilers Take Their Marks
description: In the interregnum between the Republican National Convention, which ended 10 days ago, and the Democratic National Convention, which begins tomorrow, two other candidates -- Ross Perot and Ralph Nader -- have managed to get themselves nominated on third party tickets. And while neither has much chance of winning the White House, both have some potential to be spoilers.

title: Insider's Peek For Outsiders
description: Normally, uniformed guards shoo away sightseers who arrive to view many of the finest of downtown's banking halls and office lobbies -- interiors reserved for millionaire clients or their minions: men and women with bona fide commercial missions.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Travel Watch column on page 21 of the Travel section today misstates the exchange rate of a year ago for the Greek drachma. It was 212.85 to the dollar.

title: An Angry Kafelnikov Withdraws From Open
description: He could have been a contender. But yesterday fourth-ranked Yevgeny Kafelnikov, infuriated by his demotion to the No. 7 slot in this year's subjective and controversial United States Open seeding process, hopped the first plane back to Russia as a gesture of protest.

title: When Danbury Shackled the Still River
description: A VISITOR driving through Danbury on the way to an exhibition entitled ''A River Runs Through It'' looks in vain throughout the city for a body of water.

title: The Wheels of Justice
description: There he was, one recent morning, in line at the takeout counter of a Brooklyn Heights deli waiting for his decaf and a bagel dusted with a heart-healthy spread, just like the rest of us. He carried an unmarked helmet under his arm and he was encased in spandex: the new, low-fat, user-friendly aerobocop.

title: Queen of the Muckrakers
description: Jessica Mitford Romilly TrEUhaft, known as Decca, who died last month, was among the handful of great muckraking journalists of our time. Peter Sussman of the Society of Professional Journalists puts her in a class with Upton Sinclair, Rachel Carson and Ralph Nader. ''Only funny.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Jacqueline Cabrera and Edgar Cordero
description: Jacqueline Cabrera, a daughter of Hilda and Bienvenido Cabrera of Brooklyn, is to be married today to Edgar Cordero, a son of Carmen Cordero of Brooklyn and the late Julio Cordero. The Rev. John C. Tosi is to perform the ceremony at St. James Roman Catholic Cathedral in Brooklyn.

title: Stationery Speaks Louder Than Words
description: THIS is about Freddie the Frog, who is alive and well, and a dog that is dead, and engravers' dies, which are somewhere in between. We are talking stationery here. Very expensive stationery -- engraved by hand, with tissue-paper-lined envelopes that keep prying eyes from reading the perfectly formed prose inside.

title: The Whitewater Sentences
description: Two of the defendants found guilty in the Whitewater case, James B. McDougal and former Gov. Jim Guy Tucker of Arkansas, escaped harsh sentences last week, while a third, Susan McDougal, did not.

title: St. Petersburg
description: To the Editor: Florence Fabricant's article that discussed the ''steep price'' of meals in St. Petersburg (Choice Tables, July 28) did not mention a factor I encountered on a recent trip that added to the high cost of dining. As she noted, prices are usually quoted in dollars but payment has to be made in rubles. However, at two restaurants, their conversion to rubles added 15 to 20 percent to the bill compared with the exchange rate quoted at the nearby Astoria Hotel.

title: When Opposing Abortion Is Part of a Larger 'Ethic of Life'
description: To the Editor:

description: IN DEFENSE OF MARION

title: Labor Day Festivities at Summer's End
description: WHILE not as much hoopla goes into bidding summer goodbye as in welcoming in the season, there are some special Labor Day activities that pay proper homage to the changing calendar.

title: Virginia Thomas And Hans Wydler
description: Virginia Harruff Thomas, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Harruff Thomas of Shaker Heights, Ohio, was married yesterday to Hans Laurence Wydler, a son of Susan Hart Wydler of New York and the late Hans U. Wydler. The Rev. Rodney V. Rice, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Country Club in Pepper Pike, Ohio.

title: Tempest in a Soda Truck
description: Venezuela used to be Pepsi country, but that changed abruptly when Coca-Cola made a deal with a big Venezuelan bottler. This truck was repainted with the Coke logo last week while still full of Pepsi.

title: Now Seat Belts Have Come to the Seats
description: THE Chrysler Sebring convertible is the first regular-production car built in North America to have integrated front seat belts. The system eliminates the need to anchor the shoulder belts to a pillar between the front and rear windows, instead containing the entire belt apparatus within the seat.

title: Candidate Wants Gingrich Report Released
description: Charlotte Koskoff, the Democratic challenger to Representative Nancy L. Johnson of Connecticut, demanded on Friday that Mrs. Johnson, a Republican who heads the House ethics committee, make public a special counsel's report on charges against Speaker Newt Gingrich.

title: Madison Sayles, Advertising Executive, 91
description: Madison Sayles, a founder in the 1930's of the National Advertising Service, a company that placed advertising for private businesses in college newspapers and magazines, died on Aug. 9 at his home in Norwalk, Conn. He was 91.

title: Chicago Prepares and Promises No Repeat of 1968
description: As part of their training to keep the streets calm and the ghosts in the graveyard, 2,500 local police officers recently prepared for the Democratic National Convention here by sitting in the dark. In groups of 50, they watched a documentary of the bloody clashes between the police and antiwar demonstrators in 1968, the last time the Democrats had the courage to hold a convention in the Windy City.

title: Where There's Smoke, There's Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: Rebecca Sumner, Christopher Lien
description: Rebecca Sharon Sumner, a daughter of Carol and Charles Sumner of Livingston, N.J., was married last evening to Christopher Adam Lien, the son of Claire Le Vine and Andrew Lien of San Carlos, Calif. Cantor Ellen Dreskin performed the ceremony in the Pegasus Suite at the Rainbow Room in New York.

title: How Much Is Too Much in Retail-Rich Paramus?
description: A HUNDRED new retail outlets have opened or will soon open at the expanded Garden State Plaza in Paramus, which at 2 million square feet is among the largest malls on the East Coast.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption today on page 18 of Fashions of The Times, part 2 of The Times Magazine, omits the name of the manufacturer of the turtleneck sweaters shown on the cover. They are from Banana Republic.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-23

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 14 about the decline of footnotes in books mispelled an editor's surname and misstated her title at the Harvard University Press. And the errors were repeated last Sunday in a brief report in The Week in Review. The editor is Jennifer Snodgrass, not Snodgress. She is managing editor, not managing director.

title: Steps (Squeak!) to Silence Floors
description: A HARDWOOD floor is a thing of beauty and a joy forever -- at least until it squeaks when you walk across it. Newly installed floors don't squeak much, because the boards are tight; but they can become noisy as the floor ages.

description: Bound and Gagged

title: Giuliana Dunham, Gerhard J. Mulder
description: Giuliana Hope Dunham, the daughter of Ida and Royal Dunham of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday to Gerhard Jakob Mulder, the son of Gerrit Mulder of Groningen, the Netherlands. Judge Sterling Johnson Jr. of Federal District Court in Brooklyn officiated at the Lyman Estate in Waltham, Mass.

title: Fleeting Moments Behind The Scrim
description: LINCOLN CENTER FESTIVAL '96 EVENTUALLY wound down two weeks ago, but not before it treated its audiences to a broad range of cultural events from around the world. Variety held sway, and traditional borders fell everywhere. Dance collaborated with jazz, gospel and soul sang together, puppets swam, and a new opera was unveiled while centuries-old traditional Japanese performers appeared down the street. Audiences saw a great deal, but what they didn't see were the behind-the-scenes moments -- the moments of preparation, trauma, boredom and triumph that occurred backstage. Here are some of the images they missed.

title: Tipper Gore And the Photo Op
description: ''THE last time I saw you,'' Wendy Wasserstein was saying to Tipper Gore before a large audience at the the 92d Street Y, ''you gave me a batch of your fat-free chocolate chip cookies.''

title: Style Meets Substance; Statecraft Acquires Stagecraft
description: SOME advice from last week's hairdresser to this week's, whoever it turns out to be:

title: Lebed Steps Into Chechnya
description: A week ago the Russian Army, humiliated by its Chechen foes, was plotting revenge. By midweek the acting commander of federal forces in Chechnya issued an ultimatum to the 300,000 civilians who remained in Grozny, the ravaged capital of the secessionist republic: Get out within 48 hours or ''I will use all means at my command'' to destroy the separatists who have taken control of the city.

title: You Hate When They Call, but Their Stocks Look Good
description: THE phone call always seems to come just as you are sitting down to dinner or turning on your favorite TV show. A relentlessly cheery voice interrupts your evening to doggedly hawk a new credit card, a long-distance carrier or, say, T-bone steaks delivered right to your door.

title: Leather Lungs Return From Their Vacations
description: THIS is not one of those scientific exit polls that can detect a presidential election result by 6:02 A.M. in some remote corner of Maine. This is merely my gut feeling, based on vicarious observation of the people filing into Giants Stadium Friday night to watch the ghastly 34-7 defeat to Carolina.

title: Yankees Survive A Nervous Ninth
description: Joe Torre did not have Mariano Rivera available. Is it any wonder, then, that the Yankee manager had to sweat this one out?

description: NIGHT TRAIN BLUES

title: Christine Power, Jonathan Needell
description: Christine M. Power, the daughter of Patricia M. Power of Old Westbury, L.I., and the late Paul Power Jr., was married yesterday to Jonathan Andrew Needell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin F. Needell of Bedford, N.Y. Msgr. Thomas Hartman performed the ceremony at the Carlyle in New York.

title: Silence Seen As Weapon For Terrorists
description: Seven hours after Trans World Airlines Flight 800 exploded off the coast of Long Island, a television station in Tampa, Fla., received a phone call from a man who said he represented a ''jihad'' group. He claimed responsibility for the downing of the Boeing 747 and said more attacks were imminent.

title: Drowning Out the Splash of the Paddle
description: THE sun was just rising over the hills behind Lambertville last Sunday morning as George Grother, a wiry 52-year-old, trudged out of the Delaware River hoisting his sleek red 27-foot rowing shell on his shoulders. A few rowers remained on the river, but the early-morning calm was about to end like a church service with a thumping organ postlude.

title: 3 Comedy Series Are Making Debuts With Familiar Faces in New Places

The findings suggest that people would be more willing to juggle their schedules and that the extra money could help finance more mass transit rather than more highways, said Jon Orcutt, associate director of the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, which had been trying to obtain the report for more than a year.
