title: That's Entertainment?
description: As a peep show, RED LIGHT: Inside the Sex Industry (Powerhouse Books, 635 East Ninth Street, New York, N.Y. 10009, $39.95) is eminently satisfying, a lurid glimpse into the lives of the strippers, adult-film stars, phone-sex operators, dominatrixes and prostitutes who make up the sex industry. (Think there's nothing in the realm of sexual preference that can shock anymore? Meet Marion, the vampire dominatrix who draws blood from her clients.) The photographs by Sylvia Plachy, the staff photographer at The Village Voice, depict the brutal banality of the most transgressive behavior; a series about a middle-aged man who pays a woman to wrap him in plastic and then mummify him in concrete -- all within the confines of a crummy East Village walk-up -- is particularly disturbing. When James Ridgeway, the Washington correspondent for The Voice, details a prostitute's relationship with her boyfriend or a go-go girl's worries about her cellulite, they are revealed as the vulnerable, sometimes sad, sometimes funny people they are. But when he crawls under the covers with that strangest of bedfellows, politics, he gets into trouble. Painfully politically correct, he argues that the sex industry is valuable to our society because it serves as a ''safety valve for a repressed and confused patriarchal culture'' that ''preserves, rather than threatens, the mainstream social order.'' Fair enough. But then his argument gets muddled. Is the sex industry the ultimate expression of a woman's control over her body, or is it yet another institution that affords men the opportunity to victimize them? He's never quite sure, but he seems determined to demonstrate it's one or the other. And occasionally Mr. Ridgeway goes completely off the deep end. At one point he argues that the reason single motherhood is so threatening to ''the family values crowd'' is that it ''represents a woman's right not only to have sex, but also to raise children, outside of the sanctified realm of the male-dominated family.'' Somehow, one suspects that children without fathers are not reveling in their freedom from patriarchy quite as much as Mr. Ridgeway would like to believe. Judith Newman

description: IN the five years since Yonkers passed a local landmarks ordinance, two neighborhoods have been designated historic districts and four structures have received landmark status. Now, says Lee Ellman, the city's planning director, the Lawrence Park West neighborhood could well be next.

title: Chris Davies and Thomas Fantry
description: Chris Lide Davies, the daughter of Niles Meriwether Davies Jr. and Janet Mandel Davies of Congers, N.Y., was married at her parents' house yesterday to Thomas Michael Fantry, a son of Patricia O'Gorman of Mesa, Ariz., and Edmund Fantry 2d of Manahawkin, N.J. The Rev. William Kalajian, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Parisians Adopt Tough Street
description: As soon as the blankets hit the sidewalk on Montauk Avenue, Emma Speaks starts worrying about those who might prey on the Europeans playing with her children.

title: Herbert Cornuelle, 76, Dies; Youngest Dole Co. President
description: Herbert C. Cornuelle, a business and community leader in Hawaii and the youngest man to become president of the Dole Company, died at his home in Honolulu on Tuesday of abdominal cancer. He was 76 years old.

title: Rummaging in the City's Attic
description: LUCKY LUCIANO'S mug shots are there. So are front and side views of the rest of the old Murder Inc. crime syndicate. Calling cards from Victorian-era call girls promise ''the French treatment'' at an address on Chrystie Street. A yellowed parchment from 1718 is an invoice from New York City's official ''Publick Wipper,'' for his salary of 3 pounds, 15 shillings in exchange for flogging miscreants.

title: Larger Than Life
description: THE WALLS OF JERICHO

title: Teen-Age Teamwork on the Laugh Circuit
description: LYNNE COLATRELLA and Mark McEvoy sit behind a table facing the stage at the Dressing Room Theater in Stamford on a Saturday afternoon. In front of them, 11 young men and women, aged 13 to 17, are rehearsing a scene from an upcoming improvisational comedy show.

title: THE TOP 20
description: THE 1996 PRESEASON RANKING was prepared by Malcolm Moran, who until recently bleieved that the chances of any school winning three consecutive national championships were about the same as the possibility of seeing Nebraska Coach Tom Osborne do the macarena on Bourbon Street with the ex-Husker Lawrence Phillips. But the notion of the unthinkable is subject to revision; tied scores will be settled in overtime, the Southwest Conference no longer exists, the inaugural Haka Bowl will be played in New Zealand and Northwestern is trying to get back to get back to the Rose Bowl.

title: They're the Bradys, but Who's the Other Guy?
description: Girls Town

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Advocates Say Cutbacks Threaten State's Help for the Blind
description: It has been 12 years since Carol Castellano of Madison met the teachers from New Jersey's Commission for the Blind, the first of many.

title: Helen Hiebert and Ted Katauskas
description: HELEN HIEBERT and Ted Katauskas live in a cooperative house in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, where everything from the temperature of each room to the dinner menu is a group decision. There are about 10 such houses in the borough, ranging from the T. S. Eliot House to the Big House, where Mr. Katauskas lived before moving in with Ms. Hiebert a few weeks ago.

title: The Best Philanthropy
description: To the Editor:

title: Conveyor Caution
description: To the Editor: My wife and I recently returned from a trip to the Canadian Rockies and the Calgary Stampede.

title: Prof Talk
description: THE NEW YORK University physicist Alan D. Sokal pulled off the academic caper of the year last spring when he published gibberish in the highly regarded academic journal Social Text. The problem for the editors of Social Text was that they had no idea Sokal's paper was nonsense. Sokal's parody of how academics write suggested that some scholars use language so obscure that their words are difficult even for them to comprehend.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Life of the Law

title: A Ringing Defense Of Summer Camp
description: STOP!!! A word must be written in reaction to David Bouchier's ''Rise and Fall of Summer Camp'' (July 21). Either Mr. Bouchier had one awfully terrible camping experience himself when he was a youngster or he even now, could in fact, use a good camping experience to help him with the very things he seems to attack, such as learning not to draw generalizations from preconceived, (and without a doubt), self-conceived conclusions! His misplaced, sarcastic pen was simply out to do harm to an industry that does far, far more good for children than anyone would ever imagine from the writer's words.

title: In Lambertville, Getting Up Early to Explore the Art of Farming
description: Michael S. Rassweiler owns and operates North Slope Farms in Lambertville. His wife, Julia M. Ritter, teaches modern dance and choreography and helps him when she can. They believe that art and food are inexorably intertwined, and that people should think about the production of food as art.

title: Overhaul of Welfare Prompts Uncertainties
description: THE Federal Government's radical reorganization of the welfare system as it has existed for the last 60 years has left local advocates for the poor uncertain and fearful about the potential impact on the county.

title: What's the Catch?
description: The fishing life, for better or worse, is not what it used to be.

title: Margaret Davis, Trevor Nelson
description: Margaret Ward Davis, a daughter of Carolee C. Young of Friday Harbor, Wash., and Robert G. Davis of Portland, Ore., was married yesterday to Trevor C. Nelson, the son of Suzanne K. Colt of New York and John H. Nelson of Manchester, Mass. The Rev. Marianne Wells Borg performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: Paris Boots Its Protesters
description: Illegal immigrants from Africa who occupied two Paris churches over the last five months demanding the right to stay in France legally finally found out Friday that tough new immigration laws gave them no such right.

title: Stalin Lives On in the Concert Hall, but Why?
description: ONE OF VLADIMIR NABOKOV'S truly immortal passages lies buried in one of his least-known books, his critical study of Gogol. In a dozen pages of pure hilarious poetry, inventing one unforgettably ludicrous image after another, he impresses on his non-Russian-speaking readers the amazing range of nuances the Russian language makes available in one fabulous word: poshlust (pronounced PAW-shlust; it's hardly posh).

title: The Hebron Hurdle
description: IT IS LATE AFTERNOON AND SHLOMIT BAR-KOKHBA AND BATYAH COHEN, TWO JEWISH WOMEN IN long skirts, sandals and floppy hats worn not for style but religious modesty, wheel children in strollers through the near-empty alleys of the casbah, Hebron's Arab market. They aren't supposed to be here: the Israeli Army, trying to protect the 450 settlers who live among 100,000 Arabs, forbids Jews from entering the casbah. Just recently, a 72-year-old Jewish man was stabbed and badly wounded there. But settlers insist that the more fearlessness they project, the less inclined Arabs will be to attack them. Either rule or be ruled, they say; the Middle East tolerates no other option. And so the two women try to stroll the casbah's canvas-covered passages every afternoon, slipping through side streets not guarded by soldiers.

title: Artist Makes Life's Work of Silhouettes, Cutting Profiles and Creating Nostalgia
description: THEIR profiles say, ''Draw me,'' and Sally Newcomb obliges, capturing cowlicks and curls in her winsome silhouettes. Mothers ''ooh and aah'' and remark on her talent. ''It's 40 years of hard work,'' Ms. Newcomb insisted, cheerfully cutting copies for the grandparents. ''It isn't a gift!''

title: V.A.T. Refunds Land in New York
description: For many Americans returning home from Europe, getting V.A.T. refunds means waiting on long lines at airport refund windows before the flight home. Now refunds can be obtained after the flight at Kennedy International in New York, though visitors still must get the refund vouchers validated at customs in the respective country before departing.

title: Q. and A.
description: Rescinding Porn-Video Shop Lease

title: Home Away From Home in South Africa
description: IN THE SPRING OF 1993, A YEAR OF transition and turmoil in South Africa, Louis Gossett Jr. was in that country to make the movie ''A Good Man in Africa.'' On April 10, the American actor, who is a strong supporter of the African National Congress and who had met and socialized with many of its central figures, was shocked and saddened when Chris Hani, one of the most charismatic leaders of the antiapartheid movement, was assassinated.

title: In a Subway Station, an Elevator Goes Upbeat
description: Two years ago, the three elevators at the northern end of the 181st Street station of the A train were ''dirty and dreary, with gunk stuck to the floor,'' Bruce Renfroe said.

title: Politics Goes to Movies
description: To the Editor:

title: St. Petersburg
description: To the Editor: Having returned from St. Petersburg, Russia, last month I was very interested in Florence Fabricant's article. She was completely correct about hotel dining. I was on an all-inclusive tour so almost all my meals were in the hotel dining rooms. Mashed potatoes soaked in butter, hard cheeses and salami with pearl-sized pieces of fat in it were standard fare.

title: As Dumpsters Replace Squatters, Uneasy Calm on 13th St.
description: Joe Lowndes glowered as he stood last week under a gleaming white sign attached to a row of abandoned buildings that announced the construction of ''Affordable Housing for New Yorkers'' in black letters next to a picture of a New York Big Apple.

title: The Season in Proportion
description: Unlike Eddie Murphy's Professor Klump in the remake of ''The Nutty Professor,'' fashion designers do not possess a secret potion to reformulate the human body. By manipulating lines, planes and space, however, they can make a short leg look long, a thick waist appear slim.

title: Images of Spiritual Power From Everyday Life
description: ART from the South Pacific, especially from the islands north of Australia that make up Oceania, is prized for its innate power and drama. These qualities would seem to necessitate an ample exhibition space. At the Morris Museum, however, ''The Art of Oceania'' is to be found in the vestibule-like Tregenza Gallery, and on first impression the show threatens to be slight and underwhelming.

title: How Do We Look?
description: It has been said that American women feel ''tyrannized'' by fashion, though why fashion should be singled out for blame is a bit of a mystery, considering the culture we're living in. Who needs Vogue or Elle to remind us that we fall short of the current criteria for beauty when we can turn on our televisions and tune in to ''Baywatch''? Every day, we're confronted with fantasies of youthful perfection.

title: When Buildings Fall, an Engineer Becomes a Sleuth
description: IT was everyone's worst building nightmare: Without warning, a wall collapsed in a tenement apartment building at 142 West 140th Street early on a March 1995 morning, sending three residents to their deaths as floors tilted, then partially broke off.

title: The Art of the Tart
description: THE CLUNKINESS OF MOST ITALIAN PASTRY HAS long justified my disdain. Bring on the bread and pasta! No need to save fat grams for dessert.

title: Bookshelf
description: THE FAT CAT SAT ON THE MAT. Written and illustrated by Nurit Karlin. I Can Read/ HarperCollins. $14.95. (Ages 4 to 8) This is what happened on the night Wilma the witch went out, leaving her fat cat and pet rat home alone. The cat sits on the rat's mat and won't get up. The rat enlists its friend the bat, and. . . . Funny mischief for a beginning reader.

title: Perennial Favorite in a Compact Show
description: AS titles for summer exhibitions go, ''By the Sea'' is a perennial. But oceans are vast and the theme is inexhaustible. A compact show by that name is at Paesaggio Gallery in Canton, and the territory described by the 10 artists in it is by happenstance New England, along with a couple of excursions to Florida.

title: Just Do It. Then Make Payments on It.
description: Early next month, Recreational Equipment Inc., one of the nation's largest outdoor retailers, will christen its Seattle flagship store, a spiffy 98,863-square-foot structure that features a rock-climbing wall rising gloriously inside a six-story glass-and-metal spire (left). This Zeitgeisty cathedral symbolizes the fact that outdoor gear, once the stuff of moldy canvas and dingy tin, has gone way, way upscale. Here, featuring products sold by R.E.I. and other major retailers, is a ''high end'' and ''off the deep end'' look at what your money can buy.

title: Stabbing Stirs Ethnic Dispute
description: An altercation between a group of black teen-agers and a Chinese food deliveryman that ended in the death of one youth has pitted residents in a largely black neighborhood against Chinese restaurants in the area and left both sides shaken.

title: At 49, a Punk Avatar Finds New Visibility
description: IMPISH, CAMPY AND GLEEFULLY degenerate, Iggy Pop has long been both mascot and avatar to the punk rock scene. He could well have become one of its martyrs too, having by his own admission injected, inhaled or ingested 14 different illegal drugs. All of which had kept him safely outside mainstream popular culture. That is, until now.

title: Alison Roede And Peter Howell
description: Alison Roede, a daughter of Charlotte and John Roede of Newtown Square, Pa., was married yesterday to Peter Lewis Howell, a son of Barbara Lewis Howell of Vineyard Haven, Mass., and the late William J. Howell. The Rev. James Martin, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Wharton-Sinkler estate in Philadelphia.

title: Adding a Global Touch to Salmon
description: ONE of the traditional dishes of summer used to be cold poached salmon with cucumbers and green sauce. Now American chefs are making all sorts of unusual dishes using salmon. ''Salmon is lightning-fast food,'' said James O'Shea, owner of the West Street Grill and Grappa Restaurant in Litchfield, Conn. ''There are literally dozens of recipes that take less than 15 minutes to prepare, and the seasonings are truly global: ginger, soy and curry vinaigrettes, preserved lemons, cilantro, wilted greens, pesto, olives, lentils, red wine, black beans.''

title: Helsinki's Island Playgrounds
description: TO go to Helsinki and not visit its archipelago would be like coming to New York and missing Central Park. Helsinki's islands are its history, its playground -- and its fortress.

title: Dole Praises Clinton Plan On Smoking By the Young
description: Bob Dole today praised President Clinton for issuing regulations cracking down on teen-age smoking. But Mr. Dole, whose remarks about tobacco have kept him on the defensive, stopped short of endorsing the new regulations. ''I am pleased that President Clinton has finally recognized the dangers of teen smoking,'' Mr. Dole said.

title: Donald Sultan Show Delivers a Substantial Impact
description: Donald Sultan

title: Melissa D. Hecht, Douglas R. Ellin
description: Melissa Dana Hecht, the daughter of Anita and Don Hecht of Beverly Hills, Calif., was married there yesterday evening to Douglas Reed Ellin, a son of June and Marvin Ellin of New York. Rabbi Meyer Heller performed the ceremony at the Regent Beverly Wilshire hotel.

title: NEXT TARGET: NICOTINE
description: You bet Kessler's out to infantilize the American people. This doctor, lawyer and Indian chief clearly thinks he knows what's best for us ''babies.'' Call it an occupational hazard of pediatricians.

title: The Power of the Purse
description: For the backpack and shoulder-bag crowd, it's a whole new thrill: the ladylike handbag -- in lizard patterns -- that opens and closes with a click!

title: Whitman and Kemp, Morphing for the G.O.P.
description: It wasn't difficult to tell Governor Whitman from the 13 other Republican governors who stepped onto a large podium at the Beverly Hills Hotel in Los Angeles recently. She was, after all, the one in the pastel suit.

title: Tobacco Takes a Beating
description: Flanked by teen-agers, President Clinton unveiled new Food and Drug Administration rules Friday that would regulate nicotine as a drug and restrict tobacco sales and advertising aimed at minors. The regulations marked a big change in politics.

title: Despite Shifts, Malls Are Thriving
description: TO shoppers like Eleanor Strothers, Macy's department store here is somewhat of an endangered species -- ''one of the few old-time institutions of its kind left,'' she said last week, combing the aisles in housewares.

title: Briefings and Banquets: The 'Crash' Hotel Copes
description: A FEW weeks ago, a Long Island company rented a banquet room at the Smithtown Sheraton for a pep rally designed to work its employees into a profit-making frenzy. In an adjacent room, the investigators of the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 were holding a news briefing that focused on the somber task of recovering the bodies of the victims.

title: The Last Seduction
description: BELLE DU SEIGNEURBy Albert Cohen.Translated by David Coward.974 pp. New York:Viking. $34.95.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Off Vancouver, a Snug Wilderness Retreat
description: THE first time my husband, Don, and I visited the rugged west coast of Vancouver Island was in 1974, on our honeymoon. We arrived in Victoria on a rainy December evening, checked into our hotel, then stopped at the bar for a drink. As we looked over a map of the island, a thoroughly inebriated lumberjack introduced himself. ''The best place to go,'' he slurred, ''is Vancouver Island's wild west coast.'' He then sketched out an entire itinerary for us. It was the best travel advice we ever received.

title: WELFARE CLIENTS OUTNUMBER JOBS THEY MIGHT FILL
description: It will be virtually impossible for New York City and State to move hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers from public assistance into full-time jobs over the next few years, as the new Federal law overhauling welfare intends, according to many economists and job-training experts.

title: Just 36 Holes Lie Between Woods and the History Books
description: Tiger Woods stands on the precipice now, right where he likes it, in the rarefied air that surrounds great pressure and great achievement. He is one match-play victory away from his third straight United States Amateur title, 36 holes from another unprecedented exploit on a career road that has been paved with them.

title: On a Late-Summer Quest for Atlantic Salmon, the Best Is Saved for Last
description: Standing on the gunwales in the stern of our anchored canoe, our guide Jack Lyons announced to Joe Cullman and me that half a dozen salmon were lying just above the bottom in the clear, cold water of the Matapedia River about 60 feet away.

title: Officials Fear Damage to Indian Ruins From Fire in Colorado
description: A fire that burned almost 5,000 acres at Mesa Verde National Park near here spared the most famous Anasazi cliff dwellings, archeologists have said. But the blaze may have damaged several hundred other sites in less accessible areas.

title: Kathleen Leavitt and Michael Sutton
description: Kathleen Leavitt and Michael Sutton were married yesterday by the Rev. Joseph McShane at St. Joseph's Catholic Church in Rush, N.Y.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Candy Store Offers Sweets And Hot-Dog Vendors to Go

title: Karen Goettsche And Jeff Lubell
description: Karen Christine Goettsche, a daughter of Jacqueline R. Goettsche of Stonewall, Tex., and Wayne K. Goettsche of Houston, was married last evening to Jeffrey Mark Lubell, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David Lubell of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Rabbi James S. Glazier officiated at the Blueberry Hill Inn in Goshen, Vt.

title: Ashley B. Perry, James Kineon Jr.
description: Ashley Bryant Perry, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Henry Perry 3d of Avon, Conn., was married yesterday to James Cornell Kineon Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kineon of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Frederick J. Warnecke Jr., performed the evening ceremony at St. Paul's 1827 Episcopal Church in Otis, Mass.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Guide column last Sunday about the ''Back at the Ranch'' concert in Montauk, held last Monday, carried an outdated reference to a beneficiary of the event. The Retreat, a shelter and counseling service for victims of domestic violence, declined funds from the concert because a performer, the singer James Brown, has been accused of assaulting his wife.

title: A True Believer Who Has Won the Day
description: A onetime aide to a moderate Republican in the House of Representatives remembers when he first understood the essence of Representative Jack Kemp. It was the mid-1980's, and Mr. Kemp had once again drifted from the agenda of a meeting with his party's House leaders to lecture them on economic proposals.

title: How Young Is Too Young for C.E.O.'s?
description: A 20-SOMETHING entrepreneur walks through the door with what seems like a great idea, a knockout business plan and a winning exuberance. The youngster with the flip charts could be the next Bill Gates, who founded the Microsoft Corporation at just such a tender age. More likely, though, his business venture will ''blow up,'' as the money managers say.

title: Where There's Smoke, There's Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: Dem Bums
description: The mystique of Ebbets Field remains long after its team abandoned it to the wrecking ball. A new five-part series, THE ORIGINAL AMERICA'S TEAM: THE BROOKLYN DODGERS, returns to Ebbets Field in its final glory days. The documentary profiles Pee Wee Reese (right), the legendary shortstop; Jackie Robinson (left), first black man in the 20th-century majors; Roy Campanella, the M.V.P. catcher, and Duke Snider, the Jewel of Flatbush. The last part is an analysis of the Dodgers' move to Los Angeles and its longterm effects on sports. Reese's son, Mark, who wrote and directed the series, provides viewers access to archives, interviews, anecdotes and home movies - beginning TUESDAY at 7:30 P.M. on ESPN.

title: A Pragmatist, Detroit Mayor Quietly Builds His Influence
description: When 15 insurance executives trooped into Mayor Dennis W. Archer's conference room recently to explain why they charge twice as much here as in the suburbs, the Mayor was calm and polite, hiding his irritation with a practice that had been the subject of two years' worth of meetings.

title: Sarah Schofield And Frank Herzog
description: Sarah Hildreth Schofield, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hayden Schofield of Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Frank Wilhelm Herzog, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Werner Herzog of Marburg, Germany. The Rev. Arthur D. McAskill performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Little Compton, R.I.

title: Semi-Soul Brothers
description: It made you squirm. Bob Dole was talking about the era when many people recoiled at the thought of mingling black and white blood.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: GADGET

title: Spacious Cabin, Soaring Ceilings
description: THE magazine publishers' prize squad is tapping at the door, waving an oversized check with your name on it, so you'd better decide what to do with all those millions. Build an oceanfront pleasure palace, of course. Buy the 45-foot yacht, naturally. And get a convertible, for sure.

title: Harriet Beecher Stowe's Link to Litchfield for Sale
description: DEFENSELESS as Eliza crossing the ice, the parsonage in which her creator, Harriet Beecher Stowe, was born in 1811, is up for sale. Since no one ever applied on its behalf for designation as a historic landmark, the house has no claim to protection or funds from local, state or Federal preservation agencies.

title: Happy to Eat and Run: New Jersey's Hearty Appetite for Fast Food
description: IF YOU want to know about fast food in New Jersey, talk to Robert P. Anarumo. He regularly visits the 105 Boston Market restaurants he operates in the New York metropolitan area and is always watching the competition.

title: Winning Still Isn't Everything
description: IN college, I played on the varsity basketball team. Don't get the wrong idea, though. The college basketball program I participated in wasn't the sort you see on television. I played at Drew University in Madison, a nice school, but in terms of basketball not exactly Kentucky or Seton Hall. Drew, with only 1,200 undergraduates, is simply better known for the trees on its campus than for its athletics.

title: They're the Bradys, but Who's the Other Guy?
description: The Fan

title: India Bucks The Test Ban Treaty
description: THE Clinton Administration lost a big one this week, when India torpedoed more than two years of negotiations on a treaty that would end all nuclear testing.

title: Stacy L. Temares, Andrew M. Gellert
description: Stacy Lynn Temares, the daughter of Eleanor Temares of Briarwood, Queens, and Dr. M. Lewis Temares of Miami, was married last evening to Andrew Michael Gellert, a son of Barbara and George G. Gellert of Oradell, N.J. Rabbi Neal Borovitz performed the ceremony in the Puck Building in Manhattan.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: CAPITOL OFFENSEBy Barbara Mikulski and Marylouise Oates.Dutton, $23.95.

title: A Kitchen That's Smooth and Prompt
description: ALISON by the Beach, the keenly awaited country sibling of Alison on Dominick Street in Manhattan, opened mid-season in Sagaponack. It has been packed ever since. A Monday night could pass for a Saturday elsewhere.

title: Swimming Against the Current
description: LAST Sunday, my almost-6-year-old, Eva, said, ''I hate this city.''

title: Quality vs. Stats
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 6 Feet 2 And Still Reaching Higher
description: Don't remind the newest Olympic heroine that her next hurdle, the United States Open, is lurking on the other side of the weekend. She is basking in oblivion in the deep end of the swimming pool, and if Lindsay Davenport senses she is now expected to stake her claim to her first Grand Slam title, she will probably never come out of the water.

title: Missiles Are Called Threat to Civil Aviation
description: The discovery of PETN, a chemical found in plastic explosives, in a piece of wreckage from Trans World Airlines Flight 800 has kept alive the fearsome though remote possibility that the airliner was brought down by a surface-to-air missile.

title: Enrollments Soar, Leaving Dilapidated School Buildings Bursting at the Frayed Seams
description: As a record number of students prepare to enter the nation's schools, soaring enrollments are sharply outstripping the ability to repair dilapidated schools and build new ones, education experts say.

title: If They Want You, You May Not Want Them
description: SO what's a consumer to do: go for the guarantee or not?

title: Congressional Bills Belong on the Internet
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Duty-Free Bargain-Poor?
description: THE image is a staple of international travel: The crowd of weary, unwashed and unshaven travelers exits Customs after a long trans-Atlantic flight, pushing luggage carts filled with baggage. Dangling from the carts are plastic satchels embossed with a foreign airport's logo and holding a carton of duty-free American cigarettes, bottles of Scotch or French perfume.

title: Singer and Neighbors Grapple Over Bid to Open Gravel Mine
description: Thirteen years ago, James Taylor, the singer, bought a 106-acre dairy farm in this rural community in northwestern Connecticut. Though he paid $475,000 for the pastures and sloping fields of wildflowers that cascade to the banks of the Housatonic River, he rarely visited the place.

title: Stories or No Stories, Songs to Be Sung
description: ONCE the composer-lyricist revue was what it was. ''A Grand Night for Singing,'' a laundry list of songs by Rodgers and Hammerstein, had no story pretensions. ''Side by Side by Sondheim'' was spiced by anecdotes, but no book. Such titles as ''Red, Hot 'n' Cole'' and ''Oh Coward!'' told the story. ''Curtain Up! The Jule Styne Songbook,'' currently at the Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C., is just that.

title: Unyielding, Woods Fights Back To Third Straight Amateur Title
description: In a comeback as dramatic as any in the annals of golf, Tiger Woods roared into history today. He became the first person to win three consecutive United States Amateur championships, and he did it in a fashion befitting the sport's lore, by refusing to yield, by fighting his way back from five holes down to a victory over Steve Scott on the 38th hole at Pumpkin Ridge Golf Club.

title: Chicago: A Long Way From '68
description: ''Set up an outpost at the Democratic convention,'' the newly nominated Richard Nixon told a few of his aides in 1968.

title: The Cattaraugus Miracle -- Maybe
description: There may be a small miracle taking place in Cattaraugus County, 35 miles from Buffalo, where technicians are trying to stabilize thousands of gallons of radioactive waste by mixing it with glass. If it works, and if the Federal funding for it continues, the project could well be replicated in other parts of the country that are trying to figure out how to contain Chernobyl-like quantities of lethal nuclear material.

title: Turner Revue Is Back (Minus Tina)
description: Arms swirling, eyes flashing, hips twitching, thighs pumping -- the Ikettes were back in New York City on Friday night for the first time in two decades. Their leader, Ike Turner, had brought his Ike Turner Revue to Tramps for two nights.

title: Torre's Team Is Enduring The Dog Days of August
description: With his perpetually baggy eyes, vacant expression, craggy face and 5 o'clock shadow, Joe Torre always looks beleaguered. This condition was prevalent long before Torre began his pressure-induced job of managing the Yankees. Torre acknowledges his weary demeanor and has joked about how friends ask him why he looks so tired when he has actually completed nine hours of snoozing and feels rested.

title: New Alliance Party Has Anti-Semitic Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Woods to Turn Professional
description: There are no more amateur golf mountains for him to climb, no more records worth breaking or goals worth striving for, and so Tiger Woods has decided to take it to the next level. At a news conference on Wednesday at the Greater Milwaukee Open, Woods, 20, will announce that he has decided to turn pro.

title: Dole's Supply-Side Delusion
description: As a lifelong Republican, I watched the Republican National Convention with a dismaying sense of deja vu.

title: Yankees' Past Is More Glorious Than the Present
description: Live by the bullpen. Die by the bullpen. Joe Torre must be counting the hours until his closer, John Wetteland, comes off the disabled list.

title: Sentencing in Seoul
description: One former President of South Korea was sentenced today to death and another to 22 1/2 years in jail for a 1979 coup and the deadly suppression of dissent in Kwangju the following year. Though both men may be pardoned, the trial has helped to heal a wound at the center of society.

title: Lloyd's to Appeal a Reorganization Ruling
description: Executives of Lloyd's of London, where juggling risks has been a tradition, worked through the weekend trying to overcome the latest obstacle to their effort to resolve the organization's financial crisis..

title: No Headline
description: ''It's like the Civil War, 1968, everybody's position is unchanging.'' DON ROSE, then a spokesman for anti-war demonstrators. $(A11:2$)

title: Charity for Today
description: To the Editor:

title: The Number Of Ad Pages Does Not Make The Magazine
description: Vogue is measuring its September issue in pounds (3 pounds 14 ounces), not pages (708). US magazine has announced that its ad pages for September are up 25 percent from the issue last year. Seventeen magazine trumpeted a 9.3 percent gain for September.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Some Good News Is Seen For Cigarette Stocks

title: Kenneth R. Crispell, 79, Dean And Health Expert on Presidents
description: Dr. Kenneth R. Crispell, a former dean of the University of Virginia medical school and an authority on American Presidents' health and illnesses, died on Friday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 79.

title: Cuisine Raises Debate on Cruelty and Culture
description: There is a loud whapping in the background as May Chang explains the marketing philosophy of her bustling food store in Chinatown, whapping that mixes with a clamor of orders in Cantonese and an occasional series of thumps.

title: Orioles' Valiant Run Seems Stalled
description: When Baltimore's Brady Anderson blooped a single into right field in the bottom of the fourth inning against the California Angels yesterday, a roar reverberated around sold-out Oriole Park at Camden Yards.

title: Florio Insists He's No Candidate. Party Hopes He Means It.
description: A few New Jersey Democrats looking to challenge Gov. Christine Todd Whitman next year are courting delegates with parties and baseball tickets at the Democratic National Convention to build support for their fledgling campaigns.

title: Book Sales by Public Radio Raise Protests
description: Almost every kind of retail outlet seems to be selling books these days, and not everybody is happy about it. Especially not the independent bookstores, which are feeling the muscle of the national chains and warehouse clubs elbowing them into an increasingly smaller share of a stagnant retail book market.

title: Five Children, Five Crises: For Family Series, It's Par
description: There is a reason that television families are so big: all those children increase the possibilities for weekly traumas that can be solved in an hour.

title: Bond Wins Weekend Stakes Double
description: On the day after Will's Way won the Travers Stakes but did not decide the war for 3-year-old champion, older horses raced into the spotlight in three states today, with dramatic results.

title: U.S. Job Outlook Is Little Changed
description: The nation's job outlook this fall should be roughly the same as a year earlier, though wholesalers and retailers plan to do considerable hiring, according to a new survey.

title: Erwin Leiser, a Maker of Films About the Nazi Era, Dies at 73
description: Erwin Leiser, who was born in Berlin to Jewish parents, fled Hitler's Germany and went on to win praise for documentary film making about the Nazi era, died on Thursday in Zurich, where he had lived since 1961. He was 73.

title: Clinton, Setting Out for Chicago, Denounces G.O.P.
description: An exuberant President Clinton, beginning a four-day train trip to the Democratic National Convention, slammed the Republican Congress today and called on voters to re-elect him and send the message that ''we are on the right track in this country and we're going forward.''

title: For New York's Newcomers, Anxiety Over Welfare Law
description: In New York City, where more than half the residents are immigrants or the children of immigrants, a sense of panic and confusion has rippled from the shores of Brighton Beach to the streets of Washington Heights as the sweeping Federal welfare bill has become law, affecting millions of people, but perhaps none so immediately as the foreign-born.

title: Deal by Washington Post
description: The Washington Post Company said it had reached a definitive agreement to acquire Technews Inc., publisher of the Washington Technology newspaper. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Trying Again on Sewage
description: New Jersey's largest sewage plant might not end up sending its sludge to Ohio after all. On Aug. 15, Ohio's Environmental Protection Agency granted a permit to allow the Passaic Valley Sewerage Commission to ship 50,000 tons of sterilized sludge a year to Ohio to be used as fertilizer on farms. But after widespread public opposition, the agency rescinded the permit on Friday. Passaic Valley, which treats the waste of 1.3 million northern New Jersey residents, will have to resubmit its proposal, The Associated Press reported, and Ohio will hold new public hearings.

title: Q&A / Inder Kumar Gujral : Why India Blocks Test Ban Treaty
description: India has been widely criticized for blocking a nuclear test ban treaty that has taken more than two years to negotiate. On a visit to Singapore, Inder Kumar Gujral, the Indian foreign minister, discussed the issue with Michael Richardsonof the International Herald Tribune.

title: Shakespeare Serves Up a Savory Course of Rage
description: Now here's a tip for getting rid of unwanted party guests that Amy Vanderbilt probably never gave you: put casters on your dining room table and chairs. When it comes time to unseat your visitors, have your servants wheel them around until they're dizzy, then send them spinning into the air.

title: Assessing Tobacco Companies' Legal Exposure
description: TODAY, Wall Street analysts expect to witness an event that has been something of a rarity in recent weeks: a bounce in tobacco stocks.

title: Tax Increase? Never Mind
description: Residents of 19 of Somerset County's 21 municipalities were hit with surprise tax increases last month to make up for $7.8 million that the county calculated it would lose because of successful property tax appeals. Taxes on a $200,000 home in Montgomery Township, for example, went up about $40 a year. But after the tax bills were mailed, the county discovered that the prediction resulted from a clerical error and that only $600,000 would be lost. The next tax bills, to be sent out next week, will be adjusted downward because of the overbilling, said Warren Nevins, the county tax administrator.

title: In Poll, Ardor For President, Faults and All
description: The Democratic delegates assembling for their convention here are not satisfied with Bill Clinton's efforts to help poor and middle-class Americans. But they are delighted with him nonetheless.

title: 5-Year-Old Injures 2 Siblings
description: A 3-year-old girl and her 7-year-old brother were injured yesterday afternoon when their 5-year-old brother unintentionally pushed them out a second-story window into an alley, the police said. The girl appeared to have sustained only bruises and cuts, said Sgt. Derek Glenn, a police spokesman, while her brother suffered a broken leg. Sergeant Glenn said the children were jumping on a bed next to the window when they fell. The children's stepfather, Ronald Rosario, was charged with endangering the welfare of minors for failing to supervise them properly.

title: Gilkey, Hundley, Johnson And Zilch
description: Bernard Gilkey cocked his bat and got ready to unleash a mighty swing. The Dodger right-hander Ismael Valdes had just mailed him a belt-high pitch that Gilkey couldn't wait to crush.

title: Expert at Parks Department Has Answered 10,000 Questions
description: He calls himself Mr. Memory after the character in a Hitchcock movie, ''The 39 Steps,'' and he makes a habit of memorizing 50 new facts a day. Jonathan Kuhn is the man who will eagerly tell you more than you will ever need to know about each of the city's 1,700 monuments, not all of which depict politicians and generals. There are also, he proudly declares, a 15th-century martyr, a sled dog and two gynecologists.

title: A Final, Sweet Ovation for Mantle
description: THE sun was high in the sky, the white clouds were pillowed against the light-blue universe, the No. 4 elevated train rumbled somewhere in the distance and the fans at Yankee Stadium were nestling into the furniture. It was a beautiful day for a ball game, and for a sentimental journey. Yesterday the fans had both.

title: Toll of Pilgrims in Kashmir Storm Put at 160
description: Indian officials said today that as many as 160 Hindu pilgrims and mountain guides had died of cold and hunger in a storm in the Himalayan mountains of Kashmir, and that the toll is likely to rise as rescue teams gain a fuller picture of the disaster.

title: Let's Give Animals Respect They Deserve
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Joseph Abboud Co., New York, to J. L. Dearlove & Affiliates, Chicago, as agency of record for the account of the designer apparel maker, with billings estimated at $2 million. Those duties had been handled in- house.

title: Bridge
description: Among the thousands of high school graduates headed for universities around North America this fall, the best bridge player is probably 17-year-old Kent Mignocchi of Riverdale, the Bronx, who is enrolling at Occidental College in Los Angeles.

title: In U.S. Drug War, Battlefield Is Global
description: To the Editor:

title: Agassi Practices As Players Protest
description: Maybe if it had been a question about ice cream, about Andre Agassi's favorite flavor. Maybe if that was the promise, he would have stopped running away, because he wouldn't slow down to talk about anything tougher than soft-serve yesterday.

title: In a Scripted Show, Cuomo Won't Take Just Any Role
description: His party, the aging lion said, is going to be ''tiptoeing through troubled waters, a stone at a time'' at its national convention that opens on Monday.

title: Hazy Weather Report
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Reeves's Usual Shocker Missing From Giants' Cuts
description: Every season, Giants Coach Dan Reeves has pulled some sort of shocking move, whether it was releasing Pepper Johnson in 1993 or benching linebacker Carlton Bailey the year after that. This year, however, with the team so young, and the talent so thin, there are only so many moves Reeves can make.

title: Lucky Protesters Hit The Soapbox Jackpot
description: Connoisseurs of the right to protest at Democratic conventions in Chicago gathered this afternoon for a free-speech nicety that might have left Thomas Jefferson himself speechless: a lottery, ordered by a Federal judge, was held in the downtown library to determine the lucky few citizens who would be allowed to speak their mind and protest near the doors of the convention hall.

title: Easy Test for E-Z Pass
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-6

title: A labeling device for CD-ROM's, without the Magic Marker and with the help of Mr. Coffee.
description: IF you've bought a new computer equipped with a drive that can write on a CD-ROM as well as read one, you're in rapidly growing company. Some computer industry estimates say that millions of drives that let people record their own CD-ROM's will be sold in the next year.

title: Medvedev Captures Hamlet Cup
description: Andrei Medvedev, a last-minute wild-card entry in the Waldbaum Hamlet Cup, emerged as the winner today by beating Martin Damm, 7-5, 6-3.

title: The Designer Who Made the Mac Smile
description: Much junk food has been eaten and many caffeine-laden drinks have been consumed. The code is almost complete. Then suddenly, someone realizes that the new software program will be used by people, not programmers, and not too much thought has been given to its public face.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: After Wrack and Ruin, Tourism in California Rebounds
description: After a battering by earthquakes, urban riots and recession, California is in the midst of a tourist boom. Hotels, amusement parks and attractions from San Diego to San Francisco are racking up record numbers of visitors.

title: Police Hit Drug Suppliers, And Serious Crime Falls
description: Using an assortment of old and new tactics to eliminate the drug trade in high-crime neighborhoods, the New York City Police Department is seeing the first fruits of an ambitious drug crackdown that goes beyond the arrests of low-level dealers and targets the entire networks that supply them.

title: Peace Brings New Kinds of Work to Sarajevo Hospital
description: There are no more shells thumping down on the trauma unit at Kosevo Hospital here, and for the first time in four summers, doctors and nurses are taking vacations. Water and electricity come regularly now.

title: Differences Aside, Labor Embraces the Democrats
description: The good news for labor leaders these days is that Republicans are calling them bosses again.

title: Poland's Museum of the 90's That Mocks the 90's
description: In the darkest days of Communist rule, a Polish general fresh from training in the Soviet Union wanted to make an impression on a young architect and present her with an ideal site for her dream building.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULE
description: All times are Eastern daylight time.

title: Canon Sales Unit Names Finalists
description: MCS Canon, the sales subsidiary of Canon U.S.A. in New York, has named five finalists to compete for its business-to-business advertising account, which has been handled by Goldberg Fossa Seid in New York. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: G.O.P. Town Wonders at a Changeling
description: Nobody here is surprised that a hometown girl as bright and ambitious as young Hillary Rodham from Wisner Street would rise to prominence on the American political scene.

title: Prostituted Children
description: In Manila, there are 10-year-olds who have sex with motorcycle-taxi drivers in return for two hours' worth of fares, about $6. In Bombay, thousands of girls are held in brothels as prisoners, many in cages. By conservative estimates, a million children worldwide are forced, by parents, pimps or poverty, to sell sex. After neglecting this problem for too long, nations are beginning to treat it seriously.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BORIS YELTSIN'S favorite grandson will be traveling westward this fall, The Times of London reported. Boris Okulov, 15, will leave Russia next month to enroll at Millfield School in Somerset, England, where tuition is 15,000 pounds a year. That's $23,000, or 123 million rubles.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Three years ago, IRA GLASSER, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union, made his first trip to Russia, to attend a human rights conference. He returned over the weekend to promote a project that grew out of that meeting: a translation of the A.C.L.U.'s books on legal rights into Russian.

title: Chelios Joins U.S. Cup Team
description: Defenseman Chris Chelios of the Chicago Blackhawks joined Team USA yesterday in Providence, R.I., for its final exhibition game before the World Cup hockey tournament, a 9-2 rout of Slovakia.

title: Chessie Stays Home
description: Chessie the manatee will apparently not be making an appearance in New Jersey this summer, Federal wildlife officials say. Last year, Chessie, a 10-foot-long, 1,250-pound mammal who winters in Florida, swam farther up the East Coast than any manatee had been known to go before. But Linda Taylor, a marine mammal tracker with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, said Chessie apparently turned around at Portsmouth, Va., and headed for home.

title: Seeking a Turnaround With Souped-Up Machines and a Few New Games
description: Visitors to the Nintendo Company headquarters get a taste of the personality of its president, Hiroshi Yamauchi, the minute they walk through the door. The lobby, hallways and conference rooms are all bare walls and plain tiles. There are no video game machines, no posters, no Mario dolls, nothing to suggest that this is the lair of a company that provides entertainment to millions of children.

title: People
description: * Berny Brownstein, president of the Brownstein Group, Philadelphia, was promoted to the new position of chief executive. His son, Marc, creative director, was named president and also becomes executive creative director, a new position. Also, Errin Cecil-Smith was named to the new position of public relations director; she had held a similar position at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, Philadelphia.

title: Arthur Ashe Day Tries to Plug Holes
description: Suruj Singh wasn't used to this. Here was a 12-year-old who had played tennis dozens of times, but always with one eye on the ball and the other on the court.

title: Anxiety In the Land Of Gargoyles And Giants
description: The recent alliance between NBC and Microsoft may have got off to a shaky start, but that has not muted the anxiety much. Right now, the partners' all-news cable station (MSNBC) and Internet news service may seem like minor players in the media game, but there are fears on the part of critics that this is yet another turn of the screw, as technology companies, conglomerates and the entertainment industry spoon-feed the public ever more plentiful ''products'' and prepackaged information.

title: 300 Take Boat to Stadium
description: More than 300 baseball fans boarded the Yankee Clipper ferryboat yesterday morning as direct ferry service from Weehawken to Yankee Stadium began. Other than the outcome of the game itself (the Yankees lost to the Oakland Athletics, 6-4), officials at NY Waterway, which operates the boat, reported smooth sailing. NY Waterway, which also runs ferries from Weehawken to midtown Manhattan, plans to run the boat to the stadium only for some weekend day games. The voyage around the bottom of Manhattan and up the East River to the Bronx takes 70 to 90 minutes, depending on tides, and costs $10 for a round trip. ANDY NEWMAN

title: The Plague Years
description: The first thought of Police Officer Michael Robbins in the swirling, eerily quiet aftermath of the ambush was that he was going to die. He and his partner, Talmitch Jackson, were in their patrol car, the headlights off, in a dark alley on Chicago's South Side, and both had just been riddled with bullets. They were moaning and they were soaked in blood.

title: Simple is beautiful, especially in a place as confusing as cyberspace.
description: THE whole world, it seems, is clucking over the ferocious clash between the Netscape Communications Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation. But their rush to carve the Internet into multimedia fiefs is siphoning energy away from what should be the goal: to help users and developers exploit the unique, interactive qualities of the World Wide Web.

title: Economic Calender
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Another Russian traveling west is ANATOLY KARPOV, who will be in Finland today to play what promoters are billing as the world's first open Internet chess game. After each of Mr. Karpov's moves, players worldwide will have 10 minutes to propose countermoves; a computer will tally the proposals and execute the move receiving the most votes, The Associated Press reported.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Money and Business section on Aug. 4 about a canceled merger bid between the Warnaco Group and the Authentic Fitness Corporation mispelled the given name of a former Warnaco executive and misstated the timing of her departure. She is Mindy Grossman, not Mandy; she left two years ago, not recently.

title: Superior to Humans
description: To the Editor:

title: How City Life Seduces The Brain Into Paranoia
description: ''Glass Jungle'' is a peppy look at some of the ways the human animal has adapted to what is humorously known as civilization. How do we find our way around big cities? How do we do our supermarket shopping efficiently? Why do we have so much trouble using that video recorder?

title: Metrocards to Replace School Transit Passes
description: In an effort to save money, the Transit Authority plans to replace the subway and bus passes for schoolchildren with Metrocards, which will allow the authority to limit the number of trips the students can take each day.

title: INSIDE
description: Bid for Soul of New Machine

title: A Rational Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: F.C.C. Continues Airwave Auction
description: The Federal Communications Commission begins its biggest airwaves auction yet today, with almost 1,500 advanced wireless communications licenses on the block and most big names in telecommunications lining up to bid.

title: A Charade Continues In Front of Thousands
description: EVERY play is a riot in college football.

title: Many Rutgers Players Flunk
description: The graduation rate for men's college basketball players is rising nationwide, but at Rutgers University, it is falling. Of 28 players recruited since 1989 who are no longer on the team, only seven, or one-quarter, have graduated, The Courier-News of Bridgewater reported yesterday, down from half of the players who entered the school between 1986 and 1989. Nationally, 44 percent of Division I basketball players who entered college in 1990 graduated, up from 38 percent in 1984.

title: John Phillips, 81, A Life Photographer
description: John Phillips, a photographer for Life magazine from the 1930's to the 1950's who was known for his war photographs, died on Thursday at his home in midtown Manhattan. He was 81.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the decision by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York against inviting President Clinton or Bob Dole to the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Dinner misstated the number of terms Smith served as Governor of New York. It was four, not three; they began in 1918, 1922, 1924 and 1926.

title: Is That a Missile? Snapshot on Night of Air Crash Turns Hot
description: All things being equal, Linda Kabot says she wishes she had never taken the photograph. But she did, and what can she say? In the dusky sky that serves as a backdrop for the otherwise routine snapshot, there appears to be a cylindrical object with one end aglow.

title: Jailing Mothers Is Always Too-Harsh Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Gag Order Over Simpson Reflects Shift In Attitude
description: The recent order prohibiting participants in O. J. Simpson's civil trial from discussing the case with the media is but the latest in a series of such actions by judges trying to clamp down on pretrial publicity, say constitutional scholars, free-speech advocates and some judges.

title: Ebola Scare At Hospital Proves False
description: Mistakenly fearing that two seriously ill siblings who had recently come from Africa might have been suffering from the deadly and highly contagious Ebola virus, officials shut down North Central Bronx Hospital's emergency room for more than two hours yesterday afternoon when the children were brought there for treatment.

title: U.S. Says It Suspects China Is Helping Pakistan With Missiles
description: United States intelligence agencies strongly suspect that China is helping Pakistan build a factory for medium-range missiles, creating a new problem for efforts to control the spread of nuclear weapons, Government officials said today.

title: A Political Troubleshooter Is the President's Point Man
description: It was late 1994 when Harold M. Ickes, President Clinton's tightly wound deputy chief of staff, set out to head off a looming problem that had barely shown up on the radar screen of the other trouble-shooters in the crisis-driven, feud-riven White House.

title: Lebed Suspends Chechen Talks; Blames Kremlin
description: Saying he could not possibly bring peace to Chechnya when so many people in Moscow ''want to torpedo the process,'' Aleksandr I. Lebed, the Russian national security adviser, today abruptly canceled his most important negotiating session yet and returned home to fight new battles in the Kremlin.

title: Ex-President Is Sentenced to Death in Seoul
description: The former President Chun Doo Hwan, who ruled this nation in the 1980's, was convicted this morning of treason and was sentenced to death by a three-judge panel in a hushed moment that seemed to close a chapter of repression.

title: The Open Gets Ugly, and It Hasn't Even Started Yet
description: The United States Open, always the roughest go of the four Grand Slams, and always the Slam whose competitors rarely resist the urge to behave more like critics than mere players, has outdone itself this year.

title: Dole Promises Wider Role For Military In Drug War
description: Declaring that President Clinton had ''surrendered'' in the war on drugs, Bob Dole vowed today to broaden the use of the nation's military against the influx of drugs and said he would prepare the National Guard to ''move in'' to help the fight.

title: On All-Girls School, Equality Isn't Sole Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: French President Defends Immigration Rules
description: President Jacques Chirac pledged today to hold to France's strict immigration policies despite criticism of a police roundup of Africans protesting in a Paris church.

title: Last-Minute Starter Gets 241 Yards For Penn St.
description: Somewhere other than the Nittany Valley, most anywhere else in fact, he might have been celebrated as The Man before the ink on his letter of intent had dried on signing day. But Curtis Enis chose to go to Penn State, where things are done differently. He was a linebacker at this point a season ago, and for all Enis knew when he woke up this morning, he still might not have been a starting tailback for the Nittany Lions.

title: Supporting Cast
description: Among the speakers on this evening's program:

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Software Companies To Pick Agencies
description: Three software companies are reviewing their advertising accounts.

title: Israeli President Prods Netanyahu to Meet With Arafat
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's repeated refusal to meet with the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, came under attack from an unexpected quarter today as President Ezer Weizman announced that he would meet with Mr. Arafat if Mr. Netanyahu did not.

title: A Truck Driver Dancing With a Millionaire
description: Trying to show that it is more fun to be a Democrat, even if it means having corn on the cob instead of lobster, the party faithful have been singing and dancing and toasting one another all weekend.

title: Tangier a Magnet for Africans Slipping Into Spain
description: Some nights, Farid Ahman walks along the Moroccan shore at a place where Europe is visible from Africa and counts the days before he will reach the lighthouses winking across the water on the coast of Spain.

title: A Netscape Bid For the Souls of New Machines
description: Opening a new front in its increasingly bitter war with Microsoft, the Netscape Communications Corporation plans on Monday to announce that it has created a software company that will enter an alliance with I.B.M., Oracle and four Japanese consumer electronics giants, Netscape executives said in interviews over the weekend.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Swastika Cut in Cornfield
description: A 60-foot swastika cut into a Burlington County cornfield has been erased, but the mystery of its origin remains. The swastika in Joe Goodenough's 30-acre field was discovered last week through an aerial photograph. Mr. Goodenough cut down the immature corn around the swastika Saturday; he put the value of the lost crop at $1,000. The police were treating the incident as a bias crime but said yesterday they had little hope of catching the culprit.

title: Clinton Vows Help for Aides' Legal Bills
description: President Clinton vowed today that he would help members of his Administration pay the overwhelming legal bills stemming from the Whitewater investigations ''if it's the last thing I ever do and I stay healthy.''

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: The cover is peeled off of Minute Maid's quiet switch to the Leo Burnett Company in June.
description: IT is usually difficult for the gossipy denizens of Madison Avenue to keep a secret. But one account switch -- involving a familiar grocery brand sold by one of the world's largest marketers -- managed to stay under wraps for two months before being inadvertently disclosed late last week.

title: Convention Guides, Serious and Not
description: While 15,000 journalists kill time at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago this week, 26-year-old Scott Johnson will troll the city's bars and campuses to get the regular-guy view for his one-man World Wide Web site, Publius '96.

title: May Right Side Win in Tobacco Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Planning to Offer Bills and Notes
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to bills and notes, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Stocks Down in Japan
description: Stocks were trading lower here today. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 194.64 points -- or nine-tenths of 1 percent -- to 21,034.16. On Friday, the Nikkei index lost 134.44 points.

title: Game, Set, Set, Set, Match
description: Attention, tennis establishment! It's time to realize what the rest of the world already knows. Women can go the distance.

title: As the Democrats Gather, Gingrich Gets the Attention
description: As thousands of Democrats streamed here today for their national convention, the center of attention was not President Clinton but a politician who kept a relatively low profile at his party's convention two weeks ago: Speaker Newt Gingrich.

title: The Ghosts of Chicago
description: Only 10 miles from the gleaming arena where the Democrats are converging this weekend, a decrepit brick hulk of a building lies shuttered, empty and surrounded by tall weeds. The old International Amphitheater, hard by the stockyards on the city's South Side, was the site of the chaotic 1968 Democratic convention. Nowadays an occasional auto show or rodeo takes place there, but otherwise the place is a forgotten curiosity from another era.

title: The Applause-O-Meter Still Thrives in Politics
description: When speakers at the Republican National Convention railed at the Internal Revenue Service, the dials spun up. When the word ''Republican'' was mentioned, the dials twirled down. For much of the week, references to Bob Dole froze the dials in an electronic ho-hum.

title: Polite Reply From a Judge to Giuliani
description: JUSTICE HELEN E. FREEDMAN of State Supreme Court finds mass tort litigation intriguing, likes working weekends because the phone is silent and considers jogging in Central Park a good time. Hardly does this reserved, soft-spoken judge seem the type to engender hostility.

title: Soldiers Mourn an Army That Once Was Great
description: Col. Pyotr Litovsky's eyes were red and grim from too much dust, too much vodka and too much death.

title: 28-Year-Old Snapshots Are Still Vivid, and Still Violent
description: ''There was a very important melee over by that tree,'' recalled John Schultz, pointing through the sylvan calm of Lincoln Park.

title: Corrections
description: A map last Monday showing power grids affected by a blackout in the West misidentified two states. The state labeled Colorado was Wyoming; the one labeled Kansas was Colorado.

title: Nigeria's Nobel Laureate Traces Nation's Slide
description: THE OPEN SORE OF A CONTINENT

title: Equity and Debt Offerings Scheduled During This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Police Find Factory For Heroin in Bronx
description: Police officers responding to a report of a shooting in the north Bronx on Saturday morning instead discovered a factory for brand-name heroin inside a private house, the police said yesterday.

title: Keep Boiling the Water
description: More than 275,000 residents of Jersey City, Hoboken and Lyndhurst must still boil their tap water before drinking it, three days after a power outage at a water treatment plant in Boonton allowed untreated water to enter the water system serving them. Utility workers flushed millions of gallons of water from hydrants yesterday, hoping to get rid of the untreated water. The water may be declared safe to drink as early as this afternoon, said Rich Henning, a spokesman for United Water Company, which manages the system.

title: Baxter, His Role Shrinking, Cut by Jets
description: The retooled Jet offense underwent another major overhaul today when Brad Baxter was cut after six years at fullback. He will be replaced by Richie Anderson.

title: Would the Belly Wiggle or Shake?
description: Movie magicians have taught pigs to talk and roaches to sing. Now they are giving digital muscles to run.

title: Disputes and a Distraction At Inner-City Law Firm
description: ''This is a walk-in law office,'' says Maxey Sparks, the flashy, womanizing member of a squabbling family law firm. ''We deal with real people, people with real problems.'' Not yet they don't. So far ''Sparks,'' which has its premiere tonight on the UPN network, is dealing with the distinctly unreal problem of having Robin Givens play a high-powered graduate of Stanford Law School who has joined the law firm, but who looks and dresses as if her real ambition is to model for the ''Victoria's Secret'' catalogue.

title: The New York Film Festival's French Accent
description: The New York Film Festival, now in its 34th year, will lead off on Sept. 27 with Mike Leigh's ''Secrets and Lies,'' winner of the top prize at the Cannes Film Festival in May, and will close 16 days later with the world premiere of ''The People vs. Larry Flynt,'' Milos Forman's take on the very American story of a skin-magazine publisher who carries a First Amendment fight all the way to the Supreme Court.

title: What 1968 Means
TV's 'outsiders' say they aren't getting a fair chance to bid for reruns of hits.
description: WHETHER or not bigger is better, it is certainly convenient. As mergers have reshaped the communications world, companies are eagerly flexing programming muscle by putting their own programs on cable services they already own.

title: Champion Swimmer Is Stabbed In Moscow
description: Aleksandr Popov, the fastest swimmer in the past two Olympics with dual titles in the 50- and 100-meter races, was stabbed on a Moscow street late Saturday night, the police said yesterday.

title: Stopping The Music
description: The Democratic and Republican Presidential candidates, and their party platform-writers, all have touched on international terrorism. They come right out and say they are against it.

title: Subway Link: Both Builders And Riders Get a Bonus
description: A real life quiz: you tell a contractor, finish the job a day early and you get a $35,000 bonus. Another day early, another $35,000, and so on, up to 20 days. Beyond 20 days, all alacrity goes unrewarded.

title: All Aboard the Clinton Publicity Train
description: One television station here is losing interest in political conventions. But it devoted more than half its news this afternoon to President Clinton's train-side speech in town -- after it broadcast the entire speech live.

title: Mariners Batter Key And Yanks
description: The nifty pitching matchup was supposed to be Sterling Hitchcock against Jimmy Key. It wound up being Hitchcock against Brian Boehringer after Key was smashed in the left elbow with a harsh line drive and departed in the first inning. It wound up being a highly entertaining game, anyway.

title: 3 Artists Who Play It Their Way
description: Music isn't always easily divided between artists and crowd-pleasers; sometimes serious practitioners make statements that are both idiosyncratic and beckoning. The musicians on these three CD's aren't and probably won't become pop-radio stars, but they may appeal to a sense of beauty in even a casual listener. That is to say, you can hear them alone or with a roomful of friends.

title: Agreement Ends 2-Month Strike At Hospitals and Nursing Homes
description: Negotiators for about 6,000 workers and 13 New York City hospitals and nursing homes have reached a tentative agreement on wages and benefits, apparently ending a two-month strike on terms that management and labor both embraced yesterday.

title: Sky of Blue, Beach of Green
description: Tar balls from an oil tanker spill in the Delaware Bay were the first unwelcome substance to mar the New Jersey beaches this season. Then, last week, it was dead fish, released from a commercial fishing net that had come apart. And now, a huge blanket of green algae has turned up off the coast from Asbury Park to Longport and is staining some beaches green, officials of the State Department of Environmental Protection said yesterday.

title: As One President Nears, Another Stays Away
description: When President Clinton arrives on Wednesday night in this city filled with Democrats -- aldermen, delegates, governors, senators, cabinet members and mayors -- he will find one Democrat conspicuous by his absence: Jimmy Carter, the only living Democratic former President of the United States.

title: A Classic Shirt, Scaled Down
description: For years, the only fashionable thing to wear under a jacket was a T-shirt or turtleneck. But the classic shirt has made a comeback, with designers like Ralph Lauren, Donna Karan and Tom Ford showing scaled-down men's shirts under pants suits. Scaled-down is the key for a sleek fit under this fall's skinny jackets.

title: Cone Masters Minors For the Second Time
description: David Cone sat in the dugout this evening wearing not his customary New York Yankee pinstripes, but the onion-purple home warm-up jersey of the Norwich Navigators. This was a few hours before he was to pitch his second Class AA game here, this one against the New Britain Rock Cats.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 19 about Ross Perot's acceptance speech as the Reform Party's nominee for President misstated the direction from Philadelphia for Valley Forge, Pa., where the convention was held. It is northwest, not east.

title: Rewards and Risks Are Great for Woods
description: Now the high life really begins for Tiger Woods, the 20-year-old golfer who has decided to begin his professional career. It will start with his signature on a contract with Nike worth $40 million over the next five years. His coming-out party is scheduled for Wednesday, when he is expected to announce he will play in the Greater Milwaukee Open.

title: A Foot Injury Could Keep A New Yankee Sidelined
description: Pat Listach, who has still not played a game for the Yankees three days after being acquired from Milwaukee, was placed on the 15-day disabled list today with a fractured bone in his right foot and could be lost for the season. Fractures take two to six weeks to heal, so Listach might not make his Yankee debut until 1997.

title: Suspect Is Indicted In Officer's Shooting
description: The Brooklyn man arrested in the shooting of a police officer on Aug. 15 has been indicted on multiple counts of attempted murder, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said yesterday.

title: Dwindling Returns in T.W.A. Debris Hunt
description: Salvage workers investigating the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 believe they have retrieved nearly all the wreckage from the underwater debris fields that were thought to hold the most important evidence, Federal officials said today. But they added that investigators still do not have enough evidence to label the Boeing 747's explosive destruction a crime.

title: Gliding Along, Clinton Fights Battles Past and Present
description: Wending his way by train past the rolling farm fields and cities of this battleground state in the November election, President Clinton today seemed at times to be refighting the failed 1994 Congressional elections, this time from a position of greater strength.

title: Saved From Himalayan Blizzard, Hindus Recall 'Pilgrimage to Hell'
description: When Jagdish Kela, a 34-year-old orange-seller, regained consciousness today, he pulled himself upright in his hospital bed, leaned forward with staring eyes and described in horrifying detail what he called his ''pilgrimage to hell.''

title: U.A.W. Said to Prefer Talks With G.M. and Ford First, Chrysler Later
description: The United Automobile Workers union is leaning toward negotiating a new national labor contract first at the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, and leaving the Chrysler Corporation for later, people close to the union said today.

title: Water Plant Still Vulnerable
description: An emergency generator that failed at a water treatment plant last weekend, leaving 275,000 people in northern New Jersey with contaminated drinking water, had been inoperable for more than a year, officials said yesterday.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Blind but Claiming to See in the Dark
description: THE INSULT

title: USA WASTE SERVICES ACQUIRES SOLID WASTE BUSINESS
description: Philip Environmental Inc., based in Hamilton, Ontario, said yesterday that it had sold its municipal and commercial solid nonhazardous waste business in Michigan, Ontario and Quebec to USA Waste Services Inc. for $118 million. The transaction did not include the solid nonhazardous industrial waste processing and recovery operations of Philip. Philip said that Laidlaw Waste Systems (Canada) Ltd. had begun legal action against both Philip and Dallas-based USA Waste, based on Laidlaw's right of first refusal to Philip's Quebec solid waste business. Philip said it believed the action to be without merit, as Laidlaw had failed to exercise its right.

title: Hachette Filipacchi shows that there's more than one way to sell a magazine cover to marketers.
description: A MAGAZINE publisher known for creating nontraditional advertisements -- which critics complain often stretch the boundaries of what is acceptable in pitching products -- has done it again.

title: Paul M. Gallop Is Dead at 69; Expert in the Biology of Aging
description: Paul Myron Gallop, a pioneer in the biology of aging who was the director of the Laboratory of Human Biochemistry at Children's Hospital Medical Center in Boston, died last Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. He was 69 and lived in the suburban community of Chestnut Hill.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Deal to Create 4th-Largest Temporary Service Agency

title: Animals and Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Alliance Capital Invests In Bank Austria Unit
description: Bank Austria A.G., Austria's largest bank, said yesterday that it had sold a 51 percent stake in its eastern European investment fund unit to Alliance Capital Management L.P. of the United States. No terms were disclosed for the sale of the unit, East Fund Managementberatung G.m.b.H.

title: 4 Women, A Garden, Speeches And Gossip
description: If only Mary Bruce Blackburn and her enterprising Urban Artworks project had programmed the dances differently on Sunday afternoon at the Pace Downtown Theater. The first three were relatively upbeat, the last three unrelievedly gloomy.

title: 2 Bands, 2 Kinds Of Anger
description: There are two types of angry people: those who were born angry and those who need to be pushed before they start shoving back. On a hard-rock bill on Saturday night at the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., the audience saw examples of both.

title: Lewis J. Perl, 55, Economic Analyst
description: Lewis J. Perl, an analyst for the regulated sector of the economy and a senior vice president of National Economic Research Associates of White Plains, died on Saturday while vacationing in Bethany Beach, Del. He was 55 and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: How America Stiffs the Third World
description: Aside from nasty, sometimes demagogic calls to oust the head of the United Nations, ''Booootros Booootros-Ghali,'' the issue of aid to the third world appears to be off the radar screen of American politicians.

title: Consumer Advocates Seek Uniform Faulty-Car Laws
description: Daniel Garcia, Karen Melvin and Wade Wilson did not know each other, but each adopted the same unusual driving practice -- grabbing a towel along with the car keys on rainy days.

title: Q&A
description: Riches on Mars

title: Sky Marshal Force
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Air - On Line
description: All times are Eastern

title: FOSTER GRANT GROUP MOVING TO AMERICAN GREETINGS
description: The American Greetings Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Foster Grant Group, a maker of discount sunglasses, from BEC Group Inc. Financial terms were not disclosed. Foster Grant has $90 million in annual revenue, while American Greetings, primarily a greeting card company, has $2 billion in revenue. American Greetings, based in Cleveland, said the acquisition did not signal a move away from its core business, but instead played to its strength in retail management. BEC, which also makes optical products, is based in Rye, N.Y.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: INSIDE
description: Mets Change Managers

title: A Troubled Circle in the Square Files for Bankruptcy
description: Circle in the Square, which in recent years has been one of the most troubled of New York's institutional theaters, announced yesterday that it had filed a petition of bankruptcy but had not yet created a plan of reorganization. In making the announcement, Theodore R.
