Sayers, acting chairman of the board of the Circle, said, ''It was a necessary step and should put us in an excellent position to clean everything up for the new season.''

title: Today's Schedule
description: All times are eastern

title: U.S. Cancels Talks On an Airline Deal
description: The United States has canceled a negotiating session scheduled this week with Britain to discuss the easing of restrictions on airline service between the two countries, an American official said today.

title: Chess
description: You can't trust in portents. A poor start in a tournament or a match doesn't mean a poor finish, and vice versa. Chess just isn't that predictable.

title: Lufthansa Pretax Profit Off 37% in First Half
description: Lufthansa, the German airline, said yesterday that its pretax profit fell 37 percent in the first half of the year but also said aggressive cost-cutting and higher sales would allow it to make up the drop in the second half. The company's pretax profit was 119 million marks ($80 million), down from 189 million marks a year earlier. Sales were up 6.6 percent, however, to 9.8 billion marks.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Home Video column on Friday about Webster's New World Dictionary of Media and Communications (Macmillan) misstated the book's price. It is $27.95, not $19.98.

title: Group Sees Rush to Stadium
description: A group opposed to building a minor league baseball stadium in a park in the Ironbound section of the city said yesterday that the project was being pushed through without adequate discussion.

title: Lake Victoria's Lightning-Fast Origin of Species
description: VIEWED as an evolutionary treasure chest, crowded with hundreds of closely related fish species that can be found nowhere else in the world, Africa's Lake Victoria has long attracted biologists to its shores. But while scientists probed and prodded these cichlid fish, as they are known, in the vast watery expanse of this continent's largest lake, Victoria yet managed to conceal their most magnificent secret.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Lawyer Disputes Validity of Charge in Crown Hts. Case
description: The lawyer for the man charged with instigating the fatal attack on a Hasidic doctoral student in the 1991 Crown Heights violence plans to argue that even if his client did all the things the prosecution has said, he did not commit the civil rights crime he is charged with.

title: Fallon Resigning Prudential Account
description: Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis said yesterday that it would resign the account of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, which the agency has handled since February 1995, and withdraw from a review for the account of a Prudential subsidiary, Prudential Health Care. Billings on the insurer's account were estimated at $40 million; the health care account's billings were estimated at $20 million to $30 million.

title: THOMAS H. LEE TO BUY 80% STAKE IN RAYOVAC
description: The Rayovac Corporation said yesterday that the Thomas H. Lee Company, a Boston-based investment firm, had agreed to buy 80 percent of the company, the nation's third-largest battery maker. Neither closely held Rayovac nor Thomas H. Lee would disclose the terms of the agreement. Rayovac trails Ralston-Purina Group's Eveready and Duracell International Inc. with about 25 percent of the battery market. It does, though, command about 64 percent of the rechargeable battery market with its Renewal alkaline battery. Rayovac, based in Madison, Wis., had sales of $580 million in 1995.

title: Ben Joelson, TV Writer and Producer, 70
description: Ben Joelson, an Emmy-winning television writer and producer, died on Saturday at Cedars-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 70.

title: China Raises Nuclear Stakes on the Subcontinent
description: The new evidence that China may be aiding a missile factory in Pakistan reflects Beijing's determination to thwart India's domination in the region by promoting a nuclear balance of power, as well as its defiance of American efforts to limit Chinese influence in Asia.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The shoemaker KENNETH COLE has chosen one of the nation's most prominent Republicans to help promote the opening of his new flagship store at Broadway and Houston Street. Signs scheduled to be pasted on walls all over Manhattan by tomorrow morning read OPENING WHEN AL D'AMATO'S MOUTH ISN'T. (OR SEPT . 1, WHICHEVER COMES FIRST.) The store, Mr. Cole's sixth in the metropolitan area, is to open on Friday.

title: Yasuda Buying Control Of Cigna Unit in Japan
description: The Yasuda Fire and Marine Company, a Japanese insurance company, said yesterday that it planned to take a majority stake in the Japanese unit of the Cigna Corporation, the big American life insurer. Terms of the deal, which would be the first purchase by a Japanese nonlife insurance company of a life insurance subsidiary, were not disclosed.

title: Sandoz Sells Unit Involved in Construction
description: SKW Trostberg A.G., a subsidiary of the German energy company Viag, announced yesterday that it was acquiring Master Builders Technologies from Sandoz A.G. for 1.3 billion Swiss francs ($1.09 billion). The merger will create the world's leading supplier of chemical products and systems for the construction industry, SKW said.

title: New Danson Show Faces a Delay
description: In a setback to CBS's fall television schedule, ''Ink,'' a new comedy starring Ted Danson and Mary Steenburgen, is expected to miss its Sept. 16 premiere date because its first three episodes have fallen short of expectations.

title: Bombardier of Canada Introduces a Long-Range Business Jet
description: Bombardier Inc., the world's fourth-largest manufacturer of civil aircraft, rolled out a new long-range business jet today that can circle the world in a day.

title: Firing Is No Shock to Green
description: Dallas Green took a fatalistic approach to his dismissal yesterday.

title: Putting The Boot Into Smoke
description: Nobody howled last week when the Federals asserted a right to ban and/ or edit advertising. This was strange because almost everybody opposes the Government's right to do anything nowadays.

title: To Attack Clinton, G.O.P. Reshapes a Famous Democratic Ad
description: The Republicans have introduced a new 30-second television advertisement in a few areas, including Chicago during the Democratic convention, on behalf of the Bob Dole and Jack Kemp campaign.

title: Airlines Don't Oppose Security Improvements
description: To the Editor:

title: $12 Billion Merger In Communications
description: In the latest huge merger to roil the telecommunications industry, Worldcom will buy MFS Communications for $12 billion in stock.

title: Tobacco Industry Fights Back
description: Four of the big tobacco companies that New Jersey plans to sue to recoup smoking-related Medicaid costs have gone to court to block the litigation, officials said yesterday. The companies contend that Attorney General Peter Verniero exceeded his authority last month when he promised private law firms a percentage of any money awarded in the suit, said Michael York, a lawyer for Philip Morris. Under state law, only the Legislature has the authority to make such an arrangement, Mr. York said. E. J. Miranda, a spokesman for Mr. Verniero, said yesterday that the tobacco companies' motion, filed in Superior Court in Trenton on Friday, was being reviewed by his office.

title: Prosecutor Sums Up Details Of 'Hideous' Jet Terror Plot
description: Using charts, photographs and simple exhibits like fake identification cards, a Government prosecutor yesterday wove together what had often seemed to be circumstantial pieces of testimony and evidence in an attempt to show how close Ramzi Ahmed Yousef and two co-defendants came to blowing up a dozen American jetliners.

title: Man Is Injured in a Drive-By Pellet-Gun Spree
description: Two men fired high-powered pellet guns from speeding vehicles last night on the Upper East Side and Upper West Side, striking a bystander in the neck and shattering storefront windows in a spree that lasted for more than four hours, the police said.

title: 'Star Wars' Is Fantasy; Leakage Threat Is Real
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was ANATOLY KARPOV against the world, and the world resigned. Mr. Karpov, the International Chess Federation's champion, took 32 moves and four-and-a-half hours to defeat an estimated 300 players who participated in what was billed as the world's first open Internet chess game yesterday. After each move by Mr. Karpov, who was sitting in a chess club in Helsinki, Finland, chess players transmitted their suggested responses, and a computer chose the most popular move.

title: He Paid For Speaking His Mind
description: TOO old, rumpled and opinionated, Dallas Green committed the fatal mistake for a manager of a losing team in search of an excuse. He spoke what he believed to be the truth.

title: Accustaff Set To Buy Rival In Stock Swap
description: Accustaff Inc., a fast-growing provider of temporary workers, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Career Horizons Inc., a smaller competitor, in a $1 billion stock swap.

title: Golf's New Tiger
description: Tiger Woods will have to win the Masters and the United States Open a few times before he can take a place in the golfing pantheon beside Jack Nicklaus and Bob Jones, but as an amateur player he is already in a class by himself. In a memorable demonstration of athletic skill and courage on Sunday, Woods recovered from a big deficit to win his third consecutive United States Amateur Championship, a streak unequaled by any previous golf prodigy including Nicklaus and Jones. He shows every sign of being the best golfer in a generation.

title: South Korea Judges Its Past
description: So seamlessly did South Korea's current civilian democracy evolve over the last decade from its violent and corrupt military dictatorship that it once appeared unlikely the leaders of the old regime would ever be held accountable for their misdeeds. Yesterday, however, a three-judge court in Seoul convicted former Presidents Chun Doo Hwan and Roh Tae Woo of reprehensible crimes and sentenced them to extremely severe punishments.

title: A Home-Course Advantage Goes to Identity at Saratoga
description: If there is such a thing as a home-court advantage in horse racing, a 4-year-old gelding named Identity invoked it today when he won the West Point Handicap by a neck and extended his perfect record on the grass at Saratoga Race Course.

title: Talks on Saving Redwoods May Be Near Decisive Point
description: Negotiations to save the country's largest privately owned stand of virgin redwoods have reached a ''crunch,'' a senior Clinton Administration official said today, as representatives of the corporate investor who controls the forest softly repeated his threat to begin logging there in three weeks.

title: North Carolina Rail Plan
description: The State of North Carolina has hired Nationsbank to evaluate the purchase of the 25 percent of the North Carolina Railroad Company that it does not already own. North Carolina Railroad said today that it had formed a committee of five directors to negotiate with the state. It said that the state had not made a formal offer and that there was no assurance of a purchase. The company's stock jumped $1.75, to $29.25 a share, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Mets, in Move to Serve Their Youth, Dismiss Green
description: The Mets have been unable to match the Yankees' victory total in recent seasons, but they have surpassed them in number of managers.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Convention Summary
description: FOCUS ON LAW ENFORCEMENT

title: Aaron Still Chasing Ball No. 755
description: The last ball that HANK AARON hit over a fence is tucked into an Albuquerque, N.M., safe deposit box rented by RICHARD ARNDT, who retrieved home run ball No. 755 at Milwaukee County Stadium on July 20, 1976. The next day, Arndt was fired from his part-time job on the grounds crew for taking the ball home instead of returning it to the Milwaukee Brewers, the team Aaron ended his career with after playing for the Milwaukee and Atlanta Braves.

title: Substance Behind Those Shades
description: It's hip to be Anna Kournikova, to have the sunglasses fixed atop a mane of blond, to be as cool and as trendy as sorbet.

title: Mayor Tightens Screening Of People Seeking Shelter
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he had ordered stricter screening of people who seek shelter at the long-troubled emergency homeless center in the Bronx, declaring that many were not really homeless but merely wanted a better place to live at the city's expense.

title: About the Death of Keats, But Not His Final Words
description: On Feb. 23, 1821, John Keats lay in his small room overlooking the Spanish Steps in Rome and called out to his friend, the painter Joseph Severn. ''Severn . . . I am dying . . . I shall die easy . . . don't be frightened . . . be firm and thank God it has come.''

title: 'Star Wars' Is Fantasy; Leakage Threat Is Real
description: To the Editor:

title: A Loving Look Back At Brooklyn's Bums
description: The men sat in a darkened auditorium last week, watching their youth pass on film. Occasionally, one would whisper ''Happy Felton'' or ''Hilda Chester.'' The men were Brooklyn Dodgers -- Joe Black, Pee Wee Reese, Carl Erskine, Clyde King -- plus Giant Bobby Thomson, now an honorary Bum who fits in amiably with the men (and the borough) he crushed with a single swat in 1951.

title: Nitric Oxide Levels a Clue to Severe Malaria
description: ONE of the great mysteries of malaria is that its course can vary so much from one person to the next, particularly among children. Some become dreadfully ill and die, while others -- a vast majority -- gradually develop some resistance with each bout of the disease, so that they have milder illnesses, or even no symptoms at all, despite being infected with malaria parasites.

title: Thousands Lose Power as Vital Line Fails
description: A vital power line carrying electricity across the Catskills to eastern and southern New York stopped transmitting yesterday afternoon, leaving tens of thousands of customers without power for 11 to 15 minutes as utility companies scrambled to reconfigure the state's energy flow to compensate for the lost line.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY

title: With Few Issues to Quarrel Over, Democrats Convene
description: Venturing back to the city that three decades ago was the backdrop for the party's most tumultuous convention, the Democrats met here today to nominate President Clinton for a second term with a program that featured not politicians but speakers telling personal parables of tragedy and triumph.

title: A Modernized 'Messiah,' In Mozart's Brazen Way
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival concert on Friday night was a healthy rebuke to the hard-liners of the authenticity movement. Gerard Schwarz conducted the festival orchestra, joined by the Pro Arte Chorale and four vocal soloists at Avery Fisher Hall, in a performance of Handel's ''Messiah'' in the seldom-heard 1789 arrangement Mozart made for his friend and sometime patron Baron van Swieten. This bold reorchestration and refashioning of the work is so distinctive that it rightly occupies its own listing in the Mozart catalogue.

title: No Gathering of Ideas
description: If the Democrats walked dangerously close to the line that divides pathos from bathos tonight, they seemed convinced they had stayed on the safe side.

title: Lebed Lobbies in Moscow for Peace Plan
description: As plans for a Russian troop withdrawal from the Chechen capital of Grozny ground to a halt today, Aleksandr I. Lebed, the Russian national security adviser, met with Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin to try to rally top-level support for his plan to end the war in Chechnya.

title: In Music as Well as Sports, Injuries Can End a Career
description: In the supposedly genteel realm of classical music, skirmishes in the struggle between valor and discretion generally take place on the field of self-esteem. Performers who reach beyond their physical grasp may suffer embarrassment, even ignominy, but seldom anything more concrete.

title: Mere Soap Opera? It's Mexican Magic (in Tagalog)
description: As the shadows on Honradez Street lengthened, Conrad Alvarez bustled about his open-air corner grocery store making sure all four television sets were on. It was 6:30 in the evening and it was time for ''Mari Mar,'' the country's favorite soap opera -- a blizzard of love, sex and betrayal, poverty and sudden wealth, revenge and triumph. And a talking dog.

title: Green's Message Didn't Get Through
description: It was only a few days ago that Dallas Green was sitting in the visitors' dugout at Dodger Stadium and talking about leaving the game with dignity. The subject of the conversation was the former Dodgers manager Tommy Lasorda and other baseball lifers, but there was a feeling that Green might have been talking about himself.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-8

title: How Can Meatloaf Compete?
description: Only about 35 percent of the 1,600 students at Hillsborough High School buy their lunch at the school cafeteria, but school officials hope to fatten up that number soon. Starting this fall, Hillsborough is opening an on-campus franchise of the nationwide Subway chain.

title: Slave Artifacts Under the Hearth
description: THE ground floor of the old town house on Duke of Gloucester Street stands bare. The last owner died, everything has been stripped to the brick walls and dark wooden floors, and archeologists are poking about and finding secrets from the house's 18th-century past.

title: School District Of Kiryas Joel Is Ruled Illegal
description: The State Appellate Division in Albany yesterday declared unconstitutional a special public school district carved out by former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the State Legislature for the handicapped Hasidic children of Kiryas Joel, N.Y., in rural Orange County.

title: MCI Joins Nextwave in Wireless Communications Venture
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that it had entered an agreement with the start-up company Nextwave Telecom Inc. that would enable MCI to provide the next generation of wireless telecommunications services in most of the nation's largest cities.

title: No Headline
description: ''Everybody was in a state of panic. Even those making pilgrimage in groups seemed to have decided that anybody who fell behind had to be abandoned. If you wanted to live, you didn't stop.''

title: Worldcom to Buy MFS for $12 Billion, Creating a Phone Giant
description: In a sign of the rush toward ''one-stop shopping'' in telephone service, Worldcom Inc. agreed to buy MFS Communications yesterday in a stock deal worth approximately $12 billion.

title: Corn and Soybean Prices Rise; Farm Tour Finds Poor Crops
description: Corn and soybean prices rose on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday after analysts touring Midwest farms found poor conditions.

title: Forcing Felons Off the Dole
description: A dozen inmates of the Atlantic County jail have recently learned that the check is no longer in the mail, officials said yesterday. A Federal law makes it illegal for incarcerated felons to receive Social Security benefits, or for people in jail for more than 30 days to get Supplemental Security Income benefits intended for the disabled and aged.

title: Salary and Benefits of Adelphi's Embattled President Defended by His Mentor
description: For years, Dr. John Silber, the former president and now Chancellor of Boston University, has served as a role model, mentor, colleague and friend to Dr. Peter Diamandopoulos, the embattled president of Adelphi University.

title: Roussel Shares Surge On Talk of Hoescht Deal
description: Shares in Roussel Uclaf, a French drug maker, surged yesterday after a French newspaper reported that Hoechst A.G. would buy the part of the company that it did not already own for 1,400 francs ($280) a share. Roussel characterized the report as unfounded. A spokesman for Hoescht, the German chemical company, denied any plans for a purchase of the 43.4 percent stake.

title: Aliens Seized in Paris Church Are Released From Detention
description: Almost all of the 210 illegal immigrants from Africa thrown out of a Paris church and arrested by the police on Friday were free today after official attempts to deport most of them bogged down on technical legal grounds.

title: On the Rise: Agassi Breezes in Opener
description: Olympic gold medal or not, he has been maligned lately by his less spectacularly sneakered peers, who think he thinks he's bigger than the game, big enough to deserve a seeding upgrade at the United States Open. Andre Agassi was unseeded when he won the Open in 1994, so drama surely becomes him. Little wonder he has not seemed to mind creating drama of a different type this year by accepting, and perhaps even hinting he was entitled to, a boost from his eighth-place seeding to the sixth-seeded slot.

title: California Child Molesters Face 'Chemical Castration'
description: Taking the lead in a nationwide push to enact tougher sex-crime laws, the California Legislature has all but completed action on what legal experts say will be the most punitive child molestation measure ever adopted in this country, one requiring ''chemical castration'' of repeat offenders.

title: Cuba Sentences Fugitive Businessman Vesco to 13 Years for Fraud
description: A court in Cuba convicted Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive American businessman, of economic crimes today and sentenced him to 13 years in jail.

title: Clippers Sign Wright to Three-Year Deal
description: Forward LORENZEN WRIGHT, the seventh selection in the National Basketball Association draft, signed a three-year contract with the Los Angeles Clippers, the team said yesterday. Under the N.B.A.'s rookie salary cap, the 6-foot-10-inch Wright is limited to $4.25 million over the three years of the deal. Wright, 20, an early entry in the draft, averaged 17.4 points and 10.4 rebounds a game as a sophomore at Memphis last season. (AP)

title: Mrs. Clinton Invokes Memories of Famed and Faulted
description: With a feathery touch but clear political intent, Hillary Rodham Clinton responded today to the critics of her four-year stint as First Lady by drawing on the imagery of strong women from an earlier era who battled withering criticism in their day.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MELLON BANK CORP., Pittsburgh, expanded its commercial equipment-leasing business with a definitive agreement to acquire FUL Inc., a privately held company that operates as First United Leasing. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Heads Up, Here Comes Another Blitz
description: The Giants' offensive line coach, Pete Mangurian, has said he does not expect opponents to blitz his team any more than they would anyone else. Really? If that is the case, it would be surprising.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day on Saturday about a payment by the Bankers Trust New York Corporation to a former chief executive, Charles S. Sanford Jr., misstated the terms. In exchange, Mr. Sanford agreed not to disclose information about his employment with the company and his departure; he did not agree to refrain from criticizing Bankers Trust.

title: Screening Is Tightened At Homeless Unit
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he had ordered stricter screening of people who seek shelter at the emergency homeless center in the Bronx, declaring that many were not really homeless but merely wanted a better place to live at the city's expense. Mr. Giuliani said that the new rules had already reduced overcrowding at the troubled center, a dingy office that has become an embarrassing symbol of the city's difficulties in dealing with its homeless. Over the years the center has turned into something of a grim flophouse, with dozens of families sprawling over tables and chairs for days. The Mayor said that just as his administration had lowered welfare rolls by weeding out fraud, so too would it lessen the number of people seeking shelter at the center.

title: Platform Politics
description: Bob Dole said in San Diego that he had not read the Republican platform and did not feel obliged to follow it. Bill Clinton may or may not have read the platform that will be formally voted on by the Democratic Convention today. But he will have no trouble running on it. It was clearly written to fit Mr. Clinton and the campaign planned by his main strategist, Dick Morris.

title: Foster's Expects Delay In China Profits
description: Foster's Brewing Group Ltd. of Australia has pushed back its expectations for turning a profit in China, saying its operations there would not be out of the red until at least 1999. The chief executive, Ted Kunkel, said yesterday that the China effort was about 18 months behind its target.

title: Negotiators Do Lunch
description: The chief negotiators in baseball's labor talks met for lunch yesterday, but their efforts to resolve the last few issues continued to be stalled by deliberations on the owners' side.

title: The Bottom Line in Basketball: The Fan
description: To the Editor:

title: Popov Is Recovering From Stabbing
description: A month ago, ALEKSANDR POPOV was on top of the world after winning the two sprint freestyle events in the Atlanta Olympics, earning him recognition as the world's fastest swimmer.

title: 'Star Wars' Is Fantasy; Leakage Threat Is Real
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Fiscal Monitors Warn of Rising Debt Cost
description: In the years after it skirted bankruptcy in 1975, New York City restored its financial health in part by winnowing its sizable debt. But now the city's debt burden is growing again, threatening to overrun other areas of its $33 billion annual budget, sapping already dwindling resources like so much fiscal kudzu.

title: For Dole Camp, Apocalypse as Metaphor
description: Here under the cerulean skies of one of the lushest, most tranquil communities in America, the Dole campaign today raised the specter of one of the most horrific images of modern times: nuclear war.

title: The Name May Be All That's Familiar
description: The glossy brochure that aides to Gov. Evan Bayh of Indiana distributed here in advance of his keynote speech to the Democratic National Convention identifies his major accomplishments as balancing the budget, cutting taxes, reforming welfare, reducing regulations, strengthening families and cracking down on crime.

title: Topps Selects Griffin Bacal
description: The Topps Company in New York, which markets candy, gum, trading cards and comic books, said yesterday that it had named Griffin Bacal in New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group, to its account, with billings estimated at $7 million to $10 million. The account had been at Grey Advertising in New York for two and half years; Grey resigned in April.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BRAD BRIDGEWATER may have won a gold medal in the 200-meter backstroke in Atlanta, but can he swim with the sharks of Wall Street? How about the striped bass of the Hudson River? Mr. Bridgewater will find out tomorrow, when he joins four other Olympians, along with swimmers from Bear, Stearns; Lehman Brothers, and other brokerage houses in a 25-mile relay swim from the Tappan Zee Bridge down to the World Financial Center to raise money for cancer research.

title: U.S. Wary of Punishing China For Missile Help to Pakistan
description: While the Clinton Administration has not formally declared that China is secretly helping Pakistan build a factory to produce medium-range missiles, in violation of its promises to Washington, senior officials are already trying to figure out what to do about it.

title: Gene Therapy Shows First Signs Of Bypassing Arterial Blockage
description: LAST year, researchers began the first study of gene therapy for cardiovascular disease, adding genes to clogged arteries in the hope of getting patients to grow their own bypasses. If it worked, the method could revolutionize the treatment of cardiovascular disease, but gene therapy has been characterized by great promise and little proof of success.

title: A Spate of Red Tides Menacing Coastal Seas
description: LIKE something out of a horror movie, the cell from hell attacks its victims in gruesome ways, frequently changing its body form with lightning speed. The unicellular animal, called Pfiesteria piscida, has at least 24 guises it can assume in the course of its lifetime. It can also masquerade as a plant or lie dormant for years in the absence of suitable prey.

title: Myra Livingston, 70, Who Wrote Many Books of Children's Verse
description: Myra Cohn Livingston, a poet, anthologist and teacher who wrote more than 80 books of poetry for children, died on Friday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 70.

title: Tenor Sax, Both Hefty and Vulnerable
description: About six years ago, the tenor saxophonist David S. Ware began concentrating his energies on his own group, after having spent a decade and a half as a sideman with Cecil Taylor and other avatars of jazz's avant-garde. Since then he has been known as one of the most considered and technique-minded players of the forward-looking jazz underground, but his quartet's taut and tantalizing performance at the Knitting Factory on Friday, as part of the Panasonic Village Jazz Festival, may take his reputation one step further.

title: Count Those Buses
description: To the Editor:

title: A Marriage of Percussion and Program
description: A percussion concert can turn into droning monotony, despite the variety of instruments played, if the program is not carefully considered. The percussionists of the Forum Music Group, a Taiwanese new music ensemble, clearly took that into account in planning their Sunday afternoon concert at the Taipei Theater. The works they offered ranged from the gentle textures of marimba, vibraphone and crotales in Toru Takemitsu's ''Rain Tree,'' to Georges Aperghis's theatrical and sometimes comic ''Le Quetteurs de Sons'' to a collection of more riotous and timbrally wide-ranging works by composers working in distinct styles.

title: Don't Squelch Dialogue Among Catholics
description: To the Editor:

title: Focus on Bomb Suspect Brings Tears and a Plea
description: Barbara Jewell stared into the unblinking eyes of the television cameras she has come to despise and spoke in tears today of how life had changed for her son, Richard, since he was named a month ago as a suspect in the bombing in Centennial Olympic Park.

title: Arsenio Hall to Star In a Sitcom on ABC
description: Arsenio Hall, whose syndicated talk show was among the hottest shows on television in the early 1990's, will return to the medium as the star of a situation comedy for ABC.

title: Conseco to Pay $1.7 Billion For Insurers
description: Conseco Inc., a large insurer that focuses on life and health policies, strengthened its share of markets that cater to older Americans yesterday with agreements to acquire two more companies and to consolidate its ownership of two affiliates. Altogether, the transactions will cost Conseco $1.7 billion.

title: 60's Political Lesson: Blue Jeans vs. Pearls
description: In a way, ''the vision thing'' in politics is no more sweeping than the penmanship of Paula Lent, treasurer of Ophthpac, as she dutifully signs her name to the donation checks of the eye doctors' political action committee.

title: Steps Drivers Can Take In the Face of a Lemon
description: Drivers can take several steps to protect themselves, consumer advocates say, first, to avoid buying a lemon, or, if they fear they have already done so, to get some relief.

title: Supporting Cast
description: Among the speakers on this evening's program:

title: Death Sentence for Ex-President Chun a Landmark for Korea
description: Many South Koreans rejoiced and some fumed today after a court sentenced one former President to death and another to 22 years in prison in a landmark case that underscores how far this country has come from the era of military rule that the two men represented.

title: On Bosnia Election, It's Better to Proceed
description: To the Editor:

title: A merger deal shows once again that it's all in the timing.
description: SOMETIMES it just doesn't pay to hedge.

title: Patterns
description: A First in Paris

title: Through the Internet With a Pair of Rival Guides: Why Not Hire Both?
description: PARTLY because Microsoft and Netscape executives are openly antagonistic toward each other, it is tempting to characterize this month's rival introductions of Microsoft Internet Explorer 3.0 and Netscape Navigator 3.0 as a showdown, a David and Goliath struggle or even a deathmatch for ultimate domination of cyberspace.

title: Bass Forging a Link With Danish Brewer
description: Bass P.L.C. intends to buy Allied Domecq P.L.C.'s 50 percent stake in the Carlsberg-Tetley brewing venture for $:200 million ($310 million) and will combine its own British brewing interests with the venture's other partner, Carlsberg A.S. of Denmark. If approved by regulators, the move, which was announced on Sunday, would reinstate Bass as Britain's No. 1 brewer and give it market share of about 35 percent.

title: Airlines Don't Oppose Security Improvements
description: To the Editor:

title: Otsego Prosecutor Tries To Avoid Trial Conflicts
description: There's a lot to be said for the way justice is done here in Otsego County, a lush but sparsely populated rural area that's just a four-hour drive from New York City but a million miles away from its courts. The handful of lawyers and judges have known each other for years, so disputes are often resolved with a minimum of rancor, a modicum of humor and a maximum of gossip.

title: Gencor of South Africa Posts 47% Profit Rise
description: Gencor Ltd., one of South Africa's three biggest mining companies, said yesterday that earnings before one-time items rose 47 percent in the latest fiscal year. Income before one-time items was 1.49 billion rand ($328 million) in the year ended June 30, up from 1.02 billion rand in the previous fiscal year.

title: Reefer Madness Strikes Again
description: A national tragedy,'' declared Bob Dole last week. A sign of ''moral weakness,'' added William Bennett, the former drug czar who has said he wants his old job back. Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican, lamented a lack of ''strong Presidential leadership.''

title: A Runway That Connects Laguna Beach to Wall St.
description: Mossimo Giannulli's favorite metaphor for how he's establishing his business while New York designers aren't looking is the Navy Seals.

title: Crew's Removal of Board Members Is Upheld
description: A panel of Federal judges yesterday upheld Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew's suspension of 14 New York City community school board members, including a Bronx board president who had been removed by three chancellors but returned to office by voters each time.

title: Pursuing Virtual Dinosaurs, Alive on Your Screen
description: TO hear some futurists tell it, computers will spark a renaissance in education, using fresh methods that make learning fun, and will send teachers, schools and books the way of the dinosaurs. Two new CD-ROM's about dinosaurs suggest that the old ways remain a long, long way from extinction.

title: Good Victory in Tough Game Boosts Lions
description: A week before Labor Day, the expectations of the college football season were already being revised.

title: A Spartan Trek To Hindu Shrine
description: According to Hindu beliefs, in late summer, on a night when the moon was full, the god Siva appeared inside a cave high atop the Himalayas. Devout Hindus have long aspired to make the excruciating mountain trek to Amarnath every August.

title: 3 Singers Who Show the Range of Rockabilly
description: Just as video games can seem to burn an image on the retina, so too did Friday night's rockabilly bill at the Damrosch Park Band Shell in Lincoln Center. It was an image of three motley characters lined up onstage, each with a guitar and a microphone. In the center was a tall, hulking man with a black cowboy hat; to his left was a slender woman with a pocketbook hanging off her shoulder behind her guitar; the third was a distinguished midsize man with gray hair.

title: David A. McCabe, An Art Collector And a Lawyer, 56
description: David A. McCabe, a lawyer who represented governments and large corporations, died on Sunday in Manhattan at the age of 56.

title: Jets Tutored in All Subjects but History
description: The Jets' players do not have much in the way of memories, and that might not be a bad thing. Most of them don't even know that Dave Jennings, their radio analyst, is a onetime Jet, or that if they produce a winning season it will be the team's first since 1988.

title: An Exponent of Romanticism With Wide-Ranging Moods
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival became more so on Thursday evening, when Haydn's 104th Symphony was replaced by Mozart's Fourth, to open the concert at Avery Fisher Hall. Robert Schumann thus remained the only interloper in the program, but a striking one with Helene Grimaud playing his Piano Concerto in A minor.

title: Ban Bear Hunts? Trends Converge to Force a Vote
description: After seven miles of shoving through dense underbrush, slogging through knee-deep mud and wading up to their waists through snake-infested water, the hunters finally caught up with their quarry.

title: MORRISON MERGING WITH WASHINGTON CONSTRUCTION
description: The Morrison Knudsen Corporation won court approval of its bankruptcy plan yesterday, giving the company a green light to exchange its debt for equity and to merge with a rival, the Washington Construction Group. Morrison Knudsen, an engineering company, filed for bankruptcy in June, proposing to swap $360 million of debt for new equity and other assets. Washington Construction has agreed to buy Morrison Knudsen for about $380 million. Washington Construction, based in Highland, Calif., is controlled by a Montana billionaire, Dennis Washington, who will be chairman of the new company. The merger would be effective on Sept. 11. The new company, which will keep the name Morrison Knudsen, will be based in Boise, Idaho.

title: Party Platforms: How They Compare
description: Here are some of the differences between the platform Republican adopted in San Diego and the one Democrats are expected to adopt in Chicago.

title: As Crash Costs Set Record, Who Pays Is in Dispute
description: From the $60,000 daily cost of rented salvage ships to the price of high-tech forensic equipment to police overtime, the investigation into the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 is already the nation's most expensive aircraft-accident investigation.

title: Treasury Securities Drop in Price
description: Prices of Treasury securities gave ground yesterday, with the market weighted down by coming supply and uncertainty over whether the economy will slow enough to avoid a surge in inflation.

title: Silver King, at TCI's Urging, To Purchase Home Shopping
description: Silver King Communications Inc. plans to buy Home Shopping Network Inc. in a stock swap valued at $1.27 billion, the companies announced yesterday. The deal is an attempt by Tele-Communications Inc., a major stockholder in both companies, to join the two companies while still complying with Federal ownership limits.

title: N.F.L. TRAINING CAMP REPORT
description: Buffalo Bills

title: Short Interest Up on Nasdaq
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq market rose 6.4 percent in the most recent month, the National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday.

title: SHARES OF AETRIUM DECLINE ON DISAPPOINTING OUTLOOK
description: The shares of Aetrium Inc. slid to a 52-week low yesterday after the company said the continued downturn in the semiconductor industry would cause its earnings and revenue for the rest of the year to be significantly below expectations. Aetrium now expects to earn between 18 cents and 21 cents a share in the third quarter, ending Sept. 30, on revenue of $13 million. That would be well below the 38 cents a share expected by analysts, according to First Call Inc. In the third quarter a year earlier, Aetrium had revenue of $13.5 million. The chip-testing company has cut back production and has asked certain customers for permission to push back shipping dates. On the Nasdaq stock market, Aetrium's stock fell $2.75, or 21 percent, to $10.25.

title: Islanders Cut Offers to Palffy and Green
description: MIKE MILBURY says he never heard from the agents. So as far as the general manager of the Islanders is concerned, ''It's the equivalent of if they walked out of training camp.''

title: Fidelity Manager to Join Goldman, Sachs
description: Robert A. Beckwitt, one of the brightest stars among Fidelity Investments' mutual fund managers until an aggressive bet on Latin American debt imploded in 1994, resigned from Fidelity to join Goldman, Sachs & Company, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: KMART PLANS NATIONWIDE EXPANSION OF CREDIT CARD
description: The Kmart Corporation said yesterday that it would make its new credit card available in its more than 2,100 stores across the United States. Kmart's chief executive, Floyd Hall, said the discount retailer had strong results in test-marketing of the credit card at 167 stores. Kmart, of Troy, Mich., teamed up in March with Beneficial National Bank USA, a unit of the Beneficial Corporation, to offer the card in an effort to lure shoppers from its rival Wal-Mart Stores Inc., which does not offer a credit card. Kmart will offer incentives to its credit-card shoppers, including allowing them to accumulate annual gift certificates worth as much as 6 percent of total card purchases. Beneficial will receive all the interest income from the card and assume all the credit risk.

title: Mason to Knicks: You Lose
description: ANTHONY MASON joined the Charlotte Hornets yesterday and wasted no time in sending a blunt message to his former employers, the Knicks.

title: News: When Yellow Dog Nuzzles Politician
description: To the Editor:

title: VALUJET LAYS OFF EMPLOYEES IT HAD RECALLED
description: Valujet Inc. said yesterday it had laid off 134 employees that it had recalled in anticipation of resuming service. The low-fare airline, which planned to be flying again by late this month, is not likely to resume operations until September. In late July, the carrier, which is based in Atlanta, began recalling some of the 4,000 people it employed before it shut down on June 17. But approval from Federal regulators will take longer than the airline expected. Valujet was ordered to cease flying after regulators cited safety concerns following the crash of a Valujet flight in the Florida Everglades in May.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: A Relay for Cancer Research
description: At 11:30 this morning, six swimmers will dive off the Tarrytown Boat Club's dock into the Hudson River near the Tappan Zee Bridge and swim south for 1,000 to 1,500 meters. They will then tag a boat, and teammates will take up the relay race, which is expected to end at 6 P.M. near the World Financial Center.

title: Looking Ahead Gloomily With Clear Statistics
description: THE STATE OF AMERICANS

title: Treasury Securities Rise in Price
description: Prices of Treasury securities gained yesterday, despite a disappointing two-year Treasury note auction.

title: Edberg Isn't Finished Yet. Ask Krajicek.
description: Both of them are playing moment-to-moment tennis. But where the 30-year-old Stefan Edberg, for whom this United States Open is his last United States Open, knows his best tennis moments are behind him, the 20-year-old Jennifer Capriati has to be wondering if her moment has passed her by.

title: Sound of One Fan Cheering for Reeves
description: Before fans and others send Giants Coach Dan Reeves packing after this season, they may want to listen to one of the best coaches in National Football League history. Joe Gibbs is remembered by Giants fans not only because of the once-intense rivalry between the Giants and Gibbs's Washington Redskins, but also because Gibbs was recently voted into the Hall of Fame.

title: INSIDE
description: A Battle Renewed in Israel

title: It's Shakespeare, Pardner, in a 10-Gallon Hat
description: Does anyone, by any chance, remember ''The Merry Wives of Windsor'' as a play about lawsuits? Although Shakespeare's suburban comedy has a generous complement of professions (doctor, preacher, bus boy), the only thing close to an attorney is old Justice Shallow. (''Let's kill all the lawyers'' comes from ''Henry VI.'')

title: South Korean Economy Posts 6.7% Growth Rate
description: South Korea's gross domestic product rose 6.7 percent in the second quarter of 1996 from a year ago, down from 9.7 percent growth in the second quarter of last year, the Bank of Korea said yesterday. Analysts say growth is slowing as the Korean economy is hit by declining export growth and lower corporate investment. G.D.P. rose 7.9 percent in the first quarter of 1996.

title: Flying Together Again, With Sentiment and Politesse
description: The alto saxophonist Jackie McLean and the drummer Michael Carvin came together for a reconnection on Sunday afternoon in the last installment of the Brooklyn Museum's ''Double Exposure'' jazz-duet series. In 1974, the pair made a duet album, ''Antiquity,'' for a small label, Inner City. That record went in a lot of directions: straight post-bop blues, African rhythms, song cycles. They used bamboo flutes, bells, and blocks; the recording is a curio of its time, though in a funny way its investigation of foreign rhythms and scales prefigured today's bohemian rhythm addicts in jazz like Rodney Kendrick and Leon Parker.

title: In Losing Turkey, Europe Played a Role
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Notes
description: PBS, Yes, Government, No

title: Wine Talk
description: HERE we go again: the zinfandel mystery has unraveled once more.

title: St. Hillary's Homecoming
description: The rapturous reception that women have accorded Hillary Rodham Clinton at the Democratic Convention this week is a wonder to behold. She has made a point of speaking to women's groups, and when she enters the room the women rise to their feet, jumping, whooping and wiping away tears, wearing buttons that say ''Give 'em hell, Hillary.'' They wait behind rope lines for a word, touch or glimpse. For true believers, nobody can match her Evita-like status, not even her husband, the President.

title: Excerpts From Platform Adopted at Democratic Convention
description: Following are excerpts from the platform adopted last night at the Democratic National Convention.

title: As Party's Leader, Dodd Hews the Line but With a Credible Touch
description: On Nov. 22, 1994, just after the election that turned Congress over to the Republicans, Senator Christopher J. Dodd was in his office working the phones, campaigning for minority leader. He had one eye on the television when he heard a report that Senator Jesse Helms had warned the President not to visit North Carolina without a bodyguard.

title: Is Blue Tastier Than Green?
description: To The Living Section:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Profit Motive Clouds Effort To Buy Up A-Bomb Material

title: A New Effort to Seek Peace in the Tobacco Battle
description: A new effort is under way in Washington to pass legislation that would settle the lawsuits between tobacco companies and states seeking their costs of treating tobacco-related illnesses. But it is unlikely that any bill adopting the proposal could be passed in this session of Congress, said lawyers involved in the cases who met here today.

title: Prudential of Britain Sells Reinsurance Unit
description: The big British insurer the Prudential Corporation said today that it was selling its reinsurance subsidiary, Mercantile and General, to the Swiss Reinsurance Company for $:1.75 billion ($2.7 billion), making the Swiss company the world's largest life and health reinsurer.

title: Clinton Makes Stops in Midwest for Politics and Calls for Literacy Project
description: President Clinton barnstormed Ohio and Michigan today, mixing traditional Democratic politicking at a Jeep factory with the announcement of a new Government proposal to fight illiteracy. But the strains inside his coalition also became evident when an Ohio Congresswoman sharply criticized the Nafta trade pact before a crowd gathered to hear the President.

title: Some Bosnia Voting Delayed Over Abuses
description: The Western official in charge of the September elections in Bosnia postponed municipal voting, citing abuses. The delay raised fears about whether the timetable for pulling out peacekeepers could be maintained.

title: Shop and Chop: A Tomato Challenge
description: GIVE eight Manhattan chefs $20 each; set them loose in the Union Square Greenmarket on a Wednesday morning; allow them 40 minutes to peruse and purchase and then, while crowds gather, dogs bark and rain pours down in sheets, give them 40 minutes to prepare, on the spot, an uncooked tomato-based dish for six.

title: Cash for Schools That Lure Helpful Parents
description: As Schools Chancellor, Dr. Rudy Crew is charged with setting high standards for 1.1 million children in New York City. Yesterday, he set an ambitious benchmark for their parents, too.

title: Salvation for Nonbelievers? Not in the Bible
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe's Cultural Capital For '96 Takes a Longer View
description: Every year since 1985, a different European city has been designated the region's cultural capital, but the usefulness of this exercise has never been too clear. Athens, Florence and Paris hardly needed the extra attention, while the title alone could not turn Glasgow, Antwerp and Luxembourg into veritable cultural magnets. In any event, few Europeans outside each chosen city have even heard of the program.

title: Just How Pleasurable?
description: To The Living Section:

title: Party Uses Networks' Love of Live TV to Snare Them
description: Alone among the commercial broadcast networks, ABC made a remarkable choice as it began its prime-time coverage of the Democratic National Convention here tonight. It cut almost immediately to lengthy, taped experts from speeches by Jesse Jackson and former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Bountiful Southeast Asian Produce (Tree Ears, Anyone?)
description: SOUTHEAST ASIAN ingredients that for centuries have been integral to Thai and Vietnamese cooking are increasingly available in New York. Supermarkets are now selling things like fresh lemon grass, Thai chilies, oyster mushrooms and napa cabbage. And for the more adventurous, specialty stores are offering Thai eggplants, gai choy (an Asian mustard green) and galangal, a relative of ginger.

title: After Crisis, Most Water Is Safe to Drink
description: After four days of boiling water, more than 200,000 New Jersey residents who live in Jersey City and Hoboken found out yesterday that their tap water was safe. But tests showed that the tap water in Lyndhurst, a township of 18,000, may still contain high levels of bacteria.

title: Defining Literacy Downward
description: For many years, the College Board, sponsor of the Scholastic Assessment Test, insisted that the test was ''an unchanging standard.'' But no more. The latest S.A.T. scores, which were announced last week, are the first to be graded on a new curve -- one that has lowered the test's ''unchanging standard'' and our country's educational aspirations.

title: A Pungent, Summery Voyage to Thailand
description: The lavishly photographed coffee-table book ''Thailand the Beautiful Cookbook'' by Panurat Poladitmontri and Judy Lew (Collins Publishers, San Francisco, 1992) inspires two recipes for a light summer dinner. If you have never met the Thai fish sauce called nam pla, do not be put off by the aroma. Once nam pla is mixed with food, it loses its fishy smell and adds wonderful pungency.

title: Chief Warns All Firefighters on Flouting of Safety Rules
description: In an unusual letter sent to the homes of every New York City firefighter and officer, a top Fire Department administrator has described a reckless atmosphere in which many of the department's safety rules are being ignored. Specifically citing the alteration of an oxygen mask that could pose a danger to firefighters, he warned that chiefs and officers could face transfers or other disciplinary measures if the safety rules are not more strictly enforced.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: THE CONVENTION

title: Looking Askance at Cooper-Hewitt Renovation
description: To the Editor:

title: Supporting Cast
description: Among the speakers on this evening's program:

title: A New Media Giant Puzzles About What To Do With Its Old Industrial Divisions
description: For months, Wall Street has been begging the Westinghouse Electric Corporation to split itself up. Without its sluggish industrial side, the theory goes, Westinghouse, which bought CBS for $5.4 billion last summer and is now spending $4.9 billion for the huge Infinity Broadcasting radio operation, would be a pure media company that could command share prices more than double the $15 or so at which the stock has been mired for several years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the New York Film Festival referred incompletely to the career of the director Richard Linklater. After his first film, ''Slacker,'' Mr. Linklater made ''Dazed and Confused'' and ''Before Sunrise.'' ''Suburbia,'' in this year's festival, is his fourth feature, not his second. The article also misstated the year that Andre Techine's film ''Wild Reeds'' was shown at the festival. It was 1994, not last year.

title: California Governor Cuts Off Aid for Illegal Immigrants
description: Moving aggressively under the new Federal welfare law to cut off state services to illegal immigrants, Gov. Pete Wilson today signed an executive order ending those immigrants' access to benefits ranging from public housing to prenatal care and child abuse prevention programs.

title: Municipal Elections in Bosnia Postponed, Raising Doubts About Troop Pullout
description: The Western official in charge of the September elections in Bosnia today postponed the vote for municipal officers around the country, citing ''widespread abuse of rules and regulations.''

title: 7 Iraqis Are Arrested in Britain After Hijacking From Sudan
description: Seven Iraqis seized control of a Sudan Airways jet with 196 people on board on a flight from the Sudan to Jordan Monday night, forcing it to fly to Britain before releasing the passengers and crew and giving up this afternoon.

title: New Chief Executive Of AST Is Named
description: Just weeks after posting its ninth consecutive quarterly loss, the computer maker AST Research Inc. said today that Ian Diery had resigned as chief executive and president to pursue other interests.

title: 'Boarder Baby' Suit Planned
description: A children's advocacy group plans to file a lawsuit today accusing the state of warehousing hundreds of infants in hospital wards even though they are ready to be discharged.

title: Boeing Anticipates Hiring Another 5,000 Employees
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it would hire as many as 5,000 new employees to meet growing demand for its commercial aircraft. The company also said that production of its newest model, the 777 midsize jet, would increase to seven airplanes a month in July 1997 from the current five.

title: Democrats Lay Claim to Family Values
description: The Democratic Party offered Americans its own version of family values tonight, led by Hillary Rodham Clinton, one of the party's most polarizing figures, who reached out to a constituency hotly contested by both parties with a talk about family issues and about her own family: her daughter, Chelsea, and her husband, the President.

title: Rutgers Picks a Quarterback
description: Looking for more mobility in his West Coast offense, Rutgers Coach TERRY SHEA announced that COREY VALENTINE would be the starting quarterback in Saturday's season opener against Villanova. Valentine, a sophomore known for his quick feet and ''soft-touch'' passing game, had been battling for the starting position with the hard-throwing junior RALPH SACCA since Rutgers's monthlong camp began. (AP)

title: Game Plan For Jets: Stop Elway
description: So what is the big deal when the Jets open their season Sunday against John Elway and the Broncos in Denver?

title: Hospital Contract Passed
description: Workers for 13 New York hospitals and nursing homes approved a new contract yesterday, ending a strike that began on June 24 and clearing the way for their return to work by the end of the week.

title: Stalemate in Cyprus
description: The forcible division of Cyprus into Greek and Turkish zones is as unsatisfactory and dangerous an arrangement today as it was when Turkish troops first partitioned the island in 1974 in response to a Greek coup attempt. Only a negotiated political settlement can assure peace in Cyprus and remove the danger of military conflict between Greece and Turkey. Although a United Nations-monitored cease-fire has held for the intervening 22 years, Greece and Turkey remain capable of going to war over Cyprus, in the process damaging the NATO alliance, to which both belong. The violent deaths of two Greek Cypriots in two separate incidents this month underline the dangers.

title: Penn State Lineman Injured
description: JASON HENDERSON, a Penn State senior lineman, will be sidelined at least six weeks after breaking a bone in his foot during Sunday's Kickoff Classic. The 6-foot-7-inch, 276-pound offensive tackle broke the first metatarsal bone in his right foot, said Dr. WAYNE SEBASTIANELLI, the university's director of athletic medicine. (AP)

title: U.S. Opens Quiet Talks With Rulers Of Nigeria
description: Six months after proposing tougher sanctions against Nigeria's military dictatorship that have yet to win broad international support, the Clinton Administration has taken a gentler tack, highlighted by a special envoy's trip to Nigeria last week to explore the possibility of diplomatic discussions on human rights and democracy.

title: Arafat Becomes Party To Palestinian Misery
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Notes
description: Eclair Is for Sale

title: Penalties Expected For the Bowe Camp
description: The New York State Athletic Commission seems ready to penalize Riddick Bowe's manager, Rock Newman, and perhaps Bowe, the former heavyweight champion, after a brawl following his fight last month against Andrew Golata in Madison Square Garden.

title: Saratoga Waters
description: To The Living Section:

title: A unit of Disney finds an ideal space among the remnants of the military-industrial complex.
description: A DIVISION of the Walt Disney Company plans to take occupancy of a 200,000-square-foot building once used to develop military projects. The lease is a further example of the move by entertainment-related activities to replace aerospace and military-related work in huge industrial buildings.

title: A Woman Comes to Politics Via Personal Trial
description: She calls herself a ''gentle voice'' and ''average person.'' But Carolyn McCarthy, one of the speakers at the convention tonight, has emerged as a leading combatant in the Democrats' effort to retake Congress, a neophyte candidate whose star power is built more on her personal trials than political ambitions.

title: Safe Bottled Water
description: To The Living Section:

title: Today's Schedule
description: All times are Eastern.

title: 'Hughie' Extends Run
description: The Circle in the Square production of Eugene O'Neill's ''Hughie,'' starring Al Pacino, has been extended through Oct. 9. The show, already extended once, was to close on Sept. 14. Mr. Pacino has stipulated that 100 tickets be set aside for each performance during the extension and sold at $20 each. Starting on Monday, these tickets will be sold to students and the public beginning at 10 A.M. on the day of the performance at the theater's box office, 50th Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue.

title: It's Now Confirmed: Tiger Woods Is a Pro
description: As expected, the three-time United States Amateur champion Tiger Woods confirmed today that he has turned professional. He said he would discuss the decision further at a news conference on Wednesday at the Greater Milwaukee Open.

title: Challenge to Milken Settlement Revived
description: The United States Court of Appeals in New York late Monday revived a challenge by TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc. to the 1992 global settlement of claims against Michael R. Milken and others associated with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the securities firm that filed for bankruptcy protection in January 1990.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Former Vice President DAN QUAYLE may be moving to Arizona, but he will always be a Hoosier at heart -- and maybe in the polling place.

title: We Don't Get Good Return on Our Foreign Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. TRAINING CAMP REPORT
description: Pittsburgh Steelers

title: 3 More Dynasties
description: To The Living Section:

title: Caradon Is Selling 15 of Its European Units
description: Caradon P.L.C., a British maker of heating equipment and bathroom products, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell most of its European engineering and distribution businesses for at least $:190 million ($296.4 million) to a British venture capital company. It did not name the buyer of the 15 businesses, which had profits of $:21 million ($32.8 million) in 1995 on sales of $:264 million ($411.8 million).

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a planned reorganization of Lloyd's of London referred incorrectly to a similar revamping by the Cigna Corporation. Cigna divided its property and casualty business into two units; it did not split the entire company.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GREAT LAKES CHEMICAL CORP., West Lafayette, Ind., a specialty chemicals maker, said its board had authorized the repurchase of as many as 4 million shares.

title: History's Fellow Travelers Cling to Mao's Road
description: There was a time, nearly 50 years ago, when revolutionary fervor in China attracted left-leaning Americans, with its mantras of self-reliance and manual labor, and its promise of achieving a socialist dream.

title: Eating Well
description: FROM hippie to hip capitalist in 18 years.

title: Matsushita, Freed of MCA, Reports a Profit
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company rebounded to profit in the latest quarter, as a weaker Japanese yen and better sales helped the company overturn last year's losses from an ill-advised foray into the Hollywood movie business.

title: People
description: Susan D. Plagemann, advertising director of Esquire, New York, which is published by the Hearst Magazines unit of the Hearst Corp., was promoted to the new position of associate publisher.

title: Blending Disability With Celebrity to Lure Viewers
description: ''We meet here to offer vision, not just a show for television.'' So announced Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, in his few nonprime-time minutes on the podium in Chicago on Monday night. Promises, promises.

title: As Cone Returns, Johnson Departs
description: David Cone and Randy Johnson were heroic figures in the decisive game of the Yankees-Mariner division series last October, two warriors who refused to wither and who wanted to pitch until the game was decided or until their bodies crumbled. Eventually, the latter happened to both.

title: Eating as a Family Ritual
description: To The Living Section:

title: Mets' Young Pitchers Do Not Hold a Grudge
description: Dallas Green's public criticism of Jason Isringhausen and Paul Wilson may have been one reason Green was fired by the Mets two days ago, but Isringhausen said his pitching had as much to do with it.

title: Appeals Panel Lifts a Bar to Lloyd's Plan
description: A Federal appeals court here cleared away a major legal obstacle today to the financial recovery plan for Lloyd's of London, the venerable insurance organization that has been crippled by billions in losses.

title: Yankees Are Going South by Northwest
description: Remember how proud the Yankees were of the trade that brought Graeme Lloyd and Pat Listach from the Brewers last Friday? Well, Listach is on the disabled list with a broken bone in his right foot and that is the good news. At least Listach hasn't hurt the Yankees. Lloyd definitely has.

title: Profit Motive Clouding Effort To Buy Up A-Bomb Material
description: The American Government-owned corporation that is charged with acquiring much of Russia's military stockpile of uranium for resale as civilian nuclear reactor fuel turned down repeated Russian offers this year to sell material sufficient to build 400 bombs comparable to the one that destroyed Hiroshima.

title: Strong Bills Are Ready to Chase an Elusive Title
description: It has been six seasons since Scott Norwood's 47-yard field-goal attempt sailed wide right with only four seconds to play and the Giants beat the Buffalo Bills in Super Bowl XXV. But since then the fortunes of the Bills have soared and those of the Giants have gone the way of Norwood's errant attempt.

title: Immigrant Finds Hope In Bank's Calm
description: LAST winter, Hao Ci Chen saw dress shirts all around him -- piles of them inside a noisy, windowless Brooklyn sweatshop, where he earned a penny for every dangling string he cut from each button. It wasn't a great job, but as is the case with many of his friends, it was all Hao Ci, a 14-year-old Chinese immigrant, could find in Sunset Park.

title: Clintons and Carters Don't Mix
description: The Republicans devoted a good chunk of their convention's prime TV time in San Diego to saluting former Presidents Ford, Reagan and Bush. In Chicago, by contrast, the Democrats have gone out of their way to avoid even acknowledging the existence of their party's only living former President.

title: Salvation for Nonbelievers? Not in the Bible
description: To the Editor:

title: Next Year, a Closer Look Will Be Costly at Open
description: The already extravagant cost of experiencing the United States Open tennis championships will get an expensive jolt next year when the tournament moves to a new 20,000-seat stadium being built within a lob of the old one.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Beeper a Lure in Sex Case
description: Electronic pagers are such status symbols for children nearing adolescence that a man was able to lure three boys into having sex with him merely by giving them a beeper's casing, a prosecutor said yesterday. The man, Eric J. Verga, 25, who worked at Beeper Warehouse in Waldwick, was arrested Monday on sexual assault charges after two of the boys told their parents, said Charles R. Buckley, the Acting Bergen County Prosecutor. - New Jersey Daily Briefing

title: Ex-Candidate to Stay True to Party
description: Professor Lamm spent his summer vacation running for President. Back on campus as practically a national household name, the failed Reform Party candidate vowed today to keep battling to break the two-party monopoly on American politics.

title: Quicker Than Thou. Funnier, Too.
description: LET the record show that when Dennis Miller sat down for a lunchtime interview at the Four Seasons Hotel, he did not eat lunch.

title: Dole Tries To Focus On Economy
description: Bob Dole took a break from sunbathing today to showcase his plan that he says is needed to perk up the economy -- even as new monthly figures showed that consumer confidence had reached a six-year high.

title: Valentine Earned His Second Shot
description: WHY him? What's he done lately? What's he ever done? Why can't they find a new face? Or why can't they get a top-of-the-line manager?

title: Ohio Paying Some Tuition for Religious School Students
description: Delvoland and Charlynn Shakespeare both attended the Cleveland public schools and they are determined that their sons will not do the same. They remember unruly students, uninterested teachers and security guards who could most reliably be found in the parking lot smoking pot. That was a decade ago. And things have only gotten worse, Mr. Shakespeare said.

title: No Headline
description: All the rights that made General Powell possible are now under assault for the next generation. -- JESSE JACKSON. $(A13:1.$)

title: Help Wanted?
description: If President Clinton is re-elected, his biggest cabinet decision may be whether to retain Warren Christopher as Secretary of State, and if not, with whom to replace him. The chatter inside the Administration is that Mr. Clinton will neither ask Mr. Christopher to go nor beg him to stay, but will leave the decision to him. While White House insiders say Mr. Christopher seems inclined to leave -- he'll soon break Secretary of State James Baker's record for frequent-flier miles -- he's made no final decision, and no one will rule out Christopher succeeding Christopher.

title: 'Four (12?) More Years': Albert Arnold Gore Jr.
description: ''This two-headed monster of Dole-Gingrich,'' Vice President Al Gore declared on Sunday, a sparkle in his eyes, a sinister tone in his voice, his entire body in motion, ''has launched an all-out assault on decades of progress on behalf of working men and women.''

title: Where Ladies Are Smart And Gents, Well, Genteel
description: The Kings County Shakespeare Company's production of ''Two Gentlemen of Verona'' in the band shell of Prospect Park in Brooklyn is pretty much what a happy summer theater presentation ought to be. Shakespeare's plot is as loose as ripped lace; the rustics are there for nothing but slapstick, and the mixture of poetic and prose styles makes pronunciation torture.

title: Officers Cleared in a Death
description: Three Ramsey police officers have been cleared of wrongdoing in the July 24 death of a man who was subdued with pepper spray during a struggle outside his condominium, the authorities said yesterday. An autopsy concluded that the man, Scott Tofano, who went limp while handcuffed and face down on the ground, died of asphyxiation, said Charles R. Buckley, Acting Prosecutor for Bergen County. Mr. Tofano had an enlarged heart and high levels of cocaine in his system, Mr. Buckley said. But Lawrence Biondi, the victim's brother-in-law, disputed the findings, saying that a medical examiner hired by the family determined that Mr. Tofano did not have a heart condition and that cocaine had nothing to do with his death.

title: 2 Strong Endorsements Of Clinton Presidency
description: The delegates of Bill Clinton's moderation-steeped Democratic convention were brought to their feet cheering tonight by the fiery old-line liberal rhetoric of two favorites of conventions past: Jesse Jackson and Mario M. Cuomo.

title: In Tijuana, Border Crackdown Hurts
description: For years, thousands of migrants have worked up voracious appetites and sometimes a night-time shiver in the hillside slums and dusty fields along the border fence here, as they wait hours and often days to sneak through the scrub into San Diego.

title: It's a Clashing of the Guard (Old vs. New) at American Stores
description: When Victor L. Lund, the chief executive of the American Stores Company, was told by his predecessor Lennie Sam Skaggs over a plate of eggs in 1992 that Mr. Skaggs had personally chosen him to take the helm of the then-troubled supermarket company, Mr. Lund knew he was taking on a big challenge. What he did not know was that one of the biggest problems he would face would be Mr. Skaggs himself.

title: Up Steep Flights of Stairs Into a Bit of the Recent Past
description: Stephanie Silvia's ''Solo and Other Flights,'' presented by North/South Dance on Monday night at the company studio (262 Bowery, near Houston Street, Lower East Side), was a trip into a somewhat lamented past. Up endless steep flights of wooden stairs, one tumbled into what was clearly someone's home for an evening of very home-grown dance of the sort that choreographers used to present with impunity in the 1970's.

title: A More Polite Police Force
description: Many Newark residents complain that they get snapped at when they call the police. So, less than two months after assuming his new post, Police Director Joseph J. Santiago announced a plan yesterday that is intended to teach officers and dispatchers to mind their manners and otherwise improve the department's image.

title: Patriots Owner Scolds Parcells
description: Coach BILL PARCELLS has been admonished by the owner of the New England Patriots, ROBERT KRAFT, for responding to a question about the rookie wide receiver TERRY GLENN by saying, ''She's making progress.''

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the opening of the Democratic convention in Chicago referred incorrectly in some editions to a jest by James Brady, a lifelong Republican and former press secretary for President Ronald Reagan. When Mr. Brady's wife, Sarah, joked that she and her husband seemed to have taken a wrong turn and failed to arrive in San Diego, Mr. Brady said, ''Sarah, this is the Democrat convention.'' He did not say ''isn't.''

title: The Big Givers List
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bounty of Cranberries
description: New Jersey's 42 cranberry farmers may have a record crop this year thanks to the cool and wet weather. Last year, the growers harvested a disappointing 454,000 barrels because of the heat, Neva Moore, a board member of the American Cranberry Growers Association, said yesterday. But this year, she said, they may exceed the 1994 record of 558,000 barrels. TERRY PRISTIN

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: On First Day of School, Trying to Move on From Flight 800
description: For her first day of 10th grade at Montoursville High School this morning, Desiree Phillips sported fresh white sneakers, a glinting mouthful of braces and a pin in the shape of an angel.

title: Executive Changes
description: DELPHI INFORMATION SYSTEMS INC., Rolling Meadows, Ill., said Denis Connaghan had resigned as its president and chief executive.

title: Transactions
description: Football

title: U.S. Demands Vesco's Return From Cuba, but It Is Unlikely
description: A day after a Cuban court convicted Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive American financier, of economic crimes, the Clinton Administration demanded again today that he be returned to face trial at home, though officials acknowledged that the chances seemed remote at best.

title: REPORT SHOWS U.S. WAS TOLD IN 1991 OF CHEMICAL ARMS
description: A long-classified intelligence report shows that the Pentagon, the White House, the Central Intelligence Agency and the State Department were alerted in November 1991 that chemical weapons had been stored in an Iraqi ammunition depot that was blown up earlier that year by a group of American troops.

title: Prosecution Case Is Built on Lies, Bomb-Plot Defendant Tells Jurors
description: Seizing his last chance to clear his name of charges that he plotted to blow up American jumbo jetliners in Asia, Ramzi Ahmed Yousef faced a Federal jury yesterday and argued for nearly three hours that he had been framed by the Philippines and Pakistan because they wanted to curry favor with the United States.

title: Roche Profits Rose 16% in Year's First Half
description: The drug company Roche Holding A.G. announced yesterday that its profits rose 16 percent in the first half of this year, helped by strong over-the-counter sales and a weaker Swiss franc. Roche earned 2.2 billion Swiss francs ($1.8 billion) in the first six months of 1996, up from 1.9 billion francs a year earlier. Sales were up 8 percent, to 7.8 billion francs ($6.6 billion) from 7.2 billion francs.

title: California Man Presses Free-Speech Suit Over Arrest at Bronx Presidential Debate
description: Deep in the United States Court House in lower Manhattan, where terrorists and mobsters and insider traders are called to account, a peculiar postscript to one man's adventure in Presidential politics is being written.

title: Pooh-Bahs and Princes High Above Hoi Polloi
description: The skybox Democrats emerge from time to time, peering onto the convention floor from their multiple imperial perches in a surreal variation on Huey Long's Depression-era dictum: ''Every man a king, but no man wears a crown.''

title: Bernard B. Jacobs, a Pillar of American Theater as Shubert Executive, Dies at 80
description: Bernard B. Jacobs, the president of the mighty Shubert Organization for 24 years and one of the most powerful men in the American theater, died yesterday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 80 and had homes in Manhattan and Shelter Island, L.I.

title: A Warning on Adelphi Trustees Case
description: The removal of Adelphi University's trustees would be catastrophic not only for that institution but for higher education throughout the nation, said Dr. John Silber, the chancellor of Boston University and a member of Adelphi's board.

title: Screening for Homelessness
description: New York City's leadership is right to insure that families seeking shelter at city expense really deserve it. The Draconian welfare-reform bill just passed in Washington, in addition to the declining Federal support for public housing, makes it especially vital to sort out the truly needy from those who feign homelessness to get better housing or move higher on the public housing waiting list. But Mayor Rudolph Giuliani must take special care not to throw deserving women and children into the streets. A motion filed yesterday in New York State Supreme Court suggests that the city might be doing just that.

title: The N.F.L. kicks off a campaign to unmask its incredible hulks.
description: STRIP a professional football player of his helmet, his padding and his uniform and what do you find? The National Football League would like you to discover -- apart from all the muscles and a scar or two -- an appealing personality that may help transform a fan into a fanatic.

title: Chefs' Tips: Always Taste but Never Refrigerate
description: THE eight chefs who assembled at the Union Square Greenmarket know how to produce an elegant bang for a plebeian buck.

title: A Yankee Collapse Is Not in Cards
description: Fans and other critics are never satisfied. The Yankees have been in first place for virtually four months, for every day since April 30, but their lead has shrunk by more than half during the past four weeks and the skeptics are convinced they are in the middle stages of a total collapse. Where is George Steinbrenner when you need him to do something dramatic to jolt the team back on track? Get another $5 million pitcher, get Mark McGwire, fire the manager.

title: Israeli High Court Under Attack by Religious Jews
description: The long-festering resentment that rigorously Orthodox Jews hold against Israel's activist Supreme Court broke into the open last week when several religious newspapers assailed the court's president as a ''new dictator'' and ''dangerous enemy.''

title: More Men May Seek Eating-Disorder Help
