description: THE number of young men being treated for eating disorders at a metropolitan New York hospital has been rising, a study there has found. Experts say the results may indicate either that the number of men who have such problems has increased or that more such men are seeking treatment.

title: Fish Union Investigated For Labor Violations
description: In a new phase of ongoing racketeering investigations at the Fulton Fish Market, Federal prosecutors are looking into allegations of labor law violations against the market's major union, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: With the payment of a $30 fee in a clerk's office, the 15-year marriage of the PRINCE AND PRINCESS OF WALES will officially come to an end today.

title: Chemical Weapons Pact
description: To the Editor:

title: Surprising West, Bosnia Hampers Independent TV
description: Efforts to create an independent television network that would give most Bosnians a more objective source of information have faltered because of what diplomats say is fierce opposition from an unexpected quarter: the Bosnian Government.

title: Stocks Higher, With Dow Gaining 17.38
description: Stocks rose yesterday as prospects for higher dividends and stronger-than-expected corporate earnings outweighed concerns that interest rates would rise.

title: Whitman Back on Bicycle
description: It's the end of August and time for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman to make another long-distance bicycle trip. Today, she plans to travel 45 miles along the Jersey Shore to promote tourism, her office said. The trip will begin in Sea Bright and end at Island Beach State Park.

title: CULBRO IN TALKS TO BUY CIGAR MAKER VILLAZON
description: The Culbro Corporation said yesterday that it was in preliminary talks to buy the cigar maker Villazon & Company. Villazon makes the Hoyo de Moneterey and Punch brands of premium cigars as well as moderately priced cigars. The closely held company, which is based in Tampa, Fla., makes about 70 million cigars at two factories in Honduras and one in Tampa. Culbro's General Cigar unit is the largest United States maker of premium cigars, rolling about 37 million of its Macanudo and Partegas brands in 1995. Culbro, of New York, also made 488 million moderately priced cigars under the Garcia Y Vega, White Owl and Tiparillo brands in 1995. Shares in Culbro rose $2.75, to $59.75, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SYLVESTER STALLONE rushed from the set of his latest movie, ''Copland,'' to attend to an even more important project: the birth early yesterday morning of his first daughter, SOPHIA ROSE, born to Mr. Stallone's fiancee, JENNIFER FLAVIN, a model, at South Miami Hospital.

title: Despite increased security at airports, there have been surprisingly few long lines or delays.
description: AIRLINE passengers have been pleasantly surprised that their trips to the airport have been more or less routine, even in the aftermath of the crash last month of Trans World Airlines Flight 800. Despite heightened security procedures, there have been few long lines or delays.

title: Police Raid Fly-by-Night Casino at Queens Synagogue for 2d Time in 2 Years
description: From across the metropolitan region, they came with cash and a gambling itch to the Kissena Jewish Center, an Orthodox synagogue in Queens where, four nights a week, a clandestine casino operated and the only prayers were for 7 or 11 on the dice.

title: White House Memo Deals With Delay in Surrender of Suicide Note
description: An internal White House memorandum indicates that Hillary Rodham Clinton sought to delay giving Federal law-enforcement officials an anguished note written by Vincent W. Foster Jr., the deputy White House counsel, shortly before his suicide in July 1993.

title: Art Films And Friend Are Helping Each Other Survive
description: For nearly a year Fabiano Canosa, the film programmer at the Joseph Papp Public Theater for 17 years, was a man without a movie screen, bumped from his job when the public's film program was suspended last August. Now he has a new home, the Anthology Film Archives in the East Village.

title: In Losing Turkey, Europe Played a Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Officials to Block Qaddafi Gift to Farrakhan
description: Clinton Administration officials said today that they would almost certainly reject an application from the Nation of Islam and its leader, Louis Farrakhan, to be allowed to accept a donation of more than $1 billion from Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya.

title: ATTEMPT TO CREATE AN ELECTRONIC TELEVISION GUIDE FAILS
description: United Video Satellite Group Inc. and the News Corporation said yesterday that they had ended talks to form an electronic television guide. United Video, based in Tulsa, Okla., said the companies were unable to agree on key provisions of the proposed venture, which was valued at about $350 million. In June, the companies reached a preliminary pact to form TV Guide Prevue Networks, a venture between the News Corporation's TV Guide unit and United Video's Prevue Network subsidiary, which operates the Prevue Channel on cable TV.

title: Clinton Economic Adviser Resigns His Post
description: Martin N. Baily, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that he had resigned to become a partner in the Washington office of McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm.

title: Barbershop Goes Into Retirement With Owner: Philosopher With a Straight Razor
description: Gregory Greenberg, his hair newly trimmed, paced the tiny marble- and mirror-filled Broadway Barber last evening, trying to explain why the retirement of Kay Demetriou, after a half-century of clipping, shaving and philosophizing, mattered.

title: Forehand to Strike Zone
description: Lindsay Davenport looked comfortable enough while defeating Adriana Serra-Zanetti, 6-2, 6-1, yesterday. But Davenport was a little nervous about her appearance at Shea Stadium last night; she wanted to make sure the first pitch she was to throw out before the Mets game didn't bounce up to the plate.

title: Guilty Plea in Irvin Case
description: A topless dancer indicted on drug charges along with Dallas Cowboys wide receiver MICHAEL IRVIN pleaded guilty yesterday in exchange for two years' deferred probation. ANGELA BECK, 22, pleaded guilty to a felony charge of cocaine possession, said Dallas County Assistant District Attorney MIKE GILLETT. The police found cocaine during a March 4 search of a motel room that Beck and JASMINE JENNIPHER NABWANGU occupied with Irvin.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: 10 Are Injured in Midtown By a Collapsing Scaffold
description: A 12-foot high scaffold that officials say they believe was overloaded with bricks came tumbling down onto a busy midtown Manhattan street yesterday, injuring 10 people and crushing several parked cars.

title: Chechens And Russians Sign Pact On Pullout
description: Russian and Chechen military commanders signed an agreement today committing them to a military disengagement in the ravaged capital of rebellious Chechnya. But the Russian official who brokered the truce, Aleksandr I. Lebed, remained pinned down in Moscow, unable to secure President Boris N. Yeltsin's blessing for a broader peace accord that is being denounced by Russian nationalists as a sell-out.

title: Greg Morris, 61, Television Actor
description: Greg Morris, who as the electronics expert on ''Mission: Impossible'' was one of the first black actors to star in a hit television show, died yesterday at his home in Las Vegas, Nev. He was 61.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Same Old Mets Spoil Valentine's Debut
description: In his first game as manager of the Mets, Bobby Valentine was treated to his first sour taste of one of the very things that led to the end of Dallas Green's tenure with the club on Monday.

title: Boiling Water
description: To The Living Section:

title: Personal Health
description: VIRTUALLY every woman who ovulates experiences premenstrual changes that three-fourths of women recognize as an impending period. For many, these changes involve symptoms, like breast tenderness, bloating or food cravings, that may be annoying or discomforting but that do not disrupt their lives.

title: California Pension Fund Fills Counsel Post
description: The $100 billion California Public Employees' Retirement System named Kayla J. Gillan its general counsel, a job that includes heading the fund's shareholder advocacy program.

title: Salvation for Nonbelievers? Not in the Bible
description: To the Editor:

title: Sitcoms Wrapped Around Comedians
description: Inside many of the season's new sitcoms, there's a stand-up comic struggling to get out. ''Nick Freno: Licensed Teacher'' and ''The Jamie Foxx Show'' (both with premieres tonight on WB) take comedians who seem more comfortable with one-liners and sketches, and wrap them in clunky sitcom packages.

title: ST. PAUL MAY SELL MINET GROUP INSURANCE UNIT
description: The St. Paul Companies said yesterday that it might sell its money-losing insurance brokerage, Minet Group, which analysts said could fetch $375 million. St. Paul, a property and casualty insurer, hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to help ''examine strategic alternatives'' for the unit, which arranges insurance coverage for businesses. St. Paul bought the unit, which is based in London, in 1988 for $621 million. Today, the subsidiary employs 3,700 workers in 32 offices worldwide.

title: 3 Giant Feed Companies Agree to Settle Price-Fixing Charges
description: Breaking open what the Government contended was an illegal international cartel, Federal prosecutors announced yesterday that three giant feed companies had agreed to settle criminal charges of price-fixing and testify against other participants in the conspiracy.

title: Shriver Handles Defeat a Chuckle at a Time
description: This is what you get. You get Pam Shriver staring into space after it was over, with her eyes about to spill and her chin about to quiver.

title: New Deal Lite
description: For many Americans, Christopher Reeve may well be a touching profile in courage, but Tom Baer, one of the Hollywood showmen behind this week's Democratic extravaganza, summed up Mr. Reeve's political appeal rather less poetically. Mr. Reeve, said a beaming Mr. Baer, ''is a 28 share.''

title: Teacher, Not a Celebrity
description: Stern and focused, planted behind the lectern, eschewing any attempt to top Elizabeth Dole in the charm sweepstakes, Hillary Rodham Clinton stuck to her guns tonight at the Democratic convention, playing the teacher and not the television personality in her much-anticipated appearance before the delegates gathered to renominate her husband.

title: Asia Builder Said To Forgo I.P.O.
description: Gordon Y. S. Wu, one of Asia's top builders, who brought superhighways to China, has abandoned plans to sell $9 billion (Hong Kong) of stock -- $1.16 billion -- in some of his road and rail businesses.

title: There's Goat Milk in the Dairy Case
description: GOAT'S milk and cookies? Goat's milk on cereal? In coffee?

title: Mall on Pier Changes Hands
description: Ocean One, a lackluster shopping mall on the old Million Dollar Pier in Atlantic City that was designed to resemble an ocean liner, has a new owner. The ITT Corporation, which acquired Caesars Atlantic City Hotel and Casino last year, announced yesterday that it has bought the mall from the Equitable Life Assurance Society. The price was not disclosed, but industry sources put it at between $15 million and $20 million.

title: Panel Members in Dissension On Hartford School Problems
description: Seven weeks after the State Supreme Court ruled that the concentration of poor minority students in Hartford's public schools violated the State Constitution, a state panel began seeking solutions to the problem today.

title: Supporting Cast
description: Among the speakers on this evening's program:

title: A Bronx Heart Among Green Mountains
description: GRACE PALEY writer, teacher, former city stroller -- was in her hilltop home, trying to cope with one of the realities of rural life in this town of hilly and sometimes slippery roads: car insurance.

title: Convention Summary
description: THE FORMALITIES OF CHOICE

title: Don't Pull the Plug -- Yet
description: Are the national nominating conventions obsolete? The short answer is no. They serve a valuable function for both the parties and the public. But they have surely changed dramatically, and it is hard to find anyone, except the political managers and the Hollywood types who put them together, who has a kind word to say about them. The 15,000 or so journalists who assembled in San Diego and now Chicago have tripped over themselves to find just the right adjective to describe their scorn and dismay -- ''prefabricated,'' ''scripted,'' ''prepackaged,'' ''manipulative'' and, worst of all, ''dull.''

title: The X-File Factor
description: I taught an astronomy course last fall on the possibility of extraterrestrial life. It was a general-education science class of about 20 students in which we began with evidence for the origin of life on Earth and used this information to speculate about the possibility of life, including advanced civilizations, elsewhere in the universe.

title: It's Official: Charles and Diana Split, and She Pays Her Own Bills
description: With the impersonal thwack of a rubber stamp, the tumultuous marriage of the Prince and Princess of Wales officially ended today, 15 years after it began.

title: California Bans Selling Live Animals as Food
description: To the Editor:

title: Netscape Product to Rely on I.B.M. System
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation will soon introduce a new version of its Navigator software for browsing the Internet's World Wide Web that will run on I.B.M.'s struggling OS/2 operating system, the two companies said yesterday.

title: Making Moral Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: VICTOR BORGE said he happened to open a desk drawer yesterday, and his eye was caught by the inscription on a long-forgotten envelope: ''Arrival in the U.S., August 28, 1940.''

title: Tiny Nevis, Chafing at Its Union With St. Kitts, Talks Divorce
description: With 46,000 people living on a pair of tiny Caribbean islands separated by only two miles of water, this country already holds the distinction of being the smallest in the Western Hemisphere. So why is Nevis, the smaller partner, threatening to secede and become a separate nation?

title: Find the Punishment to Fit Heinous Sex Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: FOAMEX TO SELL ITS JPS AUTOMOTIVE UNIT
description: Foamex International Inc. of Linwood, Pa., said yesterday that it would sell its JPS Automotive L.P. unit to a subsidiary of the Collins & Aikman Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., for $220 million, which includes about $198 million of debt. As a result of the sale, Foamex, a maker of foam products, said it expected to report a third-quarter loss of $59 million. Foamex also planned to restate its 1995 earnings to reflect discontinued operations, resulting in a loss from continuing operations of $1.89 a share. Foamex had sold its Perfect Fit unit earlier this month. In February, the company posted a loss of $53.1 million, or $2.01 a share, for 1995. Because of the sales, the company said it would cut its long-term debt to $460 million from $724 million, as of June 30.

title: Pete's Brewing Names Gotham
description: Pete's Brewing Company in Palo Alto, Calif., has named Gotham Inc. in New York as agency of record. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $3 million to $4 million.

title: Net Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: While the donkeys and elephants are having their quadrennial parties, what does the only Independent in Congress do? Representive BERNARD SANDERS, Socialist of Vermont, spent last weekend playing the back half of a tiger at the annual circus put on by the Bread and Puppet Theater, the international political satire troupe, in Glover, Vt.

title: Welder Ignites School Fire
description: A maintenance worker preparing an elementary school for the opening of school was critically injured when his welding torch ignited a natural-gas main yesterday morning, the police said. Although a wall at the Gillette School was partially engulfed in flames, school officials said that there was no permanent damage and that school would open on Sept. 4, as planned. The worker, Charles Hamma, was in stable condition at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston.

title: Acer Reports a Drop In 6-Months' Profits
description: The Taiwan personal computer maker Acer Inc. said yesterday that its profit fell 17.3 percent in the six months ended June 30 because of lower prices for memory chips and a write-off at its United States subsidiary. Acer also said it had halved its forecast of 1996 net profit to 3 billion Taiwan dollars, or $109.1 million.

title: Woods Says Hello to New World
description: Tiger Woods was on the range beating balls as the afternoon sun waned today on the eve of the Greater Milwaukee Open. He was at a spot between Olin Browne and Robert Wrenn, 115th and 164th on the money list respectively, and buzzing around him were golf club reps, agents, photographers and soundmen. A Nike representative tugged at his sleeve, pulling him off for a quick ad photo shoot.

title: John T. Garrity, 72, Management Expert
description: John T. Garrity, a former managing director of McKinsey & Company, the management consulting firm, and a founder of the Advanced Management Institute, died on Saturday at his home on Gibson Island, Md. He was 72.

title: Sale of Rest of Compuserve Is Delayed by H & R Block
description: H & R Block Inc. will delay the spinoff of its remaining 80 percent stake in the Compuserve Corporation, the country's second-largest on-line service, Block announced yesterday, citing Compuserve's recent quarterly losses and uncertainty in the on-line market as reasons for the decision.

title: On the Air - On Line
description: All times are Eastern

title: Ann Taylor Alters Deal With Cygne
description: The Ann Taylor Stores Corporation said yesterday that it had renegotiated the agreement to purchase Cygne Designs Inc.'s interest in their CAT U.S. Inc. joint venture and a Cygne unit to account for Ann Taylor's falling stock price.

title: Today's Schedule
description: All times are Eastern.

title: GLEASON PLANS TO ACQUIRE HERMANN PFAUTER GROUP
description: The Gleason Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Hermann Pfauter Group for an undisclosed sum. Pfauter, which makes equipment for producing cylindrical gears, has operations in Germany, where it is based, as well as the United States and Italy and has about 1,050 employees. The acquisition includes Pfauter's 76 percent interest in Pfauter-Maag Cutting Tools Inc., a producer of cylindrical gear cutting tools in the United States. Combined sales for the Pfauter operations were about $175 million in 1995. Gleason, based in Rochester, makes gear-production equipment.

title: Metallgesellschaft Set To Merge 2 Units
description: Metallgesellschaft A.G. said yesterday that it would merge its two plant construction units, folding Lentjes A.G. into Lurgi A.G.

title: Paper Designs (Don't Toss Out!)
description: FOR students, it's time for the paper chase once again. And to offer a head start, there are inexpensive paper products that can tell time, hold water -- or even hold more paper.

title: Giving Sick Pay Back
description: When Sgt. James McCauley of the Scotch Plains police retired on Aug. 1 after 25 years with the Union County Prosecutor's office, he could have done what most people do with their accumulated sick pay: pocket it. But Sergeant McCauley, 58, decided to donate the $6,000 he had coming to him to county employees who have exhausted their sick pay because of chronic illnesses. ''I have had a full and great career down there, I paid for my home, my kids' education, so I figure I had to give something back,'' Sergeant McCauley said earlier this week. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Red Lion Hotels In Merger Talks
description: Red Lion Hotels Inc. said today that it was in talks to be acquired by the Doubletree Corporation for an undisclosed amount.

title: A Few Curves Give An L Some Flair
description: TAKE a city mesmerized by its prewar elegance and then load it with new apartment houses full of banal boxes. What's one sure result? Call it a charm gap.

title: Clinton to Sum Up the Past and Look Ahead
description: Days away from the acceptance speech that will propel him into the general election campaign, President Clinton gazed out from his train-car on Monday and pronounced his address near ready.

title: Giuliani Promotes His Chief of Staff to No. 2 Spot
description: Tightening his inner circle of top aides, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday promoted his chief of staff, Randy M. Mastro, to the position of Deputy Mayor for Operations, effectively making him the second-in-command at City Hall.

title: Blazejowski Joins New League
description: CAROL BLAZEJOWSKI, regarded as one of the best to play women's basketball, is joining the new Women's National Basketball Association. She will be the league's director of basketball development. The league said Blazejowski will oversee a variety of national and community-based initiatives aimed at creating grass-roots awareness and interest in the league. Blazejowski played at Montclair State, where she was a three-time all-American. (AP)

title: The Chechen Buck Stops Where? Not in Kremlin
description: A country that has wondered whether its president would play a visible role in ending the war in Chechnya got an answer of sorts today.

title: Judge Rules for Philadelphia Officials in '85 Attack on Move
description: A Federal judge has ruled that Philadelphia's former police and fire commissioners will not have to pay damages to survivors or relatives of a devastating fire 11 years ago involving the radical group Move.

title: Seemingly Harmless Virus Tied to Reclogged Arteries
description: Each year, in medical centers around the country, cardiologists open clogged arteries, only to have the obstructions grow back in about half the patients. But no one has been able to predict which patients will have this regrowth or to prevent it.

title: Fleeing Hitler in Vain, by Luxury Ship
description: In the spring of 1939, the Nazi Government allowed 937 German Jews who could afford the fare to board a luxury cruise ship to Cuba, where corrupt officials had agreed, for a sum, to let them in. The unfortunately titled ''Voyage of the Damned'' tells the story of their trip, which began in hope and turned to despair when Havana suddenly barred their entry.

title: Greg Morris, 61, Debonair Star Of TV's 'Mission Impossible'
description: Greg Morris, who in portraying the electronics expert on ''Mission: Impossible'' was one of the first black actors to star in a hit television show, died on Tuesday at his home in Las Vegas, Nev. He was 61.

title: Longer Lives Create a Field Of Legal Need
description: THE exasperating thing about having a law practice that specializes in serving older people, Lawrence E. Davidow says, is all the calls from other lawyers seeking advice.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Target Plans to Stop Sales Of Tobacco, Citing Costs

title: Stationery That Rattles Etiquette
description: DURING the last two months, Ellen Hemrick-Giles has been sending thank-you notes for all the wedding gifts she has received. Her printed cards say ''Mrs. and Mrs. Hemrick-Giles.''

title: The Pop Life
description: Shopping for New Releases

title: Anglo American Deal With a Black Group
description: The Anglo American Corporation of South Africa Ltd. said yesterday that it would sell a 20 percent stake in the Johnnies Industrial Corporation to the National Empowerment Consortium, a group representing black business people and trade unions. Anglo first announced its intention two years ago to sell a stake in the company to increase blacks' participation in the economy.

title: Strolls in Robe Notwithstanding, Mob Figure Must Stand Trial
description: Vincent Gigante, considered the most powerful Mafia boss in America but perhaps best known for walking through his Greenwich Village neighborhood in a bathrobe and pajamas, was declared mentally competent to stand trial on murder and racketeering charges yesterday by a judge who called his odd behavior an ''elaborate deception.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17

title: Real Estate Feeding Frenzy a la U.S.May Be in Store for the Continent
description: The breakfast room at the Grand Hotel Inter-Continental on Rue Scribe in Paris seems an unlikely roost for ''vulture'' investors.

title: For Giants, A Flurry To Tie Up Loose Ends
description: The action on the field does not start until Sunday, but off the field the Giants are being extremely aggressive in terms of signing their own players.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CYCLING

title: As 2 Women Contest a Seat, Feminists Split
description: WHILE Democrats are soft-pedaling dissent at their national convention in Chicago, Democrats in New York are doing what they always do: knocking each other around.

title: The People of Kwangju Recall 1980 Massacre
description: When paratroopers stormed City Hall here 16 years ago, committing a massacre that has haunted this country ever since, Kim Young Chul was deep inside the building, clutching his gun.

title: Search for Clues in T.W.A. Crash Shifts East
description: Stymied by a string of dead ends and partial hints, the hunt for the cause of the blast that destroyed Trans World Airlines Flight 800 shifted several miles east today.

title: Gene Therapy for Lung Cancer Shows Promise, a Study Finds
description: The first study of gene therapy in people with lung cancer has shown that such treatment can shrink some tumors or halt their growth without toxic side effects, scientists announced yesterday.

title: Bridge
description: There is one North American bridge record that will never, paradoxically, be won by an American or a Canadian. It is the record for the fastest acquisition of the title of life master, and that is because a player who learns the game on his native soil acquires his expertise and his master points slowly, while a foreign player with a developed talent can get quickly out of the starting blocks.

title: Red Wings Trade Ciccarelli
description: The Detroit Red Wings traded right wing DINO CICCARELLI to the Tampa Bay Lightning yesterday for a conditional draft choice. The Red Wings coach, SCOTTY BOWMAN, in announcing the deal, said the impending waiver draft meant the team could not protect more than 18 players, a limit it exceeded. Ciccarelli, 36, is the No. 12 goal-scorer in National Hockey League history. He averaged more than a point a game in 1,079 regular-season games for 16 seasons. (AP)

title: A Gentle Judge Who Comes Down Hard in His Rulings
description: Judge Eugene H. Nickerson, who issued yesterday's ruling finding Vincent (Chin) Gigante competent to stand trial, has been known for issuing pointed opinions from the bench.

title: Everything but Tennis
description: The United States Open tennis tournament has long been a rowdy misfit in the decorous world of international tennis competition. Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe played some of their best tennis at the Open, and uncorked some of their most explosive tantrums there. With corporate titans, political stars and Hollywood celebrities occupying courtside boxes, the top matches often have the feel of a heavyweight championship fight.

title: As the Clintons Speak, Chelsea Plays a Silent and Powerful Political Role
description: ''Oh, have you seen Chelsea at all tonight?'' Hillary Rodham Clinton asked her husband on the telephone on Tuesday night, in a scene broadcast live on NBC-TV after her speech. ''Oh, she looks so pretty.''

title: Woman Shoots a Burglar
description: When a teen-ager broke into her Cumberland County home last weekend through a kitchen window, Ruth Askins was ready for him. The 68-year-old woman got a .22-caliber pistol from under her pillow and fired one round, striking the 16-year-old burglar in the chest, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The youth fled on foot and was listed in stable condition yesterday at South Jersey Hospital in Bridgeton.

title: Miscellany
description: MTV Networks, a unit of Viacom Inc., signed 10 sponsors for the 1996 MTV Video Music Awards, to be held Wednesday at Radio City Music Hall. They are: Adidas A.G.; the Airwalk brand of sneakers sold by Items International; the AT&T Corp.; the Best Buy Co.; the Budweiser beer brand of the Anheuser-Busch Cos.; the Levi's jeans brand of Levi Strauss & Co.; Nike Inc.; the Pepsi-Cola Co. and Taco Bell units of Pepsico Inc., and the Sony Playstation video game system.

title: Matchup of Power Players
description: Although the European phase of the World Cup hockey tournament has been in progress for several days, the best games are expected in the North American bracket. They begin today with what may be the most important match of the first round: Canada against Russia in Vancouver, pitting two teams with a good chance to meet again in the two-of-three-games final round during the second week of September.

title: Randall Positive in Drug Test
description: FRANKIE RANDALL, who beat Argentina's JUAN COGGI to win the World Boxing Association junior welterweight title on Aug. 16, has tested positive for drugs. The Argentine Boxing Federation said yesterday in Buenos Aires that Randall tested positive for drugs. (AP)

title: INSIDE
description: After a Fair, Vaccinations

title: Harassment Case Is Settled
description: A sportswriter who said she was dismissed after complaining about a supervisor's amorous advances, including a love letter and a gift of a heart-shaped plate, was awarded a $200,000 settlement yesterday, her lawyer said. The writer, Carmen Paul, worked for Dorf Feature Service for two years until she was dismissed six years ago, shortly after complaining about her boss, said Stuart S. Ball, one of her lawyers. Officials of Dorf, which provides The Star-Ledger of Newark with local high school and college sports coverage, declined to comment.

title: IMATION TO BUY LUMINOUS SOFTWARE COMPANY
description: The Imation Corporation, which was spun off from the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company two months ago, agreed yesterday to buy the Luminous Corporation, a closely held publishing software company, for an undisclosed amount of cash and stock. Luminous, based in Seattle, is 20 percent-owned by Adobe Systems Inc. Its market-leading products, which prepare documents for printing on professional presses, include Trapwise, Presswise and Color Central. The acquisition would increase the number of Imation's digital products for the printing industry. Imation makes data storage and imaging products. Luminous, originally part of the Aldus Corporation, was spun off to investors in January by Adobe.

title: Last Water Is Ruled Safe
description: An advisory urging some 18,000 residents of Lyndhurst to boil their drinking water was lifted yesterday afternoon, five days after a power failure allowed untreated water from a Boonton reservoir to flow into the system, said Walter Friedrichs, the township's emergency management coordinator. Hoboken and Jersey City residents had been told Tuesday that they could again drink their water, which comes from the same system.

title: ISS Is Selling Its American Unit
description: ISS A.S., a Danish concern that is the world's largest cleaning company, said yesterday that it would sell its United States operation, ISS Inc., to Aaxis Ltd. of Canada. ISS also said that before the sale was completed, it would buy a 25 percent stake in Aaxis for about $3.6 million.

title: Mocking the Shams of Rock, But Borrowing All the Styles
description: Beck knows better than to believe in a rock singer's authenticity. At the Supper Club on Tuesday night, he performed as if he'd heard and seen it all: the blues and folk revivals of the 1960's, the big beats and sampled collages of hip-hop, the sappy earnestness of confessional songwriters, the defiant blitz of punk, the passive aggression of alternative rock. They were all equivalent, all artifices. ''Everywhere I look there's a dead end waiting,'' Beck sang in the set's opener, ''Devil's Haircut.''

title: Secretive Genovese Clan Seemed Almost Immune From the Law
description: Until this summer, the hierarchy of the Genovese crime family -- the Mafia's mightiest faction -- seemed immune from prosecution.

title: Citibank Is Moving London Headquarters
description: Citibank said yesterday that it would build a 500,000-square-foot British headquarters at Canary Wharf, becoming the latest blue-chip tenant to leave London's financial center for the office development in the outlying Docklands area.

title: Philip Morris Sticks to Form and Raises Quarterly Dividend
description: The board of the Philip Morris Companies voted yesterday to increase the regular quarterly dividend, continuing a string of increases that began almost three decades ago.

title: Party Liberals Hard at Work In Explaining Welfare Stand
description: They say they enthusiastically support the President. They say they will work like crazy to bring out his vote come November. But when urban Democrats at the national convention here try to explain why President Clinton signed the Republican-sponsored Federal welfare bill, they fidget uncomfortably and lower their voices.

title: Liberia's Press, Floored, Bounces Back, Swinging
description: When Phillip Wesseh, the 36-year-old editor of one of this city's leading newspapers, set out to inspect his offices during the first lull in the fighting that swept Monrovia in April, he did not expect to be exempted from the destruction. Then again, he did not expect to be totally wiped out either.

title: Vaccinations Ordered In Wake of Rabies Case
description: Health officials have been conducting the largest rabies vaccination effort in New York State history since a baby goat at a county fair had to be killed after it was determined to have rabies. The 6-month-old goat was one of the animals that hundreds of people visiting a livestock barn at the Tioga County Fair in Owego, N.Y., were able to pet. So far, more than 2,000 people have called a rabies emergency phone line, and 345 were found to have had enough risk of exposure to have begun the painful cycle of rabies shots. Some people may have been exposed to the disease by a friendly lick on a hand that already had an innocuous cut.

title: Warning: Tobacco Law May Stunt Racing's Growth
description: When Rusty Wallace pulled into Victory Lane at the Nascar race in Bristol, Tenn., last Saturday night, he had a message in addition to his obligatory thank-yous for crew members and sponsors: Vote for Bob Dole.

title: Plato, Behold the Zebra
description: To the Editor:

title: A Deal That Would Unite The Hiltons
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation is expected to announce Thursday that after months of discussions it has concluded a joint marketing agreement with the Ladbroke Group P.L.C., the British company that owns the Hilton Hotel international chain, people close to the company said.

title: Lester Leber, 83, Founder of Top Advertising Firm
description: Lester Leber, a leading figure in the advertising industry, died on Monday at his home in Key Largo, Fla. He was 83.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Question Of Pace: Is Selig's Too Slow?
description: Even as some owners continue to lobby against the agreement baseball's labor negotiators could conclude in a matter of hours, owners and others on the management side are growing increasingly frustrated by the delay initiated by Bud Selig, the acting commissioner.

title: Two Denied Ballot Spot
description: The state's highest court denied a request yesterday to place the Legislature's only father-and-son team back on the ballot for the Sept. 10 Democratic primary in the Bronx.

title: The Incumbent as a Riddle: William Jefferson Clinton
description: On Thursday night, when he accepts the renomination of a Democratic Party that he has alternately inspired and exasperated, William Jefferson Clinton will be at once the best-known and least-knowable politician in the land.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about plans by the Boeing Company to hire as many as 5,000 new employees misstated the change in the company's stock price on Tuesday. It rose 1 percent, not 10 percent.

title: It May Be the 'Party of the Future,' but It Has Few Young Stars
description: President Clinton arrived today in Convention City after a ride on the not accidentally named 21st Century Express. Democratic orators from Hillary Rodham Clinton to Mario M. Cuomo to Vice President Al Gore, tonight's headliner, picture theirs as the party of the future and the Republicans as prisoners of the past.

title: S.E.C. Acts to Improve Stock-Trade Prices for Investors
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted rules yesterday that are expected to allow individual investors to get better prices on many trades, particularly in the Nasdaq stock market, where brokers are likely to see their profit margins decline substantially.

title: Fairgoers Get Mass Alert Over Rabies in Baby Goat
description: Day after day for nearly a week this month, hundreds of people -- parents with children, grandparents with their children's children, children by themselves -- ambled through the cavernous livestock barn at the Tioga County Fair in Owego, N.Y. They admired the horses' elegant manes and mooed back at the cows.

title: Le Parti, C'est Moi
description: The Democrats came to Chicago in 1968 and lost the Presidency.

title: NatWest Hires Morgan Stanley Executive
description: NatWest Markets, the securities arm of National Westminster Bank P.L.C., said today that it had hired Steve Yamane from Morgan Stanley & Company to head its Asian equity trading and derivatives desk.

title: Find the Punishment to Fit Heinous Sex Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Another accepted truth under fire: electric cars = cleaner air.
description: ELECTRIC cars may be expensive today and barely capable of making the round trip to Grandma's house without a recharge. But just wait. Soon enough, they will be far more practical and start making a serious dent in the smog in Los Angeles, New York and half a dozen other cities that are light-years from compliance with Federal clean air standards.

title: Collecting the Ballast for Life's Storms
description: AS a furniture maker, I need a huge supply of hardware: nails, screws, bolts of varying lengths and diameters and in a selection of colors, finishes and metals.

title: Calendar: Classes And Places To Explore
description: Urban America

title: Traveling Clinton Finishes Speech
description: After a month of drafting and re-drafting, the scramble to add the last flourishes to President Clinton's speech at the Democratic convention took place on his campaign train, where speech writers competed for Mr. Clinton's time with crowds at the back platform of his Pullman car.

title: Valentine Is 0 for 2 After Mets Lose in 12
description: Bobby Valentine must be wondering when the Mets relievers will hold onto a game for him.

title: City Hires Consultants To Seek Stadium Funds
description: Months after speculation that the New York Yankees would soon abandon their South Bronx home circulated and eventually subsided, the stadium debate resurfaced again yesterday when city officials announced that they had hired a financial consultant to help the city devise ways to pay for new or renovated stadiums for both the Yankees and the New York Mets.

title: Martin Setting Up Office in California
description: The Martin Agency said yesterday that it would open the first creative office outside its Richmond headquarters, to be named Martin Creative Los Angeles. The office, to open next week in Santa Monica, Calif., will be headed by Jean Robaire, a longtime West Coast creative executive.

title: Dutch Publisher Buying Division of Little, Brown
description: The Dutch publishing house Wolters Kluwer N.V. announced the purchase yesterday of the professional division of Little, Brown & Company, a sale that a few months ago prompted the exodus of Little, Brown's chief executive.

title: Gasoline Prices Up as Demand Shows an Unexpected Spurt
description: Gasoline prices rose yesterday after a report showed that consumption had increased unexpectedly to its highest rate in more than a year, drawing down inventories.

title: Economic Recovery Seen as Weak in Japan
description: The Bank of Japan's quarterly survey of business sentiment signaled that the nation's economic recovery had been weaker than expected, indicating that the central bank was not likely to raise interest rates soon.

title: Swept in Seattle: Ejections Amid the Yankee Dejection
description: Their impatient owner has challenged them to play better. Their calm manager has admitted that they must stop talking and start winning. Their wives and friends want to know if they should still make plans for the post-season. But the Yankees do not have a clue, on or off the field. Their free fall continued tonight, and their frustration showed in a benches-clearing brawl.

title: 4 Pianists Focused on Extremes
description: Clifford Curzon

title: Back to the Storyboard for Sitcoms
description: One of the most anticipated new series of the fall television season, ''Ink,'' starring Ted Danson and Mary Steenburgen, announced this week that it was going back for an extensive retooling that will include spiking the first four episodes, which had already been completed. The CBS series, which will miss its scheduled Sept. 16 premiere and now has no projected starting date, was only the most prominent example of what some network and studio executives are describing as crises in the production of weekly prime-time series.

title: More Consolidation In Billboard Business
description: Universal Outdoor Holdings in Chicago, an outdoor advertising company that owns about 12,700 billboards in the Midwest, has agreed to buy Outdoor Advertising Holding in Orlando, Fla., for an estimated $240 million. Outdoor Advertising Holding is the parent of a concern with about 6,400 billboards and other outdoor advertising units in Florida, South Carolina and Tennessee. The acquisition is the most recent in a series that has been rapidly consolidating the outdoor and out-of-home advertising industry.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AUTOSTOCK INC., Montreal, an auto parts retailer, said it had agreed to buy 24 Autostock warehouses outside Quebec and 125 Apple Auto Glass stores from TCG International Inc. for $49 million, or $35.8 million (United States).

title: Canadian Union To Bargain First With Chrysler
description: The Canadian Automobile Workers union announced today that it had chosen the Chrysler Corporation as its primary target for labor contract negotiations and a possible strike this autumn, the latest step in a strategy closely coordinated with American auto-union leaders.

title: Dollar Gains on Yen as Chance Of a Japanese Rate Rise Dims
description: The dollar surged against the yen yesterday after unexpected weakness in a Bank of Japan survey dashed expectations of higher Japanese interest rates.

title: William the Testy
description: Twice in the past month President Clinton has lost his temper in public.

title: A Class Act Without An Encore
description: THEY met briefly yesterday morning, in the corner of a crowded men's locker room, stopping to chat before heading out to spin a few off-day serves. Pete Sampras didn't congratulate Stefan Edberg for defeating Richard Krajicek the previous day. Champions don't pat each other on the back. They don't have to.

title: MISSISSIPPI CHEMICAL TO GET FERTILIZER UNIT
description: The Mississippi Chemical Corporation plans to buy the fertilizer operations of the First Mississippi Corporation for about $147 million in stock and the assumption of about $150 million in debt. Shares of First Mississippi jumped $3.125, or 13 percent, to $27.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. Mississippi Chemical's shares rose $1.375, to $22.675, on the Nasdaq. Under the terms of the agreement, which was announced late Tuesday, First Mississippi will spin off its chemicals operations and related businesses to its shareholders. In exchange for the fertilizer business, First Mississippi stockholders will receive 0.335 Mississippi Chemical share for each share held, though the ratio might be adjusted.

title: Ever Cheer for the Most Violists Batted In?
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ''We're at a point now where we are bleeding at the jugular, and the school board is putting little Band-Aids on the wrist, the knee and the ankle.''

title: Target Chain, Citing Costs, to Stop Selling Cigarettes
description: The Target chain, the nation's third-largest discount retailer, said yesterday that it would stop selling cigarettes because it was costing too much to keep them out of the hands of minors.

title: Ferreira, South Africa's Best, Is Stunned by Nainkin, the World's 215th Best
description: Where else except the United States Open would ninth-seeded Wayne Ferreira, often hailed as the greatest tennis talent to come out of South Africa, find himself bushwhacked in the first round by 215th-ranked David Nainkin, a tennis nobody with a Grand Slam portfolio containing zero victories and five fast losses?

title: Reliving the 'Gigantic Drama' of the Dreyfus Affair
description: THE ACCUSED

title: Delay Bosnia's Elections
description: Campaign intimidation and fraudulent voter registration in Bosnia have reached the point where minimally acceptable conditions for national elections on Sept. 14 no longer exist. The voting should be postponed 30 days and more active steps taken by NATO forces and civilian election supervisors to remedy the worst abuses by mid-October.

title: Cortines Denies Interest In Washington School Job
description: Despite a published report saying that he might be a candidate for Superintendent of the Washington, D.C., public schools, Ramon C. Cortines said yesterday that he was not interested in the job and had no reason to think it would be offered to him.

title: Bozeman Quits at California
description: His program under National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation and his personal integrity under attack, TODD BOZEMAN resigned yesterday after three and a half years as basketball coach at California.

title: Democrats Send Clinton Into Battle for a 2d Term
description: The Democratic Party tonight once again nominated Bill Clinton for President of the United States in a triumphant climax to his sometimes stormy four years in office, capping an evening of dire predictions about what might happen if the Republicans retake the White House.

title: Disappointing Gains For Alusuisse-Lonza
description: Alusuisse-Lonza Group of Switzerland said yesterday that its profit in the first half rose 5 percent, the lower end of expectations, as a decline in chemicals earnings offset higher profits in the packaging division. Alusuisse reported profits of 207 million Swiss francs, or $174 million, up from 197 million francs a year earlier.

title: Arguments Completed In Trial of 3 In Plot Case
description: Final arguments concluded yesterday in the trial of three men accused of plotting to bomb American jetliners last year, with the lawyer for one defendant, Wali Khan Amin Shah, asserting that the prosecution had still not proved that his client was involved.

title: Spotlight Shifts, and Chrebet Is in the Dark
description: ''My preseason days are over,'' the rookie announced today. ''And now it's time for me to be Keyshawn Johnson.''

title: Kemp Stumps For the Votes Of Minorities
description: Trying to draw poor minority voters from the Democratic Party, Jack Kemp toured the beleaguered South-Central section of this city today to argue that tax cuts and other incentives matter as much to people struggling for a toehold on the economic ladder as to those ensconced on an upper rung.

title: SONOCO PRODUCTS PURCHASES SPECIALTY PACKAGING
description: The Sonoco Products Company, a maker of industrial and consumer packaging, said yesterday that it had bought Specialty Packaging Group Inc., a maker of cans, fiber tubes and package designs. Terms were not disclosed. The privately held Specialty Packaging is based in Wausau, Wis. It has annual sales of $38 million. Sonoco Products is based in Hartsville, S.C.

title: Charter Schools Should Account to Taxpayers
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stocks traded lower here today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 156.65 points, or 0.76 percent, at 20,553.16. On Wednesday, the Nikkei lost 200.46 points, or about 1 percent.

title: First-Half Profits Disappoint At Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz
description: Ciba-Geigy A.G. and Sandoz A.G., which are merging to form one of the world's largest drug manufacturers, reported earnings gains for the first half of their fiscal years today that disappointed analysts.

title: Not Clean and Shiny
description: To the Editor:

title: CKE RESTAURANTS AGREES TO PURCHASE CASA BONITA
description: CKE Restaurants Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Casa Bonita Inc., the owner of 109 Taco Bueno fast-food Mexican restaurants, from Unigate P.L.C. of London for $42 million in cash. CKE, which operates about 665 Carl's Jr. fast-food outlets and other restaurants, said it planned to form a new company with outside investors to own and operate Casa Bonita. CKE plans to keep a majority interest. Shares in CKE rose $1.50, to $29, its highest close in about five years. Most of Casa Bonita's restaurants are in Texas and Oklahoma. Unigate said the sale would allow it to leave the United States restaurant market.

title: Japanese Court Rules Government Can Seize Land for U.S. Bases
description: In a move with far-reaching significance in the battle over American military bases in Japan, the Supreme Court here ruled unanimously today that the central Government has the authority to seize private land so that it can be used by United States forces.

title: Metro Digest
description: THE CONVENTION

title: Dole Criticizes Clinton as Lax On a Policy to Combat Drugs
description: Bob Dole and several California officials today attributed the recent rise in drug use among young people to what they called President Clinton's failure of moral leadership and by extension, his failure of character.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day yesterday showing the most recent results for the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company misidentified the quarter. It was the first, not the second.

title: Two Paths to One Goal: Reviving the Trombone
description: The band in residence at the Village Vanguard through Sunday, led by two young trombonists, Wycliffe Gordon and Ronald Westray, works because the two speak different though related languages.

title: Sale of BDDP Is Reported Close
description: BDDP Worldwide in Paris, the world's 15th-largest agency company, which has been for sale since the spring, is likely to be sold soon to an investment group led by top managers, executives with knowledge of the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Big Board Fines Prudential Securities
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it had fined Prudential Securities Inc. $125,000 for breaking the exchange's sales rules in 1992 and 1993.

title: Federal Panel Suggests Restrictions on Herbal Stimulant
description: Members of a Food and Drug Administration advisory committee today suggested that controversial and sometimes dangerous dietary supplements made with the natural stimulant ephedrine could probably stay on the market if made subject to new restrictions.

title: Lower Dividends For Hanson Spinoffs
description: Hanson P.L.C. sent shareholders details yesterday of its plans to spin off Imperial Tobacco Group and Millennium Chemicals, confirming they would pay lower dividends. Hanson said in January that it would split into four publicly traded companies. Hanson said Imperial, one of the biggest British cigarette makers, would have paid a dividend of 2 pence for each Hanson share if it had been independent in the current fiscal year, while Millennium's dividend would have been 0.55 pence.

title: Adding to State's Parks
description: Alighting from her bicycle, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed legislation yesterday to provide $173 million to preserve and develop open spaces and parks and to acquire watershed areas. The bill, the first appropriation under the Green Acres Bond Act that was passed by the voters last November, will add 24,000 acres to the state's parks, including 800 acres in the Wharton State Forest in the Pine Barrens.

title: Disappointing Auction Sends Bonds Lower
description: The Treasury's one-day market rally was cut short yesterday, as traders gave the Government's sale of five-year notes a disappointing reception.

title: The Fortunate Son And the First Daughter
description: John-John paced the sidewalk, anxiously awaiting Chelsea.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Bernard B. Jacobs, president of the Shubert Organization, misstated the given name and hometown of his son in some editions. He is Steven, not Jeffrey, and he lives in Oyster Bay, L.I., not Manhattan.

title: Group Seeks Reparations As Detainees
description: They were pulled from schoolhouses in Colombia and Bolivia and from offices and stores around Lima, Peru. Warships carried them to the United States, and trains left them at desolate camps near places like Missoula, Mont., and Crystal City, Tex. Some of them remained there, under guard and behind fences, for years.

title: In Maine, Egg Empire Is Under Fire
description: For more than three decades, Jack DeCoster has been an emblem of hard work and ambition in this little farming town, a self-made multimillionaire who started out with 125 hens and created an agricultural empire: Five million hens producing 23 million brown and white eggs a week.

title: U.S. Finds Mexico Is Adamant on Cuba Trade
description: An envoy of President Clinton swept through Mexico today on a mission to defend the Helms-Burton Act, which punishes foreign companies for doing business in Cuba. It promises to be an extraordinarily unpopular diplomatic pilgrimage.

title: Good Lighting Is More Than a Good Lamp
description: AT first, the gloom of a poorly lighted room seems inescapable, more like a vague depression than a decorating problem. Eventually, it may propel you to search for more fixtures: black lamps from Italy that can swivel and dip, sparkling track lights no bigger than plums or clear glass disks that hang from the ceiling, looking like supercharged halos.

title: Rules to Ease Forming of Doctor Networks
description: The Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department issued new rules yesterday making it easier for doctors to join together in networks and form other joint ventures to compete with insurance companies and health maintenance organizations.

title: One Convention Goal: Displaying Party's Advantage With Women
description: When the Republicans met in San Diego two weeks ago, they presented a procession of more than 40 women in four days, including the keynote speaker, a convention chairwoman, and, most memorably, Elizabeth Dole. As the Democrats closed out the third night of their convention this evening, they had already marched nearly 50 women across the stage and screen, including both Hillary Rodham Clinton and Tipper Gore.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Executive Changes
description: DIMON INC., Danville, Va., named Brian Harker chief financial officer and executive vice president and Dwight Ferguson to the vacant positions of president and chief operating officer of its flower division, Florimex Worldwide Inc.

title: Dances by Graham On a Summer's Night
description: The Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival is many things, from a few moments of unexpected entertainment for passing pedestrians to a long-anticipated evening out for aficionados who arrive early, armed with sandwiches and sun hats.

title: N.F.L. TRAINING CAMP REPORT
description: Buffalo Bills

title: An Outhouse in SoHo Yields Artifacts of 19th-Century Life
description: To Henry Ford, history was bunk. To Carl Sandburg, it was a pile of ashes. But to a New York City archeologist and her students, it is more particular: to them, history is an outhouse in the backyard of a three-story row house at 576 Broome Street in SoHo.

title: Betting Ring Chief, Pleading Guilty, Is Fined $1 Million
description: Raymond Marquez, also known as Spanish Raymond, who for decades was considered a king of the numbers racket in New York City, has pleaded guilty to illegal gambling charges and will pay a fine of $1 million, the Manhattan District Attorney's office announced yesterday.

title: Convention Speechmaking Is Losing Its TV Appeal
description: If you want political truth on television, maybe it's best to go to an almost-former politician. As reporters hunted for conflict on Tuesday, a favorite question was why Jesse Jackson and Mario Cuomo had been shunted away from the prime network hour of 10 to 11. Was it because they had been so loudly critical of President Clinton for signing the welfare reform bill?

title: Gray Fish Out; Stingrays In
description: Two 275-pound roughtail stingrays were released into the New Jersey State Aquarium's main fish tank yesterday after a four-week quarantine, and officials hoped they would make a splash. The stingrays, caught in the Atlantic Ocean, were acquired in hopes of boosting attendance, which has slipped somewhat this summer. Since the aquarium unveiled its $3.75 million renovation last summer -- with schools of exotic tropical fish replacing the dull gray and brown New Jersey fish that visitors had found boring -- attendance has improved by 14 percent, said Michael Crowther, the chief executive officer.

title: William M. Alexander, 84, Dies; Fostered Idea of Middle Schools
description: William M. Alexander, an educator who was a leader in the movement to supplant conventional junior high schools with middle schools that provide young adolescents with a smaller and more intimate educational environment, died on Tuesday at his home in Gainesville, Fla. He was 84.

title: Split in Japanese Coalition Hints at New Party
description: A leading politician announced his resignation from one of the parties in Japan's ruling coalition today, laying the groundwork for the formation of a new party and perhaps a long-awaited political realignment.

title: Tories Learn Limits of Personal Attacks on Demons (e.g., Laborites)
description: The Conservatives thought it would be snappy. They thought it would be pithy. And they thought, in the words of Michael Portillo, the Defense Secretary, that their latest anti-Labor advertisement would strip away their chief political opponent's cheery facade and ''reveal what lies beneath.''

title: U.S. Issues Guidelines to Help Doctors Form Health Networks
description: The Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department issued new guidelines today making it easier for doctors to band together and form their own networks and other joint ventures to compete with insurance companies and health maintenance organizations.

title: That Rumbling Being Heard Is Steinbrenner
description: George Steinbrenner has waited in the shadows, remaining mostly silent and supportive as the Yankees soared into first place by a whopping 12 games last month, then simmering as their cushion shrank to 4 games. Now Steinbrenner has grown irritated enough with his team's prolonged slump to challenge the Yankees to regroup and produce. Or else.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: What's new in logo land? Latching on to any icon that moves.
description: NO one expects McDonald's to give up its golden arches or Coca-Cola to abandon its signature red cans, but truth be told, Microsoft's flying windows icon is the wave of the future.

title: Mercedes-Benz Sales Increased 8% in Half
description: Worldwide sales for Mercedes-Benz A.G. were up nearly 8 percent in the first half of 1996, the unit of the German company Daimler-Benz said yesterday.

title: Accounts
description: Interpolis Insurance, Amsterdam, to McCann-Erickson Amsterdam, a unit of the Interpublic, as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: On Smoking, Gore Adds a Personal Note
description: His voice choked and his lips quivering, Vice President Al Gore contributed his personal experience tonight to the Clinton Administration's crusade against childhood smoking by describing in detail to the Democratic convention delegates his sister's gruesome death from lung cancer.

title: Former Rival Won't Back Perot's Race For President
description: Richard D. Lamm, the former Colorado Governor who failed to take the Reform Party's Presidential nomination from Ross Perot, announced today that he would not endorse Mr. Perot or any other Presidential candidate this year.

title: Mix-Up Seen in Backing Obesity Drug
description: The editor of The New England Journal of Medicine said yesterday that a ''genuine misunderstanding'' resulted in its publication of an editorial about a new weight-loss drug by authors who had been paid by companies selling the drug.

title: Dr. Kevorkian Runs Wild
description: Jack Kevorkian is on a rampage, and many who believe in doctor-assisted death are as horrified by what he is doing as are those on the other side of the debate.

title: I.B.M. Is Starting to Sell Networking Chips
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has started selling its proprietary networking chips for the growing multibillion-dollar market.

title: More Accusations Are Leveled At Adelphi University President
description: Gerald Jodice was an ex-convict when Adelphi University hired him for a maintenance job in 1983. But even after he was found to be stealing, he was promoted to an important managerial post by Adelphi's president, Dr. Peter Diamandopoulos, according to documents and testimony at a hearing yesterday.

title: Pakistan and China
description: To the Editor:

title: Stock Funds Seeing Cash Pour In Again
description: ''You say correction, I say buying opportunity.''

title: In One Town, Delaying Bosnia Vote Is Bitter News
description: In the seething, if nearly clandestine, world of the political opposition in this Croatian town, the news that municipal elections throughout Bosnia will be postponed for months was crushing.

title: Angry at Netanyahu, Arafat Calls General Strike
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, charged today that the expansion of Jewish settlements and actions in Jerusalem by the Israeli Government amounted to a ''declaration of war on the Palestinian people,'' and he called for a general strike on Thursday morning.

title: Dole Evoked a Poignant Note on Segregation
description: To the Editor:

title: REEBOK INVESTORS TENDER 17 MILLION SHARES FOR BUYBACK
description: Reebok International Ltd. said yesterday that investors had tendered about 17 million shares for repurchase, fewer than the 24 million its board had authorized. Reebok, the maker of athletic shoes, originally planned in late July to spend as much as $864 million, based on a price of $36 a share, to buy 33 percent of its stock in a ''Dutch auction.'' The company will now spend $612.7 million to buy 23 percent of its shares. The company also said that it would discontinue its dividend after a final quarterly payment of 7.5 cents a share on Oct. 2. The cash will be used to pay off a bank loan that will finance the stock repurchase. Shares of Reebok rose 31.25 cents, to $35.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Banner Year for Black Spot

title: Reflections From Dallas Green, Now a Gentleman Farmer
description: Two days after being given leave from what may be his last job in baseball, Dallas Green digested a 41-year career most recently marked by his dismissal as manager of the Mets and said he was not going away an angry man.

title: When All the World's a Box and the Actors Stagehands
description: AS the protagonist's world begins to deconstruct, so, too, does the set in the production of Shakespeare's ''Timon of Athens'' playing through Sunday at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

title: ENROLLMENT SURGE IN NEW YORK CITY STRAINS SCHOOLS
description: New York City's public schools are so crowded this year that thousands of their 1.06 million students will report to class next week at such unlikely places as a converted World War II torpedo factory in Brooklyn, a renovated department store in Queens, the upper floors of the Town Hall theater in midtown Manhattan and dozens of temporary aluminum trailers scattered in schoolyards across the city.

title: From Newfoundland, Songs of Rum and Shipwrecks
description: If songs are any guide, Newfoundlanders are fascinated by drinking and sinking. Three folk-pop bands from Newfoundland -- Great Big Sea, the Irish Descendants and the Punters -- performed on Wednesday night at the Bottom Line, singing about rum, shipwrecks, love and looking for work overseas. Behind the joviality, the bands' songs and patter kept alluding to problems in Newfoundland's economy.

title: Nationsbank Said to Be Set For Big Merger
description: Nationsbank, returning to an aggressive acquisition strategy after sitting out last year's flurry of big bank mergers, has agreed to buy Boatmen's Bancshares of St. Louis for $9.2 billion in stock and cash, people familiar with the transaction said yesterday.

title: Hurricane and Europe Demand Send Prices of Heating Oil Up
description: Heating oil prices rose sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, lifting crude oil, on concerns that robust European demand and a hurricane in the Caribbean would reduce shipments to the United States.

title: For Canada's brash young mining companies, that pot of gold may depend on acquisitions.
description: THE $800 million takeover by the Barrick Gold Corporation, North America's biggest gold producer, of Arequipa Resources, a tiny, four-year-old Vancouver company with potentially rich deposits in Peru, is spurring renewed interest in Canada's plentiful supply of junior mining stocks.

title: Strong U.S. Team Faces Tough Tests
description: They look like a team, these National Hockey League professionals of Team USA in the World Cup of hockey. They dress in blue blazers, khaki slacks, white shirts and red, white and blue neckties.

title: A Yankee Comedy of Errors Has No One Laughing
description: Each loss looks uglier than the one before. Each loss is one more chance for the Baltimore Orioles and the Boston Red Sox to climb nearer to the top of the American League East. Each loss is more painful, puzzling and perplexing. Did the real Yankees get kidnapped last month? Or are these the real Yankees?

title: I.M.F. May Sell Gold to Cut Debt Load of Poor
description: The International Monetary Fund has indicated for the first time that it may be willing to sell some of its $40 billion supply of gold and use the proceeds as an outright gift to reduce the foreign debts of the poorest developing countries, allowing them to improve economic growth and attract more foreign investment.

title: Who Will Fill the Void on Shubert Alley?
description: Alan Eisenberg, the executive secretary of Actors' Equity, finds it hard to imagine what Shubert Alley is going to be like without Bernard B. Jacobs, an old theater pro who was both his friend and adversary. ''He was a businessman and he was a suit,'' Mr. Eisenberg said, ''but he was a real cool guy when it came to the artistry of the business.''

title: Ex-Official Faces Sex Charge
description: The former president of the Newark City Council has been accused of sexually assaulting a woman he met in a nightclub, the police said yesterday. Gary S. Harris, who was forced to resign last year after he was convicted of accepting bribes, offered the woman a ride home from the club on Aug. 17, but said he had to stop at his house first, said Sgt. Derek Glenn. While she was waiting in Mr. Harris's living room, he came downstairs undressed and accosted her, Sergeant Glenn said.

title: Big Theater Is Proposed For Complex In Queens
description: A company founded by the basketball star Magic Johnson is opening a multi-screen movie theater in a new multimillion-dollar retail and entertainment complex planned for South Jamaica, Queens, the largest private investment in the community in decades, an official said yesterday.

title: The Exploding Strategist
description: President Clinton delivered his convention speech like the luckiest guy in Chicago instead of a candidate whose grand entrance had been marred by the year's messiest bit of campaign gossip. Until yesterday, his luck had seemed too good to last, and that turned out to be the case. Dick Morris, the undisputed author of Mr. Clinton's comeback, was the cause of a uniquely ill-timed gust of bad publicity for a White House that has seen its share of ill winds. Allegations that Mr. Morris frolicked with a Virginia prostitute came trailing clouds of irony. One of his special gifts had been crafting issues affirming family values and the sanctity of the home that invited voters to forget Mr. Clinton's confessions of infidelity.

title: G.O.P. Views Aide's Fall As Validating Dole Strategy
description: The fall of Dick Morris, President Clinton's top adviser, plays perfectly into the strategy of Bob Dole's Presidential campaign, Dole aides suggested today.

title: Restaurants
description: If George Rector, the author of the well-regarded ''Dining in New York'' in 1939, were to stroll through the restaurants of modern Manhattan, he would find very little to surprise him. Even then, the city had a lot to offer an adventurous appetite. The most glaring exception was Japanese food, which Mr. Rector dismissed as ''derivative of the Chinese.'' The only Japanese dish he seemed to like was sukiyaki; if he knew anything about sushi, he certainly kept it to himself.

title: Palestinians Stage a Strike, And Israel Gets the Message
description: Shops and buses throughout the Gaza Strip, the West Bank and East Jerusalem came to a halt this morning in response to Yasir Arafat's call for a four-hour protest against the hard-line policies of the new Israeli Government, and initial indications were that the message had had some impact.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS FOR WEEK ONE
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M. GAMES

title: Snowball Thrower Loses Appeal
description: While most people charged with throwing snowballs during a raucous Giants game last Dec. 23 pleaded guilty, paid their fines and left the incident behind them, JEFFREY LANGE decided to fight.

title: U.S. Opposes Interviews for Oklahoma Suspect
description: Prosecutors asked the Federal judge in the Oklahoma City bombing trial yesterday to deny the request of one defendant, Timothy J. McVeigh, to give a series of television and newspaper interviews next month.

title: BLACKSTONE BUYS BIG FUNERAL HOME FOR $320 MILLION
description: Prime Succession Inc., the largest privately owned United States funeral home chain, was sold yesterday for $320 million to Blackstone Capital Partners, a private merchant bank in New York, and Loewen, a Canadian funeral home and cemetery operator. Blackstone Capital Partners II Merchant Banking Fund L.P. will initially hold a 76 percent interest in the venture, the companies said. Loewen Group Inc., based in Burnaby, British Columbia, will hold the remaining 24 percent. Loewen said the agreement provides for it to buy Blackstone's stake within six years. The deal had been announced in June. At that time, the expected price was put at $295 million.

title: Democrats Bring a Fleeting Sense of Peace to a Neighborhood
description: Now that James Jackson has tasted life for a couple of weeks without drive-by shootings and brazen drug dealers on every corner, he never wants the Democratic National Convention to leave town.

title: The Mayor, Seeing Red, Purges the Reading List
description: Until recently, this Provencal town of 28,000 people was better known for its sunny Mediterranean ways and the rustic charm of its local accent than for being a center of the kind of right-wing ideological militancy that could make even a John Bircher blanch.

title: Iran Helps Iraq Evade Oil Embargo, U.S. Asserts
description: The United States has accused Iran of helping smuggle refined oil products out of Iraq in violation of the United Nations sanctions by forging shipping manifests and allowing barges and small boats to ply its coastal waters.

title: Campaign Film Stars Clinton's Mother-in-Law
description: Like any smart Hollywood producer, Linda Bloodworth-Thomason was right out there before the opening of her film, promoting the product on CNN and PBS. Ms. Thomason, of course, made ''The Man from Hope,'' the 1992 campaign biography that portrayed Bill Clinton as a man with a powerful, down-to-earth family story, and set the standard for campaign films as emotional biographies that value sensibility over sense.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: $25 and Under
description: Times have changed for Jim McMullen.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Mulholland Falls

title: Pilgrims Unprepared For Himalayan Treks
description: To the Editor:

title: Newman Is Penalized
description: For his actions in a brawl after Riddick Bowe's fight with Andrew Golota on July 11 at Madison Square Garden, Rock Newman, Bowe's manager and promoter, has agreed with the New York State Athletic Commission that his organization, Spencer Promotions, Inc., cannot promote a Bowe fight in New York through next July 31. Newman will not be allowed to even attend a Bowe fight in New York.

title: Helen Kushnick, 51, Manager And Producer for Jay Leno
description: Helen Kushnick, who managed Jay Leno's rise from small-time comic to star of the ''Tonight'' show but was dismissed as the program's executive producer four months after Mr. Leno succeeded Johnny Carson as host, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan.

title: Cone Will Come Back Against A's on Monday
description: The speculation has finally ended. David Cone is coming back to the mound on Monday against the Oakland Athletics, and the Yankees really need him.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Convent

title: No Headline
description: ''The real choice is whether we will build a bridge to the future or a bridge to the past, about whether we believe our best days are still out there or our best days are behind us, about whether we want a country of people all working together or one where you're on you're own.''

title: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
description: Japanese stocks hit their lowest level in five months today amid concern the economic recovery may stall. At midday, the Nikkei 225-stock index was off 359.73 points, or 1.75 percent, to 20,193.43, its lowest since March 15. On Thursday, it fell 156.65 points.

title: After 3 Months, U.S. Jury Gets Airliner-Bomb Conspiracy Case
description: A Federal jury yesterday began deliberating whether three men devised an elaborate scheme to blow up American airliners in Asia early last year.

title: DANA TO ACQUIRE SPX'S PISTON RING UNIT FOR $235 MILLION
description: The Dana Corporation, an auto-parts maker, agreed yesterday to acquire the piston ring and cylinder liner business of the SPX Corporation for $235 million in a transaction that would eliminate Dana's biggest competitor in those businesses. The agreement covers 13 SPX plants in the United States and Europe and three affiliated plants in Mexico. The acquisition also furthers Dana's efforts to make international sales account for 50 percent of its total revenue, up from about 28 percent. The company has completed 24 acquisitions or joint ventures since 1993. Of those, 20 involved overseas operations. The SPX business being acquired derives about 30 percent of its sales outside the United States.

title: News Summary
description: International A2-10

title: Error-Prone Mets Unravel and Padres Pick Up the Sweep
description: Changing your manager does not necessarily mean changing your stripes. Not quite yet, anyway.

title: 'Murphy Brown' Creator To Work on New Show
description: CBS announced yesterday that it had signed Diane English, the longtime executive producer of ''Murphy Brown'' to take over as executive producer of its troubled new comedy, ''Ink,'' which stars Ted Danson and Mary Steenburgen.

title: T.W.A. to Buy Building
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy an office building in St. Louis County from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation for its corporate headquarters. Terms were not disclosed. The building is near the airline's other facilities at Lambert-St. Louis International Airport, its principal domestic hub.

title: Convention Summary
description: PRESIDENT'S PLEDGES

title: Boy Dies Playing With Gun
description: A 12-year-old boy was shot and killed Wednesday as he and a friend were playing with a pair of 9-millimeter handguns that were stored in his parents' bedroom, officials said. Charles Buckley, the Acting Bergen County Prosecutor, said yesterday that no charges would be filed. Jonathan Caruso was shot once in the stomach, said Sgt. Kevin Smith of the Waldwick police. Jonathan's parents, Dominic and Eileen Caruso, told the police that the guns were kept unloaded but were stored in a case with ammunition, Sergeant Smith said.

title: Russian Plane Hits Mountain On Arctic Isle, Killing 140
description: A Russian jetliner carrying more than 140 people mostly coal miners and their families -- crashed into a mountain today on the remote Arctic island of Spitsbergen in Norwegian territory. There appeared to be no survivors, Norwegian authorities said.

title: Bulldozers In Camden Make Room for Affordable Homes
description: Workers began demolishing an entire block of abandoned, dilapidated brick town houses today as part of the Whitman administration's first major effort to help build affordable housing in this impoverished city on the Delaware River.

title: Woods Drives Long and Straight Into His New Professional Career
description: The crowd on the first hole today stretched from tee to green, flanking both sides of the fairway, four, five sometimes six deep, the sort of multitude you might see at a British Open or on a Sunday at the Masters. Or at Tiger Woods's professional debut at the Greater Milwaukee Open.

title: Daimler-Benz Reports Profit In First Half
description: Daimler-Benz A.G. posted a first-half net profit of 782 million marks, or $530 million, today, making good on its promise to bounce back after a reorganization that brought a record loss last year.

title: European Monetary Union Hits a New Round of Snags
description: Nervousness over the prospects for European monetary union spread this week, as Governments in France and Italy faced increasing pressure to avoid a slowing of their economies by extending the timetable for introducing a single currency.
