title: Robert Reinhold, Ex-Reporter For The Times, Is Dead at 54
description: Robert Reinhold, an editorial writer at The Los Angeles Times and before that a longtime reporter for The New York Times, died on Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 54.

title: Baxter Purchasing Immuno, Swiss Blood-Products Maker
description: In its latest effort to grow faster, Baxter International said yesterday that it would buy Immuno International A.G., a plodding Swiss blood-products company, for $715 million.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: QUESTAR CORP., Salt Lake City, an energy company, will buy natural-gas and oil sites in Alberta from a privately held Canadian company for $51 million. The seller's name was not disclosed.

title: Couldn't Help Giving In to Wanderlust
description: ANATOMY OF RESTLESSNESS

title: Speedy Kelly Kip Faces His Race of Truth at Saratoga
description: Kelly Kip, the speedy and undefeated 2-year-old star of the Saratoga season, drew the inside post today for the 92d running of the Hopeful Stakes, the career-making sprint that could show eight colts the route to next year's Kentucky Derby.

title: Make-Believe Espionage That's Not Just a Game
description: At what point does a children's cloak-and-dagger game of spying and secret passwords turn into a perilous real-life struggle in which human lives are actually at stake? ''The Greenhouse,'' Philippe de Broca's deceptively lighthearted allegory of wartime heroism and bogus nobility, takes as its central conceit the notion that they can be the same thing.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Eighty-four years late and somewhat less than whole, the Titanic is scheduled to arrive in New York on Sunday. A 24-foot-long, 12-ton chunk of the ship's hull, hauled up yesterday from off Newfoundland, will land at the yacht basin near the World Trade Center at a reception for passengers on the cruise ship Island Breeze, who had watched the hull emerge from the water.

title: Changes in Retailing Are Shrinking the Pool Of Trend Setters
description: When Sally Frame Kasaks, the chief executive of beleaguered Ann Taylor Stores, resigned last week, what was most surprising was not so much that she was pushed out after more than a year of slow sales. Rather, it was just how few names came up as her possible replacement.

title: Preventing Pregnancy
description: To the Editor:

title: Usury Charge Is Settled
description: The State Attorney General's Office reached a $100,000 settlement yesterday with a Delaware company that was accused in a civil suit of charging usurious interest rates on a loan to a Morris County lottery winner, state officials said yesterday. The company, Woodbridge Financial Corporation, offered Dina DeStefano a $30,000 loan that she could repay over five years from her 1987 winnings of $1.4 million, said Mark Herr, the director of the Attorney General's consumer affairs division. But Ms. DeStefano would have wound up paying the company $50,000, an interest rate of 28 percent, he said.

title: SUMMIT BANCORP TO BUY B.M.J. FINANCIAL
description: Summit Bancorporation, the biggest bank based in New Jersey, will buy the B.M.J. Financial Corporation for $164.5 million in stock. Summit said yesterday that it had agreed to pay about six-tenths of a share for each B.M.J. share. Based on Summit's closing price on Wednesday of $38.875, the offer is worth $21.77 for each share of B.M.J. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of Summit fell $1.125, to $37.75, while shares of B.M.J. rose $6.313, or 43 percent, to $20.313 in Nasdaq trading. B.M.J., which is based in Bordentown, N.J., is the parent company of the Bank of Mid-Jersey. Summit was formerly known as the UJB Financial Corporation. In March, it acquired Summit Bancorp and adopted its name.

title: Two Spectacles in a Park
description: There were intriguing coincidences in two major dance commissions of the Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival this summer.

title: Will We Pull Welfare Jobs Out of a Hat?
description: To the Editor:

title: New York City starts moving on Federal rules for notification about lead-based paint.
description: WITH the first phase of new Federal regulations on disclosure of lead-based paint in residences scheduled to take effect next Friday, the Real Estate Board of New York has sent to its members sample disclosure forms intended to help them comply with the new regulations. Similar forms will eventually be given to every person who buys or rents a home built before 1978.

title: Man Arrested in Queens Subway Slaying
description: A man being sought in the stabbing death of his estranged companion in a Queens subway station last week was arrested yesterday morning at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown Manhattan, the police said.

title: CLINTON, DECLARING 'HOPE IS BACK,' DEFENDS HIS FIRST TERM AND LISTS PLANS FOR SECOND
description: Declaring that ''hope is back in America,'' President Clinton accepted his party's nomination for a second term tonight by vowing to protect Government programs for children, the elderly and the environment in a ''strong, united American community.''

title: Clinton's Speech Accepting the Democratic Nomination for President
description: Following is President Clinton's speech last night at the Democratic National Convention in which he accepted the party's nomination for re-election as transcribed by The Associated Press:

title: Madden's World Hangs Everything Out to Dry
description: John Madden stood at the bar of a West Side restaurant and peered at his nearly new sneakers. Barely smudged sneakers are not frequently permitted on the Fox Sports football analyst's size 14 feet. Which reminded him of a story.

title: Mideast Brinkmanship
description: Yasir Arafat took a calculated gamble by calling Palestinians into the streets for a general strike yesterday and a prayer gathering at Jerusalem's Al Aksa mosque today. He directly confronted an Israeli Government with which he hopes to revive stalled peace talks. He was also risking an outburst of violent protest he might not easily control.

title: Florida Seeks to Jail 1952 Escapee From Chain Gang
description: In 1952, Eddie Brown escaped from a chain gang in Florida, making a dash for freedom through snake-infested swamps after being threatened, he says, by a prison guard. He was six months into a five-year sentence for robbing a convenience store.

title: Where the Roots Are Old and Rich
description: NEEDLESS to say, the hotel neglected to mention the foghorn.

title: A Mother Brings Up A Prodigy
description: Her mother is always there, as close to Martina Hingis's side as her racquet bag. She is there for every match, almost every meal and nearly every plane trip.

title: Party Music 30 Years Later
description: Pucho and His Latin Soul Brothers, the Cooler, 416 West 14th Street, West Village, (212) 229-0785. Henry (Pucho) Brown's group appeared in the late-1960's, when Latin music merged with soul, jazz and rock to form an exhilarating hybrid. That material has been raided and recycled by hip-hop's insatiable samplers, and lately Pucho's diverse party music, played with a group that sometimes swells to a dozen members, sounds fresh again in the downtown dance clubs. Also on the bill are Greg Tate and Mack Diva, and the Marquis Players. The concert is at 10 P.M. tomorrow. Admission is $8.

title: That Other Yeats, the Brother Whose Painting Was Poetry
description: At the Queens Museum of Art in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, there is an exhibition of just 15 quite small paintings that offers an ideal introduction to certain aspects of Irish life as it was lived 50 or more years ago.

title: New York, Cradle Of Labor History
description: IT may be hard to imagine, but not far from Manhattan in-spots like the Union Square Cafe and CBGB's, not far from the Bowery and Orchard Street, many of the nation's epic labor battles took place.

title: Lockheed Martin Picks Unit of DDB Needham
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation in Bethesda, Md., has named the DDB Needham New York unit of the Omnicom Group to handle its account, which had been divided among several agencies. Billings were estimated at $18 million to $20 million.

title: Piniella Takes Advantage of Another Chance to Taunt the Yanks' O'Neill
description: Lou Piniella loves to crawl inside Paul O'Neill's head and leave his indelible imprint there.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Labor Day will be observed on Monday.

title: A Festival Flies
description: The Lincoln Center Festival '96, consisting of 64 events over three weeks, was the most adventurous summertime fete yet attempted in Manhattan. Jaded culture-watchers wondered if it would even get off the ground, with too many offbeat performances for tourists flocking to mainstream musicals while too many of the center's usual clientele were away in the Hamptons. The critical and box-office returns are now in, and the consensus is that the festival managed a solid takeoff with an excellent chance of soaring next summer as well.

title: A Rousing Address Revives Throng of Stunned Delegates
description: Democratic delegates leapt up cheering at the sight and sound of President Clinton tonight after a long day of political anxiety over the sensational news that his main election strategist had resigned in the face of sex accusations.

title: For a Cyprus Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Takes Swift Action to Distance Itself From Political Aide
description: President Clinton's advisers moved today to contain the damage from the resignation of Dick Morris by refusing to confirm a tabloid report that he had a yearlong affair with a prostitute and by seeking to create a fire wall between him and Mr. Clinton.

title: Creator of Adelphi's Ads Assails President's Critics
description: As the creator of legendary advertising campaigns for companies like Xerox and MTV, George Lois has helped reverse the fortunes of many a corporation. He had hoped to do the same for Adelphi University, he said yesterday before a state panel that is reviewing Adelphi's troubles.

title: Residents Disrupting Drug Trade
description: Every week for the past year, Gloria Guzman and three of her seven children have joined a group of citizens for a walk on a weekend night through drug-infested neighborhoods of this small city south of West Palm Beach.

title: Jordan and Israel Find a Treaty Alone Doesn't Make Friends
description: Almost two years after they signed a peace treaty, Jordan and Israel have found that lifting decades of suspicion and hostility takes more than a formal pact.

title: Modeling a Commuter Train
description: Jonathan Benjamin, a marketing manager for New Jersey Transit, was 5 years old when he inherited his first Lionel train set from his grandfather, and he has been collecting the model trains ever since. So naturally, he was thrilled when Lionel Trains, which is based in Michigan, said it would issue a limited-edition set in December bearing the blue, magenta and orange markings of New Jersey's passenger railroad.

title: Doris Rosenblum, 71, Borough Historian and Community Advocate
description: Doris Rosenblum, an indefatigable combatant in 40 years of struggle over housing, education and development on Manhattan's Upper West Side, died of cancer yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. She was 71.

title: Dynamics Of a Constant Rise and Fall In Tempo
description: The jazz pianist Andrew Hill plays music that works only when a group is willing and able to follow his lead through the restive, liquid, mood-shifting sensibility of his writing. He's fascinated by form and the lack thereof; during Tuesday night's early set at Sweet Basil, his quartet emulated his slackening narrative until he snapped it back together again with a bit of structured melody.

title: Indonesia Must Protect Political Consensus
description: To the Editor:

title: Jardine Fleming To Pay Fine
description: Jardine Fleming Group Ltd. and its London parent said today that they would pay $20.3 million in fines and restitution after Jardine's star fund manager was caught cheating clients by pocketing trading profits.

title: From Politics to Partying
description: The Mighty Sparrow, S.O.B.'s, 204 Varick Street, at Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 243-4940. Every inflection in the voice of Trinidad's Mighty Sparrow shows intelligence and good humor. At 61, he still puts on a great concert -- when he bothers to show up on time. This singer entered music 40 years ago with the best intentions, playing politically edged calypso songs, sending up dictators, racism and Trinidadian political parties, but he eventually had to modernize and mix in the more decadent party songs of calypso's hybridized offspring, soca. But even in songs as libidinous as ''Poom Poom Shorts,'' the Mighty Sparrow squeezes in a witty editorial: ''Put on some clothes.'' The concerts are at midnight and 2 A.M. tomorrow. Admission is $20.

title: A Boost for the G.O.P.
description: The resignation of Bill Clinton's friend and chief strategist, Dick Morris, is the biggest political bombshell of 1996. As a strategist who has guided Republicans to victory in recent years, Mr. Morris held the road map to the views of most Americans. He saw and predicted the 1994 Democratic disaster, and the President sought his counsel to lead him back from the wilderness.

title: Agassi Doesn't Do Disappearing Act
description: Andre Agassi likes to give the people palpitations; predictability bores him. A tried-and-true Las Vegan, he's also interested in mirages, the more colorful the better. So that's what he became yesterday at the United States Open, the mirage of a twig-legged, hairless fellow overwhelmed by his baggy black shorts, his big yellow watch and his strapping, young opponent, Leander Paes of India, who nimbly pocketed the first set and continued to streak around the court like a comet in the next.

title: Moviefone is adding descriptions of what's playing to its film guide and ticketing service.
description: ON the last giant movie weekend of the summer, as Hollywood is about to trumpet its Labor Day film releases, Moviefone Inc. is about to trumpet its new advertising capability.

title: Economy's Pace Gained Speed In 2d Quarter
description: The Commerce Department reported today that the economy sprinted to an even bigger gain in the spring quarter than it had earlier estimated. The report, along with other data released today, suggested that an expected slowing of activity was eluding policy makers, rekindling financial markets' fears of higher interest rates.

title: Organized Labor Fires Back on Medicare
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O., which has been broadcasting television advertisements against its opponents in Congress, began broadcasting a new ad this week that attacks Republicans for voting to cut the rate of growth in Medicare spending. It responds to an advertisement by the National Republican Congressional Committee, which, in turn, responded to an ad by the labor federation. The 30-second advertisement will be broadcast on television, radio or both in the 27 Congressional districts where the Republican committee placed its ads as part of a more than $20 million television and radio campaign this year. In the script below, the target is Representative George Nethercutt, a freshman Republican from Washington State.

title: Turning A Brat Into a Pal
description: Cast as the most ardent Sonny Bono fan in the Secret Service, the funny, easygoing Sinbad supplies ''First Kid'' with a fair share of boyish charm. Sinbad plays Sam Simms (say that five times quickly) with friendliness and lighthearted flair.

title: The Chinese Missiles
description: Two ways exist for a major power to make sure that the danger of nuclear warfare remains alive -- guaranteed, both of them. The Chinese Communist Government has taken one way, the United States the other.

title: Rebels Strike in 4 Mexico States, Leaving 13 Dead
description: Armed members of a newly emerged guerrilla organization attacked police and military posts in four Mexican states late Wednesday, leaving 13 dead and 23 wounded. The nearly simultaneous strikes were the deadliest outbreak of insurgent violence in Mexico in nearly three years.

title: A Bronx School Asks: 'Just Where Will We All Sit?'
description: With her hands full of multicolored markers and bulletin-board pins, Eileen McManus, a second-grade teacher at Public School 56 in the Bronx, posted a cheery welcome for the students expected in her class next week: ''September is here and so is fall. So welcome children, welcome all.''

title: Keep in Mind
description: FAMILY BIRDING, an educational adventure every Sunday, beginning at 10 A.M. A 90-minute search through Van Cortlandt Park's woodlands for multicolored birds. For children 6 and up. Meet at the Urban Forest Ecology Center, at the south end of the Parade Ground, 241st Street entrance, Riverdale, the Bronx. Free. Binoculars and guides provided. Information: (718) 548-0912.

title: Correction
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday showing average rents and values for commercial space in two business districts of Paris carried erroneous scales. A corrected version appears today on page C2.

title: Expanded TV Coverage Turns Out to Be a Mixed Blessing
description: Bill Clinton's careful convention script went oft awry on the major commercial broadcast networks tonight.

title: Correction: Real Estate Prices in Paris
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday showing average rents and values for commercial space in two business districts of Paris carried erroneous scales. Here is the corrected version.

title: Flummoxed by the Internet, Head of Novell Resigns
description: Robert J. Frankenberg resigned yesterday as chairman, president and chief executive of Novell Inc., ending a two-and-a-half-year tenure in which the company that was once synonymous with computer networking appeared flummoxed by the explosive growth of the Internet.

title: McCORMICK & COMPANY TO BUY BACK SHARES
description: McCormick & Company, the food and spice maker, said yesterday that it planned to buy back as many as 10 million of its common shares, or about 12 percent of its stock. In Nasdaq trading, shares of the company rose $1.063, to $20.313. The company said it would pay for the repurchased shares with some of the proceeds from the sale of its Gilroy Foods Inc. subsidiary and a power plant. McCormick sold Gilroy Foods, a maker of dehydrated garlic and onion products, to the food giant Conagra Inc. for $132 million. The sale was announced in March, but no price was disclosed then. The power plant, also in Gilroy, went to the Calpine Corporation of San Jose, Calif., for $125 million.

title: Jets Play Musical Chairs With the Offensive Line
description: After the most extensive offensive overhaul in recent Jets history, the club suddenly found today that three-fifths of the offensive line could be rearranged for Sunday's season opener against a Broncos team that boasts a strong defense.

title: Tax Breaks for Education and the Middle Class
description: Following are some proposals President Clinton made in his acceptance speech last night. All would require approval by Congress.

title: New York Magazine Editor Who Led Redesign Is Ousted
description: Kurt Andersen, the brash co-founder of Spy magazine who has been editor of New York magazine since February 1994, was ousted yesterday, following weeks of rumors that he might be dismissed.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Who says you have to learn to walk before you can run? LISA LESLIE, the 6-foot-5-inch, hard-driving center for the United States Olympic women's basketball team, took a walking lesson yesterday to prepare for her debut as a Wilhelmina model this afternoon at a fashion show at the the Vibe Music Seminar, a music industry showcase.

title: Hilton-Ladbroke Agreement Is Broader Than Expected
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation and the Ladbroke Group P.L.C., which owns Hilton Hotels International, announced a broader-than-expected alliance yesterday that allows each company to buy a fifth of the other.

title: Perot to Pick a Running Mate Any Day Now
description: Nearly two weeks after winning the Reform Party's Presidential nomination, Ross Perot is still trying to settle on a running mate, a decision his aides had said he would make shortly after his nomination.

title: Jordan Again Leads Athlete-Endorsers
description: Basketball star Michael Jordan, for the sixth consecutive year, tops a list of ''most wanted'' athletes in terms of product endorsements, which is compiled annually by The Sports Marketing Letter, a newsletter based in Westport, Conn.

title: Valuing Children
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Wall Street Is Startled By Strong Economic Data

title: Center Fuel Tank Seen as Jets' Deadly Weak Spot
description: In the last decade, terrorists have twice attacked jetliners by planting bombs near the plane's center fuel tanks, both times with deadly effect, according to law enforcement officials.

title: As the Fans Outside Are Searched, the Show Goes On
description: While it's exciting that concert promoters have discovered new homes for rock shows at dance-music clubs like Webster Hall and the Roxy, it was a disappointment to find Webster Hall still being run like a dance club on Wednesday night when the Gin Blossoms and Lush performed. It was the first show at the club under its new agreement with the promoter Delsener/Slater Entertainment.

title: Dole Says He's the Trustworthy Candidate
description: Bob Dole suggested at an outdoor rally here tonight that he was more trustworthy than President Clinton, saying, ''Bob Dole is honest, his word is good, when he makes his commitment, you can take it to the bank, and that's what we need in America.''

title: Chill Behind Spotlight's Warm Glow
description: It did not seem to matter much to the Democratic partisans on the convention floor that President Clinton's chief strategist, accused of sexual peccadilloes, had headed home in disgrace.

title: Clinton Proposes Tax Cuts on Profits in Home Sales
description: Trying to counter his Republican opponent's tax plan and to placate some of his own Democrats over welfare, President Clinton this evening proposed eliminating taxes on profits from home sales and offering incentives to businesses that hire welfare recipients.

title: Taking Ellington's Path
description: Randy Weston African Rhythm Trio, Iridium, 44 West 63d Street, Manhattan, (212) 582-2121. Randy Weston has avoided the path of most mainstream jazz pianists, opting instead for deep, consolidated grooves (he's a devotee and connoisseur of Moroccan music) and driving rhythms. Mr. Weston may be the most direct descendant of Duke Ellington's spare but emphatic blues sensibility, and his trio displays this message in undiminished terms. The engagement runs through Sunday night, with shows at 8:30 and 10:30 and a midnight set tonight and tomorow. There is a $25 cover charge with a one-drink minimum. BEN RATLIFF

title: Kennedys Hold Family Convention in Their 2d Hometown
description: On his way to the glitzy George magazine party at the Art Institute the other night, a guest wondered aloud about the number of Kennedys who would be coming.

title: Valujet Gets Permission To Fly Again
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that Valujet Airlines, grounded for more than two months after a deadly crash in the Everglades, could start flying again under greater agency scrutiny.

title: First, Win the Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Let Dole Cut Taxes and Exporters Do the Rest
description: To the Editor:

title: Urban Jitters Going Critical
description: IN the startlingly good first moments of his debut feature, ''The Trigger Effect,'' the writer-director David Koepp offers razor-sharp images of modern malaise. His film captures the urban jitters so diabolically that it even locates them in a movie theater, so that Mr. Koepp's own audiences are sure to sit up and take notice.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Faithful

title: Bills' Pass Rush Will Test Brown's Release and Nerves
description: There is one characteristic about Giants quarterback Dave Brown that is irrefutable. He is one of the toughest quarterbacks in the league. Brown will need every ounce of fortitude Sunday against a Buffalo team that has one of the best pass rushes in all of football.

title: U.S. Troops Detain Serbs Briefly After Bosnia Clash
description: In one of the most serious confrontations between NATO-led peacekeeping troops and Bosnian Serbs since the signing of the peace accord last December, American peacekeepers detained some 65 Bosnian Serbs today after they assaulted Muslim refugees returning to their former homes in a Serb-controlled village.

title: No Threat to Clinton
description: The downfall of Dick Morris is not likely to hurt President Clinton's re-election campaign very much, but it will give Americans one more reason to be cynical about politics.

title: Treasury Securities Fall in Price
description: Prices of Treasury securities tumbled yesterday on the unexpected strength of the latest economic statistics, which heightened investor fears that inflation would accelerate, forcing the Fed to tighten monetary policy soon.

title: Reunion at the Garden
description: Magic Showtime at the Theater at Madison Square Garden, (212) 465-6741. The producer Quincy Jones is to headline this concert, organized by his magazine, Vibe, with Magic Johnson as host. There will be a fashion show and selections from Mr. Jones's album ''Q's Jook Joint'' performed by Tamia, Brian McNight and Take 6. And Morris Day and the Time, the good-time Minneapolis funk band that is as much ego as music, will reunite with two former members, Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis, who have become important pop producers. Tony Rich is the night's newcomer, unplugging urban rhythm and blues to create laid-back ballads of love, loss and sensitivity. The show is at 7:30 tomorrow night. Admission is $30, $40 or $50. NEIL STRAUSS

title: J. P. Morgan Names U.S. Equity Strategist
description: J. P. Morgan & Company has hired Douglas R. Cliggott, formerly of Merrill Lynch & Company, to be its United States equity strategist, in a step toward further enhancing its adolescent equity business. He will be responsible for the bank's global investment strategy, forecasting interest rates and suggesting how assets are allocated among cash, stock and bonds.

title: Maxwell Is Back With the Spurs
description: The San Antonio Spurs brought back guard VERNON MAXWELL yesterday, signing the player they had traded to the Houston Rockets in 1990. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Mexico Convenience Store
description: The Amoco Corporation and Fomento Economico Mexicano S.A., or Femsa, have opened their first jointly owned convenience store in Mexico as part of a venture that plans to invest $250 million in the country in the next decade. The new store in Monterrey is the first of 10 planned for this year.

title: Soundtracks You Can Dance To
description: If the history of rock-and-roll in most people's minds is a mental jukebox of favorite singles, albums and compact disks, the music also has its own rich cinematic tradition. From the Beatles' ''Hard Day's Night'' to ''Saturday Night Fever,'' to ''Purple Rain'' and beyond, movies and rock-and-roll have had a hit-or-miss synergy for more than four decades. ''Cinerock: Loud Films, Rare Music,'' a series that opens today at the Walter Reade Theater and runs for two weeks, surveys many of the major developments in rock and related genres since the 1960's. The emphasis is on concert movies, rather than on music-driven feature films.

title: Celebrating the Last Gasp of Summer, From the Arts to the Zoo
description: Labor Day is Monday. This year's Labor Day Parade in Manhattan, however, begins at noon on Sept. 7, proceeding up Fifth Avenue from 44th to 86th Street. Here is a sampling of activities scheduled for this weekend in the metropolitan region.

title: Subway Feud In Jet Age Of Baseball
description: OF all the bizarre subplots and simmering feuds and conflicts of interest in baseball, the twist I like best involves the Yankees' rooting for good old Lou Piniella.

title: History Painting: Yes, Those Enormous Canvases
description: With many eyes at the moment turned to Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens, where the United States Open tennis championships are under way, the Queens Museum of Art, the Open's next-door neighbor, has a couple of shows that merit more than the spillover crowd that wanders in during rain delays at the stadium.

title: Clearance for Valujet
description: The Federal Government said Valujet Airlines, grounded for more than two months after a Florida crash, could start flying again under greater agency scrutiny. Pahe A12.

title: Home Video
description: A Cornucopia of Titles

title: Women for Whom Speech Is Music
description: Forget, for the moment, about Zoe Caldwell versus Patti Lupone as Maria Callas. The divas to pay attention to, before it's too late, can be found in a theatrical land as far away from Callas's cosmopolitanism as Pittsburgh is from Milan. They are the three women in August Wilson's ''Seven Guitars,'' which concludes its run at the Walter Kerr Theater (entirely too soon) next Sunday.

title: Giuliani, Playing to the Bleacher Seats, Boycotts Tennis Open
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is an ardent fan of the New York Yankees who often uses his bully pulpit to give the kind of workaday analysis on the team's games that might be heard over beers at a dusky corner bar. But lately, the Mayor has voiced little love for another local sporting institution, the United States Open in Queens, portraying its sponsors as haughty and meddlesome.

title: Stocks Post Biggest Loss In Six Weeks
description: Stocks tumbled yesterday in their worst loss in six weeks after a surprisingly strong report on new-home sales renewed concern that in a buoyant economy borrowing costs could rise, cutting industry's profits.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Peace and Quiet in the Hamptons
description: It was a fine hot afternoon in mid-August, and noticeably quieter than Provence. There were no tractors clattering back and forth through the vines, no boisterous domestic arguments echoing through the valley, no gunfire from hunters getting their eye in before the start of the hunting season. The only sounds that afternoon were the muttering of seagulls and the whisper of water coming up the bay. Nothing in any way remarkable, except that this was a summer Sunday in the Hamptons.

title: Call-Girl Story Costs President A Key Strategist
description: Dick Morris, President Clinton's chief campaign adviser and the central force behind the emphasis on family values that had its apex at this week's Democratic convention, resigned today after a tabloid reported that he had had a relationship with a call girl.

title: Judge Urges More Care In Evaluating Homeless
description: Dissatisfied with how the city is determining who is homeless, a Manhattan judge told city officials yesterday that they must step up their efforts to insure that homeless families seeking help at an emergency office in the Bronx are not unjustly turned away.

title: Bradley's Last Beach Walk
description: A tradition will end this weekend when United States Senator Bill Bradley makes his 17th walking tour along the New Jersey coast. The four-day walk will begin this morning at the Cape May Point Lighthouse and wind up on Monday at Sandy Hook. Last year, Senator Bradley began his walk a day after he said he would not seek a fourth term. An aide said the Senator did not plan to continue the walks after he leaves office.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in New York City that are to close soon:

title: Phyllis Pearsall, 89, Dies; Creator of 'A to Z' London Maps
description: Phyllis Pearsall, who created the famous ''A to Z'' maps of London by traversing more than 3,000 miles of roads throughout the city, died on Wednesday, her business, Geographers' A-Z Map Company, said today. She was 89 years old and lived in Shoreham, England.

title: Pilgrims Unprepared For Himalayan Treks
description: To the Editor:

title: After 3 Years Of Repairs, Deck of Bridge Set to Reopen
description: After three years of repair work, the two Brooklyn-bound upper lanes of the Manhattan Bridge are scheduled to reopen to car traffic today, providing some relief to drivers who have put up with seemingly unending repair work there.

title: CRASH SIMULATION SETS T.W.A. BLAST IN ONE SMALL AREA
description: Federal investigators have created a sophisticated computer simulation of the final moments of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 showing that almost everything in the first spray of metal, luggage, and other material blown from the airplane came from one confined area on the right side of the jet, above and ahead of the wing.

title: Judge Blocks Notifying Neighbors About Past Sex Offenders
description: A new state policy of notifying communities about the presence of recently released sex offenders is unconstitutional when applied to people who committed crimes before the policy took effect, a Federal court has ruled.

title: Japan Arrests Doctor in Case Of Bad Blood
description: Japanese authorities made their first arrest today in an H.I.V.-tainted blood scandal that has disturbed the nation, filing charges against a prominent physician who many of Japan's hemophiliacs say bears responsibility for their infection with the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Car Insurers Don't Pad the Bill for New Yorkers
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: On Aug. 29, 1893, WHITCOMB L. JUDSON of Chicago was granted a patent for a ''clasp locker or unlocker for shoes.'' The device came to be known as the zipper, and NICHOLSON BAKER, the novelist and essayist, celebrated its anniversary by wrestling with several large ones attached to suitcases. Mr. Baker, who has written compellingly about staplers, paper clips, buttons and other fasteners, is leaving tomorrow with his wife and children for Ely, England, where he will work on a new novel.

title: Crawford Signs Extension With Avalanche
description: MARC CRAWFORD, who coached the Colorado Avalanche to the Stanley Cup championship this year, signed a three-year contract extension yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: Faster Economic Pace Seen

title: Mayors Attack Water Plan
description: Environmental groups, which have been hammering away for months at Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's water policies, said yesterday that 43 mayors had joined their fight. The mayors, most of them Democrats, signed a letter to the Republican Governor warning that proposed changes in state regulations would permit more toxic material to be dumped in New Jersey's rivers, lakes and estuaries and would endanger drinking water supplies.

title: Gore Forced To Make Hard Choices On Tobacco
description: Six years after Vice President Al Gore's older sister died of lung cancer in 1984, he was still accepting campaign contributions from tobacco interests. Four years after she died, while campaigning for President in North Carolina, he boasted of his experiences in the tobacco fields and curing barns of his native Tennessee. And it took several years after Nancy Gore Hunger's death for Mr. Gore and his parents to stop growing tobacco on their own farms in Carthage, Tenn.

title: Raptors Sign Walt Williams for Minimum
description: The new economics of the National Basketball Association helped the Toronto Raptors land an inexpensive, blue-chip small forward. WALT WILLIAMS, who could not find a team willing to meet his contract price, signed a one-year deal with Toronto yesterday for the N.B.A. minimum $247,500.

title: Rios and Washington Make Abrupt Exits in the Second Round
description: MaliVai Washington, this year's Wimbledon runner-up, and Marcelo Rios, the ponytailed 20-year-old firebrand who is Chile's first-ever top 10 player, found themselves rudely thumped out of the second round of the United States Open last night by a pair of upset artists with Stanford credentials.

title: For Children
description: 'Bats'

title: Doctors Take Hospital Fight To the Street
description: NORTHWEST COVENANT MEDICAL CENTER is a proud institution, so proud that its logo is the numeral 1, its motto: ''One of the best. Accreditation with Commendation.'' Its two main campuses, here and in nearby Dover, epitomize the suburban, well-cared-for hospital: Pastel landscapes hang on the walls. Floors are highly glossed. Bright signs point visitors to the proper department.

title: Bell South Names Western International
description: The Bell South Corporation in Atlanta said yesterday that it had awarded responsibilities for consolidated media buying on its account, with billings estimated at $150 million to $175 million, to the Atlanta office of Western International Media, which is owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: For a Tabloid, Another 'World Exclusive'
description: In its two decades of publication, the supermarket tabloid Star has tried to stoke circulation with ''world exclusives,'' paying liberally for scoops like photographs of O. J. Simpson's homecoming, Gennifer Flowers's claim of a 12-year romance with Bill Clinton and, most recently, a call girl's account of an affair with the Presidential adviser Dick Morris.

title: Mayor's Personal Attacks Are Unwarranted
description: To the Editor:

title: MEMTEC OF AUSTRALIA TO BUY GELMAN SCIENCES
description: Memtec Ltd., an Australian filtration company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Gelman Sciences Inc. for about $270 million in stock. Gelman, of Ann Arbor, Mich., makes filtration and health products. The company had sales of $103 million for the year that ended on July 31, 1995. Under the agreement, Memtec will exchange 1.05 of its American depository receipts for each share of Gelman. Gelman's stock closed yesterday at $29.125, up 12.5 cents, on the American Stock Exchange. Memtec's A.D.R.'s were at $30.8125, down 43.75 cents, in Nasdaq trading. A.D.R.'s are receipts for securities of foreign companies that are held in custody overseas and trade on United States markets in place of the company's stock.

title: Spotlight Yet to Shine On World-Class Show
description: For sports promoters, New York is a two-sided coin. If the flip lands heads-up, the way it usually does for the long-established United States Open tennis tournament, their show enjoys a high profile on the stage and celebrity cachet in the grandstands.

title: Soundtrack Hit Revives A Disbanded Band
description: Are simultaneous cliches better than one at a time? Primitive Radio Gods must have hoped so when they performed on Monday night at the Mercury Lounge.

title: A Life Devoted To Promoting Labor Reform
description: HERMAN BENSON, union man and labor reformer, has his office in Brooklyn's old State Street Chapel. The place was once a mortuary, although he waves off any suggestion that it is a macabre metaphor for the state of organized labor.

title: 9.1% STAKE IN CONSOLIDATED CIGAR GAINED
description: Investment partnerships affiliated with Martin Zweig have acquired a 9.1 percent stake in the class A common stock of Consolidated Cigar Holdings Inc. The investors paid a total of $16.39 million to acquire 550,000 class A shares as an investment, according to a Schedule 13D filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Consolidated Cigar, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., manufactures premium cigars, including the H. Upmann and Monte Cristo brands. The company, controlled by Ronald O. Perelman, the financier, sold 5.4 million class A shares at $23 each through an initial public offering on Aug. 15. Mr. Zweig is the chairman of the Zweig Fund Inc. and the Zweig Total Return Fund Inc.

title: Caradon in Talks To Sell a Parts Unit
description: Caradon P.L.C. said yesterday that it was in talks to sell its British automotive plastics businesses to a ''leading North American automotive components supplier.'' The Rolinx businesses, based in Banbury and Swindon, had sales of $:68 million in 1995 and net asset value of $:15.8 million ($24.6 million). Caradon did not name the possible buyer.

title: Time to Stop the Kiryas Joel Fight
description: Two years ago the Supreme Court ruled that New York State could not create a special school district for Kiryas Joel, a village of 12,000 Satmar Hasidic Jews 40 miles north of New York City. The State Legislature immediately attempted to subvert the ruling with a new law that accomplished the same end through indirect language. The State Appellate Division has now declared that that law, too, is unconstitutional. It is time for leaders of both the state and the village to stop fighting the First Amendment. The children of Kiryas Joel would be more suitably served by a compromise that meets their needs without flouting the Constitution.

title: Arrest Warrant Lifted For Thyssen Chairman
description: German authorities have lifted an arrest warrant for Dieter Vogel, the chairman of the German industrial company Thyssen A.G., the district attorney in Verlin said yesterday. While Mr. Vogel remains a prime suspect in the purported mishandling of funds during the privatization of the eastern German trading company Metallurgiehandel, the warrant was lifted because there was no danger of flight, the district attorney's office said.

title: Brinck Jackson, 86, Dies; Was Guru of the Landscape
description: John Brinckerhoff Jackson, a writer whose cultural interpretations of the American landscape encompassed parking lots, trailer camps and highways, died on Thursday at St. Vincent Hospital in Santa Fe. He was 86 and lived in La Cienega, N.M.

title: Boggs Feels Slighted as the Yankees Acquire Hayes
description: On the day Wade Boggs found out he would become a platoon player because the Yankees had acquired Charlie Hayes from the Pirates to play third base against left-handed pitchers, he ridiculed the trade with one simple, yet revealing, action.

title: QUAKER STATE SET TO PURCHASE MEDO COMPANIES
description: The Quaker State Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Medo Companies, a privately held maker of automobile air-freshener products. Financial terms were not disclosed, but the deal was for cash, Quaker State said. Medo, based in Tarrytown, N.Y., had 1995 sales of about $60 million. Quaker State, of Irving, Tex., produces motor oil and lubricants and other automotive products. It had $1 billion of revenues in 1995.

title: Pataki Panel Says Casinos Could Bring In $2.6 Billion
description: A commission created by Gov. George E. Pataki issued a report today that said casino gambling could generate as much as $2.6 billion in business for New York State annually and create 38,000 jobs.

title: Acting, Love and Play At a Very Old Institution
description: A theater director in ''La Comedie-Francaise ou L'Amour Joue'' solemnly warns, ''We mustn't be tempted by any facile tactics.'' Be assured that in the idiosyncratic world of a Frederick Wiseman documentary, there is little chance of that happening. Beginning with ''Titicut Follies'' in 1967, a harrowing descent into a state hospital for the criminally insane, Mr. Wiseman and a cameraman have been methodically wandering through American institutions ranging from a high school to a department store, a zoo to a monastery. There is never a narrator. The camera lingers, sometimes to the point of exasperation. His work has been hailed and reviled but rarely ignored.

title: INSIDE
description: Chechnya Peace Seems Near

title: Fraud Charges Are Expanded In Swindling Of Investors
description: Federal prosecutors expanded their charges yesterday against an investment adviser from Brooklyn Heights who they say financed a lavish way of life with millions of dollars swindled mostly from relatives and friends.

title: Sampras Goes to the Limit To Defeat Unknown
description: It was rush hour, as hot and as irritating as it could be. And there was Pete Sampras, stuck behind an unmarked foreign vehicle.

title: E. Garrett Cleary, Lawyer and Prosecutor, 68
description: E. Garrett Cleary, a lawyer in Rochester who had been a New York State prosecutor, a special investigator and a member of the Commission on Judicial Conduct, died on Aug. 24 at his family's summer home in Canandaigua, N.Y. He was 68 and lived in Pittsford, N.Y.

title: Who Can Defend Ads For Young Smokers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Vacationers Are Hitting the Road in Record Numbers
description: Vacationers have taken to the roads and the air in record numbers this summer, undaunted by fires in national parks, power failures in the West, a hurricane threat that forced widespread evacuations in the Southeast and unseasonably cold, rainy weather from New England to the Carolinas. Not even the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 curbed their wanderlust.

title: Arafat's Call for Prayer Protest Gets Modest Response
description: A rigid Israeli police cordon and an apparent shortage of enthusiasm among Palestinians made for a modest and peaceful turnout today at Al Aksa Mosque, where Yasir Arafat had called on Palestinians to converge for protest prayers.

title: Mixed Signs in Flurry of Economic Data
description: The United States economy is giving mixed signals, but financial markets reacted today to two nongovernmental indicators that depicted the economy as picking up speed quickly after a midyear lull.

title: Clinton Talk Turns Tables On Opponent
description: Never in memory has a candidate for President snatched his opponent's metaphor and turned it against him with such wicked effect as did President Clinton when he accepted his party's nomination on Thursday in Chicago.

title: The Story of the Week (At Least for a Day)
description: As the scandal surrounding President Clinton's top political strategist washed through the national and local news media, it splashed even into nooks and crannies.

title: Worker Killed As 2 Men Rob Jewelry Store In Midtown
description: A 20-year-old jewelry store worker was shot to death yesterday afternoon during an armed robbery at a midtown Manhattan store, the police said. After the shooting, officials said two suspects fled with a bag of assorted jewelry.

title: Just When Did 'The End' Trend Begin?
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERISTAR CASINOS STOCK TUMBLES BY 22%
description: The stock of Ameristar Casinos Inc. fell 22 percent yesterday after the company said it expected earnings for the third and fourth quarter to be below Wall Street's expectations. Ameristar attributed the shortfall to higher-than-expected expenses to relocate the company's headquarters to Las Vegas from Jackpot, Nev., and higher costs associated with the purchase of Gem Gaming Inc. Ameristar said earnings for the third quarter would be between 9 and 13 cents a share, while the fourth quarter should see net income of 7 to 10 cents a share. First Call Inc. has estimates of 25 cents a share for the third period and 12 cents a share for the final quarter. Ameristar's stock fell $1.75 to close at $6 a share on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: In Rural Mexico, Two Views of Rebels
description: During a surprise attack by masked guerrillas on Wednesday in this resort village, several rebels held Jorge Ramirez, a hotel receptionist, at gunpoint while their comrades were stealing a car outside. During the wait, the rebels ordered Mr. Ramirez to chant ''Long Live the Popular Revolutionary Army!''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Slump on Fears Fed Will Raise Rates Soon

title: Irving Gaynor Neiman, Writer, 80
description: Irving Gaynor Neiman, who wrote for radio, television and the stage, died on Sunday at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: Miles Away, Hurricane Worries Beachgoers
description: Although Hurricane Edouard was nearly 1,000 miles south of the sun-drenched beaches here, high tides, heavy surf and ''no swimming'' signs were a clear reminder today that the storm was packing a powerful long-distance punch.

title: New Wave Styles Return, On a Visit From Beijing
description: Pop styles travel at their own speed and lodge in unexpected places. Cobra, a five-woman band from Beijing that performed on Monday night at Wetlands, is just catching up to the New Wave rock of the late 1970's and early 1980's. The band has picked up the middleweight funk of Talking Heads, the succinct keyboard lines of the Cars, the saxophone hooks of Men at Work and the pop tunefulness of Blondie; its encore was Iggy Pop's ''Passenger.'' When Cobra performs at CBGB on Sept. 11, the music will have a kind of homecoming.

title: U.S. SURGICAL EXTENDS HOSTILE TAKEOVER BID
description: The U.S. Surgical Corporation said yesterday that it had extended its hostile takeover offer of $18 a share, or $235 million, for the Circon Corporation until Sept. 30. U.S. Surgical, which already held one million Circon shares, said 6.99 million shares had been tendered by Thursday, when the offer was previously scheduled to expire. U.S. Surgical now holds 63 percent of Circon's outstanding shares. Its offer was based on acquiring 67 percent of Circon's shares. Separately, the Heine Securities Corporation, the company controlled by the money manager Michael Price, acquired a 6.5 percent stake in Circon. The investor paid a total of $14.85 million to acquire 814,700 shares, according to a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Lebed Says Chechen Rebels Agree to Press Peace Talks
description: Russia's national security adviser, Aleksandr I. Lebed, announced today that he and his rebel Chechen counterparts had agreed to seek peace and postpone a decision on the status of the rebel republic of Chechnya until Dec. 31, 2001.

title: 'Obscured' Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: Somewhere, Bacchus Is Crying in His Wine
description: In the competition between grape and grain, there has never been any doubt where Rome stood. The ancient Romans had no god of beer, just Bacchus, the god of wine whose centuries-long reign over the city's banquets, bars and restaurants has never really been challenged. Until now.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Living Section on Wednesday about chefs who were challenged to create tomato dishes in 40 minutes with ingredients bought at the Union Square Greenmarket misstated the position of Alex Lee at Restaurant Daniel. He is its chef de cuisine, the first assistant to the chef. The restaurant's chef is Daniel Boulud.

title: MERISEL AGREES TO A DEAL WITH CHS ELECTRONICS
description: Merisel Inc. agreed yesterday to sell most of its European operations and all of its Latin American businesses to CHS Electronics Inc. for $130 million in cash and the assumption of $30 million of debt. Merisel, a money-losing computer and software distributor, hired Merrill Lynch & Company in April to help it explore selling all or part of the company. The transaction will make Miami-based CHS Electronics the second-largest computer- and software-products distributor in Western Europe and give it a substantial presence in Mexico. The businesses being sold generated about $1.5 billion of Merisel's $4.6 billion of revenue last year. Merisel's stock rose 50 cents, to $2.9375, in Nasdaq trading. CHS's shares climbed 56.26 cents, to $12.1875.

title: Lobo Will Not Play for the Blizzard
description: REBECCA LOBO, the former University of Connecticut basketball star and Olympic gold medalist, will not play for the New England Blizzard of the American Basketball League, team officials confirmed yesterday.

title: Just When Did 'The End' Trend Begin?
description: To the Editor:

title: In Fort Lee, Police Are the Ones Told, 'Move On, Please'
description: Without a permanent headquarters for nearly a quarter of a century, Police Chief John Orso has learned to move guns, criminal evidence and all the other elements of a station in a hurry.

title: Henke Still Keeps It Low
description: Early on a sunny morning here at the Greater Milwaukee Open, Nolan Henke administered veteran lesson No. 2 to a certain rookie professional on the PGA Tour. It had nothing to do with swing mechanics, airplane reservations or color-coordinating his weekend ensemble. It was simply this: Shoot low or eat dust.

title: 60 Walruses Plunge to Their Death, and Alaskans Wonder Why
description: Nearly 60 male walruses fell off a 200-foot bluff to their deaths on a remote beach in southwestern Alaska earlier this week. It was the third time in three years that a large number of bulls followed one another over the same cliff, Federal wildlife managers said.

title: Part-Time Prosecuting Can Be a Formidable Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Kazakstan Oil Deal
description: Hurricane Hydrocarbons Ltd. reached an agreement this week with the Government of Kazakstan to buy an 89.5 percent stake in Yuzhneftegaz, the state-owned oil and natural gas company. Hurricane, an oil and gas concern based here, said the purchase price was $120 million. Yuzhneftegaz has production fields in the South Turgai Basin in south-central Kazakstan.

title: Conventions Over, the Candidates Take to the Road
description: Roaring out of the Democratic convention, in a reprise of their 1992 campaign bus trips, President Clinton, Vice President Al Gore and their wives stormed up and down the mid-Mississippi Valley today, happily bashing Republican proposals -- if not Republicans -- all the way.

title: Florida Opts Not to Send 1952 Escapee Back to Jail
description: Law enforcement officials in Florida said yesterday they had decided not to seek the extradition of Eddie Brown, who escaped from a prison chain gang in 1952 but has lived a quiet, crime-free life for nearly four decades in Brooklyn.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Labor Day will be observed on Monday.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Police Who Move On
description: Without a permanent headquarters for nearly a quarter of a century, Chief John Orso of the Fort Lee police has learned to move guns, criminal evidence and all the other elements of a station in a hurry. For the fourth time, he is moving to temporary offices. $(Page 1.$)

title: In the Balkans, Another Mini-state Digs In
description: In her bright yellow-and-white print dress, Zlavica Rajic fairly skipped down the stairs of the ministry of justice this morning on her way to arrange for the bank transfers to cover next month's expenses for her government, even though that government has absolutely guaranteed it would cease to exist by the close of business today.

title: Lesbian Loses Court Appeal For Custody Of Daughter
description: A Florida appeals court today upheld a decision by a trial judge transferring custody of a girl, now 12, from her lesbian mother to her father, who served eight years in prison for murdering his first wife 22 years ago.

title: Sex To the Rescue
description: You knew it was bad when Democrats started talking about Bill Clinton leading us into the 21st century. Not a single Democrat within the vast range of television's mighty eye bothered to suggest this might be an unwise direction to take.

title: Mets Say the Injured Baerga's Season Is Essentially Over
description: Carlos Baerga will have to wait until next season to prove to the Cleveland Indians and the Mets that he can still be the player he once was. His chance to do that this year is all but over, now that the Mets have decided he will be used on a very limited basis, if at all, for the remainder of the season.

title: Equal Offenses Deserve Equal Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: Remembering Watts And, in the Process, Reaching for the Sky
description: The folk singer Malvina Reynolds sang of the tender grass that pushes through hard cement. Like that grass, the Watts Towers in the South Central district of Los Angeles grew toward the sky over a 33-year period, a monument of steel, mortar and found bits of glass, shells, tile and ceramics, reaching as high as 99 feet. Simon Rodia, the Italian immigrant who built the towers in his yard from 1921 to 1954, was seen simply as an eccentric. After his death, in 1965, the towers were understood as art.

title: The Players Aren't Hungry? Blame the No. 1 Pick
description: It is a tradition that is not well known to Giants fans, but has been going on for years. And the rookie first-round pick, Cedric Jones, can only smile about it.

title: The One and Only Tiger Woods
description: Now that Tiger Woods, the 20-year-old Stanford University golfer, has become the lone black star in an overwhelmingly white sport, many in the black community are hoping that he represents some sort of breakthrough. One of the most lucrative sports in America, golf is also one of the most segregated, with a notorious history of discriminating against blacks, Jews and others.

title: No Jobs, No Work
description: The success of the new welfare law depends on creating jobs for the people who will eventually lose their public assistance. Recommendations typically call for job training and public-works employment. Yet there has been little effort to create jobs in the private sector -- especially the kinds of jobs suited to aspiring entrepreneurs.

title: Oath, 16-1 Long Shot, Blows By the Favorites
description: Neither D. Wayne Lukas nor Nick Zito nor Jerry Bailey nor Gary Stevens, nor any of the other star trainers and jockeys got the prize today in the 105th running of the Spinaway Stakes, the race that has launched careers for many 2-year-old fillies.

title: Philip Morris Executives Ordered To Testify Before a Grand Jury
description: Officials of the Philip Morris Companies have been subpoenaed by the Justice Department to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating whether tobacco companies and their executives knowingly provided false information about nicotine's addictiveness, a Government official familiar with the investigation said today.

title: DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Of Winged Justice and Revenge Through Pecking
description: More than three decades after Alfred Hitchcock's film ''The Birds,'' you would think that Hollywood's special-effects wizards might have come up with a scarier ornithological blitz than the perfunctory pecking orgy that is the climax of ''The Crow: City of Angels.'' But no. When the avenging hero, Ashe (Vincent Perez), sics a flock of crows on Judah (Richard Brooks), the torture meister who runs the drug-and-sex trade in what's left of Los Angeles, one of the chintziest montages of any contemporary horror film disposes of the potbellied mobster in 10 seconds flat.

title: Frank Kuenstler, Poet and Film Maker, 68
description: Frank Kuenstler, a poet and film maker, died on Aug. 11 at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 68 and lived in Manhattan.

title: More Traces Of Explosive In Flight 800
description: Federal investigators announced yesterday that they had discovered additional traces of explosive residue on pieces of wreckage from Trans World Airlines Flight 800, but that the new evidence was still not enough for them to conclude that the plane was brought down by a criminal act.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL CHART FOR SATURDAY
description: KEY GAMES

title: Coffins for Sale, Cheap
description: The first retail coffin store in the state, and one of only a few in the country, opened its doors this week, promising cheaper prices than the area's funeral homes. Officials at the Dignity Casket Company say they sell metal and wood coffins for less than twice the wholesale price, while funeral homes may charge as much as five times the wholesale price. But George Kelder, assistant executive director of the New Jersey State Funeral Directors Association, maintained yesterday that his members' prices were competitive with Dignity's.

title: Wall Street Questions Cost Of Bank Deal
description: Nationsbank announced yesterday, as expected, a $9.46 billion bid for Boatmen's Bancshares of St. Louis.

title: The Dance Within the Hit Parade
description: Politics makes strange dance partners. The major-party conventions made clear that Republicans and Democrats alike support something beyond strong families, tax breaks, crime fighting, mom and apple pie. They are both pro-macarena, the line dance that looks like a Simon Says routine and doesn't involve too much compromising action below the shoulders. It's a dance even policy wonks can handle.

title: No Headline
description: ''Have guns, will travel.''

title: Case Completes Purchase
description: The Case Corporation, a maker of agricultural and construction equipment, completed its acquisition today of 75 percent of Steyr Landmaschinentechnik G.m.b.H., an Austrian tractor maker. Financial terms were not disclosed. Case, based in Racine, Wis., said Steyr's former parent company, Steyr-Daimler-Puch A.G., would retain a 25 percent interest. The company now will be known as Case Steyr Landmaschinentechnik A.G.

title: SIERRA SEMICONDUCTOR EXPECTS TO CUT 150 EMPLOYEES
description: The Sierra Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that it expected to dismiss 150 employees, or 30 percent of its work force, in the next few months as it stops selling chips for computer modems. Sierra announced on Wednesday that it would leave the modem chip business because of price competition in that market, resulting in a charge of $50 million to $80 million in the third quarter, depending on whether the business is sold or simply shut down. The company, based in San Jose, Calif., instead plans to focus on chips for the booming networking market. Whether or not it finds a buyer, the company expects to dismiss about 150 of its current 500 employees, said Gary Breeding, a spokesman for Sierra.

title: Arthur Lee Bass, 88, Mountain Herbalist
description: Arthur Lee Bass, a mountain herbalist in the southern Appalachians who was widely known for his knowledge of medicinal plants, died on Wednesday in Redman Park Hospital in Rome, Ga. He was 88 and lived in Leesburg.

title: Effort to Raise Part of Titanic Falters as Sea Keeps History
description: The Titanic, the unlucky ocean liner that sank on its inaugural voyage in 1912, sank again yesterday in deep Atlantic waters -- at least a large part of it did. The setback seems likely to reinforce tales that the celebrated wreck is cursed.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Rutgers Faculty Plans Strike
description: As students prepare to resume classes on Tuesday, faculty members at Rutgers University are gearing up for what could be the school's first faculty strike, a union official said yesterday. ''We find ourselves in a truly grim situation,'' said Wells Kiddie, chief negotiator for the Rutgers Council of the American Association of University Professors.

title: A Scandalous Story Rates High and Low
description: The allegation of a relationship between President Clinton's top political strategist and a prostitute was near the top of many national newscasts and big-city newspapers, but on the local level, the story received considerably less attention. In any case, Mr. Clinton appeared to be weathering the reports of scandal in his Administration and the subsequent resignation of the strategist, Dick Morris, just fine.

title: Proof That Intelligence Can Fall Below Zero
description: When it comes to truth in labeling, hand out the kudos to the new movie called ''The Stupids.''

title: Scandal Breaks the Tedium of Carefully Scripted Conventions
description: Inconvenient though the timing was for the convention's producers, it was adrenaline for the army of reporters who had been stupefied first by the Republicans and then by the Democrats. They had been reduced to rote interviews, redundant analyses and assessments that sounded like the blurbs some movie reviewers provide for use in advertisements: ''a very strong performance'' or ''very moving.''

title: Jones Finally Starts
description: Few defensive players in college ever caused the havoc Marvin Jones did with his speed, aggression and knack for hitting people on the run. And for years the Jets -- who took Jones with their No. 1 pick, the fourth over all, in the 1993 draft -- have spoken of Jones as potentially the pivotal performer in their defense.

title: Cardinal Bernardin Says He Has Inoperable Cancer
description: Declaring that ''I can say in all sincerity that I am at peace,'' Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, announced today that he has less than a year to live. On Wednesday his doctors discovered that the cancer for which he was treated over a year ago had returned, he said.

title: Radicals in South Korea Look Fondly Northward
description: Bang Nyong Hyun, a 25-year-old psychology major, has leadership qualities, middle-class roots, job prospects and a place at one of this country's most prestigious universities.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : As Late Summer Rolls Around, So Do Bikers in a Quiet Town
description: The people of little Sturgis, South Dakota, find themselves bracing each year as late summer rolls around; some leave town. What began years ago as a week of motorcycle races and rallies has evolved into perhaps the world's largest annual collection of motorcycles, and their leather-wearing, tattoo-sporting, whisky-swigging riders.

title: German Predicts A Better 1997
description: After rebounding in the second quarter, Germany's economic growth should accelerate to an annual pace of 2 percent to 2.5 percent next year, Economics Minister Gunter Rexrodt said yesterday. Mr. Rexrodt expects growth of at least 0.75 percent this year. For April through June, he said, he expected that official figures to be released next week would show a rise of 1 percent over the corresponding period last year. Growth, however modest, would end a slump that included no growth in the last two quarters of 1995 and a contraction early this year.(AP)

title: Schott Decides to Speak Her Mind
description: MARGE SCHOTT's interviews with a Denver radio station and two Ohio newspapers have drawn the attention of the National League, which is looking into the situation. On June 12, Schott was forced to give up daily control of the Reds through 1998 because of insensitive remarks. The agreement also barred her from being a spokesman for the Reds.

title: Coach Accused of Molesting
description: A Burlington County soccer and softball coach was charged yesterday with sexually assaulting two girls, the authorities said. Richard A. Gibbs, 45, of Medford was accused of videotaping the children, said to be between 10 and 12 years old, and of having sexual intercourse with at least one of them, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Gibbs, who coaches for the Medford Township Youth Athletic Association, used the Internet to communicate with other pedophiles, said James Gerrow, an assistant county prosecutor.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: Bilingual Parents Dismayed By English's Pull on Children
description: In Marcel A. Apple's bedroom, the book ''The Three Little Pigs'' rests on a shelf next to ''Mi primer libro de palabras en Espanol'' (''My First Book of Spanish Words''). The 3-year-old can sing along to both a Sesame Street song and ''La Bamba,'' or have as much fun watching ''Barney,'' a purple, English-speaking dinosaur, as he does ''Tito,'' a blue, Spanish-speaking shark.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: A Union Gives an Old Refinery a New Lease on Life
description: In an agonizing choice but one that is often faced by unions these days, members of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union approved a new contract today under which about one-third of the workers will lose their jobs when the Tosco Corporation reopens a refinery here by next July.

title: The Tyrant of Belarus
description: Belarus is a land cursed by geography and history. Over the centuries it has been overrun by Russia, Lithuania and Poland, barely preserving its own language and sense of national identity. Now, not quite five years since its liberation from the Soviet Union, Belarus is rapidly slipping back toward tyranny under an authoritarian leader, Aleksandr Lukashenko.

title: George Heinemann, 78, the Creator of TV's 'Ding Dong School'
description: George A. Heinemann, a longtime NBC television executive who developed ''Ding Dong School,'' ''Shari Lewis and Lambchop'' and other children's and educational programs, died on Aug. 21 at his home in Canaan, N.Y. He was 78.

title: GEC Alsthom In Merger Talks
description: GEC Alsthom said yesterday that it was in talks to take control of Framatome Connectors S.A., a mostly state-owned French producer of nuclear power plants with annual sales of about 17.9 billion francs ($3.5 billion). A merger would add Framatome's capabilities in nuclear power to GEC Alsthom's main business of building conventional coal-fired plants.

title: Mr. Clinton's Bridge
description: Democrats streaming home from Chicago yesterday were basking in the glow of their most self-confident convention in a generation. President Clinton's speech the night before, while not salted with memorable lines, parried the attacks by Bob Dole in San Diego and outlined what he would try to accomplish if re-elected. The embarrassment of his chief campaign strategist's sudden departure failed to dampen delegates' spirits. Voters may see the incident as raising new issues of values and character, but Mr. Clinton's speech urged them to think about larger themes.

title: A Corner of Central Park Has Become a Gathering Spot for Sunday Rumba
description: Directions to a Sunday party: enter Central Park near the Dakota on West 72d Street and walk through Strawberry Fields past the John Lennon memorial. Right about there, if the wind is blowing a certain way, you'll hear the insistent call of the drums. Tum-taca-taca-tum.

title: At Convention, a Scramble for Support for Local Races
description: Mayor Willie Brown of San Francisco began his toast by briefly mentioning that matter about re-electing the President. Then he got down to the real business of this party: lauding New York State's Comptroller and potential gubernatorial candidate, H. Carl McCall.

title: Subway Repairs Proceed Slowly and Unsteadily
description: To the Editor:

title: After Slur, Top Officer Quits
description: William Webb, the West Orange Police Director, resigned Thursday, 10 days after he made a derogatory comment to one of his black officers, officials said. The black officer, Larry Green, had asked to read some papers concerning his suspension for driving with a revoked license, said Jack Cavanaugh, the interim Police Chief. According to Chief Cavanaugh, Mr. Webb, who is white, replied, ''What is it, the blacker you are, the dumber you are?'' Mr. Webb later said he had been on medication for an ear infection at the time and did not remember making the remark.

title: The Easy One In Tax Breaks: Who's Against Homeowners?
description: It's not hard to guess what homeowners will think of the very similar plans offered by Bob Dole and Bill Clinton to expand tax breaks on home sales. Both are intended to eliminate taxes on capital gains on all but the most profitable homes.

title: Selig Conflict Is Raising Its Ugly Head
description: BASEBALL owners said it would never happen, that potential for conflict of interest when one of their own became the game's acting commissioner.

title: Italy's G.D.P. Shrinks in Quarter
description: Italy's gross domestic product contracted five-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter from the first and grew five-tenths of a percent from a year earlier. The state statistics institute Istat said Italy was ''on a threshold between growth and recession.'' It said the export boom that lifted Italy's economy in the last few years might be ending.

title: Enforce Park Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: STUNG BY ATTACKS, MEXICO INTENSIFIES SEARCH FOR REBELS
description: The Mexican Government, stung by widespread attacks this week by a new leftist guerrilla organization, condemned the rebels as terrorists and stepped up the hunt for them today in seven states.

title: Police Officer Suspended
description: A police officer has been suspended because of allegations that he harassed and stalked his former girlfriend, a civilian employee of the force, police officials said yesterday.

title: Limit on Remedial Education Is Appealed
description: Lawyers for the New York City Board of Education asked a Federal appeals court yesterday to declare invalid a 1985 United States Supreme Court ruling that bars public school teachers from entering religious schools to give remedial instruction in reading and mathematics.

title: Pettitte Halts 5-Game Skid With His 19th Victory
description: No team knows more than the Yankees how some numbers can slice at a team's psyche like so many razor blades.

title: John Moore, 68, Fashion Designer
description: John Moore, a fashion designer of the 1950's and 60's who was best known for designing Lady Bird Johnson's 1965 inaugural gown, died on Wednesday in Alice, Tex. He was 68 and lived in Alice.

title: Lloyd's to Proceed With a Revamping
description: Lloyd's of London said yesterday that it had received enough support from money-losing investors to proceed with a revamping that will keep the 308-year-old insurance market solvent. Lloyd's survival plan is intended to reverse the troubles of 1988-92, when the market was hit by $12.4 billion in losses. Lloyd's investors had to put their life savings on the line to back policies.

title: Police Say Staten Island Man Stockpiled Weapons Illegally
description: The New York City police and Federal agents arrested a Staten Island man yesterday on charges involving stockpiling assault rifles, semiautomatic handguns and armor-piercing ammunition, which police officials said he purchased with the proceeds of cocaine sales.

title: Gordon S. Brown, 88, Developer Of a Crucial Weapons System
description: Gordon S. Brown, a former dean of engineering and professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died on Aug. 23 at his retirement home in Tucson, Ariz. He was 88 and formerly lived in Concord, Mass., and Grantham, N.H.

title: Pentagon Sees A New Threat By Iraq Forces
description: After detecting threatening movements by Iraqi troops against the Kurdish districts in the north, the United States has stepped up its military activity in the region, ordering its forces ''to be prepared to deploy'' if needed, Administration officials said today.

title: Roenick Dropped From U.S. Roster
description: JEREMY ROENICK was officially dropped from the United States' World Cup roster yesterday and replaced by the Devils' BRIAN ROLSTON. Roenick, whose rights were recently traded from Chicago to Phoenix, refused to report to the American team because he is a restricted free agent without a contract. Rolston has practiced with the team on the reserve list. The United States opens tournament play tonight in Philadelphia against Canada.

title: Bridge
description: Two of New York's most experienced players have recently opened a club in Queens: Bridge Haven, at 65-55 Woodhaven Boulevard, Rego Park. They are Keith Garber and Norman Kurlander, who have won many New York titles, and they are offering duplicate bridge, rubber bridge and instruction. For information, telephone (718) 459-1030.

title: Swissair Group Reports 4th Straight Loss
description: Swissair Group had its fourth straight net loss for the first half of the year as cost-cutting programs at the Swiss national carrier were undermined by falling air fares and a widening loss at its Belgian partner, Sabena S.A. Swissair Group, which consists of airline, catering and hotel units, said its net loss shrank to 51 million francs ($42.6 million), from 86 million francs for the period a year earlier. The loss at its flight operations narrowed, Swissair said.

title: Clinton Camp Looks Within To Replace A Key Adviser
description: President Clinton summoned his top 12 political advisers this morning before taking to the campaign trail and told them not to forget the many strategic successes of Dick Morris even as he instructed them to look beyond the sudden downfall of his friend and consultant.

title: Cracks Appear Yet Again In Transit Authority Buses
description: A problem that has plagued the Transit Authority repeatedly over the years is back: at least 50 relatively new buses, battered by New York City's washboard streets, have developed cracks, officials said yesterday.

title: IRIDEX STOCK RISES ON EYE LASER APPROVAL
description: The stock of the Iridex Corporation jumped more than 15 percent yesterday, one day after the company, which makes laser systems used to treat eye diseases, received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to sell its Oculight laser. The semiconductor-based visible laser system will be used to treat a variety of eye diseases, the Mountain View, Calif., company said. Iridex expects to begin shipping the laser in the next month.

title: Chase Patterson Kimball, 64, A Crusader for Medical Ethics
description: Chase Patterson Kimball, professor emeritus of medicine and psychiatry at the University of Chicago, who was prominent in the new field of biopsychosocial medicine, died on Aug. 24 at a Chicago nursing home. He was 64.

title: The Emotional Detour Down God's Highway
description: Between almost every song Gillian Welch performed on Tuesday night at Fez with David Rawlings, her partner in song and affection, there were breaks so that the pair could tune their guitars or give instructions to the soundman. This might have been frustrating or unprofessional in a set by another group, but it was easy to forgive Ms. Welch and Mr. Rawlings. Their songs were so simple, powerful and transporting that it was nice to gain further insight into the pair's good-humored personality as they apologetically fumbled with their equipment.

title: Trying to Buy Bike Track
description: The bicycle racing track built for the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta needs a new home, and what better place than Somerville, the site of the United States Bicycling Hall of Fame? At least, that's the view of officials of the nine-year-old museum, who hope to find a corporate sponsor to buy the track, Fred Howlett, the vice president of the museum, said yesterday. The velodrome, priced at $700,000, could be put on land donated to Somerset County by the American Home Products Company, Mr. Howlett said. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Beneath the Paint: One Man's Trip Through an Old Carousel's Distant Past
description: The year was 1883, or so the story goes, when a traveling circus passed through this seaside resort and left behind a small merry-go-round.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA SETS AN ACQUISITION
description: The Royal Bank of Canada's brokerage unit agreed late on Thursday to acquire a rival, Richardson Greenshields of Canada Ltd., for $480 million (Canadian), or $350 million. RBC Dominion Securities Inc., which is 73.4 percent owned by Royal Bank, will pay a combination of cash and stock for the country's second-largest nonbank-owned brokerage firm. Midland Walwyn Inc. is the largest independent firm. The acquisition catapults RBC Dominion past Bank of Montreal's Nesbitt Burns Inc. into the No. 1 slot as Canada's largest brokerage house.
